title: Few War Resisters in Canada Seek to Return to U.S.
Price of Gold Rises And Dollar Falls In Most of Europe
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)The price of gold rose today while the dollar fell in almost all West European money markets.

title: Farm Prices Gain 1.5% in a Month
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The prices farmers get for raw products rose 1.5 percent between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Thoughts for an Emergency
description: Those pipeline guys in the South have learned how to make money from the camel drivers, opined Mel Perez, who represents 4,700 General Motors workers laid off by natural gas curtailments in New Jersey. Mr. Perez is not alone in believing that the current gas shortages were manufactured by suppliers eager to emulate the OPEC oil cartel. Reports from New Jersey suggest that many local officials and homeowners have resisted Governor Byrne's orders to cut back thermostats. The gas is somewhere, they argue, and will be delivered when the gas companies extract enough gold from panicky legislators.

title: VANCE SAYS THE U. S. WON'T BE STRIDENT OVER RIGHTS ABROAD
Increasing Shortage of Beds for Medicaid Patients In Nursing Homes Reported Acute in Bergen Country
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 31A steadily increasing shortage of beds for Medicaid patients in nursing homes throughout the state is causing alarm among the aging and their relatives, as well as among social workers, nurses and others in the health care field.

title: JULIUS FELSEN
description: JULIUS FELSEN

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Woodcock Gets Unexpected Push Toward a Race for Governorship
description: Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, received an unexpected push from Governor Byrne yesterday in regard to how quickly he would begin his quest for Mr. Byrne's job. Mr. Woodcock visited the Governor to tender his resignation as Prosecutor, effective March 1. But Mr. Byrne told him to forgo the 30day notice and to consider the resignation effective as of today. Mr. Woodcock, obviously surprised, said as he left the office, Now I'll have to go and find a Job.

title: 40% of N.B.A. Pacers Is Up for Public Sale
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (AP)The National Basketball Association's Indiana Pacers announced today a public offering for sale of 40 percent of the club.

title: Lawyers in India Protest Naming of Chief Justice
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 31 (Reuters)More than 100 lawyers with cases on the docket boycotted the Supreme Court today to protest the appointment of Mirza Hammedullah Beg as India's new chief justice over the head of a more senior colleague.

title: DR. DAVID SCHERF, AT 77, CARDIOLOGY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. David Scherf, a cardiologist, died at his Manhattan home on Sunday. He was 77 years old and lived at 10 East 85th Street.

title: F.T. C. Official Is Asked For Apology Over Nader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The director of the National Association of Arab Americans has written to President Carter protesting a. recent public characterization of Ralph Nader. as a dirty Arab by Paul Rand Dixon, a Federal Trade commissioner and a Prime target of a Nadersponsored report on the F.T.C.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1977

title: Taxes &
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Inc., the securities firm, takes a measured view of this season's most controversial accounting innovationthe replacement cost disclosures due from the nation's largest companies by the end of March.

title: ANDREW FLETCHER, 81
description: Andrew Fletcher, honorary chairman of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, 250 Park Avenue, New York City, died Sunday In his apartment at 953 Fifth Avenue. lie was 81 years old.

title: Chicago Democrats Name Candidate to Succeed Daley
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31The Democratic ward committeemen who served Richard J. Daley for more than 20 years continued their solidarity today by endorsing Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic as the party organization's candidate to serve the remaining two years of the late Mayor's term.

title: ABRAHAM G. NOVICK
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 31 (UPI) Abraham G. Novick, a nationally recognized expert on juvenile delinquency, died at the Berkshire Medical Center yesterday after a brief illness. He was 60 years old.

title: 2 Towns Set for Evacuation if Gas Is Cut Off
description: AVALON, Jan. 31This shore community of 2,100 people is prepared to use ambulances to move residents to the Community Hall at the south end of its boardwalk if natural gas to their homes is cut off. Meanwhile four miles away, in Stone Harbor, a resort town of 1,600 people, gasusing residents will be, if necessary, evacuated to their new firehouse.

title: Sann, Executive Editor, Resigns From The Post After a Dispute
description: Paul Senn, executive editor of The New York Post, resigned yesterday after more than 40 years at the paper.

title: Young, Taking Over U.N. Duties, Prepares to Leave for Africa Today
description: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Jan. 31Andrew Young took over his duties as chief United States delegate today and was welcomed by hundreds of applauding staff members.

title: Skiing
description: AT MORZINE, FRANCE

title: Lakers Success Shows Merit of Coaching System
description: As one of the hottest teams In the National Basketball Association right now, the Los Angeles Lakers are something of a surprise. But even if their hot streak runs out, their method of creating it may have a lasting effect on the style of other teams.

title: Western Union Adds Data on Plant Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Western Union Corporation disclosed today that its 1976 earnings of $34 million would be erased if It had based its depreciation charges on the current cost of replacing its entire physical plant.

title: Newcomers Have Busy Time At Finale of Ballet Theater
description: It was a busy time for newcomLers to major ballet roles last weekend. At the City Center, American Ballet Theater ended its season Sunday night with Gelsey Kirkland's being partnered by Charles Ward as a new Albrecht in Giselle. Saturday night, Martine van lamel and Clark Tippet made their debuts as Giselle and Albrecht.

title: Three Women Reported To Have Been Selected For Administration Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Carter Administration, seeking to dampen criticism about not placing enough women in highlevel jobs, has found compromise posts for at least three women who worked in the Carter transition operation, sources close to the President said today.

title: Buffalo's Effort to Dig Its Way Out Blocked by Winds and Snowdrifts
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 31Snowplows manned by city crews and National Guard troops fought a losing battle with howling winds and drifting snow today as Buffalo remained buried, isolated and paralyzed after the worst winter storm in its history.

title: A Worthwhile Complication
description: President Carter and Secretary Vance have already recognized that their desire to champion human rights in Communist countries adds a complication to foreign policy. They do not intend to speak out in every case, they say, but they do wish to burden diplomacy with ideals. When we last made that observation, it evoked the question of whether the burden is worth bearing. The answer is yes, decidedly yes.

title: Holdup Victims Shot, But Story Isn't Over
description: A man and his wife were shot during a street robbery in the Bronx last night. The police later seized a suspect they identified as the brother of a man who was slain while he was acting as an accomplice to the couple in an attempted robbery last week.

title: APPEAL COURT BARS PART OF FINANCIAL CRISIS LAW
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn held unconstitutional yesterday a section of the state's Financial Emergency Act that prevents the use of suspended wage increases and other benefits in computing pension pay.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Cold Brings Humor and Pathos
description: UNIONTOWN, Pa, Jan. 31Like any natural calamity, the cold wave gripping western Pennsylvania is marked by pathos and humor, heroism and contradictions. And, somehow, the essentials of life are provided. Knifing winds blasted subzero air through the deserted streets of downtown Pittsburgh on Saturday night, and the authorities leaned heavily on businesses to close to save fuel. It was nearly impossible for a stranger to find a simple meal, but he would have had no trouble taking in two bold action hits on the Liberty.Street porno strip.

title: Byrne to Offer $4 Billion Budget To Session of Legislature Today
description: TRENTON, Jan.31Governor Byrne will present New Jersey's first $4 billion budget tomorrow to a joint session of the Legislature.

title: Running Tide And Imp Win In Yachting
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., Jan. 31. Running Tide, a yacht found tried and true after seven years of campaigning, and Imp, a new vessel in competition for the first time, shared honors in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference's opening event, which ended here yesterday.

title: New Hospital Head in Brooklyn
description: Harold L. Wright yesterday assumed the post of president and chief executive officer of Long Island College Hospital in downtown Brooklyn. He was formerly vice president for administration of Long Island Jewish Hospital. In his new post he succeeds William K. Klein as head of the 119yearold institution.

title: 2 Senators Start Inquiry On MoneyOrder Losses
description: An investigation to determine whether the State Banking Department acted as promptly as it should have to protect thousands of buyers of money orders sold by the bankrupt U.S.N. Company was announced yesterday by two state senators.

title: Law School Is Fighting Its Way Back
description: For years, just the mention of New York Law School would evoke condescending giggles from many New York lawyers and law students. But recently that giggling has stopped, for the school is in the midst of a comeback.

title: News Summary
description: The Carter Administration will speak frankly about injustice wherever it occursincluding the Soviet Union but only from time to time and in a nonprovocative way, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said at a wideranging news conference at the State Department. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Japan's Auto Exports Rise 38.5%
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP)Japan's auto exports rose 38.5 percent in 1976 to 3.71 million units, compared with 2.68 million units the year earlier, raised by strong sales in the United States, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. According to the association, the dollar value of the automotive exports were valued at $10.3 billion in 1976, up about 44.3 percent from $7.14 billion in 1975.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Ivor Richard Ends Shuttle Trip
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 31 (Reuters) Ivor Richard, the British chairman of the stalemated Geneva conference on Rhodesia, ended his monthlong shuttle tour of southern Africa today with no firm indication of how efforts to achieve a peaceful settlement in Rhodesia could be revived.

title: 250 Fans of Mystery Stories Indulge in a Gothic Weekend
description: LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Jan. 30On a dark and stormy night, the temperature at zero, the wind howling up the mountain, sending snow hissing against leaded glass windows, there they were, 250 people with a single interest, 100 miles north of Gotham, in a cavernous parlour filled with carved chestnut, upholstered sultan's corners and memories of men long gone who had lounged there, men like Andrew Carnegie and Chester A. Arthur.

title: Stringent Code On Ethics Urged By House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31A sweeping new code of ethics was approved today by a panel in the House of Representatives. The action signaled a willingness to take stringent measures to halt what members fear is an erosion of confidence in Congress.

title: UDALL WOULD GO SLOW ON NUCLEAR ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Representative Morris K. Udall, the new chairman of the House Interior Committee, which now exercises oversight over the nation's nuclear programs, says that he is leaning toward a program that holds in abeyance the development of the fast breeder reactor as a major energy source.

title: Article 3  No Title
Bridge:
description: The world's strongest pair tournament was played in London during weekend, and resulted in a victory for a famous French partnership, Henri Svarc and JeanMichel Boulenger.

title: Ski Foundation Given Land
description: STRATTON, Vt., Jan. 31 (AP) The International Paper Company has given the United States Ski Educational Foundation more than 1,000 acres of Stratton Mountain ski area here, officials said today. The foundation, a nonprofit organization that funds and manages United States ski teams, said it would lease the land to the ski area. The terms of the lease were not disclosed. Paper company officials estimated the land's value at $1.5 million.

title: G.E. Signs U.S. Order Barring False Ad Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The General Electric Company was barred under Federal order today from making false or unsubstantiated claims about its television sets or other major appliances.

title: Walcher Gains First Victory In Cup Skiing
description: MORZINE, France, Jan. 31 (AP) Josef Watcher, a 22yearold Austrian, whipped the World's downhill skiing elite today in winning a World Cup race for the first time. And he vowed to repeat his victory at St. Anton, Austria, next weekend.

title: Advertising
description: A number of the nation's major magazine publishers, having overcome the papershortage problem and having almost come CO peace with the postal problems, are now facing production problems brought on by this miserable winter.

title: Around the Nation
Kennecott Shows 4th Quarter Loss of $5.1 Million
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's leading domestic copper producer, reported yesterday a $5.1 million loss for the fourth quarter, excluding the $11.1 million, or 33 cents a share, earned by its Peabody Coal Company subsidiary, whose sale awaits Federal Trade Commission approval.

title: Orange Juice Futures End a Rise
description: The sharp rise in prices of frozen orange juice futures10 consecutive limit advances of 3 cents a poundcame to an end yesterday in a confusing rush of selling mixed with still pending buy orders.

title: MRS. ABZUG WEIGHING RACE FOR MAYORALTY
description: A renewed flurry of activity by Bella S. Abzug meetings with potential campaign workers. and contributors, studies of poll results, talks about strategy has convinced some of her political friends and foes that she will run for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: Pictures Used to Guide Missile
description: WHITE SANDS, N.M., Jan. 31 (UPI) A missile guidance system using photographs has undergone its first successful test at White Sands Missile Range, a range spokesman said today. The system uses a photographic method of matching the target with the missile's program. It was used in a test of the Navy's Toma hawk course missile on Saturday.

title: Suffolk's Tenacious Democrat
description: It was the most important day in the mottled life of the Democratic Party of Suffolk County. For the first time in the traditionally Republican county, the Democrats had won control of the 18member legislature, and on that day, a year ago, the new county legislators were being sworn in. The attention of the audience in the woodpaneled room of the Riverhead, L. I., County Center, was riveted on the new legislators. But every so often the legislators themselves would glance, almost reverentially, at a stocky, graying man who sat some rows away from them. In turn, the man would nod at them, with a fond smile, as a father might at his children performing on stage.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: W.T.T. Pact Near For Soviet Entry
New N.B.A. Plan Would Cut Travel, Stress Rivalries
description: A Plan to curtail travel and schedule more play within divisions and conferences will be presented to the National Basketball Association owners for approval Feb. 12, a day before the AllStar Game in Milwaukee.

title: Madrid Cracks Down on Extremists
description: MADRID, Jan. 31Bolstered by new government powers after last week's outbreak of terrorism, the police today continued to detain extremists.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CAVALCADES Dixie to Broadway is the title of a new monthlong exhibition of over 300 pieces of theater memorabilia tracing the work of black Americans on stage from 1800 to 1939. The show, drawn from the collection of the ArmsteadJohnson Foundation for Theater Research, is a salute to black contributions to the performing arts during the current Black History Month. It opens today in the Community Gallery of the Metropolitan Museum (at the 81st Street entrance, off Fifth Avenue).

title: Ibsen's When We Dead Awaken Puzzling but Worthwhile Drama
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.Ibsen's final drama, When We Dead Awaken, just produced here by Stage West, is in some ways the playwright's most puzzling, most opaque drama. It is rarely givenpartly because of the difficulties of its staging and partly because of the mixture of realism and symbolism that make its texture, let alone its theme, difficult to appreciate. Yet it is a great play.

title: Bishop Who Led 2 Irregular Rites Had Received a Vatican Warning
description: An American Roman Catholic bishop who conducted two irregular rites of general absolution without individual confession did so despite knowledge of a warning from the Vatican that such procedures could violate church regulations.

title: $30,000, but Nothing for a Token
description: Two brothers carrying more than $30,000 in cash decided yesterday to save 50 cents by going through a Queens subway turnstile together on one subway token.

title: Vietnam Resistance Groups Are Merged Into One
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 31 (UPI) The National Liberation Front of South Vietnam, farmed 16 years ago to lead the war against Americans, is to be phased out this week during a fiveday meeting that began today in Saigon.

title: Miss Longet Given 30 Days
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 31 (AP)Claudine Longet, pleading with a judge to have mercy on her as the mother of three children, was sentenced today to serve 30 days in jail at a time of her own choosing in the killing of Vladimir Sabich, a professional skier with whom she had been living.

title: CARTER COOL TO PLEA ON NEW YORK'S LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The House, backing the Senate Banking Committee, today opposed a fiveyear extension of the $2.3 billion Federal loan assistance to New York City beyond its June 30, 1978, expiration date.

title: Amtrak Links Suspected Flaw in Engines to Mishaps
description: A suspected flaw in the General. Motors diesel locomotives that pull most of Amtrak's passenger fleet has prompted railroad officials to order a slowdown of trains around the nation, widely disrupting service schedules.

title: The U.N. Today
OMAN RAISES OIL PRICES 9% RETROACTIVE TO JAN. 1
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 31 (AP) Oman has raised its oil price 9 percent retroactive to Jan. 1, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: BANKS' REGULATORS TOO SLOW IN ACTING, G. A. O. STUDY FINDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The General Accounting Office, conducting an unprecedented investigation of Federal bank regulators, has concluded that they have failed to bring sufficient pressure on errant banks to mend their ways.

title: Cosmos Set 13 Games At the Meadowlands
description: The Cosmos announced yesterday they would play 13 regularseason games at the Meadowlands, beginning April 17. The Rochester Lancers will provide the opposition for the home opener, which is at 2:05 P.M. Except for two Wednesday night games in July, all other home games will be played on Sundays.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Yonkers Drivers
Emergency Natural Gas Measure Approved by 91to2 Senate Vote
3 on Trial in Tokyo Deny LockheedCase Charges
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Two former Government officials and an executive of a Japanese airline denied today that they received bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: 2 Californians Accused of Spying For Soviet Union Plead Not Guilty
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31A 23yearold student and an unemployed cabinet maker pleaded not guilty today to charges of spying for the Soviet Union in the last 18 months.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The JohnsManville Corporation said that it would delay its previously announced $77 million capital expenditure program at its asbestos mine and processing plant in Quebec pending conclusion of a provincial study of nationalization of the asbestos industry.

title: Israelis Seek an Accord On Nearby Troop Presence
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 31Foreign Minister Yigal Allon proposed an agreement today stating how near Syrian or Palestinian forces in Lebanon could approach the Israeli border.

title: JOINT CHIEFS ASSERT SOVIET IS NOT AHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Joint chiefs of Staff believe the Soviet Union has yet to achieve military superiority over the United States but is bent on seeking that superiority, they said in a statement made public today.

title: U.S. and Panama to Resume Talks On New Canal Treaty Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The United States and Panama pledged today to make a sustained and continuous effort to conclude a new treaty that would set dates for termination of American control over the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone.

title: New College Passing Rule Adds to Offense's Options
Thomas E. Mullaney
description: As the nation concentrates its efforts on nearterm solutions for the current energy crisis, thoughtful leaders in various areas of society are renewing their unheeded pleas of recent years that Washington face up to the more substantive longrange question of energy sufficiency in this country and other parts of the Western world. The United States, with, its enormous resources, tech nology and talent, has risen impressively to the challenge of great tasks in the past  and needs to do so again under the pressure of this latest and most urgent problem.

title: OLGA V. KALTENBORN, 88, NEWS ANALYST'S WIDOW
description: Olga V. Kaltenborn, widow of H. V. Kaltenborn, the colorful radio and television news broadcaster and analyst who died in 1965, died Saturday in the Sunrest Nursing Home, Port Jefferson. L.I.

title: Injured Catchings Is Out For Season, 76ers Say
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP)Harvey Catchings, center, has a fracturedislocation of the right elbow and will be lost for the remainder of the regular National Basketball Association season, the Philadelphia 76ers said tonight.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPT. SCORED ON CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Agriculture Department has done an inadequate job in preventing conflict of interest among highranking employees, a Congressional report said today.

title: Benjamin Kaufman, 72, Benefactor Of a Number of Jewish Institutions
description: Benjamin Kaufman, a realestate investment counselor and benefactor of Many Jewish institutions in New York City and in Israel, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 1056 Fifth Avenue.

title: Tarport Hap: A Hot Pacer For the Cold
description: A 5yearold mare who gets three extra blankets is uncovering some Class in winter horse racing. Tarport Hap, one of the best pacers in the country, registered a 1:591/5 mile in belowfreezing weather last Saturday night at the Meadowlands.

title: F.B. I. Ordered to Send King Tapes to Archives
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)A Federal judge today ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to turn over all tapes and transcripts gathered in the wiretapping of the. Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to the National Archives and directed that they be kept there under seal for 50 years.

title: Proposed Lane for Buses Opened to All by Brown
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today ordered the controversial diamond lane on the San Diego Free way open to all traffic.

title: Winter Is Spurring Strong Sales In Clothes, Insulation, Snow Tires
description: Although the bitter cold besetting much of the nation has caused major industrial dislocations, it also means booming business for a number of industries.

title: Elderly Brooklyn Man and Sister Found Dead in an IceFilled House
description: An 80yearold woman and her 77yearold brother, who rarely ventured from their old, ramshackle house in a tidy middleclass neighborhood in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section, were found dead yesterday amid thick layers of ice hanging from broken water nines.

title: HEAVY SNOWS STRIKE UPSTATE AREAS AGAIN
RALPH A. LEAVITT
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 31Ralph A. leavitt, chairman of the board of Chase Leavitt and Company, steamship agents, and who helped set up the Maine Maritime Academy at Castine, died yesterday at the Maine Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

title: Dow Declines 3.16 In Market Numbed By Energy Shortage
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday as the nation's energy crisis chilled investor enthusiasm.

title: NBC Stands Firm as Soviet Spokesman Denies Deal on the Olympics
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31The National Broadcasting Company today insisted that it had obtained the American television rights to the 1980 Moscow Olympics, despite an earlier denial by a Soviet Olympics Committee spokesman.

title: Market Place
description: Call it the cold weather: market. While energy stocks, particalarly natural gas producers, have been getting a lot of attention lately, the rest of the stock market has taken,a drubbing as subzero temperatures throughout much of the nation have put a drag on business.

title: Grumbling Compliance Reported To Jersey Order on Saving Fuel
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31Reports from around the state today showed a general, though grudging, compliance with Governor Byrne's executive order curtailing businesses to a 40hour week and reducing temperatures in homes and businesses to 65 degrees during the day.

title: South Africa's Government Seeks New Powers to Deal With Unrest
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 31The South African Government today unveiled sweeping legislation giving it wartime powers, including censorship of the domestic and foreign press, in the event the army is called in to suppress the recurrence of last year's riots.

title: REAGANITES TO BACK G.O.P. CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The committee that organized Ronald Reagan's nearly successful primary challenge against former President Gerald R. Ford last year has been converted into a permanent political group to back conservative Republican causes and candidates.

title: H. Julian Allen, Space Pioneer
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP) H. Julian Allen, a space pioneer whose discoveries made possible the safe return of astronauts to earth, died last weekend of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: Soviet, Undeterred On Dissidents, Seeks Improved U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31Despite an early runin over human rights, the Soviet leadership is still looking to the Administration of Jimmy Carter to help revive the kind of accommodation that flourished during the Nixon years and has stagnated since.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Picks Editor Now With The Los Angeles Times
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP)Edwin O. Guthman, the Pulitzer Prizewinning national editor of The Los Angeles Times, today was named editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer. He will be in charge of The Inquirer's editorial and oped pages when he begins his new job on March 1.

title: Auburn Is Seeking Developers for Its Gas
description: AUBURN, N. Y.In recent years, New York's Finger Lakes region has suffered along with the nation as natural gas supplies grow tight. Prices are on the rise, industry has been forced to other, far more expensive fuels and fears of damage to the economy mount.

title: Cheaper Warmth
description: WASHINGTONThe case for increasing energy conservation has been made repeatedly. Experts in and out of government agree that it costs about half as much to save a barrel of oil or the equivalent amount of electricity or natural gas as it does to produce similar amounts of new energy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
Carey Gets Volunteer Firemen Bill, First of the Year
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Twentysix days after opening its 1977 session, the New York State Legislature today sent to Governor Carey the first bill of the new year. It could not have been a more typical bill.

title: Cold and Lack of Fuel Buffet Retailers
description: The double blow of frigid temperatures and a fuel shortage in the last 10 days have caused losses in retail sales and curtailments of store operations in the Northeast, MidAtlantic states, the Midwest and parts of the South.

title: For Traveling the Yellow Brick Road
description: Adolfo has an idea or two about what men should be wearing when they ease on down the road next fall. So, last night he rented the stars of The Wiz and the stage of the Majestic Theater to tell the world.

title: Sewell and Lopez Gain Hall of Fame
Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Teresa Stratas Quits Met's Lulu
description: Teresa Stratas, the soprano who Was to take the title role in the. Metropolitan Opera's new production of Berg's Lulu next month, has withdrawn, charging the opera company with breach of contract failing to provide as much fullscale rehearsal time as she had assumed her contract guaranteed.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
S.E.C. TO SEEK SANCTIONS IN EQUITY FUNDING CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in administrative hearings convened in New York yesterday, said it would seek sanctions against Raymond L. Dirks and five others for their role in the collapse three years ago of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America.

title: Canvas Totes in Safari Motif
description: The travel package offered by the American Museum of Natural History isn't to be confused with a Cook's tour, a Linblad safari or a Holland America cruise. It is simply a collection of useful effects for the travelerduffel bag, cosmetic kits and the likein a distinctive animal print that is certain to attract attention and elicit queries.

title: Steelmakers Hit by Cutback Of Natural Gas
description: Major Eastern and Midwestern steelmakers are being forced to curtail their operations because of, natural gas cutbacks and weatherrelated Problems.

title: Mexican Leader, Outlining Plans, Sees a Challenge in National Crisis
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26The new President of Mexico, noting that 30 percent of his country's 63 million people are still living in a marginal economic state six decades after the Mexican Revolution, readily acknowledges that the nation'is passing through a period of crisis, presenting both risk and opportunity.

title: Effect of Carey Proposal on School Aid Is Detailed
Reserve Mining Is Backed by Minnesota Judges on the Dumping of Iron Ore Waste on Land
description: DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 31Three Minnesota District Court judges today ordered state environmental agencies to issue permits allowing the Reserve Mining Company to dump potentially hazardous ore waste at a disposal site on land in the northeastern corner of the state that the company prefers.

title: New Closings at West Side Highway
description: Because of increased damage to the West Side Highway from the cold weather and heavy salting, the exitentrance ramp at 57th Street will be closed today through Friday between 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., according to the Transportation Administration. During those hours, motorists are to use the exitentrance ramps at 46th and 79th Streets.

title: Ethiopia, Under Military Leaders, Is Racked by Unrest and Warfare
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (UPI)More than two years after the army overthrew the late Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia is racked by political assassinations and unrest, military suppression and a war against seccesionists in Eritrea, the northernmost province.

title: About New York
HEAVY SNOWS STRIKE UPSTATE AREAS AGAIN; Carey Appeals to Carter for AidTwo Die in Icy Brooklyn House
description: Northern New York State reeled under new howling storms yesterday that dumped more than 18 inches of snow on the Watertown area within 24 hours.

title: Alabama Wins 16th by Routing, Vanderbilt Five
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 31 (AP)Rickey, Brown's 17 points led seven Alabama players who scored in double figures tonight as the highlyranked Crimson Tide routed Vanderbilt, 9682, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: 250 Fans of Mystery Stories Indulge in a Gothic Weekend
description: LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Jan. 30On a dark and stormy night, the temperature at zero, the wind howling up the mountain, tending snow hissing against leaded glass win dows, there they were, 250 people with a single interest, 100 miles north of Gotham, in a cavernous parlour filled with carved chestnut, upholstered sultan's corners and memories of men long gone who had lounged there, men like Andrew Carnegie and Chester A. Arthur.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Having surmounted with remarkable adaptability the loss of what was then its primary food, socalled eel grass, by switching to a marine algae known as sea lettuce, the Atlantic brant (Branta bernicula hrota) now faces the threat of starvation in its wintering area along the New Jersey coast.

title: India Newspaper Figure Is Honored
description: Cushrow R. Irani, who for eight years has led the fight for freedom of the press in India, was honored in absentia last night at the 35th anniversary meeting of Freedom House.

title: Dealers Await $3 Billion Sale Of U.S. Notes
Suspense and SelfDiscipline
description: Time passes, bringing nearer the momentpossibly Thursdayon which the city must show the Court of Appeals how it will pay off a billion dollars in notes, originally subject to the moratorium the court struck down in November. We regret that agreement between the parties arrives more slowly than the deadline.

title: Index of HelpWanted Advertising Rises 6 Points in December to 105
description: The helpwanted advertising index, a monthly survey of the Conference Board, was up six points in December to 105 (1967=100) from the November level and 17 points over December 1975.

title: Sabotage Cited in Some New York Heat Failures
description: A New York City official said yesterday that sabotage was responsible for 10 to 15 percent of the heating breakdowns that have occurred during the current cold wave.

title: Philadelphia Records Coldest Month
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (Reuters) The National Weather Service said today that this January was the coldest month in Philadelphia since 1790, the first year records were kept in Pennsylvania. The average temperature in the city for the first 30 days of January was 20.1 degrees, or 12.2 below normal for a January.

title: People in Sports
description: The Yankees, who seem to believe that Willie Randolph will be their starting second baseman for a long time, showed some evidence of that sentiment yesterday by signing the 22yearold infielder to a threeyear contract. Financial terms of the agreement were, as usual, not revealed.

title: Thailand Closes Border Over Raid By the Cambodians That Killed 30
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 31 (AP)Thailand has sealed its border with Cambodia and will use drastic measures to repel future Cambodian raids across the border like the weekend killing of 30 Thai civilians, Deputy Prime Minister Boonchai Bamroongphong said today.

title: Portrait of Average Home Buyer
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)The average family buying a house says between $40,000 and $45,000 and has an annual income of $21,615, according to a survey by the National Association of Home Builders. The typical head of household is 33 years old, has already owned a house and is moving from five to 25 miles. The usual source of financing is personal savings or the proceeds of the sale of a previous home.

title: WIDE CROP INSURANCE ASKED BY BERGLAND
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 31Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today that he planned to develop an allrisk, allcrops insurance program to protect producers against disasters of the kind that had occurred in many parts of the country in the last year,

title: Dave Anderson; Cold? Put Pepper in Your Shoes
description: In the Winter of 77, the baseball players soon will escape to Florida or Arizona and the football players are thankful their season is over. The Jockeys ride for a few minutes, but then they're warm again. The golfers are in Hawaii this week. The basketball players, the tennis players, the track and field athletes and the boxers compete indoors. So do the hockey players, but they relate to the Winter of '77 perhaps better than anyone else in sports. The hockey players remember the winters of their youth. They remember the belowzero temperatures on the Saskatchewan prairies or in the Ontario mining towns. They remember the cold. They remember the wind. And they remember trying to keep warm around potbellied stoves in the shacks alongside the outdoor rinks. Denis Potvin of the New York Islanders even remembers putting pepper in his skates to keep his feet warm.

title: Soviet, Undeterred On Dissidents, Seeks Improved U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31Despite an early runin over human rights, the Soviet leadership is still looking to the Administration of Jimmy Carter to help revive the kind of accommodation that flourished during the Nixon years and has stagnated since.

title: Abortion Law Is Approved in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31  Over the strenuous, sometimes impassioned objections of religious Jews, the Israeli Parliament today passed a law that legalized abortions but fell short of providing abortion on demand.

title: PHYLLIS POPE DIES AT 83, AN EXPERT ON ASIAN ART
description: Phyllis Ackerman Pope, an expert on Asian art, died last Tuesday in Shiraz, Iran. She was 83 years old and had been a resident of that city for a number of years.

title: 18 Britons on Uganda Plane Are Reported Safe
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 31 (UPI)A plane belonging to Uganda's President, Idi Amin, and its 18 British passengers have been found safe after the craft made an emergency landing in rough weather, airline officials said today.

title: Canadiens Are Having More Trouble With Their Team Than With Foes
description: The Montreal Canadiens, running away from the rest of the National Hockey League, are unhappy. If that surprises you, the Islanders, Rangers, Buffalo Sabres, St. Louis Blues and a host of other clubs are also unhappy.

title: Orr Reported to Be Out Rest of Hockey Season
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)Bobby Orr of the Chicago Black Hawks, nursing a bad knee for most of the last two seasons, will miss the remainder of the National Hockey League season, The Chicago Tribune reported in its Tuesday editions.

title: Youth Gang Head Arrested in Killing Of Rival Last Fall
description: Michael Chen, 27yearold leader of the Flying Dragons, a Chinese youth gang, has been arrested for the murder last October of David Wong, a member of the rival Ghost Shadows gang.

title: Evel Kneivel Is Hurt In Motorcycle Leap
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)Evel Knievel, the stuntman, was injured today in a practice motorcycle leap only hours before a scheduled jump over a pool full of sharks. The nationally televised leap was canceled, spokesmen said. Mr. Knievel was taken to a hospital emerimmediately known. gency room, but his condition was not

title: SOVIET PARTY AFFIRMING WORLD REDS' LEADERSHIP
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (Reuters)The Soviet Communist Party today affirmed its claim to be at the center of the world revolutionary movement and indicated that Communists everywhere should follow its basic doctrines or face failure.

title: Pompidou Extolled as Giscard Opens $180 Million Art Complex
Mondale Says U.S. Will Keep Some Forces in Korea
description: TOKYO. Tuesday, Feb. 1Vice President Mondale affirmed the United States military and e economic commitment to Asia today and made it clear that the United States would keep some forces in South Korea.

title: Methuselah, Here I Come
description: WASHINGTONSomething dramatic and sobering happened to me on Jan. 20. When Jimmy Carter was sworn in at the age of 52, I was, for the first time in my life, older than the President of the United States.

title: Couturiers of Paris Have the World Paying Attention Again
Ten Killed in Thai Bus Crash
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 31 (AP) Ten persons were killed and seven others injured yesterday when a passenger bus ran into a heavy truck and caught fire in the northern Thai province of Chiangrai, the highway police reported.

title: DeathPenalty Bill Goes to Byrne After a 58to16 Vote in Assembly
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31The New Jersey Assembly approved a restoration of the death penalty for firstdegree murder today and sent the measure to Governor Byrne, who has indicated he will sign it.

title: Baranello, Party Leader in Suffolk Named State Democratic Chairman
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic leader, was elected ,Democratic state chairman today, an action that symbolized the growing role of the suburbs in the Democratic Party. He succeeded Patrick J. Cunningham, who resigned under pressure from Governor Carey.

title: Mexican Leader, Outlining Plans, Sees a Challenge in National Crisis
Playboy Plays Up Reader Hedonism
description: In the first campaign from its new agency, Epstein, Raboy Advertising, Playboy magazine will be using its readers to sell themselves to potential advertisers. The theme of the campaign is The Playboy reader. His lust for life.

title: Transport Agency Tightens Rules For Ship Safety After Oil Spills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Brock Adams, Transportation Secretary, in his first major action since taking office, moved today to tighten marine safety rules and practices to prevent the kinds of oil spills that have threatened United States coastlines and waterways in recent weeks.

title: Ready For Sleep
description: If Rip Van Winkle awakened this morning from his twenty years of sleep he would find surprisingly little to startle him. The price of his eyeopening coffee would certainly open his eyes, and so would the price of everything else. Perhaps the most shocking change to a man who had dozed off in 1957 would be the universal display of undressed girls on magazine covers at the newsstand where he buys his morning paper.

title: Los Angeles Funeral of Prinze Attended by Family and Friends
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP) Family and friends of Freddie Prinze said farewell today to the young television performer who took his own life. His coperformer, Jack Albertson, and best friend, Tony Orlando, read eulogies.

title: Article 1  No Title
McTear, 19YearOld Sprinter, Hoping To Leave BurnedOut Label in His Dust
description: Houston McTear has an answer for critics who contend he has burned himself out as a worldclass sprinter at the age of 19.

title: James Connors Is Dead at 53;. Father of Star Pro Tennis Player
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., Jan. 31 (AP)James Connors Sr., father of the professional tennis star Jimmy Connors, died of cancer last night at St. Elizabeth Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: PRESIDENT WILL TAKE ACTIVE ROLE TO CURB WAGE AND PRICE RISES; OPPOSES OUTRIGHT CONTROLS In Economic Message to Congress, Carter Says He Will Strengthen the Council on Stability
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Carter today put business and labor on notice that his Administration will play an active role in seeking to curb price and wage increases, but his economic deputy, Charles L. Schultze, said the President still opposed outright controls.

title: Rhodesia Says Guerrillas Herded 400 Young Blacks Across Botswana Border
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Black nationalist guerrillas have abducted 400 black students and marched them across the border to neighboring Botswana. a communiqu of the Rhodesian armed forces said today.

title: Kenya Halts Sport Events With Tanzanian Teams
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Kenyan Government suspended sports events with Tanzania today and demanded that Tanzania halt its provocative and indecent attacks.

title: Libyans Thanked on Hostage Aid
description: PARIS, Jan. 31  France officially thanked Libya today for helping end the 33month ordeal of Franoise Claustre as a hostage in the Sahara. The case of Mrs. Claustre ignited widespread indignation and charges of bungling and cowardice against the Government.

title: TENNESSEE DAM HALTED TO AWAIT ACTION ON FISH
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (AP)A little fish on the Federal Endangered Species List was helped today when the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit halted construction on the $100 million Tellico Dam project.

title: PRESIDENT WILL TAKE ACTIVE ROLE TO CURB WAGE AND PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Carter today put business and labor on notice that his Administration will play in active role in seeking to curb price and wage increases, but his economic deputy, Charles L. Schultze, said the President still opposed outright controls.

title: College Basketball
description: COACHES POLL

title: Gospel Show Incites Exuberance
description: Anytime one encounters something well outside one's own experience, one risks sounding patronizing when trying to talk about it. Evangelic musicmaking, especially the kind practiced in black churches, is very much foreign to this observer's own cultural milieu. Thus, there Is difficulty in talking about the gospel show offered Sunday at Radio City Music Hall. Even if one liked it very much indeed, one might end up sounding like a bemused anthropologist, charmed by the happy primitives. This would not only reveal one's own cultural limitations, but deny the skill and vitality of the music.

title: Scientologists Sue U.S. For Alleged Harassment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Founding Church of Scientology sued the Federal Government for $750 million to day for alleged illegal harassment of its religious activities.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Storm Puts Team on Ice
description: For the last four days the Cornell women's basketball team has been living on oatmeal, peanut butter and spaghetti in a motel one mile north of Watertown, N. Y. The 12woman team left Ithaca last Friday morning for a game that night against the women of St. Lawrence University, 200 miles away at Canton, N.Y. But a blizzard forced their two vans to abandon the snowclogged roads halfway through the trip.

title: CARTER ASKS CABINET TO SHUN OSTENTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Carter gave his Cabinet members another lecture on symbolic frugality today, asking them to eschew the traditional ostentation of their rank and place in Government.

title: More Open U.S. Diplomacy Is Message of Mondale's Trip
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31On his Air Force jetliner flying from Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland to Brussels eight days ago, Vice President Mondale sat in an armchair and quietly discussed his unusual journey through Europe to Tokyo.

title: A New Idea, For a Change
Inquiry on Assassinations Losing Favor in House
School Closings in Ohio Vex Working Mothers
description: CINCINNATI, Jan.31  When Ohio's energy, crisis closed the schools in metropolitan Cincinnati last Friday, Nancy Sherman was faced with a problem that hundreds of thousands of other working mothers across the country are having to confront during this harshest of recent winters: What do you do with the children?

title: Ralston Quits As Coach Of Broncos
description: John Ralston, the coach who led the Denver Broncos to the most successful campaign in the team's 16year history last season, resigned yesterday and thus he ended a battle for power and control of the team. The winner was Fred Gehrke, the man on the inside who had the ear of the owners, Gerald and Allan Phipps.

title: ECONOMISTS WARN COLD COULD OFFSET CARTER TAX REBATE
UNFILLED H.U.D. POSTS VEX HOUSING EXPERTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Six weeks after she was picked by President Carter to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Patricia Roberts Harris still has not selected a single person to serve in her top subCabinet positions.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Executives of Burlington Northern Inc. and the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway said yesterday that their companies had begun a joint study on the feasibility of combining the two railways.

title: Bridge:
description: A large contingent of players from the New York metropolitan area returned home Sunday after a happy week at the Bermuda regional championships, always a popular tournament.

title: HotShooting Irish Trounce Dayton for 11th Victory, 9764
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 1 (AP)Bruce Flowers scored 20 points, including six of seven shots in the first half, as Notre Dame swamped Dayton; 9764, in college basketball tonight.

title: PRICES OF BONDS FALL
description: The credit markets continued to decline yesterday, extending the current pronounced move toward higher interest rates into its fifth consecutive week. As prices dropped and rates rose, the Treasury sold $3 billion of threeyear notes at an average yield of 6.2 percentslightly more than a full percentage point higher than 1976's low for such securities, set late last year. Some traders attributed the decline in the fixedincome market to news that President Carter might raise his proposed $50aperson tax rebate because of the bigger heating bills Americans are paying during the nation's cold wave.

title: Chile's Government Backs Aide Who Left the U.S. Over Torturing Charges
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 (Reuters)The Chilean Government tonight came to the defense of Lieut. Col. Jaime Lavin Farina, a Foreign Ministry official who was asked to cut short an official visit to the United States last weekend after allegations that he had tortured political prisoners.

title: Rockies Gain 5to2 Victory Over Rangers
description: DENVER. Feb. 1 (AP)Dave Hudson, who had two assists and scored what proved to be the winning goal in the first period, and Michel Plasse. who put on a strong goaltending performance. helped the Colorado Rockies heat the New York Rangers tonight, 52.

title: A Remodeled Garden State Begins a 103Day Meeting
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 1The new Garden State Park opened the state's 1977 thoroughbred racing season today. Gurkhas Band, the 45 favorite, won the Garden State Inaugural, the openingday feature, with ridiculous ease.

title: ALLEGED ROBBERY VICTIM IS ARRESTED IN SHOOTING
Plant for Georgia Power
description: The Georgia Power Company, a unit of the Southern Company, annouced had received a license from the Federal Power Commission to build a 675,000 kilowatt hydroelectric generating plant near Rome, Ga. Construction will start by January 1979 and the plant will cost $160 million.

title: Giants Add Galat, Defensive Assistant, Product of Cradle of Football Coaches
New Yorkers, etc.
Thoughts of Others' Lot in Life Inspire Donors to Neediest Cases,
description: Young donors and many older ones continue to think of the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as it continues through its final month.

title: Palm Beach Politics: What a Swell Party
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1Earl E. T. Smith, who may be the only politician ever to have spent more than S6 a vote campaigning to be elected to a nonsalaried job with no actual power, has, after six years, decided to step down as Mayor of Palm Beach. Mr. Smith, a former United States Ambassador to Cuba, whose social lineage is impeccable (his mother was a descendant of William Tailer, the first Governor of Massachusetts, ana his grandfather was the New Orleans banker Samuel Smith) has been, by all accounts, one of the worst drivers in the town's history but one of the most popular Mayors.

title: Orange Juice Price Continues Erratic In Futures Trading
description: Prices of frozen orange juice futures contracts for near delivery continued to gain yesterday, while the distant deliveries declined further in hectic trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Plan to Build BurnTreatment Unit Is Expected to Be Rejected Tonight
description: The proposed construction of a 25story hospital for burn victims and for plastic surgery on Manhattan's East Side is expected to be rejected tonight ty the Health Systems Agency of New York City in favor of expanding a new burntreatment center that opened last December in the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center.

title: California County, Hit by Drought, Begins Tough Rationing of Water
Forget Cheese, Smile and Say Analog
description: The next time you are offered a tray of hors d'oeuvres with chunks of cheddar and slivers of aromatic tilsiter, beware of showing your cheese expertise. For that little tilsiter, genuine as it seems, may be made out of cottonseed, and the small chunk of agedlooking cheddar may have been part of a coconut.

title: Bachelor Cooking: A Happy Marriage of Art and Adventure
Nets Trade Williamson to Pacers For Draft Choice, Considerations
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 1 (AP)The New York Nets traded their leading scorer, John Williamson, to the Indiana Pacers tonight in exchange for the Pacers No. 1 pick in the 1977 collegiate draft, plus future considerations.

title: Joe Frazier Is Champ At Rainbow Grill, Too
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion who is heading his own nightclub revue at the Rainbow Grill this week and next, knows from his ring experience the value of preliminaries. They should be good enough to keep the audience interested but not so distracting that they diminish the building anticipation for the headliner.

title: O'Leary Named to F.E.A. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)President Carter today formally nominated John O'Leary, head of New Mexico's Energy Resources Board, to be administrator of the Federal Energy Administration Mr. O'Leary's selection had been announced earlier.

title: House Panel Limits Assassinations Inquiry to 2 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The House Rules Committee approved today a resolution reestablishing the Select House Committee on Assassinations, but only for the next two months and with a somewhat restricted investigative mandate.

title: Tasting Test for the Ersatz
description: What does imitation cheese taste like? Comparisons that come most quickly to mind are kneaded rubber erasers and crayons. But food terminology would more aptly apply, so let us try.

title: Article 1  No Title
PALESTINIAN AIDE DIES IN FIRE IN HIS APARTMENT
description: The press secretary of the Palestine Liberation Organization was asphyxiated in his East Side apartment last night after his mattress caught fire, apparently the result of smoking carelessness, fire officials reported.

title: New York Sunshine Law Is Obfuscated by Dodges And Ruses, Panel Finds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1Although it is only a month old, the state's sunshine law, which requires governmental bodies to conduct their business in public, is already clouded by agencies that use semantic distinctions to sabotage the law's intent, an official monitoring committee reported to the Legislature today.

title: TV, Radio to Carry Carter Speech Tonight
description: The three television networks and their local stations, Channels 2, 4 and 7, have scheduled a live telecast at 10 o'clock tonight of President Carter's address to the American people. Channel 13 will rebroadcast the speech at 11 P.M.

title: 3Pistol Police Arsenal Stolen
description: BIANCAVILLA, Sicily, Feb. 1 (UPI)Burglars broke into the town hall of this community of 20,000 inhabitants today and stole three pistolsthe entire, armament of the municipal police force.

title: The Labor Scene
description: A key election will be held next Tuesday when the 1.4 million members of the United Steel Workers Union decide whether to support the Establishment ticket. The vote is seen as a major test for organized labor. Page D7.

title: About Education
description: Scholastic Aptitude Tests are graded on a scale of 200 to 800. If Johnny gets a 525 and Bobby a 475, most people probably assume that Johnny is substantially more promising academically.

title: President Is Likely to Appear Soon On Some TV or Radio Callin Shows
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Juries Reported Planning to Indict Podiatrists in Albany Bribery Pact
DONALD K. MACKENZIE
description: Donald K. Mackenzie, a former vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York who had been financial consultant for the last five years, died Monday in. Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J., aftera long illness. He lived in Short Hills, and was 62 years old.

title: Moscow Students plan. Lake Monster Inquiry
description: MOSCOW Feb. 1 (Reuters)Plans are being made for a student expedition to investigate the reported sighting of a snakelike monster in a mountain lake in Soviet Kazakhstan, a scientist involved in the project said today.

title: Carter Discusses Human Rights And Arms Issues With Dobrynin
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter told Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin today that the United States would not back down on its commitment to strengthen human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, the White House said.

title: Letters
description: Nuclear Arms: The Unreliability Benefit

title: Israelis Use Tear Gas To Stop Protesters
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 1 (UPI)Security forces used tear gas today to break up crowds of teenage demonstrators in. Nablus on the Israelioccupied West sank of the Jordan River.

title: KEKKONEN ASKS ELECTION ON NEW TERM IN FINLAND
description: HELSINKI, Feb. 1 (UPI)President Urho Kekkonen,. who has been in office since 1956, said today he opposed any plan by Parliament to extend his present term beyond its 1978 expiration date without elections.

title: Ailing Barons of N.H.L. Unable to Pay Players
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (UPI)The Cleveland Barons were told that they would not receive paychecks today and that a highlevel meeting would be held tomorrow on whether the financially ailing National Hockey League team could finish its first season here.

title: How South Jersey Gas Has Coped With Crisis
description: FOLSOM, N.J., Feb. 1Advance planning, luck, tough bargaining, scrounging and curtailment of key customers have all been part of how the staff of the South Jersey Gas Company has coped with the natural gas crisis.

title: Miss Giordani Takes Slalom In Yugoslavia
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Feb.1(AP) Claudia Giordani, a 21yearold Italian, won the special slalom today for her first victory in this season's World Cup skiing competition. Monika Kaserer of Austria, 24, finished second and Perrine Pelen, France's 16yearold sensation, was third.

title: SOVIET ARMS TO CAIRO REPORTED CONTINUING
description: The Soviet Union is continuing the supply of weapons, ammunition and spare parts to Egypt through third countries, according to senior Israeli intelligence sources.

title: Travel Limits in the U.S. Confine Hanoi's U.N. Observers to Looking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1From the windows of their Manhattan office, the Vietnamese representatives here have a fine view of New York Harbor and the East River.

title: NBC Agrees to Pay the Russians Up to $80 Million for Olympics
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1The National Broadcasting Company has agreed to pay the highest amount in the televised history of the Olympics for exclusive rights to broadcast the Moscow games to the United States in 1980.

title: NBC Agrees to Pay the Russians Up to $80 Million for Olympics
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1The National Broadcasting Company has agreed to pay the highest amount in the televised history of the Olympics for exclusive rights to broadcast the Moscow games to the United States in 1980.

title: Lobbyists Win Reinstatement of Senate Unit on Aging
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Senate reorganization plan, severely compromised in committee, further unraveled on the Senate floor today with reinstatement of the Committee on Aging by a vote of 90 to 4.

title: TV: Can Sunspots Tan Bionic Angel?
description: IF THIS IS WEDNESDAY, you will probably watch ABC no matter what I say. Wednesday, a night nobody wanted for years, is now owned by ABC, which delivers a series of libidinal curves: Lindsay Wagner (The Bionic Woman), Robert Blake (The Bionic Baretta) and Farrah FawcettMajors (The Bionic Angel Cake).

title: Pool: Out of Halls and Into Homes
description: Along with the cigar store Indian and the trolley car, the neighborhood pool hall is all but gone.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A RISE IN SMALL BUSINESS LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.  I (UPI)The House today passed by voice vote a bill to increase the ceiling on total Federal small business loans from $6 billion to $8 billion.

title: Fire Ruins Doctor's Office At Embassy in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP)A fire today wrecked the office of the United States Embassy doctor, who serves much of the Western community, and he said the office would be closed for a month.

title: Personal Health
Okker and Roche Triumph In W.C.T. Richmond Event
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 1 (AP)Tom Okker beat Onny Parun, 63, 62, and Tony Roche turned back Wotjek Fibak, 61, 46, 64, in the opening round of the Richmond tennis tournament tonight. The first prize is $30,000 in the World Championship Tennis circuit event.

title: Berlin Choir Is Splendid In 2 Masses
description: TO JUDGE from the program distributed at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, we were about to hear the second performance within a week of Mozart's Great Mass in C minor (K. 427) in the antiquated and generally discredited edition of Alois Schmitt. We also were promised Bach's Magnificat in D with two of the four choral interpolations that were included in the first performance. in 1723.

title: At Home With Couple From the City Ballet One Long Pas de Deux
Chess:
Attempt at a Suicide In Red Square Fails
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP)A man set himself on fire in Red Square yesterday and is being treated for burns in hospital, a Soviet official said today. He described the man as mentally ill.

title: In Search of an Endangered Species: Real Danish Pastry
Southern Motels Lure Crowds With Live Music
description: RALEIGH, N.C.Thirtyfiveyearold Arthur Epps, who calls himself King. Arthur when he is behind a microphone, has had his ups and, downs as an entertainer, singing on. street corners in New York, recording his first single when he was 16, composing the sound track for a grade R. movie in the early 1960's, playing and singing in barrooms and clubs across the country.

title: W.T.T. Gets Borg, Fiancee
description: Proving that love conquers all, the Cleveland Nets of World Team Tennis will announce the signing. of Bjorn Borg and his fiancee, Mariana Simionescu, to multiyear contracts today.

title: The U. N. Today
Stage: Boesnaan Limns Indomitability of Spirit
description: THE PLAYS OF ATHOL FUGARD make such powerful political statements  they prove the validity of art as a social instrumentthat some people overlook the fact that this white South African is also a commanding, imaginative artist. This may be the reason why his most recent play, Dimetos, an experimental excursion away from Africa and into a mythical landscape, did not receive the attention and respect that it deserved when .it was staged in London last season.

title: Heroin Addiction Is Spreading Across Western Europe at a Rate Many Experts Consider Alarming
description: ROME, Feb. 1Some months ago Roberto, a 23yearold mathematics student at the University of Rome, started to experiment with sniffing heroin. A few weeks ago he injected it, became addicted and embarked on a $20aday habit.

title: Bill Voted in Albany To Protect Buyers Of Money Orders
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1The State Legislature passed an emergency bill this evening to bail out thousands of holders of worthless money orders in New York State and to protect future buyers of money orders from loss if the company that issues them fails.

title: Arts in Arkansas: They Make Music, Poetry, Even Movies
description: LITTLE ROCK TEN years ago, Arkansas did not have a symphony orchestra worthy of the name. Now it has five. Whether all are worthy of the name is debatable, but at least two are attracting highly competent musicians and one has begun to play occasionally outside the state.

title: Crossing The River Jordan
description: . WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Hamilton Jordan occupies the southwest corner office of the White House Executive SuiteGen. Alexander Haig's old command post in the Nixon days. It used to look a little like the English library in UpstairsDownstairs now it has all the tidiness of an unmade bed. The contrast is worth noting.

title: Conservation by Residential Users Of Fuel Held Inadequate by P.U.C.
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1State officials said today that conservation efforts by residential customers to reduce their use of natural gas and other fuels for home heating were inadequate and that drastic steps, such as the cutting off of supplies to some communities, were being contemplated.

title: Foreign  Trained Interns in U.S.: Last of a Breed
description: They wear the starched white jackets of their profession, identifying them as hospital physicians. Only their name tags, their faces and their imperfect English indicate that they are different from their American colleagues.

title: Mondale, Back in Capital, Says Major Nations Now Have a ClearView of U.S. Intentions
DISCOVERIES
description: Come on, confessyou've always thought you could belt it out as well as Barbra Streisand, Mick Jagger and all the rest of the best of themgiven, of course, the right musical and technical backup. If it's worth $99 to find out or just to have a lot of fun, there's a place called Dimensional Sound Studios that can make your Walter Mitty fantasy come true. The studio has a catalogue of prerecorded hitssoulful, romantic, rock, countrymost of the top tens in the last few decades. All you do is stand there and sing, sing, sing with a big band backup. The price includes an engineer, 30 minutes of studio time, and a reeltoreel copy of your performance to take home. You must, needless to say, make an appointment, and a call to Lila Wassenaar at 2476010 will not only get you that, but also instructions on what you should do in advancefor example, no sheet music is available, so you should, know the words of the song you want to record. The studio is at 301 West 54th Street, just a tra la la from midManhattan.

title: A.T .&T. Earnings Up to $3.83 Billion, A Record, for 1976
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the world's largest investorowned enterprise, yesterday announced earnings of $3.63 billion for 1976, a record for any corporation.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Just as Larry Checco stepped aboard the last car of the shuttle at Grand Central during a recent rush hour, the doors began to close. I thought I was the last passenger, he writes, but a man came running full tilt, briefcase in hand, wearing an expression of determination. The result was that he got caught, half in and half out the closing door.

title: Notes on People
description: FDERAL Trade Commissioner Paul Dixon apologized to ArabAmericans yesterday for calling Ralph Nader a dirty Arab, but Representative Edwakd Koch said that wasn't enough and he intended to ask Congress to impeach Mr. Dixon.

title: Trial to Focus on Allegations That Nixon's Old Firm Got U.S.Agencies to Hide Evidence on Arnholt Smith
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 1A bankruptcy trial opening here tomorrow will center on allegations that Richard M. Nixon's former law firm induced Government regulatory agencies in 1973 to conceal evidence of massive bank frauds by C. Arnholt Smith, a longtime political benefactor of Mr. Nixon.

title: Miss Longet's Lawyer Says She. Will Accept Sentence
description: ASPEN, Co1o., Feb. 1 (AP)  Charles Weedman, Claudine Longet's attorney, said tonight that Miss Longet had decided not to appeal her conviction and to accept her 30day jail sentence. He said the jail term would probably be next summer.

title: Black Composers Music To Be Heard in Brooklyn
description: A program of music by contemporary black composers will be given by the Brooklyn Philharmonia on Feb. 27 at the Billie Holiday Theater, 1368 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

title: A.M.C. Extends Credit With Bank's
description: DETROIT, Feb.1The American Motors Corporation announced today it had agreed in principle to extend for one year Its $72.5 million line of credit with United States banking interests and thant it had completed sale of its South Charleston, W.Va., stamping plant to help pay off $20.5 million owed a Swiss bank.

title: Man, 84, Dies in Fire Despite Wife's Efforts
description: An 84yearold bedridden man was fatally burned last night despite his wife's efforts to shield him when fire swept through the bedroom of the couple's duplex apartment at 115 East 78th Street.

title: ForeignTrained Interns in U.S.: Last of a Breed
description: They wear the starched white jackets of their profession, identifying them as hospital physicians. Only their name tags, their faces and their imperfect English indicate that they are different from their American colleagues.

title: Technology
description: RACINE, Wis.For more than two years, teams of American agricultural specialists have visited the manicured Chinese farm fields that have fed a quarter of mankind for thousands of years.

title: Careers
description: Matt Kallman of Gimbals, Anthony Conrad of RCA, J. C. Walker of Rath Racking, Arthur Taylor of CBS, Gary Childress of Dart Industries and J. W. Richard Goodwin of JohnsManville all suddenly left top executive posts in major companies last year.

title: ShortTerm Loss Seen for Banks In Interest on Checking Accounts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1A Federal Reserve Board staff stdy suggested today that banks would not be unduly harmed if they paid interest on checking account deposits, but warned that there would be an effect on bank earnings during a transition period.

title: Griffith, 39, Scoffs at Retiring
description: Emile Griffith and two of the world's ranking 147pound contenders, Wilfredo Benitez and Harold Weston Jr., will display their guile and punching prowess in Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: News Summary.
description: President Carter told the Soviet envoy at their first meeting that the United States would not hack down in its commitment for strengthened human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, He called this a commitment on a position, not an attack on the Soviet Union. Plans for next month's resumption of strategic arms negotiations in Moscow took up most of the onehour White House meeting. (Page A1, Cols. 12.)

title: White House Checking For Errors in News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)The White House wants to know not only what the news reports are saying, but also if reporters are getting their facts right.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ROOTS A Quaker Reader, a musical tribute to his faith, is Ned Rorem's initial composition since winning the Pulitzer Prize last year and his first largescale work for solo organ. The 11movement, 30minute piece contains sayings by such Quaker writers as William Penn and John Greenleaf Whittier. There are pauses. The composer calls them the silence which for members of the Society of Friends can sometimes explode into light:

title: January Vacation Proved Costly for Caiithen's Valet
Failure to Deliver Goods flamed for Raid on Thais
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 1 (Agence FiancePresse)  Cambodian Communist soldiers killed 30 people and: burned four hamlets last weekend because a Thai villager failed to deliver supplies the Cambodians had already paid for.

title: Ethiopia's Royalty Being Kept in Prison By Military Rulers
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (UPI)They once lived in opulence and for 3,000 years ruled this land of Solomon and Sheba virtually by divine right But more than two years after a military revolution swept them from power, Ethiopia's princesses, princes and aristocracy continue to languish in dank jails, their future uncertain.

title: Prague Rebuffs Foreign Critcism
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 1 (Reuters)The Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo today accused Western politicians and officials of interfering in Czechoslovakia's internal affairs by expressing concern over the fate of dissidents.

title: The Editorial Notebook
Behold, The Bond
description: The leaders,of the municipal unions, in thetir capacity as trustees Of city's five retirement systems, have been providing NeW York City with the only new cash it has been receiving. That process, begun in September 1975, is scheduled for completion on Mile 30, 1978, at the, conclusion of the threeyear fiscal plan for recovery.

title: Buffalo, Under First Sun in Week, Works to Dig Out From Blizzard
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 1Warmed by the first bright sun they had seen in a week and buoyed by a dropoff in snow flurries and driving winds, citizens of this frozen city yesterday bent to the task of digging out.

title: Islanders Pin 63 Loss on Sabres
New York and Jersey Officials Expect Outbreak of a Mild Flu
description: Outbreaks of relatively mild influenza have been reported in New York State and New Jersey, but there are no confirmed cases in New York City yet. An official said yesterday it was expected there would be soon.

title: Two Nashville Campuses Are Ordered to Merge
description: NASHVILLE, Feb.1 (AP)In what he called a radical remedy to end segregation, a Federal District judge has ordered two state universities here to merge within three years.

title: HOUSESENATE PANEL ADOPTS COMPROMISE ON GAS LEGISLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1House and Senate conferees worked out an agreement tonight on pricing of emergency natural gas sales to interstate pipelines, thus appearing to clear the way for final passage tomorrow by Congress of the Carter Administration's emergency gas allocation bill.

title: City U. Aides Assail Carey's Proposals To Cut Tuition Aid
description: Governor Carey's proposal for reducing the state's Tuition Assistance Program was attacked yesterday by officials of the City University of New York, who charged that the plan would place a grossly inequitable share of the reduction on City University students, especially those who are poor, older or selfsupporting.

title: Major Ally of Mrs. Gandhi Quits, Posing Serious Threat in Election
description: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Feb. 2Jagjivan Ram, the senior member of the Indian Cabinet, dramatically broke with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today, with a stinging denunciation of her emergency rule of the country. Mr. Ram's defection was a major poiitical development, posing a serious threat to Mrs. Gandhi in the current parliamentary election campaign.

title: CharlesF.Willard Is Dead
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP)Charles F. Willard the nation's first barnstorming pilot and the fourth American to pilot an airplane, died yesterday in Glendale Community Hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: Guests of Amin Rescued From Downed Plane
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Sixteen missing British guests of President Idi Amin of Uganda, who were stranded for two days when their plane went down in a remote part of East AfriCa, were ,rescued and flown to safety today, Kenyan air rescue coordinators said.

title: Botswana Contends 400 Black Students Fled From Rhodesia
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Feb. 1 (Agence FrancePress)Four hundred black Rhodesian students allegedly kidnapped and brought into Botswana by nationalist guerrillas on Sunday were fleeing from harassment by Rhodesian security forces, a Government spokesman said here today.

title: Problems From Climate Changes Foreseen in a 1974 C.I.A. Report
Reader's Digest Takes Unusual Payments
description: Reader's Digest has a nice image. It is always doing nice things to embellish its nice image.

title: BYRNE'S BUDGET ASKS $4 BILLION, A RECORD
Books of The Times
description: BECAUSE WALLACE STEVENS is one of my favorite poets, it is painful to have to confess that I find the journal he kept and the letters he wrote as a young man to he almost without interest.

title: The City Fridge: Days Of Wine and Yogurt
description: Hold on, I'll look, said John Updike, the writer, pulling the telephone cord over to the refrigerator and taking a census of the radishes in it: I'd say 17 radishes, 7 scallions, half a cucumber, 2 lemons looking a little tired, 1 drawer I can't open, filled with . . . my God . . . onions, 3 pounds of onions

title: Philip Thompson, 50, Dies
description: Philip A. Thompson, director of marketing research for The New York Times, died yesterday while vacationing in PortauPrince. Haiti. He was 50 years old.

title: BANKS SEEN EASING DEMAND ON THE CITY
description: The city's major banks appear to be softening their demand that the Carter Administration provide an extension of financial guarantees before New York City borrows any more money in the municipal bond market.

title: MAYORAL PRIMARY BACKED FOR JUNE 7
description: New York Democratic and Republican leaders have agreed on a June 7 primary date, but have not resolved their differences over whether there should be a runoff mayoral primary in New York City if no candidate in the first primary receives at least 40 percent of the vote.

title: Red Smith
Growers, Seeking to Hold Gains, Want to Keep Cotton Price Down
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 1 It's a tricky balance, said Jack Hamilton, a cotton farmer from Lake Providence. Miss. If you grow too much, they won't give you anything for it.

title: The Rejection of Sorensen: A Drama of Human Failing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter's effort to install Theodore C. Sorensen as the Director of Central Intelligence was not blocked. It collapsed.

title: Power of British Trade Unions: Signs of Stout Resistance Appear
description: LONDON, Feb. 1The cartoon on the front page of The Guardian showed a bored and weary bull standing on his hind legs and holding a cloth, presumably red, to the much smaller figure of a raging man. The man Is running at the bull with his fingers raised over his ears like horns. The man is a businessman.

title: Another Foot, Another Mouth
description: A phenomenon in these days of ethnic sensitivity is the inability of some public officials to bite their tongues when it might do the most good. One would think that Federal Trade Commissioner Paul Rand Dixon would have been impressed by the experience of Gen. George Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Earl Butz, former Secretary of Agriculture, before he communicated to a trade association his estimate of Ralph Nader as a dirty Arab. The comment was, if anything, more crude and, bigoted than the observations about Jews that won for General Brown a Presidential rebuke or the jokes about blacks that cost Mr. Butz his job.
