title: Vance Is Planning to Begin Soviet Visit on March 28
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will begin la visit to the Soviet Union on March 28 to discuss the limitation of strategic arms, it was announced today.

title: Travel Curbs in Soviet and U.S. Not Improved by Detente
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2An American diplomat pulled his car to the side of a road in the Soviet Union not long ago and stopped to eat a sandwich he had brought along. Within minutes a policeman swooped in on him, ordering him to keep moving. Foreigners are not allowed to stop in this area, the officer said.

title: Big Six Mayors in Albany Term Carey's Budget a Burden to Cities
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2The Mayors of the state's largest cities testified here today that the Governor's budget proposal, placed intolerable burdens on them.

title: Recreating Rheingold Brewery as Shopping Mall Studied
description: City and Federal officials are considering a plan advanced by two private developers to convert the derelict old Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn into a shopping mall that could create 2,000 new jobs and put new life into the decaying Williamsburg and Bushwick sections.

title: Curfew Is Imposed to Stop Unrest in Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Feb. 2 (Reuters)President Siaka P. Stevens declared a state of emergency and imposed a curfew in this West African country last night after clashes between proGoverninent demonstrators and students demanding his resignation. No deaths or serious injuries were reported, but all schools were closed.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, Feb. 2, 1977

title: House Panel Will Revamp Carter's Tax Package
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The tax writing committee of the House of Representatives served notice today that it would make subStantial changes in the Administration's proposals for business tax credits but would probably leave the planned $50 per person rebates on 1976 taxes unchanged.

title: Bug Proof Shelf Paper Coated With Pesticide
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 2 (AP)The Minnesota Agriculture Department says inspectors have found household shelf paper coated with Chlordane, a possible cancercausing pesticide, in two westcentral Minnesota grocery stores.

title: Chapin Says A.M.C. Hopes to Break Even
description: DETROIT, Feb 2Ten years ago, when Roy D. Chapin stood before his first shareholders meeting as the chairman of the American Motors Corporation, the company was, in his words, being counted out.

title: Nebraska Court Upholds Capital Punishment Law
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 2 (UPI)The Nebraska Supreme Court upheld the state's capital punishment law today, ruling that the law meets constitutional tests and is not cruel and unusual punishment when applied, in certain cases.

title: Improper Relief Payments
description: A state audit of the New York City welfare caseload has uncovered the names of 1,115 families who are receiving both full welfare grants in the category of Aid to Dependent Children and courtordered support payments from absent parents.

title: The Text of Jimmy Carter's First Presidential Report to the American People
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's televised speech from the White House last night, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Feld Company Schedules Bow Of Baryshnikov
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will appear with the Eliot Feld Ballet for the first time during the company's season at the City Center 55th Street Theater from March 9 through March 20. Mr. Feld will choreograph a new pas de deux to Charles Ives for Mr. Baryshnikov and Christine Sarry that will be called Variations on America. The Russian dancer has also been seen in New York with American Ballet Theater and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: TV: Fantastic Journey Stalled
description: The Fantastic Journey is a weekly sciencefantasy series that starts tonight on NBC at 8 o'clock. It is a combination of Lost in Space, Planet of the Apes and Gilligan's Island. To say more is to risk sounding like an idiot.

title: Lance Indicates He Won't Restore Ford Cuts in Environment Budget
Reports of Nearby Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplied by resort owners.)

title: CARTER URGES NATION TO UNITE ON PROGRAM OF LONGRANGE GOALS
Marine Reservists Win LongHair Suit
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Marine reservists at Glenview Naval Air Station can avoid haircuts by tucking long hair under short wigs, United States District Court Judge Alfred Y. Kirkland has ruled.

title: NBC Plan to Increase Coverage Key to $80 Million Olympics Bid
description: The key to NBC's willingness to ma more than 880 million for the rights to the 1980 Olympic Games from Moscow was its plan to present twice the coverage that ABC offered with last summer's Olympics from Montreal. It has been learned from NBC officials that the network will schedule around 1.50 hours of Olympics programming from July 19 to Aug. 3, 1980, or an average of nine hours a day. ABC devoted 78 hours of coverage to the Montreal events.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Groundhog Sees His ShadowOr Was It just TV Lights?
description: PUNXSUTAWNEY, Pa. Feb. 2The snow lay deep and even. The temperature lay even deeper5 degrees. In top hats and gooseflesh the city fathers shivered their way Gobbler's Knob.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AUNTIE MAME She's back and the St. Bart's Players, resident troupe of St. Bartholomew's Church (Park Avenue and 50th Street) have her in three WednesdaySaturday sessions, through Feb. 19. This show is a revival of the original 1956 Broadway comedy starring Rosalind Russell, not the subsequent Mame with music, ranging from Angela Lansbury to Lucille Ball (on film).

title: Pound Is Bolstered By a Record Surge In British Reserves
description: LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP)Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currency took a record leap upward last month, bolstering the pound on world currency markets and lifting hopes that the Labor Government has started to find the right answers to its economic problems.

title: Carter's Agenda: Secrecy
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2In the course of a Jawsuit against Federal officials, the plaintiffs ask for certain documents. Government lawyers hand them over. They are not classified; experts have screened them and removed any security secrets. But the Government lawyers go to court and ask for an order forbidding the plaintiffs to make the nonsecret documents public.

title: I.L.A. ISSUES A WARNING ON CONTAINERIZING RULES
description: The International Longshoremen's Association served notice yesterday on the shipping industry that it was canceling its current contract in a dispute over containerization rules, a move that could lead to a port strike here on March 7. The contract provides for cancellation on 30 days notice by either party.

title: Budget Lid Fought
description: The dismissal of a suit challenging the state law limiting annual municipal budget increases to 5 percent will be appealed, an attorney for 12 municipalities said in Morristown. Joel Murphy, who argued the case unsuccessfully before Judge Bertram Polow in Superior Court, said the case would be appealed directly to the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Commercial Conversions Offer Novelty
description: There is a certain kind of apartment that has thin white walls, low ceilings and the most compact possible arrangement of rooms. It sits within a new building of white brick, and by now it is as common a part of the landscape as the New York cabdriver or the pigeons of Central Park. For years, builders have justified the standard New York luxury highrise apartmentperhaps as mean a piece of architecture as ever carried the word luxury before iton the ground that it was the only economical alternative in a city of high land costs, high labor costs and high taxes. To build with the generous space, unusual room arrangements and quality materials of the apartment houses of 50 or more years ago. would yield a building no one could afford to live in, they argue.

title: Ohio, Starved for Natural Gas, Strives to Adjust Its Way of Life
Health Officials Disturbed By Spread of Measles
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 2 (AP)Measles, one of the most dangerous of childhood diseases, is spreading, and the national Center for Disease Control says a major cause of the increase is that states are not enforcing child vaccination laws.

title: Mary Tyler Moore, at Series End, Can Now Savor Its Innovations
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP)  On a stage in nearby Studio City on Friday, Mary Richards will produce her last newscast for station WJMTV In Minneapolis. People have been asking her how her show will end.

title: Richard Karp,Dies in Pittsburgh;Headed Opera Company Since42
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2Richard Karp, director of the Pittsburgh Opera Company since 1942, died today of, cancer at Montefiore Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Fire at Tiger Stadium Destroys Press Box
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP)Tiger Stadium's press box probably will have to be rebuilt as a result of a fire that swept the thirddeck last night. Some 45 firefighters battled the blaze or two hours. None of the regular spectator areas and none of the new mercury vapor light structures appeared much affected by the fire.

title: Solzhenitsyn Fund for Soviet Prisoners Is Disclosed
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2Details of a financial aid operation set up by Aleksandr I. Solhenitsyn, which has spent the equivalent of $360,000 to assist hundreds of Soviet political prisoners and their families, were disclosed today by a close friend of the exiled Russian author.

title: ACCOUNTING RULES LISTED FOR AUDITING OF BROKERS
description: The accounting profession's rulemakers published guidelines yesterday for auditing securities firms under the industry's recently simplified regulatory requirements.

title: AIDE OF MRS. GANDHI. RESIGNS, INCREASING HOPES OF OPPOSITION
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2Opponents of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, elated by the surprise defection of her senior Cabinet minister, conferred tonight on how to encourage further defections and unify opposition. in the campaign for next month's Parliament elections.

title: U .S.  Denies Young Condoned Presence Of Cubans in Angola
Carter Places Indiana and Ohio on Emergency Status in the Cold Crisis
description: With cold weather and shortages of natural gas continuing, President Carter yesterday declared emergencyaid status for Indiana and Ohiothe sixth and seventh states given either disaster or emergency designations so far.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT PITTSBURGH

title: Minnesota Acts on Energy
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP)Gov. Rudy Perpich has asked schoolteachers to increase public awareness of the state's energy problems and has declared February as Energy Conservation Month.

title: HELEN N. BISSELL
description: Helen Nutting Bissell, a former teacher, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was, 98 years old and lived at 1060 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bearded Collie Is Sanctioned With Hyannis Show Sunday
description: The bearded collie came into its own this week with its legitimacy as working breed competitor officially sanctioned by the American Kennel Club. The Cape Cod show, Sunday at Hyannis, Mass., marks the first time this original drover or cattle dog can aim at championship points in the East and a total of 14 will be on hand to dispel any myths that they resemble the popularized image of a collie, a word that in Scottish actually means shepherd.

title: COL BURTON ANDRUS, JAILER AT NUREMBERG
description: TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 2 (AP)Burton C. Andrus, a retired Army colonel who was in charge of security at the Nuremberg jail, died yesterday at Madigan Army Medical Center. He was 84 years old.

title: School Custodians Union Agrees on New Contract With No Cost Provision
Holloran, Nixon Honored
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 1 (AP) John Holloran of George Washington University and Norm Nixon of Duquesne University have been named as CoPlayers of the Week in the Eastern Collegiate Basketball League. Both are receiving the weekly honor for the second time this season.

title: People in Sports
description: Ed Figueroa, the Yankee pitcher who failed in two attempts at becoming the first Puerto Rican 20game winner in the major leagues, succeeded yesterday in signing a fouryear contract with the New York Club. The pact, negotiated by Jerry Kapstern, is estimated to be worth $500,000. Figueroa reportedly earned $50.000 last season.

title: Two Clues Lead To Arrest of 2 In Slaying Case
description: A pair of handcuffs and an empty blackberrybrandy bottle left at the scene led to the arrest yesterday of two men charged with the murder of a 74yearold doctor last Dec. 19 in his groundfloor office on 86th Street at Park Avenue.

title: CARTER URGES NATION TO UNITE ON PROGRAM OF LONGRANGE GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2In his first Presidential report to the nation, Jimmy Carter tonight asked Americans to unite in a spirit of cooperation and mutual effort to help him develop predictable, longrange programs that we can be sure we can afford and that we know will work.

title: President Signs Natural Gas Bill, Marking First Legislative Victory
ShotPut Mark Broken
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 2 (AP)  Helena Fibingerova of Czechoslovakia bettered her world indoor shotput record today when she reached 71 feet on her first attempt in a tournament at Olympic Hall here. Miss Fibingerova set the former indoor world record one week ago at Ostrava, Czechoslovakia, where she reached 70 feet 9 inches.

title: Links Between Budget Deficit and Inflation
description: Do Federal budget deficits cause inflation? A resounding yes to that question is the surest proof of a businessman's, banker's or politician's intellectual soundness and moral integrity. But it is not necessarily so.

title: CHOICE OF ARMS AIDE IS FACING OPPOSITION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Paul C. Warnke as the chief negotiator on arms control matters. The nomination is expected to touch off a debate in the Senate over the former Pentagon official's views on arms reduction.

title: Fernandez, a Top Guitarist
description: It was once possible to wonder which guitarist would inherit Andrds Segovia's mantle and his devoted audience, but such speculation has been pointless for some years. Rather than one legitimate heir, it is now evident Mr. Segovia already has dozens and the list of worldclass guitarists seems to grow daily.

title: Oil Cleanup Begun
description: More than 300,000 gallons of oil in two leaking tanks were pumped off a barge as a private company tried to clean up about 200 gallons of fuel that seeped into Raritan Bay. A Coast Guard spokesman said the two tanks had ruptured Tuesday night as the Bouchard Barge No. 105 hacked away from a pier at the Chevron Terminal in Perth Amboy.

title: Lebanon and Syria Announce Accord To Align Policies
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 2Syria and Lebanon announced today that they had decided to formulate a common strategy for coordinating policies.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Snowblowers in Action in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 2Look, lady, we gotta clear the street! The scene was unusual, but there was something familiar about that voice. And why not? It was the voice of Herb D'Amato, a deputy inspector with the New York City Sanitation Department, explaining to an irate Buffalo woman why he had just dumped a ton of snow in her driveway.

title: DECLINE CONTINUES IN PRICES OF BONDS
description: The credit markets, wary about President Carter's fireside chat last night and Arthur F. Burn's Congressional testimony this morning, declined sharply again yesterday. Oneyear Treasury bills sold at an average rate of 5.35 percent, up from 4.73 percent a month ago and the highest for these bills since last September. Bell System bonds, meanwhile, were priced to yield 8.30 percent, well above the 7.90 percent rate of the preceding telephone financing, but the new bonds sold slowly.

title: LEO LUCKER
description: Leo Lucker, who appeared in the Broadway production of Inherit the Wind with. Paul Muni and Ed Begley, died Tuesday night at Veteran's Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 455 West 44th Street.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1977

title: Lowenstein Is Reported In Line for Post at U.N.
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein is a leading candidate for appointment as the United States representative to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, according to sources at the United Nations.

title: Chewing Away at Inflation
description: President Carter managed to unite another coalition this week, but not quite as he intended. In his economic message to Congress, the President put Big Labor and Big Business on notice that he plans to monitor important wage settlements and price increases, so as to guard against inflation. Both were quick to record their lack of enthusiasm, reflecting their common view that monitoring is a first step toward wage and price controls.pressure of guidelines first, as management resistance stiffens in contract negotiations. Mr. Schultze hopes to overcome union hostility by offering formal or informal insurance that corporations will meet their part of the bargain by moderating price increases. The White House is not yet specific on this question but a number of ideas are being studied. One plan, offered by Mr. Okun two years ago, would compensate workers for lost purchasing power through tax rebates to lowincome families, money that the Government would recoup through tax surcharges on businesses that failed to hold prices down.

title: Oil Wealth Helps Ease Growing Pains of Riyadh, the Saudi Capital, Which Is Becoming a World City
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaThis raw boomtown, home of the Royal family, has been the capital of Saudi Arabia since Ibn Saud founded the modern dynasty early in the century.

title: Dixon W rites an Apology to Nader For Derogatory Ethnic Remark
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Federal Trade Commissioner Paul Rand Dixon, who publicly described Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, as a dirty Arab, has written to. Mr. Nader to apologize for what he called a derogatory reference to your ethnic background.

title: Champion Spark Plug Near Pact
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP)The United Auto Workers and Champion Spark Plug Company reached agreement in principle yesterday on a threeyear international contract covering five plants in the United States and one in Canada. The tentative agreement covers more than 5,000 U.A.W. members at Champion plants in Detroit; Toledo and Cambridge, Ohio; Burlington, Iowa; Hellertown, Pa., and Windsor, Canada.

title: Waitresses in Fine Restaurants: It's Hard to Surmount a Taboo
description: In an almost uniform admission of sex bias, it seems that neither men nor Women believe they can be seriously served by women as waiters in haute cuisine restaurants.

title: Untouchable Who Gained Power
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2The burly 68yearold politician who stunned India today by resigning from both the Government and Congress Party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has been a power to reckon with for three turbulent decades of Indian politics. Jagjivan Ram. popMan ularly referred to as Babuji, or Respected Father, is the unofficial leader of the nation's 85 million untouchables and one of the few of his caste to break through its restrictions and rise to eminence.

title: Gold
description: By The Associated Press

title: BANK URGES A RISE IN OFFICIAL LENDING TO DEFICIT NATIONS
description: An expansion of the International Monetary Fund is necessary if American banks are to continue lending prudently to countries having trouble with their balance of payments, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company says.

title: New York Seeks Additional Time To Repay Notes
description: New York City failed yesterday, as expected, to come up with a plan to pay off the holders of nearly $1 billion in its shortterm notes, but at the same time officials reported that the principal banks and municipal unions had taken important steps toward resolving their differences over how those shortterm notes should be repaid.

title: By Bread Alone? A WellFed Slave Is a WellFed Slave.
Schools Told to Use Gas Crisis To Teach Energy Conservation
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke urged today that schools across the state use the current natural gas emergency as a tool to teach children about the need for energy conservation.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: EXMENTAL PATIENTS TO GET LEGAL ADVICE
description: HACKENSACK, Feb 2A pilot project to provide free legal counseling or representation for former mental patients and those facing discharge from or institutionalization in psychiatric facilities was organized today by the Bergen County government.

title: Notes on People
description: Attending her first meeting of the House Rules Committee, Representative Shirley Chisholm noted that she was getting special treatment of a sort she despised. Her fellow New Yorker, Representative James J. Delaney, the chairman, kept referring to other committee members as Mr. Anderson, Mr. Bolling and so forth, but kept calling her Shirley. After that happened for the third time, Mrs. Chisholm said, Mr, Chairman, if you're going to call the others by their last names, I'd prefer to be called by my last name too. The dialogue continued something like this:

title: Miss Morerod Raises Lead With Giant Slalom Victory
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Feb. 2 (AP LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland, skiing aggressively, won today's giant slalom and increased her World Cup lead over Annemarie Proell Moser.

title: Article 10  No Title
Fredrickson Retained as Director Of National Institutes of Health
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Carter Administration announced today that it would retain Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson as director of the National Institutes of Health, the Government's main agency for the conduct and support of biomedical research.

title: Allen Ginsberg at the West End
Fear Expressed That Fed Target May Block Carter's Growth Goal
description: Several private economists expressed fears yesterday that the Federal Reserve's slightly more stringent targets for the growth of the nation's money supply this year may be insufficient to finance the 6 percent rate of economic growth the Carter Administration hopes to achieve.

title: ProGreek Terrorists Suspected
description: NICOSIA. Feb. 3 (UPI)The Cypriot Police have named members of a proGreek terrorist group as suspects in the 1974 assassination of Ambasador Davies, according to the attorney general's office.

title: Stone Leopard, a Political Thriller With Bite
description: Political thrillers have been flooding the popular book market for several years now, and their themes have been assassinations, or nearassassinations, of government figures, the Cold War, and more recentlyand fashionablythe intrigues in the Middle East. Many of these thrillers have unabashedly been roman it clefs and their characters less than thinly disguised versions of prominent men and women in the news. One of the best, or at least one of the most entertaining, is this new one by Colin Forbes.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Early Swedish Movies at the Modern
description: Ingmar Bergman's father was a clergyman. On Sundays after the service he would show movies, generally Swedish ones.Predestination is hardly necessary with a background like that. Bergman's films are modern sermons, plotted in an empty church and shapedmore than most of us realizeby the shadow and light, the bleak revelry, the sense of ghosts in the land and the mind contained the early Swedish films shown on those Sunday afternoons.This weekend, and lasting until early April, the Museum of Modern Art will be showing some of Bergman's Sunday afternoons: a collection of the best surviving examples of the Swedish silent film.Not that the program is set up that way. The show, organized by the Museum's Film Department with the help of the Swedish Film Institute (which is supplying the prints), sets out to present a body of work with a value of its own; one little known in this country. The show centers mainly around the work of two major directors, Victor Sjostrom and Mauritz Stiller.Yet take Sjostrom's "The Phantom Chariot," (March 5 and 7). It is framed in blackness, as if the light were dark and the highlights were fugitive shadows. It starts with a wild drunken brawl in a churchyard. The protagonist, played by Sjostrom himselfwho so many years later would play the old rememberer in Bergman's "Wild Strawberries"is knocked on the head. The rest of the picture is a mixture of delusion and reality: fantasies about a chariot sent to collect the souls of the dead, interwoven with flashbacks of the protagonist's own life and loves.Complex, savage and with a half-fraudulent mystery. Coarse, half-rustic figures propelled or led on by a ghostly illumination. It is a film Bergman particularly remembered being impressed by; and it is impossible to see it now without getting a new perspective upon the harsh originality of "The Seventh Seal."Sjostrom organized his films with the entrances and exits, the playing to a motionless camera, that is clearly derived from the theater. The plays, furthermore, are melodramas, and the acting has all the eye-rolling and underlined gesture common to films made between 1910 and 1920.The figures scurry and posture in a fashion that is too obsolete to be interesting. But there is something more. In "Terje Vigen," which is playing on Sunday, the movement is more poetic than dramatic. It is, in fact, the recreation of a poem by Ibsen; the legend of a man who lives by the sea and loses wife and child in a famine.The reality in this still and moving film is not the plot, but the landscapes. The landscape of rock and water, and of the gray unchanging sky. The landscape of Terje Vigen's face. Suffering is as unmovable on that face as the seams on the rocks or the waveswhich move but are replacedon the sea. The motionless camera stretches out time in such a fashion that none of these things are static but simply proceed at the speed of the earth.In contrast with the work of Sjostrom is the more agile and witty style of Mauritz Stiller, a director who inspired Lubitsch, for example. In "Love and Journalism," also playing Sunday, the plot cavorts suitably as farce. A handsome explorer returns home. A woman reporter, barred from an interview, gets a job as a pretty incompetent maid. Pretty and incompetent, that is. Love strikes, etc., etc.The real movement is not in the plot, though, but in the faces and stances of the lovers. It is a dialogue of gesture; Karin Molander as the journalist has a face that is an epigram, a bodyrelaxing and going tautthat is a retort.Another Stiller comedy, considerably more sophisticated, is his "Erotikon, (March 3 and 5); a witty, perhaps ambiguous mockery of the rich, it tells of a series of shifting relationships, among a professor, his wife, a sculptor who loves her, and others. Temptation is a game more than a reality. The mind dabbles in it; what the bodies do is almost beside the point.The more dramatic side of Stiller's work is also shown. "The Treasure of Arne" (Feb. 20 and 22) is an elaborate epic tragedy, taking place in the 16th century, and based on a novel by Selma Lagerlof. Snowbound landscapes and the sea are used to frame the small figures and their struggles.The balance of the program includes other works by Sjostrom and Stiller, and some by lesser-known directors. In particular, there is "The Prisoner of Karlsten's Fortress," which was shown yesterday. It is a knotty and silly melodrama about a man who steals a scientist's secret formula for making explosives, and hides the professor's daughter in a castle. The filmappropriately, by the Hasselblad Studios, which in those days made films as well as camerasis mainly about deep focus.One short film, "Peter the Tramp," (March 12 and 18) used Greta Garbo when she was still known as Greta Gustaffson.At every conceivable opportunity people are photographed through doorways, down passages and on the other side of windows, in order to show off the technique. It is an early example of technological follywe have the movie for the sake of the camera instead of vice versa.For programs and times on the day of a show, call 956-7078. For advance information, call 956-7284. Tickets are $2, $1.25 for students and 75 cents for the elderly and children.

title: Ram Aide Chosen. As Falcon Coach
description: The Atlanta Falcons search for a head coach has ended with the selection of Leeman Bennett. a Los Angeles Rams assistant.. Eddie LeBaron, the Falcon's new general manager, made the announcement at a news conference yesterday.

title: Graell Scores On 4 Winners, Cauthen on One
ExJersey Senator and Father Appeal Convictions in Theft of Oil
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 3 (AP)Former State Senator Jerome Epstein and his father have appealed their convictions of conspiracy to steal oil.

title: SixPlayer Soviet Squad Joins World Team Tennis
Met Basso Tests the Concert Waters
description: After 10 years of increasing acclaim for his achievements at the Metropolitan and other major opera houses, Paul Plishka is taking the concert plunge. The popular basso has given only 9 or 10 song programs in his entire career, but he's been thinking and planning and studying, and he is confident about his recital debut at Town Hall this Sunday afternoon. I don't go very fast, he says, but once I get going there's very little that gets in my way.

title: Carter May Specify A Ceiling by March 1 On Federal Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The upper ceiling that President Carter intends to impose on the number of Federal Government employees will probably become known by March 1 when his Administration offers its amendments to President Ford's last budget, the White House said today.

title: 2 Poster Shows Offer Surprises
description: Poster collecting, once reserved primarily to admirers of Henri ToulouseLautrec's provocative Parisian studies, has spread, over the last decade, to include practically all placards printed since the late 19th century. And two exhibitions on view in East Side galleries, dramatize the specialty aspects that have now developed in poster collecting.

title: Barring of Women Priests Spurs Call to Stop Giving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)A group angered by Pope Paul VI's declaration that women cannot become priests urged Roman Catholics across the nation today to withhold contributions to their churches.

title: Edward Paul Flood Dead at 84, Doctor in Bronx for Half Century
description: Dr. Edward Paul Flood, who practiced medicine in the Bronx for nearly 50 years and was president of the Bronx County Medical Society in 1938 and 1939, died Wednesday in St. Patrick's Nursing Home, the Bronx, after a brief illness. His age was 84.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: AFTER Roots, what? Well, not much tonight or tomorrow night, as though the networks knew they were going to be tired after a week of trying to figure out the significance of ABC's amazing ratings sweep. But American history makes a comeback Sunday, as fact and fiction, with some mixed and interesting results.

title: BritishSoviet Fishing Talks Due
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (UPI)The Soviet Union has agreed to open negotiations with Britain on new fishing restrictions within a 200mile limit imposed by. European Common Market countries, the British Foreigrn Office said today.

title: Many Carter Aides Picked From OftenTapped Source
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Like Presidents before him, Jimmy Carter has drawn heavily for his major appointments from such essentially Eastern sources as major corporations, Ivy League campuses, prestigious commissions and foundations and the personnel lists of past Administrations.ment suites and offices in the militaryindustrial complex.

title: Red Smith
description: Wilfredo Benitez is a small welterweight with much talent and more selfesteem. His skill made him a sort of world champion at 17 or 18, depending on which baptismal certificate he was using, but his ego could easily debauch his talent. He has been watching Muhammad All too much on television.

title: The Chat by the Fire
description: President Carter's performance beside the White House fireplace Tuesday evening was masterful in the ways he intended. His syntax matched the simplicity of his sweater. He came across as friendly and solicitous of the country's hardships and prejudices both. He satisfied the nation's paradoxical desire to be led firmly and yet to have its concerns openly recognized and addressed. Those who may have been misled by the narrow margin of his victory last November should know now that his hold on public opinion will be formidable.

title: A HardDriving Pragmatist
description: When a raging fire in a switching center knocked out 173,000 telephones in Manhattan two years ago, some experts estimated it would atke 18 months to restore service fully. Optimists said they thought it could possibly be done in six months. But Lee P. Oberst, a dynamic New York Telephone Company vice president in charge of the company's operations in the city, was put on the job, and in just 24 days all the phones were ringing again.

title: Big Store Sales Are Steady
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Editorial Board Of Times Adds 3
description: Additional appointments to the editorial board of The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page.

title: S.E.C. Weighs Move to Undo Law Barring Firms as Dual Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering administrative action to undo a Federal law that would effectively prevent securities firms from acting as both broker and investment adviser to institutions.

title: Airline Luggage Liability Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)The Civil Aeronautics Board today raised to $750 an airline's liability for lost luggage and said passengers also should be compensated for property rentals required because of misplaced luggage.

title: WIDOW OF RICKENBACKER A SUICIDE, POLICE REPORT

Aaron Guidry of Opelousas, La., arrived at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot last April he has run up an unauthorized longdistance phone bill of $2,858.54, the Marine Corps said today. Sergeant Guidry has been charged with making unauthorized. calls and referred to the commanding general for disciplinary action. A Marine spokesman said that the calls were possible because telephones on the base have direct access to the outside

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The chairman of the Congressional committee investigating the slayings of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the panel had uncorroborated evidence indicating a conspiracy in the killings.

description: For those writing a duke and wondering how lofty a salutation to extend and for those meeting the Queen of England and wondering how deep the bow or curtsy should be, help is on the way.

title: Film: 3 Women Who Didn't Wait for Lefty
description: UNION MAIDS" is 55 minutes long. It's a documentary, photographed in black-and-white and, I suspect, it's designed principally for television; but it's one of the more moving, more cheering theatrical experiences available in New York this weekend.It can be seen at noon tomorrow and Sunday, this weekend and next, at the Elgin Theater, on a double bill with "On the Line," a more elaboratein color and longer by five minutesdocumentary that, like "Union Maids," deals with cooperative social action, which is sometimes but not always trade-unionism."Union Maids" is very much about trade-unionism but it's even more about three extraordinary women, Kate Hyndman, Stella Nowicki and Sylvia Woods who, in the course of three separate interviews, which are intercut with each other and with period newsreel footage, recall their lives as women laborers and union organizers in Chicago in the late 20's and 30's.It was a sometimes brutal, bitter, mingy time for all labor and especially for women who didn't believe their places were necessarily in the home. Yet it was also a time of terrific hope, when one could believe in social and political progress and measure it by the concessions won through group action.Kate, who appears to be the oldest of the three, has the face of an elderly schoolmistress whose seeming severity is constantly denied by her comic self-appraisals and by the warmth and the passion with which she recalls her life as a labor militant and feminist. That didn't always go down too well with the labor militants who were male.Stella grew up on a farm in Michigan and, as a young woman, moved to Chicago to work in the stockyards. Sylvia, a black woman who was born and bred in New Orleans, also moved to Chicago at an early age. There, she was active in organizing the laundry workers who, as she remembers with biting humor, were mostly women who worked seven days a week and had to provide written explanations to their bosses when they were absent.Largely because of Sylvia this requirement was eventually dropped. Her ploy: to persuade every woman to give as the reason for her absenteeism, "just tired."Julia Reichert, James Klein and Miles Mogulescu, who jointly directed and produced "Union Maids," never get in the way of their subjects and never put words in their mouths. They don't have to Sylvia, Stella and Kate are three naturals, characters whose hearts and minds leap off the screen with a kind of grace and nobility I haven't seen in a documentary since Jerry Bruck's "I.F. Stone's Weekly.""On the Line," directed and produced by Barbara Margolis, has no comparable focal points and, indeed, I'm not quite sure if it has any focal point at all. It looks rather like a documentary whose material failed to provide the film maker with the kind of drama and narrative shape that Barbara Koppel found in her "Harlan County, U.S.A." Its material includes interviews with workers at the Ford Motor Company in Mahwah, N.J., with rent-striking residents at Co-op City in the Bronx, an engineer at an RCA plant who feels the company no longer values him and with a Medicaid worker.Their common complaint is that contemporary America is running amok with rising prices, unemployment, and a generally heedless attitude on the part of the people who might be able to control the economy.There's nothing especially wrong with the vision the film presents, but the vision is too diffuse to have much impact on the screen. The film maker wants it to say more than she does, to which end, I suppose, Miss Margolis uses an off-screen narrator (Rip Torn), which gives "On the Line" the feeling of an industrial film. The best, most effective, documentaries tend to speak for themselves, not through off-screen mouthpieces.

title: Chrysler Raises Prices in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)Chrysler (U.K.) Ltd. said it had raised the price in Britain of all its Europeanbuilt cars by an average of 6.5 percent, effective today. Prices of commercial vehicles were raised an average of 6 percent.

description: A 13yearold East Harlem girl was stabbed several times and then raped by an unknown assailant early yesterday morning on a stairway in the King Towers project while on her way home.

title: Nursing Home Penalized
description: The Irvington Nursing Home in Newark has lost its license. The State Department of Health announced the revocation of the license with the agreement of Allen Kilik of Short Hills, who has been legal receiver for the home since last Jan. 7. The department said that all patients at the nursing home had been moved to other healthcare facilities in the Newark area.

title: Earthquake Rocks Palm Springs
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI)An earthquake shook this desert spa shortly before dawn today. There were no damage or injury reports. The Caltech seismological laboratory in Pasadena said that the temblor measured 3.0 on the openended Richter scale. It occurred at 5:49 A.M. with the epicenter five miles northwest of Palm Springs.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 3Governor Byrne waived today the oneweek waiting period required before unemployed workers can collect unemployment benefits, thus making 52,200 newly unemployed eligible for such payments immediately. Many of these newly unemployed were laid off because of a naturalgas shortage in the state.

title: At the Movies
description: JUDGING from the reviews, you didn't miss much if you missed my movie, drawled David Warner, the pale, gaunt and refreshingly candid actor who plays an eccentric who may or may not be the impudent bastard son of John Gielgud in Providence, Alain Resnais's hallucinatory motionpicturepuzzle that is bewitching some and bewildering others at the new Cinema 3. All the reviews I've read have been bad. I think the critics are approaching it with too heavy a hand, however, looking for all sorts of things that simply don't exist. To me, Providence is a comedy.

title: Trudeau Asserts Ottawa May Conduct Referendum On Quebec Independence

title: Bus Tours to Capital for Tutankhamen

The trip includes an overnight stay at the HayAdams Hotel and shuttle bus service to the museum for the first American exhibition of personal artifacts and treasures from the tomb of the 14th century B.C. king of Egypt. The cost for the trip is $65, including light refreshments on the bus.

title: Stage: Double Bill by Albee
description: IT IS ODD to remember that Edward Albee actually started out his career as what you might term a neorealist playwright. Since then, scorning the particular and little triumphs of realism, he has moved toward the theater of sound and feeling, joining such men as James Joyce an honorary roleSamuel Beckett, Harold Pinter and even Sam Shepard. And like them, he has retained the trappings of realism while rejecting its substance. It is a theater of the heart.

Seed Co., Greenwood, S.C. 29647, or J.L. Hudson, Seedsman, P.O. Box 1058, Redwood City, Calif., 94064 (catalogue, 50 cents). Hurov's Tropical Seeds, P.O. Box 10387 C. Oahu, Honolulu, Hawaii 96816, has an extensive free list. It includes mostly foliage plants, and it makes great reading, since this firm is a seed supplier for many of the wholesale growers.

title: Population Distribution an Issue for States
description: During the Great Depression of the 1930's, California tried to exclude poverty stricken migrants from pouring in from the East. The United States Supreme Court held that this violated all the basic legal tenets on such matters as interstate reciprocity and a citizen's right to travel freely. Now the issue has arisen again, ironically for the opposite reason: the unending influx of wellheeled peoplebent on enjoying the beauties of Hawaii as a residence. Gov. George Ariyoshi has urged the Legislature to take statutory steps to limit this flow of humanity — acknowledging that the idea collides with Constitutional precedents but insisting that controls are necessary if the islands are not to be overcrowded.

title: 2 Polls Provide Support for Congressional Reforms
Music: Xenakis, Wuorinen et al.
description: IF NOTHING ELSE, Tennis Xenakis's furiously energetic Damaathen for oboe and percussion (1976), which had its premiere Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, provides a grueling workout for the performerson this occasion Nora Post and Jan Williams. Miss Post and Mr. Williams are members of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts of the State University of New York at Buffalo, which presented the Evenings for New Music concert, and which commissioned the 10minute Xenakis composition.

title: Benin Raid: An African Mystery
Benjaminto Quit Public TV Group
description: Robert S. Benjamin announced yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting at the next meeting of the board on March 9. He has held this position since December 1974

title: Boehm's Widow Carrying on the Tradition
description: To a store buyer from Chicago, Helen Boehm is the movie star of the porcelain business. To Reese Palley, the Atlantic City art dealer who is the largest purveyor of Boehm porcelain in the world, she is a woman of incredible energy. I'm not a guy of low energy myself, said Mr. Palley, but in Helen's presence all I can do is gape.

title: Market Place
description: The securities of Gulf and Western Industries fluctuated widely yesterday afternoon following word that the conglomerate's net income for the second quarter ended Jan. 31 would be off 20 to 25 percent from the yearearlier level.

title: Gas Industry Sees Weakness in Fuel Bill
description: The new natural gas bill, a top pipeline executive in Houston said yesterday, is like trying to cure a bullet wound with a BandAid. It may help things look a little healthier but underneath, the guy's still bleeding to death.

title: U.S. Has Given Private Lawyers $800,000 for Defending Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Department of Justice has paid private lawyers nearly $800,000 to represent present and former Government officials in civil suits stemming from Government surveillance activities and will ask for an additional $4.8 million to pay such legal fees next year, a Justice Department spokesman confirmed today.

title: Labor Double Bill
description: UNION MAIDS, a documentary film directed and Produced by Julia Reichert, James Klein and Miles Mogulescu; editors, Mr. Klein and Miss Reichert; directors of photography, Sherry Novick and Tony HerIza; distributed by New Day Films and Distribution Coop, Running time: 55 minutes.

title: 4 Held in Investigation Of False Insurance In Auto Registrations
description: In a special investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the state's Department of Motor Vehicles, four persons have been arersted for alregedly forging or using counterfeit documents to prove, in automobile registration, that the required insurance has been obtained.

title: SHORTAGE IN ENERGY HAS IDLED THOUSANDS
description: New York State's Labor Department estimated yesterday that 750,000 workers statewide had been forced from jobs because of recent cold and energy problems. It foresaw a potential new drain of more than $30 million a week from unemployment insurance funds if an expected 350,000 eligibles all put in claims.

title: Coalition for Democratic Majority Is Identified as AntiWarnke Group
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3A Washingtonbased group whose cochairman is an adviser of Senator Henry M. Jackson acknowledged today that it had prepared the anonymous memorandum being circulated on Capitol Hill in opposition to President Carter's nomination of Paul C. Warnke as arms control chief.

title: FRANK B. COOKSON
description: Prof Frank B. Cookson, 64 years old, who was the first dean of the School of Fine Arts of the University of Connecticut, died Wednesday at Windham Memorial Hospital in Willimantic.

title: Cause for Alarm in Peking
description: One of the most significant geopolitical developments of our time has so far gone unnoticed by leading shapers and analysts of international affairs, yet its implications for the peace and security of the world are hard to overestimate. The fact is that a whole generation of Europeans is growing up loathing China. And not for the reasons you might believe. To the European schoolchild, China doesn't mean a particular kind of social or economic system. It's simpler than that: China produces skullshattering alarm clocks and colored pencils that can't be sharpened.

title: Soybean Prices Up 13 Cents a Bushel, Best 10Day Rise
description: Marking the best rise in 10 days, soybean futures prices closed up 13 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Prices of other commodities futures traded on the exchange were also higher.

title: Steiner Wins at Ski Jump
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland. Feb. 3 (UPI)Walter Steiner of Switzerland won an international ski jump meet today, breaking the local record with his first jump, 341 feet 2 inches. This was Steiner's second victory in three meets on the Swiss circuit. Per Bergerud of Norway was second and Johna Saetre of Norway third.

title: Connecticut Insurance Post Filled
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 3The Connecticut State Senate today approved the nomination of T. F. Gilroy Baley as State Commissioner of Insurance after assurances that he would devote full time to the post.

title: Benin Raid an African Mystery
description: COTONOU, Benin, Feb. 2Shortly before 7 o'clock on the morning of Jan. 16 a plane with a blue tail whose markings were covered in white screeched to a bumpy landing at the drowsy airport here. Out jumped 80 to 100 men in battle gear, firing automatic weapons. Half were whites.

title: Tenneco Reports Record Results For the Fourth Quarter and Year
description: Tenneco Inc., one of the giant diversified industrial enterprises of the nation, whose profits have climbed sharply since 1970, yesterday again reported record results for the fourth quarter and all of 1976

title: Article 11  No Title
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mr. Carter, Mr. Warnke and the Atom
description: President Carter's choice of Paul Warnke as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and chief negotiator in the strategic arms limitation talks matches in caliber the best of his Cabinet appointments.

title: Woman, 83, Killed by Cold.
description: CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP)An 83yearold woman who refused to leave her sparsely heated home for an emergency shelter over the weekend has been found dead of exposure. The polies said that Edna Lamont was found yesterday by a minister who had gone to visit her. She was lying on a hallway floor bundled in several sweaters. The temperature in the house was 28 degrees.

title: SHORTAGE IN ENERGY HAS IDLED THOUSANDS
Gas Crisis Came Early to Texans And Lingers On
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 2It used to take only two hours for Ted Castillo to make enough money to pay his monthly home utility bill. Now it takes two days.

title: Article 1  No Title
CARTER FISCAL PLAN AND $50 TAX REBATES CRITICIZED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  Arthur F. Burns, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today he disagreed with the timing and size of President Carter's economic program and singled out for especially sharp criticism the plan to give rebates of $50 a person on 1976 taxes.

title: GEORGE F. MILLIKEN
description: George F. Milliken, a steamship industry executive, died yesteday at his home. He was 76 years old and lived at 12 Beekman Plaza.

title: Ski Areas, Unlike Buffalo, Welcome a New Snowfall
description: With snow falling on all of the Northeast ski country yesterday, prospects looked good enough to produce one of the season's top skiing weekend. Adding to the bright picture almost everywhere was a decline in wind velocity.

title: A Theater Event Called I
description: If it is difficult to describe I, the single character play being presented by the Theatre Laboratoire Vicinal of Belgium tonight and tomorrow night at the Guggenheim Museum, no one is more happy over that fact than Frdric Baal, the author, and Anne West, the Chicagoborn actress who plays the only role

title: Fire Charges Revived
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Trenton reinstated charges against a teenager accused of setting a fire that caused $100,000 damage to the Woodbridge Township Board of Education Building in 1975. The court overruled the Middlesex County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court, which had dismissed the charges on the ground that the state had failed to prosecute the case on the date it was originally scheduled for trial, June 2, 1975. The appeals court said the dismissal was clearly improper. The juvenile was identified only by his initials, G. M., in keeping with court rules for the protection of underage defendants.

title: U.S., USING NEW LAW, ORDERS EXTRA FLOW OF GAS TO THE EAST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3In the first use of the emergency powers signed into law last night by President. Carter, Richard L. Dunham, chairman of the Federal Power Commisison, signed an order today that will increase gas flowing froM The Southwest to New York City and other eastern markets.

title: Regine Crespin Lends Fire To Carmelites
description: REGINE CRESPIN is a soprano who likes to be convinced. When John Dexter, director of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Poulenc's, Dialogues of the Carmelites, which has its first performance Saturday afternoon, asked her to sing the heavy dramatic part of the First Prioress, she said thank you very much, but no. Her customary role in the opera, after all, was that of the more lyrical Second Prioress; Poulenc had even tailored the music specifically for her voice when he wrote the opera in 1956.

title: CARTER FISCAL PLAN AND $50 TAX REBATES CRITICIZED BY BURNS
City Ballet's Danish Pastry
Fires Cut Power in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 3 (AP)More than 10,000 persons in Kansas City were left without electricity for up to six hours yesterday when light rain touched off a rash of fires on dry, dusty utility poles. A spokesman for the Kansas City Power and Light Company said that the fires were on poles where dust and particles of salt used to melt snow had collected. The moisture allowed the electric current to bypass insulators clogged by dust and the current ignited the poles, he said.

title: Suit Seeks to Halt Moving of Displaced Poor to Cities
Bridge:
description: In a calendar year there are some 25 tournaments in the New York metropolitan area, generating perhaps 400 individual winners of major titles and an equal number of runnersup. But the competition is so fierce that it is relatively rare for an individual to have two successes in one weekend. A triple success is very rare indeed, although it is sometimes achieved by a player with a national reputation.

title: Boyle Reported Absolved By '74 Lie Detector Test
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP)A lie detector test after W. A. Boyle's first trial showed that he had not been involved in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski and his family, the man who administered the tests said today.

title: Port Authority Again Postpones A Decision on Concorde Service
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey postponed at least until midMarch its decision on whether to allow the Concorde supersonic airliner to operate to and from Kennedy International Airport.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Art People
description: CESAR PELLI is a gracious and dignified Argentine who until last month was living in Los Angeles earning a reputation as the creator of some of the West Coast's most refined architecture. As chief of design for the large firm of Gruen Associates, he built in California and elsewhere a series of sleek glass buildings that combined the suaveness of reflective glass with the toughness of industrial materials. The best known of them, perhaps, is the Pacific Design Center, a massive structure of blue, glass that rises out of the low buildings of West Hollywood. Los Angelenos, who are sharply divided as to its merits, call it the blue whale; most architects and critics find it one of the few pieces of serious recent architecture in Los Angeles.

title: LIFTING OF AUTO BAN PARALYZES BUFFALO
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 3Mayor Stanley Makowski, fearing this snowbound city would fall into a severe economic slump, lifted his twodayold ban on private driving early today, but reinstated it later after a transportation disaster, with private cars choking the snowdrifted streets as people tried to return to their jobs. many for the first time in a week.

title: POSSIBILITY IS RAISED OF U.S.CUBA MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The United States raised today the possibility of facetoface discussions with Cuba about the imperiled antihijacking agreement and other issues impeding normal relations.

title: Dow Falls Through Support Area As Economic Uncertainty Lingers
Manhattan Plaza Wins Approval As Housing for Performing Artists
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted last night to approve a controversial plan to use most of the troubled Manhattan Plaza apartment development near Times Square as housing for people in the performing arts. But in an unusual move, it made its approval contingent on a favorable report by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin regarding the city's effort to assure that the project's developers do not reap major profits.

title: Art: Photographs By Nadar
description: O NE OF THE GREAT portraitphotographers of all time was GaspardFelix Tournachon, better known as Nadar. In Paris in the second half of the 19th century Nadar went everywhere, knew everyone, and got many of the most remarkable men and women of the day to pose for him. He also did very well as novelist, cartoonist, autobiographer and pioneer balloonist.

title: Sales in January Surged For Major Retail Chains
Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Miss Massey Takes Lead By Shot in L.P.G.A. Event
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP)Deborah Massey of Bethlehem, Pa., held the lead by one stroke with a total of 225 after three rounds today in the Ladies Professional Golf Association qualifying tournament. Miss Massey shot a threeoverpar 75 on the 6,300yard Bent Tree Country Club course in the 72hole event.

title: Woodstock Colony: 75 Years in Art
description: ART COLONIES, those disreputable bastions of Bohemia that began in the 1890's to infiltrate our rural landscape, are a fascinating chaper in the history of American culture. Hotbeds of talk, theory and esthetic politics, they have attracted some of the best names, gone through the most interesting isms, andnot peripherallyspawned some of the most cheerful events in the annals of merrymaking.

title: STUART LONG DIES AT 63
description: AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 3Stuart Long, an Austin newsman for more than 40 years, died today. He was 63 years old.

title: Manhattan Westway Is Endorsed By New Trensportation Secretary
POLICE OF MONTREAL END THEIR SLOWDOWN
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 3Montreal's 5,200 policemen, under strong pressure from the Quebec provincial government and facing a threat of resignations by their union's leaders, ended their work slowdown today.

title: Commodity Price Index Increases 0.6 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 212.2 from 211.6 last week.

title: GEN. SALVATORE CASTAGNA
description: ROME, Feb. 3 (AP)Retired Gen. Salvatore Castagna, known as the hero of Giarabub, died yesterday in the Celio military hospital. He was 80. The resistance put up by his troops to British forces in a 1941 battle in World War II in the Libyan oasis of Giarabub became a legend and won him the praise of his enemies. After a 150day siege, the reduced forces were overpowered.

title: McCulley Joins Redskins
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 3 (AP)Pete McCulley, discharged by the Baltimore. Colts two weeks ago, was signed today by the Washington Redskins of the National Football League as receivers and conditioning coach. He replaces Dick Bielski, who took McCulley's job in Baltimore.

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS AS POUND SLIPS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 3 (UPI)The dollar closed generally higher in Europe today while the British pound dropped in the wake of another minimum lending rate cut. The price of gold was mixed.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Mr. Malik added that no thought that General Sutowo, who is in the United States now, would be able to say such debts have been incurred by Pertamina and today I am no longer an official of Pertamina.

title: British Nobility Turns Out for Traditional BlueBlooded Wedding
description: LONDON, Feb. 3The heir to the titles of the first Duke of Wellington and the wealth he gained from his conquest at Waterloo was married today to a brewery heiress who is also a greatgranddaughter of Kaiser Wilhelm II, the last German emperor.

title: Congress Gets Carter Plan to Revamp Government
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  President Carter's request for the power to reorganize the Government was sent to Capitol Hill today, the first step in what could become a lively contest between the White House and Congress.

title: Fishbein Plays Piano With Ease and Flair
description: Manuel de Falla's Fantasia Baetica is the composer's major work for piano, written for Arthur Rubinstein, yet it is rarely played. It turned up Thursday night in the slightly unorthodox program by Zenon Fishbein in Alice Tully Hall. It is a difficult piece, only partly for technical reasons. Its stylization of Spanish rhythms and melodies demands color and flexibility on the part of the pianist to keep the work from sounding longwinded.

title: Article 10  No Title
Front Page 1  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Stanford Names Charles
description: STANFORD, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP)Stanford named Russel Charles today to its football staff. Charles, an assistant at Georgia Tech and former U.C.L.A. running back, had served two years under Pepper Rodgers. Coach Bill Walsh said Charles would coach he junior varsity squad and assist the varsity on defense.

title: Kay Negotiates Purchase
description: The Kay Corporation announced that it had been negotiating with Merrill Lynch & Company whereby Kay might sell for cash its 50 percent investment in Metal Traders Inc. to Merrill Lynch, which owns the remaining 50 percent of Metal Traders, a metal trading concern. Kay is an international trading company with domestic retail jewelry subsidiaries.

title: The Chair Recognizes Senator Saul Bellow of Illinois
description: SUFFERN, N.Y.It is probably silly to complain that our Government has so little use for men and women of letters and of humane learning. The only such persons I can think of who have held something like high office in my time are Archibald MacLeish, under Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Charles Frankel, under Lyndon B. Johnson: noble emblems for the State Department but hardly makers of high policy.

title: Ambassador Seeks Asylum in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4 (UPI)Ethiopia's Ambassador to Japan, Ato Million Neqniq, left here to seek asylum in the United States on Jan. 15, Japanese foreign Ministry sources said today Abraha Ghilamichael, first secretary at the Ethiopian Embassy, said: Mr. Neqniq's departure was apparently unconnected with yesterday's coup attempt in Ethiopia.

title: Curter Considers Asking Congress For Funds to Buy Fuel for the Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Carter Administration is considering a request to Congress for emergency funds to pay fuel bills of poor families, especially those threatened with a cutoff of electricty, gas or oil for nonpayment.

title: Rdio Song Series Adapted to Pub
description: Turning a book on The American Popular Song into an eightweek nightclub series might seem to be an exercise in the obvious. Don't most nightclub singers draw their material largely from the repertory of American popular songs?

title: Emerging Portrait of Hua Indicates Shrewd, Cautious Man
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 4In the four months since Hua Kuofeng was elevated to the chairmanship of the Chinese Communist Party, an outpouring of information has begun to fill in his background, providing a portrait of a shrewd, cautious man with a knack for taking the correct political line and attracting powerful friends.

title: Partial Increase Is Urged in Con Ed Rates
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP)Two officers of the Public Service Commission recommended today that the state grant Consolidated Edison an electric rate increase of only about a fourth of the $249.8 million the company had requested.

title: Six Are Charged in Cyprus In Killing of U.S. Diplomat And a Secretary in 1974
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 4Cypriot authorities charged six men tonight with responsibility for the killing of the American Ambassador Rodger P. Davies and his secretary two and a half years ago. The suspects have been described as members of EOKA, a rightwing paramilitary organization that advocates the union of Cyprus with Greece.

title: End to Fire Unit Disputes Expected
description: Bowing to irate community members in Woodside, Queens, the city yesterday dropped plans to move the community's firerescue company to the firehouse occupied by residents of Northside, Brooklyn. City officials also said that they had an alternative proposal that should end the Northside dispute as well.

title: U.S. and Soviet Reported Trying To Perfect an AntiMissile Beam
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4American intelligence officials said today that both the Soviet Union and the United States were trying to develop highenergy beams of charged subatomic particles that would destroy incoming nuclear missiles.

title: Skeptical Congress Hears A Tax Rebate Will Work
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Despite some misgivings about the effectiveness of President Carter's plan for a oneshot tax rebate to stimulate the economy, many analysts still expect the measure to pass Congress so that checks, amounting to $200 for a family of four, would be in consumers pockets within the next two to three months.

title: Special Interests Donated $325,000 To Campaigns of 15 House Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Special interest groups representing business, industry and labor provided nearly twothirds of the money that 15 major House committee chairmen spent to win reelection last November.

title: Baltimore Man Guilty Of Jury Tampering
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 4A Federal Court jury here found Walter Weikers, 67 years old, of Baltimore, guilty today of jury tampering in the aborted trial of Gov, Marvin Mandel of Maryland. He faces a possible maximum penalty of five years in jail and/or a $5,000 fine.

title: Unexpected Trouble for Mrs. Gandhi
description: During the year and a half, until last month, that Prime Minister Gandhi stifled the democratic processes of India and imprisoned thousands of her opponents, her apologists and spokesmen offered one essential line of defense: Poor people don't need democracy. As one writer put it in a letter to this page last Nov. 12, It must be emphasized that the civil liberties that were curtailed were of relevance only to a small group. What is the value of freedom of dissent or of a free press to an illiterate farmer or a grossly underpaid teacher in an Indian village?

title: Poland Offers a Pardon To Some Price Rioters
description: WARSAW, Feb. 4 (AP)Poland's Communist Government announced today that it was granting a conditional pardon to all people convicted of rioting last June against food price increases if they show repentance and if the authorities had reason to hope they would not return to crime.

title: Victory Wears Two Faces at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4A pair of $57,000 Porsches, the kind unlikely to be towed away from city streets because they weren't built for city streets, are the cars no one figures to beat in the 24 Hours of Daytona auto race.

title: Three Men Die in Boston Fire
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Three persons died today in a threealarm fire that swept through an apartment building in Boston's Back Bay section. A Fire Department spokesman, Capt. John Collins, said that the dead persons were an unidentified man, woman and child, all apparently members of the same family.

title: W.C.T. Sues Borg and Colgate, Alleging a Breach of Contract
Article 4  No Title
description: NOW VOYAGER The world premiere of a work by David Diamond, the distinguished American composer, is an occasion, and tonight's concert at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hall also features another wellknown creative name, that of the late poet and critic, James Agee.

title: APPROVAL OF WARNKE DESCRIBED BY CARTER AS A CRUCIAL STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  President Carter said today that Senate confirmation of Paul C. Warnke as his chief armscontrol negotiator was crucial to his Administration.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT FRIDAY, Feb. 4. 1977. Petition flied by;

title: 3 Shut as Vice Places
description: New York City's Midtown Enforcement Project has ordered the closing of three midtown establishments alleged to be houses of prostitution. This civil action followed indictments obtained by Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau. The establishments are Erotica. 45 West 46th Street; Sunshine Massage Studio, 124 East 40th Street, and Galaxy 1, 127 East 47th Street.

title: Dance: City Ballet Goes Danish
description: What was it George Balanchine said, on rearrival in the Soviet Union, about classic dance? Someone said something about Leningrad being the home of classic dance, and Mr. Balanchine, gently remonstrating, replied that now New York was the home of classic dance. Certainly, the New York City Ballet is the purest classic company in he world and, by and large, the greatest company in the world.

title: Reorganization Petition Is Filed by Wiltek
description: Wiltek Inc., manufacturer of electronic communicationdata equipment, said it had filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter XI of the bankruptcy laws.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 40 Passengers Held on IND Train By 2 Gunmen as a 3d Man Robs 15
description: Two gunmen took over a northbound IND train last night and, during the sevenminute express ride between 59th and 125th Streets, held about 40 passengers captive as a third man walked through the cars demanding wallets and jewelry.

title: R. KENYON KILBON DIES
description: R. Kenyon Kilbon, former staff vice president for editorial services of RCA Corporation, died Wednesday at Hartford Hospital in Hartford. He was 60 years old.

title: Soviet Expels AP Reporter, Harasses Other Newsmen
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4The Soviet Foreign Ministry today ordered a correspondent of The Associated Press to leave the country within a week. It was the first expulsion of an American journalist in seven years, and it underscored the rising Government pressure directed against the Western press here in recent months.

title: RUMANIA ARCHBISHOP LOSES COUNCIL SEAT
description: The Orthodox Church in America yesterday in effect suspended Archbishop Valerian D. Trifa, one of its Bishops, who has been accused of Nazi war crimes, from the governing board of the National Council of Churches.

title: Paul Hebert, a Louisiana Law Dean
description: Paul M. Hebert, Dean of Louisiana State University's Law Center at Baton Rouge, died Thursday at a Baton Rouge Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: 50% Rise Is Expected in New York Metropolitan Home Heating Costs
Flames Top Bruins Amid Brawling, 63
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4 (AP)Rey Comeau scored two goals and assisted on another as the Atlanta Flames defeated the Boston Bruins, 63, in the only National Hockey League game played tonight.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA Washington patent lawyer was granted a patent this week for a pocketsize, nonlethal, electrical weapon. The invention, which has been named the Cobra, is about the size of a pack of cigarettes.

title: Soviet Drive on Critics Linked to Belgrade Meeting
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4Soviet authorities appear to have mounted a tough new campaign to try to muffle the small but increasingly vociferous dissident movement so that it will cause less embarrassment when the issue of human rights is discussed in the summer at an EastWest conference in Belgrade.

title: BEAME AIDES FOR END OF RUNOFF IN PRIMARY
description: Reversing their position of four years ago, top advisers of Mayor Beame agreed yesterday to the elimination of a runoff mayoral primary, thus making it virtually certain there would be only one primary for the mayoral, City Council President and Comptroller nominations in New York City this year.

title: Designs Crafted in Gold, For Those Who Prefer Simplicity in Jewelry
description: There's a tiny shop on Madison Avenue devoted to the simple 18karat gold jewelry that Jean Dinh Van designs. His rings, bracelets, earrings and chains are the kind of ornaments that, like a woman's wedding band or a man's signet ring, are almost never taken off.

title: New York Plan On Minority Jobs Backed at Hearing
Racal Again Raises Its Offer For Shares of Milgo Electronic
description: Racal Electronics of Britain again raised its cash bid yesterday for all shares of the Milgo Electronic Corporation to $35 a share in a bidding duel with Applied Digital Data Systems.

title: Kialoa Finishes First in 400Mile Sail Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 4Jim Kilroy's ketch, Kialoa, was the first yacht to finish the 17th annual St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale race. She came in at 4:04 this morning with an elapsed time for the 400mile trip of 42 hours 4 minutes, a record.

title: American in Kenya Stalks Tourist to Help Animals
description: AMBOSELLI, KenyaEvery morning as the small number of scientists working here leave their campsites to follow and observe elephants, baboons and lions, a young American named Wes Henry sets off in pursuit of one of the Amboselli game park's most prevalent speciesthe tourist.

title: Union Wins at Princeton
description: Library assistants at Princeton voted in favor of representation by the Princeton University Library Assistanits Association, affialiated with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The vote was 103 to 83. The election, supervised by the National Labor Relations Board, established the first whitecollar union in. the university's history, and made Princeton's library the 13th major university library in the country to unionize. An election in September 1975 ended in defeat for the union, 97 to 72.

title: 12 Dead, 160 Hurt in Crash on Chicago Elevated
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4An elevated train crowded with homewardbound passengers bounced off the back of a train ahead of it late this afternoon at one of the busiest intersections in Chicago's Loop, hurling two of its first four cars to the street about 20 feet below and leaving two others dangling from the tracks.

title: Columbia Routs Dartmouth for 50 Ivy Record
Execution by Injection Weighed
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 4 (AP)Faced with a $62,000 repair bill on its electric chair, the State of Oklahoma is considering a measure that would make it the only state in the country to execute condemned criminals by injection of drugs.

title: LAWYER'S INDICTMENT DISMISSED BY COURT
description: Justice Leon B. Po'sky of New York State Supreme Court yesterday dismissed the indictment of Kenneth Kase, a lawyer charged with bribery in the liquorlicense case that accidentally opened the door to the investigation of Patrick J. Cunningham. the Bronx Democratic leader.

title: Gil Dodds, Miler, Dies
description: The Rev. Gilbert (Gil) Dodds, America's leading onemile runner in the 1940's, and a Sullivan Award winner in 1943, died yesterday in St. Charles, Ill. His obituary appears on Page 22.

title: 14 Dead, 163 Hurt in Crash on Chicago Elevated
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4An elevated train crowded with homewardbound passengers bounced off the back of a train ahead of it late this afternoon at one of the busiest intersections in Chicago's Loop, hurling two of its first four cars to the street about 20 feet below and leaving two others dangling from the tracks.

title: Buffalo Snow Amazes Chip Carter, But He Makes No Promises of Aid
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 4President Carter's 26yearold son, James Earl (Chip), toured this severely winterstruck area today, expressing some amazement at what he saw, but offering no promise of the steppedup Federal aid for which local officials have been pressing with increasing intensity.

title: The Zone Defense Against Smut
description: New York's new smutdispersal zoning is a thoughtful, conscientious, progressive and somewhat risky legal step that already has opponents preparing for attack. It straddles the difficult issues of free speech and landuse regulation, and can be argued either way. The courts will have to decide who is the injured partythe purveyor of profitable porn, trafficking in filth with First Amendment protection, or a neighborhood being destroyed economically, socially and environmentally by the offensive use of land on a concentrated scale.

title: Electrical Weapon Patented
description: A patent has been granted for a pocketsize, nonlethal, electrical weapon that could be used for purposes of selfdefense. Page 27.

title: Township Schools Stoned In Cape Town Area
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 4 (UPI)Groups of blacks stoned schools and chased pupils from their classrooms today in a second day of unrest in black townships outside Cape Town.

title: L.I. Man Wins $980,000 in Lottery
description: A 32yearold Long Island foodservice employee yesterday won what was billed as the largest lump sum ever given away to one person in United States history$980,000.

title: Qualms About the House's Assassination Investigation
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.That new House investigation into assassinations was almost certain to fail, even if the reestablished Select Committee on Assassinations had been given the $13 million and the twoyear life span it had sought. But this week, a skeptical Congress gave it only until March 31 and $84,000 a month with which to prove that it had a reason to exist.

title: Victor in Leadership's Gun Battle Urges Arming of Ethiopian People
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 4 (Reuters)The colonel who emerged as the victor from yesterday's gun battle among the nation's military leaders called today for the arming of the people to, protect Ethiopia's 28monthold Socialist revolution.

title: Letters: On Westway
description: Stop the Protests and the Lawsuits

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1977

title: Books of The Times
Real, Honest Chocolate for That Quintessential Valentine Gift
description: Along with hearts and flowers, cupids and lace, chocolates are among the more important appurtenances of the Valentine's Day celebration. Each year around Feb. 14, tons of chocolate candy are bought for gifts, and the holiday does, in fact, usher in what can be considered the chocolate season, which runs through Easter, with its candy rabbits, chicks and eggs, and ends on Mother's Day, when chocolate is once more the favored gift.

title: Swine Flu Program Brings $10.7 Million in Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The swine flu immunization program has already resulted in 104 damage claims against the Federal Government, totaling nearly $11 million, according to a compilation by the Justice Department.

title: OPEC Throws a Gala in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Feb. 4The Iranians didn't talk much to the Saudis, but the oil cartel's big bash was nevertheless one of the best parties this city has seen lately.

title: Tax Form Stumps Commuters
