description: The New Jersey Taxation Division, which has been receiving 1,000 calls a day with questions concerning the state's new income tax, conceded yesterday that unclear instructions on its tax forms could lead to payment of a higher tax than necessary by New Jerseyans who work in New York.

title: Seoul's Envoy to U.S. To Be Replaced Soon
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Feb. 5 (AP)South Korea's Ambasador to the United States, Hahm Pyong Choon, will be replaced soon in a diplomatic shuffle involving embassies in more than a dozen countries, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: About New York
description: Thomas E. Dewey Thruway is a gray road as familiar to politicians as it is to intercity bus drivers. They plod it to Albany like a legion of Willy Lomans working the notionsselling route, their VIP license plates and bumper medallions standing out like so many sample cases.

title: Tanzania and Kenya Are in Conflict After 3Nation Airline Collapses
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 4 (UPI)Tanzania closed at least one border post with Kenya today and began seizing Kenyan aircraft and vehicles.

title: Notes on People
description: It was perhaps inevitable. Bantam Books is rushing into print with a quickie volume called Redneck Power: The Wit and Wisdom of Billy Carter, which will go on sale Feb. 15. The editors, Jeremy Rifkin and Ted Howard, have culled newspapers and television tapes for their material and offer Mr. Carter saying things like I don't even know what a redneck is. On his brother, President Carter's, drinking habits Billy Carter is quoted: Jimmy used. to drink liquor. Now he's running for President and he drinks Scotch, and I've never trusted a Scotch drinker.

title: No Rise in Postal Rates Is Expected This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)  Now that it has experienced a rare $36.3 million surplus in a period of less than two months, the Postal Service has decided against raising postal rates this year.

title: Pacific Southwest To Purchase Aircraft
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines, a unit of PSA Inc., said it had completed arrangements for the purchase of five used Boeing 727100 aircraft and two new Boeing 727200 aircraft for $44 million.

title: Legal Move by 11 New York Banks Compounds City's Fiscal Problem
VW Sets 1978 Startup
description: Volkswagenwerk AG said it expected to begin assembly at its Westmoreland, Pa., plant in April 1978.

title: For Those Interested In Manhattan Plaza
description: Manhattan Plaza is hoping to have its first tenants move in on April 1. Those interested in viewing model apartments are asked to write for an appointment to Manhattan Plaza, Post Office Box 386, Times Square Station, New York, N.Y. 10036. About 3,000 applicants have filled out forms thus far for the 1.700 apartments.

title: William S. Rose Jr. Weds Victoria Gage
description: Victoria Ellen Gage, daughter of Alan Kenneth Gage of New York and the late Elaine Tepper Gage, was married yesterday afternoon to William Stuart Rose Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rose, also of New York.

title: Korean Lobbyist Fought to Hide Document Naming 70 Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A document suggesting that Park Tong Sun, a central figure in the Korean bribery scandal here, was seeking to influence a wider range of Washington officials than previously reported was made public in Louisiana today.

title: THE OBSERVER OF LONDON MAY ADD NEW SECTIONS
description: The Observer, the 186yearold British Sunday newspaper, may introduce living or entertainment sections similar to those that have been initiated by American newspapers over the past few years, the new president of the Londonbased newspaper said yesterday.

title: SHIPPING AND MAILS
description: OUTGOING

title: Cuba Is Seeking Talks on Fishing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Cuba has notified the United States that it wants to discuss the new American law establishing a 200mile fishing zone off this country's coast, the State Department said today.

title: Sign of Changing Times: Men Are Teaching Kindergarten
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  When Richard Pappa began teaching kindergarten, he would tell colleagues at Rutgers University, where he is working for a doctorate, that he taught fifth grade. It was easier that way, considering the reaction of most people to a male kindergarten teacher.

title: Article 9  No Title
Link to Turnpike Is Set
description: Construction on the final link of Interstate Route 280 in Hudson County from Harrison to the New Jersey Turnpike is to begin this spring, the State Transportation Department said.

title: Logic Of Freedom
description: ROMEOne important argument for strengthening NATO is rarely used and is also difficult for most people to understand because it is so complex. Simply stated, it is that those Western Communist movements known collectively as Eurocommunism, which has gained great influence in Italy, has considerable potential in Spain, and is stirring in France, would rapidly lose their independence of Moscow if the equilibrium of strategic power tilted.

title: Treasury Bonds Sold at 7.63% Rate
MARIO SILVESTRI
description: The Rev. Mario Silvestri, pastor of Our Lady of Charity Church, Brooklyn, until March 1969, died Tuesday in Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream, L.I., after a short illness. He was 64 years old.

title: La Salle Expedition Is Encumbered by Civilization
description: NAPLES, Ill., Feb. 3A cutting wind was lacing snow into their iceencrusted beards this afternoon as members of the La Salle Expedition II slogged through kneedeep drifts along the frozen waters of the Illinois River.

title: Suit Attacks Feldman
description: A Republican Councilman from Wyckoff sued in Superior Court in Hackensack for dismissal of Senator Matthew Feldman as president of the Senate because of his guilty plea last November to a Federal indictment charging commercial bribery in connection with his private liquor business. The counailman, Henry P. McNamara, contended that Mr. Feldman's offense involved moral turpitude. Mr. McNamara noted that the Democratcontrolled Senate had held that Mr. Feldman's crime did not involve moral turpitude, and Mr. McNamara asked the court to rule otherwise. Mr. Feldman was ordered to reply on Feb. 16.

title: One Rhodesia Rebel Group Will Receive O.A.U. Aid: Other 2 Still Recognized
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 4 (UPI)The Liberation Committee of the Organization of African Unity announced today its support for the Patriotic Front, the most militant of three black nationalist movements fighting the white minority government in Rhodesia.

title: PHILIPS. VINE
description: Philip S. Vine, a former county judge, died Thursday at the Mercer Medical Cen ter in Trenton. He was 82 years old and a resident of Trenton.

title: Of Moose and Men
description: Every year the same old routine. Winter would rise from the Arctic ice. tour down through Canada, then swing east along the same old route: North Dakota, Minneapolis, Chicago, Lake Erie, Albany, Boston.

title: The Woman Who Sends Vital Inside Information To the World's Oil Giants
description: Wanda Jablonski may know more about the people who have oil and the people who want it than just about anybody In the world.

title: Barry Altschul Leads Quartet
description: Barry Altschul, a topnotch jazz drummer who has been a regular member of groups led by Sam Rivers and Anthony Braxton, adapts to the styles Of the musicians he plays with as easily as a chameleon changing colors. He, brings his fertile imagination, concem for dynamics and unmatched feeling for percussive color to each situation, but with Mr. Braxton he often goes in for restrained shadings, while with Mr. Rivers he punches out furious avalanches of sound to drive the saxophonist's marathon solos.

title: Sotheby Sells Oriental Rug For $200,000
description: An Oriental rug that was used to cover a pool table in a West Virginia home set a new world record for rugs, at an auction yesterday when it Was sold at Sotheby Parke Bernet in Manhattan for $200,000.

title: SUPERIOR OIL LEAPS 16 POINTS IN A SURGE OF ENERGY STOCKS
Jail Opposed for Growing Marijuana on Small Scale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Americans should not be jailed for growing small amounts of marijuana at home for their own use, Dr. Robert L. DuPont, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, suggested today.

title: Scarcity of Horses Troubles Aqueduct
Eskimos Sign Campell
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Feb. 4 (AP)Hugh Campbell, head football coach at Whitworth College in Spokane, Wash., since 1970, was named head coach today of the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League.

title: Giscard and Schmidt Hint Continued Nuclear Export
description: PARIS, Feb. 4Reacting to complaints of the Carter Administration about their plans for nuclear exports, France and West Germany today indicated intentions to continue selling nuclear technology to other countries for peaceful purposes.

title: Israel and Soviet Meet at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 4The chief delegates of the Soviet Union and Israel have had an unusual private meeting on the Middle East but once again disagreed on the question of participation by the Palestine Liberation Organization in a future Geneva conference.

title: Personal Investing
description: When Norway came to market with $150 million of fiveyear notes on Thursday, it was one more sign that the socalled Yankee bond market is one of the hottest growth items on Wall Street.

title: A Move for Office Workers Shakes Ford Country
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 4When the Ford Motor Company announced last week that it was moving some 1,700 office employees from their quiet suburban quarters here to the new Renaissance Center on the banks of the Detroit River in downtown Detroit, it shook the walls of Ford Country.

title: Sheeran Makes Plea On Crime Insurance
description: The state's Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, urged a Senate committee in Washington to retain the Federal crimeinsurance program. The program, which is due to expire April 30, provides a service to city dwellers that cannot be obtained on the open market, Mr. Sheeran said.

title: 50 Percent Increase Is Expected In Heating Costs for Homeowners
description: New York Metropolitan area homeowners who budgeted for this winter's fuel bills based on what they spent last year will find themselves over budget by about 50 percent, unless they take conservation measures or the winter suddenly and unexpectedly warms up.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1977

title: S.I. Inmate Disturbance
description: A melee that lasted about 15 minutes broke out last night at the Arthur Kill Rehabilitation Facility in the Tottenville section of Staten Island, the police reported. One inmate, 35yearold John Stubbs, was treated for head lacerations when correction officers restored order in a groundfloor recreation area. According to the police, about 50 inmates were involved in the disturbance, which may have begun with a religious argument between black Muslins and other prisoners.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE SHOWS A SHARP DROP TO 7.3% FOR JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The nation's unemployment rate in January declined by a substantial amount, half of a percentage point, to 7.3 percent of the work force but the size of improvement may be illusory, Government experts said today.

title: When Does a Mall Pall?
description: It's hard to keep a bad idea down. The proposal for a Broadway Mall keeps popping up with relentless regularity. It is the kind of dated window dressing that boosters embrace, and someone seems to love at City Hall.

title: Man Convicted in Killing
description: A Farmingdale man has been convicted of raping and murdering a Kean College student about a month before she was to have been married last year.

title: 10 More Developing Nations Get.$33.8 Million OPEC Loans
Diamond Puts Dance on Skis
description: After Matthew Diamond put two of his dancers on roller skates, it wasn't surprising that he followed this up with a duet on skis Thursday night at the American Theater Lab, 219. West 19th Street. Like many young choreographers, Mr. Diamond shares in the irreverence of his generation. Modern dance does not have to be solemn, they seem to say, and humor can be outrageous if it works.

title: Ibsen's The League of Youth, Rarely Done, Has a Revival
description: Ibsen's littleknown play The League of Youth has been revived as Lazarus was revived: altered and grisly.

title: Prices of Futures In Farm Goods Up After Early Drop
description: Farm commodity futures, after dropping most of the day, closed higher yesterday as a result of new buying in the closing minutes on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: The Nets That Might Have Been
La Salle Expedition Is Encumbered by Civilization
Legislators Get Opposing Opinions On Proposed Divorce Law Change
description: A group of New York State legislators received conflicting advice yesterday from witnesses at a hearing on how to amend a proposed divorce bill that is intended to be fairer to both husbands and wives.

title: Czechoslovak Dissidents Report 208 More Sign Human Rights Manifesto
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Human rights activists made their first move tonightin apparent defiance of Czechoslovak authoritiessince their main spokesmen were warned on Monday that the manifesto Charter 77 on human and civil rights was illegal.

title: Article 6  No Title
L.I. Man Wins $980,000 in Lottery
description: A 32yearold Long Island foodservice employee yesterday won what was billed as the largest lump sum ever given away to one person in United States history$980,000.

title: In Restrictive Singapore, Gambling Serves as Safety Valve
description: SINGAPOREIn a dimly lit coffee shop two Chinese sit motionless, staring into their coffee cups. Ten Minutes pass, 15, 20. Suddenly they look up and one smiles thinly. The other passes a $10 bill across the narrow table.

title: Egypt and Syria Announce United Political Command
description: CAIRO, Feb 4 (Reuters)Egypt and Syria, the two biggest military powers in the Arab world, today announced formation of a unified political command, setting the seal on accommodation after more than a year of antagonism.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1977

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE SHOWS A SHARP DROP TO 7.3% FOR JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 4The nation's unemployment rate in January declined by a substantial amount half of a percentage point, to 7.3 percent of the work force but the improvement may be illusory, Government experts said today.

title: Mamet Wins With Life in Theater
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4David Mamet's A Life in the Theater is comedy about the artifice of acting. In a swift 75 minutes, the author spoofs actors insecurities, pretensions and illusions  the ironies and the ignominies of the profession. The author was once an actor and he makes his actors enormously vulnerable people. His attitude is wry and affectionate.

title: Coke Plant in Kentucky Is Blacklisted by E.P.A.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4. (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has, put a coke producing plant in northeastern Kentucky on a blacklist that prevents the plant from obtaining Federal contracts.

title: Commercial Discovery Of Australian Diamonds
description: Australia's first discovery of diamonds in commercial quantities has been made in a remote part of Western Australia by a consortium headed by Conzinc Rio Tinto of Australia Ltd.

title: Tickner Wins Figure Skating Title
description: HARTFORD, Feb, 4Success finally found Charles Tickner tonight at the United States figure skating championships.

title: Groh Seeking to Regain Spot at the Top in Golf
Texstar Receives An Offer From Avnet
description: The Texstar Corporation said It had received an offer from Avnet Inc., an electronics company, for all the assets subject to all liabilities of Texstar for $34 million cash, which is estimated to come to $8.50 a share. Texstar common was last traded on the American Stock Exchange at 6.

title: CORRECTION
description: Frederick Van Vranken was incorrectly identified in The Times yesterday. He is chief operating officer of the SoGenSwiss International Corporation.

title: Senate Approves A Plan to Revamp Committee Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Senate approved today a plan to reorganize its committee structure that was heavily altered by intensive lobbying and defenses of senatorial prerogatives but that nonetheless wrought substantial changes.

title: Resumption of Flu Shots Considered by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)Under pressure from the first outbreak of AVictoria flu this year, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A Califano Jr., asked medical and scientific experts today to advise him whether to resume the nationwide influenza vaccination program.

title: Senate Approves A Plan to Revamp Committee Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Senate approved today a plan to reorganize its committee structure that was heavily altered by intensive lobbying and defenses of senatorial prerogatives but that nonetheless wrought substantial changes.

title: Pressure Is Mounting to Lift Ban On Gas Drilling Under Lake Erie
description: BUFFALO  In Chautauqua County, which borders Lake Erie to the south of here, the National Fuel Gas Company, together with some small exploration companies, has drilled hundreds of wells and is producing millions of cubic feet of natural gas each year.

title: Fitzsimmons's Son Accused of Misuse Of Teamster Funds
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 (UPI)Richard Fitzsimmons, eldest son of the teamsters union president, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, was indicted along with two other men today on charges of embezzling union severance pay funds to purchase personal insurance policies.

title: Rabin Holds Secret Talks On MideastPeaceEfforts With Ivory Coast Leader
description: TEL AVIV, Feb, 4Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin flew secretly to Geneva today and held a threehour meeting with President Felix HouphoutBoigny of the Ivory Coast.

title: Garage Talks Continue
description: Negotiators for the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade and 3,000 employees represented by Local 272 of the Teamsters met yesterday in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract. The current pact expires tonight. The union is seeking higher pay and other contract improvements. Seymour P. Gline, president of the board, which represents 600 garages in Manhattan and the Bronx, said the base pay of the employees was $168.50 a week plus fringe benefits. James McFadden, is serving as a mediator in the dispute.

title: State Buys Byrne's Car
description: The state has purchased the luxury car it rented for Governor Byrne and has leased a new one for him. Both autos will be for the Governor's use.

title: Byrne Campaigns on Train, Sharing Aisles With 9 Rivals
description: ABOARD THE JERSEY CONGRESSIONAL, Feb. 4  Governor Byrne walked the length of this 14car train yesterday and shook every hand he could reach, although he has not yet announced whether he will seek a second term this year. He passed Joseph A. Hoffman, his former campaign chairman, who has already announced his candidacy for Mr. Byrne's job. You're the first candidate I've seen, Mr. Byrne said.

title: Bally Agrees in Principle to Add World JaiAlai Inc. for $66 Million
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company, the world's largest manufacturer of slot machines, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire World JaiAlai Inc. for 1.4 million shares of its common stock valued at $66 million.

title: Article 3  No Title
Babcock Gets Award
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company announced receipt of a contract for about $20 million from the Toledo Edison Company and the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company for the fabrication of reload nuclear fuel assemblies for the DavisBesse nuclear power station at Port Clinton, Ohio.

title: Hoffman Conducts Jerseyans
Lifting of Traffic Ban Clogs Watertown Area Roads
description: WATERTOWN, Feb. 4Officials of Watertown and Jefferson County temporarily ended their ban on vehicular traffic in this snowravaged western New York region today, and scores of motorists promptly slid and skidded onto partly cleared roadways on expeditions to restock dwindling supplies of food.

title: Hershey Increases Cocoa Price 46%
description: An increase of 46 percent in the wholesale price of its one pound cans of cocoa, effective Jan. 31, was announced yesterday by the Hershey Foods Corporation.

title: U.S. and Soviet Reported Trying To Perfect an AntiMissile Beam
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4American intelligence officials said today that both the Soviet Union and the United States were trying to develop highenergy beams of charged subatomic particles that would destroy incoming nuclear missiles.

title: OPPOSITION MOUNTING TO SALE OF B.P. STOCK
description: LONDON, Feb, 4 (Reuters)The Labor Government is under pressure from a small group of ministers to think again about its plan to sell nearly $1.2 billion worth of shares in the British Petroleum Company.

title: Bridge
description: When New York's first blue ribbon individual championship begins at 1:30 P.M. today at the Manhattan Club, 228 West 71st Street, the 36 contestants, selected on the basis of past performance, and the numerous kibitzers are due for some surprises: boxes, a barometer and a menu.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Carter to Declare 9 Upstate Counties Disaster Area
description: President Carter has decided to declare nine snowbattered counties in upstate New Yorkone of them includes the beleaguered city of Buffaloas a major disaster area, Representative Henry J. Nowak, Democrat of Buffalo, said late last night.

title: Geologist Reported in Line to Head Cornell
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 4Frank H. T. Rhodes, vice president for academic affairs at the University of Michigan, is apparently in line to become the next president of Cornell University.

title: Top Advisers to Beame Support Elimination of Primary Runoff
description: Reversing their position of four years ago, top advisers of Mayor Beame agreed yesterday to the elimination of a runoff mayoral primary, thus making it virtually certain there would be only one primary for the mayoral, City Council President and comptroller nominations in New York City this year.

title: JERSEY EASES ACCESS TO ADOPTION RECORDS
Article 7  No Title
Article 5  No Title
Woman Gets 3 Years In Fraud Involving U.N.
description: Anne Lamont of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who was convicted of defrauding a businessman and a bank of $260,000, was sentenced to three years in prison yesterday. Judge Edmund L. Palmieri, who sentenced her in Federal District Court in Manhattan, also fined the 49yearold defendant $1,000 on each of seven counts.

title: 4 Other Crashes Killed Chicago Transit Riders
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (UPI)  In 40 years, the Chicago street and elevated railways had had four crashes in which passengers were killed before last night's wreck.

title: Goldin Acts to Bar Windfall Profits For Developers of Manhattan Plaza
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, said yesterday that he planned to employ an outside specialist to assure that the developers of the Manhattan Plaza apartment project did not make windfall profits from an unusual renting program approved conditionally by the Board of Estimate.

title: ABC Plans a Roots Sequel in Fall
description: ABCTV may offer a sequel next fall to the phenomenally successful television adaptation of the Alex Haley novel Roots, but probably will not repeat the original 12hour serial until the fall of next year, according to officials of the network.

title: Rep. Hinshaw Sentenced to a Year
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP)&Former Representative Andrew J. Hinshaw was sentenced today to one year in the Orange County Jail for misappropriation of tax funds while he served as county assessor. Mr. Hinshaw, 52 years old, is free pending appeal of a 1to14year state prison sentence on a bribery conviction of January 1976.

title: Man Denies Guilt in Fatal Fire
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 4 (AP)A 23yearold Holyoke man pleaded not guilty today to murder and arson charges brought after a threealarm apartmenthouse fire on Jan. 25 left one person dead and 60 others homeless. The man, Wilfredo Arturet, was ordered held on $50,000 bail by District Court Judge Michael Donohue, who continued the case to Feb. 11.

title: Article 1  No Title
Young Rests From Diplomatic Trip As Tanzania Celebrates Unity
APPROVAL OF WARNKE DESCRIBED BY CARTER AS A CRUCIAL STEP.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  President Carter said today that Senate confirmation of Paul C. Warnke as his chief armscontrol negotiator was crucial to his Administration.

title: U.S. Names Envoy to Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (Reuters)President Carter today named Richard B. Parker, presently Ambassador to Algeria, as Ambassador to Lebanon. Mr. Parker has served in dipomatic posts in several Arab countries and also in Israel. He is to succeed Francis E. Meloy Jr., who was abducted and murdered last year during a car trip through a noman's area of Beirut during the civil war there.

title: Majors and Douds Receive Coaching Awards for 1976
description: Johnny Majors, who produced the nation's No. 1 college football team at Pittsburgh in 1976 and then moved on to become head coach at Tennessee last month, received the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award last night as the Eastern University Division coach of the year.

title: Thermostats at 65, but Heat in Capital Varies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Try as they may, engineers tinkering with thermostats and bypassing steam pipes in the 160 Federal buildings in and around the capital are discovering limitations on their ability to achieve President Carter's happy medium, the cooler office.

title: Lockheed Chairman Says Review Found No Improper Fees
Part Time and Outside Work Allowed for Broker Salesmen
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would permit brokerage house salesmen to work part time and in activities other than the securities business. Up to now salesmen were required by Big Board rules to be engaged solely in the industry.

title: Gold on Capital Dome Is Sacrificed to Snow
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 4 (AP)The Capitol dome will do without its $164,000 coating of gold, but snowedin Preston County will get a $95,000 snow blower, Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th announced today. He said he thought the snow blower represented a much better sense of priorities.

title: G.M. PLANT IN LORDSTOWN WILL BE CLOSED 5TH WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4The General Motors Corporation announced today that its Lordstown, Ohio, plant would be closed for the fifth straight week beginning Monday. The 2,450 workers there have been idle since Jan. 7 because of slumping small car sales. The plant makes Chevrolet Vega and Pontiac Astre cars, on which General Motors is offering $200 rebates to spur sales.

title: Italy, Needing a Loan, Enacts Curbs
Gil Dodds, Former Mile RecordHolder, Dead at 58.
description: The Rev. Gilbert L. (Gil) Dodds, a former world indoor recordholder in the onemile run, considered the best American miler of his time, died Thursday night at Delnor Hospital in St. Charles, Ill. of a brain tumor. He was 58 years old.

title: Rhodesia Bids Botswana Let Parents Visit Students
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb 4 (Reuters) Rhodesia today sought permission from the Botswana Government to take 150 black parents across the border to meet their children, who the Rhodesian Government says, were abducted to Botswana at gunpoint.

title: Pound Gains Fractionally Against Erratic Dollar
description: LONDON Feb. 4 (AP)The pound gained fractionally against the dollar today, closing at $1.7145, compared with yesterday's $1.7133. The price of gold was mixed.

title: I Dead in R.I. Plane Crash
description: SMITHFIELD, R.I., Feb. 4 (AP)One man was killed and another was seriously injured when a light plane crashed in a field near North Central Airport here about noon today, the police said. Initial reports said the plane, a singleengine Cessna, hit a shed about onehalf mile from a landing strip after making a lowaltitude pass over the airport.

title: Pollution Charge Denied
description: Pollution Charge Denied

title: Sauerbraten, Country Style
description: BECAUSE SO MANY restaurants one comes across are wildly expensive and dully pretentious, it is doubly rewarding to find one that is moderately priced, honestly simple and solidly good, if notgreat. Add to that an air of informality that permits one to be comfortable withchildren in tow, or when wearing the most casual clothing, and that restaurant seems almost a miracle, which brings us to the old red barn that is The country Tavern in the Long Ridge section of Stamford.

title: Queen's Jubilee
description: The celebration of the 25th year of the accession to the throne of Great Britain of Queen Elizabeth II, who became monarch on the morning of this same day in 1952 upon the death of her father, King George VI, combines on stamps an obeisance to the pomp and tradition of centuries with an innovative approach and an original concept of design, theme and interpretation. The Queen's Silver Jubilee issue is indeed the crowning philatelic event of the year.

title: A Seville for Iran
description: Who's a more likely customer for a Cadillac than one who has oil? With this in mind, doubtless, General MotorsIran is bringing in parts to assemble the Cadillac Seville at a plant nine miles from Teheran. The cars, to be available in March, will be the first Cadillacs built outside the United States.

title: Music in Review
Kilimanjaro Glider Attempt
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Main Guillou, a 28yearold Parisian glider manufacturer, hopes to achieve a first next week with a successful flight from the top of Mount Kilimanjaro on a hang glider. Two previous attempts to glide off the 19,000foot mountain in Tanzania ended in failure.

title: TEAM BEGINS WRITING ARIZONA CRIME SERIES
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 5On an upper floor Of the Adams Hotel in downtown Phoenix, an unusual group of journalists, after four months of research, have begun writing a series of articles that they say will expose a deep penetration by organized crime in Arizona.

title: GAS SHORTAGE CUTS OUTPUT OF FERTILIZER
There's No Freeze On Learning
description: GARDENERS can take heart. There will be a spring again some time. On that chance and to brighten the long winter wait for the first crocus, how about going to school? All sorts of topics are aVallaDle ana classes are held at botanic gardens, local colleges and high schools. Courses are open to the public and no prior knowledge is required.

title: The EnvironmentIt's Cleaner
description: NEW JERSEY has been enjoying some success in its effort to clean up the state's environment. Some of the developments are smalla State House postman collects old paper at the capitol, sells it and donates the proceeds to his sister's churchand some of them are big, such as the state system of inspecting exhaust from automobiles, which has greatly reduced the carbon monoxide in the air.

title: Mr. Carter's Jawbone
description: WHILE the nation's attention continued to be fastened last week on the impact of the worst weather conditions in this century and on the course of the Administration's economicstimulus package, there was a new element entering the picture that has escaped much attention

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Events Today
description: WINTER ICE CARNIVAL: Trophies to be awarded for ice skating races and for original and funny coslumes; noon, Van Cortlandt Park Lake, east of Broadway and West 242d Street, the Bronx.

title: Bring back elitist universities
description: Higher education appears to be entering a period of uncertainty in the United States, and, it may well be a crucial time for undergraduate education in the liberal arts. Enrollments at liberalarts colleges are said everywhere to be down, and are not expected soon again to rise. Much talk now fills the air about undergraduate curriculum, so long out on a binge, regaining respectability: returning to fundamentals, resurrecting standards, reestablishing intellectual seriousness. But how much of this, one wonders, is merely talkand not very plain talk at that? What, moreover, would plain talk about the reform of undergraduate education sound like?

title: Marriage Announcement 14  No Title
description: Judith Beck, Teacher, And Richard Busis Plan June Wedding

title: Poet Laureate's Tribute Fit for a Queen
A.A.U. Picks Team of 12 For Swim Meet in Paris
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (UPI)Twelve swimmers, including a United States Olympian veteran, Kim Peyton of Portland, Ore., will compete in a meet Friday through next Sunday at Paris.

title: Kaunda Calls on Carter To Lead on Africa
description: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Feb. 5 (UPI)President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia called on President Carter today to take the lead in finding a peaceful solution for southern Africa and said black Africa had a lot of confidence in the new Carter Administration.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Margaret B. Lovely, 76, Dies; Director of Brooklyn Charities

title: Flyers 7, Maple Leafs 5
description: TORONTO, Feb. 5 (AP)Reg Leach, with his second goal, and Tom Bladon scored unassisted 57 seconds apart late in the third period and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 75 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the N.H.L.

title: Winter's Flowers Promise Spring
Dawns &
description: By Louise Nevelson. Taped Conversations with Diana MacKown. Illustrated. 190 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95.

title: Coaching Executives on Stage Presence
description: With the spring season of shareholder meetings barely three months away, Roger E. Ailes, Richard M. Nixon's 1968 televisioncampaign director, expects to profit. Some chief executives feel so rattled at the prospect of facing the owners that they will hire him to loosen them up a bit, to do more than just get through this year's ritual.

title: 2 Generations of Brubeck Click as Group
description: Two Generations of Brubeck, made 41 of Dave Brubeck, at the piano, and his sons, Darius, electric keyboards, Chris, electric bassist and trombonist, and Danny, drummer, is fusing into unified selfsupportive group. At the family's annual appearance at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, far from being dependent on the elder M. Brubeck as a focal point, as was the case in their earlier days together, the sons tow have grown to such strong stature that they ere, at one extreme (in the case of Danny on the drums), overshadowing their father and in general either leading him in new directions or opening up opportunities for bum to get out of the heavyhanded grind that characterized his work during his years as leader of a quartet.

title: U.S.T.A. to Name Hester To Serve as President
description: A new president will be installed by the United States Tennis Association, which opens its annual meeting tomorrow at La Costa, Calif.

title: Illegal Questions for job Interviews Detailed in New York State Booklet
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Amendments to the state's human rights law, passed during the last year by the Legislature, have made illegal dozens of personal questions commonly asked of those seeking jobs or housing.

title: Fixturing up a loft
description: Runway lights, factory lamps and diner stools used to belong in airports, factories and diners. Today, they have moved to some of the most avantgarde apartments in town, including the SoHo loft shown on these pages.

title: Rock: Blue Oyster Cult's Night
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 4When the injured Patti Smith pulled out as middle act in tonight's show at the Nassau Coliseum, the good citizens of Nassau County found themselves surrounded by their Long Island neighbors. In other words, tonight's rock show here opened with the Ramones, who come from Queens, and closed with the Blue Oyster Cult, which came out of Stony Brook in Suffolk County a few years ago and which has gone on to become about the best and most popular progressive heavymetaltand In the country.

title: County Enlarges Role in Airport
description: THE Westchester County Airport, one of the busiest general aviation airports in the country and home of the air fleets of the cream of the Fortune 500 companies. will be testing a unique management system when the country con tracts with a private company to run the airport.

title: THE JOHN JAY HOUSE
description: The article by Sol Stember on articles belonging to historic persons, Martha Washington's Bathing Suit, Jefferson's Fountain Pen and Other Reminders of Our Glorious Revolutionary Past (Travel Section, Jan. 16) was very interesting, but we feel slighted.

title: Book Ends
description: Born Again. Back in 1950 Harry Abrams founded the art book publishing house that bears his name; then, about 10 years ago he sold the company to the Times Mirror Co., a publishing conglomerate. Mr. Abrams held on to the reins however, remaining as chairman of the board and active editor. Recently, at the age of 72, Mr. Abrams resigned and announced that he was forming a new art book publishing house called Abbeville Press. Why would a man aged 72 leave the company he founded and instead of seeking quieter pastures, start all over again under another name?

title: Capitals Earn 33 Tie With Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 5Bernie Wolfe, who earlier this season thought a viral disease affecting his nervous system was going to end his goaltending career, sustained the Washington Capitals long enough tonight for them to gain a 33 tie with the New York Islanders.

title: Marriage Announcement 11  No Title
description: Jane S. Veitch, Librarian Wed To Clergyman

title: An Englishman Is No. 1 at Avis
description: Colin M. Marshall begins his Working day at The plush world headquarters of Avis Inc. in Garden City, L.I., by sticking on a lapel button proclaiming in loud red letters the car rental company's well known sloganWe try harder.

title: New  York, Connecticut and Jersey Are Surveying Energy Legislation
description: In the midst of one of the region's harshest winters, lawmakers In Albany, Trenton and Hartford have begun to deal with an avalanche of legislative proposals designed to help the three states cope with energy shortages.

title: Marriage Announcement 13  No Title
description: Lucile Howard to Be a Bride

title: Advocate Gives Errant Youth Albany's Help
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4If you describe Peter B. Edelman as a rebei or a troublemaker he smiles. But he doesn't disagree.

title: Sonya Strahl: A FrontOffice Rarity
description: About two months ago, Sonya Strahi was promoted by the North American Soccer League to the position of assistant to the commissioner, Phil Woosnam. It was, of course, a big advancement for Miss Strahl, who came to the N.A.S.L. as a secretary fewer than five years ago. But it was also a significant achievement for women in frontoffice sports careers. Few women in sports have achieved such a highlevel post, particularly in league offices or in a men's professional sport.

title: Exclusionary Zoning Plagues Courts
Tree Blight Proves To Be a Tough Foe
description: CONNECTICUT'S hemlocks and red pines are being attacked by two scaleshaped pests that are worrying experts at the state's agricultural station in New Haven.

title: Blacks &
description: In black political circles, there was a sense of letdown when it became evident that the overwhelming black vote for Jimmy Carter was not to be repaid with numerous black appointments to toplevel Administration jobs. As the black who exercises the greatest leverage with the new President, Andrew Young might have come in for sharp criticism. But in private conversations, the tendency was simply to say that tough behindthescenes bargaining was neither his forte nor his style.

title: Where to Buy Aerial Photos
description: AERIAL photographs covering the Long Island area ere available for sale from several governmental and private sources.

title: Women and children first
description: We were disappointed tnat Richard J. Margolis's article on National health insurance The dream whose time has come? (Jan. 9) failed to take into account what we believe will be the most fruitful approach: national health insurance for mothers and children; a phasedin program to serve as the basis and testing ground for an effective and highquality system of care for all Americans with a new emphasis on preventive care. Such a buildingblock approach is the key to the bill which we introduced in the last session of Congress and will reintroduce this year.

title: Competition in Oil Highly Imperfect
description: THE CONTROL OF OIL.. $y John M. Blair. Pantheon Books, New York. 441 pages. $15.

title: New &
description: Edited and Introduced By David A. Jasen. 212 pp. New York: The Seabury Press. $8.95.

title: Music: Detroiters Do New Piece
description: In the wellbalanced program that it offered in Carnegie Hall on Friday night, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra brought to town a work that it had commissioned from Michael Colgrass, a 44yearold composer who is perhaps still best known for an orchestral work called As Quiet As. His new piece is Concertmasters, and is a kind of Vivaldian concerto for three violins and orchestra.

title: The Release
description: Francolse Claustre, a French archeologist, has been freed after almost three years as a captive of rebels in Chad. Her husband, Pierre, captured in 1975, was also freed. Their release was apparently arranged through complicated negotiations involving France, Libya and the Chad rebel group. The French Government, which has been criticized for its release last month of a suspected Palestinian terrorist, Abu Daoud, said there was no connection between the two cases. The Libyan intervention in the Claustre affair was seen as part of that Government's strategy to alter its reputation in the nonArab world as an enthusiastic supporter of rebels and as a haven for terrorists.

title: Do not go gently...
description: It just doesn't make any sense to me,'rdike Shapiro says bitterly over his afternoon cup of coffee at Chef's Cafe. The Social Security Administration says it's running out of moneyand has to keep raising payroll taxes to support all the old folks. Meanwhile, there's plenty of us oldtimers hanging around who'd like to earn our own living, and they won't let us keep on working. . . It just doesn't make any sense, he says again, pausing to let his coffee cool.

title: Paperbacks
Bergdorf's Returns to Haute Couture
description: When Ira Ncimark, president of Bergdorf Goodman, turned up at the recent spring showings of the Paris haut couturiers, it seemed like a chapter from Remembrance of Things Past. Mr. Neimark was huying styles from Yves Saint Laurent, Christian Dior and Hubert de Givenchyone of whose designs is shown in the photograph  and announcing plans to open an Haute Couture section on the second floor of the Fifth Avenue specialty store.

title: Rowdies Grow Peaceful As Coach Wins a Battle
description: The internal problems that impeded the Tampa Bay Rowdies most of last season have apparently ended. The management of the club reaffirmed last Friday its complete support of Coach Eddie Firmani, who had several clasheswith Rodney Marsh, the team's controversial star and a source of disenchantment among the players.

title: Morgenthau Office, After 2 Years, Still Is in the Throes of Transition
description: Two years after taking over the post once held by the legendary Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan finds himself presiding over an office still in the throes of transition.

title: Classes to Make The Thumb Greener
LETTERS
description: Business Ethics

title: Pianists in Duet Play Some Outstanding Works
description: Appearing together for the first time on the night of Jan. 29 at Carnegie Recital Hall, Ann Zalkind and Helen Katz played three of the outstanding works from piano duet literaturethe Lebensstuerme (Op. 144) and Fantasy in F minor (Op. 103) of Schubert, and Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 497). It seems doubtful that there can be very much music of comparable quality that is as seldom performed.

title: Once Again, Arab Nations Are Hesitant on Geneva
description: CAIROEver since last October, when the Syrians and Palestinians ended their shooting war in Lebanon and the Syrians and Egyptians simultaneously ended their yearold war of words, the key Arab governments have been pressing for the resumption of the Geneva conference on the Middle East by early spring.

title: Some Reflections on My Friend, Ludwig van Beethoven
description: If you are looking for an unattached male aged 33 of a certain grace, a bit rustic but not without sophistication, may I suggest one Ludwig van Beethoven.

title: The U.S. Has a Heavy Investment in Disasters
description: WASHINGTONDay after day, as the toll from this brutal winter has mounted, the Federal Government has become more and more involved in the relief effort.

title: AfterHours Gambling Club Raided On East Side and 11 Are Arrested
description: The Police yesterday raided an elaborate afterhours gambling club on the East Side in which more than 100 patrons were said to have been playing dice and blackjack and drinking liquor sold illegally.

title: N.F.L. Games Next Jan. 1 Disturb CollegeBowl Chiefs
description: The National Football League's decision to play its two conference championship games, which decide the Super Bowl teams, on Jan. 1 next year has caused concern among the sponsors of the four major college bowl games:Rose, Cotton, Orange and Sugar. The bowl games television ratings last season went down, while pro football's went up. So what's happening? Is profootball eating its young, meaning college football?

title: The clubs Griffin Bell had to quit
description: Twenty years ago, a group of German students was brought to Atlanta as part of an exchange program and, as a matter of course, was invited by the German consul general to the Capital City Club, one of the city's two prestigious men's social clubs. During the visit, the story goes, one student asked, Are there any Jews in this club? No, he was assured, there were none. What followed was an extraordinary emotional scene. One student burst into tears and sobbed that the reason the club excluded Jews was the same reason six million had died. What had started as a polite occasion turned into a disaster, with students and club members shouting accusations at one another. That was in the mid1950's. And Atlanta, a city that considers itself the queen city of the South and prides itself on its hospitality, decorum, uptodateness and efficiency, soon pushed the Incident into the bottom drawer of its memory chest, and went about business as usual.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Freeport Turning Major Street Into a Mall

title: New York's Adjustable Abyss
description: A critical deadlineat times it was regarded as the critical deadlinefor New York City to disclose its plan for repaying a billiondollar debt has a come and gone, and the result is a familiar one in the long negotiations over the city's finances: little is clear.

title: Saddling Up in Wilton
description: ITS NOT EASY to build a flourishing retail business in a highly specialized field, and stores that cater to the horseback riding trade tend to come and go with some rapidity. One marked exception to the rule is the Saddler, on Danbury Road (Route 7) in Wilton. Twelve years ago when Albert Aquino opened shop he had no merchandising experience. He was a commercial artist commuting to Manhattan from Redding, where he had a few horses in his backyard and a sixth sense that there was a lot of growth coming in the equine area. My timing was right, he said. At that time you could start a store with 520,000. Today you couldn't buy much inventory with that kind of money.

title: Pedestrian Rush Hour
description: WHAT EVER its capacity. Seascape Inn was filled to it on a recent Saturday night. The cdptain said it was typical. The attraction can't be the food. Packed three and four deep at the bar waiting for tables (20 minutes or more with reservations, longer without), by the time the happy, hungry masses are seated will they be able to taste anything? Lighted signs flanking ,the bar say Subway. Rush hour is from 8 until 10 P.M. We felt relieved and grateful when our turn came at this Islip magnet.

title: Abducted Italian Women Free
description: BARI, Italy, Feb. 5 (AP)Vincenza Grilli, a 20yearold businesswoman abducted five days ago, was released today, and the police said they had arrested two persons and recovered a ransom reported to be $100,000. She had been seized at her small leather goods plant at Corato, near Bari. Authorities said she was in shock. The police named the two suspects as Alessandro Fusco, 19, and Riccardo. Ferrucci, 27.

description: Shirley Day, Artist, Wed To Robert Warfel Harrell

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Social Announcements

title: Bon Appetit
description: A bizarre twist was given to the now common tales of bribes paid by multinational companies last week. It seems that the former head of Indonesia's state oil company, Pertamina. shook down a score of American concerns in 1970 by requesting them to underwrite a restaurant in New York.

title: IslandHopping in the South Pacific: Paradise Enow
Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Miss Fein Engaged To Roy Allen Klein

title: Stones and Coghlan Triumph on Coast
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT IN JANUARY, based on a survey in the second week of the month, fell to 7.3 percent of the work force from 7.8 percent in December. The jobless total did not take into account the 760,000 workers idled in New York and New Jersey and thousands of others in Pennsylvania, Ohio and other states as a result of the natural gas shortage and cold weather The Federal Power Commission signed an order to increase the flow of gas to the Northeast, but the gas industry believes that the measure will not substantially alleviate the shortage, because excess supplies remain severely limited.

title: Gardner Resigning Post as chairman Of Common Cause
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)John W. Gardner, founder and chairman of Common Cause, the public affairs lobbying group, said today that he was resigning his post.

title: A Very Large Small Fish Story
2d Man Is Arrested ln Armed Robbery Of IND Passengers
description: One more suspect was arrested yesterday after three men took over a north. bound IND express train in Manhattan Friday night and demanded wallets and jewelry from about 20 passengers.

title: Newark$1.9.8 Million To Improve Downtown
Marriage Announcement 4  No Title
description: Jed Fox, a Dental Student, Is Fiance of Peggy Small

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
When a Tenor's Voice Goes to His Head
description: The curtains had just closed on the premiere last month of the Met's new production of Meyerbeer's Le Prophte. Amidst the backstage euphoria, direcfor John Dexter embraced tenor James McCracken saying: Only two other men in the world can command a stage like you do: Olivier and Scofield.

title: The Clergy's Revolution in Sexual Mores
Marriage Announcement 2  No Title
description: Anne Eaton Fiancee Of Robert B. Woolley

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Guatemalan Affair

title: What's a Name Among Neighbors?; Greenwich has a certain image .. actually, we have nothing to do with Port Chester.
description: WHEN I tell someone I'm from Hobart Avenue, they always ask me, What side of the street, Greenwich or Port Chester? Sue De Carlo said, looking up and down the gently sloping street from the front stoop of her small frame house.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingiy numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from lelt to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: Around the Nation
description: Maine Bar Association To Allow Print Ads

title: A Very Different Love Story
description: Burt and Linda Pugach's Intimate Account of Their Triumph Over Tragedy. By Berry Stainback. 300 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $8.95.

title: Egypt: The Poverty of One Man's Family
Albee Finds Hartford A Premiere Scene
description: THE REASON these two plays are in Hartford, said Edward Albee, discussing the current world premiers of his two oneact plays, Listening and Counting the Ways, is because I like the Hartford Stage Company; I like working with them. While conceding that good reviews might propel his plays to Broadway, Mr. Albee said: But what I'm thinking of is that I sort of hope that these plays will get done on Public TV, the way the Hartford production of All Over did. I'd rather have a healthy run in a congenial place. That's nicer than eking out a run on Broadway.

title: Peyser Volleys The Time Away
description: THEN the sounds of Ravel's Bolero or Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture are heard in the basement playroom of the handsome white house on Sunnyside Lane in Irvington these days,it usually means that the former Representative from the 23d Congressional District and his 14yearold son, Tommy, are trying to break the world record for unbroken tabletennis volleying.

title: Hometown Boy Back in Mt. Vernon
Help for Couples Who Want Children
Baranello Task: His Taskmaster
description: DOMINIC J. BARANELLO, the Democratic leader in Suffolk County, which until recently was a Republican bastion, is used to tough political jobs. But he really has his work cut out for him with his new post, chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

title: Army Defeats Seton Hall
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 5Steve Grant and Dino Larry combined for 26 points in the first half and Ricky Marsh put in 18 himself in the second half today as Manhattan posted a 7877 basketball victory over Hofstra and snapped a threegame losing streak.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: RALPH HOLMES, 70, DIES; RETIRED MINERALOGIST

title: What They Are Saying
description: Jim Barnett, 11year pro guard signed recently as a free agent by the Philadelphia 76ers: They took me right out of the casket.

title: Joe McCarthy Returns to TV  In Livid Color
description: They are an odd three hours. that NBC devotes this evening to Tail Gunner Joe, starting at 8 o'clock: oddly pious, oddly framed, even although this is nobody's fault but technologyoddly lighted. The career of Joseph R. McCarthy, the late junior Senator from Wisconsin to whose name an ism was attached like a sinister caboose, has been turned into one of the network's weekly Big Events, a dramatization stuffed with stars of stage and screen. It huffs and puffs and means well, and one wonders what our children will make of it. At the very least, it will acquaint them with a 1950's that wasn't situation comedy. There was more to the decade than punk sexuality, zippy music and a bunch of charactersFonzle, Richie, Potsie, PinkyWho seem to have been named after dwarfs or reindeer. Tail Gunner Joe might have been called Unhappy Days.

title: Former Egyptian Vice President Publicly Accuses Sadat of Responsibility for the Food Rioting Last Month
Too Young to Die
description: Youth and Suicide By Francine Klagsbrum 201 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $6.95. (Ages 14 and Up)

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Another Use for All That Prize Money
description: Couldn't assist in Improving the health care in our country by instituting one or more of the following:

title: Democracy In Unions: Grudging Acceptance
description: When members of the United Steelworkers of America, the largest union in the A.F.L.C.I.O., vote for new international officers on Tuesday, the safeguards for union democracy established by Federal law will be undergoing their most intensive test since Congress passed the LandrumGriffin Labor Reform Act in 1959.

title: New bodyhugging bathing suits
description: The maillot is in the swim again, but it's not the same suit women wore in the 50's. This time around it's slashed on the sides, down the hack, up the thighs (sometimes nearly to the waist), and it's usually strapless, every bit as provocative as a bikini.

title: The U.S. and Its Africa Policy
description: Ivor Richard, the British negotiator, has ended the monthlong visit to southern Africa during which he tried, and failed, to revive negotiations between the white regime of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and the black nationalists representing the majority of Rhodesians. Now, in a sense, it is the United States turn, although Washington still wants the British to play the principal mediator role: Andrew Young, the Ambassador to the United Nations, has arrived in Tanzania for talks with black leaders.

title: 2 Texas TeenAge Boys With $487,000 in Car Pose Mystery for Police
description: WACO, Tex., Feb. 5Dean Bridges, 16 years old, and Percy Garcia. 15, both of Alice, Tex., were driving through town this week when they passed a stop light. A rookie police officer stopped them and became curious about why two such young boys should be driving a 1977 Thunderbird. So he searched the trunk of the car.

title: Adoption: Easing Right to Know
description: In a decision unusual in its emphasis on psychological rather than legal reasoning, Judge Philip A. Gruccio of Superior Court in Atlantic City, N.J. has ruled that adopted adults should have easier access to their original birth certificates if they have a deep emotional need to know who their natural parents were.

title: A Ship Is Dying
description: En route from Liverpool to Copenhagen during heavy weather, the freighter Lycomedes strikes a submerged objectthe 300foot hulk of an oil rig service barge. The wreck is 31 miles off course, and the Lycomedes had been relying on radar, which Is not designed to detect subsurface obstructions. Into the 14 minutes it takes the ship to sink, Brian Callison compresses a chilling collection of marine horrors, all the more horrible because of his matteroffact tone. The behavior of men under stress gives the book a powerful chemistry, even though the only villain is the weather.

title: Pregnant With Sexism
description: LAST December the United States Supreme Court dealt the cause of equality of treatment in the work place a setback. In Gilbert v. the General Electric Company, the Court upheld an employer'sright to deny sick pay to women disabled by pregnancy.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
House Ethics: The New Barricade
Why They're ExCommuters
Marriage Announcement 16  No Title
description: Margaret Nuttle To Be the Bride Of P. F. Melcher

title: Key Figure in PX Scandal
description: Mr. Crum, the son of an American Yangtse River pilot in Shanghai, spent only about 10 years of his life in the United States. He remained unknown here until his name emerged in newspaper articles as a Rev figure in the PX investigation by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

title: How to Make the ThreePin Spare
description: Good bowlers, especially professionals, dislike shooting at spares. Not so much because they fear not converting them, but because shooting at spare means that something went wrong on the strike shot.

title: U.S. ORDERS OUSTER OF SOVIET NEWSMAN IN MOVE OF REPRISAL
Fast Route to New Jobs
Egyptian Agriculture Cannot Meet Food Needs Because of Ancient Farming Methods and the Lack of Land
A Religious Venture Into Cable TV
description: WHEN they push a button marked L on their television sets, 70,000 subscribers of cable television in Nassau and Suffolk Counties now receive a program that is being telecast by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: Film
Princeton 70, Brown 52
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 5 (AP) Princeton, led by Frank Sowinski, broke away from a 2525 tie by hitting on its first 10 floor shots in the second half tonight in rolling to a 7052 Ivy League victory over Brown.

title: Seeing Ourselves as the Airplanes See Us
When Snow Can Be a Friend
MAJOR ARSON TRIAL AN ISSUE IN CAUCASUS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  A controversial arson trial in the Caucasian republic of Georgia has reportedly shaken its cultural community and driven out its internationally renowned balletmaster.

title: Florida's Watery Zoos  Dolphins Cavort
description: There's a killer whaleYankee Doodle, by namewho signs a huge Declaration of Independence with a quill pen and any number of sea lions who play tunes on a calliope. But in the marine parks of Florida, the dolphins are the, real stars, diving through hoops, ringing bells, even singing songs. Eat your heart out, sea lions.

title: Sara P. Ridgway Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ridgway Jr. of Short Hills, N.J.; Fishers Island, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Parsons Ridgway, to Locke McLean, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. He is the son or Mr. and Mrs. Gale McLean of Potomac, Md.; York Harbor, Me., and Boca Grande, Fla.

title: NBC Paid Million To West German In Olympic Deal
description: The mystery man of the Olympic television negotiations, Lothar P. Pock, a West German theatrical producer, was paid a fee of $1 million and guaranteed undetermined additional income by the National Broadcasting company for assisting thenetwork's acquisition of the rights to the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow.

title: Paintings That Prod
description: THE PAINTINGS of John Ford are taskmasters of a sort. Not aggressive drill sergeant taskmasters bent on getting across their point through authoritarian boisterousness and intimidation. These paintings do not sternly command, nor taunt and strongarm us. They are rather taskmasters of a more sedate variety, urging us, but never to the point a exhortation, inciting, advising, encouraging and leading. They are friendly, benign taskmasters that make us work to understand them, that generally prod us to explore their intricacies.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Trail of a Varying Hare
description: NORWICH, Vt.Nestled within a stand of snowdraped pines, the voice of Jill, our beagle bitch, came to me faintly, if at all, as she plowed through deep snow on the trail of a varying hare.

title: Three More Inches of Snow Cloak New York Area
description: In New York City end most of its suburbs, three inches of snow fell yesterday, and a daylong gloom and plunging temperatures added symbol and substance to the region's toughest winter in years.

title: A Village Tries to Say No
description: NOT EVERY COMMUNITY has put out the welcome sign for the growing number of corporations seeking to move into the southern part of the state.

title: Murder in Space City
description: A Cultural Analysis of Houston Homicide Patterns. By Henry P. Lundsgaarde. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: Coast Guard to Start Patrol Soon On New 200Mile Fishing Limit
description: BOSTON, Feb, 5 (AP)Beginning the first of next month the Coast Guard will have to start patrolling 200 miles out to sea, instead of 12 miles, to watch for illegal foreign fishing vessels.

title: Lerner  Is Biding  His Time
Why can't people take humor seriously?
F.B.I. Aide Has Heart Attack
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 (UPI)Charles Bates, the man who spearheaded the Federal Bureau of Investigation's investigation and eventual capture of Patricia Hearst, was in stable condition at a local hospital today after a heart attack. He is 56 years old.

title: Conference Finds Economic Gains in South Greater Than Expected
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 2A major conference of Southern economists, scholars and historians outlined the present status and probable future of the emergent South this week and concluded that its economic growth was even more dramatic than generally believed. They also found that the energy crisis would not hurt and might help the growth of the Sunbelt, but that the overall growth rate was likely to slow down in the coming two decades as the region pulled even with the rest of the nation.

title: Elizabeth Wolff Makes Piano Debut
description: Some pianists choose for a debut program a mixed bag of old and new, simple and complex. But Elizabeth Wolff, whose New York recital debut took place in the afternoon of Jan. 29 at Carnegie Recital Hall, chose to play nothing but Brahms and Rachmaninoff, and the Brahms was far from being the intimate, inward musings of his final years. Though she demonstrated considerable agility and bravado, Miss Wolff's affinities are partly unfortunate, for she lacks the big hands and fullbodied tone such music ideally requires.

title: Travel AgentsProfits for Few and Perks for Many
description: It was more a slalomweaving his way past ins and outsthan a straight schuss perhaps, but David Lurie's love of skiing led him from suburban school teaching to where he is these days surrounded by computer terminals and telephones.

title: New Style at the UN
Court Voids a 12% Rise In H.I.P. Rates Saying Procedure Was Faulty

title: Nicolette
description: Those with a sweet tooth should know about this chocolatecovered valentine. (As a matter of fact, the hero uses hot chocolate as a metaphor for love, and his wife. thinks of her lover, a real estate agent, as a sweet man. Nobody in the novel is worried about hypoglycemia.) At the center of the confection is the relationship ,between David, an actor of 46, and Elizabeth, a career person of 31 who is a little bit pregnant. Complications. In reaction to this, David's wife, Janet, spends a naughty weekend at the Plaza with Sam, her sweet realtor.

title: Future Events

J., if you come as a guest in behalf of Englewood Hospital. There will be dancers, but only to watch. There will be other entertainers and cocktails. There will be hostesses, members of .SEED, referred to in the invitation to the 7 to 9 evening as special, enthusiastic, energetic and dedicated women who contribute their talents and abilities to meet the tremendous challenges of fundraising for the hospital. The hospital has 547 beds and serves 23 towns in Bergen County. Tickets: $25.

The Last Outcasts
description: Baseball, someone once wrote, is the game of professional athletes and amateur statisticians, The statisticians serve their purpose, too. Because of their industry and scrupulosity. there is a permanent record of the accomplishments of every player, and it is possible to make reasonably valid comparisons between men of different eras. We know, for example, that in the 20th century there have been nine batters with the ability, stamina and power to win the triple crown, leading their league for a season in batting average, home runs and runs batted in. Rogers Hornsby did it twice and Jimmy Foxx, Lou Gehrig, Chuck Klein, Mickey Mantle, Joe Medwick, Frank Robinson and Ted Williams once each, and the last to bring it off was Carl Yastrzemski, in 1967.

title: Fumes Kill Couple and Child
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 5 (AP)A young couple and their threeyearold daughter were found dead in their apartment Saturday from carbonmonoxide poisioning, authorities said. The police said Anthony Morgan, 18 years old, Regina Hill, 18, and their daughter, Tomeka Morgan, were probably overcome by the fumes at least six days earlier. Homicide detectives said four burners on a gas stove were turned on, but only one was still burning.

title: A Little More Yeast Won't Hurt
For Burt Ross, The Heat's Off
description: BURT ROSS, who recently resigned in disgust and frustration as the state's Energy Administrator, said the other day that he was emotionally and physically exhausted. but he was nevertheless eager to discuss his fallingout with Governor Byrne with vigor and passion.

title: My. Home Is a Castle
Banking Stocks, With Notable Exceptions, Fall From Favor
Exploring Inner Spacethe Closet
Junky Restored
description: Bill Burroughs and I had known each other since Xmas 1944, and at the beginning of the 50's were in deep correspondence. By then Kerouac and I considered ourselves poet/writers in Destiny, and Bill was too diffident to make such extravagant theater of self. In any case he responded to my letters with chapters of Junky, I think begun as curious sketching but soon conceived on his part to my thrilled surpriseas continuing workmanlike fragments of a book, narrative on a subject. So the bulk of the Ms. arrived sequentially in the mail, some to Paterson, New Jersey.

title: Catholic Defiance of Apartheid Is Stirring South Africa
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 4A quarter of a century after it began campaigning against apartheid, the Roman Catholic Church in South Africa has embarked on a policy of civil disobedience to the racial laws that has evoked uneasiness its own ranks and recriminations from Prime Minister John Vorster's Government.

title: Sauerbraten, Country Style
description: BECAUSE SO MANY restaurants one comes across are wildly expensive and dully pretentious, it is doubly rewarding to find one that is moderately priced, honestly simple and solidly good, if not great. Add to that an air of informality that permits one to be comfortable with children in tow, or when wearing the most casual clothing, and that restaurant seems almost a miracle, which brings us to the old red barn that is The Country Tavern in the Long Ridge section of Stamford.

title: Nelie Richardson Is Bride of Bruce P. Groberg

description: This season, fashion designers want women to look fragile and feminine. So don't get too brown in your skinrevealing maillot. It's not chic. Besides, as everyone knows, dermatologists and other skin experts agree that overexposure to sun is the single most devastating factor in the aging of skin and a leading cause of skin cancer.

title: Name That Tune? State Can't
description: SCRATCH a New Jerseyan and, if it isn't the mosquito season, you'll find a music lover. I first became aware of the state's wealth of amateur choral groupschoruses, choirs, Orpheus and oratorio societieswhen my family began joining some of them. From October through June, our house echoes with a father trolling, Ye dragons with contagious breath, a teenager practicing catches and glees and the chanteuse of the cherub choir belting out hymns.

title: When Things Get This Bad You Have to Laugh
description: Anyone in the business of architectural and urban criticism eventually gets bitter or develops a great sense of humor. Frankly, I am finding the world increasingly and wonderfully funny. A laugh a day, and I don't mean to keep from crving. There is endless entertainment in our Catch22 environment: ludicrous misjudgment, brilliant hindsight and almost endearingly awful buildings keep one constantly amused. Our frailties make us, and our buildings, more lovable.

title: More Jobs for More People
description: CREATION of more jobs throughout New Jersey remains the highest priority facing business and our state government in 1977. Although we succeeded in reducing unemployment to 11.3 percent in 1976 from the high of 13.6 percent in late 1975; we have to design and implement programs that will put the nearly 380,000 unemployed residents in the state back to work. before we can achieve our desired goal of a truly healthy state economy.

title: Columbia Tops Harvard, Holds Ivy League Lead
description: Although they could not really shake free of a dogged, physical team from Harvard, the Lions of Columbia stayed atop the Ivy League basketball standing with a 9274 victory last night before a cheering. raucous crowd of 2,675 at Levien Gymnasium.

description: The Town of Brookhaven on Long Island has decided it would rather do without some categories of Federal aid if it means having to accept new lowcost housing projects.

title: Lost Games
description: It is quite usual after tournament successes to relive the best moments, showing around your best performances, but it is more productive to delve into what went wrong in the lost games. When the United States team assembled in Haifa for the World Chess Olympiad, Kim Commons, who had just wound up his Bulgarian tour with three consecutive first prizes, filled us in on new problems created by a move that Yanis Klovan of the Soviet Union sprang on him in Primorsco. So far, no one has come up with a counterinspiration.

title: In Arts,It Isn't Just the Money
description: ON Nov. 15, 1976, the bitter battle over the culturalaffairs budget line was won, but at the sacrifice of an administrative office. Members of the Suffolk Leaislature's Cultural Affairs Committee will process the arts funding themselves.

title: Our new voice at the U.N.
description: On April 15, 1967, when he had less than a year to live, Martin Luther King Jr. led in a huge antiwar demonstration in front of the United Nations building. The setting made a thematic point that the escalating bombardment of North Vietnam flouted the U.N. Charter. For King, who had been agonizing over his proper role in the peace movement, the demonstration was full of hazards: It involved him in a momentary alliance with angry radicals who saw the war as an ultimate expression of American wickedness. King saw it as a detour, a regression, even a sickness, but he did not want his protest to be construed as antiAmerican. So he turned to the most effective negotiator in his entourage, the Rev. Andrew Young. Working quietly behind the scenes, the youthful Congregationalist minister set the terms for King's involvement in the protest, making sure Vietcong flags would be kept at a distance and radical rhetoric restrained. The protest, he insisted, had to appeal to the country's better instincts.

title: OneDay Course in Sex
description: ALMOST every Saturday for the last few months, Dr. Debora R. Phillips has been offering a oneday course in human sexuality that is designed to contain ennthinv advice for adults whose feelings about sex may have been bruised by the sexual revolution.

title: The Clubs:  Where Have the People Gone?
description: THEY like to tell the story over sandwiches and drinks in Westchester clubhouses of the wilf club in Texasor was it California?that struck oil in the rough off the ninth hole. There the club pays the members instead of the other way around. a former club president said with a laugh.

title: What's New In Paris? German Romanticism
description: The French are rediscovering the Germansthis, briefly stated, is the latest news of cultural life in Paris. And it is the Germans of the Romantic period who have suddenly achieved a remarkable visibility wherever dne turns on the Paris scene. Eric Rohmer's recent film version of Heinrich von Kleist's great story, The Marquise O, turns out to be part of a more widespread revival. There are new translations of Kleist in the book storesnot only of his wellknown stories and plays, but of his complete correspondence as welland there are new editions, too, of Novalis and E.T.A. Hoffman, and new studies of Holderlin and his contemporaries. Maurice Nadeau, who is best known in America for his History of Surrealism, has just devoted a special number of his journal, La Quinzaine Litteraire, to Le Romantisme allemand, complete with bibliographies and guides to further reading, and everything from picture books to scholarly monographs now abound in a field that wasuntil just the other day, it seemsconfined to a few academic specialists.

title: Housing Needs Cited
description: A STUDY based on the 1970 Census indicate that there is a need for housing for 219,455 lowand moderateincome families in New Jersey. And it is projected by housing experts that this figure will rise by more than 325,000 in the next 15 years.

title: Soaring Hopes for the A10
Those Shifting Stockpiles
description: Stockpiling strategic materials is crucially important to our national defense posture and to the security of the United States. Through stockpiles, we can insulate ourselves from some of the potential supply disruptions that might result from future wars.

title: Nudging of Fatal Chicago Train May Have Neutralized Safety System
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 5The Chicago Transit Authority's $25 million automatic safety system may have been neutralized yesterday afternoon as the motorman of a crowded rush hour elevated train nudged the vehicle around a sharpcurve and into the back of another train halted on the track in front of him.

title: Robert Duvall, Character Man, Will Be Playing the Lead for a Change
description: Consider three things about Robert Duvall: That he is an actor of many faces, who because of a beard or a moustache or a hairpiece or an eyepatch, never looks quite the same from role to role. That he made a lot of money last year appearing in two hit movies, Network and The Seven Per Cent Solution, and has two more big ones coming up. That he almost always plays the second lead.

title: Boston College 77, Fordham 76
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 5 (AP)Louis Benton, a freshman guard, hit on jump shots in the closing seconds of regulation and overtime tonight to lift Boston College to a 7776 victory over Fordham. Benton's 20foot shot with five seconds left in regulation tied the score, 6464. Then, with 12 seconds remaining in overtime, he connected on an 11foot jumper. He finished with 12 points.

With the slightest effort of will, you could remember it an hour from now, and, if it were important enough, you would recollect it next month, next year or next century.

description: When Hugh L.Carey became Governor two years ago, he was widely perceived as a moderately liberal, affable Brooklyn Democrat who got along well in the backslapping, backscratching milieu in the United States House of Representatives where he was weaned as a politician. He was untested as an administrator, and many wondered whether those qualities would serve him well as the chief executive of an economically and socially troubled state of 18 million people.

title: Of Islipper, Hick and Bayfolks
description: ALUEN WALKER READ, a professor emeritus of English at Columbia University, is interested in what he calls the fringes of the vocabulary, and one of those fringes is the derivatives of place names. They're evanescent, he said. Are we as free as we think in devising them, or are we programmed? I'm inclimed to think we're fairly free.
