title: News Summary
The Carter Touch
description: WASHINGTONIn a New York Magazine contest about headlines sure to be seen in the coming year, among the most frequent entries were Carter to N.Y.: Drop Daid; the obvious Amy to Star in School Play; and the ominous Mondale Pardons Carter.

title: Elakkad Plays Kanun, Egyptian Instrument
description: Mohammed Elakkad, who presented a concert at Asia House yesterday, plays an Egyptian psaltery called the kanun in a vigorous, twohanded style. The instrument resembles the insides of a piano, and Mr. Elakkad plucks the strings with the help of picks on his index fingers, using other fingers to dampen strings or to produce voicelike inflections.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
G.A.O. Study Suggests That Deserters Go Free
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)Millions of dollars are spent hunting for military deserters who eventually receive an early discharge anyway, according to a Government study that recommended that the armed services simply discharge most deserters.

title: Rhodesia Students Spurn Parents Plea To Quit Botswana
description: FRANCISTOWN, Botswana, Feb. 6 (Reuters)Anguished parents today managed to persuade only 51 of nearly 400 black Rhodesian children to return home arid abandon plans to enlist as guerrillas in the war against white rule.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's too bad that it took a disaster to produce this sensitive and moving portrait of Southern Appalachia's mountain people. But that's how Everything in Its Path: Destruction of Community In the Buffalo Creek Flood came to be written. Early in the morning of Feb. 26, 1972, after days of rain, 132 million gallons of black mud broke loose from behind a makeshift coalminingcompany dam and tore down the 17 miles of West Virginia's Buffalo Creek, inundating the 16 mountain villages that huddled in its path. Bereft of, their homes and more than 100 members of their families, some 600 survivors of thee disaster filed a lawsuit against the Pittston Corporation, owner of the mining company responsible for the faulty dam.

title: Job Losses Likely to Go On In Shortage of Natural Gas
description: Although the recent moderation of the record cold snap will allow many in the New York and New Jersey area to start going back to work this week, widespread job losses elsewhere, stemming from the natural gas shortage, are increasingly likely to continue for the rest of the winter and possibly into the spring, according to both industry and Government officials.

title: Peasant Rugs for That Country House
Smithsonian Faces G.A.O. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A Senate appropriations subcommittee has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the use of Federal funds in the Smithsonian Research Foundation, a private, nonprofit corporation set up in 1966 by the Smithsonian Institution, it was learned tonight.

title: Westminster Students Learn Leadership as Well as Music
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 6They are taught leadership of a very special kind. From the day they are accepted for enrollment, the students at Westminster Choir College know that they will be the future leaders of choral groups and choirs and that they will be in high demand.

title: EDITH BOUVIER BEALE, RECLUSE, DEAD AT 81
description: Edith Bouvier Beale, who faded from high society to reemerge among the seedy surroundings of a rundown Long Island mansion in the film Grey Gardens, died Saturday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital at the age of 81. Grey Gardens was the home she shared with her daughter, Edith, on Apoquogue Road in East Hampton.

title: State's DeathPenalty Bill Offers Many Restrictions
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6The bill restoring capital punishment in New Jersey, now on Governor Byrne's desk awaiting his signature, may be more restrictive than any such measures passed in 35 other states in the last two years. Under its provisions, before a death sentence could be imposed, a juryor a judge in a nonjury trial  would be required to weigh the mitigating circumstances against the aggravating circumstances surrounding the murder, and report in writing why the death sentence was justified.

title: Elizabeth Is Extolled on jubilee;
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) Queen Elizabeth II quietly marked 25 years on the throne today, but a small literary storm blew up over the Poet Laureate's Jubilee hymn, with one critic calling it nursery rhyme gibberish.

title: NORMAN WEITMAN, 49, DIES; EXECUTIVE AT PARAMOUNT

description: HARTFORD. Conn.. Feb. 6The lights went out on Linda Fratianne last night, but not before she had convinced the judges that she deserved to be America's newest women's figure skating champion.

description: PRAGUE, Feb. 6  Czechoslovakia's Communist leadership was reported today to be split over how to deal with the broadening human rights movement.

description: The rate of production has been drastically reduced in many areas of the country in recent days because of adverse weather conditions, it was pointed out by E. F. Andrews, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management Inc.

description: C. Russel Deyo, vice president of public relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's longlines department, died Saturday at his home in Basking Ridge. N.J. He was 58 years old.

title: WEST BERLIN SHAKEN BY DECLINE IN JOBS
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 6Alfons Steinert, a draftsman, lost his job when the West Berlin electronics company where he worked folded a few weeks ago. Like the other laidoff workers he was found eligible for unemployment compensation and began looking for a new opening.

title: Levitt Says State Cuts Its InterestFree Deposits
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt, in an unusual public audit of his department's cashmanagement practices, has reported a significant reduction in the amount of New York State money left in interestfree bank accounts.

These weekends, as President Carter is trying to push his program of economic stimulus through Congress, the lights burn late in the highceilinged offices of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: MRS. GANDHI'S RIVALS EXHORT A BIG CROWD TO REJECT HER RULE
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6The two elderly politicians who are leading the battle against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told an enthusiastically cheering crowd here today that the coming parliamentary election would decide the future of democracy in India.

description: The Collegiate Chorale took on an ambitious program Saturday night in Carnegie Hall with mixed results. It consisted of Mozart's Requiem, Handel's Utrecht Jubilate and a new work commissioned by the Chorale, David Diamond's A Secular Cantata, which received its world premiere.

title: International Group Plans to Build Big Oil Port on Remote U.S.Governed Pacific Island
description: KOROR, PalauAn international consortium of oil, banking and industrial interests, led by a New Yorker, is planning a multimilliondollar oil storage and transshipping station for supertankers on this island in the United States Trust Territory of the Pacific.

title: Psychiatrist Believes That Darwin Was Tormented by His Theories
description: A chorus of the birds singing around me. and squirrels running up the trees, and some woodpeckers laughing, and it was as pleasant and rural a scene as ever saw, and I did not care one penny how any of the beasts or birds had been formed.

title: Levesque's Car Hits Body in Road
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 6Premier Rena Levesque of Quebec, driving through Montreal early this morning, ran over the body of a man lying in the roadway and spent several hours in a local police station explaining the circumstances.

title: Soetaert, a Ranger Rookie, Turns Back Islanders, 40
description: Doug Soetaert raised his gloved hands high over his head last night and down from the Madison Square Garden stands, in response, thundered the new chant of Dougie! Dougie!

title: Scientists Find Chinese Cool to Farm Research and Seed Exchanges
description: American agricultural scientists returning from group visits to China report that the Chinese are apparently indifferent to basic agricultural research and to continued exchanges of the seeds of major foodplant varieties, such as wheat.

title: SALES IN NEW YORK FOR RETAIL STORES SLOW, SURVEY FINDS
description: The city's retail sales trend proved sluggish in January and in the fiscal year ended last month.

title: Mummer's End, Drama by Gilhooley
Chicago Will Not Appeal Decision on Police Quotas
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UPI)City officials closed the books today on a sixyear police bias controversy, announcing that they will not appeal a decision by, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit upholding courtordered racial and sexual quotas for hiring and promotion in the police department.

title: U. S. CAN'T REPLACE BRITAIN IN TALKS, NYERERE SAYS
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 6 (Reuters)President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania today told Andrew Young, the chief United States representative to the United Nations, that he did not think the United States could replace Britain as mediator in the dispute over Rhodesia.

title: They Are a Lost Generation
description: Their eyes are bleak. Some, strutting down the street, speak with false bravado. Others stand listlessly on street corners speaking in monotones of what they think peing an adult is like. Most can barely read or write. They lack good work habits that should have been built into their educational experience. They are 17 to 22 years old. The majority of them are minority youngsters. They are a lost generation.

title: Cortland Women Win
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., Feb. 6Cortland College beat St. John's Fisher College today, 9268, in a semifinal of the Manufacturers Hanover invitation for New York State women's college basketball teams. Cortland will meet Queens College next Sunday at Iona College, in New Rochelle, for the state title and a $2,000 grant from the sponsor.

title: Israel Favors Moves by U.S., Not U.N., on Mideast
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6With separate visits to Israel scheduled soon by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations, Israeli officials are stressing that they feel the prospects for a solution of the Middle East conflict rest more with initiatives taken by the United States than efforts by the United Nations.

title: Metroliner Overhaul To Regain Riders Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP)  Amtrak officials hope that a $24.4 million refurbishing, budgeted to begin this month, will stop the drop in the number of riders on the fleet of Metroliners.

title: Rumanian Wins Net Final, Defeating Miss Nagelsen
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 6Florenta Mihai of Rumania defeated Betsy Nagelsen of Winnetka, Ill., 64, 36, 64, at the Rye Town Hilton bubble court today and won the $20,000 Avon Futures of Westchester tennis tournament.

title: Red Smith
description: According to the most reliable testimony, Archie Moore, nee Archibald Lee Wright, a.k.a. The Old Gray Mongoose, is either 60 years old or 63, give or take a decade. When he was lightheavyweight champion of this manysplendored world he used to tell people that he had arrived on the planet by way of Collinsville, Ill., on Dec. 13, 1916, about a month after American voters reelected Woodrow Wilson because he had kept us out of war. (World War I, this is.). Archie was patient with his mother when she said the blessed event had really taken place in Benoit, Miss., on Dec. 13, 1913. Mother ought to know because she was there, he said, but that would make me three years old when I was born. Leaving that minor disagreement aside, we do know that 41 years have passed Since Archie, as a professional prizefighter, dismantled one Poco Kid in Hot Springs, Ark., that it took him 17 years and eight managers to win championship and that nine years later he was still defending his title. He was in his 24th year as a pro when he got off the floor four times to knock out Yvon Durelle and win the Edward J. Neil Award as the man who did the most for boxing in 1958. Even that, however, was almost 20 years ago. By now, surely, even this ageless gladiator must have settled down to a life of peace.

title: Laos Is Said to Seize Two Mekong Islands
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, Feb. 7. (Reuters)Military sources here said today that Laotian forces had landed on two small islands in the middle of the Mekong River yesterday and claimed sovereignty over the islands, which were the scene of fierce fighting in November 1975, between Thai and Pathet Lao forces. The Mekong divides the two countries.

description: BASKETBALL

description: Jane Warshaw, a copywriter with the Young & Rubicam advertising agency, and Christopher B. Reid, a vice president with Citibank, were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's home by State Supreme Court Justice Fritz W. Alexander 2d.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PROFIT OFF 22% IN LAST QUARTER
description: Standard Brands Inc., the large food processing and marketing organization, announced yesterday a 22 percent drop in net income for the last quarter of 1976, largely because of the depressed prices for sugar and corn sweeteners.

title: Washington Park Fire Razes Clubhouse. Stands
description: HOMEWOOD, Ill., Feb. 6 (AP)A tire destroyed the Washington Park race track grandstand, clubhouse and restaurant late last night, demolishing the fivestory complex. No injuries were reported.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
A FISCAL CRISIS SEEN IN PRIVATE COLLEGES
Cut Sought in School Breakfast Cost
description: Two legislators from New York City and Deputy School Chancellor Bernard Gifford said at a news conference yesterday that a statemandated school breakfast program could cost city schools at least $1 million next year unless remedial legislation is passed by the Federal or state governments.

title: Cavaliers' Rally Turned Back in Last 30 Seconds
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 6 (AP)Bubbles Hawkins scored 37 points and Al Skinner broke a tie with 30 seconds remaining as the New York Nets defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 9490. today. It was the third straight National Basketball Association victory for the Nets, who last Wednesday defeated the Boston Celtics and on Friday beat the 76ers in Philadelphia.

title: LIBERALS PROPOSING GOODMAN FOR MAYOR
description: The Liberal Party's policy committee has cleared the way for the probable endorsement for mayor of a Republican, State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan, by selecting Mr. Goodman and Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau as its preferred mayoral candidates.

description: Morning

title: OverCounter Supplementary Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National, Association of Securities Dealers, The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Music of Louise Talma Presented
description: It was fitting that Saturday night's program of music by Louise Talma at Hunter College should have included her song cycle Terre de France. Miss Talma, a professor of music at Hunter since 1952, studied composition for many summers with Nadia Boulanger at France's Fontainebleau School. What is more, her music, with its transparent textures and economic gestures, is distinctly Gallic in flavor.

title: Rescuers Herd Whales Back From Florida Beach
description: MAYPORT, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP)Rescuers worked frantically today to turn more than 200 pilot whales back into deep water as they tried to beach themselves. Despite the rescue efforts, some of the whales were stranded by low tide.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: John Hart, based in Washington, is national affairs correspondent of NBC News. This article is excerpted from a recent address at an awards ceremony in Nebraska.

title: Hotel Resident, 60, Plunges to Her Death
description: Sylvia Sherman, a resident at the Beekman Hotel at 575 Park Avenue, leaped to her death yesterday from her 15thfloor apartment to the sidewalk on 63d Street, according to the police. Before jumping, the 60yearold womanwho lived alonetelephoned her lawyer, Moses Polakoff, also a resident there. I'm going to jump, Moe, the 80yearold attorney quoted her as saying. Take care of my things.

title: 150 Friends of Seminary March Cheerfully Down Lexington Avenue
description: Garbed in divinity robes, ski caps, mufflers and overcoats, 150 faculty members, students and friends of New York Theological Seminary marched down Lexington Avenue yesterday in bright, but bitter cold weather. The parade was their way of marking the seminary's move from the heart of Turtle Bay at 235 East 49th Street, to newly remodeled quarters at 5 West 29th Street.

title: Warning System Was Working In Chicago Crash, Tests Indicate
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)Preliminary tests of the wreckage of a rapidtransit train which rammed the rear of another train, killing 11 persons Friday, indicated that the train's emergency warning system was working at the time of the accident, the Federal authorities said today.

title: Carey vs. Shanker: Showdown Over Wage Pact
Policeman Kills Gunman
description: A police officer shot and killed a gunman who pointed a pistol at him during a chase that started with a restaurant robbery in Brooklyn, police officials reported. The robbery suspect was dead on arrival at Kings County Hospital. He had been shot twice in the chest. The man's identity was not immediately known.

title: Dr. Gustave M. Gilbert Dead at 65
description: Dr. Gustave M. Gilbert, the former chairman of the psychology department of Long Island University who served as a prison psychologist during the Nuremberg war crime trials in 194546, died yesterday afternoon at the North Shore University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

title: No HusseinArafat Meeting
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 6(AP)King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Damascas today shortly after Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had left, upsetting predictions that the two men would meet for the first time in more than six years.

description: The New York Telephone Company announced over the weekend a record $1.1 billion oneyear construction program, of which $606 million was budgeted for improved facilities in the five boroughs.

description: Wheat futures prices rise despite the gravitational pull of bearish market news. Farmer holdings of huge amounts of grain may be the clue to prices. Page 37.

title: Eglevsky Ballet's Cinderella Is Marked by Fine Ensemble
description: Sergei Prokofiev's score for Cinderella has been a favorite for choreographers seeking to provide ballet's equivalent of family entertainment. The Eglevsky Ballet is rid exception. Andr Eglevsky's staging of Cinderella for his company is a very tasteful version of the ballet.

title: India Wonders About Motive for Crucial Political Defection
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6Twenty months ago, in the hot, sticky days just before and after the imposition of India's sweeping state of emergency, dissidents within the ruling Congress Party were looking hopefully to Jagjivan Ram as the only credible alternative to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 (AP)Cincinnati, powered by Mike Jones's 20 points, held off Marquette today for a 6362 victory that extended college basketball's longest current winning streak on a home court to 57 games.

description: Jo Ann Maria Kaye and JeanMarc Petin deBruny were married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. by the Rev. Richard Hoerning.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Ivor Richard, the British delegate to the United Nations and chairman of the stalled Geneva conference on Rhodesia, met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today.

description: The three television networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7 have scheduled live coverage this afternoon of President Carter's news conference, starting at 2:30. It will also be broadcast live on radio stations WCBSAM, WINS and WMCA.

description: Leonard A, Lovell, a retired partner of TippettsAbbettMcCarthyStratton, consulting engineers and architects of 345 Park Avenue, died Friday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He lived at 11 Plymouth Road, Summit, and was 69 years old.

title: Books of The Times

David Gray, secretary of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, said today.

title: Rutgers Defeats Duquesne, 9070

The trio of fast, lanky players got 64 points tonight as the Scarlet Knights ran away from Duquesne in the second half to whip the Dukes, 9070, at the old Rutgers Gym.

He plans to see 60 more games, including Benson and Johnson three more times each.

title: UNIFORM OIL PRICE RISE IS CONSIDERED BY OPEC
