Iran's Air Chief Is Killed
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 7 (AP)Iran's air force commander, Gen. Fazavel Tadayonr. was killed in a helicopter crash in the, hills northeast of Teheran, the state broadcast network said last night. Bad weather was given as the cause of the crash. No other details were available immediately.

title: The U.N. Today
Growth Costs Salvador, Pearl of Brazil, Some of Its Luster
Business Records
description: Monday, Feb. 7, 1977

title: Carter Plan Criticized
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7 (UPI)The economist Paul McCracken today called President Carter's economic proposals a Rube Goldberg contrivance.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNCNFM. Hungarian Fantasy for Bassoon and Orchestra, Weber; Violin Concerto No. lO, Vivaldi; 16thCentury Italian Lute Music, Anon; Costanza e Fortezza Suit Fax; My Joys, ChopinLiszt; Quintet: Nocturnal Music of Madrid, Boccherini.

title: $2.9 BILLION PROFIT AT GENERAL MOTORS IN 1976 SET RECORD
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7The General Motors Corporation, the nation's leading domestic automobile manufacturer, reported today fourthquarter and fullyear sales and profits that were the highest in the company's history.

title: 2 of Harold Wilson's Former Close Aides Exchange Sharp Attacks
Key U.S. Import Decisions Await Ruling in Zenith Suit
Nassau Employees Get a 6.5% Raise
description: MINEOLA, LI., Feb. 7The Nassau County Board of Supervisors voted today to grant a 6.5 percent salary increase for 800 managerial employees, but refused to provide larger increases for 89 topechelon officials.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Frees Rival Who Took Her to Court
description: NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (AP)The Government tonight freed a Socialist leader, Raj Narain, who took Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to court for electoral fraud after she defeated him in the 1971 parliamentary elections.

title: March Coffee Futures Climb 8c
description: Prices for green (unroasted) coffee deliverable next month on the docks of New York jumped 8 cents, to $2.36 a pound, yesterday. While the nearest contract is exempt from price restrictions, the later deliveries, which are restricted advanced the 3tentsapound limit.

title: Family of Black Victim in 1906 Texas Raid Recalls Stigma
description: OSSINING, N.Y.An Army captain came around and gave my mother a check for $10,000, an American flag and a military marker for my father's grave, Bettye Conyers Hardeman said. Big deal. There was no letter of apologies. That was in exchange, of course, for a man's whole life.

title: The Cast
description: CASTAWAYS, a musical, with book by Anthony Stimac, Dennis Andersen and Ron Whyte; music be Don Pippin; lyrics by Steve Brown; setIng by Scott Jonnscri; lignling by Richard Winkler; costumes by Patricia McGourty; orchestrations by Bill Brohn; music director, Dorothy Opatech; directed be Tony Tanner; production stage manager, Robert Scheer. Presented by Jeff Britton; Jimmy Merrill and Michael Sheeley, associate Producers. At the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street.

title: U.S. AGAIN COMMENTS ON SOVIET DISSIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The State Department said today that it had informed the Soviet Union that the United States was watching with concern the: case of Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, a dissident who was arrested in Moscow last week.

title: FINAL APPROVAL IS GIVEN TO SPIDERMAN AD CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission gave final approval today to a decision ending the direct advertising of SpiderMan vitamins to children.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PRIME RHYME In one of his rare public readings, Robert Penn Warren will render his poetry tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. Tickets, at $1.50, are available at the door after 7 o'clock. Stanley Kunitz will introduce the program, which is sponsored by the Academy of American Poets.

title: Carter Calls for Action On World Drug Abuse
description: GENEVA, Feb. 7In a message to the United Nations Narcotics Commission, President Carter called today for concerted international action to meet the global drug problem.

title: British Football
Paterson School Reopens
description: The Martin Luther King School in Paterson reopened yesterday after being closed for a week because of flaking from asbestoscoated ceilings. The 900student middle school was closed last Monday when the flaking asbestos was found in corridors leading to the basement cafeteria. Workers spent the week scraping the suspected cancercausing substance from the ceilings.

title: Trenton Topics
Cocteau Troupe Stages The Cenci
SHIPPING AND MAILS
description: SAILING TODAY, Feb. 3

title: The Economic Scene
description: Small businesses are hopeful that 95th Congress will be turnaround Congress as far as they are concerned after overwhelming vote in their favor by Senate last week. Page 47.

title: Endangered Butterfly Species Receive a Habitat in California
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Government wants to declare land belonging to an oil refinery, an Army rifle range and the Los Angeles International Airport as critical to the survival of several endangered species of California butterflies.

title: Carter Will Avoid Press on Occasion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)President Carter served notice today that when he leaves the White House for personal or family reasons, he intends to do so secretly even if his destination. is a public event.

title: Arms Control, Before Time Runs Out
description: WASHINGTONWe cannot, for obvious reasons, forfeit a major position in world affairs. And we must continue to rely on the executive as our principal spokesman internationally. But the retention of a strong world role and the maintenance of an effective defense posture will require that the President and his chief foreign affairs advisers begin to talk more sense to the Congress and to the people.

title: S.E.C. SAYS INSURERS ALLOT LESS MONEY FOR CLAIM PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Securities and Exchange Cornmission has found a number of insurance concerns that have, like the Government Employees Insurance Company, allotted far less money to meet predicted claims than they will need.

title: Justice Rinaldi Settles His Suit Against The Voice for $50,000
description: A $6 million libel suit by Justice Dominick S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court against The Village Voice and an advertising agency was settled for $50,000 yesterday in a pretrial conference before Justice Bernard Nadel of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Quarterly Profits Off at Lockheed And at Grumman
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Grumman Corporation, both suppliers of military aircraft to the United States Government, reported lower earnings for the fourth quarter.

title: CONTROL BOARD VOTES DISPUTED PAY RAISES IN TEACHER CONTRACT
description: The Emergency. Financial Control Board yesterday approved the contract granting a full range of disputed wage increases to 55,000 New York City teachers and other school employees  although the contract would have to be renegotiated if some of the increases are eventually determined to be illegal.

title: U.S. and Soviet Publishers Sign Agreement on CoProductions
description: In a signifcant breakthrough in international publishing, American and Soviet companies have concluded negotiations on a private, commercial basis for Englishlanguage editions of Russian works and coproductions of important works in the fields of art and medicine. In addition, a history of the Olympic Games, tentatively titled From Athens to Moscow, will be jointly undertaken before the 1980. Moscow Olympics.

title: 7 White Missionaries in Rhodesia Slain in Raid by Black Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7Seven white Roman Catholic missionaries were shot to death by black guerrillas last night at a mission station 37 miles northeast of here. The dead were two priests, a lay brother and four nuns.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph Kallinger accused his defense lawyer and Bergen County of denying him a fair trial in the proceedings that led to his conviction of murdering a nurse, court papers disclosed yesterday.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: U.S. Blocks Sale Of Israeli Planes To Ecuadoreans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The United States has blocked the sale to Ecuador of 24. Israeli fighterbombers equipped with American jet engines, the State Department said today.

title: U.S. Blocks Sale Of Israeli Planes To Ecuadoreans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The United States has blocked the sale to Ecuador of 24 Israeli fighterbombers equipped with American jet engines, the State Department said today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Meeting of Decoy Collectors
description: One of the most splendid displays of water bird decoys in the United States will be the gathering point for a twoday decoy collectors meeting at The Museums at Stony Brook, L.I., this Saturday and Sunday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Rebates on Gas Bills Are Expected From Con Ed and Brooklyn Union
description: Consolidated Edison and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company are expected to give their natural gas customers rebates on their minter gas bills, nidustry sources said; last night.

title: Press and Its Independence
description: The expulsion over the weekend of Washington based Tass correspondent after Moscow's order expelling an Associated Press reporter is raising perplexing questions about the relationship between the American press and the government. The incident poses so many contradictions that news organizations are divided on whether the Carter Administration should be lauded or condemned for its quick retaliation.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1977

title: Article 3  No Title
Senate Republican Vows to Block Runoff Primary in New York. City
description: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader and the chairman of the Senate Elections Committee, vowed yesterday to bottle up in his committee any Juneprimary bill that would retain the runoff primary provision for New York City's mayoral election.

title: West, Too, Faces a CrisisDrought
E.P.A. to Crack Down On Toxins in Sewage
Califano Moves to Remove Doctor Who Guided Swine Flu Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Dr. David J. Sencer, who helped develop the muchtroubled swine flu inoculation program, said today that he had been asked to step aside as director of the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Southern Pacific Bid Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today an application by the Southern Pacific Railroad to buy more than 900 miles of the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad.

title: GOLD PRICE ADVANCES
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) The price of gold rose today while the dollar was irregular.

title: Schlitz Concerned About TV Violence
description: Sundenly, after years of mounting violence and sex on television, there's a rush of advertisers announcing guidelines for their agencies to follow in buying commercial time.

title: Dividends and Trials for Governor Byrne
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey stands poised to reap the dividends of one long exercise in political courage. That makes the time fitting to urge him to another.

title: People in Sports
description: Mickey Lolich, who has struck out more batters than any other lefthanded hurler in history, informed the New York Mets yesterday that he would not report to their spring training camp in St. Petersburg Fla.

title: Assembly Votes Down Bill to Decriminalize Marijuana
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7The State Assembly tonight voted 53 to 11 against removing criminal sanctions for possession of small amounts of marijuana and hoshish, but the bill's spon'sor, Eldridge Hawkins, kept the proposal alive through a parliamentary maneuver.

title: Could Sonja Henie Skate Circles Round Them All?; Could Sonja Henie Skate Circles Round Them All?
description: She opened her routine with two dazzling triple jumps in the first 40 seconds and closed with two Russian splits and three consecutive butterflies. And after Linda Fratianne received the crown as America's newest women's figureskating queen last weekend, her grace and artistry were wrapped in superlatives.

title: C.I.A. and a Military Professional
description: After a bad stumble on the political ice with his failed effort to appoint Theodore Sorensen, President Carter now seeks to restore his balance by nominating an Annapolis classmate, Adm. Stanfield Turner, as Director of Central Intelligence. Admiral Turner's credentials appear, on first inspection, to be impressive. Still, the nomination raises a new question and leaves unanswered an old one.

title: G.E. Says 2 Compounds Will Be Used for PCB's At New York Factories
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP) The General Electric Company has come up with two new compounds to replace toxic polychlorinated biphenyls, the manmade chemical that has caused extensive pollution of waterways.

title: ALICE GOOD SMITH
description: Alice Good Smith, a wellknown horsewoman and widow of Gerald S. Smith, investment banker who was a leading polo player in the. 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday on a visit to Aiken, S. C. She was about 73 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Carey's Tough BlockingBack at City Hall
Boyle's Request for Bail Rejected by Judge
description: MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 7 (AP)A judge ruled today that W.A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, must stay in jail while the State Supreme Court studies a request to reconsider its decision ordering a new trial for him.

title: FEMINISTS CRITICAL OF CARTER ON JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Carter Administration has brought more women into toplevel jobs than any of its predecessors, and it will add others. But it has not satisfied women's groups in meeting the expectations raised by the Carter campaign.

title: $4,198 Over 3 Years Is in Teachers Pact
description: The new teachers contract approved yesterday by the Emergency Financial Control Board will provide average benefits of $4,198 over three years for each teacher. However, only the first two years of the pact, through Sept. 9, 1978, were given formal board approval.

title: CONTROL BOARD VOTES DISPUTED PAY RAISES IN TEACHER CONTRACT
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved the contract granting a full range of disputed wage increases to 55,000 New York City teachers and other school employees  although the contract would have to be renegotiated if some of the increases are eventually determined to be illegal.

title: The Light Touch for the Dining Room
SOME BUSINESSMEN NOW FAVOR REBATE
Young Will Confer With the Nigerians On Strain in Ties
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 7  Andrew Young, who is on a tour of Africa for President Carter, arrived here tonight for discussions with top Government officials that could ease AmericanNigerian relations badly strained for more than a year.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: WASHINGTON There was a high degree of elation here toward the end of last week among the various lobbying organizations that represent the nation's smallbusiness community. They had just won a big victory in Congress on an issue they feared was impossibly lost a few weeks ago, and they counted rising support among the legislators for their position on a different tax plan to create new jobs in the private sector of the economy.

title: Jets Hire Mazur, Ledbetter
description: John Mazur, a former head coach of the New England Patriots, Joined the Jets' coaching staff yesterday along with John Idzik and Bob Ledbetter.

title: Thais Reinforce Border Forces After a Gunfight With Laotians
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Thailand has sent reinforcements to its Mekong River border after a gun battle with Laotian soldiers, the Thai radio reported today.

title: Carter's Choice to Head C.I.A.
description: As president of the Naval College Trom 1972 to 1974, Adm. Stansfield Turner kept a sign on his door that read: I need one good idea a day. The sign was characteristic of a man whom his associates and friends describe as endlessly curious about philosophy, theater, opera, international politics and military affairs, He is quite a remarkable military officer, almost an original, said a War College associate. F. J. West, another professor at the college, spoke Of him as highly imaginative and extremely energetic.

title: Crews Struggling to Keep More Oil From Leaking Out of Hudson Barge
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 7Salvage crews struggled today to keep more heavy industrial heating oil from spilling out of a barge that struck a submerged rock ledge just north of here and has spewed a 30milelong trail of oil up and down the Hudson River.

title: BENIN ASKS U.N. STUDY OF ATTACK ON COTONOU
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7The West African country of Benin charged in the Security Council tonight that a group of airborne international mercenaries in the pay of foreign enemies had attacked Cotonou last month, leaving many dead and wounded.

title: Bridge:
description: The first New York blue ribbon individual championship, which ended Sunday night at the Manhattan Club, 228 West 71st Street, proved to be a feminine triumph.

title: Former Agnew Associate Sentenced on Tax Charge
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP)Walter J. Dilbeck, onetime business associate of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, was sentenced today to 60 days in jail and 10 months probation for filing a false Federal tax return.

title: New York City Aides See a Drop of $400 Million in Property Base
description: New York City's propertytax base, Which dropped by $829 million last year, will shrink this year by about $400 million to $38,427 billion, City Finance Department officials predicted yesterday. In the last 34 years, the total value of taxable, real estate has dropped only once beforein 1976.

title: U.S. AGAIN COMMENTS ON SOVIET DISSIDENT
Flyers Down Flames, 74, After Taking 40 Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP)Bob Kelly scored one goal and had two assists to help the Philadelphia Flyers defeat the Atlanta Flames, 74, in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: 7 White Missionaries in Rhodesia Slain in Raid by Black Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7Seven white Roman Catholic missionaries were shot to death by black guerrillas last night at a mission station 37 miles northeast of here. The dead were two priests, a lay brother and four nuns.

title: HOSPITAL FUND FOUNDS A HEALTH CARE PROGRAM
description: The United Hospital Fund of New York announced yesterday that it had founded an Institute for Health Care Studies to develop new approaches to providing healthcare services, particularly in urban areas.

title: SIDNEY FOSTER DIES
description: Sidney Foster, pianist, died yesterday at New England Medical Center in Boston from pneumonia, following an operation for removal of his spleen. He was 59 years old.

title: Stocks Mixed in a Slower. Session
description: Specialsituation and energyrelated issues continued to advance yesterday while the stock market generally closed mixed in slower trading.

title: Delta and Braniff Place Order For 30 Boeing Jet Airliners
description: Delta Air Lines and Braniff International have ordered a total of 30 727200 jet airliners from the Boeing Company, Boeing announced yesterday.

title: Top Milers Will Race At Garden
description: Niall O'Shaughnessy of Ireland, who has run the season's fastest indoor mile and 1,000yard race, will face John Walker of New Zealand the Olympic champion, in the 1,500meter run at the United States Olympic invitation track meet Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Farova Dismissal Protested
description: Thirtyfive West European and American photographers have called on the Czechoslovak Government to reinstate Anna Farova.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: JAPANESE ASSESSED BY COMMON MARKET
Defenders Sing Hymn's Praises
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)Hymns are not good poems, a representative of the beleaguered Poet Laureate of Britain said today in defense of the Jubilee Hymn that the poet wrote in honor of the 25th anniversay of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1977

title: White House Says WeatherCrisis Layoffs Totaled 1.8 Million at Height
description: President Carter's Cabinet meeting was told yesterday morning that 1,800,000 Americans had been forced out of work by the ravages of winteroand the natural gas shortage by the end of last week, just before hundreds of thousands began returning yesterday.

title: Protest Against Giscard Is Broken Up in Brittany
description: DINAN, France, Feb. 7 (UPI)Police today dispersed a noisy leftist demonstration marking the start of a twoday visit to Brittany by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Costs and Avid Interest Said to Lift Olympic Price
description: It was not the shrewdness of Soviet negotiators that caused the fees for the rights for the 1980 Summer Olympics to reach a record $85 million, but rather inflation and the growing interest of American audiences in the Olympic events, Herbert S. Schlosser, president of NBC, said yesterday at a news conference.

title: People and Business
description: Wendell Spence, a senior engineer at the Nitron division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has become an issue. He has been named in a suit filed in Superior Court in California by the NCR Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, where he previously worked. The suit seeks to enjoin him, as well as McDonnell Douglas, from using what NCR termed valuable proprietary trade secrets, to which Dr. Spence allegedly had access.

title: Hugh Shannon, Singing Pianist, Brings Talent to Cocktail Lounge
description: Hugh Shannon, who is the last of the great saloon singers and the progenitor of the contemporary line of singing pianists, is back in town in, of all places, the cocktail lounge of Chinese restaurant, David K.'s Chung Kuo Yuan, Third Avenue at 65th Street. There is really nothing particularly Chinese about the room to begin with, and once Mr. Shannon gets behind his piano, the atmosphere is pure Shannon.

title: Margaret Redfield Dies in Chicago Noted for Study on American Family
description: Margaret Park Redfield, an anthropologist closely associated with the work of her late husband, Robert Redfield, who was Hutchins Distinguished Professor of Anthrlopology at the University of Chicago, died Sunday in Chicago. She was 78 years old.

title: Spain Is Reported to Near Soviet Diplomatic Ties
description: MADRID, Feb. 7The Spanish Government is about to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet. Union for the first time since the Spanish Civil War of the 1930's, a high government source said today. An announcement is expected after Cabinet approval.

title: Article 4  No Title
Bell Unit Refunding Places $490 Million
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that the four Bell System subsidiaries seeking to refinance $630 million of highcoupon bonds were successful in purchasing $490 million of the securities. A.T.&T. described the savings in interest expense as substantial.

title: N. F. L. Owners Set to Aid Players Retired Before '59
description: PROVIDENCE. R.I., Feb. 7 (AP)The National Football League club owners have agreed to supplement the income of players who retired before 1959 and are age 65 or older, Bill Dudley announced today. The supplementary payment. Dudley said, is intended to provide the player with a total income of $10.000.

title: Judge Richard B. Austin, 76, Dies
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI)Richard B. Austin, senior judge of the Federal District Court here, died today at Ingalls Hospital in Harvey, Ill. He was 76 years old. Judge Austin had been ill for many weeks and had worked on a reduced caseload in recent months.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
Israel Is About to End Excavation Near Temple Mount
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7  A major nineyearold archeological excavation on the periphery of the ancient wall of Jerusalem's Old City. near the historic Temple Mount is, coming to a close after yielding tightly compacted layers of civilization touching, on ancient Jews, Romans, Byzantine Christians, Moslem Arabs, Crusaders and Turks.

title: Dave Anderson
Not Yet to the Licklog
description: A leftish Democrat not yet born again in the Carter faith, while recently questioning the new President's commitment to various reforms, paused long enough to observe:

title: The Democrats OneHorse Primary Sleigh
description: The election of a Mayor of the City of New York in danger of being settledforgive the phraseby default.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fourteen persons were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on obscenity charges stemming from the alleged sale of pornographic films, several of which depicted young children engaged in sexual acts. Eight of the defendants, whose arrests were announced early last month, were indicted on felony charges for the wholesale sale of obscene material to two undercover police officers who operated a pornographic book store near Times Square. One of those indicted, Edward Mishkin. who has a history of obscenity convictions, was sentenced last month to 27 weekends in jail after pleading guilty to a felony obscenity charge.

title: Workers in the Netherlands Strike Over Wages
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 7 (UPI)Thousands of workers went on strike throughout the Netherlands today to protest the refusal of employers to give automatic costofliving raises in 1977 contracts.

title: ExStudent, Now an ExPresident, Returns to Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7Gerald R. Ford returned today to the College campus where he coached football and studied law four decides ago, and he took the occasion to express regret for one of his. more controversial acts while President.

title: ExStudent, Now an ExPresident, Returns to Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7Gerald R. Ford returned today to the college campus where he coached football and studied law four decades ago, and he took the occasion to express regret for one of his more controversial acts while President.

title: Concert: In Honor of Composers
description: The American Composers Alliance celebrated its 40th anniversary last night in Alice Tully Hall. There were speakers, Aaron Copland among them. There were narrators, and a good orchestra. There was a world premiere, two New York premieres and a work commemorating the early years of the A.C.A.

title: Stroessner's Party in Paraguay Wins Election by a Wide Margin
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Colorado Party of President Alfredo Stroessner, ruler of Paraguay for the last 23 years, has won a comfortable victory in an election for a new constituent assembly.

title: ADM. TURNER PICKED BY CARTER TO HEAD INTELLIGENCE AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  President Carter nominated today Adm. Stansfield Turner, who has made a reputation as a military analyst, to be Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Montclair Chamber Orchestra Excels in First of 3 Concerts
description: The first of three concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Montclair College Chamber Orchestra, Sunday night, provided a short survey course in modern music since World War II. The welldrilled orchestra, made up of faculty members and students of the New Jersey school, played four pieces, each of which epitomized its decade.

title: Leyland Output Halted
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)British Leyland Ltd. said production of car bodies at its Castle Bromwich plant was still halted. Some 1,300 workers walked out today in a dispute over transfer of paint shop workers. The new strike has threatened the return of 2,100 employees on mini production lines at Longbridge who were laid off last week because of two other Castle Bromwich disputes.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
Taxes & Accounting Who Will Conduct Audit of City?; Taxes and Accounting: A Dispute Arises on Who Will Audit the City
description: As New York City prepares for the first fullfledged independent audit of its financesthe largest municipal audit ever attempteda politically sensitive dispute is taking shape over who should carry out the pathbreaking endeavor.

title: Defense Chief Runs Hard to Over take Rabin for Israeli Nomination
description: JERUSALEM, Feb, 7For weeks now. Shimon Peres has been shuttling between Israel's big towns and its boondocks, buttonholing members of the country's Labor Party at kaffeeklatches, conclaves, committee meetings and argumentative gatherings of citizens voluble about where they think the country should be heading.

title: Assemblyman to Offer a Bill Allowing 24Hour Bars
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7The chairman of the Assembly Commerce Committee will introduce a bill this week to allow legitimate bars to stay open around the clock, a move he says would drive illegal afterhours bottle clubs out of business.

title: Florida Local Reinstates Teamsters Expelled Over Dissident Literature
description: Two rebel unionists, expelled from a Florida teamsters local on charges arising out of their circulation of insurgent literature, have been reinstated on instructions from the parent International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Market Place
description: A steadfast commitment to growth stocks in a fiveyear period of declines for such issues has blemished the oncesparkling record of the T. Rowe Price mutual funds.

title: Big 10. Sets Playoff Date In Case of Conference Tie
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Big 10 has arranged tentatively for a playoff game March 8 to determine its representative in the National Collegiate basketball tournament should two eligible teams tie in the conference race, commissioner Wayne Duke said today.

title: CARTER SUBMITS 3 NAMES FOR SENATE CONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)PresIdent.Carter today sent three nominations to the Senate for confirmation, including that of W. Graham Claytor Jr. as Secretary of the Navy.

title: A Critical Control Board Blocks New York City Hospitals Budget
description: The revised financial plan of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation was, in effect, rejected yesterday by the State Emergency Financial Control Board on the ground that it was balanced by what the board's executive director described as false hopes and wish money.

title: About New york
description: Mugging can become a very analytical business in the retelling.

title: California Project Spurs Teachers to Improve Methods With the Objective of Better Writing in High Schools
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.  Writing courses have become so popular at Los Lomas High School in this bedroom community on the edge of San Francisco's surburan sprawl that students now have to be screened to get into the oversubscribed classes.

title: Major Narcotics Dealer Who Fled From Jail in74 Is Recaptured in Miami
description: Federal agents have captured Ernest Malizia, a major narcotics dealer who escaped from a Federal jail in Manhattan with the help of a Catholic priest more than two years ago.

title: December Consumer Debt Surged to 3Year High
From Leather jacket to Tights: The Fonz Makes It in Stratford
description: STRATFORD, Conn.  Aaayay. There he was, the Fonz, standing in, of all places, the American Shakespeare Festival Theater here, talking with, of all people, a man who looked just like William Shakespeare.

title: 65DEGREE HEAT ORDERED IN NEW YORK CITY SCHOOLS
description: In hopes of converting a 3degree shift into, a:10 percent fuel consumption reduction; the Board of Education has ordered the lowering of thermostats in all New York City schools to 65 degrees, effective Wednesday.

title: I.C.C. ASKS CONTROL OF RAIL TAKEOVERS
U.S. Says Most of Its Aid To New York City Seems Beyond Reach of Slashes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The great bulk of Federal assistance to New York City, estimated at $2.8 billion this fiscal year, is unlikely to be affected by the city's slashes in its budget, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: House Panel Finds Big Rise in Drug Use by New York's Schoolchildren
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A Congresslonal committee on drug abuse has found a very substantial increase in narcotics use among New York City schoolchildren in the last year year and a half from the seventh grade on up.

title: Results in Today's Steelworker Vote Expected to Have a Broad Impact
Jenner Decisive Winner of Sullivan Award
description: Bruce Jenner knew from past experience that the Sullivan Award was usually given out in early February. He knew this because the award was always given out to other people. Even last yearafter he had set a world record in the decathlonthe Sullivan Award found its way to someone else's trophy cabinet; it went to. Tim Shaw. the swimmer.

title: Carey's Tough BlockingBack at City Hall
description: Well before. Stephen Berger arrived home last March to run interference for Governor Carey on New York City's budget, his reputation for political and bureaucratic slugfests, had preceded him. Nothing much has happened to disappoint his fans or to mollify his critics.

title: M. DORLAND DOYLE
description: M. Dorland Doyle, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange and a founding part owner of the Washington Redskins football team, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 825 Fifth Avenue and in Southampton, L.I. A native of Chicago, he was educated at Phillips Andover Academy and served in the Army. Signal Corps aviation service in World War I.

title: College Basketball
Carter Warns Against a False Sense of Security on Energy Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  President Carter warned, today that the nation's energy problems remained critical despite ,moderating weather and the reopening of schools and plants in some areas of the country.

title: World Cup Ski Race Off
description: ST. ANTON, Austria, Feb. 7 (AP) The Kandahar World Cup downhill race, rescheduled from Saturday, was postponed today because of too much snow on the track. The event has been rescheduled for Feb. 18 at Laax, Switzerland.

title: Van Ness and Public Service Co. Disagree on Future Power Needs
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7The State Public Advocate and the state's largest electric utility disagreed sharply today over future power needs and the relative merits of nuclear energy and coal as fuels for leectricity generating plants.

title: City U., N.Y.U. and Columbia Planning a Joint Venture on Doctoral Level
For 23 Members of Three Families Stranded Together in Blizzard, a Rural House Became a Dormitory
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.. Feb. 7Twentythree members of three large families thrown together by a pounding blizzard and stranded for 10 days in a fiveroom rural house described their snowbound captivity today and offered tributes to one another and accounts of sharing rather than suffering.

title: Hajek, Prague Dissident, Reports Support Within Czechoslovakia
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 7One of Czechoslovakia's leading campaigners for human rights said today that he and his friends, deprived by the authorities of driver's licenses and telephones, had to use public transportation and walk a lot to keep in touch.

title: 1st Safire Novel in Paperback Said to Bring Over $1 Million
description: Ballantine Books Inc. paid over $1 million during a telephone auction yesterday to obtain the rights to pubilsh the paperback edition of William Safire's novel Full Disclosure, according to Morton L. Janklow, Mr. Safire's lawyer and literary agent. Mr. Janklow said he believed the price was the largest single advance ever paid for a first novel.

title: Notes on People
description: Arthur Krim, the lawyer who is chairman of United Artists Corporation, was elected chairman of the trustees of Columbia University yesterday, succeeding William E. Peterson, who stepped down after nine years service. Mr. Krim, a senior partner in the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon, was elected at the trustees regular February meeting to become the 22d chairman since Columbia's founding as King's College in 1754. ire has been a trustee since 1967. Mr. Petersen, retired president of the Irving Trust Company, had asked the board to elect a successor in anticipation of his mandatory retirement at the age of 72 next year.

title: Crews Struggling to Keep More Oil  From Leaking Out of Hudson Barge
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 7Salvage crews struggled today to keep more heavy industrial heating oil from spilling out of a barge that struck a submerged rock ledge just north of here and has spewed a 30milelong trail of oil up and down the Hudson River.

title: Events/Sports
description: 2:30 P.M., WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA: President Carter's News Conferene. (Live).

title: WILLIAM R. FARRELL
description: William R. Farrell, an advertising executive who retired as director of the Monsanto Company's marketing services department, died Wednesday in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old.

title: C. Russel Deyo, Vice President Of Public .Relations for A.T. &
description: C. Russel Deyo, vice president of public relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's longlines department, died Saturday at his home in Basking Ridge, N.J. He was 58 years old.

title: WILLIAM DANIEL LANE
description: William Daniel Lane, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam International Inc., 285 Madison Avenue, died Sunday in his home in Franklin Lakes, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 54.

title: Conference Standings
Rangers Recall Bednarski TO Replace Ailing Maloney
description: The Rangers gained some muchneeded respect by winning an intradivision game with the Islanders Sunday night, but they lost a defenseman for four to six weeks when Dave Maloney suffered a deep cut to the bone on his left wrist. He had to undergo surgery yesterday for a severed flexor tendon. The 20yearold, defenseman was injured with 2 minutes 57 seconds left in the game when he fell to the ice and was apparently struck by the skate of Clark Gillies, the Islanders captain.

title: MANILA BEGINS TRIAL OF 2 FOES OF MARCOS
description: MANILA, Feb. 7A major political trial opened here today in a dingy courtroom on an army base outside the capital. The defendants are members of two leading political families and four other men charged with plotting seven attempts on the life of Presdient Ferdinand E. Marcos and fomenting rebellion.

title: Califano Moves to Remove Doctor Who Guided Swine Flu Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Dr. David J. Sencer, who helped develop the muchtroubled swine flu inoculation program, said today that hi had been asked to step aside as director of the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Minnesotans Voting Today on Bergland's House Seat
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 7 (AP)  Voters in the 2S counties of northwestern Minnesota will pick House candidates tomorrow in the first major election of the year. Republicans are hoping it will produce an omen of better things.

title: West, Too, Faces a CrisisDrought
description: DENVER, Feb. 4Rain here is not a casual atmospheric condition; it is a gift of the Gods, wrote Frank Waters, the New Mexican author.

title: Article 5  No Title
Bond Prices Stage Retreat, Closing Little Changed,
description: The credit markets opened trading yesterday with sharp price gains, continuing the strong recovery that began last Thursday. Then, for no discernible reason, the advance stopped, prices drifted back down to close little changed from Friday's levels. Nobody knows whathappened, one corporate bond dealer said. There isn't any explanation for the selloff. It's just a very nervous market.

title: PRESS PHOTOGRAPHERS SELECT PRIZE WINNERS
description: John Cornell Jr. of Newsday and Mel Finkelstein of The Daily News shared top honors as the New York Press Photographers Association announced the winners yesterday of its 41st annual contest for the best news photographs of 1976.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY. FEBRUARY 7, 1977

title: Ramirez Wins, Gottfried Also Tennis Victor
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7 (AP)  Topseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico easily beat Zan Guerry, 61, in the opening round of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis, tournament at the California Club today.

title: Pilot Is Found Guilty In Crash at Stadium
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (AP)The pilot of a light plane that crashed into Memorial Stadium was found guilty today of three of the four charges against him.

title: Cold Hit the Everglades Like Pruning Shears
description: GAINESVILLE. Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)A University of Florida botanist said today that last month's record freeze went through Florida's Everglades like giant pruning shears and caused widespread damage to exotic plants.

title: Meadowlands Results
Coroner in Montreal Says Man Hit by Levesque's Car May Have Died Other Way
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 7A man found dead in a Montreal street after being run over by a car driven by Premier Rena Lavesque may have been killed by another impact, according to a coroner's report issued tonight.

title: Chinese Convene Four National Conferences in Peking in Drive to Modernize the Defense Establishment
Big. A Mishap Sets Up $52,459 Triple Payoff
description: As if they were tumbling off a ride at an amusement park, four jockeys spilled to the ground in the final. race at Aqueduct yesterday and inadvertently set up a $52,459 triple payoff. The return was the Big A's largest on $2 bet.

title: Tanzanians Are Resolutely Ideological on Every Subject
Bookie Accused of Killing TV Editor Because Victim Wanted to Quit Gambling
description: A bookmaker was accused yesterday of killing an ABCTV film editor in 1975 because the editor wanted to quit betting while he was ahead.

title: Catholic Missions of Rhodesia: A Major Role Since Colonial Era
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Feb. 8The massacre of seven missionaries at the St. Paul's Mission northeast of here was a blow to the Roman Catholic church, which has been at the forefront of moves to improve the lives of Rhodesia's 6.2 million blacks.

title: Weit's Fight Against Inflation Slow And Uneven, O.E.C.D. Data Show
description: The Western industrial nations are making only slow and uneven progress in their struggle against inflation, according to figures published yesterday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris.

title: Warren D. Chandler, ExSecretary Of New York Publishers Group
description: Warren D. Chandler, who was secretary of the Publishers Association of New York City for 22 years, died last Wednesday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had been living since 1973. He was 68 years old and a former resident of Larchmont. N.Y.

title: Foreman, Young Get Ring Date
description: George Foreman, the topranked heavyweight contender, will face the No. 3 contender, Jimmy Young. March 17, in a televised 12round bout at Landover. Md.. ABCTV announced yesterday.

title: MANNED SPACECRAFT LAUNCHED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7The Soviet Union launched a manned Soyuz spacecraft today to try far a new rendezvous with an orbiting space station, following up on an unsuccessful docking attempt last October.

title: Kings Seek Investigation Of Fight in Pistons' Game
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Kansas City Kings general manager, Joe Axelson, said today he had requested an investigation by the National Basketball Association into a fight that broke out during yesterday's game between the Kings and Detroit Pistons.

title: ADM. TURNER PICKED BY CARTER TO HEAD INTELLIGENCE AGENCY
Stage: Castaways Had an Idea
description: A good idea, even a great idea, never hurt a musical. Yet oddly enough, a good idea, even a great idea, never saved a musical. Castaways, a musical that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, has a tremendous idea behind it. But nothing really before it.

title: Company Reports
College .Results
Corporation Affairs
description: Racal Electronics of Britain and Applied Digital Data Systems are running neck and neck in their bid to acquire a majority of the shares of the Milgo Electronics Corporation.

title: Advertising
description: It's got a terrific amount of residual awareness, mothers remember with great fondness and it's one of the few construction toys that appeals to girls as well as boys.

title: Music: Brehm's Quarks in New York Premiere
description: Music is a tricky and unstable amalgam of science and mystery, of mathematics and the black arts. So Alvin Brehm was on solid ground in naming his new chamber work Quarks. For, you see, quarks are not only subatomic particles hypothesized by nuclear physicists, but mysterious items referred to by Joyce in Finnegans Wake (Three Quarks for Muster Mark). Since atomic physicists have long relied on such poetic constructs to explain the universe to themselves, if not to us, Mr. Brehm's synthesis seemed promising. The nucleus of an idea was there, at least.

title: The Program
description: AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA, Dennis Russell Davies, conductor; Susan Davenny Wyner, soprano; Lou Harrison and Virgil Thomson, narrators. Presented by the American Composers Alliance at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Westchester Tax Action Put Off
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 7The Westchester Board of Legislators, confused and in disagreement over the impact that a taxabatement program for business and industry would have on homeowners tax bills, today scheduled a. special Wednesday meeting to consider the plan and vote on it.

title: Carter Returns to Composer Series
description: Elliott Carter, who returned to the Composers Showcase series at the Whitney Museum Sunday night, referred in his introductory remarks to a turning point in his music in the late 1940s from a more accessible style to one that was inwardly concerned. Inward it may be, and even elitist. But you couldn't have discerned that from Sunday's crowd, which overflowed the hall and spilled into standing room at the sides.

title: Michigan Downs Minnesota by 8680 For a Commanding Lead in Big Ten
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP)Steve Grote drilled a baseline jump shot to snap an 8080 tie with one minute 33 seconds left tonight and then made a key steal in the final minute to give fifthranked Michigan an 8680 victory over eighthranked Minnesota.

title: Rhodesians, Black and White, Express Profound Disgust at the Murder of Seven Missionaries by Terrorits
description: ST. PAUL'S MISSION, Rhodesia, Feb. 8Black teenagers in school uniforms played happily today yards from the spot where seven Roman Catholic missionaries were slain by black terrorists on Sunday, but among older Rhodesians, black and white, disgust at the killings was profound.

title: Killing of Bulls Asked in Portugal
description: LISBON, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Portugal's bullfighters union asked the Government today to break with nearly two centuries of tradition and restore the willing of bulls in the ring. Portugal's 220 professional bullfighters outlined their case in a document given to the Director General of Entertainment. The ban was imposed in 1799.

title: GERMAN MISSILE UNIT TRAINS AT FORT BLISS
description: FORT BLISS, Tex.A Nike surfacetoair missile rockets into the Texas sky, wits one, exception no different from a thousand others fired on the McGregor range. The exception is the Prussian cross on one of the tail planes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported yesterday in The Times that a new contract for the city's teachers granted an average of $4,198 in wage adjustments over three years. The $4,198 figure includes benefits other than wages, and the city says the total cost will be substantially offset by concessions made by teachers.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1977

title: Carter on Arms: Balancing Urgency With a Wooing of Congress
Article 3  No Title
description: HOSTAGE: Richard Hall, right, forced at gunpoint down an Indianapolis street by a man identified as Anthony Kiritsis. Hepless police escorted them. Mr.

title: Tanzania's Leader Explains BreakUp Of African Union
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 8 (UPI)President Julius K. Nyerere said today that Tanzania had closed its border with Kenya in retaliation against a series of Kenyan actions that, he charged, were breaking up East Africa.

title: BRITISHINDUSTRY REPORT CITES PROFITABILITY DROP
Catholic 95, Wagner 68
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Catholie University overwhelmed Wagner College, 9568, tonight as Glenn Kolonics scored 27 points and Stan Cooper scored 21 for Catholic.

title: WOMAN KILLED BY STONE HURLED TO DRIVE BELOW
description: A 24yearold woman died of massive internal injuries last night after she was struck in the stomach earlier in the day by a 19pound cobblestone that was apparently thrown from a footbridge above the East River Drive as she was being driven home from work.

title: March Coffee Futures off 6 Cents
How to Prepare Chocolates the Dark and the Milk and Dipped Fruits and Nuts
description: How to Make Dark Chocolate for Dipping and Molding

title: Mark Twain Book Leads Class to Give To Neediest Cases
Dollar Off a Bit in Europe Because of Uncertainties About Effect of U.S. Winter
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)The dollar eased on European money markets today while the price of gold rose by $1 in Zurich and went up slightly in London.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IMAGINE TWO noble stags, hooves kicking at the grass, facing each other, ready to do battle for the affections of a pretty doe. One of them has seen many mating seasons come and go, but he remains in the full vigor of his maturity. Beneath his whitening pelt beats the heart of an ardent swain. The other is younger, stronger perhaps, but doubtful as to whether he wants to challenge the king of the forest.

title: $1.3 Million in Questionable Fees Cited by T.W.A. and Subsidiaries;
A Listing of Recently Published Books
Thru the Looking Glass
description: ROMEThe Italian Communist Party (PCI) is convinced the Carter Administration will change Washington's previdus attitude of the cold shoulder, according to Sergio Segre; the PCI's principal foreign policy expert. He says the old gap is already closing and expects there will be a more forthright relationship between his party and the incoming ambassador, Prof. Richard N. Gardner.

title: Wake Forest Upset, 7066, By Clemson
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 8 (UPI)Clemson's Stan Rome scored 15 points tonight and the Tigers parlayed their freethrow shooting into a 7066 upset of Wake Forest in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: Church's Ties With Manila Strained
description: MANILA, Feb. 8Strain in the relations between President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martiallaw Government and the Roman Catholic Church appears to be mounting following the reading from every pulpit in this overwhelmingly Catholic nation of a pastoral letter critical of Government measures in a number of fields.

title: Musgrave Opera to Have American Premiere
description: The Voice of Ariadne, an opera by Thea Musgrave, will be given its first American performance by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater on Sept. 30. Miss Musgrave will conduct, the stage director will be Colin Graham, and the designer will be Carl Toms. The cast will be announced later.

title: Careers
Corporation Affairs
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that its pipeline subsidiary would build a $1.55 billion, 750mile line across Saudi Arabia to reduce shipping time for oil to Europe and the United States.

title: Ledlie Laughlin, Aide at Princeton
description: Ledlie I. Laughlin, freshman adviser and associate director of admissions at Princeton University from 1928 to 1953, died Monday at his home in Princeton He was 86 years old.

title: Unmarried Households Found to Be 1.3 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)The number of American men and women living together out of wedlock has more than doubled since 1970 and now totals more than one million, the Census Bureal reported today.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: DON'T BE PUT OFF by the academic title of Julian Jaynes's The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind. Its prose is always lucid and often lyrical. Its extraordinary thesis can be explained, with a bit.of oversimplification, to any layman. Human consciousness. argues Professor Jaynes, is not what any previous theory has cracked it up to benot a property of matter or protoplasm, or a product of emergent evolution or a reticular activating system. Nor does consciousness serve the functions we tend to attribute to it: It is not a copy of experience; it is not necessary for learning or thinking, and it does not occupy space in the head or heart. Indeed, Professor Jaynes proposes, consciousness is not even necessary to behavior.

title: Plan to Temporarily Employ 2,700 Begins in Chaos
description: A program to provide 2,700 temporary jobs for unemployed people in New York City got off to a chaotic start yesterday with thousands of applicants lining, up at three job centers and many leaving because they were toldoften mistakenly, it now appearsthat they were ineligible for consideration.

title: 2 Suits by Nevada Publisher Show Tangle of Hughes Deals
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Fp. 8When Howard R. Hughes came here in 1866, his complicated political and bsiness involvements quickly led him into a working relationship with Hank Greenspun, the ownerpublisher of The Las Vegas Sun. In recent weeks, that relationship has been spread over the records of two courts that are attempting to unravel those tangles and dispense justice.

title: 2 Grants and FundRaising Aid Hermitage Restoration
description: HOHOKUS, Feb. 8The gray wall plaster has been chipped away and left in large piles inside the landmark manor house known as The Hermitage, exposing aged beams of chestnut and oak and building stones mortared together with mild and straw in 1720 and 1845.

title: India's Freed Political Prisoners Tell What Life in Jail Was Like
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 8One afternoon late last month, almost 19 months to the day after he was arrested under India's state of emergency, a 24yearold law student named Arun Jaitley was told abruptly to pack up and leave his cell in the Delhi jail.

title: NEW YORK IS ORDERED TO BEGIN REPAYMENT OF NOTES IN 30 DAYS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8The State Court of Appeals today ordered New York City to begin paying some of the holders of its $1 billion in overdue notes within 30 days an order meaning in effect that the city will have to come up with several hundred million dollars by the end of next month.

title: McBride Takes Apparent Big Lead In Vote for Steelworker President
description: PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, Feb. 9Lloyd McBride, the official family candidate for president of the United Steelworkers of American, appeared today to have taken a substantial lead in his race against Ed Sadlowski, the insurgent candidate who has attacked the union's leadership.

title: Trenton Officials Seek New Gas Sources for Industry
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8State officials met today with the heads of major industrial customers of the South Jersey Gas Company whose supplies of natural gas were virtually cut off three weeks ago in an effort to help them locate new sources of gas so as to resume normal operations.

title: SHIPPING AND MAILS
description: INCOMING

title: Hustler Editor Gets 7 Years
description: Larry C. Flynt, editor and publisher of Hustler, a national men's magazine, was found guilty in Cincinnati yesterday of engaging in organized crime and pandering obscenity. He was sentenced to to 25 years in prison and fined $10,000 on the organized crime charge and six months in jail and $1,000 on the obscenity charge.

title: Panama's Chief Meets With Zone Employees
description: PANAMA, Feb. 8 (AP)  Panama's leader has met with representatives of United States employees in the Canal Zone and appointed a commission to keep workers informed of negotiations on a new canal treaty.

title: Young Americans to Visit China
description: DENVER, Feb. 8 (UPI)An official of the Colorado Academy, a private school here, said today that 16 students who would be traveling to China later this month would he the youngest group of Americans to visit that country. The students range in age from 11 to 14 and each has attempted to become an expert on some aspect of China.

title: Reform by Madrid Opens the Way To the Legalization of Most Parties
description: MADRID, Feb. 8The Government announced a major reform of Spain's restrictive politicalassociation law tonight, opening the way to the legalization of most parties including, possibly, the Communists.

title: 2 Congress Panels Vote Rise in Funds for Jobs And Public Works Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Senate and House committees today voted major increases in President Carter's public works and jobs creation program after the President had expressed confidence earlier in the day that Congress would approve an acceptable version of his program.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW SIZABLE INCREASES
Sudanese Leader Ousts Cabinet In Wake of Attack in South
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 8 (AP)President Gaafar alNimeiry dismissed his Prime Minister and the rest of his Cabinet today, the presidential press office said. Mr. Nimeiry asked Prime Minister Rashid elTapir to continue in a caretaker status until a new Cabinet was formed, a statement added.

title: For an Immovable Primary
description: Because the setting forth of dates and conditions for primary elections in New York State lies within the hands of the Legislature, which is able to change the rules at will, the votersand candidatesof the state are now in considerable confusion about the rules for this year's campaign. The supporters of those running for the three citywide officesMayor, Comptroller and President of the Councildiffer in their views of the matter, depending on what they think will be of particular benefit. Since there are close ties between factions in the Legislature and the several candidacies, the voters resemble spectators at a tennis match who are not sure that the lines won't be redrawn, depending on who is serving, and who his friends are.

title: Arms Nominee Under Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8His friends call him brilliant a master with words, incisive, and a bold thinker. Critics find Paul C. Warnke too dovish, too soft on the Russians, and not qualified as an expert on strategic arms. These differing views have been expressed in recent days since President Carter chose the 57 yearold Washington lawyer as his nominee for the post of director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency with responsibility as chief negotiator in strategic arms talks with the Russians.

title: 10 Say They Are Candidates for Young's Seat in House
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 8The scramble for the Fifth Congressional District seat vacated by Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, appears to be shaking down into a racial but not racistbattle among four candidates, two white and two black.

title: Not for Chocaholics Only
description: There is a fad word of recent coinage that does not appear in any recognized dictionaries but is gaining more and more currency among people with an interesting addiction. These people call themselves chocaholics because they cannot resist chocolate in any of its myriad forms (though, generally, they prefer it in the form of candy ranging in color from dusky beige to mahogany, and Wacker). Now Valentine's Day, that holiday that less than a week away, is, of course, a time when givingand gettingfancy gift boxes bulging with chocolate is traditional. But for chocoholics, dreaming is a yearround exercise. not something to limit to special occasions. These are people who will oft arise from a couch of slumber to dip fingers reflectively into a chocolate box they keep handyor softshoe their way to the refrigerator where they may have placed that box the night before.

title: Goal by Trottier Starts Islanders To 4to1 Triumph Over the Kings
Yevgeny Nikolayevich Dolmatov
description: When Irving Rudd answered the telephone he was told a cablegram had arrived from Moscow. It read: Dolmatov died cable Moscow Hippodrome if you can Regards Dmitri Urnov. Irving said thank you and hung up slowly. He felt as though he had lost a father, and in a way he had. A second father, anyway. There was a time when Yevgeny Nikolayevich Dolmatov was wont to crunch his young American friend in a bear hug and call Irving his boy, and in the years between 1963 and 1970 Irving came to feel an almost filial affection for the burly excavalryman.

title: Music: Italians Beethoven
description: The Quartetto Italiano inaugurated a sixconcert series of the complete Beethoven string quartets Monday night at. the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. The series will continue tomorrow and Feb. 17 with the Italian group, and with the Juilliard Quartet March 22 and 29 and April 19. Each program offers selected examples from different periods in Beethoven's creative life.

title: About Education
description: SYRACUSEWilfred Wagner, who is 11 years old, dislikes sitting at a school desk. When he does his assignments he likes to spread his feet far apart and lean over his work with his elbows on the table.

title: Kohout Fears the Czechs Will Stage Political Trials
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 8Pavel Kohout, the playwright whose works are banned in Czechoslovakia, expressed concern today that the Government might stage political trials to crush the movement around Charter 77. a human rights declaration.

title: John Jay 76, RutgersNewark 63
description: Ted Gustus scored a gamehigh 31 points as John Jay College beat visiting RutgersNewark, 7663, last night. He connected on nine of 11 shots from the field and 13 of 14 from the foul line.

title: With Training Camp a Week Off, Cosmos Sign 2 Yugoslav Stars
description: Those frequent trips to Europe between visits to South America have finally paid dividends for Gordon Bradley, the head coach of the Cosmos, who announced yesterday the signings of two players from Yugoslavia.

title: When the Sun Sets,They Get Started
description: George Booth, the cartoonist, writes hourly reports so that he knows where his time goes. Charlemagne Palestine, a contemporary composer whose creative spirit works best at night, has blacked out all the windows in his loft so that, psychologically at least, there is no day. And Virgil Thomson, the composerwriter, has his telephone calls filtered through his hotel switchboard, denying him the temptation to while away work hours chatting.

title: HOUSE PANEL OPENS WAY FOR KOREA BRIBE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 8 (UPI)The House Rules Committee today opened the way for an investigation to determine if South Korean agents gave Congressmen bribes, gifts and kickbacks to shore up the military government In Seoul.

title: Kings Point 78, Brooklyn 65
description: Tony Litka and Jim Cronin combined for 50 points as Kings Point rushed Brooklyn College, 7865, last night. Kings Point lifted its record to 125.

title: 4 Concerns Are Convicted In Grain Fraud Inquiry
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8Three grain exporting companies and a grain elevator concern that they own jointly Were convicted here today on Federal charges of conspiring to shortweight shipments to foreign customers over a sixandahalfyear neriod endine last June.

title: Living Abroad: Mexico City
description: WITH FEWER BABIES, husbands who are a little less macho, and as many maids as ever, Mexico's bored society women have thought up a new way of getting through the dayby working.

title: The Causes of an Uncommon Citizen
description: John Gardner's announcement that he would retire this spring as chairman of Common Cause bore a typical touch of highminded understatement. Every organization must renew itself, he said of the news that led others to envision the removal of a major institution from the public scene. It is not an institution, however, that is leaving the scene, merely a single citizen. And the significance of the event rests precisely upon that fact.

title: A. H. Raskin
Otto Schoenrich, 100, Dies At His Home in Baltimore
description: Otto Schoenrich, retired senior partner in the Baltimore law firm of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosley, died yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 100 years old.

title: 2 Kidnapped Sisters Are Rescued. In a Paterson Motel
description: A 13yearold girl and her 23yearold sister were rescued by the police in a Paterson motel room early yesterday morning, three hours after they had been abducted at gunpoint by four men in a shopping mall parking lot in nearby Paramus.

title: Iran Said to Review Arms Buying in U.S. Because of Oil Lag
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: New York Senate Votes to Set Up A June Date for the 1977 Primary
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8The State Senate today passed a bill establishing a June date for this year's primary, after defeating amendments that would have made the change permanent and would have retained a runoff in the New York City mayoral race in case there was no clear victor.

title: PRESIDENT OUTLINES PROPOSALS FOR ARMS PACT WITH SOVIET, ASKS A HALT IN UNDERGROUND TESTING; QUICK ACCORD SOUGHT Carter Would Defer lssue of Russian Bomber and U.S. Cruise Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President Carter offered today to reach a quick agreement with the Soviet Union on a ceiling for strategic weapons by, postponing consideration of whether a Sovietbomber and the American cruise missile should be counted within the limits.

title: Music: School by Day, Concert Hall at Night
description: THERE ARE more places on the island of Manhattan than are dreamed of where firstrate concerts are performed. In a town house at 323 West 108th Street on certain Monday nights for example. you can hear artists of the caliber of the pianist Emanuel Ax and the Cornnosers Ouartet.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The very nicest valentines are cards drawn by children, and a kiss or two or three from a loved one. Also acceptable are a car and chauffeur, a fulltime cook, unlimited credit at a book store and big, shiny, caratful baubles. Most other things are small time but as, alas, most of us are small time, let's consider what's around.

title: Child's World
description: IT HAPPENS around the 73d or 74th playing of Frosty the Snowman on the living room stereo. You're faced with a choice: an Frosty altogether, or designate certain periods of the day when the record can be played, or buy a record player for the children's room.

title: Nicholson and Kubrick To Team in New Film
description: Two illustrious names in film circles the actor Jack Nicholson and the director Stanley Kubrickwill team up to make a movie based on The Shining, a novel by Stephen King. It will be filmed under the auspices of the Producer Circle CompanyMary Lea Johnson, Marty Richards, Robert Fryer and James Cresson.

title: SOME IN HOUSE PROTEST PAY RISE FOR CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)After in suring that a $13,000 Congressional pay rise cannot be blocked, the House provided a forum today for members who wan to go on record against it.

title: Notes on People
description: THE French actress Jeanne Moreau was married in Paris yesterday to William Friedkin, the American director of The French Connection and The Exorcist. Witnesses to the civil ceremony were the French director Alain Resnais and his wife, the former Florence Malraux. Miss Moreau, who is 49 years old, and Mr. Friedkin, 38, had been expected to marry for some time.

title: Ban Asked on Children's Wear With Flame Retardant
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8A public interest environmental group petitioned the Consumer Product Safety Commission today to ban immediately the sale of all children's pajamas and other clothing containing the flameretardant chemical Tris on the ground that the chemical was now proved to be a potent cause of cancer.

title: British Admit Irish Were Tortured
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  The British Government conceded today that it had used five torture techniques on detainees in Northern Ireland, but gave a solemn pledge to the European Court of Human Rights that it would never do so again.

title: Baking Out the Blues In Your Own Sauna
description: I can bake out a headache in about five minutes in the sauna, says Gail Merrifield Papp.

title: Soviet Says 2 Astronauts Have Linked Spacecraft With Orbiting Salyut Lab
Active Doctors Get Police Pensions
description: Five physicians, who once worked part time for the Police Department have taken advantage of a heart bill intended for disabled policemen and firemen and are receiving bonus retirement pensions of $21,900 to $25,600 annually from the city.

title: Hoboken Dedicates a Housing Project for the Elderly
description: HOBOKEN, Feb. 8Governor Byrne and other officials joined today in dedicating Marian Towers, a 154unit, $5.8 million housing development for the elderly and the latest in a series of projects springing up in this city with the assistance of state and Federal funds. Mayor Steve Cappiello described the development at First and Adams Streets as another positive step in the revitalization effort of our city.

title: Brooklyn Union Plans to Refund More Than $6 Million to Gas Users
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that it planned to refund more than $6 million to its naturalgas customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island because its profits had exceeded the rate of 13.7 percent permitted by the Public Service Commission.

title: Weber, Bowling Star, Vies With Two Sons on Tour
description: Andy Varipapa, 86yearold retired Hall of Fame bowler, has proven to be far better at knocking over pins than at prophesying. Years ago, when Varipapa first met Dick Weber at a tournament, he told him: You'll never make it. You've got to have bigger, stronger wrists. Weber weighed 135 pounds and stood 5 feet 10 inches.

title: Meadowlands Suspends Three
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Nets Late Rally Fails
Election Panel Suggests Rise in Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Federal Election Commission suggested today that Congress might wish to raise the spending limits imposed on Presidential candidates in the 1976 primary and general elections as well as therFederal subsidies for the two major party political conventions.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Egyptian Party Asks for No Vote
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8For the first time in more than two decades, an officially accredited political party appealed to Egyptian voters today to reject at the polls a measure proposed by the country's president.

title: CURB ON FLU SHOTS EASED BY CALIFANO; Elderly Can Get Bivalent VaccineBHong Kong Moratorium Lifted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Federal Government today lifted part of a sevenweek ban on flu vaccinations but kept it on the main portion of the program.
