description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President Carter hinted broadly today that he would keep his campaign promise to ask Congresg to end Federal regulation of some natural gas prices but would also take steps to prevent gas producers from making unwarranted profits.

title: Youth Gangs Are Trying an AboutFace
description: Two years ago, if George Serrano, leader of the Bronx Chingalings, had run into Akbar, president of the Brooklyn Tomahawks, on the street, they would have been at war.

title: Article 4  No Title
Chess,; What Is a Gambit? And Why? And Even, Perhaps Wherefore?
description: It is bad enough to have an opponent defeat your risky gambit by accepting the offered material and fighting his way through the complications, but when he safely declines the gambit and clobbers you positionally, it is time to ask what the purpose of the venture was to begin with.

title: Lilco Asks 15.7% Power Increase
Big Apple Is Core Of U.S. Culture
description: A report designed to show how all America benefits from New York's cultural stockpile was released yesterday morning by City Hall, with Mayor Hearne making the point that the country should contribute to the upkeep of New York's institutions that spread their artistic resources from coast to coast, and farther.

title: Personal Finance: Automobile Loans
description: BANKERS are forever coining up with new credit packages to accommodate changing needs 48month automobile loans because the old 36month limit does not give some customers enough room to cope with rising auto prices, and variable payment mortgages that help couples tailor monthly charges closer to income.

title: JAPAN PLEDGE CUT IN SHIP PRODUCTION AS AN AID TO EUROPE
ExWest Point Instructor Seizes Realtor in Anger Over Land Deal
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (UPI)A for. mer West Point gun instructor, who said he had been cheated on a real estate deal, abducted the president of a real estate company today and marched him through downtown Indianapolis with a shotgun at his head, then took his hostage to an apartment, where he held off the police.

title: Private Lives
description: IT is Egypt, I am surrounded by cats. They tick like clocks, like bombs. Actually, it is not Egypt. It is the kitchen, at 7 in the morning. I am boiling the coffee in order to feel bad because we are supposed to be boycotting coffee. We boycott South African diamonds instead. The Siamese whines. She is on top of the broom closet. The other, problematical cat, the longhaired black one who recently amazed herself with a litter of kittens, crouches in the middle of the round table, pretending to be profound. Anything that eats flies cannot be profound. The black cat, the wine glass and the peppermill make the table look like a bad Impressionist painting. I sent a memo to God pointing out that kitchen tables should not look like bad Impressionist paintings, at least before breakfast. God did not reply.

title: BURNS SEES PHOBLEM IN FINANCING DEFICIT WITH CURRENT RATES
People and Business
description: Ian J. WestwoodBooth, a British subject, is making plans to purchase and reopen the MidvaleHeppenstall forged steel plant nar Germantown, Pa., which at one point employed 1,000 workers. Mr. WestwoodBooth was unavailable for comment yesterday as he was recovering from some dental work according to a spokesman.

title: Knicks Trounce 107
description: When the Knicks are good, they are very gpod. When they are bad, they are very bad.

title: Mexico Arrests 16 In DrugPricing Inquiry
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 8The Mexican Government has arrested 16 officials and representatives of foreign pharmaceutical companies pending investigation into charges of fraud involving overpriced medicine sold to the Government.

title: Carter and the Press
Task Force on Pornography Running Short of Funds
description: The federally financed task force whose aim is to curb prostitution and pornography in midtown Manhattan is running out of money and may soon shut down.

title: RESIDENT OUTLINES PROPOSALS FOR ARMS PACT WITH SOVIET, ASKS A HALT IN UNDERGROUND TESTING
Hustler Editor Gets 7 Years
description: Larry C. Flynt, editor and publisher of Hustler, a national men's magazine, was found guilty in Cincinnati yesterday of engaging in organized crime and pandering obscenity. He was sentenced to 7 to 25 years in prison and fined $10,000 on the organized crime charge and six months in jail and $1,000 on the obscenity charee.

title: DR. HARRY E. SEANOR JR
description: Dr. Harry Eugene Seanor Jr., a former director of pediatrics at the United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., died suddenly yesterday in his home on Holly Lane. Rye. N.Y. His age was 56.

title: Revision Urged In Tuition Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8The head of New York State's program of tuition assistance for college students testified today that trying to validate the claims of tens. of thousands of students purporting to be financially independent of their parents and, therefore, deserving of grants, had become a vexing problem.

title: Advertising
description: Music, all kinds of music, not only soothes the breast of Bernard Mitchell, but also helps to fill his pockets. So he decided to try to repay this double debt. and advertising is helping.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported yesterday in The Times that a new contract for the city's teachers granted an average of $4,198 in wage adjustments over three years. The $4,198 figure includes benefits other than wages, and the city says the total cost will be substantially, offset by concessions made by teachers.

title: The Ketchup Connection
New Yorkers, etc.
description: ONCE, someone declined an invitation to one of Josh and Nedda Logan's cocktail parties, but that was because he had broken a leg, and he did not feel secure on crutches. Everyone goes to the Logans', and when they do they see everyone they have not seen since the last time they were there. It is how they keep in touch. The other night, the Logans gave a cocktail party for George Weidenfeld, the. London publisher. He is Lord Weidenfeld or Sir George, or just plain George, as in George is back in New York, so let's give him a party. Many people give parties for him, although usually the parties are not so big as the one at the Logans'.

title: Carter. Hints Deregulation of Gas Plus Ban on Unwarranted Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President Carter hinted broadly today that he would keep his campaign. promise to ask Congress to end Federal regulation of some natural gas prices but would also take steps to prevent gas producers from making unwarranted profits.

title: Disks: Remember The HurdyGurdy?
description: The twanging, droning sound of the hurdygurdy is not exactly a staple of our concert life today, but its evocative tones serve wonderfully well to recall not only our medieval past, but the exotic, Oriental influences that fed into the Western musical tradition. The instrument which combines characteristics of both stringed and keyboard instruments emerged in the Middle Ages, fell into disrepute as a beggar's symbol, reappeared in the 18th century, along with the musette (an aristocratic French form of bagpipe), as part of the pastoral revival and seems now to have disappeared into permanent nostalgia. This record isn't likely to change its status, but it is a total charmer, nonetheless.

title: Hampton's Savages To Feature Stephen Joyce
description: Stephen Joyce, starred earlier this season in The Runner Stumbles, will be featured as the anthropologist in the Equity Showcase production of Savages, by Christopher Hampton, opening at the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street, Feb. 24 and continuing through March 13. The play set in Brazil deals with the treatment of the natives there. Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Mark Taper Theater in Los Angeles, will stage the play.

title: REV. JAMES G. KELLER, BEGAN CHRISTOPHERS
description: The Rev. James G. Keller, who founded the Christophers, an ecumenical religious movement, died Monday at New York Hospital of complications arising from Parkinson's disease. The 76yearold priest lived at the Maryknoll Fathers residence at 121 East 39th Street before he was hospitalized last November.

title: WARNKE SAYS HIS AIM ON ARMS REDUCTION IS SECURITY OF U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  Paul C. Warnke pledged to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that if he was confirmed as President Carter's chief arms control negotiator he would seek ways to limit and reduce arms already in existence so as to make this country more secure.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1977

title: Young Attends A Vast Pageant In North Nigeria
description: KADUNA, Nigeria, Feb. 8Drummers sitting on camels pounded a steady beat, golden stallions charged through the dust, and stately emirs. fanned by worshipers under multicolored parasols. raised their spears to cries of adulation from the crowd.

title: U.N. COUNCIL SENDING TEAM TO INVESTIGATE BENIN RAID
description: Special to The New York Times

title: People in Sports
description: Janet Guthrie was named yesterday to drive the fastest car ever run at Indianapolis under current United States Auto Club technical limitations. Miss Guthrie, denied a chance at last year's Indy 500 starting field because of admittedly marginal equipment, will pilot the Lindsey Hopkins Lightning, which Roger McCluskey drove last October at 198.7 miles per hour in tire tests at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. She will compete in the new car at Ontario, Calif., on March 2, and hopes to qualify for the Indy 500 in May.

title: Levesque Is Attacked on Accident
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 8  Premier Ren Levesque acknowledged today that he was undergoing a difficult moment as part of the Montreal press laid direct responsibility on him for the accidental killing of a man Sunday morning and demanded a public inquiry. The Premier's embarrassment was apparent to 2,000 people who attended a luncheon of the Montreal Chamber of Commerce and listened to him urge a collective effort to revive the province's stagnant and unemploymentridden economy.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THE fame of luxury restaurants rests securely on sauces and bases made with costly ingredients. And while these may have reqquired hours, even days, of simmering, sieving and subsequent preparation, there are scores of execptions.

title: In Washington, a Serious Design
Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
COUPLE'S 5 CHILDREN KILLED BY L.I. FIRE
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Deterrents to Curtail. Juvenile Crime Disputed
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (UPI)The juvenile justice system should increase the certainty of punishment for youths who break the law and stop its preoccupation with the human needs of young criminals, a critic of rehabilitation programs says.

title: A Hot Stove And... Daddy!
description: IT occurs to me that an anthropologist might like to do some fieldwork in our kitchen. The natives are friendly and the outlook for grant money is sanguine. On the other hand, a sociologist would be bored silly by what's going on in our kitchen. It does not relate to modern mores, you see. It only looks that way.

title: ...and Where They May Be Found
description: And rarity in and or itself is no prize. At the high prices that the specialties command, customers are entitled to check carefully for the look, feel and aroma of freshness.

Ford to Produce 2 New Systems For Electronic Control of Engine
description: The automobile industry took another step yesterday in its effort to develop electronically optimized engines when the Ford Motor Company announced limited production of two new control systems.

title: Books of The Times Alias Jan Peerce
description: NO MATTER HOW you look at it, Jan Peerce has had an unusual life. He was born Jacob Pincus Perelmuth in a coldwater flat on Orchard Street in 1904 and arrived at the Metropolitan Opera at the age of 37 after having devoted most of his teens and 20's to playing violin in his own dance band on the Lower East Side and in the Catskills and most of his 30's to singing at the Center Theater and Radio City Music Hall and on popular network radio programs. By that time he had gone through so many name changes that would hardly be surprising if he were unable to identify himself with certainty today.

title: Phila. Textile 61, Villanova 57
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP)Emery Sammons scored a teamhigh 19 points tonight to lead Philadelphia Textile to a 6157 upset victory over Villanova.

description: In these days of skyrocketing costs, it's rare to find a free tennis clinic. There is one at Tennis United on East 54th Street, a center that's a rarity in itself.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Music: Guitar Personalized
description: In addition to being a superior technician, Ernesto Bitetti is a distinctively personal guitarist with a supple rhythmic sense and a penchant for understatement. His playing Sunday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. was notable for its undulating tempos and whispered dynamic shadings. Whether or not one agreed with all fo Mr. Bitetti's ideas, they were always tasteful and persuasively implemented.

title: Theater: Truths Captured By Ashes
description: THE PLAY ASHES, by the British writer David Rudkin, which opened officially last night at the Anspacher Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater complex, is probably the most important play of the season. And this is a season that has seen quite a few decent plays. This year, almost all of them have come from Britain.

title: Israeli Arabs Pay Homage To Palestinian Leader
description: TEL AVIV, Feb 8Thousands of Israeli Arabs and WestBank Arabs streamed through a muddy. winding path to a hilltop cemetery in Musmus today to pay their respects to Rashed Hussein, press attache of the Palestine observer group at the United Nations, who died last week in a hotel room fire in New York at age 41.

title: Djilas Bids Europe's Reds Make RightsPlea to Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 8Milovan Djilas, a former leader of the Yugoslav Communist Party, appealed today to West European Communist parties to try to persuade the Belgrade Government to respect human rights.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PAS DE PAVLOVA. Honoring legendary dancer, an exhibit of memorabilia opens tomorrow at the Norman Crider Ballet, Opera and Theater Gallery, 961 Madison Avenue at 75th Street. Most of the items about Anna Pavlova's life and career are also for sale, ranging from $25 and under for programs, photographs and books to upward of $10,000.

title: Best Buys
description: TRYING to find a price lower than the temperature is the sort of quest that will lead bargain hunters this week to the canned food shelves.

title: ExMondale Aide Wins Primary in Minnesota
description: MOORHEAD, Minn., Feb. (AP)Michael J. Sullivan, a former aide to Vice President Mondale, easily, won a fourway Democratic primary today and the right to bid for the House seat vacated by Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland.

title: We are Aristotle's children. Or, colonizing outer space.
description: Colonies in space? The question really shouldn't be raised. For me, anyway, it is selfanswering. Yes, of course. Why not? Let's move. Let's go there. Let's do the job.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I have learned in my first two and half weeks why Abraham Lincoln and some of the older Presidents almost went home when they first got to the White House.President Carter, talking about his difficulties in finding personnel and dealing with Congress early in his Administration. [A16:5.]

title: House Backs MilitaryBonus Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)The House of Representatives approved today a 15month extension of authority for the military to pay enlistment and reenlistment bonuses to those with critical skills. The measure, passed by a voice vote and sent to the Senate, would continue the bonus program beyond its scheduled expiration date of next June 30 to Sept. 30, 1978.

title: Kennedy Center Seeks Minority Participation
description: WASHINGTON The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, under criticism in the past for its failure to attract in its audiences a larger number o1 Washington's 75 percent black population, has announced the formation of a National Commission on Blacks to foster more minority participation in the national cultural showcase at both the performing and audience levels.

title: Topics
description: Every society, as the anthropologists tell us, has its rites of passage signifying the coming of age of a new member or the testing of a new leader. In the American political subculture, the Presidential news conference is a ritual as stylized as a Japanese No play. The chief news out of Mr. Carter's first, almost newsless news conference yesterday was that he demonstrated his mastery of this unique art form.

title: City Officials See No Cause for Alarm in Ruling
description: New York City officials yesterday sought to reassure the public that the latest ruling by the State Court of Appeals on the city's shortterm notes presented no cause for alarm. But they agreed there was now new pressure on all the parties to achieve a solution they had failed to reach for weeks.

title: MOYNIHAN NAMED TO POST ON SENATE FINANCE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 New York's freshman Senator, Daniel P. Moynihan, ended a centuryold jinx for Empire State Democrats tonight. It was rather like the old Brooklyn Dodgers winning the pennant after being alsorans for decades. The Senator confirmed that he had been named to a position on the! Powerful Senate Finance Committee.

title: How Fancy Foods Are Flown In, Out of Season...
description: Just after the new year, a prospective father phoned Joseph Doria, president of Balducci's, the produce and delicacies emporium in Greenwich Vilage, with a frantic plea. It seems that his pregnant wife couldn't do without watermelon  but unfortunately her craving had erupted out of watermelon season.

description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8Gov. Ella T. Grasso today proposed a $1.876 billion budget reflecting the steady improvement in Connecticut's economy, with some modest new initiatives, no new taxes, and provision for the state gradually to take over the cities remaining welfare burden.

description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Otis Birdsong and Cecile Rose combined for 50 points tonight to lead the University of Houston to a 10973 Southwest Conference victory over Rice.

title: Bridge.
description: It has always been recognized that France is one of the world's strongest bridgeplaying countries. In a span of 42 years, the French representatives have won the European team championship seven times, more than the representatives of any other country except Italy.

description: WHITE PLAINSLowell M. Schulman remembers the days only 12 years ago when the interest cost alone on the central Westchester land he bought was greater each year than his annual Income.

title: 2 Kidnapped. Sisters Are Rescued In a Paterson Motel
description: A 13yearold girl and her 23yearold sister were rescued by the police in a Paterson, N.J., motel room early yesterday morning, three hours after they had been abducted at gunpoint by four men in a shopping mall parking lot in nearby Paramus.

title: Vance Rejects a Visa For P.L.O. Official
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has rejected the visa application of a leading official of the Palestine Liberation Organization who had been invited to address a meeting here this weekend, a State Department official said today.

title: Carter, Telling of Woes, Sympathizes With Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8In the middle of his first news conference today, President Carter said he already knew why Abraham Lincoln had almost gone home.

title: CURB ON FLU SHOTS EASED BY CALIFANO

description: Steve Cauthen, the 16yearold jockey who has yet to receive his working papers from the State of New York, did his usual job yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Philadelphia Papers Strike Halts Distribution of One
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (UPI)A strike by 800 editorial, photographic arid business employees of The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News prevented distribution today of The Daily Neivs, but The Inquirer reached newsstands.

title: TV: Tear Jerked by Grizzly
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES of Grizzly Adams (NBC, 8 P.M.) will do. It lukewarms the heart. It is new series, spun off the movie that won NBC a 43 Nielsen share one Monday night last May. Whether, on Wednesdays, another beard and another bear can rough up ABC's bionic ratings is problematic but one hones so.

title: Solomon Wins In Opener at Miami, 63, 63
description: MIAMI. Feb. 8 (AP)Harold SoloMon, who is now tutored by Pancho Segura, brushed off unseeded Rolf Norbert.of Sweden, 63, 63, in the first round of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Stage: Macabre Miming
description: THERE WAS a phosphorescent touch of the macabre about Peter Lobdell's program of mime sketches at the Cubiculo on Monday evening. His fluidly responsive body found images of death by hanging, botched operations and magical mischance considerably more appealing than lighter observations on the human condition. A skull and crossbones had dispossessed the fluttering ribbons of traditional buffoonery on hit personal pennant.

title: How to Pass Time When You Can't Stand the Play
description: SOMETIMES there's nothing left to do in the theater but fantasize. I mean you're sitting there trying to be as attentive as a puppy who thinks he's going to be given part of a pretzel (I don't know about your household pets, but ours invariably develop passions for pretzels and you have to be extremely careful not to give them the curved parts that might catch in their throats) but either the play is droning along or the actors are and there's nary a trace of imagination anywhere in sight. So you begin to do your own imagining, just to pass the time. It's not necessarily very good daydreaming. After all, if you were the creative artist, you wouldn't be sitout front, wool gathering. But it does have some mild therapeutic value until it's time to grab your coat and get out of there.

title: Volvo Fume Device Gives Focus to Debate on Car Makers' Efforts to Cut Pollution
description: DETROIT, Feb. 8As Leonard Woodcock tells it, the question came up in a conversation between him and President Carter some time before Mr. Carter's inauguration. The Presidentelect and the head of the United Automobile Workers were talking about whether the American auto companies could meet tougher pollutioncontrol standards for cars more rapidly than they have been doing.

title: Teaching Is My Bloody Life
description: IN SIMON GRAY'S Otherwise Engaged, the new Broadway comedy hit, a London publisher decides to spend an afternoon listening to a new record of Wagner's Parsifal. The playing of the record is repeatedly interrupted by intruders an obstreperous upstairs tenant, the publisher's schoolteacher brother, a surly poet and his.aggressive mistress. The playing of the record is the plumb line of Mr. Gray's, play. The protagonist would rather hear Wagner in isolation than engage himself in emotional combat. Coolly, he remains aloof.

title: Penn, Princeton to Test Columbia's Young Lions
The U.N. Today
News item: Archeologists say a civilization greater than Pompeii's has been uncovered frozen in ice. It may be ancient Buffalo, N.Y.
description: BUFFALO  Ten years ago, when Buffalo seemed determined to put me behind bars for adVocating decriminalization of marijuana, I was moved to observe that it looked like a disaster area waiting for a disaster. Which was, I guess, just another bad Buffalo joke. Like Our weather. But disaster has come, putting us all behind bars, offlimits to the world which finds us hilarious.

title: British, Enjoying Balmy Days Get Look at Some Dirty Laundry
description: LONDON, Feb. 8This city is downright balmy. It has had two consecutive dry and sunny days with temperatures touching the 50'sideal weather for planting a tree, say, or for digging into the winter's dirty laundry and hanging it out in the goodclean air.

title: Idaho Rescinds Approval Of Eaual Rights Proposal
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 8 (AP)The Idaho Legislature today rescinded its ratification of the equal rights amendment.

description: THERE is an old story about the sailor working his small ketch through the fog in Long Island Sound when, out of the murk, there appears a huge and very new cabin cruiser.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8A twoyear struggle to preserve the old White Plains Courthouse ended early today with an agreement that the landmark be removed or demolished within one month, thu opening the site to development of a major retail complex.

title: Egam Points Up Woes of Italy's State Owned Industries
Nuclear Waste Found Leaking At Site Upstate
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency disclosed yesterday that the practice of burying lowlevel radioactive waste in 20footdeep covered trenches at a site near Buffalo had failed to prevent leakage, but that it posed no immediate hazard to health.

title: Nets Victors In Overtime
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 9By the end of tonight's Nets game at the Nassau Coliseum, the crowd of 5,497 was on its feet chanting an unlikely Bubbles, Bubbles, Bubbles and the Nets had put away the New Orleans Jazz in overtime. 9389.

title: N.F.L. Lions Keep Hudspeth
description: Tommy Hudspeth, who took over as coach of the Detroit Lions in the middle of last season, was given a threeyear contract yesterday. Details on Page 52.

title: HUSTLER CONVICTION IS PONDERED IN OHIO
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9I shouldn't have worn a pinstriped suit today; they'll think I'm in organized crime, joked Jimmy R. Flynt, president of the Flynt Distributing Company, as he walked into his office here this morning.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1977

title: How Senate's Reorganization Plan Was Scaled Down
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Like a row of dominoes that topples from the movement begun by a single falling piece, the farreaching plan to streamline the Senate by reducing its committees from 31 to 15 was knocked down last week by the pressures to reinstate a single committee: Veterans Affairs.

title: Hustler, Freedom and a Benighted Place
description: When the Supreme Court last spoke on obscenity 1973, it in effect authorized communities to establish their own definitions of the prurient or patently offensive in word or picture. Many predicted an era of confusion from the ruling, written by Chief Justice Burger for a 5to4 majority. They denied Mr. Burger's contention that, for the first time in 16 years, the Court had agreed on concrete guidelines to isolate hard core pornography from expression protected by the First Amendment.

title: Article 3  No Title
Madrid Tells Presss To Remain Silent In Terrorist Cases
description: MADRID, Feb. 9The Spanish Government today ordered a news blackout on police investigations into two unsolved political kidnappings and the murders of five Communists and three policemen.

title: 'Dick and Jane' in Screen Romp
description: When Dick Harper (George Segal) loses his job as a Los Angeles aerospace engineer, he and his wife Jane (Jane Fonda) find themselves in the classic bind of the once-upwardly mobile. They have no bank balance, owe $72,000 on their house and have already borrowed the limit on their life insurance. Their swimming pool is still an ugly hole in the ground Jane hopes they can finish it and then economize by not heating it. When they are two months in arrears, the landscape company sends around a crew to remove their plants and trees, and, while they're at it, to roll up the lawn. What to do?Dick and Jane take to crime, which is the point at which you have every right to expect that "Fun With Dick and Jane" is going to stumble over the cuteness of the gimmick that, from the opening credits, has been shadowing the film like a gloomy bill collector. The good news is that it doesn't. "Fun With Dick and Jane," written by David Giler, Jerry Belson and Mordecai Richler, and directed by Ted Kotcheff, is a deceptively sunny, sometimes uproariously funny comedy about the bad taste, vulgarity and awful aimlessness of a certain kind of middle-class American affluence.Buried not very deeply within the film, there is a small flaw. We are asked to like and to sympathize with Dick and Jane, played by Mr. Segal and Miss Fonda with a fine, earnest kind of intensity I associate with good schewball comedy of the past, and we do like them enormously, even though the characters are completely dedicated to maintaining all-wrong values. In this respect, the film seems to want to stand on both sides of the fence at once, to take credit for having a social conscience while not really honoring it. It's not enough for us to be told that Dick and Jane are really ripping off the system. They aren't that believably cynical.This may be taking the film more seriously than anyone intended, though I doubt it. Mr. Kotcheff and the men who wrote "Fun With Dick and Jane" are so aware of what it's about that they haven't hesitated to employ bad taste in their attack on it. There is no other way to explain, for example, a throwaway comedy bit that features a man whose vocal chords have been removed and who must talk through a transistorized amplifier. On the surface this has nothing to do with social satire and everything to do with callousness, but then it may be argued that "Fun With Dick and Jane" is about the callousness of the system. I'm not convinced it works.What does work are the series of scenes that are virtually blackout sketches that define, first, the degradation to which Dick and Jane are brought by their poverty, and, second, their criminal escapades, whether holding up the telephone companywhile all the legitimate customers cheeror stealing the offering at a church whose pastor preaches the profit motive"Remember," he tells his flock, "the cross is a plus sign."I never have trouble remembering that Miss Fonda is a fine dramatic actress but I'm surprised all over again every time I see her do comedy with the mixture of comic intelligence and abandon she shows here. One sequence in particular, in which she makes a botch of an attempt at fashion modeling in a crowded restaurant at lunchtime, is a nearly priceless piece of modern slapstick. Another is Dick's brief appearance as a supernumerary in the opera chorus. Old stuff and still good.The members of the supporting cast, headed by Ed McMahon as Dick's alternately smarmy and sozzled former employer, are excellent. Among those who come to mind first are John Dehner and Mary Jackson, as Jane's rich parents who, when Dick loses his job, congratulate her on the opportunity life has provided to demonstrate her self-reliance. "Oh," says mom, tears in her eyes, "I'm so happy for you!""Fun With Dick and Jane," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes a lot of vulgar language and gestures that are perfectly in keeping with the point and method of the movie.

title: Washington Monument to Close
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)  The Washington Manument will be closed Feb. 17 to 20 to receive its annual cleaning and inspection of elevator cables, the National Park Service says.

title: ALBANY PASSES A BILL ON LOST SCHOOL TIME
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9A bill giving school districts that have lost classroom time because of snow or fuel problems a painful choicelimiting themselves to seven vacation days for the rest of the school year or losing some of their state aidpassed the Legislature today with the support of Governor Carey.

title: SYRIANS ON FRONTIER, ISRAELIS ARE RESTIVE
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9The presence of Syrian troops in southern Lebanon near the Israeli border has been the focus of diplomatic footwork, a source for rumors, a vast amount of press coverage and speculation, and a spate of comments by political and military figures, giving rise to a mood that combines confusion and tension.

title: Highlights in Drive For Veterans' Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Following are highlights of the Veterans of Foreign Wars campaign to reinstate the Committee on Veterans Affairs:

title: Two Pentagon Appointees Are Permitted by Carter To Put Stocks in Trust
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)President Carter announced today exceptions to his conflictofinterest guidelines so that two top Pentagon appointees would not be required to sell large stock holdings in two corporations.

title: Bad News From the City Assessor
description: A few drops of very cold water trickled through the prosaic figures of the Finance Department's report on the 1977 assessed value of real property in New York City. The figures show that the taxable value of real property has dropped by $400 million in the past year, subject to further negotiations and challenges by owners, which may reduce the total value still more. The decline is only about onehalf the final drop noted in 1976, but that was the first in 34 years. The two years together confirm an apparent trend.

title: Equal Rights Amendment Gains in Two States
description: With only three more states needed to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment, the North Carolina House of Representatives voted for the measure yesterday 24 hours after it had suffered a setback in Idaho, United Press International reported. The amendment went to the Senate in North Carolina.

title: A Judge Faces New Challenge
description: Justice James Gibson of the New York Supreme Court readily acknowledged yesterday that his newest assignment, which was given to him by the Court of Appeals on Tuesday. would be one of the most critical in his long, sometimes controversial, career on the bench. And just as readily, the 75yearold judge stressed that this new case, however critical, was only another challenge, and that challenges were the grist of his life.

title: WaWaToo III Captures Brazilian Yacht Race
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 9 (UPI)The Brazilian yacht WaWaToo III was declared the winner of the Buenos AiresRio de Janeiro yacht race by the Rio de Janeiro Yacht Club today.

title: Port Panel Nominations
description: Nominations for the newly created Port Authority Employment Relations Panel were sent to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for formal appointment. The three nominees are Theodore H. Lang, professor of education at Baruch College, who would serve as chairman: John J. Pearce Jr., former executive director of the New Jersey State Board of Mediation, to be the New Jersey member, and Lewis B. Kaden, professor of law at Columbia University Law School, to be the New York member.

title: Navy Ship Rescued After Fire
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 9 (AP)The Navysalvage ship Preserver was towed to the Mayport, Fla., naval base today after a fire on board, an Atlantic Fleet spokesman said. The frigate Bowen took the Preserver in tow after the fire broke out aboard the salvage ship near Cat Island in the Bahamas yesterday.

title: ARGO MERCHANT OFFICER DESCRIBES MALFUNCTION
description: The second officer of wrecked oil tanker Argo Merchant testified yesterday that the ship's gyrocompass may have been malfunctioning days before the disaster, not just hours, United Press International reported.

title: Plans for Stimulus Unchanged by Cold
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 9The Carter Administration has apparently decided against recommending any additional stimulus for the economy based on the depressing effects of the cold weather.

title: Where Londoners Go to Be Unnoticed
description: LONDONJohn Osborne, the playwright, is huddled over lunch and conversation with a man and a woman at a front table in the crowded restaurant. A young man in jeans, a leather jacket and three earrings through his left ear gesticulates over his choucroute.

title: She's a Rockabilly Tough Guy
description: Marshall Chapman, who's at Reno Sweeney through Saturday opening for Louis St. Louis, is a tall, lanky country singer from Spartanburg, S.C., by way of Nashville. Miss Chapman gave every sign at her Tuesday debut set of being a potential country, and even rock, star.

title: Profit Up Sharply At Times Company As Revenues Rise
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that it earned $9.18 million, or 81 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1976. up from $1.42 million, or 13 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter.

title: Sports Today

title: Maine Proposals Offered To End Indian Land Suit
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. A (AP)  The Maine Congressional delegation has announced proposals, including an appeal to President Carter, to help resolve an Indian claims suit to two third3 the land in the. state.

description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9The American citizens band craze has suddenly caught on in Mexico even though all the equipment must be smuggled into the country and is subject at any moment to confiscation as contraband.

title: NINE ACCUSED BY MEXICO OF FRAUD ON MEDICINES
description: MEXICO CITY FEB. 9The Mexican Government tonight formally charged nine persons, including two American businessmen, with attempted fraud and falsification of documents in a case involving allegedly, overpriced medicines sold to the Government.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternate side of the street parking regulations, suspended over much of the last several weeks because of the weather, will be restored today. However they will be suspended on Saturday, Lincoln's Birthday.

title: Even Japan's Poor Areas Have Cars, Stores Full of Goods and Color TV
description: TOHOKU, JapanAsk Government officials in Tokyo to name some of the poorest of Japan's 43 prefectures, or provinces, and most will include Aomori, at the northern tip of Honshu, the central island, about 400 miles from Tokyo. Ask in Aomori Prefecture for some of the poorer towns there, and they will more than likely mention this one.

title: Hamilton Is a Surprise Selection To Succeed Geneen as I .T .T. Head
description: The longstanding question of who would succeed Harold S. Geneen as chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation appears to have been answered.

title: RECORD ORANGE CROP SEEN DESPITE COLD THAT SWEPT FLORIDA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9A record national harvest of oranges, despite the recent freeze damage to Florida's big crop, was predicted today by the Agriculture Department.

title: 32% of Workers Changed Jobs in 5Year Period
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Nearly one in three American workers gave up their jobs and changed careers during a fiveyear period.. the Labor Department found in its first major study of career, switching.

title: KOREAN BRIBE FIGURE TIED TO BANK INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  American friends of Park Tong Sun, a central figure in the Korean bribery charges here, have disclosed that Mr. Park has asserted that he Was the organizing force behind the formation of a bank that is under Federal investigation here.

title: Wine Industry Fights Proposed Government Rules That Would Set Blending and Labeling Standards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9Federal Government proposals for stiff new regulations governingthe blending and labeling of American table wines encountered strong opposition from the wine industry today at hearings here.

title: Carter Calls on Federal Workers To Link Bureaucracy With People
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 9With the happy zest of a confident candidate, President Carter today took his message of government reform and reorganization to several thousand Federal employees, assuring them that none would lose their jobs and urging them to take seriously their role as a bridge between the bureaucracy and the people.

title: Saudi King Is Facing Surgery
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 9 (AP)King Khalid of Saudi Arabia is suffering from an undisclosed ailment in his left leg and requires surgery, the Saudi state radio reported today. It said the 62yearold monarch would fly to an unspecified European capital on Friday for medical treatment.

title: Judge John S. Hastings Dies in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9John S. Hastings, a senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit here, died Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he underwent abdominal surgery Jan. 24. He was 78 years old.

title: Carter and Artis. Life Again
description: PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who had been convicted a second time of murdering three persons in a bar here 10 years ago, tonight received the same sentences as those imposed in their first trialtwo consecutive life terms and one concurrent life term for Mr. Carter and three concurrent life sentences for Mr. Artis.

description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 9 (UPI)The Communist Party of India said today that it would seek an election alliance with the ruling Congress Party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi but criticized her for promoting the interests of her son, Sanjay.

description: Th only owner of lotteryticket vending machines in New York State was shot to death late Tuesday night outside the Queens apartment building where he lived, and homicide detectives said yesterday that the murder might have been related to an attempted mob takeover of his lucrative business.

There ought to be a clear, unequivocal commitment without change to Israel.

Marcos They were sentenced tosix years at hard labor and fined $1,300 each.

title: Books of The Times
description: I think of Arthur Miller as an archetypal city man, as one of our bestknown tragedians of urban life, and so I was curious to see what he would have to say about living in Connecticut. For about 30 years, he has owned a home there, well out of commuter range, where he has sometimes spent weekends, sometimes summers, and for a while stayed all year round. Apparently, he too feels curious about how the experience has affected him, for he and his wife, the photographer Inge Morath, have just collaborated on a book. In the Country.

title: NEW YORK URBAN LEAGUE NAMES 3 AWARD WINNERS
description: The New York Urban League announced yesterday the 1977 winners of the Frederick Douglass Award. They are Episcopal Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York; Dr. Robert C. Weaver, former Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development; and Bertha Harris, founder of Key Women of America, a community service organization.

title: SALINGER'S SON PLUNGES FROM BRIDGE AND DIES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (AP)Marc Salinger, eldest son of the former White House press secretary, Pierre Salinger, jumped to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge today, the San Francisco County coroner's office said. The body was identifiedy by his mother.

description: There are more than 1,000 acres of vacant land in the South Bronx, but the only place where New York City can build a $39 million, federally financed housing project is on a platform over some railroad tracks.

title: TWO SOVIET ASTRONAUTS MOVE INTO THE SPACE LAB
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP)Two Soviet astronauts moved into the Salyut 5 space laboratory today and went to work, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported.

title: Beame, Citing Damage From Ice, Seeks Disaster Status for the City's Waterfront
description: Mayor Beame yesterday sought Federal disasterarea status for New York City's waterfront because of damage estimated at $3..5 million to $4 million from ice, snow and cold..

title: Beame Orders a Review of Police Surgeon Pensions
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered a City Hall review of police pension plans, including the possible elimination of bonus payments of more than $20,000 yearly to parttime police surgeons.

Option Trading Urged For OTC Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a rule to allow option trading on overthecounter stocks.

title: The Kiwi and the Shadow
description: Wherever he runs, John Walker of New Zealand hounded by an invisible rival. The shadow of Filbert Bayi always in the race. When the big, blond Kiwi won the Olympic gold medal in the 1,500meter run at Montreal last year, he had to wonder what would have happened if the African boycott had not kept Filbert Bayi in Tanzania; perhaps John Walker would have run even better, perhaps he would have lost. Several weeks later John Walker met the shadow in Paris at a track and field meet. Filbert Bayi and the other Tanzanian runners deserted that meet when John Walker arrived. But they had a brief encounter. When, asked John Walker, are you going to run against me? The small, slender African replied, I don't know. Nobody else knows either, but yesterday John Walker was saying that perhaps they will run against each other this year.

title: Navajo Tribal Chairman Indicted On Charges of Mail and Tax Fraud
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 9A Federal grand jury here has returned an eightcount indictment charging the Navajo tribal chairman, Peter MacDonald, with mail fraud, obtaining money by trick and subscribing to a false income tax return.

title: Petroleum Institute Says Drop Continues In Home Oil Stocks
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that supplies of home heating oil continued to decline last week, falling by nearly 7 percent.

description: LONDON, Feb. 9Queen Elizabeth flew off tonight on a Silver Jubilee tour of CommonWealth countries in the Pacific.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A LIFE Sir Thomas Morewriter, lawyer, diplomat, adviser to Henry VIII, canonized churchmanmartyr and the stage's Man for All Seasonsis the subject of a quincentennial conference tonight and tomorrow at Fordham University. The event is free to the public, students and scholars. A group of internationally recognized More experts will discuss several aspects of his life, lecturing in the Campus Center Ballroom of the Rose Hill campus on Fordham Road (adjoining the New York Botanical Garden). The tribute is sponsored by the university's English and history departments.

title: DIRECT POPULAR ELECTION IS FAVORED BY 75% IN POLL
description: Americans favor a constitutional amendment to replace the Electoral College with direct popular choice of the President by a 5to1 margin, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Jersey Turnpike Planning Study On Ways to Reduce Electric Bill
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 9 (UPI) The New Jersey Turnpike Authorit has hired the engineering concern of Howard, Needles, Tammen and Bergendoff to study ways to reduce the turnpike's $1.4 miliion annual electric bill.

title: City College Scholarships
description: Fortythree New York City high school seniors, selected for their academic ability and leadership qualities, were awarded scholarships worth $2,000 each by City College. The students are planning to attend the college upon graduation from high school. Dr. Robert Marshak, the president of the college, said at an awards ceremony that the scholarships were established recently to help outstanding New York City students who want to attend college but are having severe financial problems because of the imposition of tuition and other negative conditions which affect their families.

description: GAIRA. Harry, Belleville that the best Ideas should be common property, he contributed much so that others could share. HERBERT.

title: Beame Renames Taxi Panel Head
description: Mayor Beame submitted the name of Moses L. Kove to the City Council for reappointment as chairman of the Taxi and. Limousine Commission. Mr. Kove was appointed to the commission in 1974. His new term will run until Jan. 1, 1985. His salary will be $43,216 a year.

title: Roots Success in South Seen as Sign of Change
description: In 1957, when the late popular singer Nat (King) Cole became the first black performer to have his own network television series, several Southern stations refused to carry it, and sponsors avoided it for fear of a Southern boycott. The show was canceled within a year.

title: Unopposed for Machinists' Head
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)William W. Winpisinger was assured of election today as president of the International Association of Machinists.

title: TV: Seamy Side of 7th Avenue
description: Seventh Avenue, based on the doorstopper of a novel by Norman Bogner, is the third Best Seller this season to be serialized by NBC on Thursday nights, after Captains and the Kings and Once an Eagle. Tonight, at 9 o'clock, we get, the first two hours of a total of six, with the miniseries continuing Feb. 17 and ending Feb. 24.

title: 'Twilight's Last Gleaming': No Star
description: "Twilight's Last Gleaming" is Robert Aldrich's deadly solemn, gadgety suspense-melodrama about a disgruntled, liberal-thinking United States general, a Vietnam veteran whose out-spoken antiwar views got him railroaded to prison on a trumped-up murder charge.The general, played by Burt Lancaster, breaks out of the slammer with three other Death-Row prisoners to take possession of a Titan missile base in Montana. With his finger on the button, the renegade general demands $10-million in unmarked bills, the use of Air Force One to take him and his associates to the country of their choice, the President of the United States as hostage and, most important, a full disclosure of "the facts" about the war.These "facts," unfortunately, are fully disclosed in the course of "Twilight's Last Gleaming" and immediately ridicule the movie's claims to importance contained in its publicity. Instead, the facts suggest that Mr. Aldrich, who directed the film, and Ronald M. Cohen and Edward Huebsch, who wrote the screenplay, set in 1981, haven't yet caught up even to 1975.The facts are contained in a Top Secret memo reporting that a former President of the United States agreed to continue the Vietnam War at the insistence of his military advisers and cabinet members who argued that the senseless slaughter was the only way the Soviets would understand that the United States meant business. Good grief! All of the characters in the film, whose minds are so tiny they've totally forgotten the Pentagon Papers and Watergate, are convinced that such a move toward "open" government would result in the collapse of the American way of life and death.In "Twilight's Last Gleaming," this memo is what Alfred Hitchcock likes to call the "McGuffin," the secret thing or information that heroes and villains battle for in any Hitchcock espionage film. Mr. Hitchcock knows enough never to tell us what the McGuffin is, since nothing can seem as important as it's been built up to be. I've gone into it at some length here because the McGuffin of "Twilight's Last Gleaming" is a measure of the movie's wooly-headedness.Otherwise, the film has the appearance of a rather classy television show in which people are forever picking up and putting down telephones, buzzing secretaries, and getting into and out of various means of transportationautomobiles, jet airplanes, helicopters and elevators.Mr. Aldrich obtains a good deal of suspense from idiotic material, though his use of the split-screen doesn't double suspense as often as it Cuts it in half. There also are two decently straight performances by Mr. Lancaster and Charles Durning, who plays the President as the sort of man who has adequacy thrust upon him.The other actors are mostly terrible, including some who look as if they'd passed through old age and gone on to the embalming room.I suppose that "Twilight's Last Gleaming," which opened at three theaters yesterday, might also claim to be important in pointing out how close nuclear destruction always is, but this is important the way that a sign, "Don't Walk On The Tracks," is important as literature.

description: WASHINGTONThe inflation Impact statement, a Ford Administration attempt to systematically estimate the cost of regulations before they were imposed, is alive and well in the Federal establishment of President Carter.

description: In the first 70 days of the Police Department's crackdown in Harlem on narcotic traffickers, almost 2,000 drugrelated arrests were made, Mayor Beame said.

title: Fatal Blaze Spurs Fire Alarm Sales In Suffolk Stores
description: Suffolk County department stores reported a rush of buyers for home smoke alarms yesterday, a day after a fire in a Holbrook home took the lives of five children.

title: With Military Junta Gone, Poetry in Greece Is Reaching Floodtide
description: ATHENS, Feb. 9In 1970, Manolis Anagnostakis wrote, Words must be hammered in like nails that the wind might not take them.

title: Article 1  No Title
Rite of Spring For 4 Hands At One Piano
description: One of the nice things about being a music critic is that pleasant surprises occur from time to time when least expected. On Tuesday night at. Carnegie Hall, for example, Delores Hodgens and Samuel Howard, duopianists, provided a revelation for this listener with a performance of Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring in a fourhand version at one instrument. Fourhand arrangements of symphonic masterpieces are often fun for the players but seldom gratifying for listeners. Not so with The Rite of Spring.

title: Moynihan Gets A Major Post In the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  On being designated today as the first New Yorker on the topranking Senate Finance Committee in a halfcentury, Senator Daniel P. Moynihan called for easing New York State's tax burden and for a very hard look at Japanese trading practices.

title: Military Personnel in Turkey Are Cleared in Lockheed Case
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 9 (AP)The military prosecutor of the Turkish general staff today cleared all Turkish military personnel of charges of receiving payoffs from Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Physician, 31, Slain
description: A 31yearold resident physician at Metropolitan Hospital in New York was fatally bludgeoned as she slept in her home in WoodRidge in Bergen County. Her brotherinlaw was charged with the murder. The victim was identified as Shobha Phulwani, a native of India, who came to the United States in July 1974 to study medicine. She died of fractured skull. The suspect, 39yearold Moti Phulwani, was accused of striking her with a small metal motor. Mr. Phulwani was held without bail at his arraignment before Superior Court Judge Fred C. Galda in Hackensack. Mr. Phulwani had been staying at the home of the victim and her husband, Mohan, a New York lawyer who was said to be visiting India at the time of the slaying.

title: About New York
description: Determined to be positive about life's passage, Jim Hyland celebrated his 40th birthday by bringing a big bottle of champagne to the diningroom table as his wife and seven children watched. He popped the cork and quickly caught the bubbling geyser with his mouth. But the gush knocked his one false tooth into his windpipe and left everyone gasping along with Jim as he was rushed off to Long Island Jewish Hospital.

title: Jordan Makes Taxes His Theme As He Enters Race for Governor
Despite Bill's Ambiguities, Westchester Will Remain In Plan to Lure Industry
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 9  Despite general acknowledgement that a stateauthorized real estate tax abatement plan for businesses is full of ambiguities, group of six Democrats and two Republicans on the Westchester County Board of Legislators today beat back an attempt to scuttle county participation in the effort to attract industry.

title: Sabres Triumph and Extend Mastery Over Rangers, 21
description: Phil Esposito, thinking the puck had caught the net, began to lift his arms in celebration. But his shot with 10 seconds to play against Buffalo last night flew just wide of the goal. And when the clock had ticked off the final seconds, the Sabres were the celebrants instead with a 21 victory over the New York Rangers.

The primary focus of the group is on two musicians named DavidDavid Friedman and David Samuelseach of whom plays both vibraharp and marimba, changing places at the two instruments from one selection to another and even in the midst of a piece.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia. Feb. 9 (AP)A wave of arrests by Ethiopia's leftist military Government has followed the violent power struggle last week in which the chief of state and 10 others died, diplomats here report.

title: Moon Sect Buys Building
description: A Fifth Avenue building that formerly housed garmentindustry showrooms has been purchased for a reported $2.4 million by a publishing operation associated with the Unification Church of America, headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: The Economic Scene
description: The Carter Administration hopes to turn aside the wrath of those in Congress critical of his fiscal economic stimulus package by giving soft answers and working with them on the legislation. Page 59.

title: Soviet Visit to Prague Stirs Questions on Dissidents
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 9A Soviet Communist party delegation has arrived here for discussions, prompting speculation that is seeking information on the strains caused by emergence of the Czechoslovak human rights movement.

title: $250 Fuel Subsidy Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)The Senate Budget Committee recommended today that the Federal Government pay up to $250 of the fuel bills of low and middleincome families in areas hardest hit by the bitter winter. Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, chairman of the committee, said he understands President Carter supports such a program.

title: Britain's Share 51% In New Oil Permits
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP)Britain's Labor Government today awarded its fifth round of oil exploration licenses for drilling in the North Sea and other offshore areas.

title: Louisville Tops Southwest Louisiana for 15th in Row
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 9 (AP)Louisville won its 15th straight game tonight, with a 10382 victory over Southwestern Louisiana to tie a school record.

title: Ford's Presence Livens Barren Desert Golf Field
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9The Bob Hope Desert Classic, which derives most of its promotional and, moneyraising value from the prominence of the 384 amateurs who constitute most of its field, got off its 18th annual edition today with its most distinguished amateur everformer President Gerald R. Ford.

title: Senate Report Is Critical of F.B.I. On Presidential Nominee Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Senate Committee on Government Operations said in a report released today that the manner in which the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted background investigations on some Presidential nominees was in need of complete reevaluation and suggested new guidelines for such checks.

title: Beame Nominates New City Planner
description: Mayor Beanie announced yesterday the nomination of Theodore E. Teah to be a member of the City Planning Commission. The appointment of *Mr.Teah. a native of Indiana who has lived in the South Bronx for the last 10 years. is subject to confirmation by the Council under the city's new Charter.

title: Cowboy Art Finds Home on the Range
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.There are a bunch of fellows in the western hills called the Cowboy Artists of America, pardner, and you better not make fun of them because they might draw on you. Or maybe just whip you with their bankbooks.

title: N.T.A. Expected to Save Franklin Avenue Shuttle, Once an Austerity Target
description: The Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn, initially targeted for shutdown to help close a $30 million Transit Authority budget gap, will be saved under a plan to be submitted to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority at its monthly meeting tomorrow, according to authority sources.

title: 3,031 Westminster Hopefuls Spend a Week Brushing Up
description: Both big and small dogs got into the brushup act this week at Manhattan Obedience Training Club headquarters on East 85th Street. They were preparing for the weekend specialties and for Westminster Monday and Tuesday, when 3,031 purebred competitors will take over Madison Square Garden. The advanced bandling classes featured a crosssection of breeds including Afghan, Shih Tzu, danes, retrievers, bulldogs and terriers.

title: Notes on People
description: Princess Anne and her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips, have come under fire for plans to build a $68,000 stable on titre grounds of the Cotswold estate. To spend all this money on an elaborate building when people need houses is wrong, said Wilfred Gardner, vice chairman of the town council. The British princess and her husband, both practiced equestrians, received approval for the construction despite Mr. Gardner's criticism that th,ey are lacking in feeling for their fellows.

title: 11 PODIATRISTS NAMED IN A BRIBERY ATTEMPT

title: 2 More California Counties Told to Cut Water Use
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. .9 (UPI)  A mandatory 25 percent reduction of water consumption for 1.1 million East Bay Municipal Utility District water users has gone into effect because of the drought.

description: MADRID, Feb. 9Spain and the Soviet Union announced a resumption of diplomatic relations today, 38 years after they were broken off at the end of the Spanish Civil War.

Examples of the Modern Poetry
description: I write poems within the limits prescribed by responsible state offices

title: Chad Mitchell Back at Ballroom, Reconfirming Fine Impressions
description: Chad Mitchell, who's back at the Ballroom through Feb. 20, reconfirms the fine impression he made there last winter. Mr. Mitchell used to lead the popular Chad Mitchell Trio in the earlymid1960's, then dropped out of sight and now finds himself living under the threat of a jail sentence for allegedly smuggling marijuana into this country. In the meantime, while his case is appealed, he is trying to rekindle his performing career.

title: Carey Planning Relief Slashes Of 10% and Up
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9Governor Carey, facing a $45 million budget gap, today proposed a new plan thatwould cut home relief grants to persons under 60 years old by at least 10 percent.

title: Man Charged In Wife's Death Kills Himself
Rhodesian Army Slays Four Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 9Rhodesian security forces shot and killed four black nationalist insurgents yesterday in the area of St. Paul's Mission, where group of blacks dressed in insurgents uniforms massacred seven Catholic missionaries two days earlier.

title: Random House May Be Bought By The Times Mirror Company
description: Random House, one of the major publishers in New York, which is a subsidiary of RCA Corporation, the broadcasting and electronics conglomerate, is expected to be sold to the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles, the newspaper conglomerate with strong interests in. book publishing.

title: Rules Restrict U.S.Aided Housing In South Bronx to Site Over Tracks
description: There are more, than 1,000 acres of vacant land in the South Brorx, but the only place where New York City can build a $39 million, federally financed housing project is on a platform over some railroad tracks.

title: Congress Called Lax on Review Of U.S. Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9A Senate committee report concluded today that Congressional review of the Federal agencies that regulate a vast and increasing range of American life has been sporadic, haphazard and incomplete.

title: Leonard Silk
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 9The hope of the Carter Administration during its first weeks in office is to turn aside the wrath of its critics in Congress and elsewhere by giving soft answers. However, it hopes through making moaerate alterations in its economic programs to avoid changing the basic directions and dimensions of its policies. This was the approach taken by President Carter this week in his first postinauguration news conference. When asked his attitude toward vetoing an economic stimulation package if Congress sent it to him in a form significantly different from what he had proposed, Mr. Carter said that, while he reserved the constitutional right to veto legislation that he considered contrary to the best interests of the nation, he thought the best way to avoid vetoes was for him to work intimately with Congressand that he intended to do. He said his sense was that Congress was likely to append amendments to the fiscal package, which is to total $31 billion over the next two years, but that he could accept Congressional changes, provided that they did not drastically alter the size of the package.

title: A Substitute Gas Can Change Color Of Cooking Flame
N.F.L.Lions Name Hudspeth Coach With 3Year Contract
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 9 (UPI)Tommy Hudspeth, admitting he had been second choice for the job, signed a threeyear contract today as the Detroit Lions coach.

title: 'Cassandra Crossing' Doomed By Silly Premise, Miscasting
description: It would be paranoidas paranoid as the film itselfto see in "The Cassandra Crossing" some covert and kinky attempt at anti-American propaganda. Stupidity can be kinkier than propaganda, and this movie is profoundly, offensively stupid.The United States dirty-tricks people, it tells us, have secreted a whole laboratory full of pneumonic plague germs inside the World Health Organization headquarters in Geneva. Terrorists try to steal it and are shotwhat are United States Marine guards doing inside the W.H.O.?but one escapes to hide in the Geneva-Stockholm Express.Gray and sweaty, the terrorist goes through the train, breathing in the passengers' faces and retching over the rice in the galley. Burt Lancaster, the United States Army Intelligence chief in Geneva, learns he has a problem. Instead of getting the Swiss authorities to stop the train and quarantine everyone, he manages in some unexplained fashion to have the train sealed and dispatched to Poland.(Questions: Why doesn't he want to tell the Swiss authorities? Embarrassment? Why is it less embarrassing to tell the Polish authorities? And how does an Army Intelligence colonel manage to reroute a train without getting the national railroad officials to help?)But the border-crossing bridge is known to be fatally deficient. The conductor knows it, and so do the 1,000 passengers on board. They try to reach the engineer and tell him to stop the train. They engage in a wild machine-gun battle with American soldiers placed on the train to prevent this.(Questions: Would American soldiers really shoot down passengers so they could all go over a worm-eaten bridge together? If the conductor knows the bridge is rotten wouldn't the engineer know, too? Why doesn't the conductor simply pull the emergency signal? Why . . . oh, never mind.)Except for the photography, which is rather good, the film, which opened yesterday at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, carries out its ridiculous premises with uniform incompetence.Burt Lancaster bears his totally incomprehensible role as if it were a toothache. His jaw is clamped so tight that it looks swollen.Ingrid Thulin and Lee Strasberg are adequate in awful roles. Ava Gardner is awful in an awful role.Sophia Loren is totally miscast as a bright, quirky writer who is pursuing her divorced husband. Richard Harris, the husband, is vacuous as the neurosurgeon charged with trying to handle a pneumonic plague epidemic.The plague germs rapidly mutate into something harmless, like a cold. The film never mutates: It just goes on, becoming more and more lethal.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES LISTS CONGRESSMEN IN CAMPAIGN GIFTS
The Family Style
description: Jimmy Carter, a family man, stressed the theme of family life throughout his carripaign. He spoke with obvious sincerity about his own close family ties; he chose for his Vice President a man known as the children's Senator; in his Inaugural Address he advocated the strengthening of all American families. Yet many members of the new Administration  and the President himselfare taking on jobs that leave them little choice about the amount of time they can spend with their families.

title: St. John's Tops Army, 5755, In Overtime
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 9Army end St. John's have waged some of the most exciting and closest basketball battles seen in the East the last two decades. They throw out game plans and pick up countless bruises in a roundball form of war.

title: Margaret Ferguson Britton, 69, Headed Garden Club of Hartford
description: Margaret Ferguson Britton, president of the Garden Club of Hartford from 1955 to 1957 and from 1961 to 1963, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital after a short illness. She lived in Hartford and was 69 years old.

title: QUEEN ALIA OF JORDAN DIES IN COPTER CRASH
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 9 (UPI)Queen Alia of Jordan, third wife of King Hussein, was killed today in the crash of a Jordanian military helicopter. She was 28 years old.

title: General Telephone's Net Income And Revenues Establish Records
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which operates the nation's largest independent (nonBell) telephone system, reported yesterday profit increases of 17.3 percent for the fourth quarter and 16.7 percent for all of last Year.

title: Concert: Dvorak Chamber Music Is Spirited Fare
description: At the Marlboro Music Festival and summer school, the music of Antonin Dvorak has always occupied a prominent place. Rudolf Serkin. the guiding spirit of Marlboro, loves Dvorak. Thus it was no great surprise to find last night's program at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. devoted entirely to Dvorak, for most, and perhaps all, of the musicians happened to be Marlboro alumni. Seldom has causality worked out so well.

title: Smith Meets With Vorster in Cape Town
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia conferred today with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa in an apparent attempt to get approval for his plans for a settlement with the black majority in the former British colony. It was their first meeting in almost five months.

title: Two Primary Winners Open Minnesota Drives
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (UPI)  The Democratic and Republican winners in yesterday's seventh Congressional District primary set out today to campaign for the Feb. 22 election.

title: 4 Irishmen Are Convicted Of 6 Murders in England
description: LONDON, Feb. 9Four. Irishmen were found guilty of six murders today. The men, members of the I.R.A. Provisionals, refused to plead and the court entered a not guilty plea for them. They left the dock after calling the trial a farce and political.

title: Philadelphia Expert On Taxes Is Picked As Chief of I.R.S.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)Hopes for a quick settlement of the National Football League's playerowner disputes seemed close to collapse today after two days of negotiations.

title: Indiana Gunman Promised Immunity If Hostage Freed
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (UPI)The authorities here backed down tonight and offered complete and total immunity from prosecution to a gunman holding a real estate executive hostage at gunpoint for almost two days in an apartment believed wired with dynamite.

title: Businessmen Ask Curb on Growth Of the Government's Interference
description: A powerful group of American business leaders asked the Carter Administration and the new Congress yesterday to curb the growth of Government interference in the economy and said they wanted more of a voice in forming national policy.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 9Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City became the third announced Democratic candidate for Governor today, and promised to ease the tax burden of people on moderate income through a decent, fair income tax.

title: A Poll of East Side Catholics Ties Attendance Drop to Loss of Faith
description: A survey of Roman Catholics on .the East Side of Manhattan indicates that sharp declines in attendance at mass over the last decade have resulted from a toss of faith in the supernatural rather than disagreement with the church's moral teachings or changes in ritual.

title: Advertising
description: Advertising agencies in their search for new clients frequently must do more than produce merely excellent, effective advertising. Sometimes they even advertise, .using newspapers, magazines, direct .mail, radio or, an rare occasions, television. A good public service campaign can serve as a showcase. Press coverage doesn't hurt either.

title: Tax Cuts and. Jobs: A Vital Difference
description: The commotion in the liberal community about President Carter's proposals to stimulate the economy deserves a closer look. The dispute, although among friends, is basic: Can the programs designed to fight recession be distinguished from those needed to combat chronic unemployment?

title: Dance: The Beacon Shines Again
description: A new theater is always a special excitement. But a revived theater sometimes has something special to offer. The Beacon Theater, at Broadway and 74th Street, was built in 1928. It was one of those great movie houses, fantastic in what we now call its Art Deco Confidence, yet in its day, more simply fantastic.

title: How Senate's Reorganization Plan Was Scaled Down
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Like a row of dominoes that topples from the movement begun by a single falling piece, the farreaching plan to streamline the Senate by reducing its committees from 31 to 15 was knocked down last week by the pressures to reinstate a single committee: Veterans Affairs.

title: FOREIGNA1D CONTROL IS REPORTED SHIFTING
description: The selection of recipients of American foreign aid is increasingly outside the control of Congress, according to a new study by the Center for International Policy, a Washingtonbased research organization.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9Allard K. Lowenstein, the newly appointed American representative to the Human Rights Commission, says. the United States will press for reforms in the confidential procedures used by the United Nations for dealing with the thousands of complaints received each year from individuals charging abuse of their rights.

title: Panama Negotiator Quits as U.S. Talks On Canal Approach
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Aquilino Boyd unexpectedly resigned today as Foreign Minister of Panama, raising doubts about the resumption next week of negotiations with the United States on a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: The Brooding Hawks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9There is a peculiar, almost venomous intensity in some of the opposition to Paul Warnke as President Carter's chief arms control negotiatora feeling beyond the usual policy disagreement in a democracy. It is as if the opponents have made him a symbol of something they dislike so much that they want to destroy him.

title: Lindbergh Stamp Is Planned

title: South African Police Use Tear Gas To Quell Soweto Student Protest
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Riot policemen used tear gas today to disperse black student militants who made bonfires out of examination papers in Soweto, an area where only blacks may live, but the authorities showed marked restraint compared with their actions in the riots of last year.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Last month, the President's Commission on Olympic Sports recommended sweeping changes in the structure and scope of amateur athletics in the United States.

title: Galanos Draws on the Past to Create a Romantic Present
description: After you've had a retrospective showing of your life's work, what do you do for your next collection?

title: Union Talks Set at Washington Star
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 5Federal mediators, at the request of the management of the financially troubled Washington Star, scheduled a meeting for tomorrow afternoon between the management of the paper and the unions representing its workers.

title: An Education Aide Escapes Injury When Fired Upon
description: The top troubleshooter in dealings between the New York City Board of Education and the city's 32 community school districts, Alfredo Mathew Jr., narrowly escaped injury after he was fired at in an apparent murder attempt, the police reported yesterday.

title: Kidnapping Arrest
description: A 23yearold South Carolina man has surrendered and has been arrested as the fourth suspect in the robbery and kidnapping of two sisters from the Bergen Mall, a large shopping complex near their home in Paramus. The suspect, David Brunson, who had been staying at 20 East 42d Street, Brooklyn, after leaving his home in Marion, S.C., recently, surrendered to Paterson detectives near the George Washington Bridge after they had asked Mr. Brunson's mother and sister to appeal to him to surrender. He is being held in $250,000 bail.

title: Assembly Democrats Defer Action on Permanent Spring Primary Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9Faced with strong opposition from the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus and unable to find the votes to assure passage, the State Assembly's Democratic leadership today deferred action on a New York City mayoral primary bill that would provide for a runoff election if no candidate got more than 40 percent of the first vote.

title: Laurel Scores 34 as Hofstra Turns Back La Salle, 9389
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9  Hofstra University's defending East Coast Conference basketball champions got over a major hurdle tonight in the Palestra by holding off La Salle's Explorers, 9389.

title: Waterville Ski Instructor Says Short. Skis Lead to Long Slopes
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Feb. 9Floyd Wilkie, an assistant ski school director at this secluded White Mountains resort, was instructing a shortie ski class and expressing his teaching preference for the shortie technique. The 27yearold bearded Wilkie is among the East's most sophisticated skiers, so this attitude may seem surprising. Three years ago, the freestyle specialist placed third in the national overall competition at Heavenly Valley (Calif.) and won the Eeastern Moguls (bumps) title.

title: Trenton Topics

description: Fingers must be kept crossed, but so far the winter of '76'77 has been kinder to our health than to our environment. Most fortunately, the feared swine flu epidemic has failed to develop. The flu detected in the United States last month seems to have been the relatively mild Type BHong Kong. This month, concern has shifted to the AVictoria strain due to a localized outbreak, causing some deaths, in a Miami nursing home, and some scattered cases in Canada.

title: Mexico's New RegimeI

Yet the hope of President Jose Lopez Portillo is to achieve what even the least cynical Mexican still believes can't happen here: a government both competent and incorruptible.

title: Art People
description: BACK IN THE 1930's, Julien Levy, the art dealer, took Serge Lifar, star dancer of the Ballets Russes, to the Central Hanover Bank in New York to cash a check he'd given Lifar for his collection of ballet designs The dancer took an appraising look at the bank counters, writes Mr Levy in his new book, Memoir of an Art Gallery (Putnam, $8 95) With a joyous shout he executed a double entrzchat and a leap . . . Then he was over the counter, landing on an overturned drawer of hard coins, to the consternation of tellers and the two armed guards, who somehow saw fit not to shoot. The most famous leap of Lifer, he said, as he calmly cashed his check.
