description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP)The British pound slipped against the dollar for the second straight day today, with reports of growing opposition by labor unions to the Government's policy limiting pay increases.

title: Princeton Whips Cornell and Gains Share of Ivy Lead
description: PRINCETON, NJ., Feb. 11Pete Carril, Princeton University's volatile basketball coach, had little to cheer about this evening, even though his Tigers beat Cornell, 6249, in an Ivy League game at Jadwin Gym. This was the 1,000th basketball victory for Princeton since it started playing the game in 1901.

title: Loews Report Confirms Questionable Payments
description: The Loews Corporation said it had filed a report with the Securities and Exchange Commission on a special investigation that confirmed questionable payments of about $1.6 million during the five years from 1971 to 1976 in connection with foreign sales to its Lorillard Tobacco division.

title: Article 5  No Title
Armed Services Panel in Senate Says It Will Meet With Warnke
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. II (UPI)Paul Warnke's nomination as the head of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and as chief arms negotiator came under more criticism today in the Senate, where the Armed Services Committee announced it would question him later this month.

title: Soviet Astronauts Experimenting With Effects of Weightlessness
description: MOSCOW, Feb 11 (Reuters)The two Soviet astronauts who are orbiting earth in the Salyut 5 space laboratory have begun tests on the effect of weightlessness on humans, the Tass press agency reported today.

title: Grand Union in Deal With Cavenham (USA)
description: Cavenham (USA), subsidiary of Cavenham Limited of Britain said in Bridgeport, Conn. yesterday that the Grand Union Company's board had agreed to merge into Cavenham (USA) if Cavenham would offer $21 principal amount of its 11 percent sinking fund debentures for each Grand Union share not now owned by Cavenham (USA). The British Company now owns about 83 percent of Grand Union's stock.

title: Waldheim Is Optimistic on Mideast
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations told Israeli leaders during a twoday visit that a new, more flexible Palestinian attitude toward Israel now existed, but his report was dismissed by the Israelis as more tactical than substantive.

title: Guards Indicted in Beating
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. (AP)  Five guards from the Fishkill Correctional Facility have been Indicted on assault charges in the beating of an inmate last. September. Four of the guards pleaded innocent at hearings today, while the fifth is reported out of state, and has not been apprehended.

title: Cruise Missile Passes Test
description: POINT MUGU, Feb. 11 Calif. (UPI)A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile successfully found a target ship on a longrange, overthehorizon search mission today. The missile, in its second longrange test, was launched from the wing of an A6 Intruder aircraft, flew southward to test area bounded by the North Channel Islands and St. Nicolas Island off the California coast, and simulated a lowlevel attack on the target.

title: Bell, in Shift, Orders Civil Rights Inquiry In Chicano's Killing
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 11In a reversal of a longstanding Government policy, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today ordered a Federal grand jury inquiry into the shotgun slaying of 26yearold Richard Morales by the police chief of nearby Castroville in 1975.

title: Legislators Back Carter's Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)President Carter's plan to replace the personal income tax exemption with a tax credit won endorsements today from Representative Al Ullman and Senator Russell B. Long, chairmen of the Congressional committees responsible for Federal tax laws.

title: Dave Anderson
description: They're in Cincinnati tonight and they were in West Palm Beach on Thursday night. The night before, Bjorn Borg, the reigning Wimbledon champion, and Rod Layer, four times the Wimbledon champion, played a onenight stand at the South Mountain Arena in West Orange, NJ., just like the old touring pros did before open tournaments changed tennis. Rod Laver is 38 years old now and he's one of the few tennis pros who remember the onenight stands. In those years, touring pros were outlaws, almost outcasts. They got a big play when they opened their tour at Madison Square Garden but then they virtually vanished. They often traveled together in a station wagon, except for Pancho Gonzales, who preferred to drive alone through the night to the next stop. Oldtimers at the South Mountain Arena remembered when Pancho Gonzales played tennis there on a canvas court stretched across the ice rink in 1960. And now, in the quiet of a dreary cementblock locker room normally used by female figure skaters, Rod Laver was trying to remember if he had appeared at the South Mountain Arena before.

title: PRESIDENT INDICATES THAT HE WILL PURSUE TIE WITH VIETNAMESE
Record Concerns and Broadcaster Seek to Curb Sex and Drug Disks
description: Executives from several principal record companies and a major local broadcaster said yesterday that they would assume a certain moral control to block the proliferation of sexrock and drugrock phonograph records.

title: Plying Command Post Takes Carter Home
description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 11President Carter flew home to Georgia today on the massive military aircraft that would be the nation's airborne command post in wartime.

title: The Equal Employment Mess
description: President Carter let it drop to reporters the other day that he is contemplating a massive reorganization of civil rights enforcement efforts. So far, the contours of his plan are unclear, but we welcome the evidence of Presidential attention and concern. It comes not minute too soon for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The commission was assigned a critical role in the Federal civil rights effort in the past. Now it is deteriorating.

title: Rain Delays Cup Tennis After Aussies Take Lead
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 11 (UPI)Australia held a 10 lead over New Zealand today when rain and hail stopped play in the Eastern Zone final series of the Davis Cup tennis competition. Play will resume tomorrow.

title: Ghosts of Girlhood Lift Obscure Book To Peak of Acclaim
description: From afar I can believe my family loves me fundamentally. They only say. When fishing for treasures in the flood, be careful not to pull in girls, because that is what one says about daughters. But I watched such words come out of my own mother's and father's mouths. . . . And I had to get out of hating range. From The Woman Warrior.

title: Syrian Clash With Palestinians Worsens in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11Syrian forces and Palestinian guerrillas clashed here today in the worst fighting since the Lebanese civil war ended about three months ago. The clash was the second in two days.

title: Retail Sales Eased By 2% for January. Against December
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.11The Commerce Department reported today a 2 percent drop from December levels in January retail sales but said that consumers stepped up their buying in the first week of February by 3.3 percent.

title: Suspected Police Informer, 15, Kills Himself
description: DALLAS, Feb. 11 (UPI)The latenight telephone calls to Jesse Medina started several week ago.

title: Virginia Payne, Actress, Dies at 66
description: Virginia Payne, who was the voice of Ma Perkins for 27 yearsthe entire life of the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio soap operadied Thursday in Cincinnati. She was 66 years old.

title: LEGIONDISEASE LINKED TO MICHIGAN ILLNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Evidence linking a mysterious outbreak of illness about eight and a half years ago in Michigan to bacteria like those found in the legionnaires disease last summer was reported today by Federal scientists.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Transit Workers Protest
description: Protesting cutbacks in subway and bus service as well as in police protection, several thousand chanting transit workers picketed City Hall yesterday. Matthew Guinan, international president of the Transport Workers Union, said the group was putting pressure on the city fathers and the Transit Authority to see the light; their pennypinching policy is driving people away from the subwaysthey're decimating the system.

title: The Swamp That Breeds Heroin Addiction
S.E.C. IS ABOUT MIDWAY IN PREPARING REPORT ON SALE OF CITY BONDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission's New York regional office is about at midpoint in writing a draft report of the agency's investigation of city note and bond sales, an inquiry to. determine whether investors were properly told of new York's deteriorating financial condition.

title: City View on Bronx Housing Plan Explained
description: The question of whether a $39 million housing .project should be built on a platform over some Bronx railroad tracks took another turn yesterday when New York City housing officials said they had never wanted to move the project to vacant land nearby.

title: End of Ban on State Loans to Business Is Urged
description: Osborn Elliott, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Econcomic Development, urged state legislators yesterday to repeal the constitutional ban on using public funds for gifts or loans to private business.

title: Hanoi Toughness In South Is Seen
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 11Some former South Vietnamese military officers and civil servants still being held prisoner by the Communists are being transferred to socalled reeducation camps near Hanoi reports from Vietnam indicate.

title: Grant Says the Jets Are Absolutely Inflexible
description: M. Donald Grant,chairman of the New York Mets, yesterday defended his dealings with the New York Jets, one day after it had been revealed that the Jets were negotiating to move their club to Giants Stadium in East Rutherford. N.J.

title: Going out Guide
description: DIG YOU LATER The break in the chilly weather may be a good time for urban cliffdwellers to consider seeds, roots and leaves, with spring planting and cultivation in mind. There's a Valentine Plant Sale today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, with some experts on hand today only for practical pointers.

title: E. Vincent Curtayne, 71, Dies
description: E. Vincent Curtayne, who was a New York City Transit Authority commissioner from 1955 to 1960, died Wednesday in his home at 44 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: Two Spanish Rightists Are Rescued From Kidnappers
description: MADRID, Feb. 11Lieut. Gen. Emilio Villaescusa and Antonio Marfa de Oriot y Urquijo, a former Justice Minister, were rescued from their kidnappers today in separate apartments in outlying workingclass sections of Madrid, the Government announced tonight.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Aspiring croupiers, blackjack dealers and other prospective employes of Atlantic City's future gambling casinos were cautioned by State Attorney General William F. Hyland today against rushing out and enrolling in schools that promised to teach the skills required at the gaming tables.

title: Radio
With a Little Bit of Luck
description: MUNICHWith a little bit of luck this weekend may see some kind of breakthrough in the unhappy GreekTurkish deadlock over their own bilateral arguments and over the dispute between their related kinsmen, the GreekCypriotes and the TurkishCypriots. These have festered since Ankara sent an expeditionary force in 1974 to seize almost 40 percent of Cyprus.

title: Assassination Panel's Fate in Doubt As Sprague Faces New Allegations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The chairman of the House Select Committee on Assassinations today accused Richard A. Sprague, the committee's chief counsel, of violating the rules of the House of Representatives by continuing to work as a private attorney and refusing to file a statement of his outside income.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Sets LuxuryUnit Expansion
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., is planning a rapid expansion in the luxury specialtystore field aimed at doubling those sales in the next five years by sighting in on affluent pockets in new or existing metropolitan areas.

title: PRESIDENT INDICATES THAT HE WILL PURSUE TIE WITH VIETNAMESE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  President Carter signaled today his intention to pursue normal diplomatic relations with Vietnam by announcing that he planned to send an American delegation there to discuss missing military personnel and a wide range of other issues.

title: UConn Five Cancels Game
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP) The ConnecticutCanisius basketball game originally scheduled for Feb. 5 in Buffalo has been canceled, John Toner, the UConn athletic director, said today. The game, which wasn't held Feb. 5 because of severe weather, won't he played because no mutually agreeable makeup date was available, Toner said.

title: Article 3  No Title
New Institute at Air Force Academy Aims for MilitaryCivilian Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11A privately financed institute, with generals and admirals constituting half the board of directors, is being set up on the grounds of the Air Force Academy in Colorado with the goal of promoting a dialogue between military and civilian leaders.

title: RCA Color TV Sales To Dealers Advance
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday that its distributor sales of color television sets in January were the highest for any January in company history. Jack K. Sauter, division vice president of marketing for RCA Consumer Electronics, said that despite two fewer sales days this year distributortodealer sales topped the January 1976 level by 31 percent against the industry's gain of 19.5 percent for the month.

title: Policeman Charged With Fatal Beating Of Boy, 3, in Bronx
description: A police officer who has received five departmental awards in his nine years the force was charged with homicide yesterday in the apparent beating death of a 3yearold boy last Wednesday.

title: Backers of Dayton Integration Puzzled by High Court's Decision to Review School Plan
Why Exurbanites Won't Reurbanize Themselves
description: As the cities financial difficulties continue, proposals are beginning to surface once again to bring the suburban middle class back to the city, and to push out  or disperse  the urban poor. A returning middle class, it is thought, will revitalize the urban economy, and if poor people can be encouraged to leave, the cost of running the city will decline.

title: Energy Unit to Sell Land to Exxon
description: OAK RIDGE, Term. Feb. 11 (AP)The Energy Research and Development Administration said today that it had reached an agreement to sell about 185 acres here to the Exxon Nuclear Corporation for a proposed nuclear fuel reprocessing plant.

title: 'Fellini's Casanova' Is New Revel
description: The initial sequence says it all. It is carnival time in Venice. Fireworks are raining down on the citizens, the young and the old, the beautiful and the misshapen. Suddenly, with the help of an elaborate system of weights and pulleys, the giant head of Venus begins to emerge from the Grand Canal. The crowd cheers as the master of the revels extols the goddess of love. The head rises creakily to eye level and a cable breaks. Slowly she sinks back into the dark waters. A mother screams to a child, "Cross yourself!"Using as his text Giacomo Casanova's "The Story of My Life," Federico Fellini has created another revel of a moviespectacular, but singularly joylessthat has the effect of celebrating the absolute end of romance and eroticism. There's nothing left but sex, and sex is a terminal disease. Love is a placebo."Fellini's Casanova," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1, is much less about the self-proclaimed 18th-century philanderer, his life and his times, than it is the surreal, guilt-ridden confessions of a nice, middle-class Italian husband of the 20th century. This fellow, on reaching middle age shortly before the sexual revolution, is still tormented by fantasies that seem to him to be wicked and to the rest of us merely exhausting.I don't know how else to interpret this strange, cold, obsessed film, which I find fascinating, because I find the man who made it fascinating, a talented mixture of contradictory impulses, and as depressing as an eternal hangover. Other people, less convinced of the Fellini genius, may be driven up the wall.With "Juliet of the Spirits" in 1965, Mr. Fellini seems, in retrospect, to have entered his Roxy Theater-Radio City Music Hall period by making a series of films in which he has steadfastly insisted on giving the customers more than their money's worth of movement, color, sound, light, costumes, dcor, specialty acts, sideshow freaks, quick changes and dazzling, theatrical artifice."The Clowns" and "Roma," documentary variations on themes close to Mr. Fellini's heart, were virtually meditations upon his methods. In "Amarcord," his best film since "8," the superabundance of style was given purposeful shape by benevolence and good feelings."Fellini's Casanova" recalls "Fellini's Satyricon." Though its concerns are narrower, it's as otherworldly as that nightmare vision of the pre-Christian Roman Empire. Like that film, too, "Casanova" makes no attempt to recreate an identifiable era, but, rather, to create a completely subjective impression.Nothing is real. Mr. Fellini, who now works exclusively within a studio, creates everything himself. The studio is the locus of his interior world. It's not for him to go on location to shoot a tree or a sky when he can choose the sort of tree or sky he wants from the scenic designer. Never for a moment does he ask us to believe that any tree or sky ever looked this way, only to understand that this is how he feels about them.Now, in "Casanova," Mr. Fellini has gone one step further by, in effect, constructing his leading actor. He has molded the features of Donald Sutherland, who plays Casanova, much as if he were constructing a set, adding an imperial forehead and extending the nose and chin so that no matter how the actor turns, no matter how he is photographed, they define a grotesque absurd condition.In one of the more chilly sequences of the movie, Casanova becomes infatuated with a beautiful, life-sized mechanical doll, which he takes to bed with him. The always chastely, almost prudishly photographed sexual encounter that follows has no more, or less, meaning than any of Casanova's other affairs. It's all close-ups of Casanova's sweating forehead, accompanied by panting of the sort that suggests a critical shortness of breath. In these encounters, the orgasm is a death rattle.The closing image of the film is the aged Casanova dreaming of his youth, dancing with this mechanical doll across the frozen waters of the Grand Canal, where, below the ice, we can see the head of Venus with its empty eyes.The image is daring and beautiful, but it is repeating the film's single note for one more time than is easily supportable. Like "Satyricon," "Casanova" has the form of a frieze that ends by meeting itself where it began. With the exception of a casual reference to Casanova's father, and a sequencethe best in the filmin which he runs into his aged mother in Germany, Casanova is less characterized than he is presented as if he were someone in a pageant."Fellini's Casanova" is a Dispassion Play that inventories Casanova's conquests, one after another, in Venice, Paris, London and the courts of Germany, as his lechery leads him to lonely, cranky old age.There is, I'm afraid, a terrible puritanism at work here, for though the film is often witty, it is without much humor. There's one curious moment when Mr. Fellini has Casanova defend the intelligence and strength of women, and another in which the director shows us that poor Casanova is as much the faceless sex object to his mistresses as they are to him.The production is gigantic, but the ideas and feelings are small. One longs to go home and listen to Mozart's "Don Giovanni."

title: John A. Largay, 65, the Founder Of Buell Industries in Waterbury
description: John A. Largay, chairman and founder of Buell Industries, Waterbury, Conn. died Thursday during a visit to Naples Fla. He was 65 years old and lived at 126. Judd Hill Road in Middlebury, Conn.

title: Moynihan Asks RentControl Study With View to Phasing Out System
description: Senator Daniel P. Moynihan said yesterday that rent control was probably a cause of housing abandonment in New York City and that the state government should consider phasing it out.

title: Insurgent Staff Members Take Over WBAI in a Coup
description: A dispute between the management and staff of New York's most iconoclastic radio station, WBAIFM, spilled over onto the airwaves yesterday as rebel staff members seized the station's transmitter in the Empire State Building to block an imminent broadcasting shutdown.

title: Louis Unit Dances Glances
description: In Glances, a new dance work with a score by Dave Brubeck, Murray Louis has come up with one of his jazziest pieces.

title: 119111 Loss in Boston Jolts Playoff Hope
description: BOSTON, Feb 11The Knicks have been undone again by their lack of poise.

title: F.D.A. Reverses Position On Use of Plastic Bottles For Beer and Soft Drinks
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 11 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration today backed down on its controversial approval of the use of plastic bottles for beer and soft drinks, citing studies showing the material may cause lesions or other growths in test animals.

title: Soviet Drive Against Dissidents and the. Carter Response
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11The current Soviet campaign against dissidents and the Carter Administration's simultaneous expressions of concern have raised complex questions about how far Western pressure can push the Soviet Union on matters of individual freedom.

title: Hornblower &
description: Hornblower & WeeksHemphill Noyes Inc., the big retail brokerage house, and Spencer Trask & Company, the researchoriented brokerage firm, disclosed here yesterday that the two were holding merger talks.

title: Raise for Dr. Bloustein
description: The Rutgers Board of Governors approved an increase in the salary of Edward J. Bloustein, the university president, from $43,000 to $50,000. The increase, effective Dec. 1, was originally authorized in February, last year, but was not implemented then because of the university's budget crisis.

title: Itek Unit Gets Contract
description: The Itek Corporation of Lexington, Mass., announced that its Applied Technology division had received a $12.1 million contract from the United States Air Force for the manufacture of radar warning systems.

title: CONSUMERS BUYING RISES DESPITE COLD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Government reported today economic indicators that provided a somewhat more reassuring view of the nation's prospects despite the recent spell of unusually frigid weather.

title: RABIN THINKS U.S. WILL GET SYRIANS TO SHIFT TROOPS
description: JERUSALEM, FEB. 11Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that he was optimistic that American intercession would soon result in the withdrawal of Syrian troops from an area in southern Lebanon near Israel's northern border.

title: 'Strange Shadows in Empty Room' Sheds Little Light
description: "Strange Shadows in an Empty Room" starts when a pretty student at a university in Montreal is murdered. Her brother (Stuart Whitman), a detective, sets out to solve the mystery but he is always getting sidetracked by unconvincing red herrings, car chases, friends and unlikely suspects. These characters are played by John Saxon, Martin Landau, Tisa Farrow and Gayle Hunnicutt, among others.The film was apparently photographed in Montreal and might have been designed as a tourist brochure except that the pictures, as seen at the Cinerama 2 yesterday afternoon, were often so far out of focus it could as easily have been a promotion film for Omaha.

title: The Despairing Among Us
description: It has been a time of prominent suicides. Freddie Prinze chose to end it all at the age of 22, while perhaps the most successful person of his agea television star with a vast audience who only a few days earlier had performed for the President at the inauguration festivities. One of the world's greatest dancers, Yuri Soloviev of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet, ended his life at 36. Israel's Minister of Housing, Abraham Ofer, at age 54.

title: Couple to Leave Hospital
description: Michael and Barbara Kenny, the Holbrook, L.I. couple whose five children died early Tuesday when their house burned, are to he released from Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, officials said.

title: QUAKER UNIT URGES PEACE
description: The American Friends Service Committee said yesterday that it unequivocally supports steps to insure a free, sovereign and secure state of Israel at peace with her neighbors and that it does not speak for or on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Norway to Aid Shipbuilding
description: OSLO, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  The Norwegian Government proposed measures today to avert mass unemployment within Norway's shipbuilding industry. A Government statement said that Parliament would be asked to approve loans and state guarantees to the industry, which employs about 30,000 workers.

title: Everything You Wanted to Know About Natural Gas but Were Too Cold to Ask
description: Complaining about the natural gas shortage has been a favorite indoor .sport this winter. The weather has now warmed and the shortage eased but thousands of factories, schools and public buildings across the Eastern half of the nation remain closed because of gas shortages. What was once considered as certain as water from a tap continues to prompt numerous worries and questions.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP)A Federal district judge today sentenced Susan Saxe, the antiwar activist, to 10 years in prison for the 1970 robbery of a savings and loan company here and a breakin at a National Guard armory in Massachusetts.

title: A DURYEA VENTURE BEING INVESTIGATED
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 11The Suffolk County District Attorney is looking into a Bahamas land venture in which the State Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea Jr., is a principal investor, banking sources confirmed today.

description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 11President Carter flew home to Georgia today on the massive military aircraft that would be the nation's airborne command post in wartime.
