description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 11President Park Chung Hee has stunned the country by announcing plans to build a new capital about 60 miles south of here.

title: GAS SHIPMENT TO JERSEY APPROVED, SENATOR SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  The Federal Power Commission has approved a shipment of 1 million cubic feet of natural gas to the Elizabethtown Natural Gas Co. of New Jersey to help ease the gas shortage, according to Sen. Harrison A. Williams, Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Futures Prices Move Up For Orange Concentrate
Dividends
description: FRIDAY. FEBRUARY 11. 1977

title: Books of The Times
description: By any measure, John Charles Frmont was an uncommon American. One of the earliest scientific explorers of the West, a man of resourcefulness and courage in the wilderness, the first Presidential candidate of the Republican Party, Fremont possessed a soaring imagination that fitted precisely into the national expansionist mood of the 1840's and 50's. His glowing reports ofhis five expeditions through the west across the Mississippi helped to build his reputation, which was glamorized by the elopement of the 28yearold explorer with 16yearold Jessie Benton, the beautiful daughter of Senator Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri. Frmont's ruggedly handsome looks, his Byronic adventuresomeness and his zest, combined to make him a legendary figure.

title: Ethiopia Gets Head of State With Sweeping Powers
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, effective leader of Ethiopia for two years, was named head of state tonight with sweeping powers to carry out Marxist policies.

title: Letters
description: Defense: To Retain Our Margin of Superiority

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONHerman Spurkel, a retired resident of Long Island City, Queens, has devised a method of protecting oil paintings against shrinking, warping and cracking. He notes in Patent 4,006,771. which he was granted this week, that many valuable and important works of art become damaged because of drying and other changes in the paints or pigments employed.

title: More in Garner Tribute
description: Ellis Larkins, Jimmy Rowles, Marian McPartland and Hank Jones are among additions to the previously announced list of jazz notables who will appear at a tribute to the late Erroll Garner at St. Peter's Lutheran Church's jazz vespers tomorrow, from 5 P. M. to 9, at the Central Presbyterian Church, 64th Street and Park Avenue. The public is invited, and there is no admission charge or donation requested. Information is at 7534669.

title: Concert: 8 American Composers
description: Works created by eight American composers during the last 20 years were performed in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night given by the League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music. Henry Weinberg, David Winkler and Godfrey Winham were represented by songs, Seymour Shifrin and Robert Helps by piano music. Otto Luening by his Trio for Brass and Leo Kraft and Yehudi Wyner by choral works with Hebrew texts.

title: Navy Agrees to Pay Newport News Claim
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)  The Navy announced today settlement of a bitterly disputed shipbuilding claim that could remove a cloud over future nuclear warship construction.

title: Columbia Bows to Penn For First Ivy Loss, 8685
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11Pennsylvania, the preseason favorite to win the Ivy League championship, barely escaped with an 8685 victory over Columbia tonight in the noisy Palestra.

title: Patricia Hearst's Request For New Trial Rejected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (AP)Patricia Hearst's request for a new trial on bank robbery charges was turned down again today by Federal District Judge William Orrick.

title: Film: 'Thieves,' Gulliver Among Brobdingnagians
description: A film comedy is a windup toy that performs, when released, at its own eccentric and quirky gait. "Thieves," an expensive-looking romantic comedy, is like a windup toy whose movements are being forced by a jaded and impatient child.It has some good notions, some good jokes and some good performers. But, with rare interludes, it is wrenched and graceless. It seems to be made for an audience whose humor and emotional receptiveness have gone deaf and astigmatic. It shouts and writes extra-large; we feel like Gulliver among giggling and sighing Brobdingnagians.A dozen years ago Herb Gardner wrote "A Thousand Clowns," a play that became a movie. It was about the comic and successful effort of an eccentricplayed by Jason Robardsto live in a pleasantly nonproductive manner with his nephew and a social workerBarbara Harriswho came to reform him and stayed to join him. It was sometimes preachy and longwinded; but, in general, it was a winning and very funny defense of nuttiness in the big city.With "Thieves," which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater, mr. Gardner has tried to do the same thing. He even uses a ukulele, once again, to pluck out the musical theme. His kook, this time, is a woman and she is played by Marlo Thomas. The descending distance from "Clowns" to Thieves" is as the distance between Mr. Robards, who mostly surmounted the squashy bits, to Miss Thomas, who wallows in them and makes them bigger."Thieves" starts with an enormous East Side apartment house. It is nighttime and the camera scoots along the windows while the microphone picks up a collage of rich urban murmuring, largely having to do with sex and lack of purpose. We go through a window. It belongs to Martin Cramer (Charles Grodin), principal of a flossy private school, and Sally Cramer (Miss Thomas), teacher at a public, slum school.They've been married 12 years; their fortunes are rising and their morale is sinking. He is not the fearless and funny young rebel he was when they married. She is; and to prove it she wakes him up nights and asks what his name is. Furthermore, she has just sent all their valuable furniture away to be stored in the one-room cold-water flat they first lived in.They argue, she walks out, she comes back a week later because she has decided to have an abortion, they argue some more, she walks out again. This time she goes to the apartment of an admirer and they discuss their way into bed. Next morning she is up at dawn and off to see her septuagenarian, taxi-driving father. This father, played by Irwin Corey, is a boorish, loud-mouthed street philosopher. He comes on with the effect of 10 fingernails scraping a blackboard.The husband, meanwhile, has slept with a lonely neighbor but doesn't like it. He goes back to the Lower East Side to visit the furniture, finds it's gone, has a brush with some policemen and two bums, and returns uptown. Filled with rediscovered romance, he rejoins Sally and fires off a pistol in the air to prove he is no longer stuffy, they join hands and run twinkling up the street.The ukulele plays.There are some good, parodic touches in the film. One of Sally's small pupils steals a set of passkeys and a hand-truck and collects typewriters and television sets from every apartment in the building to offer to her. In exchange, he proposes, she is to let him pass into the seventh grade. There is a doorman who does nothing but sleep, or seems to: In fact, he's dead.The best character in the film is a mournfully choleric downstairs neighbor who is being beaten into anomie by noise, soot and urban discomfort. Hector Elizondo plays him beautifully. As Martin Cramer, Mr. Grodin is fairly characterless, but considering some of the lines he has to say, this may be a virtue.The other day John Leonard mentioned a German author who wrote delightedly that cats have two holes in their coats coinciding neatly with their eyes. Miss Thomas has holes in her skin for eyes and mouththose devices used by actors for expressiveness. But the holes don't coincide: they are much larger."Thieves" has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). The symmetrical adulteries of Sally and Martin, though not actually shown, are probably responsible.

title: Rock: Boston Heads a Triple Bill
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Feb. 11The chief interest at last night's rock triple bill at the Nassau Coliseum here was the headliner, Boston. Last August, when the group's first record came out, nobody had heard of them. In fact, they weren't even a band yet; the record had been made by Tom Scholz, the leader and songwriter, who overdubbed nearly all the guiar, bass and keyboard parts, and Brad Delp, the singer, plus a drummer.

title: Harvester Resumption
description: International Harvester Company said it was resuming full production at its Fort Wayne, Ind., plant, which had been closed for two weeks because of natural gas curtailments. Of the plant's 9,500 employees, only 5,200 production workers were laid off during the closure. These now are being recalled, the company said.

title: A SCHOOL AIDE URGES CUSTODIAN CONTROLS
description: Tighter controls over New York City's more than 1,000 school custodians, including a prohibition against nepotism, have been recommended by Dr. Bernard. R. Gifford, the Deputy School Chancellor.

title: Czech HardLiners Said to Lose Round in Bid to Stop Drive for Rights
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 11Leading campaigners for broader freedoms in Czechoslovakia say they believe that the Communist Party hardliners have lost the first round in what may be a long fight.

title: Boulez Gives 2 Concerts in One
description: Nobody has ever quite settled on the ideal way to present new music to symphony audiences. The all modern programreferred to trenchantly by George Szell as the common grave of contemporary musicdoesn't really work, and yet the formula for mixing today and yesterday is hard to find and apply with consistent success. But wait. Pierre Boulez may have hit on the most sensible scheme, either by chance or by design, at Thursday night's New York Philharmonic subscription. His program broke down into two distinct concerts.

title: Club's Decision Not to Invite Young Stirs Controversy in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11  Printed across the front of the International House, World Trade Center in New Orleans is the organization's reason for being: Dedicated to world peace, trade and understanding.

title: Policeman Convicted
description: Sandy Check, a suspended 30yearold policeman from Brooklyn, has been convicted of participating in a narcotics conspiracy, including the sale of half an ounce of heroin for $1,350. Peter Sudler, the Federal prosecutor, said Mr. Check would face up to 15 years in prison and a 525,000 fine on each of three counts in Federal District Court in Manhattan. A codefendant, Philip Marasco of Jackson Heights, Queens, was also convicted of the conspiracy.

title: 2 Held in Arsons
description: Two men were arrested in separate incidents of alleged arsonone in Newark in which a mother and daughter were killed, the other in the Bronx, where hundreds of tenants were forced to flee from their apartments. The man arrested in connection with the Newark blaze was identified by the police as Pedro Garcia Camacho, 18 years old. The man arrested in the Bronx blaze was Samuel Miller, 20, of 121 St. Nicholas Avenue.

title: Cauthen Stirs Claim of Foul By the State
New Paternity Affidavits Ordered For Welfare Aid in New York City
Letters: On the Daoud Affair
description: The Ambassador's Outrageous Argument

title: BERGLAND TO FIGHT NEW MUTUAL FUND FOR FARM INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland, expressing concern over a new type of mutual fund planned by a large Chicago bank to invest in farm land, said today that he would lobby the Treasury to try to block a key ruling needed to get the operation started.

title: Topless Raid Against Cellist Is ReCreated
description: On February 9, 1967, the New York City police interrupted a performance by Charlotte Moorman of Nam June Paik's Opera Sextronique by arresting the two principals. Miss Moorman was playing the cello nude from the waist up, as Mr. Paik's score dictated, and, although the composer was released from custody and not charged, Miss Moorman was tried and convicted for partial nudity. The sentence was suspended.

title: City to Rehire Last Of LaidOff Firemen
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that 60 laidoff firemen, the last of 897 who had been let go on June 30, 1975, because of the fiscal crisis, would be rehired as of Feb. 25. The rehiring of all 897 was made possible through a combination of improved management, accelerated retirements and Federal aid.

title: CATHOLICS WIDENING ANTIAPARTHEID ROLE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 11The Roman Catholic Church announced today that it intended to appoint black priests to white parishes as part of major church reforms in South Africa.

title: Bomb Blast in L.I. School Injures Student
description: A time bomb exploded yesterday morning in the library of Roslyn High School on Long Island. One 17yearold student who was near the scene of the blast was injured when splinters from the bomb struck him in the shoulder.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 11 (Reuters)The Maine Central Railroad, one of only three independent Northeastern railroads, said today that an order by the Interstate Commerce Commission could drive it into bankruptcy.

title: J. Brock Stokes, 42, Chairman Of Oppenheimer Corp., Is Dead
description: J. Brock Stokes, chairman of the board of Oppenheimer Corporation, an investment concern, died Tuesday while visiting Los Angeles on a business trip. He was 42 years old.

title: Canada's Cost of Living Up 0.9% In Month, With Food Rising 1.2%
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (Reuters)The cost of living in Canada jumped ninetenths of 1 percent last month, the sharpest monthly rise since November 1975, Statistics Canada said today.

title: ICM Artists Schedules Takeover Of Operation of Hurok Concerts
description: ICM Artists, Ltd., a subsidiary of Marvin Josephson Associates Inc., announced yesterday that it had taken over the current operations of Hurok Concerts Inc., as of Thursday.

title: At Saks Hackensack, Last Touches Before Opening
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 11The last little cosmetic touches were being made in the bright and airy new Saks Fifth Avenue store here today for its Valentine's Day opening on Monday.

title: Nevada Assembly Defeats Equal Rights by 24 to 15
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 11 (UPI) The Nevada Assembly defeated the equal rights amendment today by a vote of 24 to 15.

title: TunaCatching Device Releases Porpoises
description: In tuna fishing, a good many porpoises have been destroyed. James M. Seabrooke of Petaluma, Calif., reports an estimate that 300,000 a year have been killed by American tuna seiners. He was granted patent 4,006,549 for a porpoisereleasing tuna seine.

title: Putting Nature Back Into the Frozen Yogurt
description: The question Is, What does the consumer perceive yogurt to be? explained Bruce Rae, marketing director of H.P. Hood, in announcing his company's recent reduction of chemicals in its frozen mix, Frogurt.

title: Learning to Be Tough At Government Cost
description: WASHINGTON  Myrna Fogle, a professional writer at the Department of Agriculture, completed a threeday assertiveness training workshop, on a Thursday and walked into her office the following Monday and negotiated a promotion.

title: Assassination Probe, Revisited
description: The assassination that will not die, is how a headline writer once described the unending controversies over the murder of President Kennedy. The shabby turmoil in the House of Representatives over its investigation of that assassination, and that of Martin Luther King, lends new truth to that phrase and casts new doubt on the House investigation.

title: Prison Drug Aide Seized
description: An undercover Queens detective arrested a specialist who works with drug addicts at the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Men on charges of possession and sale of cocaine.

title: Tanzania Closes Roads To Tourists From Kenya
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 11 (UPDTanzania announced today that it had permanently barred tourists from entering the country by road from Kenya.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the mostpopular conventions In modern tournament play is Drury. When partner has bid one spade or one heart in third seat, a twoclub bid asks him to bid two diamonds if he has a minimum or subminimum hand. This will often permit the partnership to remain safely at the twolevel when each player has about 11 highcard points.

title: Small Nozzles For InkJet Printing
description: In inkjet printing, a process for which a bright future is predicted, no type or press is involved, but tiny drops of ink are released onto a moving sheet of paper in letters and numbers controlled by a computer.

title: Beame Vows to Bring Pressure to Resolve JetsShea Dispute
description: Mayor Beame promised yesterday to exert every pressure to resolve the Shea Stadium dispute that has caused the New York Jets to consider moving their National Football League team to New Jersey.

title: Personal Investing
description: Individual investment money has been draining out of the stock market for yeats now and Alfred M. Isselbacher, who owns the Isselbacher Gallery on Madison Avenue, thinks he knows where a lot of the cash has gone.

title: SHIPPING AND MAILS
description: OUTGOING

title: WALTER DEGNAN, 68
description: Walter J. Degnan, the first and only president of the American Federation of School Administrators, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the union's offices. at 110 East 42d Street. He lived at 2 Walworth Avenue in Scarsdale, N.Y., and would have been 69 years old tomorrow.

title: Music: Maazel Leads Clevelanders in Beethoven
description: This year is the 150th anniversary of the death of Beethoven, and noises about the event will probably be going on all this season and next. Last night in Carnegie Hall the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by Lorin Maazel started its Beethoven seriesa group of concerts that will take in all of the nine symphonies, the five piano concertos with Emil Gilels and some other music.

title: I.B.M. WINS ANTITRUST SUIT OVER CALIFORNIA COMPUTER
description: A Los Angeles Federal judge directed a verdict for the International Business Machines Corporation and against California Computer Products Inc. in a major antitrust action brought by the peripheralequipment producer against the computer industry giant several months ago.

title: Rockefeller Archive Contains a Wealth on Wealth
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y.In this stately pleasure home, Queen Victoria. resplendent in oils, is monarch of all she surveys in the powder room.

title: Article 6  No Title
SUPREME COURT BARS WILEY APPOINTMENT
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that State Senator Stephen B. Wiley, Democrat of Morristown, could not be appointed to the high court because he was in the Legislature when the justices salaries were raised in 1974.

title: Young Calls Full War Last Resort in Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Andrew Young arrived here today on his way home from a tour of Africa and said that he thought a shooting war to gain black rule in Rhodesia would be a last resortout of desperation.

title: 'Sentinel,' Less a Horror Film Than Dull
description: If the movie industry is going to go on turning out works about Satanism, perhaps some of the larger film schools should consider adding a course in Theology, or at least Pastoral Protocol.It is the kind of nagging thought that arises at a viewing of Michael Winner's "The Sentinel," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli, Columbia II and other theaters.Nagging thoughts are not supposed to arise in horror pictureslast summer Mr. Winner predicted that this picture would be extremely horrifying  but "The Sentinel" has long stretches where there is nothing to do but notice things.For example, the film's thesis is that there is a tiny unplugged passageway to Hell in Brooklyn Heights. The Roman Catholic Church periodically chooses, by lot, some unfortunate nonvolunteer to sit by the hole and make sure the devils don't get out.I'm not saying that this is totally impossibleunlikely, of course, but not impossible. There are a lot of holes in Brooklyn Heights. But the film shows us an assemblage of what look like cardinals and canons-major meeting to choose the next nonvolunteer: in this case a New York fashion model played by Cristina Raines. We all know that such decisions are not made by the top brass but by strange old priests on pension in Cape May.Then again, the inscription on the chink comes from Dante. It is the line about "abandon all hope ye who enter." Now it is not generally held that Dante actually visited Hell. He stayed around Florence, pretty much, and worked from second-hand reports. What is quite certain is that he never got to Brooklyn.Are these pedantic objections, considering Mr. Winner's strenuous effort to remind us of "Rosemary's Baby"a magnificent old apartment, a hopeful young couple, sinister neighbors and so on? The point is he has not given us much else.There is Miss Raines as Alison Parker, looking sicker day by day. There is her crooked lover, Michael Lerman (Chris Sarandon) and just whose side he is on isn't clear until the end, and then he switches. There is a great deal of latex and makeup.The film's plot need not be revealed much further, other than to say that it is a struggle. On one side is the Church trying to get Alisonwho has rented the apartment simply because it has a nice view of New Yorkon the job as the sentinel. On the other side are a lot of devils, in the form of reincarnated murderers, who try to persuade her to kill herself first.This is where the latex comes in. At first, the devils simply take the form of odd neighbors. As the movie goes on, they reveal their real shapesgaping wounds, absent noses, melted features and so on. Her own father, an unpleasant man given to orgies in the upstairs bedroom, is one of the gang.The confrontations are supposed to be terrifying but the most they offer is some mild creepiness. Miss Raines does a pretty good job as the distraught woman in a no-win situation. Mr. Sarandon and actors such as Burgess Meredith and Sylvia Miles, who are devils, drop by to collect their pay. Mr. Winner has sweetened the mess with some nudity, a little masturbation and a dash of lesbianism.

title: Sadat's Decrees Approved, but Gain Is Doubted
description: CAIRO, Feb. IIThe Egyptian Government said today that 99.4 percent of the voters approved yesterday the tough lawandorder measures decreed by President Anwar elSadat following the foodprice riots of last month, but Western diplomats expressed doubt that the President's position had been bolstered.

title: Walker Slated To Run 1,500 Here Tonight
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U. S., After a Delay Attacks Arrest of Soviet Dissident
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11After some initial indecision, the Carter Administration moved on two fronts today to express concern over the arrest in Moscow of another prominent humanrights activist, Yuri Orlov.

title: PRESBYTERIES REJECT NEW BOOK OF CREEDS
description: Efforts to unify the nation's two largest branches of the Presbyterian church received a setback yesterday when the Southernbased Presbyterian Church in the United States rejected a book of confessions that would have served as a common basis of faith.

title: CATHOLICS WIDENING ANTIAPARTHEID ROLE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 11The Roman Catholic Church announced today that it intended to appoint black priests to white parishes as part of major church reforms in South Africa.

title: Wilmington Reports Earthquake
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 11 (AP)A, small earthquake surprised residents here. yesterday; There were no reports of injuries or damage. Robert Jordan, a state geologist, said that preliminary information indicated the earthquake occurred at 2:14 P.M. in the southwestern part of the city.

title: Rockefeller Archive Contains a Wealth on Wealth
ExPolice Chief Jailed
description: A former Lawnside Borough police chief was sentenced to one to two years in prison for accepting bribes to fix gambling cases. Judge Leon Wingate of Camden County Court imposed the sentence on Floard Catlatt, 47 years old, who had been police chief for 13 years until he was removed following his conviction last December.

title: Hanoi Toughness In South Is Seen
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 11Some former South Vietnamese military officers and civil servants still being held prisoner by the Communists are being transferred to socalled reeducation camps near Hanoi, reports from Vietnam indicate.

title: Gas Truck Crashes and Explodes
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (AP)One of two tanks on a tandem truck carrying 16,000 gallons of gasoline exploded and burned after the truck crashed on a busy freeway in downtown Detroit about noon today, the police said. The truck driver and an occupant of another car suffered minor injuries. Witnesses said that the truck hit a guardrail and flipped over when the driver swerved to avoid a car that had cut in front to reach an exit ramp.

title: Few Bright Spots in OnceBooming Florida Economy
description: MIAMIThere are few sunny spots in the Florida economy these days.

title: China Indicates Concern Over U.S. Detente Policy
description: PEKING, Feb. 11For the first time China publicly indicated its concern yesterday over President Carter's pursuit of detente with the Soviet Union.

title: Madlock Goes to Giants As Cubs Obtain Murcer
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)Bill Madlock, winner of two straight National League batting championships, was traded today by the Chicago Cubs to the San Francisco Giants in a fiveplayer deal in which the Cubs key acquisition was Bobby Murcer, the outfielder.

title: Women Ski Into Major Role at Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 11Not long ago it was considered something special by young women to receive an invitation to the Dartmouth Carnival to watch the men compete. Today the men were watching the women compete as the twoday skiing phase of the colorful winter jamboree got under way.

title: Travelers Fourth Quarter Profit $1.03 a Share, 16% Above 1975 Level
description: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's second largest publicly owned insurance enterprise after the Aetna Insurance Company, reported yesterday a fourthquarter net income of $44.7 million, or $1.03 a share, up 16.1 percent from $38.5 million, or 88 cents a share, in the final quarter rf 1975.

title: BONN STANDS BY SALE OF ATOMIC EQUIPMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. IIWest Germany has refused to budge from its commitment to sell nuclear equipment with weaponsmaking potential to Brazil despite strong demands put forward by the United States in confidential meetings yesterday and today, Administration officials reported.

title: McIlhargey's Suspension Lifted, Pending an Appeal
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 11 (AP)The 10 game suspension of Vancouver's defenseman, Jack Mcllhargey, was lifted today by Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, pending the outcome of an appeal hearing requested by the Canucks.

title: Military Honors for Ilyushin
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP)  The Soviet aircraft designer. Sergei V. Ilyushin, was buried with military honors today at Moscow's Novodevichy Cemetery, the resting place of many leading Soviet figures. Mr. Ilyushin died Wednesday after a grave illness, Tass, the official press agency reported. He was 82.

title: CONSUMERS' BUYING RISES DESPITE COLD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Government reported today economic indicators that provided a somewhat more reassuring view of the nation's prospects despite the recent spell of unusually frigid weather.

title: Encore for That EarlyMovie Modern Furniture
description: The earlymovie modern look that North Carolina mass manufacturers are now reproducing, is as glamorous and glittering as any decorating the film sets that Jean Harlow graced in the 1930's.

title: 76ers 118, Pacers 109
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP)Four baskets by Julius Erving and a 3point play by George McGinnis provided the Philadelphia 76ers with a 118109 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: Head of State Alcoholism Agency Is Like a Juggler on a Tightrope
description: Riley Regan is like a man on a tightrope carrying a grand piano across the Great Gorge. The odds are against him, but if nobody asks him for a match he just might make it.

title: Mailers Ordered Back At Philadelphia Papers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (UPI)A Federal district judge tonight ordered mailers at The Evening Bulletin and the strikebound Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News to return to work. Judge Herbert Fogel was also hearing an injunction request against the delivery drivers at the three newspapers.

title: Milgo Electronics Postpones Meeting
description: The Milgo Electronics Corporation said in Miami yesterday that its annual meeting, scheduled for March 4, had been postponed. A new date will be announced later.

title: 8 Louisiana Officials Plead Guilty To Vote Fraud in Congress Race
description: NEW ORLEANS. Feb. 11Eight voting commissioners pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of stealing 239 votes in behalf of Representative Richard A. Tonry in the Oct. 2 Democratic primary election, in which he defeated the favored candidate by 184 votes.

title: Article 7  No Title
MEDITERRANEAN CLEANUP SOME PROGRESS IS MADE
description: ATHENS, Feb. 11Sixteen countries that border the Mediterranean agreed today on a set of principles for combating pollution in their common sea, but they disagreed on how strict specific rules should be and how fast they should be implemented.

title: Keele Takes College Post
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)Tom Keele, the offensive coordinator for British Columbia of the Canadian Football League last season, was named to a similar post yesterday at Long Beach State.

title: Random House Sale Talks Pushed
description: Negotiations for the purchase of Random House Inc. from the RCA Corporation by the Times Mirror Company progressed yesterday under tight security, according to industry sources. Both companies declined to say more than the original announcement on Wednesday, which stated simply that negotiations were taking place.

title: THE REV. ARNOLD H. LOWE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11 (UPI)  The Rev. Arnold H. Lowe, once named preacher of the year at the church attended by President Eisenhower, died last night in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Bell, in Shift, Orders Civil Rights Inquiry In Chicano's Killing
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 11In a reversal of a longstanding Government policy, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today ordered a Federal grand jury inquiry into the shotgun slaying of 26yearold Richard Morales by the police chief of nearby Castroville in 1975.

title: India Mourns Death of President
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 11 Thousands of people tonight filed solemnly past the flowercovered bier of Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed, President of India, who died of a heart attack here this morning at the age of 71.

title: Merger of FarMarCo. And Farmland Industries Voted at Annual Meeting
description: Voting delegates of the member cooperatives of FarMarCo in Hutchinson, Kan., the nation's largest grain cooperative, voted yesterday in Denver to merge with Farmland Industries, of Kansas City, Mo., the country's largest agricultural cooperative.

title: Dismissal of Moritt Case Is Urged
description: The special state prosecutor for the criminaljustice system. John F. Keenan, moved yesterday to dismiss the indictment of former Judge Fred Moritt of Civil Court in Brooklyn. Mr. Moritt was charged with using the salary of his law secretary to finance the production of a musical play the judge had written. Mr. Keenan said the 71yearold judge was too ill to stand trial.

title: About New York
description: Maybe if the city offered M. Donald Grant of the Mets the controlling seat on the Emergency Financial Control Board plus exclusive hot dog rights to the entire city, he would accept the gift of plastic grass for Shea Stadium that would enable us to view Joe Namath in his pantyhose commercials next season as our own'Joe Willie and not Governor Byrne's.

title: Article 2  No Title
The Academy of Saints Rejects the Lincoln Application
description: AMHERST, Mass.Most Americans think of Abraham Lincoln as a saintly railsplitter who called himself Abe, spoke in a deep, fatherly voice, disdained material rewards and personified America's ideal Everyman. That is the Lincoln of mythology, but it is not the Lincoln of reality.

title: New York Council Leaders Give $60,500 in Lulus to Chairmen
description: A total of $60,500 in lulusstipends in lieu of expenseshas been parceled out by leaders of the New York City Council to the heads of 17 committees, it was announced yesterday.

title: Article 4  No Title
People and Business
description: The Ford Motor Company's chairman, Henry Ford 2d, said yesterday that he would name a successor this year, putting control of the No. 2 auto producer outside of his family for the first time in its 74year history.

title: BEAME AND PRESIDENT TALK ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Mayor Beame met with President Carter for a halfhour at the White House yesterday to discusp the New York City situation andin passing, Mr. Beame saidthe Mayor's own political plans this year.

title: INDIANAPOLIS GUNMAN IS HELD IN KIDNAPPING
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 11 (AP)Anthony G. Kiritsis, who considered himself a free man after releasing the hostage he held during a 63hour siege, was arraigned today on a list of charges, including kidnapping.

title: GREEN LIGHT SOUGHT FOR STORAGE OF GAS
description: Officials of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest public utility, plan to go to Albany next week to deliver to the New York Department of Environmental Conservation a petition to speed an investigation of a liquefied natural gas facility on Staten Island.

title: Carter Discloses His Trust Accord To Limit Any Conflicts of Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  President Carter released today the details of a trust agreement that is designed to limit personal conflicts of interest by removing him from control of the agricultural land and the peanut warehouse business in Georgia that he owns with some of his relatives.

title: Braves Win, 9694, on Smith's Basket.
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 11A soaring turnaround jump shot by Randy Smith with two seconds left tonight, canceled another spate of heroics by Mike Bantom and Bubbles Hawkins as the BuffaloBraves slipped past the Nets, 9694.

title: VENDOR'S WIFE WON $35,000 IN LOTTERY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP)The estranged wife of Arthur Milgram, a lottery vendor who was slain last Tuesday, won $35,000 in the state lottery two years ago with a ticket obtained from the lotteryticket vending enterprise run by her husband.

title: College to Get $250,000
description: The Foundation of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has announced a $250,000 gift from the ScheringPlough Foundation Inc. of Kenilworth.

title: Insurgent Staff Members at WBAI Seize Transmitter
description: A dispute between the management and staff of New York's most iconoclastic radio station, WBAIFM, spilled over onto the airwaves yesterday as rebel staff members seized the station's transmitter in the Empire State Building to block an imminent broadcasting shutdown.

title: ITALY SAYS I.M.F. IS READY TO DISCUSS A NEW LOAN
description: ROME, Feb. 11 (UPI)The International Monetary Fund, apparently satisfied with Premier Giulio Andreotti's latest austerity measures, is ready to resume negotiations for a $530 million standby loan to Italy, the Government said today.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Yankees have signed three more players, bringing their total to 22 of 39. Elrod Hendricks, a 36yearold reserve catcher, signed a oneyear contract. Twoyear contracts were signed by Dave Bergman, a 23yearold first basemanoutfielder and Ron Guidry, 26, a lefthanded relief pitcher Bergman batted .295 for Syracuse in the Class AAA International League last year. In 7 games with the Yankees last season, Guidry had a 5.62 earned run average and no decisions. At Syracuse, his wonlost record was 51, with an 0.68 e.r.a. and 9 saves.

title: Alertness Tests For Highway Drivers
description: A man who was once a slave laborer in Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union and later studied engineering in his native Poland has been granted a United States patent. Waclaw K. Slomski, who now lives in Syracuse, has invented a device to test a subject's alertness and rate of perception.

title: Owners Notified by Ford On Pollution Control Part
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company began notifying owners of 4.4 million 197374 cars and light trucks today that part of their pollution control system might fail.

title: Princess's Husband Stopped for Speeding
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP)Three weeks after Princess Anne was fined for driving 96 miles an hour on an expressway, her husband has been given a ticket for speeding.

title: Article 1  No Title
Man With Shotgun, Holding 8 Hostages, Demands His Child
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 11 (AP)A man with a shotgun took eight hostages in a home for unwed mothers tonight and threatened to kill them unless he received information about a baby he said was born there 20 years ago.

title: Notes on People
description: Benjamin F. Holman, a former NBCTV reporter in Washington who was appointed director of the Community Relations Service in the Justice Department in the Nixon Administration in 1969, was dismissed yesterday. It was indicated that Mr. Holman, who is black, would be replaced for the time being by his deputy, Gilbert Pompa.

title: U.S. Sailors on Italian Isle Find Amity but No Social Life
description: LA NIADDALENA, Sardinia, Feb. 11  Local girls are virtually nonexistent as far as personnel of visiting ships are concerned. Due to their society's rules, the local residents prefer that their daughters go out with other residents.

title: MOTORMAN IN FATAL CRASH SAYS SAFETY GEAR FAILED
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UPI)The motorman says poor visibility from his cab and the failure of a safety system resulted in the Feb. 4 elevated train accident that killed 11 persons and injured nearly 200, his lawyer said today.

title: A New Piece by Janet Soares Is Performed by Dance Uptown
description: Dance Uptown grew out of Janet Soares's desire to provide a performing space for choreographers that would be free of the prevailing restrictions that entangled other locales. It was an idea that found its time and 10 years later the organization continues to provide performing locations; the proscenium arch stage, gymnasium openness or even outdoor spots depending on the individual needs. In the time that Dance Uptown has been going, several other institutions on Morningside Heights, including the theater of Riverside Church and the Synod House of St. John the Divine have become host to dancers and one can only suspect that they were encouraged by the example of Dance Uptown's success.

title: Present Schedule Format Retained
description: The N.B.A, owners, decided to retain the present format for scheduling. In this method each of the 22 teams plays 19 of the clubs four times season and the other clubs three times.

title: Article 1  No Title
FISHER PUTTING MARK ON EA OPERATIONS
description: Officially, he is only filling in, but in fact, Harold L. Fisher, acting chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and heir apparent to David L. Yimich, has begun to put his own stamp on the multibilliondollar state agency.

title: The Wildlife Of the Industrial Northeast
description: A moose walked through Hartford, Conn. one day several years ago. Somehow, it had made its way down from Canada or northern New England and a wellmeaning game warden, hoping to move it easily to a more favorable habitat, shot it with a tranquilizer drug. The moose went the way of others in modem cities; it died of an overdose.

title: ...I've Heard That Rock Before
description: THE setting is a very popular bar in central Westchester. A dimly lit room that seems no more than 4 by 4 feet, where mostly standingroomonly crowds of students pay an average $2.50 cover and $1.25 a drink every night of the week just to listen to some live music. This is the kind of suburban mecca that once, not so long ago, could have been the typical outoftheway birthplace for many of rock n roll's most accomplished artists, where one could hear the forceful, innovative sounds of tomorrowtoday.

title: Steve Lubin Plays Fortepiano and Grand
description: The fortepiano has been a chimera until recent seasons, a unicorn of keyboard, often heard about but not heard except by scholars and museum curators. But this late 18thcentury contraption, which looks like a harpsichord and sounds like a piano being played in the next apartment, has been turning up lately on the recital stage, with enlightening results.

title: Penn 59, Cornell 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP)Tim Smith led the University of Pennsylvania on an 182 secondhalf spurt tonight en route to a 5941 victory over Cornell at the Palestra.

title: Letters
description: Justice would be better served (The case against capital punishment by Abe Fortas, Jan. 23) if the family of a murdered victim would be allowed to pass sentence on the murderer, rather than a jury of unconcerned people and a judge whose only duty is to follow the laws given to him. Sunbury, Pa.

title: Padres Winfield Sets Up An $800 Scholarship Fund
Three Impresarios Who Changed The Record Catalogue
description: When Edison invented the phonograph, he also founded an industry and created several new professions. One of these was the craft of the record producer, the A. & R. man, who deals with artists and the music they want to perform.

title: Inflation Rate Holds the Key
description: The key to the stock market, it's said, is the behavior of interest rates.The key to interest rates, it's commonly believed, is inflation.

title: Mini Revolution in the Computer World
description: Among the nation's technology leaders, Bell Laboratories is highly regarded for its expert management, and mistakes in decisionmaking at this major subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are considered rare.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: A general trend or movement toward smaller cameras and smaller film has been characteristic of the entire evolution of photography since its beginflings, and when Kodak introduced the pocket Instamatic camera and the 110 film cartridge on March 16, 1972, this trend was sharply accelerated. The trend towards miniaturization results from the desire of many photographers to have an instrument that is light in weight, compact, reliable, and capable or producing prints of good quality, yet inexpensive to operate. Now, after almost five years, there is no doubt that manufacturers, processors and photographers have accepted the 110 format, and cameras and films are be ginning to approach this ideal.

title: Knightly Marvin Triumphs
description: BOWIE, Md.. Feb. 12 (AP)Knightly Marvin upset five other 3yearolds in the $27,800 W. P. Burch Stakes at Bowie Race Course today. Ridden by Bobby Gilbert, Knightly Marvin circled his rivals at the top of the stretch to beat Do The Bump by a length and complete the six furlongs in 1:11 2/5.

title: $2 Million Settlement Is Reported In Women's Bias Suit Against NBC
description: NBC reportedly has agreed to a $2 million outofcourt settlement of a sex bias suit brought by women employees.

title: Toughest Job to Hold? A Head Coach in N.F.L.; About Pro Football
description: The hiring of Tommy Hudspeth by the Detroit Lions last week completed the roster of head coaches in the tional Football League for the coming season. Counting Hudspeth, John McVay of the Giants and Jim Ringo of the Buffalo Bills, all of whom held interim appointments last season after the discharge of predecessors, the N.F.L. has six new head coaches for 1977. The others are Lee Bennett at Atlanta, Rea Miller in Denver and Walt Michaels with the Jets.

title: HOURS ARE CUT AGAIN AT SOME LIBRARIES
description: At least 40 of the New York Public Library's 83 branch libraries are scheduled to be open only two days a week starting next Friday, because of the system's continuing fiscal crisis, according to Edward Holmgren, chief of the branch library division.

title: Rockville Centre Tries Again
description: FACED for the second time in 13 years with the alternatives of either closing an allegedly seggegated grade school or upgrading it to make it more attractive to white transfer students, the Rockville Centre Board of Education has chosen the latteragain.

title: A Plea for Less Law
description: WASHINGTONA subtle but perceptible tremor rippled through Washington's legal community the other day. Although the lay public may also have noted a certain Presidential statement with passing interest, rankandfile members of the law profession were observed muttering to themselves and looking somewhat furtively over their shoulders.

title: Harry the Horse Steels for an Ordeal:
Confidence Ebbing
description: WASHINGTONThe nation's cold wave finally eased last week, bringing at least a temporary surcease in the myriad economic problems related to it, but the controversy over tax and spending programs to attack the prime issue of the dayhow to reduce unemployment significantlyhas heated up in the political realm here and in other sectors of American society.

title: Bess Truman Is 92 Today
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 12 (UPI) Elizabeth Virginia Wallace was a 5yearold blueeyed tomboy when a myopic 6yearold boy named Harry Truman fell in love with her at Sunday School in 1890.

title: CHESS
description: One type of confrontation that perpetually reappears in many forms in many games is that in which one side consumes time in the opening for the sake of acquiring the pair of bishops, while the other side is granted a lead in development and space.

title: Shutting Out The Sunshine
description: NEW YORK STATE'S sunshine law, which has opened previously closed meetings of government bodies to the public, has been in effect for barely month, but long enough to have be come the target of municipal attorneys looking for loopholes, and resistance to it among legislators has been growing at a fast pace in Westchester County.

title: Home and office: Bridging the gap
description: MILAN, ItalyFor years, Gae Aulenti, one of Italy's top architects and industrial designers, searched this historic North Italian city for adjoining structures that could be adapted to serve as her office and her home. What she found three years ago was an 18thcentury house in front of an 18thcentury palazzo.

title: Spirit of '76 Deleted From President's Plane
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)The Presidential jet, Air Force One, no longer has Spirit of '76 painted on its nose.

title: Uncertainty in the Figures
description: No one knows exactly how many people are, handicapped. Government figures vary widely, from 40 to 68 million; The 1970 United States Census, the first to ask about disabilities, produced the lower figure, which does not include the handicapped in institutionsor the many persons believed to have omitted mention of their disabilities in the census report. The higher figure includes persons with heart disease, cancer, diabetes, epilepsy and a history of emotional illness. The following statistics were provided by the National Arts and the Handicapped Information Service and are drawn from several sources, including the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: When Paul Newman Talks...
description: HE is hounded by autographseeking natives in Bimini, and his sunglasses are snatched off his face on Fifth Avenue. But at home in Westport, Paul Newman enjoys as much privacy as any leading man and international sex symbol has a right to expect.

title: Jumping the Bell
description: WE'RE amused by the fuss surrounding the Public Service Commission's decision to make New York Telephone accept his and her phone listings. Our names have appeared to gether in the Westchester phone book for more than a year.

title: Sally Adkins Sets Wedding
description: The engagement of Sally Denison Adkins, a lawyer, to William Jolliffe Bostian, a thirdyear law student, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. Dale Adkins Jr. of Salisbury, Md. Mr. Bostian is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Logan Bostian of Virginia Beach. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Margaret R. Finch Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Baker Finch of Lawrence. L.I., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Riker Finch. to Arthur Charrington Ames Nicol. son of Elizabeth Charrington NluIctaur or warrenton. va., ana the late Carlyle Forrest Nicol Jr. A May wedding is planned in New York.

title: Young Returns, Sees Some Hope of Rhodesian Talks
GARDENING
description: EACH year, the Associated Landscape Contractors of America conducts a national competition to define and honor excellence in landscape design and and construction. its awards are the Oscars of horticulture. This year's awards were presented by Lady Bird Johnson on Jan. 26 at the organization's annual meeting in Palm Springs, Calif., and the Dix Hills concern of Steven Dubner Landscaping Inc. received a grand award in the residential division.

title: The Nation
Two Win First Stakes,  Races
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)Two Californiabred horses who had never before won a stakes raceMr. Bold Batter and Keep the Promise  captured the two sections of the $35,030 Camino Real Handicap today at Santa Anita.

title: Libraries Closed Tomorrow
14 Authors Tell How to Instruct Writing Classes
description: Do not condescend to these kids, Ralph Ellison urged several hundred publicschool English teachers, mostly from the city's high schools and community colleges, at a seminar last week on The Author, the Student and the Art of Teaching Writing. It was held at the Graduate Center of the City University, 33 West 42d Street.

title: Hail Hilarious Is Favored In Rich Coast Race Today
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)Donald Pierce and Hail Hilarious, victorious in two stakes races at Santa Anita this meeting, team again tomorrow in the $115,300 La Canada Stakes. The probable favorite in the 1mile race for older fillies, Hail Hilarious will carry top weight of 121 pounds against eight rivals.

title: Federation Is Seeking to Get Coaches
description: The United States Soccer Federation has on file about 1.800 licensed coaches, a number that Walt Chyzowych, director of coaching nationwide, feels is only a drop in the bucket compared with the number needed in the near future.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market continued its 1977 slide last week despite news that the adverse impact of the recent severely cold weather on the economy was receding.

title: St. Peter's 76, Mt. St. Mary's 64
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12Bob Fazio scored 23 points and grabbed 14 rebounds and a teammate, Benny Allen, netted 17 points to lift St. Peters to a 7664 victory over Mount St. Mary's tonight.

title: A Consumer Sunrise in the West
description: For those concerned about consumer interests, a lovely flare went up on the western horizon the other day when Governor Brown of California appointed 60 persons to state regulatory boards that oversee a variety of professions. Although advertised with a fair amount of California showmanship, the action was rooted in a substantial political achievement.

title: The Street of Crocodiles
description: Thirtyfive years ago. Bruno Schulz. a 50yearold high school art teacher in command of one of the most original literary imaginations of modern Europe, was gunned down by a Jewhunting contingent of SS men in the streets of an insignificant provincial town in eastern Galicia. On the map of Poland the town hides itself from you; you have to search out the tiniest print to discover Drogobych. In this cramped crevice of a place Schulz too hid himselfthough not from the Nazis. Urged on by a group of writers, the Polish underground devised a means of escapefalse papers and a hiding place.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NOT every neighborhood in the suburbs is one big happy Brotherhood Week. When hostilities break out across the hedge, it is often difficult to pinpoint the origins. Historians can tell, you how wars start, but go try to analyze a dispute between neighbors. Even if it gets as far as court, it will be hard to place the moral blame because each side is so righteous in the belief that God and morality are hanging over its shoulder.

title: Westminster Judging Program
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A number of woman inmates at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility may be transferred to a men's prison near Buffalo in an effort to reduce the population of the facility, the state's only women's prison, and to move upstate women closer to their homes.

title: Thousands Are Picketing, Filing Suits and Lobbying for Promised Equal Protection of the Law
description: One symbol for race discrimination in the nineteensixties was the absence of free choice of seats on buses. The handicapped, whatever their race, often cannot even get on the busor through revolving doors, up escalators, or Into classrooms and offices. This arbitrary exclusion from society has produced an aggressive civil rights movement by the nation's 50 million handicapped persons for mobility, education and jobs.worked for blacks, including angry and ironic slogans such as You gave us your dimes, now we want our rights, thousands of the disabled are picketing, filing suits and lobbying for the equal protection promised but never received under the Fourteenth Amendment. For example: .

title: A Luxury Legislative Job
description: A SUFFOLK Democrat who was removed from the bench because of judicial misconduct and pressured to resign as a Democratic town leader because of his ineffectiveness is nevertheless holding a $15,000 parttime job in the State Assembly.

title: Contaminated Worker Files Claim
description: RICHLAND, Wash, Feb. 11 (AP)The Federal Government has declined to comment on a $975,000 injury claim filed by Harold McCluskey, a nuclear plant worker contaminated with radioactivity in a chemical explosion, against the Energy Research and Development Administration, The claim was filed Dec. 8 but was not made public until. Mr. McCluskey, 64 years old, was discharged from the Hanford Environmental Health Foundations emergency decontamination facility this week. The explosion occurred last Aug. 30 at a plant operated by the Atlantic Richfield Hanford Company under Government contract.

title: Yale Bets on Ethics
description: FOR four years Yale has tried to do more than just keep an eye on the stock market to protect its considerable investments. The university has picked up, with some false starts and misdirected efforts, the burden of the conscientious, ethical investor.

title: `You Can Hear the Destruction
description: TOMMY GORZISKA was walking on water last week, but his face showed no elation. The water had frozen into a highway of ice one foot thick in New Rochelle Harbor, locking in around boats, docks, and pilings, and exerting a destructive force as it shifted with the tides.

title: Library Fines Enacted
description: WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 12 (AP)Forgetting to return a library book on time in Wichita could cost from $25 to $250. The Wichita City Commission adopted Tuesday an ordinance that makes such forgetfulness a misdemeanor when it involves books from the Wichita Public Library.

title: POLICE ARE ACCUSED IN WETBACK ATTACKS
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. l2Some Mexican law enforcement officers follow wetbacks across the border into California and rob them at gunpoint, Police Chief William B. Kolender of San Diego has alleged.

title: Pittore's Walking Tall Wins
David Oscar Guttman to Wed Gail Kaplan, a Ph.D. Student
description: Gail Ann Kaplan, a candidate for a doctorate in American history at Columbia University, and David Oscar Guttman, who is completing his fourth year at New York University School of Medicine, plan to be married in April.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MOST houses built in this area during the last 30 years have copper water lines that are joined or assembled with soldered fittings.

title: Tour Earnings
description: P.G.A. GOLF

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN July 1 rolls around, a 58yearold graduate of the Harvard Law School who practices law in White Plains and lives in Greenburgh will take office as president of the New York State Bar Association, an organization of more than 25,000 members in the state's 11 judicial districts.

title: Soviet Woman Sets Mark
description: KEYSTONE, Colo., Feb. 12 (AP)Vera Bryndzey of the Soviet Union set a course record as she won the 500meter race today in 41.7 seconds at the women's world speedskating championships. The 2yearold course had its first major competition last week.

title: Rep. Tonry Accused Of Illegal Balloting In Disputed Election
Helping Birds Through Winter
description: INRILE Westchester's toboggan slopes and skating ponds beckon lovers of outdoor sports, there are those who just plain hate cold weather. They can enjoy a popular indoor sport this winter: backyard birding.

title: Headliners
description: Lloyd McBride, the regular candidate for president of the United Steelworkers of America, has beaten the reform contender, Ed Sadlowski, and the immediate effect of Mr. McBride's victory will probably be peaceful negotiations with the steel industry. The union, the largest in the A.F.L.C.I.O. and a pacesetter for organized labor, bargains under a nostrike agreement, and talks on a new threeyear contract begin tomorrow. Mr. McBride, a career unionist, was the candidate of the retiring president, I. W. Abel, whose stewardship brought substantial economic gains to the union's 1.4 million members. The average earnings in basic steel are $8.00 an hour; costofliving escalators are solid. In general, wages and benefits in steel are among the best in the country for industrial workers; increases for steelworkers have kept ahead of inflation while those for workers in most other industries have barely kept up.

title: LETTER FROM S.U.N.Y.
description: I LOOK at the freshmen. They have come to Purchase at its best time. They will never be bored. This past fall, liberalarts students could become involved in a theater company that eventually gave a performance. A Playwright's Workshop was put together by students who wanted to act write or direct. A Chamber Music group was formed by liberalarts and music students who wanted to play and sing together.

title: 100 Years of Edison's Wonderful Talking Machine
News Summary
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY, 10,1977

description: MOST houses built in this area during the last 30 years have copper water lines that are joined or assembled with soldered fittings.

description: We like the new Connecticut Weekly; it is a welcome addition.

description: OUTGOING

title: Jacqueline Anne Soi Fiancee Of Capt. Thomas J. DeCaro
Airborne Command to Move
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb., Febe 12 (UPI)The Strategic Air Command said yesterday that the National Emergency Airborne Command Post would be moved from Andrews Air Force Base near Washington to SAC headquarters here this summer. It said the operation would involve an estimated 1,200 persons and their families and should boost Offutt's annual payroll by $6 million to about $182 million.

title: Dance: Premiere of Arporisms
Fire Destroys Michigan Hotel
description: MENOMINEE, Mich. Feb. 12 (AP)Three persons were hospitalized with injuries today when the 96yearold, fourstory Menominee Hotel was destroyed by fire. The blaze broke out about 1:20 A.M. and raged out of control for five hours. The stone structure, built in 1881, was a total loss, fire officials said.

title: Shoppers Bypass FreeBus Bargain
description: WESTCHESTER'S shoppers apparently will not forsake their cars for buses even if the rides are free.

title: LOUIS J.M. BEEL, 74, DIES
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Feb. 12 (AP)A former Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Louis J.M. Beel, died in a hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 74.

title: It Is Addressing Important Political and Social Issues, and It Has the Last Word on New York City Finances
Swamp Skating: The Cold Facts
description: DURING the last few mild winters, I had almost forgotten why I have never really minded winter. I complained about it like everyone else, but underneath I never had the urge to fly to the sunny beaches of Florida. Now,after all this prolonged cold, I know why. I love to skate. It's not that I'm an accomplished skater, or even very good. I'm just a runofthemill New Jersey swamp skater.

title: Junior Title to Canadian
description: MEGEVE, France, Feb. 12 (UPI)Carolyn Skoczen of Canada won the European junior figureskating championship today, beating Christa Jorda of Austria and Corine Wyrsch of Switzerland.

title: Auto Strike 40 Years Ago Noted by G.M. and Union
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12Forty years after the bloody sitdown strike that produced their first agreement, the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Coro poration commemorated the occasion here last night with a friendly dinner.

title: A Taste Of Wine In Paris
description: Paris Is not for winelovers. If your passion is wine you'll head for Bordeaux, Burgundy, the Loire Valley, the Cote de Rhone, the Beaujolais or champagne countrypractically anywhere in France except Paris. There are times, however, when the choice is not ours. A short vacation, for example, shared with someone who yearns for the incomparable beauty of Paris, someone who means even more to you than wine itself.

title: Limelighters and Kingston Trio at the Westbury Fair
Filling the Bill with Fillo Dough
description: WHAT do spanakopetes (also known as spanakopitta), quiche Lorraine and mom's apple pie have in common? All threethe Greek spinach pie, the French pastry and the beloved symbol of Americanaare made with dough.

title: A Wind Ensemble, Ricercare, in Debut
description: Michel Piguet is a Swiss authority and teacher on the playing of old wind instruments who founded a Renaissance wind ensemble called Ricercare in 1963. Its personnel has naturally changed over the years, and when it made its debut here on Thursday at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ithad three Amricans in it, Bruce Dickey, Stanley King and Robin Howell. Gabriel Garrido was the fourth member of the quintet, which is based in Basel and is headed by Mr. Piguet himself.

title: Fantasy Mansion Becomes An Inn
description: SIOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  The road four and a half miles from this white washed New England town meanders through the woods and suddenly, like some magic carpet Italian palazzo, a sprawling yellow brick mansion appearswith stainedglass windows, circular driveway. Romanesque archways and sculptured fountain.

title: The Littlest Inmates
description: ANN POE, a correction officer at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, was on the job late one winter afternoon. Wearing a pink smock over her blue uniform, she sat at her desk with a tiny baby propped on her shoulder and patted its back. Come on, come on, baby, she chanted, Let's get that burp up.

title: Rock: Electric Light Orchestra
description: The Electric Light Orchestra, which sold out Madison Square Garden (except for a block of seats directly behind its slideprojection screen) Friday night, is the most commercially successful of the classical rockers at the moment, and it's easy enoueh to hear why.

title: You Can Hear the Destruction
APPEAL IS ALLOWED IN FATAL AIR CRASH
Miss Peyton of U.S. First In 200 Freestyle Swim
description: BOULOGNEBILLANCOURT, France, Feb. 12 (UPI)Kim Peyton of Portland, Ore., a member of the victorious United States 400meter freestyle relay team at the Montreal Olympics, captured the 200meter women's freestyle event today at the annual Tilt international swim meet. Miss Peyton led from the start in the BoulogneBillancourt 25meter pool, turning first at the halfway mark in 59.10 seconds and beating her nearest rival, Susanne Ackum of Sweden, by more than two seconds in time of 2 minutes 02.02 seconds. Miss Ackum finished second in a time of 2:04.40 and Birgit Wachtler of East Germany was third in 2:04.50.

title: Maryland 84, Clemson 78
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 12 (AP) Jo Jo Hunter, a freshman, scored a careerhigh of 24 points as Maryland upset Clemson today, 8478.

title: A Haven from the Elements
description: THIS is hardly the time of year to be thinking of shore restaurants. Or is it? It's hard to believe right now that the snow and ice inevitably will disappear and that not too many weeks from now Ye Olde School Inn will be playing host to summer guests.

title: Feathering Your Nest
Point of View
description: Enthusiasm for converting vast areas of Manhattan's commercial and manufacturing buildings to housing stock has recently risen from the Canal Street and Soho areas as far north as midtown. Proponents of residential conversion and its stopgap measure, legalized loft living, offer a scenario of fashionable and artistic projects and complexes, with Soho as an arts center and the Garment District as a crafts epicenter, But this scenario presages the end, not the renewal, of urban diversity.

title: Providence 99, L.I.U. 85
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I. (AP), Feb. 12 Bob Cooper and Joe Hassett, seniors playing in their final home game, turned in outstanding performances as they helped Providence today to a 9985 victory over Long Island Univer

title: Marquette 86, Manhattan  60
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 12 (AP)Bo Ellis poured in 18 of his 22 points in the second half and Butch Lee added 20 to lead Marquette over Manhattan, 8660, today.

title: Camien Excels at the Mile
description: Tom Camien of Sewanhaka High ran two solid onemile races, Greg Thompson of Malverne could clear only 6 feet 2 inches in the high jump, Joe Toles of Uniondale posted a meet record or 1:14.3 in the 600yard run and Steve Guida of Centerreach won his fifth straight sprint event.

title: Teachers Pact Said to Weaken Control Board
Sicilian variations; Spaghettini alla siracusana (Thin spaghetti Syracusestyle); Farsumagru (Stuffed meat roll); La cassata siciliana (Sicilianstyle cake with ricotta filling); Frosting
description: The food of Sicily has been influenced by the island's many conquerors Greek, Roman, Norman, Arab, Spanish and Frenchand so is surprisingly varied, as the recipes outlined on this page show. We find the flavors of Greece in the spaghetti, the Arab influence in the stuffing of the meat roll and the colorful decoration of the cake. To make a Sicilian meal, add a bottle of white Sicilian Corvo wine to these three dishes, and buon appetito!

title: Paul Klaas to Wed Barbara Bockhaus
description: Barbara Ann Bockhaus and Paul Barry Klaas, a senior at the Harvard Law School, plan to be married in July.

title: The Future of AudioIt's All In the Stars
description: IF I were to take bets on the future shape of audio, I would say that the basic quality of reproduced sound will improve only slightly over the best now attainable. After all, we already can record and reproduce the sonic spectrum with sufficient precision to create convincing replicas of musical reality. Great gains remain to be realized not so much in the sound per se as in methods to capture acoustic ambiencethe spatial concomitants of sound that contribute to the emotional effect of music.

title: StstststststStuttering
If You Go .. .
description: . . . By car, from SanDiego, take Interstate. 15 to Via Rancho Parkway. From Los Angeles, take Interstate 5 and State Highway 78 east to Escondido, then 115 south to Via Rancho Parkway. Cush Tours of San Diego (7142399711) offers bus transportation to and from the park, seven days a week, twice a day. The price is $8 for adults, $3.50 for children, and includes transportation, admission and the monorail.

title: Shangrila Victor Among Afghans
description: Ch. Shangrila Pharahna Kunasata, virtually a newcomer on the circuit, scored an upset last night by taking the top award at the 39th Afghan Hound Club of American specialty at the StatlerHilton Hotel. Shangrila is owned by Dr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Burger of Evansville, Ind., and was handled by Carl Sanders Jr. There were 313 entries in the show.

title: NEW MAP SERIES TO SHOW THE MAGNETIC FIELD IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)The Government is publishing a new series of maps showing the magnetic field in the United States.

title: John Norton Is the Fiance Of Miss Morey
description: The engagement of Alexandra Holt Morey to John Douglas Norton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan T. Morey of Princeton, N. J , parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Paul F. Norton of Amherst, Mass.

title: J. R. Van Wagner Jr. to Wed Alyce Kilpatrick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ringland F. Kilpatrick

title: Uncertain Yield of Carter Job Bill To Intensify Debate on Spending
Kentucky 89, Auburn. 82
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 12 (UPI)Jack Givens scored 24 points and Larry Johnson netted 18 to spark Kentucky to an 89.82 victory over Auburn tonight.

title: If You Go ...
description: . . . to the Kenya Coast, you'll find agreeable weather throughout most of the year. April and May are the two wettest months, but even then there is an average of more than six hours of sun a day. The average monthly temperature is highest in March83 degrees.

title: Melissa Leach Fiancee Of George F. Dickson
Eastchester, Whichchester?
