title: This Happy Land
description: WASHINGTONNo wars are going on anywhere. The nation is in a time of relative prosperity. Interesting new faces are in the news, and no new scandals or old hatreds poison the public atmosphere.

title: Woman Gains in Effort To Become a Priest
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (UPI)Rosalie MuschalReinhardt, a 43yearold suburban housewife, became the first married woman in the United States today to fulfill all academic requirements for ordination to the Roman Catholic priesthood.

title: Bingham Holds Talks in Cuba
description: HAVANA. Feb. 13 (Reuters)Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of New York, held extensive talks here today with Cuba's Vice President in charge or foreign affairs, Carlos Rafael Rodriguez. Aides to Mr. Bingham declined to comment on, the meeting, but when Mr. Bingham arrived here on Thursday he said that one of the topics he intended to discuss was the possible lifting of the United States embargo on trade to Cuba.

title: City Ballet Guild to Raise Funds at Auction Tonight
description: The New York City Ballet Guild will hold a cocktail party and auction this evening on the promenade of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, to raise money to help make up for the losses sustained by the company during the recent strike.

title: Spring Already Here in Retailer's Minds
description: Not unlike the abrupt change in the weather from bitter to balmy, the nation's stores are rushing the seasons.

title: Statewide Water Rationing Urged As California Drought Takes Toll
description: SAN FRANCISCO Feb. 13As the 17 monthold drought n California worsens and water becomes more precious, a growing number of people have begun to advocate statewide mandatory water rationing.

title: Frederica von Stade Winning In WideRanging Song Recital
description: Some recitalists attract polite and attentive audiences, some attract noisy gatherings of fanatics, and a few, such as Frederica von ptade, seem to draw around themselves circles of friends and lovers. Miss von Stade's song recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday, perhaps the most consistently winning program that she has yet presented in New York, quickly turned into just such a love feast. She could do no wrong.

title: Vance Mission To the Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance begins the Carter Administration's. most important foreign policy initiative tomorrow night by flying to the Middle East for talks with Israeli and key Arab leaders that he hopes will provide some clues on now to break the 18month diplomatic impasse before another war or oil embargo evolves. Like his predecessor, Henry A. Kissinger, Mr. Vance says that the opportunities for a settlement now seem better than ever. But while there are grounds for some hope, there are equally valid reasons for viewing prospects in the Middle East with extreme caution.

title: Rangers Tally 6 in 2d Period, Drub Leafs, 83
description: Swift on the attack, bruising on defense and strong in goal in the final period, the Rangers crushed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 83, at Madison Square Garden last night, scoring six goals in the middle period. It was the the most productive period of the season for the Rangers, matching the National Hockey League high for goals in a period this season, achieved by Montreal.

title: State Regents vs. the State U.
description: A recent court decision upholding the right of the New York State Board of Regents to close two doctoral programs at the State University Center at Albany constitutes a major victory for the Regents in a power struggle with the State University. From the point of view of the university, however, the decision by Justice Harold J. Hughes of the State Supreme Court is merely the latest round in a conflict that has important implications for the nature of higher education in the state.

title: The Fox in Phil Bieber's Past
description: From Coral Gables, Fla., where he always spends the winter, Phil Bieber weighs in with another of those tales that make the heart grow fonder of the Postal Service:.

title: There's a Ring of History to Diamond Betrothals
description: Everybody remembers Romeo and Juliet. But what about Maximilian of Austria and Mary of Burgundy?

title: Huge Transportation Fair to Seek To Lure Aviation Industry to State
description: POMONA, Feb, 13While. casino gambling is getting most of the attention in Alantic City's hopedfor rejuvenation, major contributions are under way in this suburb 10 miles northwest.

title: Now, Mr. President ...
description: LOS ANGELES  For modernday Presidents, few words are more important than communicate. A simple word represents a complicated, changing process that is essential in the conduct and understanding of government. Leadership depends not only on what the President says but on the public perception of what he does.ally is to praise or criticize broadly, or to advocate a course of selfinterest. When people speak to a President, they usually are awed.

title: ChickenHawk Trade Found Attracting More Young Boys to Times Square Area
description: The night was bitterly cold on Times Square. Prostitutes and other shady habitus had taken refuge indoors, and the gaudy lights and tawdry attractions of 42d Street beckoned only to a few gawking tourists.

title: To Feel the Pain of Mexico
description: The first foreign head of government to visit Jimmy Carter's White House is another new President, Jos Lpez Portillo, and their meeting today is a symbol of the traditional amity and the intense interdependence between Mexico and the United States. Yet the nature of that interdependence is such that, regardless of the amity, there are no easy, shortterm measures Mr. Carter can take to help his guest cope with Mexico's formidable problems.

title: Consensus on Rates: Higher Later On, but Uncertain for the Near Future
description: After falling fast in January and bouncing back forcefully but briefly early in February, the credit markets last week took a break from all that excitement. Prices did not move very far, and trading activity quieted down as bond traders, investment bankers, portfolio managers and moneymarket economists stepped back to survey the damage and to decide where they thought the money and bond markets were headed next.

title: 6 Years After Fatal Bombing, Madison's Anger Has Eased
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 13Like an old wound, the past still festers in this college town.

title: Article 1  No Title
Some Carter Aides Find Glitter Fading and Frustration Setting In
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 13The bloom is off the Rose Garden. Nearlya month after they moved into the White House, some of President Carter's aides have discovered that running the Government is not quite so heady as running for it. The glitter of my lovely office overlooking the White House is fading fast, lamented one young official whose early infatuation with a highceilinged suite in the Old Executive Office Building has been diluted by the effects of 18hour workdays.

title: Under Fire
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan was recently reported as saying that cuts in the Fire Department's manPower may have been less harmful than expected. Statistics were printed, ostensibly to reassure the citizens that the risk factor, though not diminishing, his nevertheless not increased.

title: Promoter Dreams of New Dream Mile
description: Two years ago this week, Filbert Bayi of Tanzania and John Walker of New Zealand last met in a mile raceat the San Diego Indoor Games. Two years later, the same promoter is trying to bridge political waters and bring Bayi, Walker and Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland together for what would be a truly dream mile Friday night.

title: LOUIS I. WHITLOCK
description: Louis I. Whitlock, treasurer of the Whitlock Cordage Company from 1921 to 1961, died Saturday in the Westfield (N.J.) Convalescent Home. He lived at 246 Bradford Road in Hillside, N.J., and was a former resident of Elizabeth. N.J.

title: Stalled Ft. Lee Apartment Complex May Be Revived in Different Form
description: FORT LEE, N. J.  A $75 million development project here just south of the George Washington Bridge that was halted during construction two years ago because of financial problems may be revived in a sharply different form.

title: Erving's Star Bright But West Team Wins
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 13The real Julius Erving emerged today.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Aunt Is Joining Foes
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 13Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, who is Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's aunt, disclosed today that she was joining the political opposition and planned to work actively against the Government in the parliamentary election campaign.

title: Cauthen Set to Ride Today
description: Steve Cauthen, the sensational 16yearold apprentice jockey who ran afoul of the state child labor laws, apparently will be back in the saddle again today at Aqueduct.

title: Complex Ohio Experiment to Try Different Uses of Cable Television
description: A massive cable television experiment will begin in Columbus, Ohio, next month involving 30channel programming, paybyprogram selectivity, twoway communications between viewer and broadcaster and a cable hookup that can serve as a fire and burgler alarm.

title: South Korea Fighter Retains W.B.C. Crown
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 13 (AP)Yum DongKyun of South Korea won a unanimous decision over Jose Cervantes of Colombia today and retained the World Boxing Council's light featherweight boxing title. It was the champion's first defense since he took the crown from Royal Kobayashi of Japan last Nov. 24.

title: NEW REPORT ASSAILS SCHOOL CUSTODIANS
description: Branding the New York City school custodians operation as corrupt and sick to its core, the deputy school chancellor said yesterday that he would remove the system's longtime chief of custodians and ask the Board of Education to call in the State Investigation Commission to conduct a thorough inquiry into the $100 millionayear program.

title: 3 Escapees Hunted
description: A police search continued without success yesterday for three young prisoners who escaped Friday night from the adolescent jail on Rikers Island. The threePhillip Harris, Jerry Hudgins and Tracy Robinson  escaped by climbing out a window they had pried open with a metal table leg and driving off the island in a car belonging to a Correction Department employee.

title: Opera: Stylish Salome at the Met
description: The performance of Salome at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon may not have been the most polished or vocally opulent presentation of Strauss's study in bejeweled decadence, but at least everyone concerned knew exactly what the opera requires in terms of style and atmosphere.

title: Youth Seized in Holdup
description: A 20yearold youth was captured, according to the police, after he had fled a bus at Archer Avenue and Merrick Avenue in Queens on which he allegedly had robbed 30 persons of about $70 Saturday night after brandishing a nickleplated revolver. The suspect was identified as David Sims of 1647 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica. The incident was the latest in several bus holdups in Queens in recent days.

title: ENERGY CHIEF WARNS COMFORT WILL DROP AND PRICES WILL RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Federal Energy Administrator, John F. O'Leary, told the American people today that this Carter Administration's energy policy would call for higher prices, less comfort at home and some way to take some of the fat out of the driving habits In this country.

title: S.E.C. Advised to Require Subjective Corporate Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Corporate managers should provide more subjective as well as factual information about their. companies but should be given wide latitude in deciding how to do it, a blueribbon advisory panel told the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

title: Pope Calls Killing of Missionaries In Rhodesia an Act Without Reason
description: ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Pope Paul VI today described the killing of three Jesuit priests and four nuns in Rhodesia last week as an act of violence without reason.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GIDYNSKIDr. Joseph C. (wife, Janina) Gldynskl, son Andrew and daughter Christina sincerely thank their friends for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: Lillian Carter Leads U.S. Group at Funeral in India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 13India today buried its fifth President, Fakhruddin All Ahmed, in a solemn and colorful ceremony marked by traditional pomp and pageantry.

title: Sports Today
description: DOG SHOW

title: Shakespeare Theater Looking to 1978
description: The American Shakespeare Theater, which was recently forced by financial hardship to cancel its repertory season for this spring and summer, is now starting deliberations to reopen in 1978.

title: Hackensack Concert Slated
description: The Martin Luther King Male Glee Club, a 30voice group of high school and college students from Harlem and other parts of New York City, will give a concert on Friday at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J. The performance will be sponsored by the Bergen County Community Action Program as part of its cultural activities.

title: Calvert Alexander, A Priest and Editor, Dies at Fordham U.
description: The Rev. Calvert P. Alexander, editor of Jesuit Missions magazine from 1938 until 1963, died Saturday at MurrayWeigel Hall, the Fordham University Jesuit residence in the Bronx. He was 76 years old.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: AT WEST ORANGE, N.J. SUBURBAN ESSEX

title: Hotline Offering Help On State Tax Return
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)A tollfree New Jersey state incometax hotline will begin operating tomorrow to help state residents prepare their returns.

title: WideRanging increase in Taxes Imposed by Belgium's Government
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The Government of Belgium imposed heavy tax increases today on cigarettes, gasolint, and wines and liquor.

title: Dance: Disappointing TwoActer
description: Grethe Holby, who has appeared in such experimental productions as Einstein on the Beach and with Laura Dean's Company, presented a twoact work of her own called Dancers Saturday night at American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: California Debates Sweeping Plan To Decentralize Control of Schools
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13California, the nation's laboratory for numerous social experiments, is heading toward a political test that could fundamentally change public education in the state.

title: Financier's Home Bombed By the I.R.A. in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The home of a prominent Jewish financier was bombed today in another attack by the Irish Republican Army on Northern Ireland's business community.

title: Description of U.S. Help With Syrians in Lebanon Given to Israeli Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, Feb, 13The beginning of a withdrawal of Syrian troops from an area in southern Lebanon near Israel's northern border was described to the Israeli Cabinet today as a diplomatic achievement made possible by the intercession of the United States.

title: OBASANJO'S FORMULA SUCCEEDS IN NIGERIA
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 13One year after he became a reluctant head of state, Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo has brought a measure of stability to Nigeria and won popular support from a nation traumatized by the assassination of an inspirational leader.

title: Woman Chosen to Head Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13When Rose Elizabeth Bird graduated magna cum laude from Long Island University in 1958, her goal was to get a doctorate and then become either a teacher or a foreign correspondent. However, after a stint as a legislative aide in the California Legislature in 1962 while she was attending graduate school at the University of California. Berkeley, she switched to saw because law.yers were the ones who basically ran the society and system.

title: Thai Crown Prince Is Said to Escape An Attack by Communist Guerrillas
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn escaped unhurt today when Communist guerrillas ambushed his military truck, the Thailand radio reported.

title: City Revenue Gain Hailed
description: The Office of the State Comptroller reported that the Bureau of Water Register in the New York City Department of Water Resources had achieved revenue gains of more than $2.2 million a year by adopting some of the recommendations made in an audit report in 1971. But in a followup audit, the Comptroller's office asserted that further revenue gains and savings could be gained if the bureau adopted other measures recommended then.

title: Finance Panel Urges a Doubled New York City Tax on Nonresidents
description: The Temporary Commission on City Finances recommended today that the New York City income tax on nonresidents be doubled but that all other major personal taxes in the city be left essentially unchanged.

title: Massengale Posts 67337 And Scores by 6 Strokes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 13For Rik Massengale the fifth and final round of the Bob Hope Desert Classic today was rather like a tapin putt as he went through the formal motions of winning the tournament and leaving 77 other golf pros behind to compete for second and lesser places.

title: Low Risks High Returns Help Make Car Stealing A RapidGrow Venture
description: Chances are better than average that if you are the happy owner of a new or recent Mercedes 450, a. Cadillac Seville, a Lincoln Continental, or the very latest in lowslung Jaguars, your automobile will be stolen soon.

title: Commodities
description: The Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices has been rising for two months. Can an inflationary upswell be far behind?

title: Panama Canal Talks Resuming Today, With Both Sides Hoping for New Treaty by June
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13On a tiny tropical island 35 miles off Panama's Pacific coast, a courtly whitehaired American and a youthful blackhaired Panamanian half a century his junior will take up this week a negotiation critical for both countries.

title: Advertising
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications, having acquired the Petroleum Engineering Publishing Company, now claims to be tied for first place among business paper publishers with McGrawHill Publications.

title: Waldheim Will Send Aides To Brief U.S. and Soviet
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said on his return here today that he was sending top aides to Washington and Moscow to report on the results of his Middle East peace mission.

title: Rhodesia Guerrilla War Ugly on Both Sides
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 13While the seven white missionaries slain last week may have been the most mourned victims of the Rhodesian war, they were only,a fraction of the 59 civilians who died during the week's fightingmost of them black and 30 of them by government guns.

title: U.S. Wrestlers Win
description: WARSAW, Feb. 13 (AP)A United States team, led by Tom Hazell and Brady Hall, beat Poland, 62, in freestyle competition today.

title: Senate Plan Cuts Regional Share Of Aid for Public Works Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13A maneuver in the Senate threatens to slash $160 million from the public works allocations anticipated by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut under new legislation now being drafted for 1977 and 1978.

title: Looters Descend on Warehouses Burned Out on West 30th Street
description: It was balmy weather for Sunday afternoon footing, and hardly anybody went away emptyhanded yesterday from a row of burnedout warehouses on West 30th Street near 12th Avenue.

title: More Aid Allotted for Appealing School Budget Cuts
description: The New Jersey Department of Education has $65 million available this year to local school boards that appeal for the restoration of budget cuts made by governing bodies$7 million more than was spent in the last 10 years.

title: Tiny Computer on a Chip Ready for Soaring Sales
description: After years of electronic industry ballyhoo, the microprocessora microscopic computer laid out on a fingernailsize square of siliconis on the threshold of mass markets.

title: Golden. Gate Beaches Dirtied by Oil Spill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)A heavy concentration of thick fuel oil that spilled from a drydocked freighter dirtied the beaches and waters off Golden Gate Park today, the Coast Guard reported.

title: An ExOlympic Skier Wins Troublesome 30Mile Race.
description: GOSHEN, Vt., Feb. 13In the Vermont Travelers Marathon ski touring race today, some of the competitors seemed to find it more difficult to reach the.start than to get to the finish, and at .least five leading performers backtracked more than a mile after having become lost during the race.

title: NEW REPORT ASSAILS SCHOOL CUSTODIANS
description: Branding the New York City school custodians operation as corrupt and sick to its core, the deputy school chancellor said yesterday that he would remove the system's longtime chief of custodians and ask the Board of Education to call in the State Investigation Commission to conduct, a thorough inquiry into the $100 millionayear program.

title: Cypriots Expect Problems in Talks
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 13The decision to resume discussions on the future of Cyprus; was described today as a real breakthrough by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations. But Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders make it clear that they remain far apart on key issues, and that any settlement would require long and difficult bargaining.

title: Czechs Detain Times Reporter, Seize His Notes
description: GMUND, Austria, Feb. 13Czechoslovak police ordered this reporter off the PragueVienna express last night, held him incommunicado and confiscated notebooks, other papers and unused stationery.

title: ABRAHAM SCHEINBERG
description: Rabbi Abraham Scheinberg, the spiritual leader of the Hebrew Alliance of Brighton (Beach) in Brooklyn for more than 40 years, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 122 Brightwater Court in Brooklyn.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The effort to explain why the current business recovery is so sluggishand what can be done to make the economy take off into sustainable and noninflationary growthhas come to focus on the weakness of business investment in new plant and equipment. During the first seven quarters 21 months of recovery after each of the five previous recessions, business investment (corrected for inflation) increased 5.3 percent over the previous prerecession businesscycle peak. But at the same point in the 197576 recovery, real business investment was still 11.8 percent below its prerecession peak in 1973.

title: Times Are Hard for That OldTime Marrying Judge Waiting for Elopers
description: A ladder at the window at midnight. A furtive couple, rushing to the waiting car or train. Whether romantic, defiant or desperate, they eloped.

title: Tanzanian Leader Names A New Prime Minister
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 13 (Reuters)President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania shuffled his Government today, promoting Defense Minister Edward Sokoine to Prime Minister while stripping a longtime associate of this position and another top post.

title: JUSTICE CORTLAND JOHNSON OF STATE SUPREME COURT
description: Justice Cortland A. Johnson, a member of the State Supreme Court from 1943 to 1961 and a senior judge until 1967. died Saturday at his home, 67 Hilton Avenue, Garden City, L.I. He was 85 years old.

title: Theater: A Couple of Comedies
description: The Soft Touch at the Ensemble Studio Theater, is a crazy comedy, more Loony Tunes than Merrie Melodies, Room Service crossbred with Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Momma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feeling So Sad. Stop the Parade (which closed this weekend at Playwrights Horizon on West 42d Street and will reopen Thursday at Playwrights Horizon/ Queens) is an oldfashioned western comedy with delusions of modernity. It pretends to be an act of women's consciousnessraising. The first play feverish; the second, episodic.

title: ENERGY CHIEF WARNS COMFORT WILL DROP AND PRICES WILL RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Fegeral Energy Administrator, John F. O'Leary, told the American people today that the Carter Administration's energy, .policy would call for higher prices, less comfort at home and some way to take some of the fat out of the driving habits in this country.

title: Miss Higgins Defeats Mrs. Rankin in Playoff
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP)Pam Higgins sank a 3foot putt for a par 4 on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today to capture a $50,000 tournament of the. Ladies Professional Golf Association. The victory was worth $7,500.

title: Police Suggest Ways To. Discourage Theft
description: If a professional thief wants your car, there's nothing you can do to stop him, says Lieut. John J. Hill, commander of the police auto squad. You can discourage him, but you can't stop him

title: Levasseur Triumphs In TwoSport Action
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y.,Feb. 13 Mark Levasseur, a 15yearold high school student who divides his winter athletic activities between hockey and ski jumping, was a triple winner over the weekend.

title: Steelworkers Open Talks With Producers Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)The United Steelworkers of America and the nation's steel producers open contract talks tomorrow with substantial wage increases and lifetime job security heading a wideranging set of bargaining goals.

title: School Papers Fill a Gap In Philadelphia Strike
description: Special to The New York Times

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: On the day and days following a request by a transplanted English woman for a source for English bangers (sausages) this desk was ?? with replies from readers, most of them recommending with heartfelt praise the bangers made and shipped by McArthur's Smokehouse in Millerton, N.Y. Many of them sent catalogues and we heard from the smokehouse owner as well.

title: John Nelson Is Guest Conductor At American Symphony Concert
description: John Nelson, who was guest conductor of the American Symphony OrchesIra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall,. has often struck one as more successful in gentle music than in dramatic music, and that was the case with this concert.

title: Letters
description: Of Oil, Oceans and the Environmentalisis

title: New Books
description: Ancient Mysteries, by Rupert Furneaux (McGrawHill, $7.95). Mysteries of time and space examined, including questions behind the city of Atlantis and the Egyptian pyramids.

title: Bill Would Require a Meditation Period in Schools
description: TRENTON, Feb.13The State Assembly has scheduled debate tomorrow on a bill that would require New Jersey public schools to open each day with a brief period of silent meditation.

title: Boudreaux Beats LeDoux
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13It was a beautiful fight card in the United States Navy's Holsey Field House today. There were six bouts from featherweights to heavyweights, and there were three technical knockouts and one highly controversial decision.

title: Article 6  No Title
ALBERT W. BROWNELL
description: Albert W. Brownell, former advertising sales executive; died at his home in Levittown, L.I., on Jan. 23. He was 88 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Precipitation Data

title: Dogs Get a Final Check As Show Opens Today
description: Ghoice, a white standard poodle in Corrtinental clip with ears ensconced in pink cellophane wrappings, struck a regal pose yesterday afternoon on the sidewalk outside of Madison Square Garden while inside any number of other poodles, Lhasa Apsos, terriers and, working dogs relaxed or were being bathed, combed or brushed in preparation for the Westminster show which opens today.

title: Raphael, Pop Singer, Gets Energy From Roots
description: Raphael, the Spanish pop singer who packed the Felt Forum twice yesterday, seems to have adapted to the musical constraints of the European middleoftheroad without entirely abandoning the particularity of his Iberian heritage. He sings The Little Drummer Boy and other evergreens, he dances liquidly while wielding a cane and top hat, and he mugs for the adoring fans who throw roses at his feet. Still, many of the songs he performs have a brooding, intense Spanish flavor, and this, one suspects, is one of the secrets of his appeal.

title: CLEANUP OF OIL SPILL HELD 10% EFFECTIVE
description: A Federal environment monitor estimated yesterday that cleanup efforts led by the United States Coast Guard would probably not pick up more than 10 percent of 420,000 gallons of oil spilled 10 days ago into the Hudson River by a grounded barge north of Bear Mountain.

title: Rhodesian Defense Chief Resigns
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 13 (UPI)Defense Minister Reginald Cowper resigned today, saying he was making way for someone who might be able to provide the panacea for Rhodesia's search for soldiers to fight black guerrillas.

title: More States Moving to Scrutinize Budget Practices of Their Cities
description: An increasing number of states are taking steps to scrutinize, and in some cases control, the budgetary practices of their municipalities in an attempt to avoid the credit problems that have plagued New York City.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Indian Refugees Making a Living In the Subways
description: Dinesh Patel runs the newsstand by the West Side IRT subway in the Times Square station. Hiralal Patel operates the news and candy stand on the IND southhound nlatform at Columbus Circle.

title: Seymour. Berl Dies. in Jersey
description: Seymour Berl, for the last eight years financial vice president of Dell Publishing Company, a division of Doubleday & Company, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack at St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N.J. He was 47 years old and lived in Short Hills. N.J.

title: U. S. STEEL TO BE SOURCE OF PIPE FOR ALASKAN GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The Alaskan Arctic Gas Pipeline Company said today the United States Steel Corporation had agreed to supply steel for the proposed natural gas pipeline from Alaska to Canada and the lower 48 states.

title: U.S. Said to Be Developing HighSpeed Warships
description: LONDON, Monday, Feb. 14 (UPI) The United States is developing 3,000 ton, 80knot antisubmarine frigates for the 1980's and may well have a fleet of warships of up to 8,000 tons capable of the same high speeds by 1990, Jane's Surface Skimmers, one of a series of authoritative books on sea and air technology, said today.

title: Czechs Detain Times Reporter, Seize His Notes
description: GMUND, Austria, Feb. 13??yak police ordered this reporter off the PragueVienna express last night, held him incommunicado for two hours and confiscated notebooks, other papers and unused stationery.

title: 3 Top Teams Fall, but Dons Roll On
description: Three of the nation's highly ranked college basketball teams  U.C.L.A., Louisville and Michiganwere toppled during the weekend, but the only major undefeated team, San Francisco, swept to its 25th triumph and clinched a tie for the championship of the West Coast Athletic Conference.

title: Books of The Times
description: An unfriendly professor called her the Red Virgin. Her brother called her a sergeantmajor angel. Trotsky, whom she criticized for his conduct toward the Kronstadt sailors, was furious: If that's how you think, why did you put us up? Do you belong to the Salvation Army? A family of farmers for whom she worked decided that they didn't want her around any more: She never washed her hands before milking the cows; she never changed her clothes; and, worst of all, in the fields she never stopped talking about the future martyrdom of the Jews, poverty, deportations, and about the terrible war she foresaw in the near future. When they offered her a fine cream cheese, she pushed it away, saying that the little Indochinese were hungry.

title: Concert: Vivid Musica Aeterna
description: The newsiest aspect of the Saturday evening Musica Aeterna concert at the Metropolitan Museum (which was repeated yesterday afternoon) was the United States premiere of a Mass in F by Pergolesi. It had its charms, but the real pleasure of the night came with the singing of Judith Blegen (especially in the Handel Psalm No. 112) and the orchestral and choral work in the concluding Bach Magnificat.

title: American Takes Marathon
description: KYOTO, Japan, Feb. 13 (UNI)Bill Rodgers, an American, won the annual marathon race today in this city 250 miles west of Tokyo. He was clocked in 2 hours 14 minutes 26.2 seconds.

title: The Frigid Weather Made Life Miserable for Pets, Too
description: The canaries stopped singing in Boston because, it was drafty. Housebroken puppies in Westport refused to go outside. Rhinestonestudded pet sweaters sold out in Detroit. And in New York, the goldfish swam sluggishly.

title: jazzRock: By 3
description: Three jazzrock groups played for five hours at the Palladium Saturday night, and together their performances constituted a display of the state of the art. Jazzrock has been enduring a period of doldrums since Mahavishnu Orchestra and Return to Forever, two of the idiom's most accomplished groups, disbanded, but the music Saturday was brimming with vitality. And there was an overall attention to clarity and nuance that suggested that some of the more selfindulgent aspects of jazzrock are on the wane.

title: Yesterday's Records
Rates May Rise, Long Term
description: Interest rates appear to be headed higher this year but the shortterm outlook is anything but clear. Page 41.

title: GOLDWATER SIGNS PACT TO WRITE HIS MEMOIRS
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona who was a Presidential candidate in 1964, has joined the group of wellknown Washington officials, past and present, who are writing their memoirs.

title: Man Who Held His Son As Hostage Is Charged
description: WHEATON, Md., Feb. 13 (UPI)The police held a suburban Washington man without bond today for keeping his 6 yearold sort hostage for five hours yesterday in the home of his estranged wife.

title: Nastase Beats Fibak With Ace At Match Point
description: MEXICO CITY. Feb. 13 (UPI)Ilie Nastase served an ace at match point today and bent Wojtek Fibak, 46, 62, 7??for the $30,000 first prize in the World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Market Place: Weak Stocks

title: Fletcher Takes Prizes For Articles on Dogs
description: Walter R. Fletcher, who recently retired as dogshow editor after nearly 50 years with The New York Times, received all four awards offered in the over500,000 circulation category last night at the Dog Writers Association of America dinner. The awards were for the best column, best news report, best syndicated column and best single feature story for 1976. It was the 13th year in a row that Fletcher has been honored and it gave him a total of 24 prizes from the association.

title: Indira Gandhi's Aunt Joined Foes To Live at Peace With Myself
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 14Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Prime Minister. In'ira Gandhi' aunt, said today that she had decided to join the political campaign against her niece to help put an end to the authoritarian trend which has groWn to vast proportions in India.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
Herbert Seelig, 67, ExChairman Of Printers Chapel at The Times
description: Herbert Seelig, who was chairman in 1957 and 1958 of the New York Times chapel of the New York Typographical Union, died Sunday in Gainesville, Fla., where he was living in retirement. He was 67 years old.

title: Roe to Enter the Democratic Gubernatorial Primary
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14The field of gubernatorial aspirants continued to grow as Representative Robert A. Roe announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Beame Appoints Deputy Mayor To Seek Accord in Jet Dispute

NEW PANELS TO PICK APPEAL JUDGE NAMES
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 14President Carter will set up within the next few days a new system for choosing Federal appeals court judges under which the President will be bound to make his selections from lists of people recommended to him by commissions composed of lawyers and nonlawyers, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today.

title: State Democratic Chief Calls Role Of New York City in Party Waning
description: Dominic J. Baranello, the new Democratic state chairman, declared yesterday that New York Citys once overwhelming influence in the state party was waning and that the future of the Democratic Party is going to come out of the suburbs.

title: Advertising

U.S. Delivers Protest to Panama Over the Detention of American
description: PANAMA, Feb. 14 (AP)The United States delivered a formal protest to the Panamanian Government today over the detention last week of William Drummond, an American employed as a Canal Zone policeman.

title: Czech Underground Literature Circulating From Hand to Hand
description: VIENNA, Feb. 14  A middleaged Czech in a Prague park the other day pulled a few yellow onionskin sheets out of a. sheaf in his briefcase and presented them to a foreigner who was walking with him.

description: Fire Kills Mother and Two Children

title: Library of the Performing Arts Will Open at Kennedy Center
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)  The Kennedy Center and the Library of Congress announced today plans to open a library of the performing arts at the center.

title: China Shifts a Regional Party Chief
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 14China has appointed a new Communist Party chief in Yunnan Province and shuffled the administration there, the provincial radio reported. The step was evidently taken to tighten Peking's control over an area that has long been racked by factional confict.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The State Department said today that Israeli drilling for oil in the Gulf of Suez off Sinai territory seized from Egypt in 1967 was illegal and not helpful to efforts to get peace negotiations under way.

SPECIAL INTEREST AID SOARED IN 76 RACES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Corporations, labor'unions and professional and trade associations channeled more than $22.5 million into the political campaigns of Senate and House candidates in 1976, record high and nearly twice as much as they provided in 1974.

title: 4 BROTHERS ARE SLAIN AT TRAILER IN INDIANA
description: HOLLANDSBURG, Ind., Feb. 14 (AP)Four brothers, ranging in age from 14 to 22, were killed by shotgun blasts to the head in execution style early today after being ordered to lie face down on the floor of t'eir family's mobile home.

RICHARD E. CHALLENGER
description: Richard E. Challenger, a . retired dc,. countaxit.for the John, D. RoCkefeller family at 30 Rockefeller'Plaza, died last Saturday in ,New York Hospital of dOmplit cations following a burn accident. He lived at 402 Hancock Avenue, Mount Vernon, and was 63 years Mr.'Chall lenger, who attended Caltthibii University, is survived by two daughters, Lisa, and Mrs. Joseph .Hurd, and two grandchildren.

title: STEEL OUTPUT UP IN WEEK 5.6% TO 2.12 MILLION TONS
Vance's Trip Gives Aide a Quick Boost
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14With Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance off to the Middle East tonight, the acting secretary will be Arthur A. Hartman, Assistant Secretary for European Affairs, who is normally several steps down, the hierarchy.

title: School Results
West German Sees Arab Willingness
description: BONN, Feb. 14West Germany's Foreign Minister, HansDietrich Genschet, who returned Saturday from a tour of Arab capitals, has told Secretary of State Vance that he believes the Arab side is more willing than at any time in the last four years to seek a peaceful solution to the Middle East conflict.

title: Accounting Battle
Mobil Will Decide Soon if It Will Quit City, Warner Says
STANISLAS IDZIKOWSKI, 82, BALLETS BUSSES DANCER
description: Stanislas Idzikowski, who was a, leading dancer in Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, died Saturday in a London nursing home. He was 82 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: H.E.W. SEEKS AGENCY WITH POWER TO LIMIT COST OF HEALTH CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed creating a new agency with authority to set limits on rising health care costs for the country, Administration sources said today.

title: Fassbinder: A New Director Movie Buffs Dote On
description: MUNICH RAINER WERNER FASSBINDER is a 30yearold director who has already made 28 films. It is hard to believe that this paunchy figure who looks like a high school athlete gone to seed, with a scraggly, reddishblond beard, motorcycle jacket, red polo shirt and grubby fingernails, is really the messiah of the new German film.

title: Sealyham Is Judged Best at Westminster
description: Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl became the fourth Sealyham in Westminister history to go best in show as the twoday event ended last night at Madison Square Garden. The selection was a popular choice with the crowd of 8,000.

title: Saudi Arabia's January Figures Show No Increase in Oil Output
description: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Saudi Arabia's oil production in January averaged 8.28 million barrels day, the oil ministry's Under Secretary, Abdel Aziz Turki, told the official Saudi news agency today. The daily average for all last year was about 8 million barrels, and the daily average in December was 9.1 million barrels.

title: All About: Mattresses
description: WHAT home furnishing do you use more than any other, in continuous stretches of time? Unless you're a virtuoso sleepwalker, an aficionado of hammocks or have really splendid insomnia, it's a mattress.

title: Rhodesia Blacks Joining Uprising By the Hundreds
description: FRANCISTOWN, Botswana, Feb. 15Hundreds of young black Rhodesians are moving through an overcrowded camp outside Francistown each week, heading for guerrilla training camps in neighboring Zambia.

title: Advertising
description: D'ArcyMacManus & Masius has acquired a majority of the stock in Masius, WynneWilliams (Holdings), its Londonbased international partner agency for the last four years.

title: Cauthen: 3 More Firsts
description: Steve Cauthen continued his winning touch at Aqueduct yesterday by bringing home two favorites and a long shot in eight trips to the post. The triple increased the 16yearold apprentice jockey's winner total for the winter meeting to 96. He also has had seven winners at Santa Anita in California this year.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: CANADA ALLOTS MORE GAS TO MEET U.S. EMERGENCY
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15 (AP)An additional 12 billion cubic feet of natural gas has been licensed for emergency export to the United States, the National Energy Board said today.

title: EARLY CLIMB FADES IN CORPORATE BONDS
description: The corporate bond market, which early yesterday afternoon seemed about to make its first advance in a week, lost its gains late in the day after a $150 million list of highgrade telephone and industrial company bonds was put out for

title: CBS Tells Affiliates of High Hopes
description: MIAMI BEACH

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unles otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on Iho New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: Westminster Dog Show
CORRECTION
description: In an item in the Notes on People column last Wednesday concerning Harold R. Tyler's joining a New York law firm, the changed name of the firm was given incorrectly. The correct name is Patterson, Belknap, Webb Tyler.

title: Dow Climbs 5.99 as an Increase In NewCar Sales Buoys Market
description: The stock market extended Monday's moderate advance yesterday, buoyed by reports of stronger new car sales.

title: Rhodesia Blacks Joining Uprising By the Hundreds
description: FRANCISTOWN, Botswana, Feb. 15Hundreds Of young black Rhodesians are moving through an overcrowded camp outside Francistown each week, heading for guerrilla training camps in neighboring Zambia.

title: The Last Goodbyes of the 5 Who Were Shot Down
description: A dedicated policeman, a survivor of the Italian campaign in World War II, former high school football star, a man who worked all his life for an elusive goal independenceand a young immigrant from India: they bade loved ones goodbye Monday morning and went off to work. None returned.

title: Finian's Rainbow Coming to Jones Beach
description: Finian's Rainbow. the E. Y. (Yip) HarburgBurton LaneFred Saidy hit musical, which ran on Broadway for 725 performances starting in 1947, has been selected as this summer's attraction at the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, L.I. Under the direction of John Fearnly, it will be presented at the 8,200seat outdoor theater from June 30 through Sept. 4.

title: Private Lives
description: YOUTH DROPPED in on us the other night. after dinner. Youth had curly locks, and eyes that had seen the floors of some oceans, and he spoke the latest foreign language: like, man, your know, laidback. In his steerhide motorcycle jacket with the snapon lamb collar, his liedyed bellbottom dungarees, his calfskin Wellington boots, Youth was so together that the rest of us felt left out.

title: Powerful Lasers Reported Bound For American and Soviet Arsenals
description: The death ray is still in the realm of science fiction, but lasers powerful enough to inflict significant damage are moving toward the arsenals of the Soviet Union and the United States

title: Personal Health
description: A YEAR ago this month, Federal District Judge John J. Sirica suffered a massive heart attack while delivering a speech. Although the former Watergate judge had no heart beat and was legally dead for four minutes, a deputy Federal marshal saved his life and his brain by immediately doing mouthtomouth breathing and chest compression until hospital rescuers arrived.

title: Japan's Trade With China Fell 20% to $3.03 Billion in 75'76
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15 (AP)Japan's trade with China fell 20 percent between 1975 and 1976 to $3.03 billion, the first decline in eight years, the Japan External Trade Organization disclosed today.

title: Kaiser Aluminum To Close 2 Potlines
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation became yesterday one of the first casualties of the drought in the Pacific Northwest. Cornell C. Maier, president and chief executive, said yesterday that the company was being forced to close down two potlines at its Mead, Wash., plant, idling 200 employees, because of the Bonneville Power Administration's inability to supply necessary power due to the worsening drought along its hydroelectric system and the scarcity of alternate sources of power supply.

title: U.S. ASSURES ARMS PARLEY IT WILL PUSH FOR ACURBS
description: GENEVA, Feb 15The Carter Administration assured the 30nation disarmament conference today that it was giving the highest priority to achieving international accords banning all nuclear testing and outlawing chemical weapons.

title: SANJAY GANDHI SEEKS A SEAT IN PARLIAMENT
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's son Sanjay, whose activities as her close political adviser have caused dissension within the ruling Congress Party, was nominated by the party today to make his first run for Parliament in next month's elections.

title: New York Raises Ceilings on Income In Public Housing
description: In an attempt to comply with Federal regulations and get more upwardly mobile families into its 241 projects, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday a sharp increase in the maximum income a family could have and still be admitted to the city's lowrent public housing.

title: Thumb Wrestlers Throw Hands Into the Ring
description: Promoters of the Thum Wrasslin game demonstrating their product at an exhibition in Manhattan. The object is to lock thumbs; the contestant who cannot move his (or her) thumb loses. Finger covers are used to keep fingernails from hurting the opponent.

title: The Princess Who Is Everywhere
description: DIANE VON FURSTENBERG princess, author, dress company president, cover girl and mother of twoslipped off a patent leather pump, folded a slim calf under a slim knee, settled back against a valentinepink satin pillow, tossed her head such a way that the curls ended up looking like something that had just left Kenneth's, and meditated for moment. The secret to life, she said is organization.

title: Islanders Scoring
description: MONDAY NIGHT

title: Television
Chesimard Murder Trial Opens
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 15The murder trial of Joanne Chesimard opened today with the prosecution accusing her of having executed a state trooper with his own weapon and the defense contending that she is innocent, she has committed no crime.

title: Carter Aide Impressed by Parley With Homosexuals Alleging Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)A White House aide has scheduled a meeting next month with 10 representatives of a homosexual rights activist group after what she described as a very impressive session with two of them last week.

title: U.S.O. Shifts With the Times
description: The Stage Door Canteen is dimly remembered as a song, and even more dimly remembered as a movie about soldiers and girls at New York's wartime U. S. O. As a club, it is a virtually forgotten relic of World War II years.

title: Mengelt, Gilmore Help Bulls Pin a 114106 Loss on Nets
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP)John Mengelt, a reserve, connected on 12 of 13 shots from the floor and Artis Gilmore displayed a rugged fourthquarter scoring and rebounding punch tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 114106 triumph over the New York Nets in a National Basketball Association contest.

title: Some Donors To Neediest Give 2d Time
description: As the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters its final weeks, many of its loyal supporters are contributing a second time.

title: Authorities Think Arsonist Set West Virginia Fires
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 15(AP)At least four of the fires that broke out at five downtown hotels within an hour last night were deliberately set, probably by one person, the authorities said today.

title: THREE CAR INSURERS RAISE THEIR RATES
description: At least three major automobile insurance companies have escaped efforts by the New York State Insurance Department to maintain a moratorium on premium increases and have raised their rates by as much as 29 percent.

title: Lillian Carter Goes Home To Her Clinic Post in India
description: VIKHROLI, India. Feb. 15  With tearful kisses and warm hugs, Lillian Carter paid a nostalgic visit today to the public health clinic where she had served as a Peace Corps nurse 10 years ago.

title: Bill on Exemptions To Rent Increases For Elderly Gains
description: A bill to permit thousands of qualified elderly tenants in rentcontrolled and rentstabilized apartments to carry forward a part of their present rentincrease exemptions when they move was approved yesterday by the New York City Council's General Welfare Committee.

title: 2 Blacks Get Top Justice Dept. Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)President Carter nominated two blacks and two women today as top Justice Department aides to Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, including the first black as head of the civil rights division.

title: Citizens of Canada Cease To Be Subjects of Britain As New Law Takes Effect
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15Citizens of Canada ceased to be British subjects today with the formal proclamation of new citizenship legislation that also makes it easier to become a Canadian.

title: CARTER'S GOALS HINGE ON GROWTH ABOVE 5%, CONGRESS OFFICE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Congressional Budget Office served notice today that the economic goals of the Carter Administrationa balanced budget, full employment, new social programsmay be in conflict unless the nation can achieve an unusually high growth rate through 1980 of more than 5 percent annually. The last quarter's annual growth rate was 3 percent.

title: U.S. Duties on British Spirits Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Treasury Department said it would no longer collect countervailing duties on spirits of any kind imported from Britain, The order on spirits from Britain has been in effect since 1914, although it has been amended several times as export bounties have been eliminated.

title: National Gypsum Plant
description: The National Gypsum Company of Dallas announced that its Gold Bond buildings products division would build a multimillion dollar wallboard plant on the Hudson River near Rensselaer, N.Y., to serve the territory formerly supplied by its New Haven, Conn., plant, which was closed two years ago. The company said that the new gypsum plant, which will be its 19th such unit, will be the first opened in New York since 1964.

title: Justice Department Urges Prison For Convicted Antitrust Violators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Justice Department has more than 100 grand jury investigations of criminal antitrust violations pending and intends to tell Federal judges clearly and unequivocally that convicted violators should spend time in prison, an official of the antitrust division said today.

title: VANCE IS IN ISRAEL ON MIDEAST MISSION
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived today to start what he called a quest for peace in the Middle East, with the emphasis, on the search for a comprehensive settlement rather than the limited accords favored by Israel.

title: Technology
description: For the last 20 years, Andrew H. Bobeck of the Bell Telephone Laboratories has been working on how to harness knowledge of magnetism to the creation of devices that could store or process electronic information. He is a pioneer in developing what are called magnetic bubble memories.

title: Home Fashions League Presents Award to Publisher of The Times
description: Arthur O. Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, was presented yesterday with the Big Apple Award for outstanding commitment to New York City by the New York chapter of the National Home Fashions League.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Child's World
description: A BABY'S first bath is often a short trip from tension to bliss. At first the parent feels awkward, stiffarmed, settling the baby into the water, and as the water touches the baby's skin the child starts to wail. But soon the soothing reality of it prevails. Large, warm hands stroke new skin. Warm water gently touches the top of the head and makes the thin hair sway like seagrass. Child and parent are tranquil.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Panel Urges CitySuburb Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The United States Civil Rights Commission said today that school children in large metropolitan areas would have to be bused across city and county boundaries if the increasing segregation of their schools is to be reversed.

title: Cowan Had 4 Pistols But Not One Permit
description: Rifles and muskets such as those owned by Frederick Cowan, as well as shotguns, can be purchased anywhere in the state except New York City without a permit by anyone who is over 18, a state police officer said yesterday. But all counties require license to purchase pistols such as the four that Mr. Cowan was carrying.

title: Vatican's Ban on Ordination of Women Also Excludes Them From Holding Key Administrative Jobs
description: ROME, Feb. 15 (AP)The Vatican, a male fortress a decade ago, has since granted women an increasing number of jobs, but its ban on women priests bars women from any executive or decisionmaking posts.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: H. E. W. Warns of Flood Of Compensation Cases
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15 (UPI)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is facing suits from hundreds of asbestos workers who say the Government failed to warn them about a disabling lung disease.

title: Occidental Petroleum Profits Up
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday fourthquarter net income of $71.7 million, equal to $1.14 a share, or four times the $17.7 million. or 20 cents a share, earned in the corresponding final quarter of 1975. Net sales of $1.6 billion were up 46 percent from $1.1 billion in the prior year's period.

title: Jersey City Gets AA Baseball Club
description: Jersey City got a baseball team yesterday, its first in organized baseball in 16 years.

title: St. John's Bows To Seton Hall; Mosley Stars
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 15The intensity and excitement of the battle for supremacy among Metropolitanarea college basketball teams was heightened tonight by Seton Hall's 7569 victory over St. John's.

title: U. N. Agency Says Israel Tortures and Pillages
description: GENEVA, Feb. 15The United Nations Human Rights Commission adopted resolution today accusing Israel of practicing torture and the pillaging of archeological and cultural property in the Arab, territories it occupies.

title: Hold Me Is Moving To Westside Cabaret
description: Jules Feiffer's Hold Me! an entertainment drawn from Mr. Feiffer's cartoons and sketches of the last 20 years, will move Saturday from the Subplot Cafe at the American Place Theater to the Westside Cabaret Theater, 407 West 43d Street, for an indefinite run.

title: Fassbinder Festival To Begin March 9
description: The first Fassbinder film festival in this country, including 13 of the young director's films, will start March 9 at the New Yorker Theater. It will offer revivals of The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant, Fox and His Friends and The Merchant of Four Seasons, among others, as well as the American premiere of his latest film, Chinese Roulette.

title: Personal Finance: SafeDeposit Boxes
description: A PERSON who has been dealing with the same New Jersey bank for a quarter of a century was startled the other day when he went to get a stock certificate out of his safedeposit box.

title: New Weapons Systems Up $18.5 Billion in Cost In Last 6 Months of 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)The total cost of major new United States weapons has registered its highest jump in more than six years, the Pentagon reported today.

title: Fight Pledged on C.U.N.Y. Budget
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15Assemblyman meiyin H. Miller, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the Higher Education Committee, said today he had resolved himself to make a fight for restoring $ll million to the budget for City University's senior colleges.

title: The Carter Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The cynical view of American politics, widely expressed during the recent Presidential campaign, was that it really didn't make much difference who won. With every passing day of his first month in the White House, however, President Carter is demonstrating that it does make a difference.

title: Music: Exciting Violinist
description: ELMAR OLIVEIRA, the 1975 winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation contest, established his credentials as a major young artist last year when he gave the first of his award recitals in Alice Tully Hall. On Monday night, in the same auditorium, the violinist gave a second award recital that solidified his stature.

title: Tonry Opposes Vote Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)Representative Richard Tonry, Democrat of Louisiana, asked a special House panel today to throw out charges that he won his seat through a vote fraud in a Democratic primary.

title: Chesimard Murder Trial Opens in New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 15The murder trial of Joanne Chesimard opened today with the prosecution accusing her of having. executed a state trooper with his own weapon, and the defense contending that she is innocent, she has committed no crime.

title: Monsters, 2 OneActers, To Open at Astor Place
description: Monsters, a pair of oneact plays costarring James Coco and Robert Drivas, will be presented by Adela Holzer, at the Astor Place Playhouse, 434 Lafayette Street, on March 10. The two plays are The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie by Albert Innaurato and Sideshow by William Dews.

title: A 5:30 A.M. Phone Call to Carter Starts a Tightly Structured Day
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Very, very early yesterday morning, a telephone rang in one of this city's bedrooms, shattering its predawn somnolence. It rang just once.

title: An Easy Technique Can Save Lives In Heart Attacks
description: CPR cannot save all persons whose lungs and heart stop functioning. In some, so much heart muscle was damaged by the attack that the heart can no longer be an effective pump. Or the attack may irreversibly damage the heart's electrical conduction system. Sometimes the victim dies despite effective CPR because he inhales his own vomit, and other times it is difficult or impossible to transport the CPRmaintained patient to where he can get advanced medical care.

title: NewCar Sales in Early February Surpassed 1976 Period by 19.1%
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15Domestic newcar sales were up 19.1 percent in early February from last year as the industry recovered some of the business lost last month because of the weather, according to reports from the four domestic companies.

title: Bethlehem Steel Says Industry Needs a 5% Increase in Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Company believes the industry needs a 5 percent acrossthehoard price increase right now to restore its profit margins, Lewis W. Foy, chairman of the nation's secondlargest steelmaker, said yesterday.

title: Market Place
description: These are rather heady days for the cement industry, a business generally regarded by many investors as rather prosaic. Profits are up and dividends have improved.

title: Health Agency Consultant Resigns
description: Howard J. Rubenstein, a key political adviser to Mayor Beame, has resigned as a public relations consultant to a citywide health planning agency to avoid possible conflict of interest with voluntary hospitals that are also clients of his.

title: Playing the Devil's Advocate, as It Were
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A flurry of recent court cases suggests we are facing another test of how genuine our pluralism is and whether we will guarantee freedom of religion to movements that were not foreseen when the First Amendment was written.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GIDYNSKIDr. Joseph C., wife, Janina Gidvnski, M.D., son, Andrew, and daughter, Christina, sincerely thank their friends for their kind expressions of sympathy In their recent bereavement.

title: Notes on People
description: PARTLY in order to redress what he considers his family's grievance against history, the Duke of Wellington is coming to town Sunday. The eighth Duke and descendant of the hero of the Battle of Waterloo brings with him a longstanding complaint that Napoleon, defeated by his ancestor at Waterloo, always gets more notice as the vanquished than does the Iron Duke as victor. The Duke is coming to New York chiefly in behalf of his Waterloo Committee, set up in 1973 to combat the Frenchbiased influence at the historic site of the battle that ended Napoleon's dream of conquest. While here, the Duke will put on display the original silkthread uniform worn by his famous forebear at Waterloo. Alongside itsweet revenge!at Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries, he'll place Napoleon's uniform coat, captured during the battle and recently acquired by the Library of Imperial History of the Royal Windsor Group.

title: Pop: Andrew Gold Glistens
description: Andrew Gold, who has been Linda Ronstadt's musical director for several years now, is emerging as the latest wunderkind of Los Angeles pop. Although he is only 25 years old, he is a capable guitarist, bassist, pianist, and drummer. He has recorded with Carly Simon, James Taylor, and Maria Muldaur, and has written songs for Leo Saver and Judy Collins, among others.

title: Spain Lifts Some Press Curbs Imposed to Combat Terrorists
description: MADRID, Feb. 15The Spanish Government lifted its ban today on news reports of police investigations into the kidnappings of two prominent rightist figures who it says were freed on Friday.

title: Miller Withdraws Play For Further Work
description: Alan Ayckbourn's six  character comedy. Absent Friends, will make its American debut this spring at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. replacing the previously announced presentation of Arthur Miller's The Archbishop's Ceiling.

title: SANJAY GANDHI SEEKS A SEAT IN PARLIAMENT
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's son Sanjay, whose activities as her close political adviser have caused dissension within the ruling Congress Party, was nominated by the party today to make his first run for Parliament in next month's elections.

title: Chess
description: Lax Defense Gives 2d Chance To Side That Starts Shakily

title: ISRAELI LABOR PARTY PONDERS ITS FUTURE
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15A week before the Israeli Labor Party's highly charged nominating convention, the governing party is reeling from the latest in a series of scandals and political setbacks that raise serious questions about the future of the party, which has dominated Israeli political life since the country was founded in 1948.

title: Best Buys
description: ON MONDAY, the novelty items were ornate chocolates and flowery cards. Today, when the attention of shoppers turns from the cardiac concerns of Valentine's Day to more routine nourishment, the novelty items are brisket of beef and carrots

title: The U.N. Today
Dividends
description: TUESDAY. FEBRUARY 15. 1977

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Du Pont Set to Resume Building Quebec Plant
description: Du Pont of Canada Ltd. announced that it would resume construction early next month of its $55 million polyester yarn plant near Coteau du Lac, Quebec. Work was halted last spring because of poor market conditions and completion now is scheduled this fall. The cost of finishing the plant was estimated at between $6 million and $7 million.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1977

title: Food Stamp Buyers Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)Participation in the Government's food stamp program increased by 200,000 in December, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's preliminary figures showed that 17.4 million people received food stamps that month, the most recent tabulated. The report said that $277.9 million was paid in December for stamps worth $698.5 million.

title: The Wolf Gets a Better Image With Biologist's Help
description: ELY. Minn.  A crimson pool of blood lay frozen in the snow. Ravens pecked at the last shreds of what had been a deer

title: 176 Moroccans Are Jailed On Plotting Charges
description: CASABLANCA. Morocco, Feb. 15 (Reuters)A court here imposed jail sentences today on 176 leftists for plotting to overthrow King Hassap and establish a people's republic in Morocco.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Said to Criticize Officials of New York and Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15A Securities and Exchange Commission staff investigation that is still in progress has in its preliminary stage been severely critical of both high New York City officials and officials of major banks, who coordinated their activities at the outset of the city's fiscal crisis, according to persons familiar with the investigation.

title: FORD RAISES PROFITS 0.6% FOR 3 MONTHS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15The Ford Motor Company reported today net earnings of $171 million, or $1.81 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1976  an increase of just sixtenths or one percent from the $170 million earned during the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Times Plans Home Section
description: The New York Times will publish, beginning March 17, a new Thursday section about the home, it was announced by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher. Called The Home Section,it will emphasize furniture and furnishings, design and decoration, landscaping and gardening, and home entertaining and life styles.

title: Barons Sale Falls Through; Swig Vows to Pay Players
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP)Although the proposed sale of the Cleveland Barons to Sanford Greenberg has fallen through, the current owner, Mel Swig,said today his players would be paid and the default of their contracts would be forestalled.

title: For Fortune, Joy, LongLife: Chinese Feast
description: WHAT WOULD YOU like for the next 12 months? Health? Wealth? Happiness? An untroubed, carefree life? Or perhaps a combination of all these things? Well, as the year of the dragon lumbers out and the year of the snake slithers in, these perquisites and more can be yours according to Chinese tradition and most of the Chinese cooks we know. The Chinese New Year will be celebrated Friday.

title: Music: Maazel at Sixes and Sevens
description: A VERY FISHER HALL'S appraisal period went into a new phase on Monday night with the appearance there of the Cleveland Orchestra under its music director, Lorin Maazel. Until Mr. Maazel conducted his allBeethoven program, the only orchestra to have played in the remodeled hall was the New York Philharmonic.

title: Bingham Finds Cuba Ready to Talk
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15A New York congressman said today after more than eight hours of talks with the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, that Cuba wished to cooperate with the United States immediately in several areas.

title: King Defends Decision In Favor of Boudreaux
description: Don King was in town yesterday to announce his promotion of a 12round heavyweight fight March 17 in Puerto Rico between George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, and Jimmy Young. King also announced that the World Boxing Association lightweight championship, a 15rounder between Roberto Duran of Panama and Jose Marquez, the fourthranked challenger from Puerto Rico, would be on the same card.

title: William D. Rhew, 75, ExOfficer Of General Motors Acceptance Corp
description: William Dowell Rhew, retired secretary of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived on Fairchild Road in Sharon.

title: Denmark's Social Democrats Gain In Election on Pledge to Create Jobs
description: COPENHAGEN. Feb. 15 (AP)Denmark's Social Democrats, who have governed as a minority since January 1975, scored significant gains in general elections today as voters responded to Prime Minister Anker jorgensen's call for a mandate to tackle unemployment, mounting foreign debts and labor disputes.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: ELECTIONLAW PANEL URGED TO REVISE PLAN
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15The State Election Law Enforcement Commission was urged today to revise proposed regulations on public financing of gubernatorial elections to prevent an unwarranted drain on state funds and to allow the public a greater flow of information about candidates.

title: Fear of Frying? Not When It's Optional
description: IT'S NOT that cooking ever really went out of style. But, for a while there, it wasn't easy for a liberated woman to admit that it was fun. After all those centuries of oppression, who could dare to love the smell of simmering soup, or confess to a passion for homemade granola. let alone pate de canard en croute?

title: Port Washington Classic Draws U.S. and Foreign Junior Tennis Stars
description: Tennis prodigies from all over the country and abroad, eager parents and nervous coaches make up the scene for the Port Washington Classic, the biggest junior tournament of the winter, which opens tomorrow morning at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy.

title: More Plant Closings Threatened As Rockwell Talks Remain Stalled
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP)No new bargaining sessions were scheduled today as contract talks remained suspended in the 10day old strike against Rockwell International car and truck component plants in Six states

title: James River Fishing Ban Partially Lifted
description: RICHMOND. Feb. 15The opening of the shad season in Virginia has been nightmare for the state's fishermen and a prospective disappointment for lovers of shad roe.

title: The Wolf Gets a Better Image With Biologist's Help
description: ELY. Minn.  A crimson pool of blood lay frozen in the snow. Ravens pecked at the last shreds of what had been a deer.

title: Elizabeth LeadPoisoning Clinic May Become a Model
description: ELIZABETH  A clinic at Elizabeth General Hospital for the treatmen of lead poisoningthe only one of its kind in Union Countymay become model for the rest of the country.

title: Sri Lanka Lifts 6Year Emergency
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 15 (UPI)Prime Minister Sirithavo Bandaranaike lifted today Sri Lanka's sixyear state of emergency, saying that she wanted to remove restraints from the general elections scheduled for this year. The Government also announced that all persons arrested under the emergency laws, including political prisoners, had been released.

title: Wheat and Corn Futures Show a Rise, Oats Decline
description: Wheat and corn futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as soybeans futures prices were mixed and those of oats declined.

title: 9 More Months of Drought Expected for Northwest
description: WASHINGTON,Feb. 15 (UPI)There is a very high degree of certainty that drought in California and other Pacific Coast states will continue for at least the next nine months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: VANCE IS IN ISRAEL ON MIDEAST MISSION
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived today to start what he called a quest for peace in the Middle East, with the emphasis, on the search for a comprehensive settlement rather than the limited accords fatored by Israel.

title: Shell Uncovers Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Shell Oil Company investigators have uncovered $387,000 paid to a representative who may have transmitted some of it to officials of an unidentifed foreign government, a Shell filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

title: All Cosmos Set to Train Except for a Brazilian
description: Pele will be absent from this morning's opening of the Cosmos training camp at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J..

title: Actually, This Article Is About Taxation
description: On Feb. 10, in a visit with employees of the Department of Housing arid Urban Development, President Carter'said, Those of you who are living in sin, I hope you will get married. e wonder whether anyone has told him how much this could cost the individuals involved?

title: Leinsdorf to Conduct In Berlin for 3 Years
description: Erich Leinsdorf will become chief conductor of the Radio Symphony of West Berlin for three yars, beginning next Sept. 1. The former conductor of the Boston Symphony, who is with the Metropolitan Opera this season, has been invited to become music director of the German orchestra, but his guestconducting commitmenest made it impossible for him to accept the administrative responsibilities that went with the post, so it was arranged for him to take the post of chief conductor.

title: S.I. SCHOOL CUSTODIAN UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: A school custodian who allegedly paid $11,000 to a ghost employee and then pocketed the money is being investigate by District Attorney Thomas R. Sullivan of Staten Island. The custodian is also said to have forged a signature so he could obtain extra payments to which he was not entitled.

title: Careers
description: Jay F. Morris, a Government official, conducts an unusual talent search each year. As director of the President's Commission on Personnel Interchange, he heads a sevenyearold program that puts Government middle managers into corporate jobs for a year and brings corporate executives into Government for a year.

title: The Greening of the Pension Funds
description: It should come as no surprise that imaginative marketers are about to sell a mutual fund whose assets are not stocks and bonds but farm land. The value of good farm land has easily tripled in the last six years, while the Dow Jones Average has remained soggy. Now Merrill Lynch and the Continental Illinois Bank are proposing AgLand I, a fund which would buy $50 million in farm land and lease it back to farmer tenants. The units of AgLand I would be sold to pension funds, which already are the nation's largest investors.

title: JAMES LIVERMORE, 84, ENGINEERING CONSULTANT
description: Joseph Mason Livermore, a longtime staff engineer with Lockwood, Greene Engineers Inc. and later with the U.S. Rubber Company, now called Uniroyal Inc., died Saturday at a hospital in Oregon City, Ore. He lived in Oregon City and was 84 years old.

title: Bar Association Rejects a Proposal To Call for End of Death Penalty
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 15The American Bar Association rejected today a proposal by some of its members that the A.B.A. urge the repeal of all state death penalty laws.

title: About Real Estate
description: The goal is the flowering of West 42d Street into a center of the arts, something of a consolidated offoff Broadway on the south side of the street from 9th to 10th Avenues. The impresario in the task is the 42d Street Redevelopment Corporation.

title: G. M. Ready to Drop Truck Plan in Poland
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has been trying for two years to conclude an agreement with Poland for a $1 billion truck plant, will have to go another way if no accord is reached within three or four months, according to Reuben R. Jensen, executive vice president in charge of G.M.'s overseas operations.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Last of Syrian Troops Leave Lebanese Region Near Border of Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Syrian troops of the Arab peacekeeping force completed a withdrawal today from southern Lebanon's sensitive Nabatiye area, a move apparently timed to coincide with the start of a Middle East tour by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: TV: Kipling's Tale of Young Kipling
description: HIPPED FROM INDIA with his younger sister, 6yearold Rudyard Kipling disembarks and promptly declares, I hate England. Actually, young Rudyard is called Punch, with his sister inevitably named Judy, in Baa Baa Blacksheep, an autobiographical tale that under no circumstances should he confused with the current and ludicrous NBC series of the same name. The story by Kipling, who of course became what many consider the prototypical Englishman, has been chosen to open a series of five dramatizations called Childhood, produced by James Brabazon for Britain's Granada Television. The programs begin on public televsion tonight at 9 and givo very indication of adding up to an exquisite collection.

title: Cold Forced a Heavy Cut In Production, Fed Reports
description: American industry cut back production sharply last month as a result of the bitter cold weather and resultant shortages of natural gas, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

title: Panama and the U.S. Resume Canal Talks
