description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)President Carter's chief energy adviser, James R. Schlesinger, told Congress today that passage of a Federal strip mining reclamation law was a prerequisite to a national energy policy making greater use of coal.

title: Beame Says Rent Curbs May Hurt Values
description: Mayor Beame said for the first time yesterday that rent control and New York City's other rent regulations had apparently contributed to the decline in value of the city's apartment buildings, but at the same time he reiterated his support for strict regulation of the rents of all apartments.

title: Lady Luck, the borrowed cup leaks.
description: For over a year, my family has been cheating the Government by combining mutually exclusive governmental aid programs. welfare, disability insurance, unemployment, student loans, scholarships, grants and personal loans.

title: 1971 State of Emergency Lapses in Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 16The state of emergency under which Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike ruled since March 1971 lapsed today as a result of last week's recessing of Parliament. By law, the President must proclaim a renewal of the emergency each month and then have it announced in Parliament.

title: Spain, With Kidnapping Behind It, Turns Its Attention to the Elections
description: MADRID, Feb. 16Political Madrid is back on its feet and buzzing. The liberation of a general and a rightwing former Justice Ministeras bizarre as their original kidnappingshas lifted a roadblock from Spain's incipient democracy. Political wheeling and dealing is back in fashion.

title: Celanese Posts Price Rise
description: The Celanese Fibers Marketing Company announced a price increase of 10 cents a pound on all acetate filament yarn products for warp knitting applications, effective April 4. The company said that the principal items involved are the 55 denier acetate products, the new price of which will be 93 cents a pound.

title: Thai Princess Killed by Rebel Fire as Her Copter Flies Aid Mission
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Feb. 17 (UPI)Princess Vibhavadi Rangsit of Thailand insisted that her helicopter pick up two wounded policemen in a guerrilla area and was killed by Communist groundfire, the police said today.

title: Argentina Is Planning Return to Democracy
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 (UPI)President Jorge Rafael Videla has told high military officers that the Government plans a gradual return to democracy in Argentina starting next year, press reports said today.

title: Brazil Raises Price Of Coffee $4 a Sack
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Brazilian Coffee Institute raised the price of coffee again today, lifting its export tax to $107 from $103 per 132pound sack.

title: A Profit Quest Preys on Naivete Of Plant Purchaser
description: The van with outofstate license plates came to a halt in front of Green Pastures, a popular plant store at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A young man bounced out and into the store.

title: OPEC COMPROMISE TO END PRICE SPLIT DENIED BY OFFICIAL
description: VIENNA, Feb. 16 (UPI)An official of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries denied today that OPEC's economic commission had agreed on a compromise formula ending the oil price split.

title: ANOTHER CONCILIATORY STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  President Carter said today he had received information from indirect sources that Cuba intended to remove its troops from Ango la and remarked that such a step would make it possible to consider normalizing relations with the Government of President Fidel Castro.

title: Carey Asks Legislature to Lift Ban On Drilling for Gas in Lake Erie
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to lift its 88yea;old ban on drilling for natural gas under Lake Erie.

title: Federal Agency Finds Westway Pollution Peril
description: The controversial $1.6 billion Westway project in Manhattan was branded environmentally unsatisfactory yesterday by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The proposal has been approved by the Secretaries of Transportation in both the Ford and Carter Administrations.

title: JURY SAYS 21 FAKED BILLS FOR OVERTIME
description: Twentyone elevator repairmen at city housing projects who allegedly billed the city for overtime averaging $50 a day while they were out fishing, at race tracks, in bars or just doing nothing, were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on forgery and other charges.

title: A Profit Quest Preys on Naivete Of Plant Purchaser
description: The van with outofstate license plates came to a halt front of Green Pastures, a popular plant store at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A young man bounced out and into the store. Hey, man he said, you want to buy some beautiful big cacti?

title: Music: Cherry Rhodes, Organist
description: Cherry Rhodes, one of this country's betterknown concert organists, played a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night under the sponsorship of the New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists. The first such presentation in New York by the guild, the event was one of a series of recitals it organized for this month to focus attention upon the organ, its literature and performers. The other recitals are being given in various churches.

title: Television
A White Enclave?
description: BERKELEY, Calif.The deans of California's great state law schools are a sober lot, not given to hysteria. And so one listens when they say this: If a recent decision of the State Supreme Court stands, they will soon have virtually no black or Chicano studentsand the same will be true of California's medical and other professional schools.

title: Abraham Dickenstein, 76, Dead; Founder of AmpalAmerican Israel
description: Abraham Dickenstein, founder and past president of the AmpalAmerican Israel Corporation, died Wednesday in his home in Tel Aviv. He was 76 years old.

title: PANEL DENIES REBATE ON INCOME OF $30,000
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The House Ways and Means Committee, in a drafting session on the tax aspects of President Carter's economic stimulus package, voted today to cut off a proposed tax rebate to those earning a gross income of more than $30,000 a year and to try to reach more poor families with the money.

title: 2 Credit Card and Store Concerns Ordered to Refund Overpayments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission today 041ered two big credit card compaqies, an oil company and two major department store chains to refund more than $3 million to consumers who have overpaid their bills.

title: Saudis and Indians Weigh Alaskan Bid
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 16 Representatives of private investors in Saudi Arabia are discussing with an Alaskan Indian corporation, Koniag, Inc., the polsibility of joint bidding in a Federal offshore oil and gas lease sale tentative,? scheduled for November of this year, officers of Koniag said today.

title: GEICO Raises AutoInsuring Rates
description: The Government Employees Insurance Company yesterday became the fourth major insurer to take advantage of a lapse in a New York State law requiring prior approval of auto insurance rate increases, and raised its rates an average of 18.2 percent, effectively immediately. The increases can, however, be rolled back by action of the New York State Insurance Superintendent, even if the law is not renewed, if he finds them to be excessive.

title: Cashin Enters Jersey City Race
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 16 (UPI)A stockbroker, who twice served as campaign director for Mayor Paul T. Jordan, says he will enter the Jersey City mayoral election in May. Arthur Cashin, 35 years old, said yesterday that he would run for the city's top post to be vacated by Dr. Jordan, who is seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Steel Union Aim Poses Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Lifetime securitya guaranteed Job and a guaranteed income for lifewould seem to be an audacious concept for an American worker. Yet that is precisely what the United Steelworkers of America, one of the country's biggest industrial unions said it would demand in its new contract. A job for life with a decent, respectable income for life, is the way I. W. Abel, the union's president, described the goal.

title: 186th Ballot Ends SixWeek Impasse in Illinois Senate
description: SPRINGFIELD, I11., Feb. 16 (UPI)Chicago Democrat, Thomas Hynes, was elected president of the Illinois Senate early today on the 186th ballot, ending a hitter sixweek fight.

title: Dollar, Pound and Gold Show Gains
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP)The dollar firmed today against the strong European currencies of Switzerland and West Germany. The British pound kept up a modest improvement, and the price of gold moved up 25 cents an ounce.

title: LAWRENCE WASSERSTEIN
description: Lawrence Wasserstein, president and general manager of Radio Station WWDJ, Hackensack, N. 3., for five years, died Tuesday in his home, 417 Charnwood Road, New Providence, N. J. after a long illness. He was 48 years old. Mr. Wasserstein, who had been in the communications field many years, was graduated from Pace University in 1951. He is survived by his wife, the former Shirley G. Sporn; a son, Jeffrey A.; his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Wasserstein of North Miami Beach, Fla., and a sister

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order, of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Events Today
description: THE CHERRY ORCHARD by Anton Chekhov, new English version by JeanClaude van !??? Directed be Andrei Serban. Cast includes Irene Worth, George Voskovec, Marybeih Hurt. Al to Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, al 6:15.

title: Westinghouse Deliberations Go On Behind Closed Doors
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16Last night, the chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and two utility chiefs forsook their customary polished circles for a drab, smallish courtroom here and a judge tired of listening to lawyers.

title: Madison's Mayor Places Second in Primary Vote; Faces Runoff on April 5
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 16In a bid for a third term, Mayor Paul Soglin of Madison placed second in a primary election yesterday, receiving less than 31 percent of the vote while a younger, conservative candidate received 39 percent. Four other candidates were eliminated.

title: Waldheim Feels P. L. O. Is Changing,
description: VIENNA, Feb. 16Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that an evolutionary process was going on in the Palestine Liberation Organization that might eventually lead to a smaller solution in the Middle East than the one hardline Palestinians were still advocating.

title: Detroit Class Still Bears Scars of Teacher's Slaying
description: DETROIT. Feb. 15Had it not been such a bizarre incident, the fatal shooting of 45yearold Bettye McCaster might have been recorded on the police blotter here as just another chapter in the nation's tragic story of violence and crime.

title: G.M. Says 82% of Net Came From the U.S.
description: The General Motors Corporation disclosed in its annual report that 82 percent of its 1976 net income of $2.9 billion came from United States operations, compared with 85. percent in 1975. The United States operations provided 76 percent of dollar sales in 1976, up from 72 percent in 1975.

title: Waldheim Criticizes Czech Police Over Treatment of Correspondent
description: VIENNA, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations today criticized Czechoslovak police for ordering a New York Times correspondent off a Viennabound train and forcing him to carry his luggage two miles into Austria.

title: CONCORDE FLIGHTS. BACKED BY CARTER
description: President Carter, in messages to the leaders of Britain and France, has reaffirmed the decision of the previous Administration authorizing a 16month test of Concorde landings in Washington and New York City. But the President's press secretary said yesterday that Mr. Carter still thought the authorization had been a mistake and that the President had said in his messages that he cannot direct authorities in New York as to what decisions they should make.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1977

title: Samuels Is One of Two Reportedly Under Study To Be G.S.A. Director
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16White House sources said tonight that Howard Samuels, former head of the New York's Off Track Betting Commission, and Jay Solomon, a shopping center developer in Tennessee, were the only two persons being considered by President Carter to head the General Services Administration.

title: Jasper Team Out to End Irish Streak
description: A rubber match between Notre Dame and Manhattan, teams that have been up and down, is the feature of tonight's college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. In the first game, which begins at 7 P.M., struggling Fordham plays Lafayette.

title: Nikolais's`Tower Is Performed Along With Styx and Temple
description: Alwin Nikolais's Tower, which was presented Tuesday evening at the Beacon Theater in Program C as part of the joint season with Murray Louis, started out life as part of a fulllength work, Vaudeville of the Elements, But it has existed so long as a separate entity that one despairs of ever seeing the total work again. It is dance in which the human race gets a cool going over from the choreographer.

title: WBAI Board Cuts Phones as Dispute Continues
description: WBAIFM's management, which last Friday took the station off the air to foil a takeover by the staff, yesterday disconnected the station's business telephones as staff and management remained at odds over union recognition and future programming.

title: Bad Weather Lifts Prices of Soybean And Grain Futures
description: Reports of continued unsatisfactory weather conditions in the growing areas of the country as well as improved export business sent grain and soybean futures prices up again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Danish Leader Is Seeking To Broaden Government
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen, whose Social Democratic Party scored significant gains in general elections yesterday, opened talks with other party leaders today amid growing skepticism that he would succeed in forming a majority coalition.

title: Haven on the Hill for Troubled TeenAgers
description: WESTPORT, Conn.From the outside, the Saugatuck Congregational Church stands like the glistening white, steepled centerpiece of so many other New England towns. Unlike so many other churches that bustle for a few hours on Sunday and spend the rest of the week in dignified repose, the Westport church is alive round the clock.

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For Periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) over the counter.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions.

title: Madison Quartet Plays With Eye to Structures
description: The Madison Quartet was formerly named the Amici Quartet, but the change does not mean its members are any less friendly to one another these days. The string group, which gave a concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, takes its new name from Madison County, N.Y., where Colgate University is situated. The Madison is a quartetinrdsidence at the school, once known as Madison College.

title: Noteholder Frustrated By Lag on Redemption
description: James McGivney was turned away from State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterdaywhere he had gone in the hope of finding out what he should do to redeem $20,000 worth of city notesand was told to return Tuesday. If he does, however, Mr. McGivney is likely to be sent home again.

title: Superhot, MetalRich Water Sought by Diving Scientists
description: Beginning today, in a series of dives that call to mind a Jules Verne adventure, scientists will descend 9,200 feet below the surface of the Pacific Ocean to explore and sample eruptions of superheated, metalrich water from the sea floor.

title: Likud Bid to Check Israeli Labor Party's Finances Provokes an Angry Debate and Shouts of Thieves!
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16At a raucoussometimes screamingsession of Parliament, Israel's major opposition political party attempted today to capitalize on a scandal involving the ruling Labor Party and to win approval of a motion ordering an inquiry into the Labor Party's finances.

title: Greyhound May End Listing of Its Stock
description: Gerald H. Trautman, chairman of the Greyhound Corporation, has threatened to abandon his company's listing on the New York Stock Exchange, saying, I don't feel the exchange should get into the internal affairs of a corporation.

title: Islanders Scoring
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Los Angeles. Dionne (35) (Gorieg, Sargent), 16:77. 2, Los Angeles, Venasky (?) 17:47. Penaltiesislander bench, served by Howatt, 6:52; Hart, major 8:09; Murphy, 8:57; Lewis, ?:53; Kozak, double minor, 14:39; Hovott, 14.37; D. Potvin, 15:34; Komadoskl, 20:00,

title: 2 Policemen Kill Youth On Roof as He Lunges At One With a Knife
description: A 19yearold youth was fatally shot by two New York City policemen yesterday after he allegedly lunged at one of them with a knife when they surprised him on a Bronx roof where they had been sent to investigate reports of gunfire.

title: For Panama, Talks With U.S. Come at a Time of Discontent
description: PANAMA, Feb. 15As negotiations with the United States for a new Panama Canal treaty enter a crucial stage, Panama finds itself in the midst of deep economic discontent and growing political dissatisfaction with its strongman, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera.

title: Stray Mortar Shell Explodes, Wounding 15 at Ft. Bragg, N.C.
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C., Feb. 16 (AP)A mortar shell exploded outside a target area here in a training exercise today, wounding 15 officers and enlisted men, snokcsman at this Army base said.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1977

title: Carter's Choice For Civil Rights
description: We were sitting on a powder keg here in Red Bank when Drew came to town in 1971 to represent a black family that was suing the town for alleged racial harassment, attorney Martin Barger recalled. We feared the situation mignt escalate into another race riot as we had experienced the past two years, Mr. Barger said, but thanks to Drew the powder keg didn't blow. The comments by Mr. Barger, who represented the small New Jersey town and its police department in the 1971 case, were typical of those by friends and professional advversaries of Drew Saunders Days 3d, who was nominated by President Carter on, Tuesday to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

title: Business Records
description: Pelltion filed by;

title: England Draws With India In Cricket Series Finale
description: BOMBAY, India, Feb. 16 (Reuters)England hung on today to draw in the fifth cricket test against India and clinch the series, 31. England started its second innings needing 214 runs to win in 245 minutes but on a crumbling pitch it was defeat rather than victory it spent most of the day contemplating. England was most vulnerable at 113 runs for five crickets with 15.2 of the final 20 overs remaining, but a defiant unbeaten 58 by Keith Fletcher saw England through to 152 for seven at the close.

title: Common Market Confers With Soviet on Fisheries In First Direct Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today explicitly recognized the existence of the European Common Market as negotiations opened on a fisheries agreement.

title: F.B.I. ADMITS IT TAPPED DECAVALCANTE ILLEGALLY
description: The F.B.I. has admitted illegally placing a listening device in the offices of New Jersey organized crime figure, Simone DeCavalcante, in the mid1960's, it was disclosed yesterday in Washington.

title: Lack of Snow in West Precipitates Alteration of World Cup Schedule
description: The continued snow shortages in most of the West's highmountain country caused plans yesterday for the World Cup events scheduled next month for Sun Valley, Idaho, and Heavenly Valley, Calif., to be altered. Our greatest concern is over the downhill competitions, said Hank Tauber, the director of the United States Alpine squad, speaking from Sun Valley. Originally, a downhill was to have been held at each of the resorts. It could be that both these races will have to be moved to Europe.

title: 280 Haitians Upheld By a Federal Judge In Deportation Fight
description: Deportation orders against 280 Haitians have been ruled invalid by a Federal judge in Miami who said that the Haitians had not been allowed to present their pleas for asylum during exclusion hearings conducted by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Knicks Win From Bulls By 123103
description: The erratic Knicks and the more erratic Walt Frazier needed a lift in morale and the Chicago Bulls provided it last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Reports of Area Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplied by resort owners.)

title: New York Human Resources Aide Criticizes Carey's DayCare Plan
description: J. Henry Smith, New York City's Human Resources Administrator, charged yesterday that Governor Carey's administration would subvert Congressional intent by withholding S14 million in Federal daycare money that the city expected to get under a bill signed by President Gerald R. Ford last summer.

title: Concert: Music for the Five Winds
description: HENTRY BRANT, one of New York's more adventuresome composers, wrote a piece three years ago for the Dorian Wind Quintet called Prevailing Winds. Last year, he made a new version for the pianist Hilde Somer and the quintet, titling it Secret Strings and Prevailing Winds. It had its premiere Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. in a program of 20thcentury music presented by the Center for InterAmerican Relations in cooperation with the Y.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales were an estimated $12.86 billion, up 7 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.08 billion. Department store sales were about $1.01 billion, up 6 percent from last year's $953 million.

title: Moscow Bows to Common Market On Licensing of Fishing Vessels
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today bowed to Common Market pressure and submitted applications to license some 40 vessels to fish inside the European Community's 200mile fishing zone over the next six weeks.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Thursday, February 17, 1977

title: Lukens Steel Shipments Cut by Shortage of Gas
description: The Lukens Steel Company of Coatsville, Pa., said that its firstquarter shipments would be significantly curtailed by the reduced natural gas supply and severe winter weather. W. E. Mullestein, chairman, said that we expect to recover from the setback as the year progresses.

title: Little Likelihood Is Seen Of Swine Flu This Winter
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17 (UPI)There is very little likelihood of a major outbreak of swine flu for the rest of this winter, influenza experts said today, but the danger of future outbreaks of the disease remains.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE CARTERS seems to be exercising their influence on American popular music even quicker than anyone might have anticipated. At least they are if New York is any indication. Not heretofore known as a center of country music, progressive country or even country rock, New York suddenly finds itself inundated with the stuff. Sea Level is at the Radio City Music Hall, and the Marshall Tucker Band is at the Palladium this weekend. As of this month there is a whole clubthe Lone Star Cafe on Fifth Avenue at 13th Streetdevoted to the music. And even cabarets normally associated with vastly different, more urban styles are beginning to book Southerners. Last week, Reno Sweeney had Marshall Chapman, and Tramps had (and has for 10 more days) Sid Selvidge. Both are quite remarkable; if the South has more like them, then let the inundation continue.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: TO WALK ALONG Grand Street is to wrap oneself in the ethnic history and cultural fabric of New York City. Grand Street evokes memories of the city's labor movement, the Jewish Lower East Side ghetto, the wave of Italian immigration, the lengthening sprawl of Chinatown, and of one of its new frontiers. SoHo, where Grand Street Quietly begins.

title: So You Can't Fight City Hall?
description: There is a popular notion that you can't fight City Hall but M. Donald Grant doesn't share it. The Mets' chairman of the board, poised and shifty, has been going around and around with the aggressive, crowdpleasing Abe Beame, and up to now Abe hasn't laid a glove on him.

title: MURDER SUSPECT, 16, SAID TO HAVE RECORD
description: A 16yearold Brooklyn youth accused of the recent murder of an elderly woman in Coop City had a record of violent sex crimes and had been under supervision by state juvenile authorities at the time of the homicide, State Senator Ralph J. Marino said yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1977

title: Man Held for Offering To Pay Boys for Sex
description: A 33yearold Valley Stream, L.I., man was arrested in Times Square last night on charges of offering two young runaway brothers from New Jersey $20 each to have sexual relations with him, the police reported.

title: BELL DISPUTES A REPORT ON KOREANCASE CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell disputed today a newspaper report that he had told President Carter that he expected indictments of several present and former Congressmen in connection with the inquiry of South Korean efforts to buy influence on Capitol Hill.

title: Steelmakers' Opposition to Bans On Rhodesian Chrome Softening
description: A severely depressed domestic stainless steel industry, coupled with technological advances in the preparation of chrome ores, has softened industry opposition toward sanctions on Rhodesian chrome imports.

title: Broadway
description: IT WAS really only a question of who would bring The Shadow Box into New York, and not a matter of whether it would come in at all. The play by Michael Cristofer was done first at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, and most recently at the Long Wharf in New Haven, and a number of producers have wanted to bring it to Broadway. Now Ken Marsolais, Lester Osterman, Leonard Soloway and Al Francis will join to do just that, and they will open The Shadow Box at the Morosco Theater on March 31, with the previews beginning March 25.

title: White House Seeks the Payment Of 3 Years' U.S. Dues to UNESCO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The Carter Administration today asked Congress for nearly $70 million for three years' dues to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, including two years of arrears.

title: Publisher in Atlanta Buys Ads To Rebut Times Magazine Article
description: The publisher of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution has placed advertisements in two Washington newspapers and The New York Times to rebut some statements in a Feb. 6 New York Times Magazine article.

title: Article 1  No Title
Carter Is Said to Ask Mansfield To Head Mission to North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)President Carter wants former Senator Mike Mansfield to head a mission to Hanoi to seek a full accounting of missing United States servicemen and hold talks on rebuilding American  Vietnamese relations, an official source said today.

title: Labor Group Urges Cargo Policy to Aid U. S.Flag Vessels
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17The executive council of the Maritime Trades Department of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called Department of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for the development of a national argo policy that would assure the American fleet a substantial share of the nation's cargo in the trade routes of the world.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Dolores Ibarruri, the 81yearold president of the Spanish Communist Party, hopes to return home next month after nearly 40 years of exile in Moscow, a party spokesman said today.

title: On Mott, Greet The Year 4675
description: THE CHINESE New Year begins today, and you can hear it live and staccato if you go downtown to Chinatown. Arriving in a flurry of celebration, the happy time crests tomorrow and Sunday with a clangor in the air, gleeful traffic in the streets and abundant feasts for all palates.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday misstated the estimated cost of the Westway highway project. The correct figure is $1.16 billion.

title: N.F.L. and Players in Tentative Accord
description: Negotiators for the National Football League and its Players Association reported a tentative settlement yesterday after more than three years of suits, strikes and strained labor relations.

title: Pupils' Bazaar Helps Neediest And the Elderly
description: SADDLE BROOK, N. J., Feb. 17For the 49 youngsters In the fifth grade at the Salome H. Long Memorial School in this Bergen County community, today was a day for special learning. It was a day for learning about caring and sharing and salesmanship, about adding and subtractingbut especially it was a day for helping others

title: Carter Moves on Reorganization With End Run Past Rep. Brooks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17He has only the most profound admiration for Jack Brooks, President Carter told 10 members of the House Government Operations Committee at a White House meeting today, and he did not want to give the appearance of going over the head of the Texas Democrat who is the committee's chairman.

title: Books of The Times
description: CHARLES BAUDELAIRE was a very good poet, whose life reads like that of a very bad poet. In this poorly written but welldocumented biography, Alex de Jonge calls Baudelaire the creator of modern art, the first writer to map modern man's unhappy consciousness. There is some truth in the statements, but it is also true that Baudelaire was the model for much of the tiresome posturing and silliness that surrounds certain schools of contemporary poetry.

title: Taft Five Has the Attitude, And Power to Reach Top
description: When the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs roll around, one of the first questions interested observers ask is: What does Taft have? The Blue Devils from the Bronx won the P.S.A.L. title in 1974 and 1975, and last season were eliminated in a bitter semifinal loss to Lafayette. This year, Taft seems to have the right Sports combination again, starting with Coach Don Adams. I thought we had an excellent team this season, Adams said yesterday, but we lost some games because of our attitude. It took us a while to realize that. We tended to take other teams too easily. They don't have to get souped up for us.

title: Weekend Gardening: Beeches or Birches
description: OUR BIRCH TREES, their white bark and charcoalblack bristling branches adding a penandink effect to the frosted landscape, are particularly handsome this time of year. And I'll appreciate them even more in a few months when their delicate chartreuse leaves open to the spring sun. Even so, I will take the chain saw to them sooner or later. The reason is leaf miners.

title: Jazz, Folk, Classical: Variety Is the Theme
Revised Figures for Money Supply Indicate Practically No Changes
description: Final and revised figures for the growth of the nation's money supply last year were issued yesterday by the New York Federal Reserve bank. They showed practically no change from its earlier estimates.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Jonathan B. Bingham was in his pajamas and his wife, Jane, was draped in a bath towel in their hotel room in Havana Monday night when there was an unexpected knock at the door. The Bronx Democrat opened the door and it was Fidel Castro, he said. He had thought we would be warned beforehand and he was very embarrassed. Mr. Bingham, reporting in Washington on his sixday trip to Cuba, said that Mr. Castro later drove the Binghams through Havana and to some cattlebreeding farms. We spent over seven hours with him, Mr. Bingham said. He has a feeling of admiration for President Carter as a man of moral principle.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Tire makers and other industries in Ohio are seeking natural gas supplies on their own or leased properties. Page D12.

title: U.S. Banks Raised Foreign Lending. To a Record $20.6 Billion for 1976
description: American banks increased their foreign lending by a record $20.6 billion last year, in a development that was expected to heighten the debate over the rapid growth of such overseas bank lending in recent years.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1977

title: 35,000 Strike in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 17 (AP)More than 35,000 Israeli engineers and teachers went on strike today, demanding pay increases of up to 38 percent on salaries that average $400 a month. Meanwhile, the schedule of El Al Airlines was disrupted by heavy absenteeism among maintenance workers that was attributed by the management to the rejection of a fourday week for nightshift workers.

title: Transit Police Are Redeployed to Anticrime Patrols
description: Apparently under pressure, Chief Sanford D. Garelik of the Transit Police acknowledged last night that he was redeploying his policemen from turnstile posts to catch fare evaders to anticrime patrols on subway trains and stations.

title: Woodcock Opens Campaign to Be Republican Nominee for Governor
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Feb. 17Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the former state legislator who recently resigned as Bergen County Prosecutor, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: Rumania Seizes Leading Dissidents; Ceausescu Terms Them Traitors
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania. Feb. 17A number of wellknown campaigners for human rights were arrested here today as President Nicolae Ceausescu delivered a speech denouncing dissidents and wouldbe emigrants as traitors to Rumania.

title: Upstate College Raises Tuition
description: Allan A. Kuusisto, president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., announced a 7.7 percent, or $400 increase in room, board and tuition for a total of $5,600 next year. Tuition will increase from $3,570 to $3,870, room from $750 to $800 and board from $880 to $930.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Art: Ellsworth Kelly, A Grand Showing
description: ELLSWORTH KELLY is one of the most serious artists around. He can woo and win, when he feels like it, but he really prefers to make an exact longpondered statement and say, in effect, There you are. Take it or leave it.

title: Vendor's Slaying Spurs Reopening Of a U.S. Inquiry Into State Lottery
description: Last week's gangstyle slaying of the New York State lottery's largest ticket vendor has prompted the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan to reopen an investigation into the lottery that was suspended in duplicateticket scandal late in 1975.

title: JUDGE VOIDS THE SALE OF U S. LEASES FOR OIL OFF NORTHEAST COAST
description: A Federal judge voided the Govern ment's sale of $1.13 billion in leases for oil and gas drilling rights in the Atlantic Ocean yesterday because, he said, there was considerable evidence that environmental impact statements and public hearings for the issues had been a charade.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNCNFM. Etude, Debussy; Sonata No. 2, Pezel; Pas de Caractere, Glazunov; Symphony No. 7, Boyce; Sinfonia from the Christmas Oratorio, Bach; Zapateado, Turina.

title: Space Shuttle Begins a Year's Tests Today As Prelude to Possible New Era in Flight
description: EDWARDS, Calif., Feb. 17Someday, in the notsosciencefiction future, sturdy spaceplanes will fly orbital freight. They will deliver satellites for communications, weather forecasting and scientific research, among other cargoes. Then these winged vehicles, with astronauts at the controls and scientists and other passengers aboard, will return to a glide landing on Earth.

title: 4 Invade a Park Ave. Apartment, Tie Up 7 and Ransack Premises
description: A Park Avenue apartment was invaded yesterday by four men, one armed with a handgun, who ransacked the premises and escaped with a small amount of cash and valuables.

title: A Concert Starring The Piccolo
description: It's sort of frustrating to be a piccolo player, says Laurence Trott, who has been the chief piccolo player of the Buffalo Philharmonic for the last 19 years. It's such an incredibly difficult instrument that you have to be at the top of your form all the time, and then you just sit there in the orchestra and wait for something to happen, which it usually doesn't. There are a few symphonic pieces that exploit the real beauty and other remarkable qualities of the piccolo, but not all that many.

title: Burmese Report Heavy Fighting Against Rebels Near Thai Border
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 17 (AP)Government soldiers killed 56 rebel Karen tribesmen and wounded 84 in a series of battles in southeast Burma last week, according to a Government spokesman.

title: DOLLAR IS MIXED ABROAD; POUND LOSES SOME GROUND
description: BRUSSELS. Feb. 17 (UPI)The dollar closed mixed on European money markets today and the British pound lost some ground.

title: Flyers Rout Rangers, 71; Davidson Plays 2 Periods
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17Poor Ranger goaltending and a defense sent reeling by the merciless aggression of the Philadelphia Flyers reseulted in a 71 New York loss tonight in the Spectrum, the worst defeat the Rangers have ever suffered to the Flyers. The teams had tid in all three previous meetings this season.

title: WIDE VARIANCE FOUND IN FEES FOR SURGERY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17An analysis of Medicare fees paid to doctors for four common operations has found enormous differences in charges throughout the country, even after making allowances for regional costofliving differences, according to a consumer study released today.

title: Panel on Casino Gambling Issues Proposals on Rules and Controls
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17A special committee of law enforcement and State Treasury officials issued its first recommendations today on rules and controls for future legalized casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: METEORITES FOUND BY ANTARCTIC TEAM
description: Ignoring the ridicule of scientists who said their mission was futile, two American geologists and a Japanese colleague, aided by sharpeyed helicopter crewmen, have discovered a bonanza of meteorites sitting atop the The Antarctic ice sheet.

title: News Summary
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt made a move aimed at breaking the Middle East impasse with a proposal that the Palestinians form an official and declared link with Jordan even before the conference on the Middle East is resumed in Geneva. He made the proposal at a news conference in Cairo with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. If the Palestinians agree to the proposal, they would form a joint delegation with Jordan. This would make unlikely the formation of a separate, independent Palestinian state. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Restaurants
description: IN THE LAST MONTH, there have been two additions to the city's rapidly growing roster of expensive and elegant Indian restaurants, apparently one of the in ethnic trends of the moment. Of these two, the more elaborate, ambitious and successful is Raga on 48th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, on the premises formerly occupied by the Forum of the XII Caesars. Opulence obviously suits this site, for the silk and damask trappings of Imperial Rome have given way to the lavish and equally luxurious appurtenances of the Eastern maharajahs.

title: 5 Children Killed in House Fire
description: LUMBERTON, N.C., Feb. 17 (AP)Five young children left alone in a rural house near here died in a fire today. The authorities said Dorothy Locklear, mother of three of the victims and an aunt of the other two, had left the children alone while she went to visit her father.

title: CAREY ASKS MONITOR OF CITY HEALTH CARE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Governor Carey proposed today the appointment of a new toplevel administrator with full authority over New York City's entire health care system, including the power to close both voluntary and municipal hospitals.

title: Amin Seeks Leadership Meeting
description: NAIROBI. Feb. 17 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda today invited the presidents of Tanzania and Kenya to an emergency meeting next week to discuss the growing feud among the East African nations.

title: DOCTORS BACK A DRUG TO CURB BLOOD CLOTS
description: A committee of physicians and scientists recommended yesterday that an anticoagulant drug be used routinely to prevent the development of potentially fatal blood clots in certain patients undergoing major surgery.

title: Letters
description: In arguing that the right of dissent should be upheld in your Feb. 1 editorial A Worthwhile Complication, you listed as a selfish reason for encouraging dissent abroad the nourishing of dissent here at home. While that is a bonus to expect from a forthright policy in support of civil liberties outside the United States, it is not the only selfish reason for such a policy. Especially in the setting of the 1975 Helsinki accords, a country's internal conduct is made a contributing factor to the security of its neighbors.

title: In Roving Bicentennial Exhibit, 12 Obscure Americans Face the Nations
description: What do Americans look like? Do they look like the gangsters and politicians and movie queens that people see in films and pictures all over the world?

title: EXAIDE TO BUCKLEY PLANS NEW MORNING NEWSPAPER
description: A new morning daily newspaper for the metropolitan area is being planned by a former aide to former United States Senpttor James L. Buckley and a former editor of Newsweek and The New York Herald Tribune.

title: Jazz Goes to the New School
description: Four years ago, Chuck Israels, a jazz bassist who had played with Bill Evans for several years and was then freelancing in the studios, started an orchestra called the National Jazz Ensemble, to play the classics of jazz from Jelly Roll Morton and Duke Ellington to Thelonious Monk and Ornette Coleman. He hoped to make it a permanent, resident repertory orchestra, equivalent, in jazz terms, to the New York Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony.

title: Martha's Vineyard Votes to Secede
description: CHILMARK, Mass., Feb. 17 (AP)Some residents of Martha's Vineyard, angered by the prospect of losing their only delegate to the state legislature, are trying to secede from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: The U.N. Today
Brooklyn Gets New Style of Opera
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has been host to numerous opera companies since it was built in 1908, but this weekend it has gone into the opera business itself for the first time. The type of opera offered will be anything but standard fare and even the setting will involve a departure, taking place not in the Brooklyn Academy's beautiful opera house, but in its Lepercq space. The first of the productions, a triple bill of esoteric works, will open tonight at 8. It will be repeated tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 2.

title: Estimate Board Postpones a Vote On Pornography
description: Under pressure from the Borough Presidents of Brooklyn and Queens, the New York City Board of Estimate put off yesterday a vote on New York City's proposed zoning amendments that would sharply curtail the number of pornographic uses in all five boroughs. The vote was put off for two weeks. Donald R. Manes of Queens and Howard Golden of Brooklyn both said they would oppose the proposal unless the board added an amendment that would ban all adult bookstores and movie theaters, peep shows, topless bars and massage parlors from every borough in the city except Manhattan and a small area in the Bronx.

title: Rhodesia Calm on Chrome Move
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17Rhodesian officials, undismayed by the Carter Administration's move to repeal the Byrd amendment are confident that they can divert their chrome exports into other markets and that some of the ore will continue to reach the United States despite any renewed boycott.

title: Korean Agent or Merely a Hostess? Washington Woman Is the Topic of Rumor and Unanswered Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Who is Susie? There are those who believe that she is a sort of latterday Mata Hari. Others see her more as a sort of Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm, skipping innocently through the corridors of power.

title: Sunday
description: AN 1842STYLE HOLIDAY

title: Mexico Oil Reserve Soars; Put at 60 Billion Barrels
description: MEXICO CITY. Feb. 17Despite conservative official estimates. Mexico's crude oil reserves are now believed to exceed 60 billion barrels, roughly six times greater than Alaska's North Slope deposits and much larger than previously estimated.

title: At the Movies
description: I LOVE BEING regarded as a sex symbol, but I can't take it too seriously, said the grinning, bushyhaired, adolescentlooking actor. Although he recently made an impressive movie debut as the smirkingly villainous high school senior who gets a lethal comeuppance from the cruelly ostracized Sissy. Spacek in Carrie, he is better known as Vinnie. Barbarino, the most endearingly disruptive member of the Sweathogs, a pack of spunky Brooklyn high school lads on television's Welcome Back, Kotter.

title: New Black Rhodesian Movement Fights Uncle Tom Charge
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17To his political rivals, he is a stooge, an Uncle Tom in a pinstripe suit who is controlled and financed by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith. But Jeremiah S. Chirau, the newest of a long line of contenders for the leadership of a blackruled Rhodesia, dismisses the criticism just as he does the gasoline bombs that have been tossed at his home.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday misstated the estimated cost of the Westway highway project. The correct figure is $1.16 billion.

title: In Memoriam
description: LEAVYLeonard, Feb. 18, 1966. Cher ished memory of my dear husband. All my love. Dorothy.

title: S. E. Prentice, Investor, Weds Nancy M. Reilly
description: Nancy M. Reilly and Sheldon Ellsworth Prentice, both of New York, were married here yesterday in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)

title: Quincy Howe, Newscaster, Dies; Long a Defender of Civil Liberties
description: Quincy Howe, a pioneer in radio and television news commentary and lifelong defender of civil liberties, died yesterday at an East Side nursing home of cancer of the larynx: He was 76 years old.

title: 24 Reported Slain in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Sixteen guerrillas and two white Rhodesian soldiers were killed in the last 24 hours, a security forces communiqu said today. Guerrillas also killed six tribesmen in three separate incidents and wounded a white government employee, it said.

title: The Program
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Pierre Boulez, conductor; Garrick, Ohlsson, pianist. At Avery Fisher Hall.

title: About Real Estate
description: There are elderly people in the city whose rents have gone up to 50 percent or even 60 percent of monthly income. Those are hardship situations, but for some, relief has come.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Kissinger Signs With NBCTV For News Programs for 5 Years
description: Henry A. Kissinger will be on television for at least the next five years.

title: HOUSE UNIT APPROVES EMPLOYMENT CREDIT AND REBATES OF $50; Ways and Means Panel Completes Action on Stimulus PackageChecks Could Come in April
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The House Ways and Means Committee completed action today on President Carter's economic stimulus package, approving a $50 tax rebate and changes in the standard deduction that would help lowerincome groups, but making substantial changes in the projected benefits for business.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: H.E.W., Warning of Funds Cutoff, To Review Six School Racial Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today ordered a reopening of six school desegregation cases that earlier Administrations had left in limbo rather than order Federal funds cut off.

title: CHICAGO OPTIONS BOARD INCREASES TRADING LIST
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange, in a move it described as remaining competitive, said yesterday that it would begin trading Wednesday in options for six stocks already traded on the American Stock Exchange and one now traded on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It is no longer fashionable to have a fat baby.

title: Dow Falls 4.57 in Slower Trading, Ending 3Session Technical Rally
description: The stock market's threesession technical rally ended abruptly yesterday as prices declined in slower trading.

title: U.S. TO INVESTIGATE LAG IN GAS OUTPUT IN GULF OF MEXICO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  Reporting that natural gas production in four gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico has been substantially below maximum rates, Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus said today that he would order a comprehensive investigation into whether producers had been deliberately holding back gas to drive prices higher.

title: Carter Establishes Merit Selection of Appellate fudges, but Yields to Senators on District Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  President Carter today created a commission that would make merit recommendations for Federal judgeships at the appellate level, but he left unchanged the traditional influence of patronage on appointments to Federal district courts.

title: MARTIN KANE, EXEDITOR FOR SPORTS ILLUSTRATED
description: Martin Kane, a writer and editor for Sports Illustrated magazine for 17 years died last week at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: Surprise in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 17Mr. Sadat's proposal that the P.L.O. should espouse an official and declared link with Jordan was greeted with surprise tonight by a spokeman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry. According to the official, no response was expected from the Israelis until the text of the Cairo press conference had been scrutinized.

title: OilLease Ruling Has Broad Ramifications
description: If the parties in the Federal Court action voiding last August's sale of oil and gas leases in the Atlantic Ocean agreed on anything, it was that the decision was an important one. For the United States's energy progress, and particularly its offshoreleasing program, it was yet another setback, although the effect of oil and gas from these leases on the national problem would have been minimal. For the environmental groups and local governments that have steadfastly maintained that they were misled about the prospects for increased tanker traffic and increased environmental risks, the decision was a moral victory.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Takes Her Campaign To Farm Region That Elected Her
description: RAE BARELI, India, Feb. 17Prime Minister Indira Gandhi took her reelection campaign to her parliamentary constituency here today, asking the voters to give her another term so that she could work to make India an even greater nation.

title: Bridge:
description: For most novice players, the first venture into open tournament play, where cries of director punctuate the silence every few minutes, is a harrowing experience. For some, indeed, once is enough, and they retire thankfully to, the morepeaceful atmosphere of local duplicate games and rubber bridge in the home.

title: BEAME'S M.A.C. PLAN STIRS AN UNEASINESS
description: Bankers and the leaders of municipal unions expressed reservations yesterday about Mayor Beame's new proposal to restore investor confidence in New York City finances by giving new powers to the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state agency.

title: Massengale Shines Again With 65
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17Rik Massengale is taking up where he left off last week, when he dominated the Desert Classic from wire to wire and won by six strokes.

title: Mets Throw Jets for Loss In Shea Dispute
description: The New York Jets offered City Hall a compromise to a compromise yesterday in their deadlock with the Nets over the sharing of Shea Stadium. But the baseball team told Mayor Hearne that the offer was a backward step.

title: Art: Joseph Stella, A Puzzling Figure
description: THIS YEAR marks the centenary of the Italianborn American artist, Joseph Stella, who won considerable fame for his monumental paintings of the Brooklyn Bridge in the 1920's, but whose untidy and somewhat contradictory career has been something of a conundrum for critics and historians ever since.

title: Giants Check the Wounded
description: It was physical examination day at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., yesterday, postseason physicals for those Giants injured during the 1976 football season. The most celebrated knee of all did not show. Larry Csonka was somewhere in the South en route to his appointment with Dr. John Marshall, the club's orthopedic surgeon from New York's Hospital of Special Surgery.

title: C.B. Slang Glossary Is Offered by RCA
description: RCA has come up with a great little traffic builder for the dealers that handle its citizen band radio line. It is a book that contains a glossary of selected C.B. slang, a list of the 10 code (1034 is help me quick) and a truck channel guide, all in a kids' coloring book.

title: Don't be lazy, Lem. Look at it this way:
description: There is no other month like this. Cold, sleet, rain, snow, and sunshine. But we must make the best of it. There is the cellar to be cleaned out. Might as well do it now as any time, and a great deal better than put it off till the spring work begins to press.

title: Excerpts From the Ruling Voiding Sale of Offshore Oil and Gas Leases
description: We find that the Secretary [Thomas Kleppe, former Secretary of the Interior] 1) ignored the practical effects of local governmental licensing, permitting and review powers in the NEPA [National Environmental Policy Act] documents; 2) failed to consider the environmental impact of specific probable pipeline routes from the outer continental shelf, in spite of the fact that projection of such routes is routinely made by industry and could have been made by the Secretary or his agents; 3) greatly overstated peak oil and gas production for Sale 40 and significantly understated the cost of such production, including pipeline construction; this resulted in a serious lack of consideration of the likelihood and attendant dangers of increased tanker traffic and an overestimate of the net value of the entire project; 4) failed to consider the possible impact of particular tractselection choices on the feasibility and sites of pipelines; there was no consideration of the alternatives of either excluding industrypreferred tracts, or including less highly desired tracts in the final sale offer because of related onshore impacts and developments; and 5) failed to consider the alternative of separating exploration from production leasing. Adequate consideration of these factors might have led to modifications in the Sale 40 leasing program, resulting in greater environmental protection without impairing reasonable exploitation of offshore hydrocarbon resources

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17Before 60 of New Jersey's 49,000 deaf residents, Governor Byrne signed into law today a bill that will require that every newborn child in the state, except those whose parents have religious objections, be given a test for the detection of hearing impairments.

title: DAVID S. HERZOG, 87, DIES; REALTOR'S CHIEF ENGINEER
description: David Sulzberger Herzog, former chief engineer of Samuel A. Herzog and Company, realtors, died Wednesday night at New York Hospital after a fourmonthlong illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 1125 Park Avenue.

title: Parents in Detroit Ordered To Immunize Children
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP)Parents of Detroit elementary schoolchildren have been given an ultimatum: Either get their youngsters immunized against major diseases by March 7, or keep them home.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Tips on Tickets
description: Ashes may be seen tonight, tomorrow an Sunday at 8 P.M. and tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets at all prices are available at the box office, open from 1 to 8 P.M. The Public Theater is at 425 Lafayette Street. Information: 6776350.

title: Lay Teachers' Union Vote Blocked in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)A Federal district judge today temporarily blocked a bargaining election among lay teachers in some 200 elementary schools in the Philadelphia Roman Catholic Archdiocese.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Judge Penalizes Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17Federal education funds for Chicago's financially strapped schools were ordered withheld today by a Federal administrative judge who ruled that the Board of Education was discriminating against minority teachers and pupils in the way it assigned teachers.

title: New York State to Get $51 Million For Youths' Summer Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Federal allotments for this year's summer job programs for disadvantaged youths will amount to $51 million for New York State, $20.7 million for New Jersey and $8.8 million for Connecticut, it was announced today.

title: Dance: The Murray Louis Wit
description: MURRAY LOUIS came up with a sparkling and bright new solo Wednesday night on the third program of the season that the Murray Louis Dance Company is currently sharing with the Nikolais Dance Theater at the Beacon Theater.

title: Gribetz Wears the Power Mantle Lightly
description: ALBANYJudah Gribetz, counsel to the Governor, has a deceptively bland, rotund countenance. He looks sort of like a large version of Bashful in the Snow White movie.

title: Ski Areas Ready for Cold, Busy Weekend
Polaroid increases Earnings in Quarter 29.1% for a Record
description: The Polaroid Corporation announced record gains in fourthquarter and annual sales and earnings for 1976 yesterday, even as it was introducing several new lines of instant cameras and films that signaled greater emphasis on commercial and technical markets.

title: Jones of 76ers Sustains Possible Wrist Fracture
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (UPI)Caldwell Jones of the Philadelphia 76ers suffered a possible fracture of a bone in his wrist last night and his status for the remainder of the National Basketball Association season is uncertain, a team spokesman said today.

title: Market Place
description: The nation's publicly owned brokerage firms enjoyed record profits last year, thanks to booming stockexchange volume, a brisk business in options and surging revenues in fixedincome securities.

title: Sakharov Receives Carter Letter Affirming Commitment on Rights
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17Andrei D. Sakharov, a leading figure in the Soviet dissident movement, today received a letter from President Carter assuring him of the Administration's commitment to human rights.

title: The Saudi Connection and the Arab Boycott
description: HE AMICABLE 44year relationship with Saudi Arabia has become a matter of prime importance to the United States. This is true for economic and political reasons, and, most critically, for reasons of United States security. Our national interest requires that this relationship, in a manner consistent with principle, be supported and strengthened. Instead, we seem bent on destroying it.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Feb. 17, 1977

title: Checking a Child's Height and Weight
description: Pediatricians usually hope to keep a child's length and weight commensurate. So if a boy is in the 75th percentile in lengthmeaning that 25 percent of the youngsters his age are longer than he isthen his weight should ideally also be in the 75th percentile. On the chart above, this would be 27.25 inches and 18.7 pounds.

title: Two Planning Expansion Of Checker, Taxi Maker
description: With pending options to buy a 50 percent interest in the Checker Motors Corporation, Edward N. Cole, a retired General Motors president, and Victor Potamkin, the New York Cadillac dealer, plan to revamp and expand the 55yearold taxicab and auto concern, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CURRIER HOLMAN, 65, BEEF PROCESSOR, DIES
description: DAKOTA CITY, Neb., Feb. 17 (AP)Currier J. Holman, cofounder of Iowa Beef Processors Inc., died yesterday after an apparent heart attack at his winter home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: Crosland's Condition Is Stable
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland, seized with a stroke on Sunday, remained in critical but stable condition today, doctors said. A spokesman at Radcliffe Infirmary near Oxford said he was in about the same condition as yesterday when a steady deterioration had been halted. His Americanborn wife, Susan, has been keeping a bedside vigil since her husband was rushed to the hospital near their home.

title: Dentist, 75, Is Stabbed to Death In His Office in The Bronx
description: A 75yearold semiretired dentist was found slain last night in his office residence in the Melrose section of the Bronx, his throat cut by a knife, the police reported.

title: Jack Wilkins, 55, Dies In Fall From Mountain; A Reporter in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 17 (AP)Jack Wilkins, a reporter for The Seattle PostIntelligencer and a mountainclimbing enthusiast, died yesterday from a fall while climbing Mount Rainier. He was 55 years old.

title: Gribetz Wears His PowerBut Lightly
description: ALBANYJudah Gribetz, counsel to the Governor, has a deceptively bland, rotund countenance. He looks sort of like a large version of Bashful in the Snow White movie.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Angered by charges that they were part of a corrupt schoolcustodial system and bitter over a planned ban on the employment of their relatives, members of the custodians union voted down a tentative new contract that had been negotiated earlier this month with the New York City Board of Education.

title: STATE COURT UP HOLDS ANTILOITERING LAW
description: A controversial New York State antiloitering statute enacted last summer to curb prostitution was upheld yesterday in an appellate court decision, overturning a Manhattan Criminal Court judge's ruling that the statute was unconstitutional.

title: Memorial Services
description: TAYLORJean Hayes. A memorial service for Jean Hayes Taylor, wife of Bernard Taylor and mother of Jean Taylor Lipps?? will be held at the Riverside Church Chapel, on Saturday. February 19, 1977 at 1 P.M. Church address: The Riverside Church, 122nd Street and Riverside Drive.

title: U.S. Aide Calls Death Dismaying
description: GENEVA, Feb. 17The United States representative at the United Nations Human Rights Commission described today as dismaying the news of the death of the Archbishop of Uganda and two Government ministers.

title: POLICEMAN KILLED BY CULTIST BURIED
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17Police Officer Allen B, McLeod of New Rochelle, the 32yearold policeman who was one of five persons shot to death by a Nazi cultist last Monday, was buried today after a funeral at the Memorial United Methofl ist Church here. He was one of those cut down by Frederick W. Cowan in a shooting spree at the offices of the Neptune Worldwide Moving Company.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Seven North Jersey car dealers pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges they had hired an expert to roll back mileage figures on 300 used cars over four years. United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said the dealers had agreed to reimburse car buyers for the difference between what they paid and what the cars would have cost with accurate odometer readings. The dealers admitted hiring Eugene Gary Kocses, a professional rollback expert who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges in November, to perform his service for $20 to $40 per car, Mr. Goldstein said. The owners and officers of the dealerships pleaded guilty to a variety of charges, including conspiracy to violate odometertampering statutes and using the mails to send fraudulent registration materials to Trenton. They face up to a year in jail and $50,000 fines on the conspiracy charges and five years and $1,000 fines for the mail fraud pleas.

title: Esmark Steps Up Bid for Inmont
description: Esmark Inc., a large diversified company that owns Swift and Company, other food and chemical companies and International Playtex Inc.; yesterday made a $177.5 million bid for Inmont Inc., the world's largest producer of printing ink. The Esmark bid was $22.50 a share, or its equivalent in Esmark common stock, for the 7.9 million Inmont shares outstanding. Earlier, before Esmark had made a definite tender offer for Inmont shares, Inmont had sent a letter to Esmark stating that its board had concluded that the acquisition would not be in the best interests of Inmont or its shareholders.

title: Publishing: Kohout And Colette
description: KAFKA LIVES. His character K always seems to be on trial in certain countries where words are considered flammable. Once again, a K is in trouble. This time he is not a fictional character.

title: TREASURY NOTES SET AVERAGE 5.98% RATE
description: The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 5.98 percent, slightly lower than many Government securities dealers predicted on Wednesday as the market for Treasury notes gained some strength

title: Clifford in Athens on Mission for Carter to Resolve Cyprus Problem and Heal GreekTurkish Breach
description: ATHENS, Feb. 17Clark M. Clifford arrived today with an assignment from president Carter to find ways of solving the Cyprus problem and ending tensions between Greece and Turkey, which have disrupted the North Atlantic Treaty Ordanization.

title: Czech Dissidents Urge Government to Release Plague Disputes Times Reporter on His Detention
description: VIENNA, Feb. 17Humanrights activists in Czechoslovakia addressed a letter to the Government today requesting tilt release from prison of four persons arrested last month during a sweeping in quiry into a protest movement that had produced Charter 77, a manifesto de manding broader human freedoms.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: I.R.S. Agent Linked To Gulf Oil Favors
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17A Federal prosecutor charged today that the Internal Revenue Service supervisor who found the Gulf Oil Corporation was not liable for taxes on money it funneled into its political slush fund was rewarded that same day by Gulf for his work.

title: Check Account Plan Loses in House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The House Banking Committee decided today to scrap a measure that would have permitted all savings institutions in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania to offer customers noninterestbearing checking accounts.

title: 100 Feared Drowned in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 17 (AP)About a hundred persons are feared dead in the collision of two motor launches in the Pashur river near Chalna, the Bangladesh press agency said today. More than 300 persons were reported aboard the ferry launch Rokeya when it collided with another launch yesterday. A hundred passengers were rescued and a hundred are beleved to have drowned. Apparently the others swam ashore.

title: CAREY ASKS MONITOR OF CITY HEALTH CARE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Governor Carey proposed today the appointment of a new toplevel administrator with full authority over New York City's entire health care system, including the power to close both voluntary and municipal hospitals.

title: FEARS FUEL UNEASE iN SOUTH PHILIPPINES
description: COTABATO, Philippines, Feb. 16The weight of four years of civil war, 10,000 dead and a half million made homeless, a history of decades of Moslem resentment of the increasing numbers of Christied settlers from other islands in what Moslems consider their ancestral lands, accompanied by many outbursts of violence and communal warfare, lie heavily on the ceasefire in southern Mindanao.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WHEN the teasersthose brief clips designed to grab the audience at the start of a programare dreadfully limp, a new series may be presumed to be in trouble. Tonight's specimen is Hunter, a mysteryadventure series beginning on CBS at 10 o'clock. Several persons in white smocks are looking terribly worried. One asks: Is there anything else we can do? Another responds: Well, somebody might be able to shut off the valve, but its too radioactive in there. The boredom meter trembles ominously.

title: The Poverty Of Power
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The new President of Mexico, Jos Lpez Portillo, and President Carter had a useful and amiable visit here over the last few days, but this first state occasion for both of them is a reminder of the poverty of powerof how little even the most influential politicians can do to relieve the basic problems of two such friendly but different neighboring states.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: AKRONOne of the mostdiscussed projects in business circles in this major industrial city these days is the effort being made by nonenergy companies here and elsewhere in Ohio to find supplies of natural gas on their own or leased properties. The The search has been spurred by the fuel cutbacks of the last few years, especially the traumas related to the harsh winter of 197677.

title: Quebec's New Government, Plagued by the LanguagePolicy Problem, Is Trying to Find the Right Worth
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 16The Quebec Government is trying to develop a language policy under contradictory pressures from those who want Quebec to be an exclusively French nation and those trying to preserve its status as a province within predominantly Englishspeaking Canada.

title: Mexican Chief, in Speech to House, Asks More Sensible U.S. Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)In a speech greeted with nearsilence, President Jos Lpez Portillo of Mexico told the House of Representatives today that the United States must adopt more sensible hemispheric policies and promote a new international economic order.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: People in Sports
description: Sandy Alomar, a utility infielder who batted .239 with one home run in 67 games last season, was traded yesterday by the Yankees to the Texas Rangers for two minor league infielders and an undisclosed amount of dash.

title: How to Afford Less Natural Gas
description: The Carter Administration's energy program won't ready for another two months, but pieces of it are already floating about as trial balloons. The most airworthy concern natural gas, a commodity that in almost everyone's reckoning now is too cheap.

title: R. J. Reynolds Profits Up 17.4% In 4th Quarter and 4.5% in Year
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries Inc., the nation's largest cigarette producer, had a 17.4 percent profit gain in the fourth quarter and a 4.5 percent rise for all of last year, it reported yesterday from WinstonSalem, N.C. Sales and earnings for both periods set records.

title: Met Opera to Increase Its Prices Next Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced that it will raise admission prices for its performances next season. The Increases will average 20 percent on a soldout house, but will not be equal across the board.

title: Management: Picking Those To Go Abroad
description: There is a new look to the Americans being sent abroad to work for multinational companiesnot so much in appearance as in attitudes.

title: Advertising
description: Just like anyone else, an advertiser wnats to know if he's getting what he's paying for. And he wants the assurance from a disinterested party.

title: Flu Epidemic in Japanese Schools
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (AP)More than half a million Japanese schoolchildren came down with influenza last week in an epidemic that has struck nearly 1.4 million since fall, the Health Ministry said today. Nearly 8,000 schools on the islands of Honshu and Kyushu have had to curtail classes.

title: The Uganda Disease
description: Evil politics know no boundaries. Far from the scene of Idi Amin's barbarities against his people, his tyranny has a way of corrupting human sensibility, becoming predictable, habitual, the usual, and blunting the capacity for outrage. Then we are all his victims.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Study Shows Prison Population Rose 13% in 1976 to Set a Record
description: There were 283,268 persons in state and Federal prisons as of Jan. 1, a 13 percent increase over the previous record of 250,042 on Jan. 1, 1976, according to the annual compilation by Corrections magazine.

title: Daytona 500 Trials Taken, By Petty and Yarborough:
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb.17Richard Petty and Cale Yarborough, a pair of Southern gentlemen, won the 125mile qualifying races today for Sunday's Daytona 500, an event that is as chic as cornmeal hush puppies this year. With a President in the White House who just loves stock car racing, as do most Southerners, Daytona International Speedway has more Confederate flags flying than usual.

title: Gulf to Build Coke Plant
description: The Gulf Trading and Transportation Company of Pittsburgh, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation announced that it would construct its first petroleum coke calcining plant. H. I. Goodman, president, said that the 400,000tonayear plant would be at Lake Charles, La. Full operation is expected in mid1978. The cost of the unit was not disclosed. Calcined petroleum coke is used in the manufacture of metals.

title: Money
description: Thursday, February 17, 1977

title: PAYMENTS BY C.I.A. TO HUSSEIN CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Senate Intelligence Committee will look into allegations that the Central Intelligence Agency for 20 years has made secret annual payments totaling millions of dollars to King Hussein of Jordan, a committee spokesman said tonight.

title: Southeast to See Rocket Test
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP)The United States Air Force has scheduled a highaltitude rocket test for Tuesday that will create a multicolored cloud that may be visible throughout the Southeast. A similar test Dec. 1 created a colored cloud that was visible as far away as Tennessee.

title: Cold in January Slowed Growth of Personal Income
description: The growth of personal income slowed last month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, as cold weather continued to depress the nation's economic barometers. Some of the slower growth in personal income, however, had to do with other factors than the weather.

title: Saturday
description: BUFFALO IN BROOKLYN

title: Kissinger Signs With NBCTV For News Programs for 5 Years
description: Henry A. Kissinger will be on television for at least the next five years.

title: F.D.A. To Hear Testimony On Cancer Drug Laetrile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration, acting under a Federal court order, announced today that it would listen to public testimony about Laetrile, the controversial cancer drug.

title: Friday
description: CENTRAL PARK SHEIKS

title: Wilson Plastics Price Up
description: The Ralph Wilson Plastics Company of Temple, Tex., a division of Dart Industries, said that it was increasing prices for all decorative laminated products by about 7 percent, effective March 1 because of higher material, utility and labor costs. Decorative laminates are used for interior surfacing of walls, doors, furniture, cabinets and counter tops.

title: Death of Archbishop Held by Amin Brings Demands for Investigations
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 17Demands mounted today for international inquiries into the death of the Anglican Archbishop of Uganda, as Government spokesmen in Kampala insisted that the churchman and two Government ministers were killed in an automobile accident yesterday just after they had been arrested on charges of plotting to overthrow the Government of President Idi Amin.

title: PRESIDENT CANCELS ISRAELI BOMB SALE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  President Carter has canceled the sale of concussion bombs to Israel, the White House announced today.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: A Bazaar by 49 Pupils Benefits Neediest Cases and 2 Centers for Elderly
description: SADDLE BROOK, N. J Feb.17For the 49 youngsters in the fifth grade at the Salome H. Long Memorial School in this Bergen County community, today was a day for special learning. It was a clay for learning about caring and sharing and salesmanship, about adding and substractingbut especially it was a day for helping others

title: SADAT SUGGESTS LINK OF P.L.O. AND JORDAN BEFORE PEACE TALK
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, in a proposal aimed at breaking the diplomatic impasse in the Middle East, said tonight that the Palestinians should form an official and declared link with Jordan even before a Geneva peace conference is reconvened.

title: Vote for Bergland Seat First Test Of Party Strength Since Nov. 2
description: MOORHEAD, Minn., Feb. 17The first test of strength between the Democratic and Republican parties since President Carter's election last November will take place in Minnesota's Seventh Congressional District Tuesday.

title: Antiques
description: THE 33D ANNUAL National Antiques Show which opens tomorrow for a nineday run at Madison Square Garden, will be, as usual, a curiosityfilled bazaar offering the wares of 275 dealers and at least one exhibition of an extraordinary private collection.

title: 16 Artists Put All of Their Craft Into 60 Baskets
description: Basket weaving has become in the last few years a serious mode for creative expression, calling on the talents of established fiber artists and metalsmiths, as well as traditional basket makers. And one of the best shows ever assembled locally on the subject has opened at the Florence Duhl Gallery, 31 West 54th Street.

title: Saigon Prelate Reported Arrested
description: ROME, Feb. 17 (UPI)The coadjutor bishop of Saigon has been arrested by Communist authorities, a Vatican spokesman said today. Msgr. Romeo Panciroli made the statement in denying what he said were published reports that Archbishop Franois Xavier Nguyen Van Thuan was dead.

title: Northville Oil Terminal Authorized by Panama
description: Northville Industries, a large independent marketer and storage company of oil on the North Shore of Long Island, said yesterday that it had been authorized by the Government of Panama to establish a supertanker transshipment terminal on Panama's Pacific Coast.

title: Carter Drops Proposals to Open Cabinet Meetings to Reporters
