description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  President Carter rescinded today an earlier decision to open the meetings of his Cabinet to press coverage, saying that its members were almost unanimously opposed.

title: Bitter Oranges, a Scent of Spring
description: Bitter oranges, among the city's more obscure harbingers of spring, have just made their annual debut at Martin's Gift Basket Shop, 1264 Third Avenue between 72d and 73d Streets.

title: Cash Wins Over Paper as Racal Acquires Control of Milgo
description: In one of the most hotly contested acquisition battles in corporate history, Racal Electronics Ltd. apparently won control yesterday of the Milgo Electronic Corporation in a downtothewire race against Applied Digital Data Systems.

title: APeg For All Our Hearts
description: There are plays that are eternal classics, others that are hardy perennials and others that show up, like Halley's Comet, at long intervals. The third category of this profundity probably covers Peg O' My Heart, the drama that is unfolding weekends at the Lion Theater Company's small theater at 422 West 42d Street.

title: Democrat Seeking Nomination for Nassau Executive
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., Feb. 17Assemblyman Lewis J. Yevoli of Old Bethpage today became the first Democrat to announce formally that he would seek his party's nomination for Nassau County Executive.

title: Texas Railroad Commission Urges AllOut Oil Production in March
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17 (AP)The Texas Railroad Commission urged oilmen today to resume allout production in March, with Jon Newton, the new commissioner pledging that the regulatory agency would not play politics with the present energy crisis.

title: New York City Antiloitering Statute Is Upheld by Appellate Court Panel
description: A controversial New York State antiloitering statute enacted last summer to curb prostitution was upheld yesterday in an appellate court decision, overturning a Manhattan Criminal Court judge's ruling that the statute was unconstitutional.

title: Art People
description: RBUCKMINSTER FULLER, architect, engineer, mathematician, poet, philosopher and Ell father of the geodesic dome, has joined forces with Goldylocksor maybe it's the other way around. Their collaboration has resulted in Tetrascroll, a book of original lithographic drawings with text printed on 26 attached equilateral triangles.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Even Cauthen's Losses Entice Bettors
description: A $2 horseplayer doubling his bet on Steve Cauthen every time the 16yearold apprentice jockey rides a loser would have to wager $2,048 after only a 10race losing streak, For the $10 player using a simple doublingup system of progression betting, a 10race slump would mean a wager of $26,880 on the next mount Cauthen rode. Despite the hazards of such systems, it appears that at least some New York horseplayers are using progression betting as they follow racing's hottest celebrity.

title: Catch the Subway of the Future
description: Real New York subway riders rarely miss a chance to ride one of the new subways that have opened in the last decade or so in places like Montreal, San Francisco and Mexico City. And while they may scoff at the limited routes or curtailed hours of the new systems, they usually come away impressed, at least by the look of them.

title: Cash Price Up 5c On Colombia Coffee In Futures Trading
description: The cash price for Colombian coffee rose 5 cents to $2.47 a pound yesterday and the nearest futures delivery on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange followed suit.

title: Indonesia Settles Legal Disputes On Tanker Charter With 2 Lines
description: The Indonesian Government announced that it had settled legal disputes over tanker charters with two shipping companies  the National Shipping and Trading Corporation of New York and the Fair Ocean Trading Company of Hong Kong.

title: Young Cites Savage Incidents
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 Andrew Young, the United States representative at the United Nations, deplored yesterday suspicious deaths in both Uganda and in South Africa as savage incidents that make us all ashamed.

title: Lopez Portillo Promises Aid for Tourists in Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Jos Lpez Portillo of Mexico told officials of the American Automobile Association last night that his country would take steps in the next two weeks to assure the security of American tourists, the association said today.

title: Japan Shows Payments Deficit
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Japan's overall balance of payments slumped to an $850 million deficit in January, compared with a $464 million surplus in December, but Finance Ministry officials said today the downturn had been expected because of seasonal factors.

title: Zukerman Minds His Music
description: Pinchas Zukerman, the celebrated young violin virtuoso, says he has been practicing several months for his only New York recital of the seasonat Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoonbut it's not the kind of playing likely to waken neighbors.

title: Topics
description: In Maine, a $600 million hydroelectric project is being held up by the discovery in the affected area of a rare and nottoofragrant plant called the furbish lousewort. In Tennessee. the T.V.A. has been enjoined against finishing a nearly completed dam which appears to threaten an equally rare fish, the threeinch snail darter. And in California efforts are being made to sequester a few acres of land belonging to the Los Angeles International Airport, among others, to protect the habitat of some endangered species of butterfly.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday. Feb. 17, 1977

title: JEWISH UNIT MAILS REPORT OF ARABBOYCOTT EASING
description: The American Jewish Congress yesterday hailed a report by the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry that Iraq, Kuwait, Libya and Saudi Arabia had eased the Arab economic boycott of Israel by no longer requiring that negative certificates of origin be shipped with goods from the United States.

title: St. Peter's 99, Monmouth 98
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 17Paul Siljee's running 30foot jump shot at the buzzer tonight gave St. Peter's a 9998 victory over Monmouth in overtime.

title: Bumbling on Busing
description: Obfuscating the law of the land and gratuitously suggesting that a Supreme Court minority really had expressed the will of the majority, Attorney General Griffin Bell gave some unsurprising glimpses last week into his laggard position on school desegregation. Less expectable was his sloppy performance as a lawyer.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Tobacco Trade Group Is Indicted On U.S. Charge of Fixing Prices
description: A tobacco trade association was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a Federal charge of conspiracy to fix wholesale cigarette prices amounting to hundreds of millions of dollars in New York City.

title: CHILDREN'S CENTER TO CLOSE IN MARCH
description: The Children's Center, a violenceplagued institution that has been the target of criticism and official investigations for years, will be closed on March 15, a spokesman for J. Henry Smith, the New York City Human Resources Administrator, announced yesterday.

title: Russi Tops Ski Drill
description: LAAX. Switzerland, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Bernhard Russi of Switzerland and Peter Wirnsperger of Austria clocked today's fastest practice times for a World Ski Cup downhill race. Russi set a time of 2 minutes 04.46 seconds for the 3,600meter (about 2.2 miles course with its vertical drop of 1,000 meters (3,280 feet). Wirnsperger clocked 2:04.77.

title: SCHOOL MEDITATION ADVANCES IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17The Assembly passed today a bill to require publicschool teachers to conduct a brief period of solemn meditation with the participation of all the pupils at the beginning of each school day.

title: Ten Games Approved in Ivy Football
description: Ivy League football teams were granted permission to play 10 games during certain future seasons as the eight Ivy presidents voted to lift the longstanding restriction of nine games at a meeting in New York City on Wednesday.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Declines 1.2%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.9 billion tonmiles, off 1.2 percent from the yearearlier level.

title: Stage: A Cherry Orchard That Celebrates Genius
description: To stage a classic is an easy thing but to restore that classic to the hands, mind and blood of its creator is in itself an act of creativity. And that is precisely what Andrei Serban and his team of collaborators and clowns have done with their production of Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, which opened last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. It is a celebration of genius, like the cleaning of a great painting, a fresh exposition of an old philosophy.

title: Congress and Carter: An Uneasy Adjustment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17At a dinner in his honor last night at the City Tavern in Georgetown, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. put his finger on a problem that is bothering Congress and could be troublesome for the Carter White House in the months to come. In a characteristically rambling and humorous discourse on the House of Representatives, the Massachusetts Democrat warned that if President Carter tried to go over the heads of Congress to appeal for support from the public in some confrontation with Capitol Hill, That would he a glaring mistake.

title: High Tides Around New York
Restaurant Concern Admits Kickbacks, S. L. A. Declares
description: Restaurant Associates, which operates Mama Leone's, The Brasserie and several other eating places in New York City, has admitted taking $250,000 in kickbacks from liquor, wine and beer makers and wholesalers as inducements to buy their products, the State Liquor Authority said yesterday.

title: Television
F.B.I. Nominating Panel Named
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)President Carter announced today that he has asked nine persons to serve on a commission to choose a new Federal Bureau of Investigation director, including its current Director, Clarence M. Kelley; Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, and Erving Shapiro, chairman of the Du Pont Company.

title: Books of the Times
description: One of the reasons writers write is because they write better than they talk, or at least they think they do. Photographic portraits of film directors even when the pictures are full of dramatic contrasts of light, have a stinging kind of focus and express an obvious affectionare much like oral interviews wih authors. They show us the person, all right, and sometimes they show us how he would like us to see him (which is of some interest, I suppose, though not a lot), but they tell us very little about the man inside and nothing about his work. Film directors wouldn't be what they are if they weren't capable of a certain amount of dissembling.

title: Notre Dame, Lafayette Fives Win
description: The Jaspers of Manhattan, ceding three or four inches a man to the huskier Notre Dame team, took the favored Irish down to the wire last night at Madison Square Garden before losing, 8076.

title: Music: Elliott Carter
description: One of the fruits of the Bicentennial fell into the laps of the New York Philharmonic audience last night. It was the world premiere of Elliott Carter's A Symphony of Three Orchestras. The score had been commissioned by the Philharmonic from the National Endowment for the Arts as part of the Bicentennial observances.

title: In Ashes A Star Rises Out of Pain
description: As a member of the original Broadway cast of Equus, Roberta Maxwell played a love scene in the nude, night after night for 10 months. But the petite, darkhaired actress says she has never felt more exposed, more naked to the eyes of the world, than she does in her role in Ashes, which is a weekend favorite at the Public Theater. In David Rudkin's bitterly humorous drama about a childless couple's desperate efforts to have a baby, Miss Maxwell has been warmly praised for her tough but tender portrait of the wife, a woman whose love is tested by humiliation, pain and, finally, the terror of emptiness.

title: Moscow Declares It Can Match Any New Weapon Developed by U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, said today that attempts by the United States to achieve military superiority were pointless because Moscow could match any new weapons.

title: Fashion Gurus Bundle Up, Putting Warmth Before Chic
description: Does it make you feel better to know that the gurus of fashion are human?

title: For Children
description: Films

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: BEAME'S M,A,C, PLAN STIRS AN UNEASINESS
description: Bankers and the leaders of municipal unions expressed reservations yesterday about Mayor Beame's new proposal to restore investor confidence in New York City finances by giving new powers to the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state agency.

title: Cooking With Intermedia
description: Matt Turney, once one of Martha Graham's leading dancers, and Elaine Summers, an avantgarde choreographer concerned with integrating film and dance, will join forces this weekend at the Kitchen, the performance space at 484 Broome Street.

title: Bad Teeth a Burglar's Undoing
description: No one seems to have seen him do it, but early last Monday afternoon, a daring burglar apparently swung out from a 31stfloor terrace of a luxury apartment building high above the traffic on East 58th Street and dropped to the terrace of the apartment below.

title: Uganda Says Autopsy Confirms Report on Archbishop's Death in Auto
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 18The Uganda radio said today that autopsies proved the country's Anglican Archbishop and two Cabinet ministers had died in an auto accident as the Government had originally announced.

title: Mrs. Abzug Confirms Talk With Carter on F.T.C. Job
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Bella Abzug confirmed today that she talked about a job on the Federal Trade Commission when she net with President Carter at the White House Monday. She said that she would make up her mind on several options open to her within the next few weeks.

title: Carter Hints at Curb On WarRoom Jets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)President Carter, apparently dismayed by the cost, has told the Pentagon in effect that it should not buy any more $117 million emergency command post planes like the one he flew in last week.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.8% FOR JANUARY, HIGHEST IN 18 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Fed. 18Cold weather, and the resulting higher prices of food and fuel last month, contributed to the sharpest rise in consumer prices in 18 months, the Government reported today.

title: Needy American Women, Waiting for Equity
description: Sarah Jones (fictitious, but typical) may not be one of the neediest cases, but she's not much better off than some. She works full time as a clerktypist, earning $6,760 a year. She's divorced and gets $1,200 a year in child support. She thinks of herself as needing to manage on her own, and capable of it. She works, keeps house, shops and takes care of her children, Jimmy, 8, and Mary, 3.

title: Two Skyscrapers Damaged by Bombs In MidManhattan
description: Two powerful bomb explosions extensively damaged the Chrysler and Gulf & Western Buildings in midtown Manhattan late last night. The police said one minor injury was reported.

title: Automatic Transmission Has Ratio of 5 Speeds
description: A senior staff engineer for the Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, Mich., was granted a patent this week for a fivespeed automatic transmission. Charles C. Bookout assigned Patent 4,007,648 to the company, which has indicated that there are no present plans for manufacture.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Wagner's r'Dle walkuere,??;poulenc'Dlalogues of the Carmelites, 8.

title: EXREP. RALPH BEERMANN
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 18Former Representative Ralph Beermann, 64 years old, of Dakota City, Neb., was killed last night when the small airplane he was landing at the Sioux City, Iowa, airport crashed short of the runway, apparently after striking a pole.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED ON HEALTH MONITOR
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Top aides to Governor, Carey and Mayor Beame reached what they called conceptual agreement today on a Carey proposal for a new toplevel administrator to run the city's health care system

title: Defendant Cuts Throat in Court
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Feb. 18 (AP)The judge was about to impose a 5to50 year sentence on a convicted burglar when the defendant pulled a doubleedged razor from his prison uniform and slit his throat. Jimmy Robinson, 33 years old, was reported in stable condition at a hospital here following the incident Wednesday.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Feb. 18, 1977

title: Recital: Wolf on the Harpsichord
description: The late Edwin Fischer, whose playing of Bach was once considered by many to be the last word in Baroque performance practice, once declared that anyone who played Bach with expression did not understand him. Fischer meant, no doubt, expression as the 19thcentury musician conveyed it, and his statement therefore has some validity in the decades when Bach's works were being stripped of the Romantic veneer that they had acquired in the time of Busoni, Schumann and Brahms.

title: Martin Marietta Layoff
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said that a subsidiary, Martin Marietta Aluminum, had laid off 60 workers, or 5 percent of its work force, because of hydropower shortages resulting from the drought in the Northwest. The cutback follows similar action by other aluminum producers in the region.

title: Virginians Giving Up Land To Save It From Strip Mines
description: LOUISA, Va.Fighting the industrialization of this rolling former plantation country, the notsogentle gentlefolk of Louisa County are covering the conservation battlefield here with environmental landmarks.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18The New Jersey Council of Churches called on Governor Byrne today to restore to the budget $3.2 million requested by the Violent Crime Compensation Board, which has a growing backlog of cases.

title: Treasury Bill Yields UP in 3 and 6 Months
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned yesterday in Washington in both the 91day anti 180day maturities.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.8% FOR JANUARY, HIGHEST IN 18 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Cold weather, and the resulting higher prices of food and fuel last month, contributed to the sharpest rise in consumer prices in 18 months, the Government reported today.

title: Vietnam Releases 1,000 Prisoners
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 18 (UPI)Vietnam has set free more than 1,000 prisoners who worked for the United States and Americanbacked governments in South Vietnam during the war, the official Vietnam News Agency announced today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: SOME LATIN NATIONS UNEASY ON U.S, TIES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18  President Carter's insistence on worldwide respect for human rights has made Latin America's most repressive military regimes uneasy about their future relations with the United States.

title: Construction Picketing Bill Fought
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)The National Right to Work Committee said Thursday that it had commitments from 45 senators and 198 House members to oppose a new legislative move to expand picketing rights for construction unions. The list was released a day after Representative Frank Thompson, Democrat of New Jersey, introduced a bill that would permit unions to picket an entire construction site, even though their dispute was with one contractor.

title: Unions and Industry Oppose Bill to Ban 16 Chemicals Found CancerProducing
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18A bill that would ban the production and use in New Jersey of 16 chemicals identified as carcinogenic, or cancerproducing, encountered opposition today from organized labor and industry, whose spokesmen said that such legistation would be disastrous to the state's economy.

title: Suffolk Presses U.S. To Reconsider Sale Of Ocean Oil Leases
description: John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, is pressing the Interior Department in Washington to reconsider the planned sale of oil and gas drilling rights off Massachusetts in the light of a Federal judge's ruling Thursday that voided last year's sale of such leases off New Jersey.

title: Three Seats Sold by Amex
description: The American Stock Exchange reported the sale of three membership seats yesterday. The first sold for $49,000, unchanged from the prior sale on Feb. 2, the second sold for $52,000 and the third seat sold for $52,000. Seats on the Amex are now quoted at $35,000 bid and $54,000 ask.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TWO'S COMPANYPaul Ableman's enigmatic theater piece, Green Julia, drew a staunch following when the twocharacter play, which opened in England in 1965, arrived here five years ago at the Sheridan Square Playhouse in Greenwich Village.

title: Pennsylvanian Dies in Blaze
description: ABINGTON, Pa., Feb. 18 (AP)A fivealarm apartment fire claimed the life of at least one person and left several others injured today. The fire occurred in a multistory, 52unit building at the Berrell Manor Apartments on Davisville Road. The police said that the cause of the fire was unknown.

title: U .S. Tries to Minimize the Impact Of Report on C.I.A. Aid to Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Carter Administration sought today to minimize the possible impact on its Middle East diplomatic efforts of published reports that the Central Intelligence Agency had made secret payments to Jordan's King Hussein for 20 years.

title: Dayton Names Whittlesey
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP)Tony Whittlesey, former head football coach at Bluffton College, was named today as an assistant at the University of Dayton. The 29yearold Whittlesey was at Bluffton for a year and posted a 531 wonlosttied mark. He will coordinate the offensive unit at Dayton.

title: People in Sports
description: Derek Sanderson, the flamboyant center waived through the National Hockey League and sent to the minors by the St. Louis Blues, has been acquired by the Vancouver Canucks, The 30yearold Sanderson, who has played in 545 N.H.L. games, was expected to be in the Canucks lineup last night in Vancouver against the Atlanta Flames. Following talks with the Blues general manager Emile Francis, Vancouver has assumed Sanderson's N.H.L. contract.

title: Greek Communications Struck
description: ATHENS, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Greece's communications with the outside world were sharply curtailed today by a 24hour strike of 25,000 workers. A skeleton staff will operate essential services and receive distress messages from ships, a union spokesman said.

title: Rights Request in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb 18The Carter Administration today called on the United Nations Human Rights Commission to ask Moscow for information about the fate of dissidents who have been reported arrested and detained. The United States submitted the draft of a telegram that it wants the 32nation commission to send to the Soviet Government.

title: Brown Upsets Columbia Five
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 18 (AP)Brian Saunders scored a careerhigh 39 points tonight and Brown snapped a sixgame losing streak with a 9183 Ivy League basketball upset of Columbia.

title: Treasurer of M.A.C. Getting a H.U.D. Post
description: Donna E. Shalala, treasurer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, is expected to be nominated as an assistant secretary for the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, it was learned yesterday.

title: Garelik Redeploys 108 Policemen in Subways to Curb a Rise in Crime
description: Under direct orders from Harold L. Fisher, acting chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's police chief, Sanford D. Garelik, yesterday redeployed 108 additional policemen to train and station patrols to help curb a recent upsurge in subway crime.

title: Television
description: 6:30 (2)Sunrise Semester (4)A Better Way (5)Patterns for Living (7)News

title: A majestic, Anachronistic Viennese Ball
description: VIENNA, Feb. 18For Christa Waldhelm, younger daughter of the United Nations Secretary General, it was a comingout party so Old World as to seem anachronistic.

title: Cigarette Lighter Rings Bell When Hot
description: William Draghi of Jackson Heights, Queens, has patented an automotive cigarette lighter that rings a bell when it is hot enough. He says that other pushpull lighters, by staying silent, often let the smoker forget to pull them out of the dashboard and ignite the tobacco.

title: Two Die in Nursing Home Fire
description: ZION, Ill., Feb. 18 (UPI)Two persons were killed and nine others, including two firemen, were injured late last night in a fire at the Zion Nursing Home. The dead were identified as Phillip Hoffman, 88 years old, of Bloomington, and Estelle Wallen, 68, of Justice.

title: Reliance Electric Backs Acquisition of Reliable
description: The Reliance Electric Company announced in Cleveland that its board had approved the acquisition of the Reliable Electric Company of Franklin Park, Ill., for 1.59 million shares of Reliance's common stock valued at about $48 million.

title: Screen: A Homicidal Maniac
description: "The Town That Dreaded Sundown" is about a homicidal maniac who terrorized Texarkana, Ark., during the spring and summer of 1946. If, as the off-screen narrator tells us, the facts are true (only the names have been changed), then the phantom killer was actually a pair of unidentified male feet.Charles B. Pierce, the director and producer, shows us those feet, from the trouser cuffs down, when he isn't showing us a couple of police cars screeching around corners at 25 miles an hour, or an atrocity being committed by the killer, who loved to lurk around lovers' lane.A couple of professional actors, Ben Johnson and Andrew Prine, head the cast, but the film looks nonprofessional in evey other respect. It opened yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters.

title: QUEBEC CLOTH MILLS FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 18One of Quebec's biggest knitting mills is about to close down, another was temporarily saved from closing by lastminute Government help, while a major company making household linens has begun to lay off workers.

title: Dr. Thomas N. Sheen Dead at 75; Headed Tuberculosis Association
description: He graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1921, and got his medical degree at the University of Louvain in Belgium in 1927. He also studied medicine in Paris and Vienna.

title: 70 Tons of Toxic Chemical Found In Ohio River; Drinking Risk Cited
description: CINCINNATI,Feb. 18 (AP)About 70 tons of a toxic cleaning fluid, carbon tetrachloride, flowed into the Ohio River from West Virginia's Kanawha River today, contaminating drinking water downstream.

title: ABC Stresses Miss Walters Will Stay On
description: The president of ABC television attempted yesterday to quell the gossip about Barbara Walters's career at his network.

title: Letters: On Energy Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Agency Upholds Inquiry By F.B.I. Into Murder of Dr. King
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 18A major review by the Justice Department has concluded that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was thoroughly, honestly and successfully conducted, and that the best available evidence suggests that James Earl Ray, the convicted murderer, acted alone.

title: Stock Specialist's Role Defended As MarriageMaker in Trading
description: When you're trading, so many things enter into it, said Robert J. Fraiman as he tried to convey what it's like for a specialist on the busy floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Fiji Parliament's Term Ends
description: SUVA, Fiji, Feb. 18 (AP)Governor General Sir George Cakobaq dissolved the Fiji Parliament today at the end of its fiveyear term in preparation for general elections March 19April 2.

title: Women Holding Festival Of Experimental Movies
description: The 1977 Festival of ExperimentalPersonal Films by Women, coordinated by Sylvianna Goldsmith, has opened at the Women's Interart Center, 549 West 52d Street, and will run through Feb. 27. A crosssection of films by 26 leading women experimental film makers, including Storm deHirsch and Chick Strand, will be shown.

title: Mistreated Land, Waiting for Reform
description: PENINSULA. OhioIn northeastern Ohio, amid striking examples of the shameful, destructive acts Americans often commit against their environment, a grand experiment in conservation is taking place: In the pleasant but unspectacular Cuyahoga River valley, a national park is being constructed.

title: Justice Agency Upholds Inquiry By F.B.I.Into Murder of Dr. King
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 18A major review by the Justice Department has concluded that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, was thoroughly, honestly and successfully conducted, and that the best available evidence suggests that James Earl Ray, the convicted murderer, acted alone.

title: Exchanges Threatened by Black Box Era
description: Two longvital New York institu tions, the New York and the American Stock Exchanges, face uncertainty and change, with their very existences at stake as the Securities and Exchange Commission seeks to carry out its mandate to set up a national market for trading securities.

title: Aztec Sacrifices Laid to Hunger, Not Just Religion
description: Above, Dr. Michael Harner. Right, a depiction of human sacrifice practiced by the Aztecs. Above left, the royal city of Tenochtitlan, showing pyramids and, at far right, the rack estimated by Spaniards to have held 136,000 skulls.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: 3 Sentenced in Beating of Woman; Merola Hails Persistent Detective
description: Three reputed members of a Bronx youth gang were sentenced to jail yesterday for the severe beating of a 20yearold woman who rebuffed the sexual advances of another gang member.

title: H .U .D .Plans to Aid Poorest Cities, Revising Community Aid Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Carter Administration disclosed today that it planned to overhaul the Government's main program for battling urban blight by channeling more money into the poorest and neediest cities.

title: Two Classics Are Presented By City Ballet
description: Two of the brilliantly murkier works in the New York City Ballet's active repertory are Serenade and La Sonnambula, but their surface sheen is so glistening that one rarely probes into their studied ambiguity. They are both poetic, celebrating classic dance and its realization in one case, and obsessional emotion with Gothic overtones in the other. They appeared together Thursday evening at the New York State Theater.

title: ExLottery Chief Says He Fought Milgram Operation
description: A former director of the New York State Lottery, Jerry Bruno, told a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday that he had tried to break up the lottery vendingmachine operations of Arthur Milgram, who was slain in gangland style in Queens last week.

title: Tax Official Accepted Gulf Oil Gifts
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18The Internal Revenue Service supervisor who handled Gulf Oil Corporation tax audits admitted accepting hundreds of gratuities and gifts from Gulf, including five trips for himself and his family, an I.R.S. criminal investigator testified today.

title: Volkswagen Is Weighing Taxi Version of Rabbit
description: Volkswagen's North American manufacturing subsidiary has held informal discussions about building a taxicab version of its Rabbit car here, a Volkswagen spokesman said yesterday.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: PHONE UNION TO PUSH WOMAN JOB DEMANDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Communications Workers of America said today that upgrading the status and wages of jobs traditionally considered to he women's work in the telephone industry would be be a major demand in its forthcoming contract negotiations with the Bell System.

title: Loser in Steel Union Vote Files Election Protest
description: Ed Sadlowski, who was apparently defeated in his bid for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America last week by a margin of nearly 3 to 2, filed a protest with the union in Pittsburgh yesterday seeking to overturn the election.

title: Acquittal Is Returned In a Subway Slaying
description: A 21yearold Brooklyn man who last year allegedly shot and killed a subwaytrain rider in a dispute over a seat before dozens of witnesses was acquitted of seconddegree murder yesterday by a state Supreme Court jury in Manhattan that concluded an intenttokill was not proved.

title: Jacques Tati and His Movies Return After Enforced Vacation
description: PARISJacques Tati, the inventor of Mr. Hulot, who has been on an enforced holiday for most of the last eight years, says he is going back to work.

title: Players Give the Barons Owner Ultimatum and Tuesday Deadline
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP) The Cleveland Barons hockey players today told the club's majority owner, Mel Swig, that he had till Tuesday noon either to pay their overdue salaries or to commit himself to sell the financially encumbered National Hockey League franchise. If he does not comply, they said, they will stop playing and will be free agents.

title: SADAT DECLARATION IS LAUDED BY VANCE
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that President Anwar elSadat's latest proposal for a PalestinianJordanian link had narrowed the gap between Israel and the Arab states for negotiations at Geneva. He added, however, that major differences remained.

title: Rita Shane Enters Prophete at the Met
description: Rita Shane came into the cast of Meyerbeer's Le Prophte in the performance given by the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night. She took over the demanding role of Berthe, previously filled by Renata Scotto.

title: Deaths
description: GRACEWilliam J. MD. The administration. faculty and students of New York Medical College record with doep. sorrow the death of William J. Grace, MD. Professor of Medicine and father of Christopher J. Grace. a member of the class of 1979. We extend our sincere sympathy to all the family.

title: 3 Pakistan Political Workers Shot to Death in Campaigning
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Three people were shot to death as Pakistan's general election campaign took a violent turn, newspapers reported today.

title: Cauthen Sets a Record With 105 Meet Winners
description: Surfers have their endless summers, and Steve Cauthen has his endles winter.

title: Crosland Dies at 58
description: LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland died in a hospital early today, the Foreign Office announced. He was 58 years old.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post postions Letter designates OTB listing

title: The Cast

Jim Roberson; editor, Tom Boutross; music, Jaime MendozaNava; distributed by American International Pictures. Running time: 90 minutes. At the Cinerama 2, Broadway at 47th Street. and other theatres. This film has been rated R.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA New York chiropractor has begun raising lobsters from their postlarval state, when they are about a half inch long, to a marketable size of six inches or more and a marketable weight of one or two pounds.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The Harlem Globetrotters winning all the time is not a fix, Meadowlark Lemon was saying. Nobody gives me anything. I tell those guys on the New Jersey Reds, Any time you block any of my shots, you got a steak dinner in any restaurant you choose.

title: Bucks Rally Wins
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 18The Knicks misery on the road got worse here tonight, if that's possible.

title: Contract Murder Suspect Sought
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18(UPI)The Miami police have issued an arrest warrant for a suspect in what is believed to have been the contract murder of a Bay of Pigs veteran, Alberto Pico, who was shot and killed at a shopping plaza last month. The warrant named a convicted drug dealer, Francisco Marizal, 46 years old, who the police said had been pointed out by sources in the Cuban community.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: San Francisco Ballet Has a Style All of Its Own
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The San Francisco Ballet is the oldest extant classic ballet company in the United States, having been originally formed by William Christensen in 1937. William's brother, Lew Christensen, became director of the company in 1951 and in 1973 he was joined by Michael Smuin as associate director. Today both Lew Christensen and Michael Smuin, his former pupil, are named as joint directors.

title: About New York
description: By week's end, with most public attention waning, three researchers in antiSemitic extremism could relax and agree among themselves that some time not too far in the future another frustrated man with the now tiresomely familiar loner's profile would turn to a gun for power and kill people with random vengeance.

title: Mrs. Chesimard Bids U.S. Court Bar Trial Sessions on Her Sabbath
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18Lawyers for Joanne Chesimard urged a Federal 10judge panel today to order a New Jersey court not to hold sessions in her murder trial on Fridays.

title: Deaths
description: OREMLANDRichard. Beloved husband of of Candy. Cherished son of Dr.Benlamin and the lale Peuline. Dear brother of Louise Kane. Services at the Bouleyard Chaoels, 1901 Flatbush Avenue, corner or Avenue L. Brooklyn, Sunday at 9:30 A.M.

title: New York City Found Holding Up Despite Cutbacks
description: The Beame administration yesterday released a generally optimistic management report that said that despite severe budgetary and personnel cutbacks in recent months New York City was holding its own in providing essential municipal services to residents.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Friday, February 18, 1977

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Miss Williams at Bottom Line
description: Deniece Williams, who performed Thursday evening, at the Bottom Line, possesses a remarkably affecting and wideranging voice. Her very, very high register reminds one of Minnie Ripperton, and Miss Williams encourages the comparison by performing Miss Ripperton's Loving You. But while Miss Ripperton uses her extra octaves almost as a separate instrument, Miss Williams has integrated her entire range into a naturalsounding approach. She also programs vocal timbres intelligently moving from a pure soprano to a robust midrange to a low gospel moan in accordance with the demands of her material.

title: GANG STABS AND BEATS WOMAN, 60, ON SUBWAY
description: Eight teenagers who were identified as members of the Devil Rebels Gang, a Brooklyn youth gang, stabbed and beat at 60yearold woman as she was returning home on the subway last night from her job. She was admitted to Lutheran Hospital and her condition was not made known.

title: Jail Terms Reduced For Paper Officers
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP)Jail sentences imposed on 14 executives of paper box manufacturing companies who pleaded no contest to Federal pricefixing charges have been reduced by t Federal judge.

title: Money
description: Friday, February 18, 1977

title: AREA PRICE INDEX UP 0.8% IN JANUARY
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose eighttenths of 1 percent last month as a result of price increases for certain foods, energy, homeowner property taxes, medical care and auto registration fees. The rise was the same as the increase nationwide.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of past positions

title: Deaths
description: SHEENDr. Thomas N., died Feb. 15, 1977, after a lone illness. He leaves his wife, the former Elteen Halley and three daughters, Elteen Khauw of peterboro, N.H., Marle Minnick of Mill Neck and Anne Sheen of Lexington, Kr., and two brothers, Bisehop Fulton J. Sheen of New York and At B. Sheen of Clearwater, Fla. A private, funeral mass was held at Holy Trinity Church. In lleu of flowers please send donations to Holy Trinity Church, or the Southampton Hospital Building Fund.

description: PERTMANIsiuore. Beloved husband of Louise, ?????????????????? and ??????.Dear mother of Fanny ?????? and loving grandmother of ????? and ???????. Services Sunday, 12:00 noon at The Riverside, ???? Central Ave???, ??? ????????? , Queens.

title: Schools in Costly Custody
description: Historians of New York City affairs recollect, vaguely, that they first encountered dismay over the financial arrangements for school custodians a quarter century ago. A school management survey raised questions about the wisdom of treating the custodians as independent contractors, virtually without supervision by the Board of Education and with virtually total discretion over the spending of custodial funds; that is, they were found free to pocket all maintenance monies not actually spent on their buildings.

title: CASINO PLAN DRAFTED FOR NEW YORK STATE
description: In a move to head off potential tourist dollar losses to New Jersey, the State Department of Commerce is drafting legislation to remove the constitutional ban on casino gambling in New York.

title: Monsanto Closes Plastic Bottle Units Over F.D.A. Report
description: The Monsanto Company shut down yesterday three plants that manufacture plastic bottles as welt as a Lopac resin production unit at Springfield, Mass, E. A. Bauer, executive vice president of Monsanto, said the closings were because of uncertainties created by a recent Food and Drug Administration statement on plastic bottles.

title: Notes on People
description: President Carter formally nominated Max Cleland yesterday to be administrator of veterans affairs and Samuel W. Brown Jr. to be director of ACTION, the volunteer Federal service agency. Both nominations had been forecast. Mr. Cleland, a 34yearold former Georgia State Senator, is a triple amputee veteran of Vietnam. He is on the staff of the Senate Committee on Veterans Affairs. His salary will be $44,600 plus the Federal pay raise that goes into effect tonight. Mr. Brown, 33, came to prominence as an antiwar activist in the 1960's, and is the Treasurer of Colorado, an elective post. His salary will be $42,000 plus the new pay raise.

title: Anne B. Galvin Wed to Lawyer
description: St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Bartley Galvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Thaddeus Galvin Jr., to Robert Flinn Ottaway, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Palmer Ottaway. Both families are of Grosse Pointe Farms.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: ECONOMY'S GROWTH IN FOURTH QUARTER SMALLEST SINCE 75
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The economy grew even more slowly than originally estimated over the last three months of 1976, registering the smallest expansion since the first quarter of 1975, the Government said today.

title: DR. GEORGE SCHWARTZ
description: Dr. George Schwartz, author of the book Illustrated Operative Surgery and of many medical articles, died yesterday in his home in Miami Beach. He was 79 years old.

title: Manila Aide Says 1,441 Are Held in Security Cases
description: MANILA, Feb. 18Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile said today that 1,441 persons were under detention in the Philippines for what he called charges of crimes against national security.

title: Excerpts From Justice Department Report on Dr. King Assassination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The following are excerpts from the report of the Justice Department Task Force that reviewed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT DETROIT

title: E.P.A,STAFF INCREASE OF 600 IS PLEDGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  President Carter's budget director, Bert Lance, met with a group of environmentalists today and pledged to increase the staff of the Environmental Protection Agency by 600 persons, according to a participant in the meeting.

title: Jordan Is Indignant
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18The Government of Jordan reacted with indignation tonight to the report published in Washington today that King Hussein had secretly received millions of dollars in the last 20 years from the Central Intelligence Aeency.

title: Los Angeles, Beset by Problems, Fears It, Too, Is Facing a Decline
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 Los Angeles, which was called the prototype of the American city of the future only a few years ago, is beginning to wonder: Has the future come and gone?

title: Jets to Remain At Shea Stadium As Mets Relent
description: The battle between New York and New Jersey over the football Jets was unexpectedly settled last night when Mayor Beame announced that the team would stay in Shea Stadium and not follow the Giants into the new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Due to an error in transcribing a reporter's story, The Times on Thurs day misstated the estimated cost of the Westway highway project. The correct figure is $1.16 billion.

title: S.E.C. WON'T SUPPORT COMPANIES THAT BAR BOYCOTT PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has changed its mind and decided not to support companies seeking to exclude stockholder resolutions on the Arab boycott from consideration at their annual meetings.

title: Klammer Triumphs In Ski Race
description: LAAX, Switzerland, Feb. 18 (AP)Franz Klammer of Austria regained the lead in World Cup ski standing today when he triumphed in the Kandahar downhill race. Klammer, beaten in the last two World Cup downhill events, set a track record of 1 minute 59.10 seconds and moved back in front of Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, the 1976 winner, in the cup standing.

title: ProWestway U.S Decision Final
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that the Westway highway project in Manhattan carried his final approval, despite the release of a critical report this week by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Fleet of 72 Yachts Sets Sail For 2Day Lipton Cup Race
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18A nice place to be today was aboard a yacht sailing up to Fort Lauderdale and then across the bouncy Gulf Stream to Gun Cay in the Bahamas in the annual Lipton Cup race. There were about 600 sailors so blessed as a fleet of 72 yachts took off from Government Cut here this morning in a 110mile triangular race that will end back at the start tomorrow. It was event No. 4 of six in the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit's annual series.

title: SOVIET ARSON DEFENDANTS ARE SAID TO DENY GUILT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (UPI)Seven defendants in a controversial arson case in the republic of Georgia withdrew their confessions during the trial but were found guilty and sentenced to prison, according to a Georgia newspaper reaching Moscow today.

title: Swift to Close Meat Units Because of Poor Profits
description: Swift and Company, the meat packing and processing unit of Esmark Inc., announced yesterday that it would close five of its meat plants on Aug. 18 because of poor earnings.

title: County Leaders Move to Broaden Association to Improve Leadership
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 18Officials who govern the state's 21 counties plan a reorganization of their association. Leanna Brown, the former director of the Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders, disclosed today.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Bayer and Ciba Plan Joint Plant in Germany
description: Two of Europe's leading chemical concerns, Bayer, A.G., of West Germany and the CibaGeigy Groups of Switzerland, announced plans for building a $208 million chemical plant at Brunsbttel in the West German state of SchleswigHolstein.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Howard Stein, the first deputy administrator of the Human Resources Administration, announced yesterday that all 250 remaining employees of the Children's Center would be given other jobs under his agency. The violenceplagued Children's Center, which once housed as many as 300 children, is to close on March 15.

title: EBEN AYERS, 85; EXAIDE TO ROOSEVELT AND TRUMAN
description: WASHINGTON,Feb. 18 (AP)Eben Ayers, who served in the White House under Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, died last night. He was 85 years old.

title: Deaths
description: GRACEWilliam J., M.D, With Profound grief, the Board of Trustees, Sisters of Charity, Medical Staff and Departments of St. Vincent's Hospital ??Medical Center record the death of William J. Grace, M.D., their beloved and highly. esteemed Director of Medicine. He was greatly respected worldwide, having served on several Medical Boards and Committees, written numberless articles, held several editorial appoint1 ments, especially as editor of the, American Journal of Medicine, His dedication, expertise and skill inspired the numerous young Doctors who were fortunate enough to train under him. These Physicians are a living memorial to this great man, His kindness. his humaneness and sincere dedication to superb Patient care permeated his every action and influenced all who came in contact with him. His passing marks a very sad hour In the history of St. Vincent's Hospital ?? Medical Center and also In the history of Medi. cine in general. The entire Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital a Medical Center offers their heartfelt smoothly & prayers to his beloved wife. devoted bereaved

title: Inflation Fear Depresses Stocks; Trading Is Slowest in 2 Months
description: Fears of an upsurge in the inflationary spiral pushed down stock prices yesterday in the year's slowest trading.

title: Pipeline Delay Lifts Cost
description: Canadian Arctic Gas Pipeline Ltd. said that a previously announced oneyear delay on construction of the proposed Mackenzie Valley gas pipeline, together with design changes, have Increased estimated costs by $475 million to $7.48 billion. It added that the contingency overrun costs on the line, which would be built in Western Canada to link up with natural gas supplies in Prudhoe Bay in Alaska, have also risen, by $115 million to $1.87 billion.

title: Radio
description: 6 A.M ., WNYCAM: Morning Solitude. Henry Du MontMotets for the King's Chapel, John DowlandSongs and Ayres.

description: WASHINGTON,Feb. 18On the date President Carter effectuated a fireside discourse to announce his intention to implement new directives to minimize the quantity and maximize the understanding of regulations promulgated by the Federal Government, recipients of the Federal Register were hereby subjected to the following:

title: Bridge:
description: There is one situation in which it is very difficult to apply the brakes in the bidding, and even experienced players are liable to overreach themselves.

title: 15 Hurt by OffTarget Mortar
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., Feb. 18 (AP)A mortar round that exploded and injured 15 paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division during a live fire exercise yesterday was at least 875 yards off target, Army officials say.

title: Virginians Giving Up Land To Save It From Strip Mines
description: LOUISA, Va.Fighting the industrialization of this rolling former plantation country, the notsogentle gentlefolk of Louisa County are covering the conservation battlefield here with environmental landmarks.

title: Jets to Remain At Shea Stadium For 1977 Season
description: The battle between New York and New Jersey over the football Jets was unexpectedly settled las night when Mayor Beame announced that the team would stay in Shea Stadium and not follow the Giants into the new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: U.S. STOUTLY DEFENDS LETTER THAT CARTER WROTE TO SAKHAROV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Administration stoutly defended President Carter's letter to Andrei D. Sakharov today in the face of Soviet warnings that official American expressions of sympathy and support for Russian dissidents could damage relations between Moscow and Washington.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Monday is Washington's Birthday. Public and parochial schools, libraries, post offices, banks, security and commodity markets, government offices and nearly all business offices will be closed. Most large department and specialty stores will be open.

title: More Heads of State Are Reported To Have Received C.I.A. Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18In addition to making clandestine cash payments to King Hussein of Jordan, the United States, through the Central Intelligence Agency, has given cash directly to a number of other foreign leaders in return for favors over the years, intelligence officials said today.

title: ADRIAN M.MASSIE, BANKER, DEAD AT 80
description: Adrian M. Massie, former chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Trust Company, died yesterday at the Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived at 280 Round Hill road, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Personal Investing
description: Shelter for capital gains, immediate tax deductions, a high yield of 7 percent or more and the psychic satisfaction of doing good are all part of an investment blend that more and more philanthropic organizations are beginning to promote.

title: California Trading Stamp Concern Purchases Buffalo Evening News
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 18 (AP)The Buffalo Evening News, owned by the same family for more than a century, will be sold for about $33 million to Blue Chip Stamps, a California trading stamp company, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Diplomats in Beirut Still Hope for Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18The disclosure of payments by the Central Intelligence Agency to King Hussein is an embarassment to the United States,may cast a chill on JordanianSyrian efforts toward union, and is certain to be used by Hussein's Palestinian enemies as an argument against Arab pressure for a formal link between Jordan and the proposed Palestinian state.

title: Dollar Ends Mixed In Trading Abroad; Gold at $136.625
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 (UPI) The dollar had a mixed closing on European money markets today and the British pound lost some Around.

title: Aztec Sacrifices Laid to Hunger, Not Just Religion
description: The Aztecs sacrificed human beings atop their sacred pyramids not simply for religious reasons but because they had to eat people to obtain protein needed in their diet, a New York anthropologist has suggested.

title: People and Business
description: Milton W. Hudson, a highly regarded New York economist little known outside to banking and academic circles, spent his first day yesterday in the newly created post of assistant to the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur F. Burns, a job that promises to do little to enhance his visibility.

title: DR. WILLIAM J. GRACE OF ST. VINCENT'S DIES
description: Dr. William J. Grace, director of medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital since 1958 and the first head of a hospital in the United States to use a mobile emergency service for coronary attack victims, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 80 Deep Vale Drive.Manhassett. L.I.

title: Stimulator on Clothing Warns Soldier of Attack
description: A soldier needs to be advised of the presence of enemy aircraft or tanks without being distracted from his own weapon, whether it is a Redeye missile or an antitank weapon.

title: Nick Combest, 52, Trainer Of Thoroughbred Horses, Is Killed in Car Accident
description: Nick Combest, a horse trainer and former jockey, was killed late Thursday night in an automobile accident in Hewlett, L. I. He was 52 years old and lived in Franklin Square. L. I.

title: Bare ruin'd tires, where late the sweet birds sang
description: Bare ruin'd tires, where late the sweet birds sang

title: Plea by Czech Pop Singer
description: PRAGUE, Feb 18 (Reuters)A Czechoslovak pop singer, Marta Kubisova, banned from singing here since 1970, today asked artists around the world to help stop the process of suppression of civil rights in Czechoslovakia.

title: Outbreaks of InfluenzaB Reported by 13 States
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 18 (UPI)Thirteen states have reported outbreaks of influenzaB, the national Center for Disease Control said here today, and in four of the states the outbreaks have been widespread.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE FLOWN IN A SUCCESSFUL TEST
description: EDWARDS, Calif., Feb. 18The nation's space shuttle took to the air here today in the first flight test of the type of versatile, reusable spaceplane destined to be the orbital ferry of the 1980's.

title: Bomb Explodes at Airport As Argentine Chief Leaves
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18A bomb exploded near the runway of the municipal airport here today as President Jorge Rafael Videla took off in a military plane.

title: Detroit Suburb That Recalled Its Mayor Voting Today on Recall of His Successor
description: HIGHLAND PARK. Mich., Feb. 18This island city surrounded by Detroit may be is roistering and juicy a slice of urban America as any other 2.89 square miles in the country. Once a legendary place in the annals of industry, it is gripped today by the classic turmoil of a respectably middleclass community trying to stay that way in the face of seemingly unstoppable forces of decay.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoff subject to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: Marseilles Believes It Has More to Offer Than Fisticuffs
description: MARSEILLES, FranceWhile Paris, in the cold gray north, fancies itself as the world capital of romance, the people of this usually sunny Mediterranean city feel they live in a place where love also flourishes, albeit alongside traditional porttown violence.

title: Beame Chats With the People Over the Radio
description: Stealing a march on President Carter, Mayor Beame picked up a telephone last night and chatted persontoperson with New Yorkers over the radio.

title: Knight's Disciple Has Army Rolling Again
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 17In the commissary, where the wives of the officers buy groceries. they're talking about the pick and roll in the same sentence as the dinner roll. Around the coffee machines, where the faculty members chat, they're talking about the motion offense as well as strategic defense. In the library, where the cadets are supposed to be studying, they're whispering about the tough mantoman instead of the Swamp Fox.

title: Ulasewicz Is Given Probation in Tax Case
description: Anthony T. Ulasewicz, the retired New York City police officer who worked as a confidential investigator for former President Richard M. Nixon, was sentenced yesterday to one year of unsupervised probation for filing false income tax returns for the years 1971 and 1972.

title: President Is Withdrawing Ford Nomination of Toon As Ambassador to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)President Carter today withdrew the nomination of Malcolm Toon, a career diplomat, to be ambassador to the Soviet Union, a post Mr. Toon now occupies under a temporary appointment.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Monday is Washington's Birthday. Public and parochial schools, libraries, post offices, hanks, security and commodity markets, government offices and nearly all business offices will be closed. Most large department and specialty stores will be open.

title: Deaths
description: BABCOCKPatricia (Greene), In Boston, Mass., Feb. 17, 1977, beloved daughter of K. Barry of Florida and the late Kathryn (Brady). Sister of the late Sarah Dearborn Greene. Funeral service in the Trinity Church Copley Square, Boston, Mass., Saturday February 19th at 2 P.M. Relatives and friends respectfully invited. Contributions may be sent to Dr. William Davies Sohier c/o Cox Cancer Center at Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston in Patricia Babcock's honor, Arrangements WatermanMcDonald Funeral Home, Boston, Mass.

title: P.L.O. Feels Pressure on Charter
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18Palestinian leaders may find themselves forced to revise the national charter of the Palestine Liberation Organization and to accept a formal link between the proposed Palestinian state and Jordan, as suggested yesterday by President Anwar elSadat, informed Palestinian sources said today.

title: Sutton Opens Campaign Offices In Queens as Symbolic of City
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, the first major black candidate for Mayor of New York City, opened his campaign headquarters yesterday in a grim corner of another boroughQueenswith the help of Rocco Barbella, better known as Rocky Graziano, the former middleweight boxing champion.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1977

title: Schippers, III, Drops Boheme
description: Thomas Schippers has had to cancel his engagement to conduct the new production of La Bohme at the Metropolitan Opera because of complication from viral pneumonia. The Puccini work is scheduled to open next Wednesday. James Levine, music director of the company, will replace him. Mr. Schippers's illness has also forced him to cancel several concepts with the Cincinnati Symphony, of which he is music director.

title: Meadowlands Results
Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: 2dPlace Finish Helps Foyt Win I.R.O.C.Series
description: PAYTONA BEACH. Fla., Feb. 18Cale Yarborough won the race today, but A. J. Foyt won more than a race atDaytona International Speedway. He couldn't have done it without Yarborough.

title: Nassau County Unit To Weigh Proposal For Shopping Mall
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 18The Nassau County Board of Supervisors will be asked to approve a lease to begin developing a $20 million shopping center at Mitchel Field, Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive, announced today.

title: U.S. STOUTLY DEFENDS LETTER THAT CARTER WROTE TO SAKHAROV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Administration stoutly defended President Carter's letter to Andrei D. Sakharov today in the face of Soviet warnings that official American expressions of sympathy and support for Russian dissidents could damage relations between Moscow and Washington.

title: U.S. Tries to Minimize the Impact Of Report on C.I.A. Aid to Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Carter Administration sought today to minimize the possible impact on its Middle East diplomatic efforts of published reports that the Central Intelligence Agency had made secret payments to Jordan's King Hussein for 20 years.

title: HEALEY ASKS UNIONS TO KEEP PAY CURBS
description: LONDON, Feb. 18The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, warned today that Britain faced economic catastrophe and the anarchy of strikes if it abandoned its voluntary payrestraint policy.

title: Wadkins Getting Health And Golf Game in Form
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18He is 27 years old, married and the father of a bright 3yearold daughter. Yet his almost childish facial features make him look like an adolescent boy, an image subtly enhanced by Southerners predilection for diminutives in namesLanny in this case, for Gerald Lanston Wadkins.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: CURBS ON DISSIDENTS EASED BY RUMANIANS
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 18The Rumanian police today partly lifted their cordon around the homes of several dissidents here, and at least 10 passports were promised to members of their families.

title: ISRAEL IS CAUTIOUS ON SADAT PROPOSAL
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 18A Foreign Ministry official said today that Israel wanted to hear details from United States officials before issuing a formal response to President Anwar elSadat's suggestion that the Palestine Liberation Organization establish a declared link with Jordan before a reconvening of the Geneva peace conference.

title: Fund Investing In Farm Lands Termed an Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)Financial companies told Congressmen today that a mutual fund program to invest in farm land would help rather than hurt the small farmer.

title: CASINO PLAN DRAFTED FOR NEW YORK STATE
description: In a move to head off potential tourist dollar losses to New Jersey, the State Department of Commerce is drafting legislation to remove the constitutional ban on casino gambling in New York.

title: Brawl Mars Game
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 18The New York Nets produced 36 minutes of lethargy and 12 minutes of fireworks against the Seattle SuperSonics tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, and as is usual with such things, the lethargy prevailed.

title: Japan Given Fishing Quota For U.S. Waters
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18 (AP)  The United States has notified Japan that its fishing quota in the 200mile United States fishery zones has been set at 1,190,960 tons for 1977, the Fisheries Agency said today.

title: Rotterdam Brought to a Standstill As Strike Spreads to Dockworkers
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 18(Reuters)Rotterdam, normally the world's busiest port, came to a standstill today when a strike spread to all dockworkers.

title: Ourselves as Russia Sees Us
description: MUNICH, West GermanyHaving just attended a seminar in this city dealing with EastWest military balances and presumed intentions, and at which many qualified observers were present including cabinet ministers, generals and ambassadors, one can only depart with gloomy forebodings. Not that many people are expecting war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Even the most hawkish retract their talons on this point.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1977

title: G.M. Plans SolarPower Hot Water System in Homes
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, says it may begin selling a solarpowered hot water heating system for homes next year.

title: The Once ArtsyCraftsy Artisans Are Now Big Time
description: BALTIMORE. Feb. 18  American crafts have become a serious profession for thousands of people. This became apparent here yesterday when the first Northeast Winter Market opened in 84,000 square feet of space with 350 selected craftsmen exhibiting everything from appliqu to zithers.

title: Los Angeles Absenteeism Linked to Busing Protest
description: LOS ANGELES. Feb. 18 (AP)A number of students stayed away from public schools today in an apparent protest of proposed busing for desegregation in the city's 600,000student school district.

title: White Motor in Pact
description: The White Motor Corporation said it had reached an agreement with Consolidated Freightways Inc. ending litigation in a dispute over truck distribution. The agreement provides that the companies will end on Dec. 7, 1977, an arrangement under which White Motor distributed trucks produced by Consolidated. Consolidated is establishing its own distribution network to market the trucks under the name Freightliner.

title: Forum on Jewish Films
description: A threeday forum on Jewish films is to start this evening at 8 o'clock at the Martin Steinberg Center of the American Jewish Congress, 15 East 84th Street. Tomorrow at 10 A.M., Howard Kissel, film critic for Women's Wear Daily, and Arthur Sainer, theater critic for The Village Voice, and others will examine the question of What Is a Jewish Film? Dore Schary, film producer; Harold Mayer, film producer, and Peter Schnall, film maker, will discuss how they made Jewish films. Between 3 and 5 P.M. tomorrow, people from government and the private sector will discuss aspects of fund raising.

title: The 100 Percent Solution
description: In the realm Of intercontinental warfare and the arms race, the vocabulary of the military experts in Washington and Moscow has overwhelmed the people who would be on the receiving end of the newly programmed final solutions. Technical words are themselves war weapons. They act to take decisions out of the hands and minds of legislators and laymen. It is as if you were not qualified to think about the consequences of nucleartipped missiles unless you knew the difference between MIRV's and MARV's.

title: Rapid Turnover and Policy Reviews Stir Uncertainty in State Department
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Nearly month after the departure of Henry A. Kissinger the State Department remains in the throes of uncertainty, marked by a rapid turnover of personnel and a reassessment of key policy issues, but also by a mood of buoyancy in the Foreign Service, which sees evidence of open debate in the hierarchy for the first time in years.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The Daily Life of the Aztecs, by Jacquos Soustelle/The Macmillan Company, The New York Times and The Bettman Archive

title: Wheat Futures Advance Sharply; Reports of Strong Wind a Factor
description: Wheat futures rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with heavy buying spurring prices near the close.

title: H.U.D. Plans to Give More Community Aid To the Poorest Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Carter Administration disclosed today that it planned to overhaul the Government's main program for battling urban blight by channeling more money into the poorest and neediest cities.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1977

title: Jordan Urges Changes in U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON. Feb 18Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City said today that New Jersey's older communities stood to lose $33.85 million in the next three years under a scalingdown procedure permitted under the current Federal formula for community development b?? grants.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE FLOWN IN A SUCCESSFUL TEST
description: EDWARDS, Calif., Feb. 18The nation's space shuttle took to the air here today in the first flight test of the type of versatile, reusable spaceplane destined to be the orbital ferry of the 1980's.

title: Investing in Charity Funds
description: More philanthropic organizations are promoting pooledincome funds. Donors get in capital gains shelter, immediate tax deductions, a yield of 7 percent or more and the satisfaction of supporting a worthy cause. Page 30.

title: Detective Acquitted Of Extorting Bribes From Drug Suspects
description: A detective accused of extorting money from narcotics suspects was acquitted in State Supreme Court yesterday after a trial at which Deputy Mayor Nicholas Scoppetta and several wellknown present and former Federal law enforcement officials testified as character witnesses for both sides

title: EAST GERMANS TAKE A PROTEST CALMLY
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 17A dozen Prominent East German writers who protested the expulsion of a dissident singer last fall feared the worstbut three months later not one has been arrested and all have been allowed by the Government to keep publishing.

title: School Board Opposes Bill to Alter Custodial System Now Under Fire
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that it was opposed to legislation that would compel the adoption of a direct school custodial system to replace the traditional arrangement, which has come under fire for alleged corruption, waste and nepotism.

title: Oil Shale Down There, Waiting to Be Tapped
description: LOS ANGELES  Over millions of years, huge quantities of organic matter were created in the Rocky Mountains, locked in as a rockhard substance called oil shale, Heat this rock to 900 degrees Fahrenheit and these organics produce oil comparable to imported and domestic crude oil. In Colorado, Utah and Wyoming there are nearly two trillion barrels of shale oil in place. It is the largest potential source of recoverable oil in the world.

title: Illness Wasn't Due to Asbestos
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, Feb. 18 (AP)A 13yearold student whose illness was attributed to asbestos ceilings, leading to school closings and a statewide search for the cancercausing fiber, has been sick with mononucleosis, his doctor said today.

title: Rothko Fund Changes Its Position On Marlborough Sales Contracts
description: Seven sets of lawyers gathered again yesterday to argue over the estate of Mark Rothko, one of the 20th century's leading abstractexpressionist paintersbut there was a change in the lineup.

title: First Round on Rent Control
description: The New York State Legislature has begun to address the explosive issue of rent regulation. This is the moment, therefore, to face up to a definition of what ought to be the guiding principles for intelligent legislation in this field.

title: Dreyfus to Raise Management Fee
description: The Dreyfus Fund, with assets of about $1.5 billion, said yesterday that directors had voted an increase in the management fee charged, subject to shareholder approval, to 65/100ths of 1 percent on the first $1.5 billion from the present 50/100ths. A spokesman said that the fund had no intention of eliminating the 8 percent sales charge.

title: Hollywood Group's Boycott of Emmy Awards Show Symptomatic of Division Within Television Industry
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18Production of this year's Emmy awards show for the best programming in television is jeopardized by a deep split within the television industry that is rooted in a feud involving egos, economics, and historical change within the industry.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: G.M. Said to Be Studied By Justice Department For Criminal Tax Fraud
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Justice Department is reported to be investigating the General Motors Corporation for criminal tax fraud in a case that could involve individuals as well as the comp?n??.

title: 1,000 Spirit Panaceas That Give lnstantLight
description: During the last two years Nathaniel Lande has been through existential therapy, has visited psychics and faith healers, has attended revival meetings and has been Rolphed. He's experienced est. has taken the plunge at Esalen and has leaped over flames with witches at Stonehenge.

title: Los Angeles, Beset by Problems, Fears It, Too, Is Facing a Decline
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18Los Angeles, which was called the prototype of the American city of the future only a few years ago, is beginning to wonder: Has the future come and gone?

title: Closed End Funds
description: Week ending Feb. 18, 1977

title: Essex Council To Promote Arts
description: FOR some 65,000 residents of Essex County, the postman is bringing a surmise. No, it's not taxrebate checksthey're due in Aprilbut it is something that, at least for many of those living in 12 towns in the area, will be just as valuable.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: File on the Tsar

title: The Sakharov Letter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Jimmy Carter has adjusted to Washington, but Washington hasn't yet adjusted to him. He keeps doing as he likes.

title: Baseball in 1977: Even Free Agents Report This Week
description: From Miami Stadium in Florida to Desert Sun Stadium in Yuma, Ariz., baseball training camps will begin rustling this week. And the big news this year is just that: They will begin rustling on time.

title: MUSIC
description: A YALE WOMAN brought curiosity, perserverance and a little bit of luck along with her last summer to the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, and as a result, the House of Usher will fall again next weekend in New Haven. The occasion will be the world premiere at Yale's Jonathan Edwards College of La Chute de la Maison Usher, an opera by Claude Debussy based on Edgar Allan Poe's chilling tale of terror.

title: Leslie Drexler Is Married On L.I. to Fredric Salzberg
description: Leslie Drexler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Drexler of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Fredric Salzberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Salzberg of Roslyn, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ephraim R. Wolf at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: LEO M. SATLOF
description: Dr. Leo M. Satlof, a general practitioner in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died yesterday at his home in Sunrise, Fla. He was 76 years old and until his retirement in 1975 lived here at 100 Thayer Street.

title: French Miniser Confers in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Louis de Guiringaud of France conferred with Syrian leaders today on the prospects of moves toward peace in the Middle East. He had separate meetings with President Hafez alAssad, Prime Minister Ahdel Rahman Khleifawi and his host, Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam.

title: CLEVELAND WILL TEST CARTER SCHOOL POLICY
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 17In 1969, President Nixon reversed the executive branch school integration policy of the preceding Democratic Administrations that was generally in support of desegregation advocates.

title: SHOP TALK
description: AS the taste for Far Eastern cuisine has moved from Chinatown, up Broadway and across the city line into Westchester, small shops selling Oriental gifts and groceries have appeared here and there throughout the county. But none has the variety and volume of MeidiYa, a grocery store that is basically Japanese but is plentifully stocked with ingredients for Chinese and Korean cooking as well.

title: NEW DETENTE DRIVE BY OLD BRANDT AIDE
description: BONN. Feb. 19Egon Bahr, the architect and secret negotiator of former Chancellor Willy Brandt's policy of improved relations with the East Germans, is hack at work for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: Men's Lib: Coping With Changing Roles
description: THE other evening. Gerald Davidson, a Stony Brook clinical psychologist, had some male acquaintancesanother psychologist, a youthservices worker and a shoemakerover to his home in Port Jefferson. It seemed not unlike any other group of suburban men who meet on occasion to play cards, talk and drink.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: BOSTON Not everyone dotes on Roman art. The girl is rare who capitulates on Valentine's Day before the gift of a lifesize marble bust of an unsmiling and noseless Imperial administrator. A Roman conjugal sarcophagus is undeniably a beautiful thing, with its evocation of embraces that continue after death; but, once again, not everyone wants it about the house.

title: I.L.O Report Is Doubtful That High Pay Makes Lip For Harm of Night Work
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19  Workers should think twice before accepting night work because extra pay may not compensate for its unfavorable effects on family and social life and on health, according to a study by the International Labor Organization.

title: Partners: The University and
description: A NEW educational concept geared toward the practical aspects of education and the placing of students in the business community will be offered by Hofstra University at its newly formed Center for Career Development.

title: Carter Sends a Personal Message Of Condolence to Crosland Widov
