description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reuters)President Carter today sent a personal message of condolence to the widow of Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland of Britain.

title: Pond, Unhappy, Weighs An End to Racing Career
description: Lennie Pond, one of the top drivers in Southern stock car racing last year, will be watching today's Daytona 500 from the sidelines. And as much as he loves racing, he says he won't go back unless I can go back better than when I left.

title: Fashion
description: Corselets have returned, but not the oldfashioned undertheclothes kind. These corselets are meant to be worn as tops with full skirts (especially the kneebaring ones). They're frankly sexy and provide an alternative to the more demure clothes being shown for spring. It all started in Paris with Yves Saint Laurent. Last October, in his spring readytowear collection, he launched the corselet, showing it with everything from long ruffly skirts to tailored walking shorts. Americans loved the corselet, and designers here adapted it at more modest prices. But the corselets shown on these pages, like Saint Laurent's, are a far cry from the corselets of the past: the binding outer garments of the Middle Ages, the tight inner bodices stiffened with whalebone, wooden splints and steel of the late17th and 18th centuries, even the Merry Widow of the 1940'sa boned undergarment that pinched the waist into shape, leaving the wearer breathless. Today's cotton corselet is soft and unconstructed and is either laced or buttoned. It can be worn to the beach or to parties, and under a shirt jacket it can even go to the office as a replacement for last Tshirt halter.

title: Experiments With DNA Have Huge Risks as Well as Benefits
description: WASHINGTONRecombinant DNA research is a subject so abstruse that until recent years, it was seldom mentioned beyond the biologist's laboratory.

title: On Corporate Image Building
description: IT was not so long ago that the rolling hills of Fairfield County were filled with the expansive country estates of the wealthy, prized sanctuaries that permitted their occupants freedom from the pressures of the city but the proximity to remain in touch with its activities. Such places began to disappear after World War II as the rising middle class crowded into Fairfield and turned little country towns into big suburbs. The single sprawling estate seemed a remnant of another erawhich it was, until a totally new kind of country estate came along to take its place.

title: TV VIEW
description: CBS's Who's Who;Soft, Slick but Smart

title: FIGHT REPORTED LOST BY HUGHES INSTITUTE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19While no public announcement has been made, confidential sources disclosed this week that the Howard Hughes Medical Institute has lost a sevenyear struggle to retain a favorable status under the 1969 Federal law that reformed tax rules for foundations.

title: Vicksburg at Peace Nurtured by Its River, Obsessed With Its Past
description: I've lived here all my life, a Vicksburger told me, but every time I sight the Mississippi I get goose pimples. For the river is Vicksburg. It determined the town's location, halfway between Memphis and New Orleans, and provided a highway for the waves of French, British and Spanish explorers and colonists who exterminated each other, not to mention the indigenous Yazoo and Tunica Indian populations. Riverboat gamblers, buccaneering flatboatmen and freebooters of all sorts followed in short order, derringers and bowie knives at the ready. And in 1863, the river brought the Union Siege of Vicksburg, the most brutal event of its kind in this nation's history.

title: Beame's Plan May Lack Key Backers
description: Mayor Beame has presented his plan for an outside agency to monitor New York City's finances in the future but there are signs the proposal may not fully please those it must, the banks kind the municipal labor unions.

title: POLITICS
description: THERE are now enough major gubernatorial candidates from both parties to examine precisely just how various positions on the state income tax are shaping up. Exactly how important the issue will be in November remains to be seen, but right now it is believed to be on the top of the list of voter concern.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: If any place deserves to be called the crossroads of civilization, it is probably Asia Minor, the heartland of modern Turkey. Dozens of different peoples passed through this territory: Hittites and Phrygians, Lydians and Lycians, Persians and Greeks, Romans and Turks. Few of them left more powerful and intriguing monuments than the early Christiansmonuments to faith, and to terror.

title: Four Mountains, 10,000 Skiers, 50 Miles of Trails and the Longest Gondola in the World
description: There we were, in the middle of a mountain, in the middle of a ski resort, in the middle of Vermontin the middle of a light snow and we were lost. For a quarter hour my wife and I had seen no one as we twisted and dropped down a difficult run studded with trees. Only after edging against a massive pine to check our bearings did we realize that our trail map was missing, and we had no clue where we were.

title: Carter Set to Ask Congress to Abolish Loans for Students
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)Presi dent Carter intends to ask Congress to abolish the $332 million loan program for college students, according to the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee.

title: Fashion
description: We don't have much left, George Rapaport was saying. We're out of smalls in this B.V.D. thermal number altogether. I got a shipment of 30 dozen sets in last week, but the way they're selling they won't last two weeks, and that's it until fall.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: A basic discography of contemporary New York underground rock.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: VERY often when a job pops up that calls for the use of an electric soldering iron or gun, the handyman finds that he can't locate his spool of solderor he forgets to take it along when he takes the tool to the place where the work is to be done. One handy way to keep the wire solder always readily available is to wrap a length of it around the electric cord, near the handle, as shown in the photograph at right. That way, the solder will always be stored with the gun or iron, and it will always be ready for use when needed.

title: Mary B. Simon, Dana D. Streep Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary B. Simon, to Dana D. Streep, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Streep of Mystic, Conn. A July wedding is planned at the Simon home.

title: POLITICS
description: IF you call the number listed in the book for the Conservative Party of Westchester County, the chances are that Barbara Price will pick up the telephone. After all, it is in the front hall just outside the kitchen of her Yonkers home. She is the wife of the party chairman, Wilson G. Price.

title: Accountants And Lawyers Reap Windfall From '76 Law
description: The Tax Reform Act of 1976 was full of major provisions, but the biggest thing it provided early on was burgeoning business for lawyers, accountants, brokers and publishers.

title: Tracing their roots
description: Last month, before the largest television audience ever assembled in the United States, the several generations of Kunta Kinte lived and died, made their way from freedom to slavery, and finally achieved a dubious freedom. When the last episode of Roots was shown, 80 million people were watching, two million more than watched the previous record holder which was, ironically enough, Gone With the Wind.

title: In ismarck's DayWealth Accrued in Public Office
description: When President Carter disclosed an agreement last weekend whereby his former business interests were placed in trust so that they would not be substantially affected by any Federal policy taken during his Administration, he was acting in accord with current sensibilities. Such was not always the case.

title: Congress Is Getting A Hybrid Budget
description: President Carter will submit to Congress this week his amendments to the proposed budget for fiscal 1978, a document that establishes the Government's priorities for the corning year. As the product of a Presidential transition, the budget will be a hybrid, bearing the marks of both the Carter and Ford Administrations; the influence of the new President is likely to be most evident in a higher level of spending, especially on social welfare, than his predecessor would have wished.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Hollywood as Social Critic: Reducing Our Ills to Absurdity

title: POLITICAL LINEAGES AN ALBANY TRADITION
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19In a State Legislature not particularly known for decorum, it was probably one of the wilder moments.

title: Islanders Rout Rangers, Trail Flyers by 4 Points
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19The Islanders and the Rangers unleashed their anxieties on each other tonight at Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders, whose problem lies in catching firstplace Philadelphia, were assuaged with a 52 victory, which moved them to within 4 points of the Flyers, who lost to Montreal.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: So Far, It's a Presidency Trying to Do Without Pomp
description: WASHINGTONBill Simon, one of President Carter's youthful aides, strolled nonchalantly into the Oval Office reception room this past week and began rummaging through a stack of newspapers and magazines on the secretary's desk. Wow, he suddenly shouted, pulling an advance copy of one publication from the pile. I can't get my little hands on this for at least another week. How'd you come up with it already?

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE altered President Carter's proposal for business tax credits to stimulate the economy. It erased the option of taking an enlarged investment tax credit or a 4 percent employment credit. Instead the committee offered an incremental employment tax credit, the net effect of which would provide a maximum subsidy of $1,600 on new hirings after a corporation had already increased its employment level by 3 percent. The proposal, which Is subject to reversal in the Senate, would be of negligible benefit to major industrial concerns but was supported by small businessmen...

title: Pamperer of Palates
description: APROMINENT attorney, who, lawyerlike, clung to his anonymity, said recently that, although he looked all around, he couldn't find a bakery with Danish pastry to compare with the Danish served at the Down Town Club in Newark. They just don't make it the same, he complained.

title: Three Years' War
description: At the Super Bowl one of the lawyers for the National Football League Players Association said he thought a new contract with the owners could be achieved in six weeks. That was Jan. 8, and anybody who can count on his fingers will realize that the lawyer ought to be making the betting line on the games.

title: BOMB NOTE ASKS END TO U.S. INVESTIGATION
description: A call for halting a Federal grand jury investigation was among demands found yesterday in a message left after two explosions Friday midnight at Manhattan skyscrapers. Two men were slightly injured.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: VERY often when a job pops up that calls for the use of an electric soldering iron or gun, the handyman finds that he can't locate his spool of solderor he forgets to take it along when he takes the tool to the place where the work is to be done. One handy way to keep the wire solder always readily available is to wrap a length of it around the electric cord, near the handle, as shown in the photograph at right. That way, the solder wild always be stored with the gun or iron, and it will always be ready for use when needed.

title: Laughing Last
description: The Hiss Case. A sibilant whisper of a generation's obsession. One can hear echoes of the late 1940'sthe ferocious debates in faculty lounges and barrooms, the immersion in apartment leases, vacation schedules, typewriter markings, pumpkin papers, automobile transactions, as later generations would debate the condition of Bullet 399 or the linguistic ambiguities of a White House tape.

title: Penelope H. Fowler Is Married to Thomas K. Doyle
description: Penelope Holden Fowler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Fowler of Evanston, Ill., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas K. Doyle of Bayville, L.I., son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Edward Doyle of County Wexford, Ireland, formerly of Bayville.

title: Child Care
description: I have just finished reading about 30 recentlypublished or soontobepublished books on child care and, if I were a young parent today, I might cut my throat.

title: Big Thaw a Threat as Big as Big Freeze
description: As ice in the rivers and bays has swollen to a thickness of two feet, millions of dollars worth of docks and pilings have been uprooted by the tides. But now a threat as great as the big freeze faces boatyards and marinasthe big thaw. Altogether, the resulting loss of dock space may make spring a little late for boatmen.

title: INTERVIEW
description: AMUSEUM curator has found the last of the Mohicans, not in the dusty pages of the James Fenimore Cooper novel but alive and thriving in central Wisconsin.

title: It Won't Make You Rich
description: Take care, Lord Chesterfield advised his longsuffering son, not to understand editions and titlepages too well. Like a good many of the old gentleman's obiter dicta, this comment may be dismissed as foolishnesselegant ignorance was his idealbut the same sort of remark is still being used to beat poor book collectors, who are supposed to care more about the monetary value of books than what's in them. This is unfair; collectors are already worried enough about what they're doing. In no other common human pursuit do the esthetic and commercial principles come into such abrupt and painful collision.

title: Boggs Wins Title Dive
description: BURNIE, Tasmania, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Phil Boggs, an Olympic diving champion, set a record today in beating Robb Cragg,, a United States teammate, in the Australian threemeter diving championships. Judges consistently marked Bogge's brilliant dives with scores of 9 or more as he finished with 630.21 points.

title: The Last Picture Show?
description: Ron Lesser says he's a gambling man. He operates movie houses in Mt. Kisco, Yorktown and Peekskill, N.Y., and books films for himself and several other theaterowners. Like his late father, he has been in the business all of his adult life.

title: Her Son, The Candidate
description: Sanjay Gandhi, a son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, has been nominated as a Congress Party candidate in India's March 16 election. If he wins, it will be his first elective office and, both his friends and foes suspect, the first step toward succeeding his mother.

title: Letters: Memories Of Israel
description: In regard to the article by Robert W. Stock, Packaged Israel: Fun, NoBut Food for the Soul (Travel Section, Feb. 6), I would like to tell you of my experiences. In 1964, I went to Israel determined to meet the people. With a pack on my back, I began to hitchhike my way across the country. In Safad, money being scarce, I asked an Israeli where I could find a cheap room. I ended up in a rabbi's house, where next morning I had breakfast. The rabbi's wife refused payment: I take no money from a widow, she told me sternly.

title: Lilian Sandburg, Widow Of Carl Sandburg, Dies In Asheville, N.C., at 93
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 19 (AP)Lilian Sandburg, widow of Carl Sandburg, the poet and historian, died at her home here yesterday. She was 93 years old.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT Paintings by Robert Natkin. Today to March 22, Carlson Art Gallery of the Arts and Humanities Center, 84 Iranistan Ave.

title: Division on Women Beset by Trouble
description: THE state's Division on Women is in trouble again. There's a division, but no director, and little resemblance to any kind of a program has been carried out. In fact, the division has been in trouble since its inception in 1974, creating headaches for Governor Byrne, whose attempts to appoint a permanent director have come to nothing.

title: British Arrest Three Friends Of Two Americans Ordered Out
description: LONDON, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Three friends of a former C.I.A. agent and an American writer, both ordered out of the country, have been arrested by Scotland Yard under the Official Secrets Act, their associates said today.

title: Winter's Silver Lining: Alfresco Ice Skating
description: METEOROLOGISTS and politicians are calling this winter the worst of the century, but for those with a taste for alfresco ice skating, it may well be one of the best. Weeks of record low temperatures have produced an abundance of navigable ice on southern Connecticut's lakes, streams and ponds for the first time in recent memory.

title: Letters
description: During the past decade the ideology of terror has gained acceptance in many Western universities and in some segments of the press through the argument that its use is justified by the revolutionary epoch of liberation and because it is merely a temporary method. The argument is both unethical and spurious: In reality the terrorists' means and ends have long merged into a permanent totalitarian synthesis, consequently they can no longer be considered liberators.

title: Volunteers Trained For Nursing Homes
description: A pilot project now under way in five counties is expected to improve the quality of life in New Jersey nursing homes. The key to the success of the program is the use of organized volunteers.

title: Private Phone Equipment
description: New York State's Public Service Commission has taken an important step toward ending telephone company domination over the sale of equipment. As long as it meets certain standards, customers should be able to buy and install their own apparatus instead of, as is usually the case, renting from their phone company, the commission said last week.

title: ENROLLMENTS ARE DOWN IN NEW ENGLAND COLLEGES
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP)Enrollments at New England colleges are on the decline, for the first time since the recordkeeping was started in 1960.

title: L. G. Judd Is Fiance Of Lynne S. Carman
description: Lynne Susan Carman and Lawrence G. Judd, who are in the Ph.D. program in school and community psychology at Hofstra University, plan to be married in August.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Anne L. Tully Betrothed To Bruce Meyer Herman
description: Mr. and Mrs. George M. Tully of Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Louise Tully, to Bruce Meyer Herman, son or Mr. and Mrs. Ben Herman of Lower Burrell, Pa. A wedding in the fall is planned.

title: Prague Presses Religious Leaders To Issue Declarations of Loyalty
description: VIENNA, Feb. 19Spiritual leaders of the Christian churches and the Jewish community in Czechoslovakia have been persuaded to issue declarations of loyalty to the Communist Government, but they have clearly attempted to be as vague as possible.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Flow does one prevent mildew forming in the bathroom? Ours has a window which is kept open in the summer, and the room is heated in the winter, but we have ugly mildew in the grout and on any damp cloth used in the room.M.S.. Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: GARDENING
description: THE roots of American gardening are buried deeply in the Island, The first commercial nursery in America, for example, was started in 1737 in Flushing. Its founder, William Prince, was a descendant of Thomas Prince, an early Governor of the Plymouth Colony.

title: Segovia, at 84, Communicates With Mastery
description: Andrs Segovia gave his only New York recital of the season on Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall. It was one day after he had celebrated his 84th birthday, and despite that awesome figure, the guitarist is still the consummate artist. He also remains unassail ably popular. The hall was filled; the stage in back of him held as many people as the law allows.

title: Leah Simpson Plans Nuptials
description: Leah Simpson, a principal dancer with the Beverly Brown Dance Ensemble of New York, and Warren Dillaway Ayres Jr., a financial staff associate with Union Carbide in New York, plan to be married in May.

title: Syracuse Routs St. John's by 7955
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 19Manley Field House is one of those basketball arenas that has a reputation as a nice place to live but I'd hate to visit there. And it's only Syracuse University that lives there.

title: Why the Bard Was Banished
description: THE AMERICAN SHAKESPEARE Theater at Stratford, which has in recent years been trying to change its status as a New York summer outpost into one that has thrown in altogether with its home state, has declared a long intermission that will, if all goes well, end next year.

title: Finley, Defying Kuhn, Makes $400,000 Deal
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP)Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's owner, sold a relief pitcher, Paul Lindblad, to the Texas Rangers today for $400,000 and set up another confrontation with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Article 2  No Title
Kathleen Thompson Bride of John McCurdy
description: Kathleen Acheson Thompson, an associate editor with Scholastic Magazines Inc., and John Stuart McCurdy, an account supervisor with Richard K. Manoff Inc., advertising agency, were married yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: For Antiques Lucky Number Can Be 7
description: ANTIQUE HUNTING may be the liveliest game in Connecticut. Played out on Route 7, known as the antiques strip, it might mean beating the competitor in the other car to that elusive find that might be ahead in one of the 25 or more antiques shops that dot the 15 miles or so of road between Norwalk and Danbury.

title: The Washington House of Sulgrave
description: The landlord's wife, Muriel Salisbury, pulled one of the two beer pumps behind the bar of The Star, the plainand onlypub in Sulgrave, and a halfpint of bitter gushed into my glass. The pumps have hunting scenes handpainted on their china handles and, as Mrs. Salisbury explained, A lot of Americans who pop in for a drink admire them so much they want to take them home. The pumps, of course, stay right where they are. Sulgrave, a remote village in the county of Northhamptonshire, manages to hold its own despite some strong influences from across the Atlantic.

title: LETTERS
description: The Last Mile for the Nation's Subways? (Feb. 6) is only a confirmation of what New York City has experienced for the last 10 and more years, and the facts brought out after the construction of the Bay Area Rapid Transit and the Washington Metro: people are not moles. Not only do subways engender claustrophobia, but their noise, record of crimes and accidents with their attendant difficulties of escaping, make them undesirable.

title: CHESS
description: The single strategic theme usually will not dominate a game, but will have to share top billing with another, or with several others. And what commonly happens is that one strategy, sharply pursued convinces the defender that he must take the game out of the course that is so evidently going to succeed for his opponent.

title: The Price of Spring
description: There used to be a country saying that you have earn spring by working your way through January and February. By midMarch, or whenever spring arrived, you presumably had done enough penance, shoveled enough snow and toted enough firewood, to entitle you to it. That certainly is true this time around.

title: Rep. Carter's Son, 22, Dies
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 19 (AP)  William Starr Carter, 22 years old, son of Representative Tim Lee Carter, Republican of Kentucky, died of leukemia today at the Vanderbilt University Hospital here. He was a student at Western Kentucky University and was a director of the People's Bank of Tompkinsville, Ky., where funeral services will be held Monday.

title: Learning To Live Small Gracefully
description: With most of the nation's people concentrated in sprawling, increasingly urbanized regional centers, questions of highdensity living are generating intense interest. This is the last of a series of articles exploring the subject.

title: The Teen Ager as Counselor
description: THE teenagers sat crossedlegged in a circle on the floor, unimpressed by their surroundings. It was purely coincidental that they were meeting in a magnificent old mansion on an 80acre national wildlife refuge in Lloyd Harbor. Even the flashbulbs intermittently lighting the room and the tape recorder microphone in full view did not lessen their concentration.

title: Anthony Crosland Dies in Britain; Callaghan to Name New Secretary
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland died early today, and Prime Minister James Callaghan is left with the problem of replacing him at a time when the ranks of seasoned ministerial possibilities in the Labor Party have been depleted.

title: Needed: More Stimulus and an AntiInflation Plan
description: The latest economic figuresprices up, production downraise further danger signals for the economy as a whole, and pose urgent questions about President Carter's stimulus program. Does it provide enough stimulus? Will it have too much inflationary impact? After Congressional revision, is it more nearly on target than before?

title: The Sails That Go Up When It Freezes
description: WHEN the thermometer freezes and the wind comes blasting out of the Arctic and across the Sound, most Long Islanders are either huddled closv to their oil burners or vigorously complaining about petroleum prices. But at the same time, members of the Eastern Ice Yacht Association's affiliated clubs are skimming over the frozen lakes and bays at speeds that occasionally exceed 100 miles an hourthree or four times faster than the wind.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: A Physical Fitness Plan for the Elderly
description: THE director of a community service organization in Newark has developed an unusual proposal calling for the creation, at a cost of $1.8 million, of a physicalfitness center for the elderly. If implemented, the program is expected to be watched closely by health planners throughout the nation to determine if it helps to cut the cost of medical care faced by the impoverished aged.

title: Tet Holiday Has Special Purpose For Vietnamese
description: Several hundred Vietnamese refugees and their friends gathered in Queens yesterday to hold a celebration for Tet, which, while it offered a showcase for the gay dances and fireworks that normally adorn the New Year holiday, also represented a deliberate effort to help buttress a flagging sense of community and pride.

title: An Obscure Gangster Is Emerging As the Mafia Chieftain in New York
description: No man in organized crime is getting more attention from Federal and local law enforcement officials than Carmine Galante, a gangster who is little known to the public, but widely feared and respected by members of the underworld.

title: Pressing Times Befall Widow Of Sir Winston
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Lady SpencerChurchill is selling six of her most cherished paintings, including two by her late husband, Sir Winston Churchill, and a portrait of herself and her daughter, Sarah, in an effort to make ends meet. Over the past few months, she has also sold furniture and silver.

title: Van Buren, Tech Triumph
description: Brooklyn Tech took the Brooklyn title and Van Buren captured top honors for Queens yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League borough indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory. Bronx and Manhattan schools will compete Friday at the same site.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The noise made by last week's International Conference of Little Magazines in Architecture on the subject, After Modern Architecture, could well be likened to the proverbial sound of trees falling in solitude in a forest. Who, except the Almighty, hears it, and does it make a noise at all?

title: The quest for the philosophical novel
description: Thanks to The Moviegoer, The Last Gentleman and Love in the Ruins, readers have come to expect a good deal of Walker Percy. His virtues, in this age of mostly terrible fiction, are notable. Though he cares about plot and character, making fictions that easily translate into movies, he is a serious, even moderately philosophical novelist not at all ashamed of his seriousness. Nor should he be: the familiar philosophical questions he raises, and his ways of raising them, are as interesting as his characters and plots, or anyway they would be if he had any idea of how to answer them. He cares about technique, enough so thatas is often the case in the very best fictiontechnique is one of the things we watch with interest, though here sometimes with dismay. He's clever, witty, efficient, concerned, and his fictions pass one of the two or three most important esthetic tests: they're memorable. All this I say without much reservation, which is to say I think he's a novelist people ought to read, as they will anyway, since he's caught on.

title: Article 4  No Title
LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE oil spilled by the Argo Merchant never washed up on the South Shore beaches, but the slick has reached the minds of the Island's Congressional delegation.

title: Nets Defeat Knicks In Lethargic Game At Garden, 86 to 85
description: With each game, the National Basketball season is turning into a nightmare for the Knicks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 19 (AP)Leah Poulos won two events today in women's competition and Peter Mueller, a fellow American, won the men's 500 meters and finished second in the 1,000 meters in an international speed skating tournament at the Olympic outdoor rink. Miss Poulos won the 500 meters in 43.49 seconds and the 1,000 in 1:29.17. Cindy Seikkula of the United States was fourth in 44.53 and Nancy Swider of the United States sixth in 45.61.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI)Mandatory water rationing in homes because of the California drought spread today from the San Francisco Bay Area south to the Monterey Peninsula, where 50gallonaday limits were imposed for individuals.

title: Miss Kavanagh Sets September Wedding To Arthur Gardiner
description: Dervorgilla Anne Kavanagh, a training specialist with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Arthur Denny Gardiner, who is with the commercial brokerage department at Cushman & Wakefield Inc., plan to be married in September.

title: Alberta Jean ZotacI4 Peter M. Baigent Set Wedding for June 18
description: Catherine E. K. Zotack of Vero Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alberta Jean Zotack, to Peter Michael Baigent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Baigent of Halifax, England.

title: Doris Pinner Is Married
description: Doris Pinner, a freelance photographer, was married yesterday afternoon in Stamford, Conn., to Melvin A. Brenner. He is vicepresident of schedules and industry affairs for Trans World Airlines. The Rev. Joel Baehr performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Universalist Church. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Brenner's first wife died. The couple will live in Greenwich, Conn. late Joseph R. McCurdy. His mother is development officer at Sarah Lawrence College. His father was in public relations with the RCA Corporation.

title: The Life of a Cop's Wife
description: YOU turn on the television or go to the movies and you can see many stories about policemen, but few of them delve into the lives of their families.

title: The Plan Affects All Schools in Disadvantaged Neighborhoods
description: LOS ANGELESFour years ago, California began an ambitious program of elementary school reform called Early Childhood Education. The program, which now involves 52 percent of the state's public school children from kindergarten through third grade, seeks to provide a strong foundation in basic learning skills through individual instruction in the child's early school years. Volunteers and paid teaching assistants are brought into the classroom so that the pupiladult ratio is never more than 10 to 1. In this way, it was hoped when the program began. children would get a better start and approach the upper grades with the confidence needed for success. Moreover, the procedure was planned to make superfluous the costly remedial efforts required to correct the habit of failure established in the first years of education for far too many children.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayFirst Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association 48th allbreed show and obedience trial, Hartford Civic Center, Asylum Street, Hartford, Conn.; 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Staking a Claim In Greenwich
description: WITH ONE EYE on Greenwich's affluent residents, another on the community's rapidly increasing transient work force and a hand extended in help to the female population, the Connecticut Women's Bank is preparing to open its doors.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Rudy Tomjanovich of the Houston Rockets, on how playing pro basketball has helped him in real life: It's those threeweek road trips. When I come off the road after three weeks, my wife looks awfully good to me.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Shortly after the Soviet Union subscribed in 1975 to the Helsinki agreement, which calls for observance of human rights, among other niceties, Sergie A. Kovalev became the first Soviet dissident to be tried for alleged antigovernment activity. The biologist was sentenced to seven years in a strict regime labor camp.

title: Food
description: Once in a rare while, we discover a formula for a dish that seems the ultimate, the definitive, the ne plus ultra of its kind. Over the years, we have printed recipes for a score or more desserts called chocolate mousse. We are convinced that the finest chocolate mousse creation ever whipped up in our kitchen is the one printed here.

title: Mrs. Rankin Leads at 139; 2 Get Aces
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI) Two holesinone were scored today and Judy Rankin gained a twostroke lead in the $50,000 Orange Blossom Classic, a Ladies Professional Golf Association event. Miss Rankin had a round of 70, two under par, for a 139 total.

title: Coping in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaEarly in 1967, 15 years out of Yale and Harvard Law school, 10 years out of his presidency of the West Brooklyn Reform Democrats, Philip C. Jessup Jr. arrived in Indonesia looking for nickelor, at least then, looking for the rights to look for nickel.

title: Miss Flaxman Wed To David Millheiser
description: At Temple EmanuEl in Dallas last evening, Margaret Flaxman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Blum Flaxman of Dallas, was married to David B. Millheiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian H. Millheiser, of Bayport, L.I. Rabbi Levi A. Olan performed the ceremony.

title: A Family That Sings Together
description: SEATED at a brightred electronic organ in the tiny dining room of her Montclair home and surrounded by nine of her 10 children, Barbara Ritchwood smiled, bowed her head and began to sing. The children, except for 4monthold Thomas, joined in.

title: Edith Knowles to Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John H. Knowles of New York and Chestnut Hill, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Edith LaCroix Knowles, to Thomas Marshall Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Williams of Short Hills, N.J., and Sagaponack, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Louis's Scheherezade Is Danced
description: The druginduced separation of self into two or more personalities is a theme that has worn very thin since the turnedon 60's. It was surprising that Murray Louis should set his hand to such a ballet as recently as three years ago, and still more surprising that he should have attempted to scale Scheherezade as a fullevening work. It has several excellent parts but is basically a small idea puffed out, and was presented at the Beacon Theater on Friday evening during the current Murray LouisAlwin Nikolais season.

title: Prices Going Their Usual WayUp
description: The Consumer Price Index rose elghttenths of 1 percent in January, double December's rise and the largest monthly increase since July 1975. Moreover, the Impact on retail prices of the severe cold weather late last month has not yet been fully reflected in the statistics.

title: The 1976 Campaign Funds
description: Another report on how much money special interest groups gave Congressional candidates in 1976 has been issued by Common Cause, and the report demonstrates that some consequences of the campaign reform act of 1974 have been as predicted.

title: Letters
description: Campus revolutionaries

title: Bid to Save White Plains Courthouse Is Abandoned
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 19An agreement signed Wednesday in Federal Court in Manhattan between White Plains officials and preservationists has set March 18 for the start of demolition of this city's historic courthouse.

title: Palaces And Prisons
description: One has only to think of Bloomsbury to realize how few American writers have been tempted by that supple, discursive and adaptable genre, the literary memoirstanding still for a leisurely and contemplative backward glance at one's life and friends. In two previous books, Thresholds and Showcases, Dorothea Straus has proved herself admirably unaffected by this chronic American restlessness. Now in her late 50's, Mrs. Straus is blessed with a long, crowded, and enviably unfaded memory for family members and settings, and for the multitude of novelists, poets, critics and editors in the New York literary world, which she has known intimately through her long marriage to the publisher Roger Williams Straus Jr.

title: West Va., Never Trailing, Stuns Notre Dame. 8168
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 19 (AP) Maurice Robinson scored 21 points as West Virginia upset Notre Dame, 8168, today. The smaller Mountaineers (159) gained an early lead and never trailed in the game.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHEN the weather is bleak and the wind is biting. our hearts turn toward the hearthand indoor diversion. It's a time for hooks, backgammon or bridge. And it's a time to knit one, purl two, crochet, crossstitch, continental or crewel.

title: Here comes The Kid!
description: Let's go kid, the bettors call out through chattering teeth as 16yearold Steve Cauthen rides another horse onto the track at Aqueduct. Frozen drifts of dirty snow choke the paddock, but the horseplayers don't feel the cold or see the bleakness. All winter long, with a heatwave performance unmatched in the history of New York racing, the 95pound apprentice jockey they call The Kid has been making the grass grow and the flowers bloom for those who plant their dreams in a parimutuel ticket.

title: Dale M. Johns, U.P.I. Newsman And Executive for 35 Years
description: Dale M. Johns, a United Press International newsman and executive for 35 years until his retirement two months ago, died yesterday in his home in Riverside. Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: 710, WNCNFM. Medieval Cathedral Music, Various; Missa Quatuor Vocum Cantate Domino, Cosset; Psalms from Cycle of Holy Songs, Rorem; Salve Regina, Lienas; The Eternal Gospel, Janacek; Four Motets, Schutz; Three Choral Works, Schubert.

title: F.B.I. Reports a Sharp Decline In Bombings in U.S. Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)The number of bombings in the United States declined sharply last year, and Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said he was optimistic that the trend would continue.

title: Waiting for a Lead From Con Edison
description: WITH hundreds of thousands of people thrown out of work throughout the Northeast and Middle West because of the shortage of natural gas, perhaps we are ready to begin to tap the greatest single reservoir of allwaste.

title: A Talk With Walker Percy
description: I lived a hundred miles from William Faulkner but he meant less to me than Albert Camus, said Walker Percy. I may have been lucky that way.

title: In the Tenant Press, The Cause Is All
description: In the Tenants Voice office, a windowless room above a Kings Highway storefront in Brooklyn, Jackie Goldman, a reporter, is complaining about missing pencils, misspelled words and the heat. It's too hot in here. she jokes. Let's go on a rent strike!

title: POLITICS
description: THERE IS something about the price of whisky that drives men to flights of insurrection or anarchy, not only in the craggy hills of Aberdeen or the lonesome backwoods of western Pennsylvania, but also in the normally staid, lawabiding state of Connecticut.

title: Two New Stages for Modern Dance
description: A new choreographer is coming to town. His name will not be up on some concert hall marquee. But Danny Williams Grossman and Dance Company will mace its American debut on March 2 in a congenial, lively little West 19th Street dance space called the American Theater Laboratory. The Torontobased choreographer, for ten years a lead dancer with Paul Taylor, is considered one or Canada's most interesting new dance talents though he is largely unknown here as a choreographer. But dance talents, though he is largely unistrative group that runs American Theater Lab and is producing Mr. Grossman's week of concerts, will provide him with a place to perform, all the administrative and technical services a harried choreographer could dream ofand an audience.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Picture Credit

title: A Correction For The New York Times From The Atlanta Journal & Constitution
description: The material below is appearing as a paid advertisement because The New York Times refused to print it in full as a letter to the editor on the editorial page.

title: Urban Sprawl on the North German Plain Forces NATO to Rethink Its Strategy Against a Soviet Ivasion
description: Urban sprawl across the North German plain is forcing North Atlantic Treaty Organization commanders to reexamine the tactical concepts for the defense of that traditional invasion route, according to senior officers.

title: The Long Island Weekly asked the three G.O.P. candidates why they want to be Nassau County Executive. Here are the replies from their offices:
description: EXPERIENCE. Accomplishments. Bossism. These are the issues the real issuesin the contest for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive. I have held the post for six years and can point to a record of solid achievement for the people of our county.MOST residents of Nassau County are up against it that's a harsh fact but it must be recognized. Nassau's residents earn relatively high incomes, but their gains are wiped out because they are among the most high ly taxed. people in the nation.

title: Snowfall Is Forecast In Metropolitan Area
description: Snow starting early this morning and possibly mixing with rain was predicted by the National Weather Service and accumulations in the metropolitan area between 2 and 4 inches was indicated.

title: Orion Shines the Brightest in Lhasa Apso Show World
description: Orion is February's brightest constellation of stars, forming the Hunter with his two dogs, so this year a little champion with the same name made his mark and reached the Westminster final. Over the last 20 years other contenders have come close, but Ch. Yojimbo Orion the only Lhasa Apso to triumph in the nonsporting group at Madison Square Garden. Like the proverbial cat with nine lives, Orion had a unique start in life. John R. Thyssen of Van Nuys, Calif., his handler, explained that Orion was an unexpected puppy. After a veterinarian told Mrs. Elaine Spaeth of Canoga Park, Calif., that Blackbay Sassafhrass wasn't having puppies, she found Orion on the garage's cold cement floor.

title: 74 NUCLEAR PLANTS TOLD TO STRENGTHEN ANTITERRORIST GUARD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19After a yearlong study, a Federal agency has concluded that the possible threat of terrorist actions against the nation's 74 civilianoperated nuclear facilities requires an immediate and significant increase in security.

title: DALEY'S HEIR FACING ONLY ONE REAL RIVAL
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19As filings for Chicago's special mayoral primary closed today, the only challenge of any consequence to Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic came from Democratic Alderman Roman Pucinski.

title: A Graduate Who Says He Can't Read
description: When 18yearold Edward Donohue walked through the door of the Lindenhurst Diner on Long Island one day recently he had already decided that he would order a cheeseburger.

title: Ad by Struggling Law Firm Led to National Test Case
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 18It was not what you would call a slick and glossy advertisement. In truth, it was rather dry. It made no boasts of offering the best or good quality'; for illustration, it had only a small stylized drawing of the scales of justice. The advertisement appeared only once, in a Sunday newspaper.

title: Money to Lend By, and for, Women
description: IN THE past, money has been used to keep women apart from a community. Now we're trying to use money to bring women together, said Penelope Hastings, treasurer of the newly chartered Westchester Women's Federal Credit Union.

title: Orestes P.Chornock Dies in Bridgeport; Greek Church Head
description: Metropolitan Orestes P. Chornock of the CarpathoRussian Greek Catholic Diocese in the United States, who was pastor of the St. John's Greek Catholic Church in Bridgeport, Conn., died Thursday morning at the Bridgeport Hospital after a long illness. He was 93 years old.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to Vicksburg, the Holiday Inn ($19 per night, twin accommodations), Downtowner Motel and Magnolia Motor Hotel are all close by the National Military Park, while the Quality Inn and Ramada Inn are only slightly farther away. Food is cheaper in Vicksburg than in comparable restaurants in the South; Tuminello's Kitchen specializes in Gulf shrimps and oysters; the Old Southern Tearoom of the Downtowner Motel serves a variety of catfish dishes in an antebellum setting. Dinner at Tuminello's starts at about $4 and at the Old Southern Tearoom at $5.25. The Holiday Inn has surprisingly good fried chicken and shrimp at reasonable prices.

title: ART VIEW
description: LONDON The noise made by last week's International moment is undoubtedly Queen Elizabeth II's Silver Jubilee, which has been seized upon the occasion to fill the newspapers and the airwaves with endless, smiling accounts of the life of the royal family before, during and after the Queen's accession to the throne 25 years ago. One of the minor events organized to mark this royal anniversary is an exhibition of The Queen's Pictures at Buckingham Palace and it Is of course an immensely popular show.

title: Pravda Charges That Sad at Lies On Soviet Role
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19The Soviet Union today made a scorching personal attack on President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, accusing him of spreading lies, slander and falsification about the Soviet role in Egypt and the Middle East.

title: Clifford's Cyprus Mission
description: Clark M. Clifford, President Carter's personal emissary, has begun consultations in Athens, Ankara and Nicosia seeking a solution to the conflict on Cyprus and an end to tensions between Greece and Turkey. Previous attempts by Washington to influence Greece and Turkey and their copatriots on Cyprus have led to resentment in those countries and, despite signs of a new willingness among the disputants to compromise, Mr. Clifford's role will be difficult.

title: Leslie Coleman Fiancee Of Donald L. Chasen
description: Leslie Coleman, a systems support representative in the Boston branch office of Inforex Inc., a manufacturer of minicomputers, and Donald Lewis Chasen, who is in private practice specializing in real estate law and a partner in Stachhouse Associates, a Boston real estate consulting concern, will be married April 16 in Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles is one of the most uncommon pitchers in baseball, but he suffers from the most common weakness in golf: the slice.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: A new theater for dance can never be less than interesting. There seems to be a general opinion in the city that we need some new temple for Terpsichore. Oliver Smith has had such a dream for the Manhattan Center, which I think still could be that ideal: a theater devoted to dance and of the proper opera house proportions.

title: THEATER
description: IN the film All About Eve, a Hollywoodbound theater director defends his move by saying, Wherever there's magic and make believe and an audiencethere's Theater. He defines theater as encompassing everyone from the Lone Ranger to Sarah Bernhardt, and concludes with: The theater's for everybodyyou included, but not exclusivelyso don't approve or disapprove. It may not be your theater, but it's theater for somebody, somewhere.

title: The Names Of the Lost
description: HE power to look around and see and the strength of a living syntax have distinguished Philip Levine's poetry at its best. In Not This Pig (1968) and They Fed They Lion (1972), he awakened and moved readers with poems meant to be read. That is high praise when so much recent poetry seems seated off from what people see or how people might speak when movedsealed off either by coy mannerism or by the standard poetic diction of a chic reticence: that tongue of a place where the dusty Stone of your blood eats Light like the snowy breathing of Water, et cetera.

title: Andrus and Officials Of Western States To Discuss Drought
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 19The drought afflicting Western states was the prime topic tonight when Interior Secretary Cecil B. Andrus and Senator Frank Church. both Idaho Democrats, spoke at a party fund raiser here.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Shadowbrook may not be one of the best restaurants in New Jersey, but it certainly seems like one of the biggest. The different dining rooms are truly of heroic proportions and, apparently, all kinds of, rooms for private parties stretch off into the distance. For warmer days, there are literally acres of grounds.

title: Zoning Blocks Unification Church
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 19The Tarrytown Board of Trustees has unanimously approved amendments to its zoning ordinance that would severely restrict the ability of the Unification Church, founded and headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, to build a university complex here.

title: STUDENT TV STATION OPENS AT COLUMBIA
description: After three years of planning, a studentrun cable television station at Columbia College made its first broadcast to the Morningside Heights campus last week.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: RightTurn Advocate Urges Tests for Drivers

title: Judith Bonnie Bass, Jack Levy Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Bass of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Bonnie Bass, to Jack Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Levy of Cynwyd, Pa. A July wedding is planned.

title: Opera: Experiments in Brooklyn
description: Ever since the MiniMet ceased operations after only one season a few years ago, New York has needed an opera group devoted to intimate and experimental works that the city's established companies find impractical to stage. The New Opera Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music aims to fill the gap and the company made its opening statement Friday night at the Academy's Lepercq Space with three oneact operas. A repeat performance is scheduled for this afternoon.

title: My Truth
description: Mussolini, of course, was that man who gave Fascism a bad name. Judging from this belated memoir by his daughter, he did not do much for the image of fathersinlaw either.

title: Joseph Scelzo Jr. to Wed Margaret Orbe
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Orbe Jr. of Glen Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Orbe, to Joseph F. Scelzo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scelzo of Oradell, N.J.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The Qualities Of Distilled Water

title: Roger Greene to Wed Robin Fleisig, Writer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl Fleisig of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Fleisig, to Roger Greene, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray J. Greene of Riverdale, the Bronx. The couple plan to be married in April.

title: STAMPS
description: Belgium is observing through coinmemoratives and countless other ways the 400th anniversary of the birth of the great Flemish artist, Peter Paul Rubens. With other countries joining in, and many more to come, Rubens Year 1977 will be a prime occasion for collectors.

title: The Death Penalty And the Governor
description: AFTER several months of negotiation, the New Jersey Legislature has reached agreement on the reinstitution of capital punishment. Now that both houses have passed a compromise deathpenalty bill, Governor Byrne is being pressed to sign the legislation into law. It is ironic that Mr. Byrne should have the final voice in this matter.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY?; The Old College Try (Motorized Div.)
description: FRANKLY, I don't go along with all the fuss being made about Governor Byrne's daughter using a New Jersey state car for her personal use while attending Georgetown University in Washington. The way I see it, here is a mana father faced with those awful college tuition billssimply trying to make ends meet. I mean, Brendan Byrne has shown us the way, just as a Governor and first citizen of his state should.

title: Even the Orchestra Applauds When He Takes the Podium
description: Making his way through the music stands to the podium, Klaus Tennstedt broke into a smile as he saw the members of the Toronto Symphony stamping their feet and applauding. It was only a rehearsal, with no one watching from those empty seats out front, but there he was, receiving a miniature ovation.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: CLEVELANDOne brief thaw late in winter does not herald the arrival of spring, but the warmer temperatures of the last two weeks have gladdened the spirits of leading businessmen here and in other parts of the industrial heartland in the eastern half of the country.

title: Mets: Shaky Down the Middle
description: Three of the 10 best earnedrun averages in the National League last year belonged to Tom Seaver, Jerry Koosman and Jon Matlack, and the best team average belonged to the New York Mets. But once that glittering fact is established, the tide creeps in.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHILE other Princetonians were enjoying the pastoral pursuits of summer, Donald Warnock was redecorating and stocking the Princeton Gourmet a store that has been in business locally for 23 years and one that he bought six months ago.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One of the three upperlevel westbound lanes on the George Washington Bridge will be closed Tuesday as work begins on the resurfacing of the bridge. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the lane would be closed after the morning rush hour. One lane is scheduled to be closed until midJuly, when resurfacing of all of the bridge highway is expected to be completed.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Help for Atlantic Salmon
description: Regarded by some as the enfant terrible of international Atlantic salmon fisheries negotiations, and by others as one of the salmon's most effective charnpitins, Richard A. Buck of Hancock, N. H., was jubilant a few days ago when he reported that additional protection for his favorite fish was forthcoming.

title: Farm Area Down, Land Prices Up
description: HOW many farms are there in Connecticut? Is it 3,799? Or 3,401? Or 2,441? The correct answer, according to a preliminary report of the 1974 National Census of Agriculture, just released, is any one of these figures. It all depends on which defenition of a farm is used, and there are three definitions in the census report.

title: World's Best Selling Scotch: Made in Japan
description: GOTEMBA, JapanThe Japanese are famous for their ability to mimic foreign products, which they then market at lower prices than the original. But no other product has given more headaches to its foreign originators than Japanese Scotch whisky.

title: Directory Planned Of Female Leaders In 4 Ethnic Groups
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 19A new type of Who's Who, to be known as a Directory of Significant 20th Century American Minority Women, is being compiled here. If all goes well, it should be ready for the printer by Dec. 31.

title: N.F.L. OldTimers Get Bigger Benefits
description: While the current group of pro football players awaits the details of the new pact with management to determine their degree of satisfaction, another contingent is expressing gratitude. For the oldtimers, players whose careers finished before 1959 and who were therefore excluded from the munificent Bert Bell pension plan, the National Football League has begun to provide increased benefits. Grateful now, the oldtimers at first had to fight for what they believed was right. The fight was worth it.

title: Living Too Close To the Water's Edge
description: IN the cluttered back office of Squires Mens and Boys Apparel in Chappaqua a light tan water stain reaches 40 inches up the beaverboard wall. At the top of that stain is penciled Sept. 26, 1975, and Larry Caso, who owns Squires, recalls that day.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Dr. Bernard R. Gifford, Deputy Chancellor, New York City public schools.

title: Miss O'Donnell Wed To Jeffrey B. Carroll
description: Lynda Ann O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. O'Donnell of Guilford, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. George's Roman Catholic Church, to Jeffrey Burke Carroll, son of Sidney Burke Carroll of New York and Thomas S. Carroll of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Daniel McSheffrey performed the ceremony.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, through its new Rule 317 on replacement cost accounting, is requiring that the accounting profession and some 1,000 nonfinancial corporations muddy the waters in this year's annual reports with the inclusion of highly controversial estimates on replacement cost accounting.

title: POLITICS
description: IT was all sweetness and light when Gilbert C. Hanse, the Village of Babylon Mayor and Town of Babylon Republican leaderan interesting combinationwas elected Suffolk County Republican Party chairman earlier this month.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AFTER a hectic week of writing to meet a deadline, I took an afternoon off recently to unwind. Outside, the sun reflected brightly off the ice covering East Bay, and an almost balmy air temperature of 37 degrees was luring me out.

title: The Case of Norwalk's Sinking Homes
description: IF YOU SINK your money into a house, should you have to watch the house sink too? That is a question confronting a group of frustrated people who invested their savings in the purchase of private houses in a middleincome development in Norwalk.

title: Fashion
description: Shortly after the November elections, two Americans who had been very much in the national limelight visited their optometrists.

title: American Civil Liberties Union Finds Itself in the Midst of Wrenching Internal Debate on Goals and Methods
description: Longtime friends in the American Civil Liberties Union no longer speak to one another, a disputed election has divided and embarrassed the organization, and two of its leading lawyers have resigned, asserting that the organization has lost its values and become too docile.

title: Letters, Numbers, It's All in the Game
description: RECREATIONAL mathematicians in New Jersey, are no doubt familiar with puzzles in which letters are substituted for numbers, and the problem is to find out what number each letter stands for. A simple example should suffice for those not familiar with the form:

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market staged a technical rally last week, after six consecutive weeks of declines, with the Dow Jones industrial average moving ahead 8.72 points to 940.24.

title: Matzohs Shipped to Jews in Egypt
description: More than a ton of matzohsflat thin unleavened bread essential for the observance of Passoverleft a Brooklyn pier last week aboard the Prudential Lines steamship Lash Pacifico, bound for Alexandria to enable Egypt's 400 Jews to celebrate one of their major festivals which this year begins at sundown on April 2.

title: Leon Hess, the Jets' New Muscle
description: Nov that the Jets have arranged a Shea Stadium treaty with the Mets, it's time they arranged Joe Namath's future.

title: Prisoners to Get Community Aid
description: TO EASE overcrowding at state prisons and to prepare inmates for a return to society, state correction officials have contracted with a communitybased group to provide a residential setting for prisoners who are within six months of parole or release.

title: INDOCHINA REFUGEES FIND U.S. LIFE HARSH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.19Most of the 145,000 Indochinese refugees who have fled to the United States since South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were taken over by the Communists seem to be finding life in this strange new land a harsh and often unrewarding struggle.

title: Kiss Satisfies Need for Glitter At Rock Show
description: Stumbling in the darkness into a Kiss concert, as this wellmeaning observer did Friday at Madison Square Garden, might lead one directly to dire meditations on the decline of Western civilization. How else, after all, are we to interpret an entertainment that highlights a bass player spitting blood atop a tower, surrounded by swirls of smoke and bathed in bilious green light, all the while dressed in a blackleather and silver costume that makes him look like a diabolical armadillo? And the sight of this apparition evoking a dull, throaty roar of appreciation from the soldout house, the cries of the multitude overlaid with the treble piping of a large prepubescent minority?

title: Looking at Life From a Tollbooth Window
description: FROM her window in a tollbooth on the Hutchinson River Parkway, near the Bronx city line, Madeline Jones enjoys a distinctive view of the world.

title: Physicians' Assistants Face Loss Of Right to Prescribe Medication
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19The new chairman of the Assembly's Education Committee, citing questions of competence and the possibility of malpractice, has prepared legislation that would cancel a regulation allowing physicians' assistants to write prescriptions.

title: MRS. ABZUG REJECTS ADMINISTRATION JOB
description: Former Representative Bella S. Abzug said yesterday that she would not accept President Carter's offer of a post in his Administration. The decision appeared to move her closer to a race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York.

title: On Ethics: Let the Third Shoe Drop
description: Today is a $13,100 clay for members of Congress, Federal judges and other officials. This is the effective date of the first meaningful Federal pay raise since 1969. It is to be welcomed. High officials should not be left so unprotected against inflation that they must grope for outside income or abandon public service. The new raise is necessary and just.

title: Art Carney: I Brought the Paunch To the Part
description: LOS ANGELES You look too old to be a cop, says the wiseguy young gardener to Art Carney's Ira Wells, the brokendown private eye in the new hit film The Late Show. Don't worry, replies Wells, this is just a disguise.

title: The Hostelries And Beaches of Modern Cancun
description: And now the wunderkind has come of age. Nine hotels and a Club Mediterranee have reared up on the smokesoft beaches of Cancun. Many more are under way. The airport hacked out of the Yucatan jungle echoes to the roar of jets disgorging legions of pastyfaced North Americans who are beginning to pack the offshore sandspit, filling the deck chairs, crisscrossing its waters. . . .

title: Astronauts Simulate Flight in a Mock Space Shuttle Run by Computer
description: DOWNEY, Calif., Feb. 19Leo Krupp sat in the cockpit, clutching the hand controller. Ahead, he could see what appeared to be the runway at Cape Canaveral. Fla., looming closer and closer.

title: Realty News
description: Occupancy in New York City's hotels and motor hotels climbed last year to ifs highest levels since 1969 and improved almost 10 percent over 1975, according to Stephen W. Brener, senior vice president of HelmsleySpear Inc. and head of that company's hospitality division.

title: Sunday Observer
description: After his recent visit to Tokyo, Vice President Mondale revealed that he and the Japanese had discussed a broad range of issues. Anyone who has ever gazed on this magnificent range can imagine the poetic nature of the Vice President's talk with the Japanese, for it is one of the most moving spectacles nature affords.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: VERY often when a job pops up that calls for the use of an electric soldering iron or gun, the handyman finds that he can't locate his spool of solderor he forgets to take it along when he takes the tool to the place where the work is to be done. One handy way to keep the wire solder always readily available is to wrap a length of it ??nd the electric cord, near the handle, as shown in the photograph at right. That way, the solder will always be stored with the gun or iron, and it will always be ready for use when needed.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED ON BMT AFTER A RAPE ATTEMPT
description: A man who allegedly tried to rape a woman in a Brooklyn subway station early yesterday morning was arrested by Transit Authority policemen minutes later.

title: SHOT FIRED INTO A HOME WOUNDS BROOKLYN GIRL, 10
description: A 10yearold Brooklyn girl sitting in her living room was shot last night by an assailant who fired a shotgun blast, through a window into her family's firstfloor apartment. The girl, Marie Snead of 736 Schneck Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, was listed in good condition at Brookdale Hospital with pellet wounds in the hack.

title: Birthdays
description: Some people are embarrassed or depressed by birthdays, or resent or forget them. Not Linda Rannells Lewis. To her, a birthday is a feast of personal resurrection, a time to celebrate myself, to dance on tables if I have a mind to. So unabashed is she by her annual milestone that she starts right out by telling us how old she is (look it up yourselfpage 4), and then moves naturally into a charming, unhurried meditation on the theme of birthdays in general.

title: What's Doing is BERLIN
description: ISLANDBerlin is an island, truncated and maimed but doggedly clinging to life, a glittering great city set in the sandy plains of Brandenburg, no longer the capital of Germany but still the leading German metropolis. Berlin not only survived World War II and the Cold War era but continues to thrive under duress. The war left the city in ruins, with 80 percent of its housing and public buildings damaged or destroyed. Life postwar EastWest conflict wrenched Berlin in two, the strife culminating in the erection of the Wall, that modern anachronism of barbed wire and concrete, as the dividing line between West Berlin, showcase and Western outpost, and East Berlin, capital of the Communist German Democratic Republic. Since the Communist sealoff in 1961, West Berlin has been ringed by a 100mile perimeter of fences, wire and border fortifications, with just a few outlets for travel. But in the five years since the Big Powers concluded their Berlin pact, tensions have gradually subsided and the city has ceased being one of the world's perennial trouble spots. Berlin affords, tourists the opportunity of seeing East and West almost at a single glance. Visits to East Berlin from the Western half are possible and worthwhile. Firsttime visitors need valid passports, and the East Germans have since the beginning of this year required tourists to obtain visas on crossing to East Berlin. Visas are available for $2 at the border checkpoints. No visas are required for Americans or other Westerners*entering West Berlin.

title: Is He a Galahad or Just a Gadfly?
description: ?? are two predominant ?? about Robert Jan Mrazck, the youngest member of the Suffolk County Legislature. There is the view that the 30yearold Democrat from Centerport is brash, arrogant and more concerned with hogging headlines than with formulating substantive policy. This view is held by many of Mr. Mrazek's colleagues in the 18member Legislature, some of whom are naturally envious of the publicity that the freshman Legislator has obtained in the last 12 months, his first year in office.

title: Must We Really Be the Things That We Own?
description: CHAIRLIFT Number Two ascends the lower slopes of Stratton Mountain in Vermont carrying a suburban housewife on her Dynastar skis. The noise is unbearable. Snowmaking machines, propelled by jet engines, smother some of her words. She repeats that she has lived in Simsbury, Conn., for seven years and she is lonely. Her neighbors want to talk about plants and homes, she wants to talk about politics and poetry. She made some friends through the Great Books Club but is usually treated as an appendagethe mother of X, the wife of Y. She rarely sees people on the streets. There are no sidewalks in Simsbury.

title: The Cinderella of Instruments Finds a Prince Charming
description: A masterclass for viola players? There was a time, and not so long ago, when such an idea would have prompted a laugh in the music business. The Cinderella of instruments, pining for so long by the fireside, seemed scarcely the thing for solo exploits, and a masterclass would probably have betrayed two serious weaknessesthe shortage of a master and the shortage of a class. But no he is laughing this season as that unquestioned master, Walter Trampler, takes his instrument to the stage of the Mannes School for three such sessions, the last of them to be held on March 3 (the first was closed to the public, the second took place earlier this month).

title: Allbritton's Name Is Back On The Washington Star But as Chairman Now
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The name of Joe L. Allbritton, the millionaire banker from Texas who bought control of the financially troubled Washington Star for about $28 million in 1974, reappeared on the newspaper's masthead in Sunday's editions after an unexplained absence of two weeks but as chairman of the board rather than publisher.

title: A Tomato of the Future?
description: EVERY year Connecticut disposes of more than 100,000 tons of sewage sludge that, although it can serve as an excellent soil conditioner and fertilizer, is usually burned or buried.

title: A Home for Lindy's Plane
description: ROOSEVELT FIELD A FEW weeks ago, the Jenny sped past the President of the United States, but these days she is hanging from the rafters at Roosevelt Field.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Seedsmen know the way to a gardener's heart. The growfromseed geraniums they introduced a few years ago are a smashing success. With minimum effort the seeds take hold when started indoors and the plants grow quickly into magnificent size for the garden with beautiful, colorful flowers. Everyone who has tried them finds a special delight in raising their own geraniums from seed.

title: Report From New York's Rock Underground
description: The New York rock scene of the past couple of years has attracted an enormous amount of attention, but up to now nobody except those who went down to CBGB's or Max's Kansas City could actually hear all the music. Now, with the release this past week of Television's Elektra album, Marquee Moon, all the major New York bands of this sort are represented by nationally distributed record labels, and outsiders are at last in a position to draw their own conclusions.

title: On the Border: Barriers and Anger
description: JOE FURFARO gets a chuckle from telling people that I own the county line. The southern boundary of his yard in Pearl River is, in fact, the border separating Rockland County in New York and Bergen County in New Jersey.

title: SCANDAL IN ISRAEL BUOYS RABIN RIVALS
description: JERUSALEM, Fell 19A scandal that is rocking Israel's ruling Labor Party has buoyed the hopes of two politicians, one a Labor stalwart and the other a novice who heads a new Israeli party that calls for electoral and social changes.

title: THE NIGHT CARTER TOOK OVER THE PARTY
description: WALTER Mondale was sitting in the living room of the Kennedy Suite on the 34th floor of the Carlyle Hotel, the suite John F. Kennedy had often used while President. At the Carlyle, the bellmen wore white gloves, but Mondale was wearing old slacks and sneakers, alternately pacing to the windows and drinking coffee, then trying to make conversation with his wife, Joan, and three staff members. No one could think of much to say. The telephone rangMondale's administrative assistant, Richard Moe, looked at his watchat 8:26 A.M.

title: MAILBAG
description: To The Editor:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: VERY often when a job pops up that calls for the use of an electric soldering iron or gun, the handyman finds that he can't locate his spool of solderor he forgets to take it along when he takes the tool to the place where the work is to be done. One handy way to keep the wire solder always readily available is to wrap a length of around the electric cord, near the handle, as shown in the photograph at right. That way, the solder will always be stored with the gun or iron, and it will always be ready for use when needed.

title: Carter Ignores Soviet on Dissent
description: Washington's rhetorical campaign on behalf of the rights of dissenters in Communistbloc nations has taken on significant new dimensions following President Carter's strongest thrust yet: Despite Soviet objections to his past efforts on human rights, he wrote a personal and supportive letter to Andrei Sakharov, the prominent physicist and leading Russian dissident.

title: Exurbia Schools Struggle With Rising Enrollment and Limited Funds
description: BOHEMIA, N.Y., Feb. 19Scattered around the country are dozens of school districtsa few of them here in eastern Long Islandthat exemplify a curious phenomenon. Their enrollments are continuing to expand while most of the school systems around them are retrenching.

title: Riyadh Is No Longer Just Another Mideast Capital
description: In recent days, two principal actors on the Middle East diplomatic stage have made separate but related pilgrimages to the remote Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh. Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organizaton, flew in for talks with the Saudi leaders on Thursday, and Secretary of State Cyrus Vance arrived there yesterday. Both journeys, coming in a fastpaced week of Middle East maneuverings, reveal much about where the real power lies in that part of the world.

title: Article 6  No Title
TEAR GAS CANNISTER SET OFF AT THE MET
description: A nearcapacity audience of almost 4,000 operagoers, expecting the curtain to rise on Poulenc's Dialogues of the Carmelites were routed from the Metropolitan Opera last night by the acrid fumes of a tear gas canister set off in the house while the musicians were tuning up.

title: Lynn M. Porsche Is Married to Gary Schultz
description: The First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lynn Maigret Porsche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Louis Porsche of New Canaan, to Gary Gerold Schultz, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Victor Carl Schultz of Sun City, Ariz.

title: Daytona 500 Slated Today And the Accent Is Modified
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19The Daytona 500, the $414,000 crown jewel of what has become the most popular form of automobile racing in the world, will have two added starters tomorrowa woman and a hyphen.

title: Italian Reds Facing Problems of Growth
description: ROME, Feb. 19After a period of steady growth, the Italian Communist Party is coming under new pressures.

title: Train Opposes Nuclear Power
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)Russell E. Train, the former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, says American energy policy should aim for the phasing out and eventual elemination of all nuclear power.

title: WIDOW OF DOUBLE AGENT SUING OVER HIS DEATH
description: EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 19 (AP)Acting on written instructions from her husband, the widow of a double agent for United States Army Intelligence has filed $22.5million suit against eight Army officers, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and party or parties unknown in the Army, F.B.I. and Central Intelligence Agency.

title: But Not Much Has Improved For Nation's Migrant Workers
description: LOS ANGELES In a movie called Bound for Glory, Woody Guthrie is transformed from an aimless itinerant sign painter into a driven union organizer by the sight of migrant farmworkers in California, people without steady work, permanent homes and the confidence that next week they would eat.

title: His Specialty Is Comedy With A Cutting Edge
description: I guess I have played a few heels lately, said Charles Grodin, looking sheepish and a bit puzzled. I like to think I have almost none of that in me. But I sure do understand it in othersand even more, I find it funny. Grodin's knack for comedy with a cutting edge has won him applause and a growing following on Broadway and in Hollywood. He was the engagingly sincere philanderer in Same Time, Next Year, opposite Ellen Burstyn, when that durable comedy opened at the Brooks Atkinson two years ago. Before that, in the 1972 film The Heartbreak Kid, he coolly abandoned his new wife, Jeannie Berlin, in their honeymoon suite and went drooling off after Cybill Shepherd. Currently, in the updated movie of King Kong, he is Fred Wilson, the grim and greedy oilman who stops at nothing in the way of exploiting the lovesmitten ape until Kong finally puts his foot down (on him).

title: Arkansas Widow, 63, Battles Ozark Hunters Who Invade Her Retreat
description: HATTON, Ark., Feb. 19After traveling alone in 53 countries without incident, 63yearold Billee Sanford bought a 10acre retreat here in the Ozark Mountains and settled down to the quiet life. But Mrs. Sanford is an animal lover and her retreat near Whiskey Peak is in the middle of mountain hunting country.

title: Town Hit by a BirthControl Riot Looks Forward to Indian Election
description: MUZAFFARNAGAR, IndiaThe old man stroked his scraggly white beard thoughtfully as his friends, nodding agreement, pressed, close around to hear his streetcorner pronouncement: We can't let the Government get away with all this coercion in family planning. I'll vote for anyone who is against it.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IT'S AN exciting time to be part of that challenge . . .
