When Governor Byrne is speaking, his listeners aren't sure whether the line like the foregoing is just his speechwriter's wellmeaning cliche or whether the Governor is about to spring another joke on them in his deceptive, deadpan style.

title: Brash, young and postmodern
description: The typical successful architect's office is cool and sleek, with Breuer chairs, soft lighting and perhaps a modern print or two. But the headquarters of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates in an old office building in Manhattan's East 20's contains a moose head, a carpet from the old Boxy Theater, a neon sign blaring A Spicier New York is Up to You and, in the place of honor where certificates attesting to the architects legal registration are usually hung, one partner's Army discharge and another's elementaryschool diploma.

title: Yale Ponders A New Kingman
description: IT will be many months, perhaps a year or more, before the 18 trustees of Yale University cast their votes from highbacked chairs at Woodbridge Hall to elect a new president for the university, but the ritual has begun.

title: Elizabeth Compton, Smith Alumna, Engaged
description: Elizabeth Ayers Compton, director of music at the First Baptist Church in Northampton, Mass., and Andrew Howard Eichenfield, who is in his third year at the Chicago Medical School, plan to be married.

title: Give Me a Ring Not in Jakarta
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaDespite a new $840 million domestic communications network that includes a domestic satellite system, the telephone continues to be the most persistent frustration for foreign businessmen in Jakarta.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: ALICE IN WONDERLAND, by Lewis Carroll. (St. Martin's Press $4.95.) A score of editions of this Victorian classic are available in soft covers, but this largetype, largeformat version enhances its appeal for young and old; 42 of John Tenniel's original illustrations take on more by being magnified.

title: Madelle Grassi Becomes Bride
description: Madelle Hegeler Grassi of Southampton, L.I., and New York was married yesterday afternoon to George G. Semerjian, president of Meadowmere Construction and Real Estate Corporation in Southampton.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Points are out of fashion. On the stage, nowadays, the point of a play is rarely its point. It is the style and complications that count; the mess more than the message. It is the sensation of flight, the small updrafts, that provide the excitement; not the destination, which tends to amount to a great circle and back to the place we took off from.

title: Guilt and Pride Felt by Youths Viewing Roots
description: The morning after Kunta Kinte's foot was cut off on the television series Roots because he had tried to run away from slavery, a black pupil walked into his high school in New Orleans and said he wanted to fight somebody.

title: 9 Aces Help Gerulaitis Overcome Lutz in Final
description: OCEAN CITY, Md., Feb. 19 (AP) Vitas Gerulaitis settled down after a shaky start and scored a 36, 61, 62 victory over Bob Lutz today in the final of the $100,000 Ocean City International tennis tournament.

title: Both Sides Of the Concorde
description: In what has become as much a political dispute as one concerning the nuisance potential of the supersonic Concorde jet, President Carter has issued statements on New York City's ban of Concorde landings that (1) reaffirmed to the British and French Governments the Ford Administration's authorization of 16month tests of the AngloFrench plane at Kennedy International Airport and at Washington's Dulles Airport, and (2) made it clear he could not order New York authorities to let the Concordes in.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: San Jose Nursery Benefit
description: The 16th annual bridge party and fashion show for the benefit of the San Jos Day Nursery will be held Saturday afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Tickets ($25 for patrons or $5 for individuals) can be obtained from the beneficiary at 432 West 20th Street.

title: INTERVIEW
description: AFTER 24 years as a New York. City firefighter24 years during which he was blown from the roof of a blazing pier, suffered injuries ranging from scalds to burns, survived the collapse of burning buildings and witnessed the sudden death of his comrades Joseph E. Galvin went into retirement at the age of 50 on the first day of 1977.

title: Susan V Bergesch, Banker, Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis William Bergesch of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Virginia Bergesch, to Eugene Baylis Shanks Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Shanks of Nashville. The couple plan to be married in April.

title: HUSSEIN RELUCTANT TO FORM P.L.O. LINK BEFORE ARAB ASSENT
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 19King Hussein of Jordan has told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance that he is reluctant to forge a link with the Palestine Liberation Organization until key Arab leaders formally join with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in proposing such a move to overcome the Middle East diplomatic deadlock.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Luv, by Murray Schisgal, starring Neil Hirsch. Kate Hulbert and Bill Felts. Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and a matinee performance Thursday at 2 P.M. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6. $4.50 to $6.50. Discounts for groups, students and the elderly are available for all performances except Saturday evening. 6281169.

title: Karen Mannarino, Teacher, Married to David C. Frisch
description: Karen Lundquist Mannarino and David Craig Frisch, both of Baldwin, L.I., were married there yesterday morning in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. R. Sidney Pinch.

title: Academy Aims to Develop Top Skiers
description: LAST BURKE, Vt.I'll tell you where our future ski champions will come from, said Warren Witherell, headmaster of Burke Mountain Academy. We're going to have to raise them. And right here at Burke, we're doing our part. Convinced that development programs right on the mountain were the only Skiing ways to create top American Alpine competitors on a sustained basis, Witherell founded his school in 1970. His curriculum, which offers a high school diploma as well as the chance to become a top racer, has been highly successful.

title: Freebies for Soil and Soul
description: EVERY fall, Scarsdale homeowners pile their leaves by the curb where a village truck scoops them up. In the spring, they claim them back as black gold a mix of composted leaves and fertilizer used to enrich the soil.

title: P.L.O. Uncertain on Hussein Talks In Wake of C.I.A.'s Aid Disclosures
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19The Palestine Liberation Organization is considering whether it wants to go ahead with planned talks with King Hussein of Jordan following published reports that the American Central Intelligence Agency had made secret payments to the monarch for 20 years.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER ton Avenue, SomersetBarefoot in the Park. Wednesday and Sunday, 8 P.M.; Friday and Saturday, 7 P.M. (through March 6). $16. including dinner; group rates. Reservations suggested. (201) 4692522.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MAYBE it's because of these foul weekends that start on Fridays with media predictions of disastrous storms that always seem to work into only an annoying light fall of snow. Or the predictions of snow flurries that leave kneehigh drifts in the driveway. At any rate, they've scared us, and we haven't had any kind of social season to brag of since winter began.

title: Jack Dweck Will Marry Shari A. Koslowe
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Koslowe of Mamaroneck, N. Y.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shari Ann Koslowe, to Jack Dweck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Dweck of Brooklyn. The couple plan to be married on June 5.

title: Miss Rising Is the Fiancee Of P. J. Turner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Rising Jr. of Brightwaters and Glen Head, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Anne Rising, to Preston John Turner, son of Ethel Persons Turner of Williston, Vt., and the late ?? M. Turner.

title: The Changing Patterns of Life
description: The Bureau of the Census has confirmed statistically the extent to which basic changes In marriage and family living have taken place in the United States.

title: Purtzer Leads Wadkins by 3 Strokes at 66201
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19In each of the six pro golf tournaments played thus far this season, the winner was either the leader or coleader at the end of the third round. If that pattern holds up in the finale of the 51st Los Angeles open tomorrow, Tom Purtzer will win.

title: Little Angie
description: Anyone who writes a Gothic tale faces the problem of what to do with the banalities inherent in the genre. Little Angie and The Shining use radically different strategies: the first is parody, the other ignores the problem altogether.

title: Former Bank Aide And 2 Others Guilty In $ 1 Million Fraud
description: A former Chemical Bank official and two other men have been found guilty of a conspiracy charge and the misapplication of $1.2 million of bank funds obtained through a series of improper loans.

title: Instant Replay in Parks: Not Until It's Perfect
description: There are few objective sports fans to most fans, officials are good or bad depending upon the outcome of a controversial decision.

title: The Message Is, Recycle When Starting Seeds Indoors
description: Years ago, when life seemed simpler and a penny saved was still a penny earned, housewives as well as professional nurserymen discovered the value of salvaging tin cans for use as plant containers. These improvised pots may not have been beautiful, and they tended to rust, but they were cheap and served their purpose.

title: Mary O'Horo Engaged To Michael Silverman
description: Mrs. William J. O'Horo of Canton, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Teresa O'Horo, to Michael Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Silverman of Cambridge and Rockport, Mass.

title: Horse Shows
Italian Government Is Demanding Stricter Laws Against Handguns Following a Series of Violent Incidents
description: ROME, Feb. 19After a series of incidents in which several persons have been killed, the Italian Government has decided to ask stricter penalties for illegal use of handguns and other weapons.

title: Were the 1952 Pirates the Worst Ever? Maybe So
description: One of my favorite events on baseball schedules is OldTimers' Day. Many clubs hold theirs in connection with an event, like the 20th anniversary of winning a pennant

title: Denunciation by Vatican
description: ROME, Feb. 19 (UPI)The Vatican radio described Uganda's official explanation of the death of Archbishop Janani Luwum as unswallowable today. It said news of the Archbishop's death was painful but not surprising and called him a martyr.

title: Anne P. Young, Thomas Cosden Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Anne Payne Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hendricks Young of New York, to Thomas B. Cosden took place last evening at the home in Englewood, N.J., of Mrs. James M. Cosden, mother of the bridegroom. Mayor Sondra Greenberg of Englewood performed the ceremony. Norma Cirincione and Gordon Sancher attended the couple.

title: F.A.L.N. Tied To 49 Blasts Since Aug. '74
description: Following is a list of 49 explosions attributed to the Fuerzas Armadas de Liberacion National (F.A.L.N.) by its own claims or those of investigators, as compiled from records of the New York City Police Department and other law enforcement agencies:

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: 1977, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Saturday, Feb. 19. 41st day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: So. Connecticut Takes Title in Eastern Track
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP)Southern Connecticut, led by George Springsteen, rallied in the final two events today to beat Brandeis and Coast Guard for the Eastern intercollegiate indoor track and field championship. Springsteen won the pole vault by clearing 15 feet and Wayne Durrigan took third in the shotput with a toss of 50 feet 10 inches. That enabled Southern Connecticut to finish with 39 points, including 26 in the field events.

title: Dr. Marietta Guidon Is Bride of Conrad Grundlehner
description: Dr. Marietta Ferebee Guidon, a resident physician in her second year at the Jefferson Medical Center in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Conrad Ernest Grundlehner, manager of computer application for Hay Associates, Philadelphia management consultants.

title: 15 Horses Dead in Fire At New England Raceway
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP)Fifteen race horses perished in a fire that broke out shortly before dawn today at New England Harness Raceway.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Yankees: Fearsome on the Field
description: On paper, green (for money) paper, the Yankees have the most fearsome team in the American League. In the clubhouse, they also may have the most fightable team in the American League.

title: Laetitia Kelly Frothingham Is Betrothed To Stephen Mead Jr., an Aide of Citibank
description: Laetitia Kelly Frothingham, an administrative assistant for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and Stephen Mead Jr., who is with the correspondent banking division of Citibank, will be married in April.

title: Zummo Concert at the Intermedia
description: The Experimental Intermedia Foundation, a loft at 224 Centre Street that is genially run by the composer Phill Niblock, is in the midst of one of its periodic festivals of contemporary music. Peter Zummo opened the series on Friday night with a concert he called The Trombone That Devoured Cleveland. Michael Cooper will be presenting his Perfection Is Not an Accident tonight, and Scott Johnson's Strictly Business will be performed tomorrow night. The events are at 9 P.M.

title: In Business To Find the Unfound
description: THE callers are all seeking that elusive something, but it is rarely love they are after. More likely they want a backyard skating rink, or a bongo drum, or a touch football team, and can't find them. So they turn to one of two county finding services thatone for a fee, one for freewill make the search.

title: Turnpike Drops CrossState Road
description: FACED with insurmountable financial odds and political opposition, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has finally abandoned its efforts to construct a 38mile expressway diagonally across the center of the state.

title: Katherine Harjes Roberts Married to Michael Billig
description: Katherine Hades Roberts of Westburg, Vt., widow of Lieut. Cyrus S. Roberts, U.S.A., was married yesterday to Michael Franklin Billig, a chiropractor in St. Johnsbury, Vt. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elmer S. Billig in St. Johnsbury by the Rev. Clyde Campbell, a Congregational minister.

title: Marcia Hamill Married
description: Marcia Ann Hamill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chalmers Martin Hamill Jr. of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to John Michael Blake of Greenwich, Conn. He is a son of the late Mary Fusich Blake and the late John J. Blake 3d and stepson of Madeliene K. Blake of Greenwich. The Rev. Donald Stauffer performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside. Dorothy Hamill, the figure skater, was maid of honor for her sister and James L. Dunster served as best man.

title: Criminals At Large
description: For a lively and complicated story of highlevel maneuvering, take a look at THREE POTATO, FOUR by Wilfred Greatorex (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $8.95). It's espionage, in a way; and finance in a way; and also a love story, in a way. Altogether it's a heady mix in which there is never a relaxation of tension.

title: Paulus Hook: Disputed Enclave
description: JERSEY CITY To get to Paulus Hook, this city's oldest neighborhood, from the westsay, from the Greenville section  the traveler probably would proceed along a dismal stretch of Grand Street embodying rotting tenements, tomblike housing projects and longabandoned lots where winter winds rip through discarded furniture. That is, before he comes to the neat rows of darkcolored brownstones that characterize Paulus Hook's pocket of downtown.

title: Heavy Snowstorms Upstate Caused A Major Decline in Milk Receipts
description: Stormforced milk dumping by upstate dairy farmers contributed to a 10 million pound decline in milk receipts in the New YorkNew Jersey milk marketing area in January 1977, compared to January 1976.

title: For young readers
description: Ashanti to Zulu, which has been awarded the 1977 Caldecott Medal for excellence in illustration, is a large, colorfully illustrated book that strives to introduce the reader to 26 African peoples by depicting a custom important to each. A single custom can hardly convey much that is meaningful about any culture, and in that sense the hook is severely limited. Within those limitations, however, interesting facts abound.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENERS in suburbia are getting back to nature. If the trend continues, the power mower may become a relic in back of the garage.

title: Dare to Be Great
description: This is a good little book about an earnest con artist who ripped off the American public for $75 million. Glenn W. Turner, who was frequently described himself as a harelipped sharecropper's son (leaving some doubt as to which of them was afflicted), built an ephemeral fortune on a pyramid selling scheme in the late 1960's and early 70's. He first pushed cosmetics and later a motivation course called Dare to Be Great. But the real bait was the right to sell the righttosell to other suckers on the principle of a chain letter. One bought a cosmetics distributorship for $4,500 and became entitled to sell distributorships to others, pocketing a fat commission. Turner packaged this dubious enterprise with a religious fervor that would make Billy Sunday look like the Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Scoppetta Takes Over the Inquiry On School Custodians' Operations
description: The New York City Investigation Commissioner, intervening at the request of the Board of Education, has taken complete charge of the citywide inquiry into allegations or corruption in the $100 millionayear custodial service program.

title: ART
description: IT is at once disturbing and heartening to write about the Long Island Professional Artists Guild exhibition on view at the Union Carbide Building in New York City. And it would perhaps be best to rid ourselves of the disturbances immediately, for in that way we can end on an upbeat note.

title: Questions/Answers
description: CONTROL FOR STEM BORERS

title: Cholesterol's Transportation
description: High cholesterol levels in the blood do nut necessarily always portend increased risk of heart attack, according to recent studies. What matters is which of several cholesterolcarrying chemicals is responsible for the high cholesterol levels.

title: Nigerian Soldiers Burn Home of a Dissident Musician
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 19Several hundred soldiers attacked the home of Nigeria's bestknown musician and most prominent dissident yesterday, setting ablaze and touching off a fivehour disturbance in the sprawling slum section of Lagos known as Surulere.

title: Miss Seaman Bride Of Christopher Kuhn
description: Deborah Hayes Seaman and Christopher Leo Kuhn were married yesterday in the Westover School Chapel in Middlebury, Conn., by the Rev. John Gibson, an Episcopal priest.

title: THEATER
description: IN the film All About Eve, a Hollywoodbaund theater director defends his move by saying, Wherever there's magic and make believe and an audiencethere's Theater. He defines theater as encompassing everyone from the Lone Ranger to Sarah Bernhardt, and concludes with: The theater's for everybodyyou included, but not exclusivelyso don't approve or disapprove. It may not be your theater, but it's theater for somebody, somewhere.

title: Anthony Crosland Is Dead at 58; Foreign Secretary for Past Year
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Anthony Crosland, the British Foreign Secretary, died before dawn today at the Radcliffe Infirmary in Oxford, where he had been taken after suffering a stroke last Sunday. He was 58 years old.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: As frigid temperatures began moving across much of the country again last week and threatened to deliver another body blow to the dwindling supplies of natural gas and other heating fuels, the heavy cost of the American energy crisis of 1977 was being toted up in the nation's capital and elsewhere.

title: G.M. Is Target of Inquiry By Justice Department Into Possible Tax Fraud
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19 (UPI)The Justice Department, already investigating the General Motors Corporation on antitrust matters, is taking another look at the world's largest automobile manufacturer from a tax fraud standpoint.

title: American League: Orioles Weaker, Indians Stronger, Watch Out for the Angels
description: Through the departure of a trio of free agents, the Orioles figure to be weaker in offense, defense and pitching this season. So what else is there?

title: Sadat Squeezes P.L.O. So It Will Fit Into Geneva
description: The diplomatic effort to resume the ArabIsraeli peace talks in Geneva gained considerable momentum last week during Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to the Middle East with the public suggestion by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that the Palestinians join a confederation with Jordan. Since to the weakened Palestinians such a suggestion is almost a directive, the effect was to increase optimism that the Geneva talks can be resumed this year, even though substantial obstacles remain.

title: A Yacht or a Garden for an Opulent Wedding
description: For his 60th birthday, an unsuspecting Edwin Beinecke, a director of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, was driven in a rented limousine up the ramp: of a Staten Island ferry where 200 friends waited. Cheering wildly and waving hats, the wellwishers and the guest of honor sailed up the Hudson while a band played and cocktails were served.

title: The Offseason Blues of an Auto Driver
description: I don't know how many times I've towed my formula roadracing car (a smaller version of Grand Prix Formula One machines) all night to a race and stopped at a gas station where the attendant points to the trailer and asks, Hey, feller, is that a boat?

title: Organized Labor Is Catching On in the South
description: ATLANTAIf the last two decades can be called the years of civil rights revolution in the South, the next two are likely to belong to a revolution of a different kind: the rise of organized labor in the South. Unlike the civil rights revolution, however, there has been no watershed, such as the United States Supreme Court decision of 1954, that marks the beginning of change. Instead, there has been a slow chipping away of Southern resistance to organized labor, both in the courts and in the plants.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge, Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien. Conn. Suitable, local and children's working hunters; pleasure horses, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Mr. Rabin Is Hardly a ShooIn This Week for Renomination
description: JERUSALEMLate in 1973, after the trauma of the October 7 war, Israel's longentrenched Labor Party was at its lowest ebb. The names of such party figures as Golda Meir and Moshe Dayan had been tarnished by criticism over Israel's slow response to the Arab attack. Talk was widespread that Labor's domination of Israeli political life would come to an end in the 1973 election. It did not happen; although Labor's strength in the 120member Parliament or Knesset was eroded. Nevertheless, Labor emerged as still the most potent political force In Israel. As in the past, it did not have enough seats in Parliament to form a majority and, once again, had to woo smaller political entitles to form a coalition Government. The new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, had moved swiftly from the party's backbenches to Israel's number one office and became the first Sabra, nativeborn Israeli, to preside over the state's affairs.

title: Notes: Catching Up With the Classics
description: Want to catch up on your reading while driving crosscountry? Or dip into the classics while sunning with eyes closed on a secluded Caribbean beach? A California outfit called Books on Tape makes it happen.

title: Murder in New Rochelle
description: Four workers at a New Rochelle moving company were murdered last week by a disgruntled employee who then killed a policeman during a siege of the plant; the siege ended after the killer took his own life. The episode emphasized anew the impossibility of identifying such potential murderers despite the clues they present.

title: Andy Devine, SqueakyVoiced TV and Film Star, Dies
description: ORANGE, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP)Andy Devine, the squeaky voiced deputy of television's Wild Bill Hickok series, died yesterday in a local hospital, a family spokesman said.

title: Chemical Ship Burns Off France
description: CHERBOURG, France, Feb. 18 (UPI)A Greek tanker carrying highly toxic chemicals burst into flames today in the English Channel 12 miles off the French coast and was escorted still burning to Le Havre, the coast guard reported. Coast guard vessels and others ships evacuated 25 crew members of the tanker Patrina, but 10 others stayed aboard.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Afterward. Is there life after Manhattan? John Egle, a veteran of New York's Publishers Row. set out to see for himself five years ago when he moved to Georgia and established a small regional publishing house among the magnolias of a county seat town called Covington.

title: Mercy College Brings Classes to the
description: STUDENTS call Mercy College in Yonkers the asphalt campus or the shopping center college. Tucked into a corner of the upper mall at Cross County Shopping Center, the college is at the heart of a promoter's paradisea 71.4 acre commercial complex at the hub of suburban Westchester County with 80 retail stores and 5,400 free parking spaces.

title: VICTORCANDELL,73,PAINTER MURALIST AT IRAQ PAVILION
description: Victor Candell, an awardwinning painter whose works were displayed in galleries and museums across the country, died Tuesday. He was 73 years old.

title: History Made of Memories
description: JESS J. PEARCE, the Dobbs Ferry village historian, was recalling growing up along the Hudson more than half a century ago:

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Breakey
description: Karen Forbes Breakey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Stewart Breakey of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Chester J. Hinshaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Hinshaw of Sacramento, Calif.

title: The Firm That Beam the Name of Bismarck's Banker
description: The sign on the door of 30 Broad Street, a few doors south of the New York Stock Exchange, reads Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc. It's a small brokerage firm that for four decades has conducted its business with studied staidness and a low profile in the Wall Street community.

title: R. H. Weisman Weds Annette F. Gallagher
description: The Presbyterian Church of Bedford, N. Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Annette Frances Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Philip Gallagher of London to Robert Harold Weisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Weisman of Lawrence, L.I.

title: Contrasts for a Convent
description: THE BLUE POINT THE Ursuline Convent here was built some 40 years ago as a small house for teenaged girls who had decided to devote their lives to the service of the church. Today the convent is seeking to care for nuns at the end of that life of service.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Knowing the rules is important to the craft of photography, but breaking them on occasion frees the mind and unfetters the imagination. For example, high shutter speeds are necessary to stop action, but try using slow shutter speeds. The resulting image blur will be more convincing and realistic than freezing the motion with high shutter speeds.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Though 65 is the age when most business executives retire, shipping magnates usually go on forever. So it seemed noteworthy when C. Y. Tung, the shipowner from Hong Kong, declared recently that 43 years in the business is enough.

title: Teilhard
description: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, S.J. is one of those rare modern figures whose life both invites dramatization and frustrates it. A French Jesuit priest of deep piety, in his way almost a mystic, he was all but declared a heretic in his own time by the Catholic Church he loved. Born in Auvergne, France, in 1881, this gifted and distinguished paleontologist participated in the 1930's digs and discoveries of the Peking Man. He got along well with his secular fellowscientists but left most of them variously confused or disturbed by his persistent religiosity and his odd theories about a kind of qualitative, spiritual evolution. A man of great social, grace, he was lionized by hostesses in Paris, Peking and New York; but he managed to keep the look and temperament of an ascetic. He could not be called a happy manforbidden by his superiors to publish his life work and condemned by an uncomprehending theological bureaucracy to virtual exile from his beloved Paris. Yet he communicated a remarkable kind of serenity to those around him, wherever he was. He was not quite of this world, always something of a mystery, In the two decades since his death in New York, in fact, Teilhard has grown into a magusinresidence for Catholic literary typesthe latest Teilhard figure being the enigmatic priesttraveler of The Exorcist.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors of British things are about to experience something like our Bicentennial. Great Britain is marking the Jubilee Year celebrating the accession of Queen Elizabeth II to the throne. On Feb. 2, 1952, while Elizabeth and Prince Philip were deep in the African bush country on a tour, she was notified of the death of her father, George VI.

title: Mary Cardamone Fiancee of Joseph Saunders
description: Associate Justice Richard J. Cardamone of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Cardamone of New Hartford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Brian Cardamone, to Joseph E. F. Saunders. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Saunders of Corning, N.Y., where Mr. Saunders is manager of public information for the Corning Glass Works.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: For a young music student, one's first piano recital is a great event. As the luck of the draw had itand it was a lucky drawmy first pianist was Mischa Levitzki in Carnegie Hall. That would have been around 1928. In those days student tickets, priced at 35 cents, were available. There were plenty of student ticxets for anything from Rachmaninoff down. Levitzki was a headliner in those days. He was a young man, around 30 (but that was aged to a boy of 13), and everybody was talking about what a great pianist he was. On his recital was Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue. That was one of my pieces at the time, and naturally one had to check up on the competition. So off to the top balcony of Carnegie Hall I hastened.

title: Auto Rates Up in Michigan
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19 (UPI)  The Automobile Club of Michigan announced this week that it will raise auto insurance rates an average 17.4 percent March 1, increasing the annual premiums for its 1.1 million members by about $43.

title: ENCOUNTER
description: Peter and I were beginning the fourth month of a long awaited exploration of European architecture, seeing for the first time buildings and spaces we had known only in books. Our Volkswagen camper, The Albatross, had become a comfortable home and had carried us without incident through Yugoslavia and Greece and into the hill towns of northern Italy.

title: BRIDGE
description: Tournament bridge is perhaps the only serious competitive activity in which the age spread of the contestants is more than half a century and the veterans sometimes win. The best performance in the veteran category so far this year, and one that will be hard to match, occurred in Bermuda last month: Richard Frey and Dan Frey of New York, with combined ages of about 140 years placed second in the Regional Master Pairs and thereby qualified for the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the next Fall Nationals, an event restricted to players with outstanding records.

title: When Is a Farm Not a Farm?
description: HOW many farms are there in New Jersey? 8,055? 7,329? 5,384? The correct answer according to a recently released preliminary report on the 1974 national agriculture census, is any one of the above figures. It all depends on which definition of a farm is used, and all three are used in the census.

title: Editors'
description: Fiction & Poetry

title: Pacific Studies: Listening for The Neutrinos ...
description: A detection system, involving large numbers of microphones positioned 18,000 feet beneath the surface of the sea northeast of Maui in the Hawaaian Islands, has been proposed to listen for highenergy subatomic particles coming from outer space. The site was chosen because it offers a large volume of water, which is necessary for the experiment, but is close enough to shore to be reached by underwater electric cables.

title: Radio
description: 6 A.M.5 P.M., WORAM: Leukemia Radiothon. Anne Meara, host. Live, from the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

title: Pele Is Planning to Report to Cosmos Early
description: Time is precious to Peld and he plans to be generous with it. The Brazilian will join the Cosmos for training a week earlier than he is supposed to. That will be during the last week in March. almost five weeks after Gordon Bradley and his troops started running around on the AstroTurf at the Meadowlands, new home of the Cosmos.

title: Rx for Broken China. Porcelain and Glass
description: Contrary to the first impulse that most people have when a household item made of china, glass or porcelain cracks, breaks, or chips, it is not always necessary to throw the piece away. In many cases modern adhesives can be used to make permanent repairs that will restore items to an almost like new condition. All that is needed, in addition to some tubes of the right kind of adhesive, is a bit of patience, a basic familiarity with the most important mending techniques, a few odds and ends to help assemble pieces or holds parts together while the adhesive sets, and possibly some jars or tubes of touchup paint for concealing the repairs made.

title: National League: No Achilles Heel on Reds, Dodgers Solid, Phils a Cast of Stars
description: Four pennants in seven years, two world titles in a row, and the only questions seem to be: Can the Mean Machine resist the strain of today's money market? And when Sparky Anderson calls to the bull pen, which he does often, will any lefthander answer?

title: Coop Madness: Making Changes
description: The first symptom is giddiness; disorder follows quickly.

title: But Then, So Does the Blame for All the Troubles
description: A police dog poked its nose under chairs and tables, sniffing for bombs, while members of the Emergency Financial Control Board waited to take their seats at their last meeting. At the same time, members of a community group, the New York City Crisis Center, distributed mimeographed sheets denouncing the gentlemen of the board as criminals for cutting city services.

title: INTERVIEW
description: MICHAEL KAHN was pleased, but not content. The New Jersey Drama Critics had cited him as best director for his staging of The Heiress at the McCarter Theater in Princeton. And actors and other artists associated with The Heiress and two other plays presented at McCarter, where Mr. Kahn is producing director, had won a total of six other awards, while The Heiress was named best play of the 1976 Bicentennial season.

title: Test Failures Ring School Alarm Bells
description: WAS YOUR child in the fourth grade last fall? Could he answer this question, one of 72 in the mathematical portion of the Educational Assessment Program test that was given to fourth graders last fall:

title: Foreigners in Oxford Crew Bring a Stir
description: OXFORD, England, Feb. 19With just a month remaining before the OxfordCambridge boat race, the president of the Oxford University Boat Club finally announced the boatings for this year's crew and promptly rekindled the colonial controversy.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 (AP)Rightwing Christian forces overran a Moslem town in southern Lebanon that once served as a base for Palestinian raids into Israel and killed many civilians, according to fleeing residents. Reports on the death toll ranged from 21 to 50.

title: Labor's Tough Approach Clear
description: The nation's labor unions have begun to make clear what they will ask from employers and from the Federal Government this year. Both sets of requests, and the responses they evoke, could have a substantial effect on the economy.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Rutgers Topples Cincinnati Before 13,697 at the Garden
description: Two of three local basketball teams achieved success yesterday in a college tripleheader at Madison Square Garden that attracted 13,697 fans.

title: Miss Atwood Is Bride Of James G. Clune 3d
description: Elizabeth Oldis Atwood, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Bertram deHeus Atwood of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday in Old Lyme's First Congregational Church to James Gerald Clune 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Clune of Salem, N.Y.

title: There Is New Emphasis on Appointing Lobbyists for the People
description: The list of professions and occupations in the region that need state or municipal licenses takes up at least onethird of the Yellow Pages in many telephone directories.

title: C. J. Conroy 3d Fiance Of Deborah L. Carter
description: Deborah Lamont Carter, a student at the Art Students League in New York, and Charles Joseph Conroy 3d, a student at Columbia University's School of Law, plan to be married.

title: SUNY, at 6, Assesses a Dream
description: THERE was a sense of almost zany elation at the State University of New York at Purchase when the college admitted its first fulltime students six years ago.

title: The Official National League Baseball Schedule for the 1977 Season
Dance: Cincinnatians Display an Eclectic Metier
description: The Cincinnati Ballet made a rare New York appearance Friday night, with the stirring presence of the singer Odelta, to add to the attractions of a Program presented at Pace University.

title: Where TV Documentaries Don't Dare to Tread
description: There are seven deadly taboos in the world of television documentaries. You will rarely if ever see documentaries on your home screen about:

title: DINING OUT
description: THE good doctor from Brightwaters who tipped us off certainly knows his noodles. He promised firstrate food at this outpost of Chinatown in Babylon and warned us not to dress up. This is not a place to take your inlaws to celebrate their anniversary. The pallid light of hanging lanterns and a few strands of old Christmas tinsel do nothing to relieve the drab setting.

title: Shelter Island Plagued by Ice; Damage Estimated at $300,000
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I.If the bane of Buffalo this winter has been snow, then the curse of Shelter Island has been ice.

title: Rhodesian Cavalry in Action Again
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 19Half a century after the cavalry became a ceremonial relic in most armies, a squadron of horseborne infantry is proving to be one of the most successful units in Rhodesia's effort to supress black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Stenshjemmet Sets Mark
description: OSLO, Feb. 19 (AP)Kay Arne Stenshjemmet won the 500 and 5,000 meter races today at the opening of the Norwegian national speed skating championships. He won the 500 meters in 39.19 seconds and the 5,000 in 7:11.62 for a national record. Sten Stensen, who set the previous national record of 7:15.76 last year, finished second in 7:12.81.

title: Two Staff Men Play Top Roles In Drafting New '77 Law
description: WASHINGTONNo one has ever voted for them, and their names, even in Washington's mostin circles, are not exactly on the tip of anyone's tongue. Working for Congress as the chief technicians of tax legislation, both Bernard (Bobby) Shapiro and Ward Hussey much prefer anonymity.

title: Engagements
description: ColchamiroAbramowitz

title: Weber, 47, Takes 26th Bowling Title
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 19 (AP)Dick Weber, the highest moneywinner in the sport, captured his 26th professional bowling title today by defeating Gary Mage of Seattle, 227191, in this week's $75,000 tournament final.

title: The President Affirms His Style
description: President Carter sat down last week with a small group of reporters to talk over what might be called professional problemshis and theirsand the discussion amounted to another demonstration of the Carter frankness and determination to protect his privacy.

title: Unions Call for Extension of Labor Rights to Public Employees
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19The Publie Employee Department of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for passage of legislation that would extend collective bargaining rights and coverage of the National Labor Relations Act to state and local governments.

title: Everything in Its Path
description: In Everything in Its Path Kai Erikson accomplishes a tour de force producing a volume that should fascinate the general reader at the same time as it challenges the academic social scientist. It is not only rich in content but beautifully written.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayMercedesBenz Club of America, ConnecticutWestchester Section dinner and safety seminar at Oxford House, Route 67, Oxford, Conn. Dinner at 4:30; seminar at 6 P.M.

title: Panama Treaty Talks Resuming
description: Panama and the United States have resumed formal negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty that both sides want but are unlikely to agree upon quickly. The parties are still far apart on terms, and there are political factors in Panama and Washington that may mean delay even if the negotiators should reach agreement.

title: Music in Review
description: We owe the musical term tone cluster to Henry Cowell, whose piano works familiarized composers and listeners with the practice of using the palm, fist or forearm to depress chains of adjacent notes. Cowell was also one of the first to instruct pianists to duck under the lid in order to stroke and pluck the strings directly.

title: Secrets, Cash and Mr. Kissinger
description: Henry Kissinger's sale of his memoirs to Little, Brown for $2 million and of his television services to NBC for an estimated $1.5 million demonstrates once again that high public office can lead to instant wealth. Mr. Kissinger is not alone. Former Presidents Nixon and Ford are also engaged in book and television projects, while lesser figures in their and previous administrations have successfully capitalized on their years in office.

title: As Hartford Goes
description: WITHIN the last decade, Hartford has changed from a wellfinanced, wellmanaged city with a low crime rate to a crimeridden city that badly neglects its public works and has a tax rate so high that it drives working taxpayers out and discourages new industry from moving in.

title: Karen Worden Plans To Be Married in May To David Anderson
description: Karen Augusta Worden and David William Anderson, both of New York, plan to be married in May. Mr. and Mrs. Clee Oakley Worden Jr. of Glen Arm, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Johannes Anderson of Timonium, Md.

title: Waigwa Wins as Five Better FourMinute Mile
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb.19The times were terrific but the races were even better at the San Diego Indoor Games last night on the famous fast track of the San Diego Sports Arena.

title: INTERVIEW
description: I KNEW there had been a mur der, I knew there had been a trial, and I knew the case had been dismissedbut that was all I knew, said John A. Danaher Jr., the recently appointed investigator in the Peter Reilly case.

title: ART
description: GEORGE SEGAL, a New Jersey artist whose latest works are on view at the Sidney Janis Gallery in New York, closes the mental and physical distance between sculpture and the observer. When one looks at traditional sculpture, the works themselves sometimes seem to recoil, to resist examination. But Mr. Segal snakes his works more accessible than most.

title: The Winter of 191718 Was a Cold One...
description: IT had been such a cold January that, at the end of it, G. Harold Noyes, the meteorologist in charge of the Weather Bureau in Trenton, said that maybe the oldtimers would would stop saying that winters weren't what they used to be.

title: Majesty
description: In Britainsince Queen Elizabeth II came to the throne just 25 years agothis is Silver Jubilee Year. It means that the Queen herself has an even more heavily stacked engagement diary than usualin May attending Parliament to hear a Loyal Address from both the Lords and the Commons; in June going to St. Paul's Cathedral for a service of thanksgiving; three weeks later reviewing what's left of the British fleet at Spithead; in July visiting West Germany to inspect the remnants of her Army; in August even risking a trip to Northern Ireland to see her somewhat less than tranquil subjects there. But in terms of publishing it has also meant something elsea whole torrent of books (rumored eventually to be no less than 50 in total) pouring from the presses on the myth and magic of monarchy.

title: Format Changes Planned For Devon Horse Show
description: The Devon horse show will add a division and eliminate two others this year. In addition, a new method has been devised to determine the leading junior rider. Two amateur fivegaited saddlehorse events will be held, but the hackney horse and Welsh pony breeding divisions will be dropped from the event which is scheduled for May 27 through June 4 at Devon, Pa. The Devon show is the most prestigious outdoor competition in the east and any changes in its format are significant, indeed, to the equestrian world.

title: Dr. Stephen Bakios, Dentist, Is the Fiance of Elaine Utley
description: Mr. and Mrs. George D. Utley of Bedford, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Marie Utley, to Dr. Stephen N. Bakios, son of Mr. and Mr. Nicholas Bakios of Jamestown, R. I. The couple plan to be married in August.

title: Yacht Racing Knows No Ancient Mariners
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19The sport in which one can compete at the highest levels regardless of age is yacht racing. The best example would be George Van, a pixie from Detroit who happens to be 73, although one could never suspect it and whose skills include swimming. socializing and steering.

title: E.P.A Says Carbon Tetrachloride Spill in Ohio River, Moving Faster Than Predicted, Is Past Cincinnati
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Feb. 19People hereabouts are undoubtedly scratching their heads over the Great Carbon Tetrachloride Spill.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Hall of Fame Nominee
description: To the Sports Editors

title: An Idyll of Mr. Penn's Sylvania
description: BERKELEY, Calif.I refuse to take It anymore. I refuse to see another television commercial or program in which the virtues of smalltown life are practically deified.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: In Vigorous Defense Of Norwalk's Virtues

title: Give Up? Here Are the Answers
description: READERS were asked last week to find the correct numbers to substitute for the letters in the following multiplication:

title: Locomotive Lease Is Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Amtrak, the national railroad passenger corporation, said it had extended for two months, until April, its sixmonth lease of an electric locomotive built by ASER of Sweden. Amtrak said the locomotive had operated extremely well on the New YorkWashington route in the recent severe cold weather.

title: Commuter Tax Idea Comes Up Once More
description: A familiar idea, raising New York City's commuter tax, has been suggested once again, but the chances of that happening are as slim as ever.

title: Park Agency Rejects A Proposal To Develop Area Near Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP)The Adirondack Park Agency has rejected a proposal for development of 340 homes in the nearby Town of North Elba. The proposal involved a 1,300acre largely underdeveloped tract known as Last Chance Ranch along Heart Lake Road in the Essex County town.

title: 2 Adults, 2 Children Are Killed in a Blaze in Brooklyn Building
description: Two adults and two young children died in a twoalarm fire that destroyed three  story dwelling early yesterday morning in the Borough Park district of Brooklyn.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: A Leading Saudi Prince Dies
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 19 (AP)Prince Abdel Aziz ibn Musaid ibn Gelwi, an uncle of King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, died today at the age of 100, the Saudi radio reported. Once a noted desert warrior, he was one or the founders of the Saudi monarchy, ??

title: BRIDGE
description: A HOPEFUL contingent of Connecticut bridge players marched determinedly along the longest road in the world of contract bridge last weekend, but almost all fell by the wayside. They were competing in the third stage of the American Contract Bridge League's Grand National Team Championship, which began at the club level three months ago and will end in Chicago in July.

title: Born in a County
description: INVENTED in a Scarsdale backyard in 1928, the allweather sport of platform tennis, played with shorthandled paddles and a yellow ball on a raised deck bounded by heavy chicken wire, has become one of the nation's fastestgrowing leisuretime activities.

title: A RHODESIAN OFFICER IS SLAIN IN BOTSWANA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 19The Rhodesian security forces said tonight that a white police officer was killed yesterday on a raid into Botswana. This was the first time the Government has acknowledged an operation Inside the neighboring black state.

title: Coop City Strike May Put Liberal In State Assembly for First Time
description: The political spillover from the rancorous Coop City strike poses the possibility, according to some politicians, that the Liberal Party might win its first seat ever in State Assembly.

title: The Purchasing Power of C.I.A.
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has paid millions of dollars to King Hussein of Jordan over the last 20 years and made cash payments to other foreign leaders, apparently in return for information and a favorable attitude toward the United States. The agency has now been ordered by President Carter to stop.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I LOVE Westchester  its quiet coves on the Sound, its hilly upcountry, its spectacular views of the Hudson, its proximity to New York City. So you can imagine my dismay when I found myself living in the outer reaches of Long Island.

title: This Week in Sports
description: College Basketball

title: The Burden of Blue Cross
description: I AM a small Paterson employer who is struggling to overcome the neverending profit threats to my business's survival. The current Blue Cross rate Increase request should serve as a warning that this added burden will help to drive more small businesses like mine beyond the unprofitable margin into oblivion.

title: Stowe Has a Motto: Makine Green From White
description: STOWE, Vt.Here in the land where manna from heaven comes down in white flakes and where the national anthem begins, Oh say can you ski, and the year is described as nine months of winter and three months of poor sleddin' not everybody is heading out to the slopes.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Costliest Place to Live
description: The Hague is the most expensive of 91 cities for foreigners to live in, and Mexico City is the least expensive, according to United Nations figures.

title: The Neighbors: Canada Is Shaken by Quebec Issue
description: MONTREAL  A country named Canada, which the United States is accustomed to see stretching calmly and amicably along its northern border, is currently in a most peculiar state: It is not completely sure if it is going to be a country any more.

title: Tennessee Rail Tracks Cleared
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 19 (AP)Trains were scheduled back onto the MemphistoBrownsville line today for the first time since Thursday's 56car derailment. Railroad crewmen worked in shifts around the clock to clear the tracks of the cars of a Louisville & Nashville freight that derailed about 10 miles southwest of here.

title: Speed Skating Today on L.I.
description: Barth Levy, a fourtime national men's indoor champion, and Leslie Moore, second among women indoors last season, are among more than 150 skaters entered in the New York State indoor open speedskating championships from 1 to 6 P.M. today at the Nassau Arena, on Magnolia Boulevard Long Beach, L.I. Senior championships for skaters 25 years and older will be held in conjunction.

title: Income Tax: Tristate Headache
description: BETWEEN now and April 15, many residents of New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania will be playing musical chairs with income taxforms, and it won't be an amusing parlor game.

title: The Cousteau Team Charts a More Serious Course
description: This Thursday evening at 9:30 on Channel 13 Captain Jacques Ives Cousteau and his youngest son, Philippe, will launch the first of six halfhour specials documenting men's rape of the planet earth. Called Oasis in Space, the miniseries, which examines such imminent global catastrophes as poisoning of the environment with chemical waste, the pollution of the oceans, the population explosion and mass starvation, marks a daring departure for the former French naval officer and premier aquanautdaring because there is every possibility that so dour a list of subjects will turn viewers off, or vice versa, and failure has no precedent in the Cousteau saga.

title: Article 1  No Title
GARDENING
description: THE days have lengthened sufficiently now for New Jersey's indooroutdoor gardeners to get some houseplant chores out of the way before it's time to turn energies toward the outdoors.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENERS are getting back to nature. If the trend continues, the power mower may become a relic in back of the garage.

title: Article 5  No Title
Road Princess Is First; 2 Winners for Cauthen
description: An hour after completing a twowinner day at Aqueduct, 16yearold Steve Cauthen caught a 6 P.M. jet to California last night for another Sunday appearance at Santa Anita.

title: Soares Has Audience With Pope
description: ROME, Feb, 19 (Reuters)Prime Minister Mario Sores of Portugal, who is on a tour of European Common Market capitals, had a private audience with Pope Paul VI today. Yesterday, Mr. Sores won the Italian Government's support for Portugal's entry into the Common Market.

title: Lame Duck and Fair Water
description: For almost four years the Chicago Bridge R Iron Company has been trying to turn to its own industrial uses one of the last unspoiled estuaries on this country's southern Atlantic coast. Against the advice of the Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Department of the Interior, the Environmental Protection Agency and conservation organizations throughout the country, the company is close to getting what it wants. On Jan. 1924 hours before he left officeformer Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann slipped the necessary approval to his Army Corps of Engineers, which last week issued the required permit.

title: Warmth for Winter Campers
description: WINTER camping usually conjures up an image of huddled Eskimos dejectedly trying to coax life into a few damp twigs with fint and steel. But winter camping is finally coming into its own. In Westchester, Ward Pound Ridge Reservation is the place to go for a taste of winter camping. This county park has 24 shelters open yearround to hardy campers.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: AT the entrance to the site in Harrison on which Texaco's sprawling new concrete and glass headquarters is rising sits a fine old Georgian mansion. The old wooden house once commanded much of the site; now it seems shunted aside for the new arrival. But while the two buildings are in one sense utterly different, they are in another way quite the same; the suburban corporate headquarters is really the country estate of our time.

title: A Taxpayers' Camelot in New Jersey
description: Somewhere in the dreams of every high corporate executive there must be a place where industries could all gather together in an isolated little community and not have to worry about the everincreasing burden of property taxes for schools, welfare and other public services.

title: Town Officials With Union Cards?
description: WHEN Jeanne Shaffer quit her job as planning assistant for the town of Greenwich last December, her colleagues threw a party for her at Manero's. Many of the 75 people present, including Miss Shaffer, were members of a new union, the Greenwich Association of Management and Professional employees, formed two years earlier to correct the very problems that led to Miss Shaffer's resignation.

title: Mary Hicks Fiancee Of Kevin Kelleher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert George Hicks of Greenwich and New Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Hick, to Kevin Joseph Kelleher, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Michael Kelleher of Ansonia, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Headliners
description: Attempted Assassination

title: Archbishop's Body Buried Secretly by Uganda Aides
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19The body of the Anglican Archbishop of Uganda was secretly buried by Uganda authorities yesterday, forcing the cancellation of funeral services that had been scheduled for tomorrow.

title: A Rural Haven For Nazis' Victims
description: JEFFERSON THIRTYTWO years ago, eight priests, each weighing less than 75 pounds and barely alive, were lifted to stretchers by American G.I.'s who were liberating the prisoners at two Nazi death camps, Auschwitz and Dachau.

title: A Milestone for the New Route 7
description: AFTER 20 years on the scarred battlefield of the proposed Route 7 Expressway between Norwalk and Danbury, the environmentalists appear at last to be yielding ground to the highway builders.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
The Murderous General Amin
description: The Anglican Archbishop of Uganda and two of that nation's cabinet ministers have been killed after they were accused of treason by Uganda's violent, erratic, despotic ruler, Idi Amin. He said they died in a car accident caused by their effort to escape. Given his recordtens of thousands of political murders in the last six yearspractically nobody believed him.

title: Tuna Boats Ordered to Permit Federal Inspectors to Go Aboard
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered tuna boats to submit to boarding for investigations of whether they used forbidden fishing methods that allegedly kill a large number of porpoises.

title: VILLAGE UNRUFFLED BY NEW SATELLITES
description: WAINGAPU, Indonesia, Feb. 13On a hill overlooking the harbor of this town of grassroofed huts and tintopped shacks there stands a $2 million collection of buidings topped by a huge circular dish that sparkles in the noonday sun.

title: George Francis Fredericks Marries Elizabeth H. Phair
description: Elizabeth Honor Phair and George Francis Fredericks, 1975 graduates of St. John's University, were married at noon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Brooklyn by the Rev. Richard D. Lee, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I, too, have been at Sarah Lawrence College for two years, and would like to offer another opinion about the school. While some of the statements made by the author of a Letter from Sarah Lawrence [Feb. 6] might be based on fact, I find that the author has misinterpreted them and hence gives a misleading impression of the school. My experiences here have been very different from Mr. Farber's, and it angers me when I think that he has tried to present a general picture of the college.

title: INVESTING
description: An independent Quebec doesn't have much appeal to American investors. Ever since the Parti Qubcois came to power in midNovember. Quebec bonds have been declining and the efforts of Premier Rend Levesque to reassure Americans so far have produced no noticeable impact on the credit markets.

title: The Environment And the Schools
description: IN a time of societal preoccupation, we have unfortunately witnessed the diminution of child advocates, People are uptight. their environment is being poisoned, they are afraid to leave their homes; taxes are high, and so is inflation and unemployment. Film and television violence, mirrors of the culture, consume the population. In such a time, it is reasonable to expect people to become increasingly conservative in their support of and choice of school programs.

title: RAZING OF 700 HOMES NEAR AIRPORT URGED
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 19A proposal that San Diego demolish nearly 700 houses beneath the noisy, nervewracking flight path to Lindbergh Field has rekindled controversy over what pilots have called the country's scariest metropolitan airport.

title: LETTER FROM PACE
description: PACE PLEASANTVILLE, one of three Pace campusesManhattan and White Plains are the other twois perhaps a microcosm of the postVietnam small college. The current student is more prone to be concerned with classwork than with spending time objecting to university or government actions.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE folks who run The Fishmarket in Chappaqua know what they're about. They have set up shop in a storefront location in the middle of Westchester, offer a variety of fresh fish and seafood cooked with an Italian accent, and send you home after an allbutcomplete dinner having paid only $6 to $9. Is it any wonder the place is crowded, particularly on weekends?

title: FOOD
description: HAWKING hot cross buns (oneapenny, twoapenny) on Good Friday began in 18thcentury England. Today, just as Christmas decorations are hung in our stores by Thanksgiving, the season for hot cross buns has become longer than the latter part of Holy Week.

title: More Carter Hints on Cuba Relations
description: President Carter has again emphasized the importance his Administration attaches to dealings with Cuba: He said last week that a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola would be an important step toward restoration of diplomatic relations between Washington and Havana. The comment appears, however, to be less an exact precondition for restoring ties than a preliminary negotiating position before talks between Cuba and the United States beginprobably by the end of the year.

title: Columbus Rallies to Assist Closed Schools
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 18At the Glidden paint store on High Street on this city's north side, the shelves are filled with cans of paint and the aisles with elementary school students studying reading and math. Several miles to the east, at the home of Jane Pratt, another group of public school students is in the basement attending a music class.

title: The Situation Of Poetry
description: OBERT PINSKY describes his new book as an essay about the current state of the modernist tradition. The word contemporary in his subtitle refers to poetry published since about 1959: older poems are invoked to illustrate some of the traditions in which poetry has been written during the past twenty years or so.

title: Few but Resolute
description: WASHINGTONAndrei D. Sakharov, the balding, Nobel Prizewinning Soviet dissident, may have his picture on the cover of Time magazine or be seen by millions of Americans in a television interview, but his own countrymen would not recognize his face.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE folks who run The Fishmarket in Chappaqua know what they're about. They have set up shop in a storefront location in the middle of Westchester, offer a variety of fresh fish and seafood cooked with an Italian accent, and send you home after an allbutcomplete dinner having paid only $6 to $9. Is it any wonder the place is crowded, particularly on weekends?

title: ...Mexico Also Has Its Difficulties
description: MEXICO CITYFor a country with a history of upheavals and a proven potential for violence, Mexico has been a surprisingly stable neighbor to the United States for the past 60 years, offering both a safe market for investment and a friendly hideaway for vacations. But in recent months, many United States officials, business. men and travellers have suddenly become alarmed by reports of political and economic unrest south of the Rio Grande. Almost overnight, the forgotten neighbor is no longer being taken for granted.

title: Insurance Frauds By Arab Students Said to Aid P.L.O.
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb.19Insurance investigators believe that as much as $5 million in fraudulent insurance claims have been collected by Middle Eastern students in this country since 1971 and funneled to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: SOVIET AIRLINER CRASHES; NUMBER OF DEAD UNKNOWN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Reuters)A Soviet Ilyushin airliner crashed last Tuesday on a domestic flight between Central Asia and the Caucasus, killing an undisclosed number of people, an official of the state airline Aeroflot said today.

title: ...And Testing Hot. Hot Water
description: Scientists using the deepdiving research submarine Alvin have begun a series of explorations intended to study eruptions of hot water from the floor of the Pacific Ocean 500 miles west of Ecuador.

title: Ellen Singer Betrothed To Dr. Eric C. Gechter
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Singer of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Meryl Singer, to Dr. Eric C. Gechter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Gechter of Fort Lee. N.J.

title: The Other Budgetary Power
description: WASHINGTONIt's been nearly three years since Congress set up its own budget office and hired an economist from the Brookings Institution to run it. Dr. Alice M. Rivlin and her staff of 200 macroeconomists, micro.economists, econometricians, fiscal assessors and other specialists in the esoteric art of economic analysis have today become a substantial force in Congressional management of the Federal pursestrings.

title: Controlling Hospital Costs
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed creating a Federal agency with authority to control the cost of hospital services, a leading factor in the nation's rapidly rising medical care bill. The proposal reflects the Administration's belief that cost control is a prerequisite for establishing a national healthcare insurance system.

title: An Under30 Commuter on the 8:47
description: AS a child growing up in a suburban bedroom community, I observed and absorbed the ritual etiquette of commuting the way children in all cultures osmose their world. Mommies lined up in cars at the station. The train pulled in. The mommies moved over to the passenger seat and the briefcase men drove the cars home. There was the inviolable pecking order of rushhour platforms, as grown men staked out claims on the spot where the train door was bound to open. The trains regularly deposited domestic workers to clean suburban houses and serve at elegant dinner parties. The private club car on the 4:20, the banker's train, shuttled the captains of industry.

title: Scientists Fear Bid to Regulate Genetic Studies
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 19Scientists meeting here today expressed concern over the possibility that strict regulation of certain areas of genetic research might be extended unwisely to hamper broad areas of biological research and experiment.

title: Rohatyn Says The Banks' Are Trying to Keep Out of Mayoral Race
description: The banks are clearly playing a major role in the city's fiscal affairs, but there are no signs yet of any significant attempt to influence the mayoral election. The banks are trying to stay away from the political process., trying not to come clown on anyone's side, said a man who should knowFelix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and a general partner in Lazard Frres & Company, one of the city's financial citadels.

title: Quebec Play, Saying That French Heritage Is Being Consumed, Makes Audience Face Fear and Hate
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 19  Since last November, a play has been arousing audiences in this province with the message that hate and fear are basic sentiments in a French Quebec struggling to maintain its identity against English Canada.

title: MUSIC
description: A YALE WOMAN brought curiosity, perserverance and a little bit of luck along with her last summer to the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, and as a result, the House of Usher will fall again next weekend in New Haven. The occasion will be the world premiere at Yale's Jonathan Edwards College of La Chute de la Maison Usher, an opera by Claude Debussy based on Edgar Allan Poe's chilling tale of terror.

title: Design
description: Six years ago Winthrop Faulkner, a Washington, D.C., architect, and his wife, Jeanne, an interior designer, bought a 200yearold stone barn near Middleburg, Va. Because it was huge80 feet long and 40 feet widethey decided to convert only half of it into living quarters, a weekend retreat, leaving the rest unfinished. That turned out to be a wise decision, because in the time they have owned it, heating costs have skyrocketed.

title: CHARLES VENTURA DIES; EXSYNDICATED COLUMNIST
description: ATLANTA. Feb. 19 (UP)Charles Ventura, 73 years old, former syndicated New York society columnist, died today of pneumonia after a yearlong fight against leukemia.

title: Radar Spotters Get More Tricky
description: THEY are usually inocuouslooking black boxes with matte finish and their trade namesFuzzbuster, Snooper, Bearbeater, Bearfinderare descriptive, if not very subtle. Truck drivers and others who make their living driving call them seeingeye dogs, and the manufacturers tout themin the words of one of themas a way to give yourself parity in the electronic war on the road.

title: The anatomy of a reporter's murder
description: PHOENIX. The Ivanhoe is a cocktail lounge at 3033 North Central Avenue. It is a dark place with red carpets and cheap, fakemedieval dcor. The wood paneling is plastic, the antique brick on the walls is imitation, and the fire that seems to flicker in the fireplace is a rotating light bulb. The Ivanhoe opens each morning about 6:30, and before long it begins to fill up with the regulars, who while away their mornings, and then their afternoons, drinking, talking, playing cards and trying to make deals, using the two telephones placed on the bar for customers' use.

title: Where Do We Go Now?
description: PARISThe firm, fresh attitude of President Carter has given new leadership to internal movements for freedom and human rights in a whole series of lands governed by one or another form of autocracy, and this rather abrupt switch in American methods, if not aspirations, may well end up in destabilizing more than one oppressive regime.

title: Offshore Drilling Is Delayed
description: Judge Jack B. Weinstein of the United States District Court in Brooklyn, who does not shrink from unexpected decisions, has voided $1.13 billion in Atlantic Ocean drilling leases approved by the Secretary of the Interior during the Ford Administration, but has given the Government and oil companies time to appeal.

title: Taxes and Civil Liberties
description: SAN JOSE. Calif.Pretrial hearings last week in the complex taxfraud trial of Harry Margolis, a Bay area lawyer, and his associates raised the broad issue of whether the Government has violated the defendant's civil liberties an issue likely to appear in future cases involving the Internal Revenue Service as well.

title: Football Saved His Career
description: Hollywood's transition from silent films to talkies in the late 1920's almost ended Andy Devine's movie career.

title: MALCOLM H. FROST
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Feb. 19 Malcolm H. Frost, a former New York City lawyer and business executive, died Thursday in a hospital at Biddeford after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Differences on Westway Effect
description: Different branches of the Government look at the same thingin this case, the proposed $1.16 billion Westway project for lower Manhattanin different ways. Though the highway has been approved both by Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams and by his predecessor, William T. Coleman Jr., the Environmental Protection Agency has now labelled the project environmentally unsatisfactory.

title: Shaggy dog story
description: Working away on their various books, in a farmhouse in North Brooklin, Me., are the four members of what has been called a family literary phenomenon: Jose Yglesias, his wife, Helen Yglesias, and their sons. Lewis Cole and Rafael Yglesias. Recent publicity has likened them to other writing clans: the Lardners, the Benchleys, the Brontes, even the Irving Wallaces. We asked the writing Yglesii to put aside their individual projects and collaborate on a story. Herewith, the family miniature, about their late, great dachshund, Sam.

title: Madeline W. Einhorn Wed To Carl Glick, Stockbroker
description: Madeline W. Einhorn, widow of Bernard W. Einhorn, who was a general partner in Kuhn. Loeb & Company, was married yesterday afternoon to Carl Glick, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Neuberger & Berman.

title: DETROIT WILL SET UP PANEL ON MORTGAGES
description: DETROIT, Feb.20This city's mortgage lending community and city leaders have reached agreement on a voluntary program that could significantly reduce the widespread practice called redlining.

title: Some Primary Considerations
description: One way or the other, the date for the primary election in New York City and New York State will almost certainly have to be set this week. Aides of both Democratic and Republican legislative leaders, who had been trying to negotiate a date, conceded that if there were no agreement tomorrow or Wednesday, the primary would have to be held in September because there would not be sufficient time for the preliminaries to a June primary. The date is of prime interest to candidates and their supporters but the maneuvering and stratagems that go into setting a date provide a case study of politics that overwhelms any merits of the issue.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Xerox Fights to Stay Ahead in the Copier Field
description: The fastgrowing multibilliondollar market for plainpaper copiers is acting as if nobody had invented electronic mail and other proposed methods of computerizing the flood of paper in the world's offices.

title: Capitals Gain Deadlock by Rallying Late
description: LANDOVER, Md., Feb. 20The Islanders picked the wrong weekend to play the Washington Capitals. For the third straight time the best the potent New Yorkers could get from the supposedly weaker Caps was a tie. Tonight, at the Capital Centre, the score was 22.

title: Two Americans Take World SpeedSkating Titles
description: INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 20 (AP) Eric Heiden, the teenaged speedskater from Madison, Wis., and 20yearold Kim Kostron of St. Paul captured the overall championships today in the world junior competition. Each of them set world records in one or more events on the way to the titles.

title: Knicks Recover and Trounce Nets, 10080
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 20The Knicks discovered a fullcourt press and the capabilities of their veterans this afternoon and buzzed past the Nets at the Coliseum, 10080.

title: 7 Years After the Defeat of Biafra, Its People Make a Strong Recovery
description: ENUGU, Nigeria, Feb. 16Biafra is only a distant memory. Seven years after its towns were overrun and its starving population fled panicstricken into the jungle, the area occupied by the onetime rebel state of the Ibo people in eastern Nigeria is staging an economic comeback.

title: Loss of Millions in Fees Because of Faulty Billing Cited at Harlem Hospital
description: New york city's Harlem Hospital Center has lost millions of dollars because of chaotic recordkeeping and failures to ask the Government to pay for services provided to poor patients within the time limits set by the Medicaid program, according to a report released yesterday by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: Police Cutbacks in New York City Appear to Be Lowering Morale
description: After almost two years of trying to cope with budget and personnel cuts, New York City's police force appears to be more beset than ever by internal dissension. Interviews with scores of officers on patrol duty and with highranking commanders indicate that morale, job performance and absenteeism are worsening, rather than improving.

title: New York City Ballet Completes Season in a Shower of Flowers
description: Last night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet ended its strange winter season in a shower of flowers thrown by a grateful audience. For many weeksincluding most of the performances of The Nutcrackerthe ballet had been closed by a strike of the musicians, and as a result, the company gave fewer performances this year than ever before.

title: TV: British Microbes and Men
description: Medicine does not take easily to dramatization, At one extreme, usually identified with Paul Muni's Louis Pasteur, content is reduced to the romanticized portrayal of a courageous, albeit eccentric, hero. At the other, closer to straight documentary, the enormous quantity of technical information stifles any significant development of character. Microbes and Men, a sixpart series beginning on public television tonight at 8, attempts a middle course but generally winds up in the annoying category of neither here nothere.

title: Baptist Pastor Quits Plains, Ga., Church; Cites Rift on Blacks
description: PLAINS, Ga., Feb. 20 (AP)The Rev. Bruce Edwards said today that he had resigned effective April 30 as pastor of the Plains Baptist Church, of which President Carter was a member until he moved to Washington.

title: Clifford P. Morehouse, Lay Leader In Episcopal Church, Is Dead at 72
description: Clifford P. Morehouse, one of the bestknown laymen in the Episcopal Church and former president of its powerful House of Deputies, died in a Sarasota, Fla., hospital on Thursday. He was 72 years old.

title: Moliere's Bourgeois Comes Alive In San Francisco Production
description: The enormous variety of the arts in the San Francisco Bay area is truly impressive. As with Washington, to take another example, San Francisco has an output of varying artistic enterprises that feed all appetites.
