description: OTHER BONDS

title: Cork Defective? Here's a Solution
description: One of the most frustrating experiences for a cookor a host for that matteris to suddenly discover the cork of the bottle you wanted to use for a sauce or a stew has suddenly plunged or been forced into the bottle and into the wine. Most people in that case resort to a funnel and sieve or some other alternative.

title: Perez Calls Report Vile
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 22President Carlos Andres Perez, who has denounced the report of C.I.A. in to him as vile and false, said m a statement published today, that his Government would take the issue to its final consequences.

title: Firestone Lifts Quarterly Net 17.7%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday a 17.7 percent earnings increase for the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, following the 72 percent plunge in earnings in the preceding three months caused by an extended strike. The report, from Akron headquarters, said sales were up 13.7 percent.

title: Production of Steel Rose 6.8% In Week to Highest Level in 77
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 19 reached its highest weekly level for this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association said that the nation's steel mills poured 2.26 million tons of steel, a gain of 6.8 percent over the proceeding week when 2.12 million tons were produced. This meant that that industry was utilizing 73.6 percent of its total available capability, also the highest level of the year.

title: Suspect in Three Murders Seized
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP)Policemen have arrested a 21yearold man and charged him with murdering three Southwest Philadelphia residents, including a 14yearold girl, yesterday afternoon. William Blannon of Philadelphia, was charged with three counts of murder, the police said today.

title: Carey Not Averse to Some Casinos
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would not oppose casino gambling in areas of New York State where it would be an ideal addition.

title: Bistate Coalition Urged for Racing
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 22A bistate coalition similar to the Port Authority could resolve the growing problems of race tracks in the metropolitan area in the view of ??? of the most powerful figures in the sport.

title: Big British Bank Makes an Offer For Assets of Bancal TriState
description: The Standard Chartered Bank, major British bank with 512.75 billion in assets, announced last night that it was making an offer for the assets of the Bancal TriState Corporation, a San Franciscobased holding company whose keystone bank is the 113yearold Bank of California.

title: After Hectic Battle, Israeli Labor Party Delegates Choose Chief Today
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 22'014;Israel's governing Labor Party, beset by scandal and defections, opened its nominating convention here today with cries for unity, boosterism and speeches from leaders of the Socialist International who had been invited for the occasion.

title: Meany Says Federation Will Open Major Drive for New Labor Laws
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla.. Feb. 22The A.F.L.C.I.O. said today that it would conduct an aggressive, wellfinanced campaign this year to change the National Labor Relations Act and win passage of other key labor legislation.

description: Opp Radio City Post Office Entire 15th Floor a Penthouse

title: House Panel Says Texaco Holds Back Gas Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)The Texaco Oil Company has reserves in the Gulf of Mexico containing more than 500 billion cubic feet of natural gas but failed to produce from these reservoirs because of its desire to maximize its profits, Congressional investigators said today.

title: Carter Seeks to Cut $200 Million From Breeder Reactor Program
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 22The Carter Administration said today it was cutting $200 million from the most controversial of the Government's nuclearenergy procrams the fast breeder reactor.

title: Citizen Role in Government Emerges as Theme of California's Gov. Brown
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22Gov. Edmund G: Brown Jr., midway through his first term, of office, continues to bring wornen, Minorities and others outside the administration echelon into government at a rate unmatched in the nation.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Television
TV: Insidious View Of Nuclear Power
description: NUCLEAR ENERGY may be replacing the threat of natural disasters such as floods or invasions of killer bees as one of television's popular plotting gimmicks. Nuclear plants are convenient targets for the unbalanced and/or subversive, determined to unleash massive destruction and keep viewers glued to their sets for an hour or so. Opponents of nuclear energy couldn't be more pleased with the implied linking of the plants and an atomic explosion on the scale of Hiroshima. Proponents are understandably furious.

title: John Hubley, 62, Leading Creator, Producer of Animated Films, Dies
description: John Hubley, a leading creator and producer of animated films, died Monday night during heart surgery at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He had homes on East 72d Street and in Montauk, L. I. He', was G2 years old.

title: Blacks Entry Halted To Catholic Schools In South Africa Area
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 22 (AP)The Roman Catholic Church agreed today to suspend admission of black students into its white schools in the Cape area pending the outcome of negotiations with the white minority Government.

title: Aid to Chiang Groundless
description: A spokesman for the Chinese Nationalist Government yesterday denied as totally groundless published reports that the Central Intelligence Agency had made secret personal payments to the late Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek. The denial, by 1cheng Loh, the counselor for information for the Nationalist Embassy in Washington and the director of the Chinese Information Service in New York, was supported by Ray S. Cline, the C.I.A.'s former deputy director of intelligence, who served as the agency's chief in Taipei, Taiwan, from 1958 to 1962.

title: In Memoriam
description: FROMMERJack. Precious lovino mempries always. Dorothy Frommor and Family.

title: About Real Estate
description: CARMEL, N.Y.Legend wants us to believe that Benjamin Kittredge, a man of wealth, first came upon the land he was to buy for his hilltop mansion during a journey across Putnam County on a horse.

title: Statue Depicts Ali's Punch
description: A 9foot tall, 1,100pound statue of Muhammad Ali, constructed from more than 100 automobile bumpers, will be one of the featured pieces at an exhibition of art depicting boxers at the National Art Museum of Sports in Madison Square Garden from next Monday to March 27.

title: People and Business
description: Two former officials of the Penn Central Transportation Company and two attorneys went on trial yesterday, charged with having carried out a repairloan scheme that caused the railroad to lose $4 million 10 months before it became bankrupt in June 1970.

title: AVERY BERLOW COHAN, 62, A PROFESSOR OF FINANCE
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 22 (AP)Dr. Avery Berlow Cohan, professor of finance at the University of North Carolina for 20 years, died last night at Duke Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Inmont Board Rejects Esmark Acquisition
description: The board of directors of the Inmont Corporation decided at a special meeting to reject the proposal of Esmark Inc. to acquire all outstanding shares of Inmont at $22.50 a share. The company said the rejection was based on the fact that the Esmark proposal was not in the best interests of the company and its shareholders at this time, based upon  the upward trend in sales, earnings and excellent future growth prospects. Inmont said that it was mailing to its stockholders letter concerning the Esmark proposal.

description: BIBI ANDERSSON, Ingmar Bergman's winter sunlight, is 40 or a year or two older. I am in my prime, she says, laughing at the phrase somewhat.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Venezuela's representative at the Organization of American States demanded today that the United States deny a newspaper report that President Carlos Andres Perez received payments from the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1960's while serving as Minister of Interior.

title: Boy Scouts of America Adopt Name of Scouting/USA
description: The Boy Scouts of America, having become something more than an organization for boys and concerned with its image among minority groups, has changed its name to Scouting/USA.

title: Q&A
description: Q have lost a recipe you printed for a fine mustard sauce. it contained a sharp mustard and is one of the best sauces I have ever tried. Could you reprint it?

title: U. S. Says Transportation Bore BruntShipments Also Were Down
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)New orders for durable goods fell 4 percent in January with all the decline coming in the weatherstricken transportation industry, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Vadnais, Still Suspended, Awaits Campbell's Ruling
description: Carol Vadnais of the New York Rangers will remain under suspension until the National Hockey League president, Clarence Campbell, completes his investigation of last week's stickswinging incident involving the New York Islanders left wing, Garry Howatt.

title: Market Place
description: The International Business Machines Corporation rates superlatives in Wall Street. Renowned as the classic growth company, its shares fetch a higher price than any other issue on the New York Stock Exchange. And for years, I.B.M. has been by far the biggest single holding of institutions.

description: Nets vs. Denver Nuggets, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.T., 8 P.M. (Television Channel 10 (Cable), 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 8 P.M., Wgdb, 10 P.M., delayed broadcast)

title: A Touch of Coney For Palm Springs
description: ALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 22 'When I first came here, wow, what a letdown, says Mel Haber, proprietor of Melwyn's, the hot in restaurant this season in Palm Springs. I mean, even the mountains were ugly. How can they make ugly mountains? I asked myself. is it possible?

title: Price of Gold Continues To Rise, Closing in London At High Since November
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP)The price of gold continued a rise in Europe today and closed in London at its highest level since midNovember. The dollar had a mixed day.

title: Expressly on Subways
description: Subway trains are fewer and shorter these days, and Stan Fischler's Uptown. Downtown is the perfect vade mecum while you're waiting, provided that you are an admirer of the subway system, when it's at its best, and sympathetic when it's not. Mr. Fischler has the feeling for subways that courses through the veins of many New Yorkers who grew up with noses pressed to the front window of the first car in days when they were kneehigh to a handstrap. He gives us a good, fast run through the history of the subway, from the first bootleg operationit was a twoblock fancy affair finished sub rose, as well as sub terra, because of political oppositionto the system that carries millions of us to and from work today.

title: Court to Weigh College Admission That Gives Minorities Preference
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Supreme Court agreed today to decide on the constitutionality of state university admission programs that give special preferences to blacks and other minoritygroup members, often to the disadvantage of betterQualified white applicants.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Bail of $1 million was set for a Russian seaman charged with passing United States space secrets to the Soviet Union. Judge George H. Barlow set the bail in Federal District Court in Trenton for Ivan N. Rogalsky, 34 years old, of Jackson Township, who was arrested Jan. 7 in Lakewood on charges of conspiring to pass secrets to the Soviet Union. Mr. Rogalsky, who came to the United States five years ago after jumping ship in Spain, has denied the charges. The Federal Government did not oppose setting bail for Mr. Rogalsky despite its earlier argument that the Soviet Union had agreed to help Mr. Rogalsky flee the United States by taking him aboard a Russian ship in Delaware Bay if he was arrested. However, Assistant United States Attorney William Braniff asked that the bail be set at $1 million.

title: Leonora Parsons Prowell Is Wed to Raymond C. Stein
description: Leonora Parsons Prowell of New York and Hadlyme, Conn., widow of Richard P. Prowell, was married in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church yesterday to Raymond C. Stein of New York, a widower. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Colony Club, of which the bride is member.

title: Senate Unit Condemns Uganda
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved a resolution today condemning the recent actions of the Government of Uganda and urging other nations to stop supplying arms to that country. The Soviet Union and Libya are the principal suppliers.

title: Shearing Cuts Loose Stylishly
description: In the 30 years since George Shearing arrived in this country from England, the pianist has built a firm identity. based on the blend of piano, guitar and vibraphone in the quintet that he led for most of those years and in his own lockedhands piano playing. The quintet and the style eventually became a trapa limitationfrom which he has recently extricated himself by cutting down to the trio with which he is now playing at Hopper's, II th Street at Avenue of the Americas.

title: Michael Lien. 40. ExTimes Photographer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Michael B Lien, a former staff photographer for The New York Times., died today at University Hospital in Baltimore of injuries sustained in an automobile accident Dec. 1. He was 40 years old.

title: Round 7 for Cockfighting Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22For the seventh year running, Assemblyman Armando Montano, at the urging of his South Bronx constituents, has introduced a bill to legalize cockfighting in New York State. For the seventh year running, the bill has been sent to the Assembly Agriculture Committee, where it is expected to roost for the rest of the session.

title: Jazz: Lavish Sam Rivers
description: Sam Rivers, the jazz saxophonist and composer, has been leading a big band on Monday nights at Storyville, 41 East 58th St. Although he has recorded one bigband album, Crystals, and is putting the finishing touches on another, Mr. Rivers's reputation still hinges on his abilities as a tenor saxophonist. This is not really surprising, for he is probably the most gifted, original and audacious contemporary player on that instrument. But Mr. Rivers has been composing and arranging for big bands since the early 1950's, when the Herb Pomeroy band of Boston played some of his charts. He has developed a sound and style that is very much his own.

title: BIG BOARD REGISTERS DIP IN SHORT INTEREST
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest in the month ended Feb. 15 decreased 612,364 shares to 26,261,329 shares. The short interest on Feb. 13, 1976, the yearearlier level, totaled 25,647,279 shares.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: CONSIDER THESE poor rhymesters in their garrets. They are hungry. Their shanks are turning blue. The very marrow of their bones is congealed by the bitter cold. They try to warm themselves, and you, by rubbing their wits together. And what is their reward? To each a bottle of chilled champagne.

title: High Court Lets Stand Decision On a Vesco Debt of $2.4 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court decision that a company controlled by Robert L. Vesco must pay a $2.4 million legal debt owed by Mr. Vesco.

title: UnionBanker Talks Fail to Break Impasse on New York City's Debt
description: Union leaders and highlevel bankers resumed their talks on the future of outside review of New York City finances for more than an hour yesterday, but failed to break an impasse that has held up resolution of the city's pressing debt problems.

title: Living Abroad: Paris
description: Raymond Barre, the former economics professor who is the roundest, shortest and perhaps drollest Prime Minister the Fifth Republic has ever had, drew a roomful of guffaws the other day with an ironic afterlunch allusion to his countrymen's lack of selfdiscipline in the interest of curbing inflation.

title: Around the Nation
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 22 (AP)The Government charged today that a Republican Congressional aspirant planned to kill Vice President Rockefeller with a cyanide. bullet during last July 4th weekend as part of an alleged John Birch Society plot.

title: Henry K. Chang, 92; Chinese Nationalist Held Envoy Posts
description: Henry Kunghui Chang, a longtime Chinese diplomat, died Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 92 years old and a resident of New Rochelle.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 22The Supreme Court took the following actions today.

title: Republicans vs. Reform
description: The Republicans in the Legislature are giving the state an object lesson in why Governor Carey's court reorganization proposal is an important item on the reform agenda in Albany. They had to be drawn kicking and screaming into a special session of the Legislature last summer to give the first required approval to the proposal, which is designed to increase professionalism and decrease politics in the state's judicial system. Now they are playing a political game that threatens to scuttle the entire package.

title: Panel Says Chile is Still Using Torture
description: GENEVA. Feb. 22  A fivemember United Nations panel charged in a report published today that the Chilean military Government was continuing to torture detained persons as a regular practice. But the panel also said that there had been a decrease in the last several months in the numbers involved, and it charged that more subtle forms of torture were now beine employed.

title: Knicks Defeat Jazz, 119102, for 2d in Row
description: The Knicks have won two in a row. That may not sound like much, hut for the Knicks it is.

title: H.U.D. Secretary Lists Staff Choices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has sent her first group of staff appointments to the White House, Administration sources said today.

title: Netherlands Building Strike Ends
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 23 (Reuters)A 16day nationwide building strike ended today when union and management representatives reached a compromise on wages and improved vacation benefits. Building workers, who struck to back demands for a 2 percent increase in basic wages, will get 1 percent immediately and half a percent next July. Vacation bonuses will also be increased.

title: A Supergraphics Textile Designer Scales Down
description: His patterns are bold, his colors clear. These two characteristics have helped propel Peter Condu to the top of Sweden's textile world and put his fabrics on the walls and windows of some of Stockholm's most prestigious modern homes and offices.

title: TEXACO DENIES GAS IS HELD OFF MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)A Texaco official today denied that his company was withholding natural gas and contended that such charges were undercutting the effort to develop a sound national energy policy.

description: Carlo Fassi the former coach of Dorothy Hamill, the reigning Olympic figureskating champion, may soon find out exactly how short and sassy Miss Hamill can be.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Who's to blame for the natural gas shortage?

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Prime Minister Trudeau returned to Ottawa today obviously impressed with President Carter's approach to policymaking in foreign affairs and matters closer to home, including American relations with Canada.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb: 23 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission, ending an inquiry begun in 1972, today rejected proposals to split the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from its equipment supply company, Western Electric.

title: Suit by Women at The Times Determined a ClassAction Case
description: Judge Henry F. Werker has decided that a sexdiscrimination complaint filed by women employees of The New York Times can proceed as a classaction suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Gold Continues to Rise in Europe as Dollar Advances on Most Markets
description: LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP)The price of gold continued to climb on European bullion markets today and the dollar rose on most foreign exchange markets.

title: Kirbo Describes Informal Night At White House
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23Charles H. Kirbo was complaining this morning of a stiff right leg, the result of a midnight bowling match in the White House with the President of the United States.

title: Beame Backs a StepUp of Hiring Among the Minorities and W omen
description: Mayor Beame yesterday approved con troversial new rules and regulations aimed at broadening job opportunities for members of minority groups and women in nonconstruction areas of city work.

title: Dr. Norman M. Weinrod, 63, Obstetrician and Gynecologist
description: Dr. Norman M. Weinrod, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died Tuesday at his country home In East Quogue, L.I. He was 63 years old and a resident of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Justice for G. Gordon Liddy
description: To end a strange caper in the strangest way, four of the convicted Watergate burglars have agreed to accept $200,000 from former President Nixon's still undissipated 1972 campaign fund. The outofcourt settlement on its face recognizes the plaintiffs claim that they had been misled into believing their crime was a service sponsored by the Government in the interest of national security.

title: Rangers Break Jinx On Toronto's Ice, 54
description: TORONTO, Feb. 23The Toronto Maple Leafs, who insist on playing highscoring hockey games of late, were on the losing end of the shootout tonight, falling by 54 to a determined Ranger squad.

title: ExTexas Marshal Indicted in a Death
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23 (AP)A Feder al grand jury indicted a former Texas town marshal today for violating the civil rights of a MexicanAmerican construe don worker he allegedly shot to death in 1975.

title: Yes, yes, it's graft. But don't fight.
description: How interesting it is to come home after a few years overseas and find my country still trying to save the rest of the world. To most foreigners our attitudes toward international corruption are simply incredible. It is not so much, an outsider might say, that Americans believe themselves moral, it is that they believe that the world must play by their rules.

description: To Lawrence D'Aponte, the issue is simple: Five dollars an hour is just not enough to live on.

title: Lipkin Leads Youths Smoothly
description: Tne National Orchestral Association, New York's training orchestra, is being guided this season under a succession of three conductors. Seymour Lipkin, the second of these, led a concert in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night to bring his sixweek session with the players to a close.

title: Song: Machaut Early Music Ensemble Plays Remede de Fortune
description: Everybody's heard of Chaucer and Boccaccio, both of whom flourished in the 14th century, but Guillaume de Machaut, a Frenchman who was their contemporary, is a less wellknown poet by far. Indeed, his place in art history is based on his musical compositions rather than his literary output.

title: The Chilling Outlook for Britain's Laborites
description: LONDON, Feb. 23The political arithmetic is unmistakable and for the leaders of Britain's embattled Labor Party Government, more than a little chilling: of the 312 seats in the House of Commons currently held by the Labor Party, 41 are accounted for by Scots. AsNews Analysis things now stand, the Gov ernment has a bare working majority only because it cart command Liberal and Scottish Nationalist support on nost key issues should it lose its Scotlish seats in the next general election, its chances of holding office would be nil.

title: Nadjari Says Leaders In 3 Counties Back Him for District Attorney
description: Maurice H. Nadjari said last night that business, civic and political leaders from Queens and two other counties had been urging him to run for district attorney in their areas.

title: Dow Dips 1.66 After Burns Voices Pessimism on Inflation's Outlook
description: Inflation fears caused the stock market yesterday to register a modest decline in continued slow trading. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.66 points to 938.25. Its high for the session was posted at 11:30 A.M. when the average was ahead 0.50 point.

title: Czech Defector in Britain Is Said to Tell About Spying in Bonn
description: LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 24 (neuters) A Czechoslovak agent has defected to Britain, disclosing the identities of many Communist agents working in and around Bonn, The Daily Telegraph reported today.

title: RABIN BEATS PERES IN CONTEST TO LEAD RULING ISRAELI PARTY
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 23By a slim margin of 41 votes out of nearly 3,000, the governing Labor Party tonight nominated Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin to lead it into the elections scheduled for May 17 and to be its candidate for a second term as the head of the Israeli Government.

title: Parties and Issues in the Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSThe strikers belong to Local 74 of the Service Employees International Union, representing about 2,500 cleaners and handymen. These workersalong with 1,000 firemen and stationary engineers who belong to Local 94 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, who are not on strikeare direct employees of school custodians and are not covered by Civil Service.

title: Dangerous Precedent?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter appears to have won the political battle for authority, in the form he wants it, to reorganize the executive branch. He outmaneuvered his main opponent in Congress, Jack Brooks of Texas, by visiting with the members of Mr. Brooks's committee and winning them over to his approach. Mr. Brooks has found himself treated in the press as an obstructionist.

title: And Suddenly The Sun Breaks Out
description: Finally, after increasing doubts that this is the temperate zone, there came that first day of sensing the power of sunshine. This basic annual discovery caught people in various attitudes yesterday, and they altered their lives accordingly, if only to tilt their faces up and squint gratefully or to pick sunny patches for the routine of life. The traction was good for running or sitting as the temperature stopped just short of 50 degrees and helped dry out this winterbeaten region. The pleasures of stoopsitting with a beer and a crunchy sandwich were rediscovered. A few people shed coats. All at once, things became warm and bright.

title: Closing of 5 Alcoholism Centers Stirs Heated Opposition in State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23An order from the New York State Division of Alcoholism halting admissions to five rehabilitation centers around the state drew sharp criticism today from State Senator Joseph R. Pisani and the president of the State Association of Councils on Alcoholism.

title: Ulster Businessman Is Killed
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 23 (AP)A businessman was killed and another wounded in separate incidents today, bringing to four the number of business leaders attacked in four months. The dead man was Peter Hill, 45, coowner with his brother of Hill's (Derry) Ltd., furniture and drapery company. A second attack, in Belfast, resulted in the wounding of Leonard Steinberg, a director of the Stanley chain of legal betting shops.

title: $2 Million in Bonds Stolen in Manhattan Seized With 3 on L. I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I. Feb. 23The Nassau County District Attorney announced today the arrest of three men on charges of attempting to sell $2.5 million in stolen securities to a police undercover agent.

title: Siberian Husky's Trip Home Tougher Than Competition
description: An Arctic dog is in real trouble when he forgets his sled, and that is what happened to Ch. Dudley's Varska this week after the Siberian husky had outclassed 1,626 other competitors for the Hartford hestinshow punchbowl.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 23The high point of the Legislature's primary election debate last night was a hand gesture by Senator John D. Calandra that cannot be accurately described here. His fellow Republican, Nelson A. Rockefeller, the longago Governor of growth budgets, would recognize it, as would many other ordinary people who occasionally dabble in the araohie.

title: VANCE PLANS TO RECEIVE CUBAN EXILES TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance is scheduled to meet with six Cuban exile leaders on Friday to discuss the Carter Administration's policy toward the Government of President Fidel Castro.

description: A turbulent storm system struck the nation's midsection yesterday with tornadoes, violent winds, snow, freezing rain and ust storms, according to United Press International.

description: Antiboycott legislation is about to come before Congress again, raising two issues: how to guide American business through the Arab boycott against Israel in a morally defensible way, and how to handle a delicate Middle East diplomatic problem.

title: Market Place Stabilization of Fertilizer Stocks
description: Fertilizer stocks have been contrary market performers in the last several years. They moved up briskly in late 1974 while the rest of the market was falling apart. Then, in 1975 and most of 1976, they were one of the market's worstacting groups.

description: The Vatican has reasserted its disapproval of the granting of general absolutioo without individual confession as it was performed on two occasions late last Year in the Diocese of Memphis.

description: Lent, the 40day penitential prelude to Easter, began yesterday, and millions of Christians observed Ash Wednesday, the beginning of the traditional Lenten period of selfdenial, increased religious devotions and a renewed emphasis on works of charity.

description: A strike by 2,500 cleaners and handymen created confusion in New York City's public schools yesterday, caused more than a million pupils to go home early without lunch, and forced authorities to take emergency heat maintenance and garbagedisposal measures.

Hershey, who ran the Selective Service System from World War II to the war in Vietnam, is reported seriously ill following an apparent cerebral hemorrhage. The 83yearold retired Army general has been in intensive care at Walter Reed Army Medical Center since his admission on Sunday, Peter Esker, a hospita spokesman, said. He's currently listed as very seriously ill, Mr. Esker said.

title: Bridge: BottomSeed Beats Top One In Rare Result at Tourney
description: In any game or sport it hardly ever happens that the topseed loses to the bottom seed in the first round of an event. This curious circumstance occurred recently in the North Jersey double knockout team championship, which continues through most of the year.

The court yesterday rebuked the woman, Ella Filippone of Basking Ridge, who had pleaded guilty to false swearing before the Boards of Adjustment of Florham Park and Morristown.

description: William W. Scranton, former United States representative to the United Nations, has been elected to the board of The New York Times Company. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and president of the company, announced yesterday.

title: Canada's Newest Oldest Friend
description: Suddenly the United States has been cast as the great defender, instead of the enemy, of Canadian nationalism. That is how Prime Minister Trudeau perceived his mission to Washington this week and how President Carter, in careful and subtle comment, summarized their talks. The protection of Canada's federation against separatist challenge is a concern for Americans, as the President noted but a matter for Canadians alone to resolve.

This was a new production of the Puccini perennialnew to New York, anyway. It was on loan from the Chicago Opera. The big American houses have been exchanging productions in recent years, and it is a fine as well as a moneysaving idea. Especially when the production is as attractive as this Boheme.

Brown Jr's nomination of Rose Bird to be chief justice of the California Supreme Court has come under heavy partisan attack that involves the political ambition of one of the three members of a commission that will decide whether she is to be confirmed.

title: Federal Controls On Airlines Seen Increasing Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The domestic airline industry could have cut its operating costs between 1969 and 1974 and passed on to passengers nearly $2 billion a year in savings if the Government had not controlled fares, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said at his news conference that he wanted to make American concern for human rights felt around the world and never intended to single out the Soviet Union as the only major transgressor. He recalled his recent remarks about political prisoners in South Korea. Cuba and other Latin American countries and said recent actions in Uganda had disgusted the entire civilized world. His statement was seen as a gesture to case friction with the Soviet Union, which has complained that United States comments were interference in internal affairs. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Music: Brooklyn Philharmonia
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia can sometimes be more ambitious than satisfying. What with Lukas Foss's typically ingenuous, slightly giddy remarks and some occasionally rather painfully scrappy playing, it's tempting to be patronizing about the whole proposition.

title: 2 Die in Clash With Mexican Police
description: JUCHITAN, Mexico, Feb. 23 (AP)The police fired today on demonstrators at4empting to free imprisoned students, killing two youngsters and injuring 16 Persons, on official in this Oaxaca town Said. The demonstrations were reportedly Organized by local vocational and secondary schools that support a university Strike in Oaxaca, the state capital.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Yonkers Returning To Bond Market
description: The Yonkers City Council voted to return to the bond market to obtain $2.07.5 million for financing four capitalimprovement projects. The $2.075 million was p:Irt of a $5.3 million program that included 23 capitalimprovement projects.

title: ExSecret Service Agent Indicted For Stealing Federal Ammunition
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (AP)A 53yearold former Secret Service agent who once guarded United States Presidents has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges he stole 18,500 rounds of ammunition belonging to the service.

title: Joseph B. Phillips, Former Reporter, Newsweek Editor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Joseph B. Phillips, a retired Foreign Service office, newspaper reporter and magazine editor, died yesterday of multiple myekmaa m Sibley Memorial Mespital here. He was 77 years old.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: High Court Upholds E.P.A. Curbs On Industrywide Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the Federal Government's authority to impose binding industrywide regulations controlling the amount of pollutants that factories may dump into the nation's waterways.

title: President's Proposal To Cut Dams Angers Democrats in House
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23 (AP)Angry louse Democrats summoned up comparit.tons with the Nixon Administration today in denouncing President Carter's decision to stop new spending of 19 big water control projects.

title: First CloseUp of a Martian Moon Maps a Mysterious, Murky Place
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 23It is a dark and lumpy place, pocked by craters and grooved in some mysterious way, ancient and rugged, deeply ridged and hummocky, roughly like the highlands of Earth's moon.

title: No Early Westchester Shift From Con Edison Is Seen
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 23Alfred B. DelBello the Westchester County Executivei yvho is seeking to replace Consolidated, Edison as the major supplier of ??? in the county, conceded today it might be a matter of years before that objective could be achieved.

title: NAVI TO SAVE MILLIONS BY CONSOLIDATING BASES
description: WASHINGTON. 23 (AP)The Navy has announced base consolidations and other actions that it said would eliminate 500 civilian jobs and 16 military positions at an annual saving of about $5 million.

title: Bonds Make Pronounced Move Toward a Rise in Interest Rates
description: Credit markets, reacting to a warning from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board that increased Federal spending could be inflationary, made a pronounced move toward higher interest rates and lower bond prices yesterday. The Treas Credit Marketsury sold new fouryear notes at an average rate of 6.88 percent, which was higher than dealers expected late Tuesday. The Bell System sold $130 million of bonds) in the key corporate financing of the week, but investors were slow to buy the new securities. Some new taxexempt bonds broke more than two points shortly after they were auctioned.

title: GEORGE W. FISH, 81, DR. KILDARE MODEL
description: Dr. George Winthrop Fish, a retired urologist whose experiences provided the original inspiration for the popular Dr. Kildare series in books, movies and television, died Tuesday at his home at 10 Three Mill Harbor Drive, East Hampton, L.I. He was 81 years old.

title: Dave Anderson Henry Jordan and Joe Roth Class
description: They went quickly. Too quickly. Henry Jordan was only 42 years old when he died of a heart attack. Joe Roth was only 21 when he died of cancer. Some of the scoundrels in sports would not be missed, but noblemen like Henry Jordan and Joe Roth will he missed. The shame is that neither was as celebrated as he deserved to be. Henry Jordan was a humorous, agile and prematurely bald defensive tackle on the Green Bay Packers when they won five National Football League championships in seven years. But he never got Sports of The Time the FlenCillnes that Ills Coacn, Vince Lonlhardi, or many of his famous teammates did. Joe Roth was a quarterback at the University of California, the most sophisticated passer since Joe Namath, according to some N.F.L. scouts last season. But he didn't live long enough to get the headlines for having been a firstround draft choice. Even so, each left a heritage that's more important than headlines. People in sports call it class.

title: Washington &Business Status of AntiInflation Programs
description: WASHINGTONTo check inflation, the Carter Administration is looking beyond wage and price monitoring to the whole range of the Government's economic activities, including regulatory and tax policies.

title: Turner Backed By Senate Panel For C.I.A. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)The Senate Intelligence Committee unanimously recommended today that Adm. Stansfield Turner be confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Yachting
description: MIAMI;NASSAU RACE

title: Vandals Rob Rectory On Lower East Side
description: After gaining entry to a Lower East Side rectory by telling an elderly priest they wanted ashes for Ash Wednesday, two men yesterday ransacked the rectory and fled with $3,800 in cash, the police said.

title: H.E.W. Panel Starts Work on a Plan to Overhaul the Government's Various Assistance Programs for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Department of Health, Education and Welfare's reform panel has begun work on a plan to overhaul the nation's troubled income support programs.

title: No Cut for Yankee Batboys
description: The New York Yankees, with one of baseball's higherpriced collection of players, voted last year against giving their four batboys any share of World Series money.

title: Albany Autopsy On a Slashed Budget
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Life with the state budget has been somewhat calmer than usual this year because the grim economic realities have been ground in. Traditionally the Governor proposes a budget, whereupon the Legislature carries on like King Lear on the heath.

title: Senate Panel Extends Water Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23A 5316 million allocation to New York State for construction under the Clean Water Act would be extended for another year under action taken today by the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. The &location is now set to expire Sept. 30. If the full Senate concurs, New York would have until Sept. 30, 1978 to get the money obligated to a specific project.

title: Michael Baker Jr., 65, ExPenn State Trustee And Millionaire Engineer
description: HERSHEY, Pa., Feb. 23 (AP)Michael Baker Jr., who made millions on engineering contracts, died last night at the Hershey Medical Center, where he recently underwent heart surgery. He was 65 years old.

title: Rift Over Pastor In Plains Linked To Adopted Boy
description: PLAINS, Ga., Feb. 23One of the factors that played a little known but apparently significant role in the Rev. Bruce Edwards's resignation last Sunday as pastor of the Plains Baptist Church was disapproval by some church members of the adoption by the Edwards family of a nonCaucasian child.

title: Syracuse 106, Niagara 82
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP)Jimmy Williams led a balanced scoring attack as Syracuse defeated Niagara, 10682, tonight.

description: Article 10  No Title

description: MARKET INDEX

title: Burns Finds Business Nervous Over Federal Deficit W nts 1.114.F. to Watch Banks Loans to Poor Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, said today there was a certain nervousness in the business community about the size and growth of the Federal deficit and the continuation and Possible intensification of inflation. He also said he did not think this was the right time for President Carter to talk about an incomes policy to moderate wage and price increases because of businessmen's tears that price controls are down the road.

title: Schools Feel First Impact Of the Walkout Confusion
description: Confronted with 700 pounds of thawed chicken legs, Jessie Ingram and her kitchen staff cooked all morning at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side yesterday  even though, to minimize garbage problems during the maintenance workers strike, no lunch was to be served to the 2.300 students.

description: ELIZABETH, Feb. 23A 300foot opendeck barge, the McAllister Transporter, was formally commissioned today.

title: So What's the Bad Word?
description: Englsh suffers endless indignities, but it does not suffer in silence. So many expressions offend against hearing, taste or intelligence that linguistic vigilantes are forever deploying the weapons of authority, scorn, imprecation, even despair. A few of the critics manage to keep their powder wry.

title: Berglund Abolishes 11 Advisory Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)Eleven of the Agriculture Department's 108 advisory committees are going out of business as part of President Carter's campaign to simplify the Federal Government.

title: Levesque Accuses Trudean of Distortion Concerning Quebec in Speech to Congress
description: QUEBEC, Feb. 23Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec accused Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today of distortion in telling the United States Congress that only a small minority in Quebec wished to get out of the Canadian confederation.

title: MidFebruary Auto Sales Off 7.5%
description: DETROIT. Feb. 23American auto sales dropped 7.5 percent in midFebruary from last year and analysts cited the aftereffects of the January weather.

description: BOYS BASKETBALL

title: Meadowlands Joins Circuit The new Meadowlands track in East
description: Rutherford, N. J., has been added to the harness racing's Grand Circuit for 1977. The dates assigned are May 30 through June 4.

title: Insurer Ordered to Stop Writing Auto Policies in New York State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23The Empire Mutual insurance Company, one of the five largest writers of automobile insurance in New York State, has been ordered to stop writing policies because of severe financial problems resulting from heavy claims, particularly for cars stolen in New York City.

title: Cauthen in Doldrums? Rides Only One Winner After 7 Straight Races Without a Score
description: Even Steve Cauthen can't win em all.

title: Producers Start Seminars For HighSchool Students
description: Morton Gottlieb, producer of the comedy hit Same Time, Next Year, and Kenneth Waissman and Maxine Fox, producers of the longrunning musical Grease,, will speak today on producing in the first of five seminars on theater at Broadway houses for highschool students.

title: In Memorium
description: FRIEDMANSamuel. Very much missed and loved.

title: Possible Coffee Rigging Is Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)A Federal regulatory agency announced today that it was investigating the possible manipulation of United States coffee prices by commodities brokers from foreign coffee I producing countries.

title: Suit by Chris Craft Seesawed in Courts For Several Years
description: A little more than two years ago, Judge Milton Pollack, sitting in a Federal court in Manhattan, granted damages of roughly S1.7 million, plus interest, to Chris. Craft Industries Inc., the boat maker.

title: Notes on People
description: Patrick O'Neal, the actor, was sued for $280,000 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by an advert Rising agency that said he had failed to disclose that he was a former alcoholic when he signed a contract to make two television commercials about beer. The Kenyon & Eckhardt adagency said the commercials featuring Mr. O'Neal praising Andeker beer, a product of the Pabst Brewing Company were filmed in Mr. O'Neal's restaurant, The Ginger Man, but before they could he used, newspaper articles appeared listing the actor among show business personalities who said their lives were nearly ruined by drink. Subsequently, Mr. O'Neal's name appeared on the printed program for a forum sponsored by the National Council on Alcoholism. All this, Kenyon & Eckhardt's court papers said, rendered the O'Neal commercials useless and without value.

title: Scientists in Australia Photograph A Star Flashing 11 Times a Second
description: DENVER, Feb. 23Astronomers at the new AngloAustralian observatory at Siding Spring, Australia, have photographed a star that is flashing 11 times a second.

title: Mild London ByElection May Yield Signs of Britain's Political Trends
description: LONDON, Feb. 23You would think that the constituency should be represented by Robert Morley, Britain's television pitchman.

title: Women Voters Unit Assaying Operation Of Courts in Illinois
description: CHICAGOThere was a tawdry familiarity about the parade passing before Associate Circuit Judge Robert Cusick in Branch 44 of Women's Courtwigged prostitutes accused of soliciting or disorderly conduct a wellgroomed, middleaged white woman accused of shoplifting, and two embarrassed young men charged with seeking the services of a prostitute.

title: Waterbury Teachers Strike for a 2d Time In Last Two Months
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 23For the second time in two months, the 29 public schools here were shut down today by a teachers strike in a protracted contract dispute.

title: New Council Lines To Be Set Friday
description: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader, announced yesterday that the special Council redistricting commission would hold its final meeting at 11 A.M. tomorrow at City Hall and adopt new lines for 33 councilmanic districts the same day.

title: BIG BOARD PLANS SURVEY ON PUBLIC STOCK BUYING
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday plans for a survey later this year aimed at finding out how the public feels about investing in stocks.

title: Federal Controls On Airlines Seen Increasing Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The domestic airline industry could have cut its operating costs between 1969 and 1974 and passed on to passengers nearly $2 billion a year in savings if the Government had not controlled fares, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: NEW YORK OPPOSED ON RESERVOIR PLANS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23:Delegates from. New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware said today they would go to the United States Supreme Court if necessary to keep New York State from taking control of the flow of water from three huge reservoirs in the Delaware River Basin.

title: Deaths
description: ATWELLDaniel J., of Woodcliff Lake, N. J., on Feb. 21, 1977, beloved imsband of Ann Reynolds and father of Michael Atwell and Mrs. Nancy Sem. Mei also grandfather of Tay Atwell, Laurel, Atyssa and Daniel Semple. Private services. For further information cpnact the Vanderplaat Mineral Home, Wyckoff, N. J. Memorial donations may be made to the Valley Hospital, Riagewood, N. J. or Hie American Heart Association.

title: Scenery Falls as Opera Opens
description: Rossini's Barber of Seville, which opened the New York City Opera's Spring season at the New York State Theater last night, was disrupted whena 30foothigh section of the scenery  pitched forward and crashed to the stage. No one was injured. Pausing only to allow the reverberations of the unscored thunderclap to die away, Sarah Caldwell, who was conducting the special production she had brought with her from Boston lifted her baton and delivered the downbeat.

title: Behind the Scenes at WLBT in Jackson
description: JACKSON, Miss.What is unusual about television station WLBT here is not always apparent on the screen. Most hours of the day it is a fairly typical NBC affiliate carrying the standard c'rnrnercial fare.

title: Paris Police Disrupt A Rights Protest By a Soviet Exile
description: PARIS, Feb. 23 (AP)French policem today interrupted a protest demonstration by an exiled Soviet dissident, Andrei D. Amalrik, as he picketed the Presidential Palace. The interruption provoked him to say that the French police were completely comparable to the Soviet security oolice.

title: Corporation Affairs OwensIllinois Lifts Prices For Glass Containers by 8%
description: OwensIllinois Inc. took the lead yesterday in raising prices on glass containers by about 8 percent, effective April 1.

title: Hope H. Liberman Is Married to Julian Bach
description: Hope Harris Liberman, widow of Herman N. Liberman Jr., and Julian Bath, both of New York, were married yesterday evening at the home of the bride's brotherinlaw and sister, Mr. And Mrs. Richard L. Blum of New York.

title: Radio
description: 67 WNCNFM. Ballade in F, Chopin Danse Slave, Chabrier Overture to Les Cloches de Comeville, Playquette Flute Sonata in A. Mozart Variations on a Theme by Rossini, Chopin Tema Variato, Weber.

title: Echeverria, Playing According to Rules, Drops Out of Sight
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23It was no secret that he ruled until his last day in office, an aide said of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria Alvarez, but since he stepped down, he has turned his back on politics. He is respecting the rules of the came.

title: Rail Service to Atlantic City Proposed by Jersey Senator
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)A New. Tersey legislator is asking Federal and state officials to study the feasibility of highspeed rail service from Newark to Atlantic City and its future gambling casinos.

title: Utility Can Sell Its Land for Park
description: HARTFORD., Feb. 23 (AP)The United Illuminating Company has won approval to sell undeveloped Charles Island and sections of the nearby Milford shoreline to enlarge Silver Sands State Park. The State Public Utilities Control Authority approved the $552,950 sale of the land, which covers 72 acres. No one appeared in opposition to the sale during a hearing.

title: AMIN ACKNOWLEDGES MUTINY IN HIS ARMY
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 23Indications of unrest in Uganda increased today as President Idi Amin acknowledged to visiting British reporters that some dissident soldiers attempted to mutiny last Saturday and last night. He said that seven soldiers were killed in the incidents but that order was quickly restored.

title: Power Plant Hearings Delayed
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23 (UPI)The Public Service Commission today announced a twoweek delay in the start of hearings into the relative economic benefits of nuclear and fossilfuel electric generating facilities. A spokesman said the delay had been caused by a conflict in the schedule of the hearing officer, Robert Reed. The hearings were originally set to begin March R. but were postponed until 10 A.M. March 22 at the commi5sion's headquarters in the Empire State Plaza.

title: 5 Salmon Aides Indicted for Fraud
description: A 47count Federal indictment charged yesterday that five former principals of S. J. Salmon & Company, a defunct stock brokerage concern, conducted a fraudulent scheme to obtain more than $500,000 from the Securities Investors Protection Corporation.

title: BOEING'S EARNINGS UP 82% IN QUARTER
description: The Boeing Company, the nation's largest producer of commercial jet aircraft, and also in other aerospace activities, reported yesterday an 82 percent jump in fourthquarter earnings and a 34.9 percent climb for the year as a whole.

title: 5 Injured in Jersey Plant Fire
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 23 (AP)  Five persons were injured yesterday when propane  powered truck ignited at the Purepac Pharmaceutical Company here. Firefighters said a ball of flames encircled a forklift truck being repaired by Angelo Pennella, 62, of Colonia, burning him. Another employee and three firefighters were also injured.. The shipping section of the plant was extensively damaged, officials said.

title: Radio Communication Cloud Test Reset for Today by Air Force
description: ELGIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Feb. 23 (UPI)The Air Force will try again tomorrow night to float a 100milewide I cloud of barium crystals 116 miles above the Gulf of Mexico in a test aimed at j learning if such a cloud could block radiocommunication between an earth satellite and a plane.

description: x 3 for 2 split.sublect to approval, payable date unannounced.

He recalled his recent remarks about political prisoners in South Korea, Cuba and other Latin American countries and said recent actions in Uganda had disgusted the entire civilized world. His statement was seen as a gesture to ease friction with the Soviet Union, which has complained that United States comments were interference in internal affairs. I Page 1, Column 6.1

title: Books of The Times A Tear for Surrealism
description: DEATH OF A HAWKER. By JanwilAent van de Wettering. 185 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $6.95.

title: Witnesses Say Jerseyan Vowed to Kill Rockefeller
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Feb, 23A Secret Service agent and a pudgy informer nicknamed Kojak testified in Federal District Court today that a New Jersey member of the John Birch Society threatened twice last spring to assassinate Nelson A. Rockefeller then Vice President, and others during the Bicentennial Fourth of July weekend.

title: Support Prices Are Increased for '77 Crops
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland announced today increases in Federal target prices for basic. 1977 crops, reflecting higher farm production costs. The targets are used in computing how much farmers are to receive in Federal subsidies if cash market prices fall too much. Basically, farmers get direct payments if market prices fall below the targets.

title: RAOUL QUERZE
description: Raoul Querze, a teacher of singing and a tenor who appeared as Almaviva in Feodor Challapin's production of Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia at the Mecca Temple Auditorium in 1927 died Monday in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Conservationists Labeled Unfair to New Ski Areas
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Feb. 23Sep Benedikter, who was brought to Sun Valley from the Austrian Alps by W. Averell Harriman in 1936 to start a ski school, insists conservationists are unfair to recreational skiing. The formerinstructor, now a semiNews retired skiarea consultant, was one of 10 persons inof ducted into the National Skiing Hall of Fame in neighboring Ishpeming last Saturday. He emphasized that investors interested in creating Alpine ski centers were being balked by ecologists.

title: Hamilton 114, Clarkson 92
description: POTSDAM, N. Y.. Feb. 23John Klbuberg, a resident of Wantagh, L. I., became Hamilton's leading career scorer tonight. Klauberg scored 27 points to lead the Hamilton basketball team over Clarkson, 11492. He now has 1,348 points in less than three years of varsity competition, breaking the mark of 1.335 previously held by Warren Palmer. Klauberg's recordsetting basket came with only two minutes elapsed in the second half.

title: Suffolk County Puts Tax Services To Test and Finds That They Err
description: A test of the accuracy of incometax returns prepared by 10 commercial tax preparers by the Suffolk County Department of Consumer Affairs found that they made from six to 13 errors in computing the Federal tax to be paid on a model return. The test found that the errors would have cost the fictitious couple fil7,jng the return as much as $304.

title: CHESIMARD ATTORNEY ACTS TO CALL KELLEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 23Attorneys for Joanne Chesimard filed papers today in Superior Court asking Judge Theodore Appleby to subpoena Clarence M. Kelley, the F.B.I. Director Senator Frank Church and other Federal and New York law enforcement officials to testify about a program designed to harass and disrupt black activist organizations.

title: Prices Up Sharply In Soybean Futures Other Gains Listed
description: Prices of soybean futures soared yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after dropping the day before. Prices of wheat, corn and oats also pulled upward.

title: Bond to Close Times Square Store
description: Bond Stores, the retail clothing chain, said yesterday that it would in all probability close its main New York store in Times Square by June 30 after several years of unprofitable operations.

title: Trifecta Pays $5,074
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 23 (AP)A $5,074.80 trifecta payoff shared the spotlight with the feature race winner, Growl, at Meadowlands Raceway tonight. Miss Easy Direct, an 181 shot, set off the trifecta, paying $37.20 to win. Smoky Affair and Derby Lee completed the large return on 8110 in the third race. Growl took the sixth race and paid $11.20.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York. Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Magistrate Delays NBC Pact With Women Employees
description: A Federal magistrate objected yesterday to a provision in the proposed $21 million settlement of a sexdiscrimination suit by women employees of the National Broadcasting Company.

title: World News Briefs Panama Talks Recess U.S. Reports Problems
description: PANAMA, Feb. 23 (AP)United States negotiators for a new Panama Canal treaty returned home today after declaring that there are still major problems in the talks.

title: 3 States Oppose New York's Plan To Control Delaware Water Flow
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23Delegates from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware said today they would go to the United States Supreme Court if necessary to keep New York State from taking control of the flow of water from three huge reservoirs in the Delaware River Basin.

description: ACROSS

title: New Escalators for Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23 (AP)The New Jersey Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner, said the Federal Government had approved a program to allow the Port Authority of New York and New Jersy to pay the $1.7 milion cost of new escalators for Newark's Penn Station, but a spokesman for the Federal Railroad Association yesterday declined to say the approval has been given. Under the financing plans, the Port Authority would pay to replace nine escalators in the rail terminal, but would be reimbursed proportionately when the Federal Government has computed the state, local and Federal shares of the rehabilitation costs.

title: WALKOUT IS HOBBLING SCHOOLS IN NEW YORK
description: A strike by 2,500 cleaners and handy men created confusion in New York City's public schools yesterday, caused mere than a million pupils to go home early without lunch, and forced authorities to take emergency heat, maintenance and garbagedisposal measures.

title: Romero Leading in El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Feb. 23 (Reuters)San Salvador returned to normal today as demonstrators protesting against the apparent victory of Gen. Carlos Romero for the Presidency lifted roadblocks in the suburbs. With more than half the votes counted, General Romero, the candidate of the ruling National Conciliation Party, had 660,371 votes to 304,151 for Col. Ernesto Claramount, the candidate of the centerleft National Opposition Union.

title: The U.N. Today Feb. 24. 1977 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Outer Space Scientific and Technical Subcommittee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
