description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Advertising K. E. and Its Roster of Supporters
description: As the marketers cost of doing business continued to climb, LeoArthur Kelmenson, president and since 1970 chief executive of Kenyon & Eckhardt, became convinced that agencies had to be surer and surer of the advice they gave their clients. So he began about two years ago recruiting heavyweights for top management positions.

title: NonNegotiable Checks Included In Armed Yonkers Bank Robbery
description: YONKERS, Feb. 23The holdup men who escaped yesterday from the Hudson Valley National Bank here with what was thought to he more than a million rloilars may find their haul considerably diluted by large amounts of nonnegotiable checks, a Federal Bureau of Investigation official said today.

title: COUNCILMAN SUES CITY FOR $5 MILLION IN FALL
description: A New York City Councilman, Frank S. Biondolillo, filed a S5 million negligence claim against the city yesterday for serious injuries he sustained when he slipped on a tuna sandwich and fell down a flight of stairs at City Hall.

title: Senate Panel Votes To Restore Funds For Public Works
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee voted 9 to 3 today to restore all but bout $20 million of the $154 million in publicworks money that it had recently islashed from allotments for New York, I New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: PARAGUAY IS FREEING POLITICAL PRISONERS
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 23 (AP)As in other. Latin American countries, the 23year regime of President Alfredo Stroessner is beginning to release political prisoners. Former inmates tell of torture andg inhumane treatment while in confinement.

title: Alex Chilton, Rock Legend, Back
description: Rockandroll is full of spuriously hyped legends, but Alex Chilton, who closed a twonight run at the Lower Manhattan Ocean Club Tuesday and who will return to CBGB's (with Talking Heads) March 35, really is legendary.

title: The Age of Suspicion, Still Ticking
description: The Attorney General's list is gone. The Subversive Activities Control Board has disappeared. The hysteria and witchhunting of the 1950's have become topics for television retrospection. Yet the McCarthy Era still lives, ticking away in our laws, creating embarrassment and harm to the national interest. Yesterday, in his news conference, President Carter took disapproving note of one of the most repellent legacies. His view merits applause and prompt translation into corrective legislation.

title: Iona 116, Long Island U. 90
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 23Iona, with seven players scoring in double figures strengthened its bid for an E.C.A.C. playoff berth with a 11690 rout of Long Island tonight.

title: Spend More Time With the Family? Carter's Aides Find They Can't
description: WASHINGTON, FEB. 23According to his wife, Frank Moore hasn't managed to make it home for dinner a single night since he went to work at the White House a month ago.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Airlines Warned of Bad Jet Parts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)Warning of possible hazards, the Government said today that it had ordered airlines to remove immediately three bogus parts from Boeing 737 jets.

title: Senate Panel Sets Special Debate To Weigh Warnke Qualifications
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23The Senate Armed Services Committee today ended two days of sharp questioning of Paul C. Warnke, and then scheduled an unusual debate next Monday on Mr. Warnke's sualifications to serve as President Carters chief armscontrol negotiator and director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: MINNESOTA VICTORY ELATES REPUBLICANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Jubilant Republican Party leaders said today that the upset victory of Arlan Stangeland in a special Congressional election yesterday in Minnesota heralded the party's resurgence in 1978.

title: Philippines, Upset After U.S. Defeat in Indochina, Seeks New Role in Southeast Asia Power Balance
description: MANILA, Feb. 20The American defeat in Indochint has given the Philip pines, traditionally America's closest ally in Asia, an acute case of schizophrenia,President Ferdinand E. Marcos is working hard to establish on advontaeous place for his country in the new balance of power in Southeast Asia and the world, and often the tone of Philippine officials and the controlled press is unaccustomedly antiAmerican. But the heart does not appear to he in it.

title: Supreme Court Overturns Award Won by ChrisCraft
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Supreme Court overturned today the biggest damage award ever made under Federal securities lawsa S35.8 million judgment that a Federal appeals court awarded to ChrisCraft Industries Inc., in 1975, in the litigation over ChrisCraft's unsuccessful bid to take over the Piper Aircraft Corporation.

title: Rohatvn Views Casinos as Financial Aid to the City
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, suggested yesterday that stateoperated gambling casinos could be part of a unified strategy to preserve and expand the shrinking tax base of financially ailing New York City.

title: Barons Get Refinancing, Players Back in Uniform
description: The battered Cleveland Barons of the National Hockey League, who seemed headed for extinction as late as 4 A.M. yesterday, have received a $1.3 million Band Aid that should carry them to the end of the season, six weeks away.

title: MRS. ABZUG HEARS ADVICE ON CAMPAIGN
description: With the New York primary date now set for June and time running out for candidates to enter the mayoral race, Bella S. Abzug acted like a mayoral candidate yesteruay, but did not announce her candidacy.

title: New Escalators for Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23 (AP)The New Jersey Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner, said the Federal Government had approved a program to allow the Port Authority of New York and New Jersy to pay the $1.7 milion cost of new escalators for Newark's Penn Station, but a spokesman for the Federal Railroad Association yesterday declined to say the approval has been given. Under the financing plans, the Port Authority would pay to replace nine escalators in the rail terminal, but would be reimbursed proportionately when the Federal Government has computed the state, local and Federal shares of the rehabilitation costs.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press LondonDave (Roy) Green. 119 pounds, Britain, outoolnted Mario Guilloti, 1221/2. Argentina. 10 rounds.

title: Goernmental Financing Is Urged tO Ease Banks International Load
description: LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters)Since 1973, bank financing has borne a very large and, perhaps excessive share of total balanceofpayments financing, according to John Kirbyshire, chief adviser to the Bank of Eneland.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CHICAGO (NL)Signed Bin Bonham, Sieve Rrnko, riont nanded Pitchers Bill Buckner, pone Clines, outfieleers Steve Ontiveros, Ivan De Jest's, infielders..

title: 2 WOMEN TO RESIST INQUIRY ON BOMBING
description: The two women who have been resisting Government efforts to get them to testify before a grand jury that is looking into terrorist bombings asserted yesterAay that the Government inquiry was a massive fishing expedition aimed at destroying the Puerto Rican independence movement.

title: Ossining Youth Stricken With Reye's Syndrome 4th Westchester Victim
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Feb. 23 (AP)A 16yearold Ossining boy has become the fourth youth in the last two weeks in northern Westchester County to be stricken With the rare disease known as Reye's Syndrome.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: The New York Times Company yester day declared a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock, payable March 28 to stockholders of record March 18. A regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share was declared on the 51/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable April 1 to stockholders of record March 18.

title: Japanese Students Tensely Undergo Annual Exam Hell
description: TOKYO, Feb. 22 It is grueling, it is expensive, it is frightening. It supports a vast industry and causes sleepless nights, ulcers and suicides.

title: Edith Barrett, Longtime Actress On Stage and Screen, Dies at 64 Victory Over Typecasting
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 23 (AP)Edith Barrett, longtime stage and film actress, died of a heart attack yesterday at a nursing home here. She was 64 years old.

title: You can move on. And on. But somewhere it must end.
description: The following open letter Is adapted from the book The Town That Fought to Save Itself. The author a writer, lives in California.

title: 6% INTEREST IS SET ON MORATORIUM NOTES
description: Justice James Gibson of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that holders of New York City notes should receive 6 percent annual inter..st on the value of their notes from the time of maturity to the time of repayment.

title: Five Killed in Plane Crash
description: SPRINGDALE, Ark., Feb. 23 (AP)Four life insurance executives and the female pilot of a private airplane were killed yesterday when the plane exploded and crashed. The victims were Nancy Barrett, pildt of the twinengine Piper Navajo, and Jimfriy Kenneth Fulkerson, 35 years old James Ward Jr.. 35 Fabe Ingram, 42, and Real Yowell, 34, all vice presidents for World Service Life Insurance Company.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Nets Late Outburst Sinks Nuggets,. 9188
description: UNIONDALE, L.L, Feb. 23The New York Nets, trailing the worst record in the National Basketball Association behind them, ambushed the league's best tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, defeating Denver. 9188.

title: CARTER IS SAID TO DENY C.I.A. PAID VENEZUELAN
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 23 (Reuters) The Venezuelan Foreign Minister says that President Carter has denied a report in The New York Times that the Central Intelligence Agency gave money to President Carlos Andras Parez in the early 1960's. Foreign Minister Raman Escovar Salom said last night that the denial, dismissing the report as groundless and malicious, was contained in a letter delivered to Mr. Parez yesterday by the United States ambassador.

title: Resorts Jumping, but Who's Skiing?
description: LENOX, Mass.Whether or not it snows makes little difference to the modern ski resort hotel these days. There is so much going on that a guest can hardly find time to strap on a pair of boots and take a run downhill without missing some of the fun inside.

title: Carter Errs on Rabin And U.S.Uganda Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)President Carter made two errors in his news conference today, which the White House staff later corrected.

title: $,16 Billion Package To Aid the Economy Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The House recommended today a $16.4 billion package of tax cuts and spending increases to stimulate the economy over the next seven months.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Jersey Briefs Seized Records Studied
description: Hudson County investigators were studying stacks of parking violations and purchasing records seized during a raid of the municipal complex and a local lumber company in North Bergen.

title: ShaleLike Material Reported
description: DENVER, Feb. 23The principal investigators of the Viking project tolda scientific meeting here today that they had found on Phobos what they believe is a material rich in carbonaceous chondrites somewhat similar to oil shale.

title: CARTER SAYS HOLDUP IN SUPPLIES OF GAS IS UNDERSTANDABLE HIS STAND COMES AS A SURPRISE
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23  President Carter said today that it was understandable that natural gas is withheld from the market by producers waiting for higher prices.

title: Youths Rescued As Adventure Goes Awry
description: Three youngsters who thought that sailing on ice floes would be fun, had time to reflect on their folly as they sat marooned in Boston's Dorchester Bay. Police rescued boys from their slowly disintergrating rafts in 30 feet of water.

title: Where to Plug Into Television
description: Television, the underground New York rock band, will be at CBGB's through tomorrow. Ordinarily that would not be so unusual: the band has played the Bowery club persistently for nearly three years. It can even claim legitimate credit for starting the whole CBGB's scene, as the first rock band to play there. But people who like to be in on things from the outset might make an effort to get down to the club this weekend, because Television's tenure at the club may be drawing to a close.

title: Golsteyn and Shaw: On the Road Back
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 24The blood on the walls shows how seriously some Giants take the racquetball games. But the only National Football League team so far in Giants Stadium is thinking seriously of football as well this offseason.

title: N.Y. State Audit Finds Improper Medicaid Payments
description: The first fullfledged audit of Medicaid eligibilty in New York State indicates that $200 million a year is being lost statewide in payments for ineligible persons and in overpayment errors.

title: Art: Radical, Traditional Degas
description: OF ALL the myths and misperceptions that afflicted the life of art in the great age of the Impressionist masters, perhaps the most preposterous was the notion that these inspired artists represented some radical repudiation of the past. The truth was exactly the reverse, of course. Manet, Renoir, Pissarroall worshipped at the shrine of the old masters. And none was more assiduous in his study of pictorial tradition than Edgar Degas (18341917). Yet out of his profound attachment to the past, Degas produced some of the most radical artistic innovations of his time.

title: Management
description: The annual meeting season is stirring starting the buildup toward the last two weeks of April, the year's busiest meeting period. For chief executives, it may be a time of verbal bouquets or verbal batterings.

title: A Budget Blessed by Inexperience
description: President Carter's revision of the Ford budget shows the advantages and dangers of inexperience. Although total expenditures were increased to advance the goal of economic stimulus and recovery, the budget is noteworthy for two sets of politically daring reductions. The President proposed delays, leading to cuts, in defense and in some major water projects.

title: Lauda Fastest in Practice
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 24 (AP) Niki Lauda dominated practice today at Kyalami for the March 5 South African Grand Prix. The 29yearold Austrian set the pace in his 12cylinder Ferrari with a lap of 1 minute 15.6 seconds, an average of 120 miles an hour. Jody Scheckter of South Africa was timed in 1:15.8 in his WolfFord; Patrick Depailler of France clocked 1:16 A in his sixwheel Tyrell, and the world driving champion, James Hunt of Britain, powered his McLaren M23 through a lap in 1:16.8.

title: Opera: Pavarotti Shines in 13oheme
description: IT WAS IN PUCCINI's La Bobeme that Luciano Pavarotti conquered New York, and he was back at the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night as Rodolfo. This was a new production of the Puccini perennialnew to New York, anyway. It was on loan from the Chicago Opera. The big American houses have been exchanging productions in recent years, and it is a fine as well as a moneysaving idea. Especially when the production is as attractive as this Boheme.

title: Prisoner in Turkeyan American's Nightmare
description: In the fall of 1970, Billy Hayes, a 23yearold from Long Island, was one of several hundred American youths traveling through Europe and Asia. It was the thing to do at the time of the Vietnam War and the domestic troubles of the late 1960's. Most young men and women went abroad to clear their heads a bit some on journeys of selfdiscovery. Billy Hayes, who had dropped out of Marquette University, had no particular ambition as he roamed: He made friends and he used drugs. But suddenly one day in Istanbul. Mr. Hayes's sojourn abroad turned into a nightmare.

title: REV. MARTIN F. BUCKLEY
description: The Rev. Martin F. Buckley, who served in several Roman Catholic parishes inthe New York metropolitan area and was an Army chaplain for 30 years, died Mon day at his home in Port Jefferson, I. where he lived in retirement with his sis ter, Charlotte Peterson. He was 63 year old.

title: Monserrat Fined After Guilty Plea
description: Joseph Monserrat, a member of the New York City Board of Education and its president for two years, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of conflict of interest stemming from his connection with an audiovisual company doing business with city schools.

title: Perry Suffers Sprained Ankle
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP)Ronnie Perry, the star freshman who was tuning up for the start of the playoffs next week, suffered a severely sprained left ankle tonight as Holy Cross breezed to a 11189 victory over Boston University.

title: Mafia Said to Have Slain Rosselli Because of His Senate Testimony
description: Shortly after John Rosselli testified before a Senate committee that he had participated in Central Intelligence Agency plots to kill Fidel Castro, a Washington friend asked him if he wasn't afraid for his life. The 70yearold Mafia figure appeared unconcerned: Who'd want to kill an old man like me? he asked. fished a 55gallon oil drum from Dumfoundling Bay and found Mr. Rosselli's body inside, there was no shortage of suspects, ranging from the C.I.A. to Cuban agents or the Mafia itself.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges have issued the following reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies:

title: Across the Plaza, Another Orchard
description: With all the theatrical activity that goes on in New York, it is not surprising for two versions of a classic play to surface at roughly the same time. But the arrival of The Cherry Orchard, directed by Alan Schneider, at Juilliard's Theater Center, almost simultaneously with that of Andrei Serban's Cherry Orchard across Lincoln Center Plaza at the Vivian Beaumont. Theater, did raise a few eyebrows.

title: Massage Parlor Loses
description: New York City won permission yesterday to close a socalled massage parlor without a preliminary hearing after Justice Thomas J. Hughes ruled in State. Supreme Court in Manhattan that the undisputed use of the parlor, the Sunshine Massage Studio at 12 East 42d Street, to promote prostitution violated the terms of the certificate of occupancy. Alice Hampton, the parlor's manager, had pleaded guilty and was fined for promoting prostitution.

title: Books of The Times
description: LET'S ASSUME for a moment that Erich Segal's Love Story was a decent enough novelnot cheaply sentimental, selfpitying, gratuitous and slick. Assume it was a harmless read, worth the few hours it took to weep through and the four hankies it took to blow the nose and dab the eyes. The question then Is, Goes its sequel, Oliver's Story, live up to it? I don't think so. The new novelabout how Oliver Barett IV recovers from Jenifer eavilleri's death with a little help from psychotherapy and a love affair with departmentstore heiresslacks something that Love Story seems to have had. Symmetry of plot? Contrast of character types? The lingering La Dame aux Camellias death? Something.. The incessant coyness of Mr. Segal's prose and dialogue seems less  surprising, if surprisingly incessant coyness can be considered a virtue. The breezy slickness seems more like  a hurricane of hair oil.

title: Associated Press
description: TANKER MEETS BRIDGE: The sulphur tanker Marine Floridian after it smashed into a bridge over the James River

title: Senate Confirms Turner for C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 24 (AP)The Senate unanimously confirmed today the appointment of Adm. Stansfield Turner to be Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: The New York Times/John Soto

title: The Pop Life
description: KATE AND ANNA McGarrigle put out record early last year that was as beloved by the critics as it was ignored by the public. This particular critic raved about it, but so did a lot of othersso many that a full year later, when thousands of better publicized albums had come along to challenge its memory, the disk still placed No. 5 in Robert Christgau's annual poll of 66 rock critics nationwide.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 9yearold boy was killed by a train early today after he was trapped on a Long Island Rail Road overpass. The victim's 12yearold brother narrowly escaped injury. The Suffolk County police said that Michael Konon of 3 Frati Road, East Farmingdale, LI., tried to run from the trestle, which spans Route 109 at Southern State Parkway, but Was struck a glancing blow by the train.

title: 2D CHEMICAL SPILL FLOWS, INTO WEST VIRGINIA RIVERS
description: SOUTH CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Three tons of carbon tetrachlorifle seeped out of a ruptured tank at the FMC Corporation chemical plant today, threatening communities down the Kanawha and Ohio Rivers for the second consecutive week.

title: Red Smith
description: Howard Davis Jr., the 1976 Olympic lightweight champion, took a professional record of 0 victories, 0 defeats and 0 draws, including 0 knockouts, into a ring in Las Vegas last month, pitched a sixround shutout against an absorbent character named Jose Resto and walked away with a purse of $17,500.

title: Sweeping Pupils Under the Rug
description: The strike by 2,500 cleaners and handymen of the public schools custodial staff constitutes the latest assault against this city's schoolchildren. Subject even normal times to the endemic disadvantages of urban education, these children have suffered a succession strikes and other disruptions caused by adults whose duty it ought to be to keep schools going. The present strike has further shortened the already truncated classroom time, and shut several schools altogether. School lunches have been canceleda mere inconvenience for affluent youngsters but a hardship for the poor.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: The New York Times/Frank C. Doveherty

title: In Memoriam
description: REYBACKRoslyn. Razle we are always thinking of YOU. GLENN and GARY. WEINMANIsak Walker. Feb. 25, 1951: In abiding love and unfading memory of my adored father.

title: At the Movies
description: RINGO STARR, the beloved Beatle of yesteryear, yearns to be known as Ringo Starr, movie star. That's why he has tackled the challenging role of a mad Hungarian director who masterminds the comeback of his sensuous, blond former wife in Sextette. Mr. Starr clearly has his histrionic work cut out for him, since his leading lady is one of filmdom's most seductive scenestealers: Mae West.

title: Soviet Physicist Deported In Canadian Spy Case
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Immigration Department said today that Soviet exchange physicist, Lev G. Khvostantsev, had been arrested and deported on suspicion of espionage.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Stake: Shaw's Caesar and Cleopatra
description: THERE IS PROBABLY something for everyone to dislike in Shaw's Caesar and Cleopatra, an overinflated play that floats over the theater like a pompous dirigible in search of a mooring. However, that having been said, the production of the play by Ellis Rabb, which opened last night at the Palace Theater, is not at all bad, even if somewhat conventional in'its concept of Egyptian grandeur and Shavian dialectic.

title: Red Wings 3, Penguins 2
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP)Fred Williams, Bob Ritchie, and Dave Kelly, all rookies, each scored his second goal of the season and gave the Detroit Red Wings a comeback, 32, victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in the N.H.L.

title: Bishop F. J. Warnecke, 70, Dies; Episcopal Leader of Ecumenism
description: Bishop Frederick J. Warnecke, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Bethlehem, Pa., from 1954 until his retirement in 1971, died Wednesday at a Boca Raton, Fla.. hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: AUTO OUTPUT SCHEDULED TO DROP 0.3% THIS WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24American autc makers are scheduled to build 199,69E cars this week, 0.3 percent below the 200,305 units built last week, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: Broadway
description: THERE is a passion in Trish Van DeVere's life, and it is ideological. Miss Van DeVere will stay with Sly Fox until May, and then she will start working seriously on a onewoman show about Victoria Woodhull, Everyone theater, it seems, now wants to do a oneman, or onewoman, show, but Miss Van DeVere wants to do one out of conviction.

title: BILLY CARTER ASSERTS TIMES MISQUOTED HIM
description: PLAINS, Ga., Feb. 24 (AP)Billy Carter says he was misquoted in a report that the resignation of the Rev. Bruce Edwards as pastor of the Plains Baptist Church was precipitated by the minister's adoption of a nonCaucasian child.

title: 1,800 skiers Are Preparing For Touring Race Tomorrow
description: HAYWARD, Wis., Feb. 24  More than 1,800 skiers, a record field for the United Slates, will start Saturday in the 55kilometer Birkebeiner ski touring race over the rolling country of the Badger State. As expected, we'll have more than 400 skiers from Norway in our race,' said Ken Snow, the manager of the Telemark Lodge in nearby Cable.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: RHODESIA WILL SEEK TO DEPORT A BISHOP
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 24The Rhodesian Government announced today that it would seek to deport the Roman Catholic Bishop of Umtali, who won reduction in a jail sentence earlier in the day.

title: (Churchmen Say Amin Is Carrying Out Drive Against 2 Uganda Tribes)
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 24Prominent church sources here, including some who have recently left Uganda, have said that the current turbulence in that country began a month ago with the opening of a Government campaign against Christian churchmen and members of the predominantly Christian Lango and Acholi tribes.

title: People and Business
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said yesterday that banks should pay less attention to the man in Singapore and more attention to the man in Nassau County. The Wisconsin Democrat, in an address at the 32d annual Board of Realtors mortgage conference in Great Neck, said: Small business needs loans, farmers need loans, homeowners need loans. Plenty of Americans want loans at low interest rates. The American loan market is not soft.

title: Verona's StarCross'd Kids Are Bask
description: ROMEO AND JULIET. What again? Maybe the most performed play over the last 300 or so years, done by everyone from the immortal Duse to the tyros in the local school drama society. Yet it's back this weekend and full of promise.

description: 11 A.M.35pound weight thro N: Larry Hart, Peter Farmer, Emmift Berry, Pete Gallo, Harold Connolly, George Frenn.

description: FIRST$6.000, pace, ci., mile. Prob.

title: LACK OF HEAT CLOSES 16 NEW YORK SCHOOLS
description: Lack of heat forced the closing yesterday of 16 New York City schools with nearly 17,000 pupils, and at many other schools teachers and youngsters had to wear coats thtir damp, cold classrooms as boilerroom workers refused to cross picket lines set up by striking school cleaners and handymen.

title: Melville Reports to the S.E.C. $315,000 of Questionable Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Melville Corporation has found $315,000 of questionable transactions in an investigation covering the last five years, according to a filing made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: S. Whitney Satterlee Dies at 69; Was Retired Banking Executive
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Feb. 24S. Whitney Satterlee, a retired New York City banking executive, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old and had resided at 6 Gold Street.

title: Mr. Trudeau, what's a Canuck?
description: Recently, a reader questioned the use of the word Canuck by New York Times columnist William Safire. Mr. Safire asked Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for his opinion of the word's current usage and meaning, and received the following reply.

title: Economic Scene: Worries of Nation's Steelmakers
description: being fashioned in Washington, the threat of even tighter Governmental regulation of their operations and the effects of the winter's frigid weather.

title: Its a lot more than the news
description: Its a lot more than the news

title: British Seeking a Way to Discourage Visit by Amin
description: LONDON, Feb. 24Horrified by what has been happening in Uganda, yet powerless to do much of anything about it, the British are casting about for some means of keeping as far from these shores as possible the man they consider the villain of the pieceField Marshal Idi Amin, President for life of Uganda.

title: Rutgers Subdues Villanova, Takes Title
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24 Rutgers won the East Division of the Eastern Collegiate Basketball League tonight, beating Villanova, 8781, before a standingroomonly crowd in the Barn.

title: A Retrospective of Women Master Builders at Work
description: That woman was an architect, not mailorder bride, and the directory was a listing of female architects, drawn up in the late 1930's by the Women's Architectural Club of Chicago. The group was eventually absorbed into the American Institute of Architects and later became known as a club for architects wives.

title: Cyprus Trip Evokes Memories For Clifford of Truman Doctrine
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 24During his recent trip to Athens, Clark M. Clifford visited a statue of Harry S. Truman, sponsor of the policy that helped save Greece and Turkey from Communist subversion in the late 1940's. Later, Mr. Clifford expressed regret that the statue had been defaced in recent years by antiAmerican protesters.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The Committee on the Present Danger, through the chairman of its executive committee, Eugene V. Roskm, denies that it opposes effective arms limitation but, to the contrary, insists that it favors hardheaded and verifiable agreements to control and reduce armaments (letter Feb. 17).

title: S.E.C. IS TIGHTENING RULE ON DISCLOSING BIG STOCKHOLDERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Securities and Exchange Commission, responding partly to fears of some members of Congress that foreign investors may secretly acquire large stakes in American compl, nies, adopted rules today to expand the amount of information publicly available about corporate ownership. Many large, investors not now clearly subject to such disclosure will be forced to tell the corn, mission of their holdings whenever they exceed 5 percent of a company's stock.

title: Jordan and P.L.O. Agree, in First Talks Since 1970, on Forming Lir&
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 24The Government of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization have reached agreement in principle on the need for strong link between Jordan and a proposed Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip, accordina to authoritative Jordanian officials.

title: Rumania and Senegal Chiefs Meet
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Rumanian head of state, Nicolae Ceaucescu, today held first round of talks here with President Leopold S. Senghor on bilateral cooperation and major international issues. Mr. Ceaucescu began his visit here yesterday.

title: Lack of Heat in Strike Closes 16 New York Schools
description: Lack of heat forced the closing yesterday of 16 New York City schools with nearly 17,000 pupils, and at many other schools teachers and youngsters had to wear coats in their damp, cold classrooms as boilerroom workers refused to cross picket lines set up by striking school cleaners and handymen.

title: WESTCHESTER YOUTH, 16, DIES OF REYE'S SYNDROME
description: A 16yearold Ossining youth, one of four youngsters in northern Westchester County to come down with Reye's Syndrome in the last two weeks, died yesterday in the County Medical Center in Valhalla.

title: Rabin Says Peres Would Be Member Of His Government
description: JERUSALEM, Feb, 24Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that he would include his political rival, Defense Minister Shimoct Peres, in his Cabinet if, as expected, he Is returned to office in the midMay general elections.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: Article 17  No Title

title: Saluting a National Treasure at 75
description: She possessed one of the outstanding voices of the century, and she broke racial barriers to become one of America's most honored women, but to the 24 members of Marian Anderson's extended family she is simply Aunt Marian.

title: REVENUE HOPES GROW IN NEW YORK LOTTERY
description: New York State's new lottery, which started last September, was expected yesterday to bring in for the state an estk mated total of $90 million by the end of the current budget year, or $30 million above the first estimates.

title: Carter Says Foreign Intelligence Sources Are Questioning Their Safety After Reports on the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24  President Carter said today that recently published reports about the Central Intelligence Agency's contacts abroad have prompted some foreigners who had been providing important information to the United States to question the secrecy and safety of their roles.

title: Amalrik Sees Paris Legislators
description: PARIS, Feb. 24 (AP)The exiled Soviet dissident Andrei D. Amalrik, seized yesterday when he made an abortive attempt to meet President Valery Giscard d'Es taing, met for 90 minutes today with ma jority legislators in the Senate.

title: Soybeans Advance 10 Cents, Pulling Up Prices for Grains
description: Prices of soybean futures advanced 10 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, again pulling up also the prices of the soybean products and grains traded on the same exchange. Yesterday's rise in soybeans brought the twoth.y advance to 31 cents a bushel.

title: $750 MILLION MORE PROPOSED FOR CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called today for an increase in Federal assistance to cities by $750 million next year, with most of the money to go toward a new action fund for cities with serious deterioration problems.

title: Adirondack Railway Plans Approved by State Officials
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24An abandoned 118mile railroad bed running through the heart of the Adirondack Park got a start today toward rebirth when state officials announced that they had approved the plans of a group of private investors to rehabilitate the old track and operate it as a scenic recreational railway.

title: Regents Weigh a 5Week School Closing Next Winter
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The State Board of Regents is considering a revised school calendar that would require all schools to close, for five weeks next winter to conserve fuel. Under the proposal, school would begin next Sept. 1 and end June 30, 1978.

title: New Unemployment Claims Drop
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  New claims for unemployment insurance filed in the week ended Feb. 12 numbered 608,000, off by 147,400 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: CHEMICAL BANK CITED FOR FAILURE TO LIST BIG CASH EXCHANGES
description: The Chemical Bank was indicted yesterday on a charge of having failed to report 500 cash transactions, amounting to $8.5 million, as required by the Federal Bank Secrecy Act.

title: Antiques
description: SEATS, an uncommon exhibition of the furniture three centuries have sat upon, opened at the Yale University Art Gallery this week and will remain on view through April 24. The show, which should prove of major interest to collectors of antique furniture, is historically wide ranging, and it is also democratic. It includes everything from rare Chippendales carved for aristocrats to the more common Windsors on which farmers and factory workers paused.

title: Scientists Are Told of Population Shift to Rural Areas
description: DENVER, Feb. 24The rural renaissance of the 1970's has been generated by younger, better educated and more affluent people who arc demanding of their new country surroundings more of the urban amenities that they left behind a group of sociologists told a national science meeting here today.

title: Television
description: FRIDAY

title: Amends for Yank Batboys
description: Sparky Lyle, the Yankee relief pitcher, said yesterday that the Yankees would pay their four batboys World Series shares of $100 each out of the players fine fund.

title: Bronx Bank Robbed Of $20,000 by Woman
description: A stocky young robber held up Chemical Bank branch in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, escaping with $20,000 and leaving seasoned detectives shaking their heads in wonder.

title: H.E.W. Investigator Named
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 24 (AP)President Carter chose a veteran government in estigator today for a new job to rent it houd and abuse of programs administered by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: White Rhodesia, Rocked byWar, Still Confident
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 24A war that began with a machinegun attack on a remote homestead on the night of Dec. 22, 1972, has become a struggle for survival for Rhodesia's 270,000 whites, even though the fighting has been confined mostly to the vast reaches of this country's bushland. But now there is concern that the attacks by black insurgents could spread into the towns and cities.

title: Arabs Said to Draft Plan to Give Egypt $1 Billion This Y ear
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24Four Arab countries headed by Saudi Arabia have agreed to give Egypt more than Si billion this year to help the country in its severe economic strain, according to sources close to the Arab economic community.

title: JERSEY SET TO TREAT ITS DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24Some drunken drivers will have to undergo treatment for alcoholism, and auto insurance rates will be reduced for thousands of drivers because six penalty points will be removed from their records.

title: Reserve Report
description: DAILY AVERAGES

title: MORE FUNDS VOTED FOR ANTICRIME UNIT
description: The Federally financed task force seeking to curb prostitution and pornography in midtown Manhattan received tentative financing for another year yesterday after its director was ordered to discontinue using an investigative technique that he had called critical to the project's success.

title: Publishing: Fiction Gets Lease on Life
description: IN THE CURRENT ISSUE of that valuable literary quarterly, the Hudson Review, the critic Joseph Epstein poses the question, Is Fiction Necessary? After considering some clinkers, he finally finds a few novels with prose and plot and point of view to prove that it still is. In the same issue, John Gardner writes on Moral Fiction, saying that the effect of the best fiction is to humanize, to clear the air, increase our understanding and offer models of just behavior.

title: JOHN BURLINSON M'TIGUE
description: John Burlingson McTigue, aretircd partner of Andrew McTigue & Sons Far Rockaway realestate and insurance concern, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L. I: He lived at 126 North Wood Lane, Woodmere, and was 83 years old.

title: CARTER CALLS C.I.A. STORY ABOUT BRANDT GROUNDLESS
description: BONN. Feb. 24President Carter has expressed regret to former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany about publication of unsubstantiated rumors that Mr. Brandt had taken money from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Loans of $50 Million to Yugoslavia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The World Bank announced today two loans totaling $50 million to improve agricultural production in Yugoslavia. Both loans will be for 15 years with an annual interest rate of 8.5 percent.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: Index

title: Music: Bostonians Mingle Old and New Sonorities
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night wasmore like an exercise in sound than anything else. Melody, harmony and musical structure were present in varying degree, but it was the quality and diversity of sonorities that held the interest.

title: Weekend Gardening: Gems From Junk
description: THE DUMP is open two days a week, and our town is roughly divided into those who visit it Wednesday and those who socialize there over the back of pickup trucks and trailers on Saturday. Having been part of the Wednesday contingent for some time now, I find it very difficult to switch. And because midweek trips to town in the past month seem to have perversely always included a dumphardwarestoregrocery run, the number of pieces of junk to be carted off have grown into rather impressive little hill behind the garage. And while pondering when to begin to tackle the job I was told by certain members of the family that the freeze will not hold forever, and when the thaw comes, something else is going to hit our refuse pileevery stray dog and raccoon within a 20mile radius.

title: Tanker Explodes In 50Mile Slick West of Honolulu
description: HONOLULU (UPI)A crippled Liberian tanker leaking millions of gallons of crude oil along a slick 50 miles long exploded in flames 360 miles west of Honolulu yesterday. All but one of the 39 crewmen aboard were rescued.

title: Judge Bars Dam Work That Might Harm Fish
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 24 (AP)The Tennessee Valley Authority was ordered today to halt any work on the $116 million Tellico Dam project that might harm the habitat of the snail darter, a three inch fish on the Federal endangered species list.

title: Rollback in Auto Insurance Rates In New York State Is ShortLived
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24A shortlived rollback of automobile insurance premiums took place today as Democrats and Republicans in the State Legislature sought to score political points on a volatile subiect.

title: Industrial Incentive Board Gives Some Exemptions on Realty Tax
description: In its first action since it was formed three months ago, the New York City Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board has approved partial realestate tax exemptions for nine private projects to cost $33.7 million.

title: Main Street, Hackensack, to Get Face Lift
description: HACKSENSACK, Feb. 24Main Street, once a major shopping artery before the big Bergen County malls nearby began swallowing up most of the business will get a $650,000 face lift as part of a longrange multimilliondollar revitalization of downtown Hackensack, officials said today.

title: Snow Stories Flow As Buffalo Begins to Thaw
description: BUFFALOThe good word here Is thaw. The snow is, if not gone, at least manageable again, transformed from the smothering white pall of January to random heapssome 10 feet tallthat includes ice and silt peppered with the grime of the Bethlehem and Republic Steel smokestacks. The small boys playing hockey on roller skates and the old men who have heard firsthand of the unbeatable blizzard of 1889 have already consigned the latest natural disaster to legend; their comments begin Remember when  ?

title: Ballet: Eglevsky on the Dance
description: Andre Eglevsky spoke Wednesday evening with quiet authority on the art of partnering and had members of his ballet company demonstrate the fine points to a rapt audience at Town Hall. As one of the great male dancers of our time, who can command the performing stage, he similarly dominated the all too short presentation of The Art of the Pas de Deux with his own wit and wisdom.

title: Raytheon Picked For Navy System
description: The Navy announced the selection of the Raytheon Company to produce new electronic warfare system for surface vessels. The project is said to be worth $180 million over a fouryear period. It added that the selection of Raytheon over Hughes Aircraft was made in advance of a formal production goahead decision.

description: A Galanos for $75? A Mainbocher for $95? It isn't a joke, it's for real. True, the couture clothes at Fabulous Ft'lions, 387 Avenue of the Americas near Waverly Place, date to the 1960's, but then most of them have never been worn and besides, such things tend to be timeless.

title: Pennsylvania Officials Among 9 Killed in Plane Crash
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.. Feb. 24 (AP)A twinengine state plane crashed into home in a Harrisburg suburb and exploded today, killing Pennsylvania's state Republican chairman, the state Transportation Secretary and seven other persons.

title: Pavlova Is Still Casting the Spell
description: Interest in ballet has grown so remarkably in recent years that one of the most crowded spots along Madison Avenue these days is the Norman Crider gallerybookshop, which is paying tribute to Anna Pavlova through this weekend with a special exhibition.

description: DENVER, Feb. 24 (AP)The election of Prof. Arthur Jensen, the controversial psychologist, to the American Association for the Advancement of Science was reaffirmed today despite a member's claim that it was an endorsement of racism.

title: Illinois Power Delays Completion of Unit
description: The Illinois Power Company Sala that completion of the second 950,000kilowatt unit at its nuclear power station near Clinton had been deferred to 1988 from mid1984. Work on the first unit that has been under way since October 1975 will be continued.

title: LOCAL ARMS CUTBACKS OPPOSED BY SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Carter Administration got a taste today of how difficult it is to cut a military budget when the political interests of members of Congress in constituent jobs and business investments come into play.

title: Notes on People
description: Joe Armstrong, publisher of Rolling Stone magazine, announced yesterday the appointment of Jack Ford to the post of assistant to the publisher. A son of the former President, Gerald R. Ford, Mr. Ford, who has a degree in forestry, also will be involved in development of Rolling Stone's new sister publication, Outside, devoted to the outdoors. I have always been interested in communications, Mr. Ford said. I was attracted by the energy and personality of the people here. The 24yearold Mr. Ford, who described Rolling Stone as the most exciting and credible publication today, signed a contract with the magazine the night before the Fords left the White House. The amount of his salary was not disclosed.

title: Mexicans Cross Border In Record Numbers
description: CALEXICO, Calif. Feb. 24 (AP)Illegal aliens are entering the United States from Mexico in record numbers, and border patrol officers say they are losing the battle to control the flow.

title: Pepsico's Profits Climbed 18.6% In 4th Quarter and 27% for Year
description: Pepsico Inc., the nation's second largest soft drink producer, reported yesterday an 18.6 percent rise in fourthquarter profits and 27 percent for all of last year with a marked improvement in profit marains.

title: Harry G. Grover Is Dead at 86; Former Patent Lawyer for RCA

description: American business now plans to spend $139.8 billion on new plants and equip, ment in 1977, McGraw Hill publications said yesterday..The figure, about 2 p0.. centage points higher than last fall's esti mate, represents an increase of 15 per; cent Over capital expenditures of $121.23 billion in 1976.

title: The Rhodesian Massacre
description: The event happened Feb. 6, it is now Feb. 25, and we only know one thing for certain about the murder of seven white Roman Catholic missionaries at St. Paul's Mission in the Rhodesian bush: It is that the mission exists and seven of its staff were murdered. All the rest is hearsay or speculation.

title: Officials Start Training in Use of Alcoholism Law
description: TRENTON. Feb. 24With public intoxication scheduled to be decriminalized on May 9, state officials began today series of meetings designed to acquaint law enforcement and health officials with the provisions of the new law and to develop guidelines on how alcoholics will be handled and referred for treatment.

title: Montauk: On the Beach at Land's End in Winter
description: MONTAUK, that bust ling summer spot of bikinis and tennis shorts, has on its winter clothes. Summer homes and resort areas are boarded up; the beaches are cloaked in white and see you in April signs hang from the restaurants. But in its wintertime mood of solitude and serenity, Montauk is ideal for long walks on the beach, watching seagulls dive for their breakfast against the morning sun, and gazing into the chilly waters waiting for the cod and oollack to bite.

title: Soviet Said to Fear Dissident Issue May Damage Relations With West
description: VIENNA, Feb. 24An Italian Communist Party delegation that visited Moscow recently to discuss issues of political dissent in Eastern Europe found the Soviet leadership concerned about the effect the dissident movement might have on relations between East and West.

title: Brooklyn College Student Shot to Death by Robbers While Driving a Taxi
description: A 26yearold Brooklyn College psychology major who was to have been married next month was shot and killed yesterday during a robbery while driving a taxi in Harlem.

description: Yesterday was doomsday.

title: Larchmont Student in Utah Died Of Exposure, State Examiner Says
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 24 (AP)A University of Utah student whose body was found in mountains east of Salt Lake died of exposure Sunday night or Monday morning, the State Medical Examiner said today.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Women in American Architecture: A Historical and Contemporary Perspective, at the Brooklyn Museum through April 15. Today and Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Admission is free. For information on concurrent events call the Architectural League at 6284500. The 224page hardcover catalogue, published by the Whitney Library of Design, is available at $25 from the Brooklyn Museum shop.

title: Hawks Beat Knicks In Overtime, 101 to 98
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 24Consistency, not a hot streak or two, is what wins professional basketball games, said Coach Red Holzman, after his New York Knicks, lost, 10198, to the Atlanta Hawks in overtime at The Omni before 9.281.

title: About Real Estate
description: Some people were building driveways and calling them plazas and getting an enormous floorarea bonus. They would put in exhaust vents on what was supposed to be a public plaza and get a million dollars worth of additional density. Some people were building the spaces under ground. Even developers agree this isn't right.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: When Ezra Pound wrote his poem Coitus decades ago, the guitar and the piano had not yet been plugged into electric sockets. But the young composer Fred Lerdahl is using these electronic instruments, as well as some conventional strings, in his new vocalchamber piece, Eros, based on the Pound poem. Eros will have its world premiere tonight at 8 with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall. (The program will be repeated Sunday at 5 P.M.) The concert will also include works by Haydn, Dvorak and Mozart. The Chamber Music Society's regular membersthe violinist Jaime Laredo, the violist Walter Trampler, the cellist Leslie Parnas, the flutist Paula Robison and the pianist Richard Goodewill be joined by several guest performers, including Beverly Morgan, mezzosoprano, for the Lerdahl work. Tickets, $7 and $8, available at the box office.

title: Film: History of Newsreels
description: THE NEWSREELS died on American screens in 1967, but they were in poor shape for 10 years or so before that. There was no way they could compete with television news footage, either in speed or convenience. Nor, generally speaking, in quality. Most of the time they were patchy views of a rather scatterbrained reality. Sneezing contests would alternate with politicians cutting ribbons and South Americans rioting.But once in a while there was something unforgettable: the Hindenburg floated loftily into sight and suddenly settled on the ground like burning tinsel; a middle-aged Frenchman wept at Toulon when the fleet was scuttled. The newsreel cameras and the big screen provided an authority to these things that television equipment couldn't manage. Also there was the effect of waiting a day or two to see a disaster you had read of. World events were discrete, individual, weighty. They did not flood us.A diffuse, somewhat unsatisfactory but reasonably interesting retrospective of newsreels in America is provided by "Yesterday's Witness," which opened yesterday at the Film Forum.Starting with the logos of the different companiesthe Warner-Path rooster, the globe circled by the word "Universal," the Paramount cameraman standing in profile and turning his camera to the audienceit goes on to show the newsreel's history and format.Some of the footage is worth remembering. There is the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay by the Japanese in the 1930's. A cameraman was aboard and got the whole thing. There is the execution of a Cuban by firing-squad, again in the 30's; and a lovely scene of Bess Truman trying unsuccessfully to break a champagne bottle on a new airplane.The film does not try to show the best footage, however. It tries for a mix of the devastating and the trivialas any ordinary week's newsreel might have shown. The result is authentic, but sometimes tedious.Intercut with this are interviews with the old, organ-toned commentators, and with some of the principal cameramen. Unused footage from the crash of an airplane into the Empire State Building shows the charred bodies inside the office where the plane struck. After it we are shown a touching interview with Max Markman, who was the photographer. He breaks down recalling the scene and mutters "Cut, cut," as the camera captures his tears.There are several short items on the same program. One is a take-off on the newsreel style. Called "The Ritz Newsiola," it is funny for a few minutes, but turns fairly pointless. There is a tiny film about a rudimentary portable movie projector in a Pakistani market; and one about a mobile movie-showing team in Cuba.

description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24George Meany said today that organized labor would be willing to serve on a labormanagement committee to advise President Carter on economic policy should the President decide to form one.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Tass, the official Soviet press agency, today issued what appeared to he a thinly disguised appeal to President Carter to call off his meeting next week with the exiled Soviet dissident Vladimir K. Bukovsky.

description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 24 (Reuters)President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has shuffled his Cabinet, replacing nine ministers and creating two new deputy prime ministerships for Foreign Minister Nguzal KarlIBond and Political Affairs Minister Engulu Baangampongo, who retain their other portfolios.

description: Two letter bombs addressed to Puerto Rican bank branches in New York City were discovered early yesterday, the police said. Two others were found Wednesday.

Vance said in presenting the Carter Administration's foreignaid program to the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. But, Mr. Vance said, there will be no cuts in aid to South Korea or to other strategically situated allies, no matter what human rights violations may exist in such countries, because security commitments were the overriding consideration. title: Regulations for Planned Superports Roil Oilmen
description: FREEPORT, Tex., Feb. 23Every other day, on average, a 700foot tanker most often old and most often of Liberian registry, negotiates the shallow channel and twisting harbor here to disgorge some 200,000 barrels of thick crude oil at the Phillips Petroleum Pier. The crude oil generally begins the journey in Africa; the ships come only from Curacao in the Caribbean.

title: P. S. A. L. Quintets Head to Stretch With Quarterfinals This Weekend
description: There are eight teams remaining in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs, all heading for quarterfinal games this weekend. Each has a reason it got this far, each has a reason why It will get further. Take McKee, for example. We beat a good team [South Shore] last Saturday and and we didn't have our best day, said Coach Mickey Burns of the Staten Island school, the only unbeaten team of the eight. We were very confident before the South Shore game. Last year we were emotionally exhausted for the playoffs. Nov we're very confident.

These workersalong with 1,000 firemen and stationary engineers who belong to Local 94 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, who are not on strikeare direct employees of school custodians and are not covered by Civil Service.

title: STUDY PREDICTS NEED FOR NUCLEAR ENERGY
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 24New Jersey will need 20 nuclear reactors by the year 2000 to provide for its electrical energy need unless an aggressive conservation program.coupled with development of alternate generation systems is begun immediately.

title: Bond Prices Decline in Reaction To Report of MoneySupply Rise
description: The credit markets, after drifting lower yesterday in the wake of their sharp decline Wednesday, sold off further late in the afternoon in a reaction to the Federal Reserve's report of increases in the nation's money supply. The Treasury's new touryear notes mat were auctioned on Wednesday dipped an eighth of a point, and the Treasury 8's of 1986 the star of the bond market's late1976 surgetraded mare than six points below the early December high. New bond issues sold slowly.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 24The sentencing of Wendy Yoshimura, who was convicted last month on charges of illegally possessing a machine gun and explosives, was postponed today until March 17.

description: DINAN, France  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on the stump in the provinces impresses a foreigner who has observed political leaders campaign on three continents as a Don Quixote in a gray vested suit and dark blue tie, full of genuine idealism but with no helmet to protect the balding head of the Fifth Republic of France.

title: Arabs Said to Draft Plan to Give Egypt $1 Billion This Year
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24Four Arab countries headed by Saudi Arabia have agreed to give Egypt more than Sl billion this year to help the country in its severe economic strain, according to sources close to the Arab economic community.

title: Newark Officials Slash Budget In Effort to Meet State Limits
description: NEWYARK, Feb. 24The Mayor's office and the City Council today struck out S1.8 million in proposed employee salary increases in the Mayor's recommended 1977 operating budget with the understanding that the raises will go right back in after the state approves the budget.

title: On Doomsday Planets Clash, But Th ere Isn't Much Doom
description: Yesterday was doomsuay.

title: DECISION PENDING IN BOMBING INQUIRY
description: Federal District Judge Marvin Frankel yesterday reserved decision on the Government's motion that a grand jury witness be held in contempt for refusing to answer the jury's questions in connection with its investigation of terrorist bombings.

title: Court Denies Effort To Restore Charges Against Blumenthal
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The lengthy legal troubles of Albert H. Blumenthal, the former majority leader of the State Assembly, ended today when the state's highest court refused to allow the special state prosecutor for nursing homes to appeal the dismissal of a 12count perjury and bribery indictment against the Manhattan Democrat.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times on Feb. 16 about Lynn R. Williams, a Canadian labor leader, a photograph of Len Stevens, another labor leader, was inadvertently substituted for one of Mr. Williams because of erroneous caption material provided by United Press International.

title: We Want Our Custodians Back, 7th Graders In Bronx Plead During Day Shortened by Strike
description: A group of seventhgrade girls knocked on the principal's door at Junior High School 136 in the South Bronx yesterday, the second day of a strike by school maintenance workers. They were carrying a poster with a handlettered message: We want our custodians back.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 2,600 gallons of lowlevel radioactive water spilled onto the floor of a building at the Public Service Electric and Gas Company's nuclear power plant in Salem County. There were no injuries.

title: Beneficial Plans to Buy JSC Unit's Receivables
description: The Beneficial Corporation of Wilmington, Del.. has reached an agreement in principle for the purchase of all of the receivables of the finance group of the Interstate Securities Company, a subsidiary of the ISC Financial Corporation of Kansas City, Mo.

description: Dandridge 10 72 27, Meycrs 7 34 17, Nater 6 00 12, Buckner 5 22 12, Winters 13 33 29. BridGeman 5 14 11, Walton 5 23 12, Restani 5 00 10, Garrett 0 12 1, Lloyd 0,00 0. Totals 56 1930 131.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (API  Money rates for Thursdar.

title: Aid Cut to RightsViolating Nations Is Break. With U.S. Pragmatism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24President Carter's decision to reduce foreign aid to three countries is a break with the pragmatism displayed by the United States since World War H. By announcing the sanctions against Argentina, Ethiopia and Uruguay, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance underscored the President's assertion yesterday that his concern about human rights was a global policy, not directed solely at the Soviet Union. The statement took some of the sting out of earlier criticism of Moscow.

title: Drunken Drivers Face Treatment Under Change in Traffic Penalties
description: In Camden County. State Senator Joseph A. Maressa, a Democrat and a former state trooper who sponsored the new measure, is from Berlin.

title: Regents Weigt a 5Week School Closing Next Winter
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The State Board of Regents is considering a revised school calendar that would require all schools to close for five weeks next winter to conserve fuel. Under the proposal, school would begin next Sept. 1 and end June 30. 1978.

title: 2 Leading Ladies fo Share Spotlight
description: Mary Martin and Ethel Merman, who have been to the Broadway musical what Guy Lombardo is to New Year's Eve, held a news conference yesterday morning to make a disclosure: For the first time in their careers, the two singers will costar on a Broadwaystage.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.On Jan. 7, 1776, the greatest fall of snow that had been known in England in the memory of man began. The Gentleman's Magazine reported snow drifts of incredible depth  flocks of sheep buried, carriages of all kinds overturned or detained upon the roads; the mails retarded; postboys and travellers frozen to death in pursuing their usual occupations, the intercourse between town and town interrupted.

title: Zurich Gold Price Up $2 and Dollar Climbs in Europe
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP)Gold prices continued their steady climb today, jumping more than $2 an ounce in Zurich. The dollar also rose on European ex, changes.

title: Radio
description: 11:00 AM. WNCN. Toccata. Palau Slavonic Dance. No. 6. Dvorak Theme Varie from Namounajalo Flute Concerto in F. Vivaldi; Triana from Iberia, Albeniz; 6 Landler, Beethoven.

title: Business Records
description: JO ANN LA MARCH, else lnor, as Joann Hal Katonale, N.Y. liabilities, 51.964; assets none.

title: New York School Board Drops Custodian Accused of Kickbacks
description: The Board of Education, at a special meeting yesterday, dismissed Robert R. Cappetta, until recently the custodian of Far Rockaway High School in Queens.

title: Soviet's 200Mile Limit In Effect March 1
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today announced that a 200mile fishing zone will go into force from March 1 along its Pacific and Arctic coastlines.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DETROIT

title: Both Sides Are Glum in 17th Day Of Philadelphia Newspaper Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24The mood glum on both sides of North Broad Street. The Newspaper Guild's strike against The Inquirer and The Daily News continues into its 17th day, with negotiations at a standstill since Tuesday.

title: SALVADOR NAMES A WINNER OPPOSITION CHARGES FRAUD
description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 24 (AP)The Government's candidate, Carlos Humberto Romero, was declared Presidentelect of El Salvador tonight, and the opposition charged that the results were fraudulent.

title: Heavy Floods Cover Some Roads in Area
description: Heavy flooding was reported by the police last night in parts of the New York metropolitan area, and in the city at least 20 cars were abandoned on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 23d and 60th Streets because of flooding.

title: Mr. Rabin's Tentative Victory
description: All Israelis deserve to be congratulated for their tolerance of democracy in the midst of siege and the hardships imposed by it. Prime Minister Rabin, who was so narrowly selected yesterday to continue to lead the Labor Party, deserves special understanding for enduring a severe challenge from his Defense Minister, Shimon Peres, and for having to lead a nation through the delicate preliminaries of negotiation while still facing an uphill battle for reelection next May.

title: A's Trade Ron Fairly; Reacquire Minor Leaguer
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)The Oakland A's today traded Ron Fairly, a 39yearold first basemen, to the Toronto Blue Jays for $30,000 and Mike Weathers, a 27yearold second baseman.

title: Various Incentives Drive Trackmen in A.A.U.Meet
description: It will be just another onemile race for Filbert Bayi at Madison Square Garden tonight, but it could be the start of something big on the international scene for Kevin Price.

title: A Clash of Values
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Feb. 24Given its present makeup and trend, the Supreme Court may well decide that affirmative action to increase the enrollment of disadvantaged minority groups in professional schools actually is unconstitutional reverse discrimination.

title: John A. Coleman, Philanthropist, Big Board Chairman, Dies at 75
description: John A. Coleman, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange from 1943 to 1947 and a leading fund raiser for the Roman Catholic Church, died of a heart failure Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WRILE SHORT on major artistic achievements, television is almost recklessly lavish with small sociological insights. Consider, for this weekend's prime example, the image of the lesbian. Until fairly recently, the exploitation of that image was almost entirely negative. One of the more notorious scenarios had a group or murderous lesbians running a particularly nasty ripoff home for the aged.

title: S.E.C. IS TIGHTENING RULE ON DISCLOSING BIG STOCKHOLDERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Securities and Exchange Commission, responding partly to fears of some members of Congress that foreign investors may secretly acquire large stakes in American compl, nies, adopted rules today to expand the amount of information publicly available about corporate ownership. Many large, investors not now clearly subject to such disclosure will be forced to tell the corn, mission of their holdings whenever they exceed 5 percent of a company's stock.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: All seats for the Sergiu Luca recital are $6 and can be obtained at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium box office of the Metropolitan Museum. The program begins at 8 P.M.

title: CHEMICAL BANK CITED FOR FAILURE TO LIST BIG CASH EXCHANGES
description: The Chemical Bank was indicted yesterday on a charge of having failed to report 500 cash transactions, amounting to $8.5 million, as required by the Federal Bank Security Act.

title: New Energy Agency Would Be Granted Broad Power Base
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Carter Administration's plan to create a cabinetlevel Department of Energy would give the agency broad powers over the leasing of public lands and over energy production, powers now held by the Interior Department.

title: St. Peter's, Manhattan Are Victors
description: St. Peter's College, which had spent much of its season losing close basketball games, turned it around last night at Madison Square Garden by overcoming a 14point deficit and defeating Seton Hall, 9089.

title: Andy Young At the U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24The young men closest to President Carter  Hamilton Jordan, Andrew Young, Jack Watson, Stuart Eizenstathave several things in common They are all out of Georgia, all highly intelligent and articulate, all personally confident and attractive, and all exercising Federal and world power, where they have little or no experience.

title: BELL MAY INTERVIEW DR. KING'S MURDERER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he was still troubled by some of the unanswered questions surrounding the assassination of the Rev. Dr, Martin Luther King Jr nearly a decade ago, and that he might try to answer them by intersiews with James Earl Ray, Dr. King's convicted murderer.

title: White Rhodesia, Rocked by War, Still Confident
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 24A war that began with a machinegun attack on a remote homestead on the night of Dec. 22, 1972, has become a struggle for survival for Rhodesia's 270,000 whites, even though the fighting has been confined mostly to the vast reaches of this country's bushland. But now there is concern that the attacks by black insurgents could spread into the towns and cities.

title: Goldin Says City Has $500 Million In Unpaid Parking Tickets on File
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that there was $500 million in unpaid parking tickets in the inventory of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, and he urged a program to speed collections.

description: ATLANTIC CROWN (ACLI. Le Havre March 5, RotterMm 6 end Southampton 7; sails from Pt. Elizabeth, N.J. HELLENIC LAUREL (Hellenlct. Dubal March 30, Maname Aprli 3, Damman 5 and Karachi (6; sails from 57th St., Brooklyn.

title: Market Place
description: Bank trust departments, mammoth managers of other people's money, made Dow Chemical and the American Telephone and Telegraph company their favorite additions to stock portfolios in the final quarter of 1976. This was a period when many issues declined in price and then staged a sharp yearend rally.

title: Art: The Potpourri At Fourcade's
description: NATURE abhors a vacuum, we were told in school. But nature's likes and dislikes don't affect what we see in the galleries. If someone leaves a vacuum around it is likely to stay there until someone else comes alone and fill it uo.

title: Rosselli Called a Victim of Mafia Because of His Senate Testimony
description: Shortly after John Rosselli testified before a Senate committee that he had participated in Central Intelligence Agency plots to kill Fidel Castro, a Washington friend asked him if he wasn't afraid for his life. The 70yearold Mafia figure appeared unconcerned: Who'd want to kill an old man like me? he asked.

title: PARENT'S/CHILDREN
description: The situation has become intolerable. Your child simply cannot go on that way any longerwhatever that way may be. You suspect that you need help. And you know the city must be thick with therapists, but you don't know how to begin.

title: The Seldom Scene Strum Country Style
description: Many entertainers have been forced to take fulltime jobs to keep themselves supplied with guitar picks, hair spray, throat lozenges, food and lodgings and other niceties that their performing careers could not afford them. It is a little different with the Seldom Scene, the awardwinning bluegrass group that plays in Greenwich Village tomorrow night.

title: People in Sports
description: After deliberating for 1 hour 20 minutes, a jury in Amarillo, Tex., yesterday found Ernie Holmes innocent of charges of possession of cocaine. The star defensive tackle of the Pittsburgh Steelers had been charged with purchasing a container of the drug for $20 in a hotel restroom on Jan. 31, 1976.

title: 6Year Ban on Mafia, Cosa Nostra Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A justice Department spokesman said today that sixyear ban on the use of the terms Mafia and Costra Nostra apparently is ended, after Attorney General Griffin B. Bell made several references to the Mafia at a meeting with reporters.

title: Hunt, in From the Cold, Joining The Watergate Lecture Troupe
description: BROOKLINE. Mass., Feb. 24E. Howard Hunt Jr. was wearing a buttondown shirt, a striped tie and a doublebreasted, pinstriped suit. His pipe was close at hand, but he had stopped wearing his dark glasses. He was ready to begin a new career on the lecture circuit.

title: Music: A Near Miss and a Near Hit in City Opera's Barbiere
description: FOR a few sickening moments It looked as if heavy drama (The Fall of the House of Bartolo) were going to replace light comedy (II Barbiere di Siviglia) at the opening performance of the New York City Opera's spring season on Wednesday night. A huge section of the revolving set toppled over toward the orchestra pit as the final scene was about to start in Rossini's comedy, which starred Beverly Sills as Rosina.

title: Derelict Called Illinois Heiress
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. (UPI)  A ragsclad woman known to her neighbors as Garbage Mary has turned out to be a wealthy heiress from a Galesburg, III., family, police confirmed yesterday.

title: For Children
description: IMAGINATION, a poetry participation workshop with Joanna Featmerstone, actress, will be presented for children 6 and older at 3 P.M. on Saturday in the Central Children's Room of the New York Public Llorary's Donnell Center 20 West 53d Street. Miss Featherstone will direct the program or rhymes, poems, street chants and games be black authors. Free. 7906359.

title: Threat of a Lack Of Oils for Heat Appears to Pass
description: The threat of a heating oil shortage that has hung over the nation during the recent weeks of intense cold appears to have passed as stocks of middle distillate rose last week for the first time since November.

title: World News Briefs
description: World News Briefs

title: Army Engineers Oppose Completing Florida Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)  The Army Corps of Engineers recommended today that the Government scrap plans to complete the Cross Florida Barge Canal, a controversial waterway between the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico which has already cost more than $60 million.

title: Aqueduct Plans Switch To 48Hour Entry Rule
description: Starting next month, New York horseplayers will have only themselves to blame if they can't get their handicapping homework done on time.

title: Gary Player Leads Strange By Shot on 68
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP)Gary Player tamed gusty breezes that swept the Inverrary Golf and Country Club course today for a fourunderpar 68 and took the firstround ead in the $250,000 Jackie GleasonInverrary Classic.

title: CONSERVATIVE IS VICTOR IN BYELECTION IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Feb. 24The Conservative Party maintained its traditional hold on the constituency of the City of London and Westminster South in a byelection today.

title: Product Pluggers Find Gold in Silver Screen
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 24In a new movie called The Late Show, actors and actresses spend considerable time drinking PepsiCola, and signs and truck advertising the No. 2 cola appear on the screen regularly.
