title: Tips on Tickets
description: New York Philomusica will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Pratt Institute, Memorial Hall, Willoughby Street at Hall Street in Brooklyn. Tickets are $3. Information: 6363422. Also at 3 P.M. on Sunday at the New York Shakespeare Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street in Manhattan. Tickets are $6. Information: 6776350.

title: Gen. Hershey's Condition Worse
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)The Condition of Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, 83 years old, worsened today, and doctors said he would require immediate surgery to remove a blood clot from the brain. General Hershey, who organized the milltary induction of more than 10 million men after Pearl Harbor, was admitted to Walter Reed Naval Hospital Sunday for treatment of a cerebral hemorrhage.

title: New York on $5 A Datefor The Fun of It
description: OH YES, we know money can't buy happiness, but on Friday or Saturday night in New York, it sure can help. Send most any couple out on the town with enough cashbuy them tickets for the Met, or an evening of dancing at the Rainbow Room, or dinner at Luteceand unless he rips her Halston, unless she throws the tarte a 1'orange in his face, they are apt have a fairly good time.

title: A New Portrait on America's Literary Map
description: Standing near a bend in the Mississippi River and a large patch of black alluvial soil, so rich a man will grow if he stands in it long enough, is the town of Eunola, where Beverly Lowry has set her first novel. Take a sociologist's crosscut plug of Eunola, and you'd find a topmost layer of doctors, lawyers cotton brokers. Methodists. Episcopalians, gardenclub women and so cmthe visible Funola, the people who thought they were the town and that when they said everybody in town it would always mean what had in the past  Down below, at the gravel level, were the rest, working folks, ethnics, rednecks and, at the very bottom, the blacks.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE CLEARS CHRISTOPHER'S NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has approved the nomination of Warren M. Christopher as Deputy Secretary of State after inquiring briefly into his possible knowledgewhich the nominee deniedof the Army surveillance of civilians in the late 1960's. Mr. Christopher's nomination, approved by voice vote, now goes %to the full Senate.

title: Van Dyk Agrees to Sell Most of Its Assets
description: The Van Dyk Research Corporation of Whippany, N.J., operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, has entered a definitive agreement to sell substantially all of its assets for $14 million cash to the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. Excepted from the assets are Van Dyk's rights in pending litigation against the Xerox Corporation and the Apeco Corporation.

title: Portugal Adopts Austerity Measures; Escudo Cut by 15%
description: LISBON, Feb. 25The Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares tonight announced a package of austerity measures, including a 15 percent devaluation of the escudo, to improve Portugal's ailing economy.

title: Personal Investing
description: In the last week or so, sales of the mutual fund industry's newest product the taxexempt municipal bond funds have apparently passed the $1 billion mark. Page 29.

title: L.I. Woman Wins State Lottery
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25 (UPI)A 57yearold Long Island woman who quit her job about a month ago became the state's newest instant millionaire today when she won the grand prize in the New York lottery. I can't believe it, said the woman, Marjorie Jones of Northport, She sobbed several times as her husband, Albert, 64 years old and her sister, Shirley Zeller, helped her to the stage after her name was chosen from among 74 finalists for the first prize of a $1,000 a week for life with a guaranteed minimum of $1 million.

title: OFFICER ACQUITTED IN DEATH OF A BLACK
description: A white police officer who had been accused of killing a 22yearold black student on April 9, 1973, and leaving his own toy pistol beside the body to bolster a claim of selfdefense has been acquitted of a murder charge.

title: Trade Union Chief Is Shot to Death In Addis Ababa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Gunmen burst into the offices of Ethiopia's trade union federation today and shot to death the organization's chief officer, a union statement said.

title: Deaths
description: BAILOWITZMeyer Of Spring Vallc N.Y. Formerly or Brooklyn. beloved father of staniey Bauownn loving grandtatner of Andrea and Jordan. Services 10:30 A.M. Sunuay at Heilman Memorial Chapels, Inc., 164 W. Central Ave. (Route 5.) Spring Valley, N.Y. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, N.Y.

title: Grace to Acquire Aceto
description: W. R. Grace & Company announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire the assets and assume the liabilities of the Aceto Chemical Company in exchange for 750,000 shares of Grace common. Grace common shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $28.25 giving the transaction a value of about $22 million.

title: Briton's Pursuit Of Justice Frees Theft Defendant
description: A London investment counselor who was eager to see justice done won applause in Manhattan Criminal Court last night after he successfully pleaded for the dismissal of larceny charges against an unemployed man whose arrest he had witnessed Thursday night.

title: Issue of Rights Said to Split Yugoslav Leaders
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 25A report has come to light that Yugoslavia's highest Communist leaders are somewhat at odds on ways to handle appeals for greater respect of human rights in this country. But, according to an informant, the hard liners in the party leadership are understood to be supported by President Tito himself, and therefore the current repressive atmosphere is likely to continue.

title: Cauthen Survives a Mishap as Apprentice Jockey Rides Five Winners at Aqueduct for the Fourth Time
description: Even for Steve Cauthen, horse racing can be an uncertain sport of ups and downs.

title: INSURANCE FRAUD RING REPORTED IN 7 STATES
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25A looseknit ring of Arab foreign students whom California authorities have accused of massive insurance fraud are operating extensively in New York and at least five other states besides California, insurance investigators said today.

title: A FORMER I, R, S. AIDE CONVICTED OF TAKING GULF OIL'S TRIP GIFTS
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25Cyril J. Niederberger, a former supervisor at the Internal Revenue Service, has been convicted of taking trips paid for by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON  A chemist on a Florida college faculty believes that the synthetic benzene and acetylene produced by a process he invented can help curb the energy crunch and lessen petroleum imports. Dr. Murry A. Tamers, associate professor of physical chemistry at Nova University's Life Science Center in Fort Lauderdale, was granted Patent 4,009,219 for the method this week.

title: Warnke Controversy Reflects Wider Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The controversy over President Carter's nomination of Paul C. Warnke as arms negotiator is symptomatic of a broader division in Washington on how to strike an acceptable bargain with Moscow. Both sides have predicted what one senator calls a hullaballoo when Mr. Warnke's name goes to the Senate floor next week. Although most expect him to be confirmed, some predict a test of strength on the broader issue of arms control.

title: Protection Is Termed Aim of Monitoring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee has authorized the Federal Bureau of Investigation to monitor selectively and watch the contacts of members and staff of the committee. Senate sources said today.

title: Eli Lilly Plans Plant
description: Eli Lilly & Company plans to build a $24 million parenteral products manufacturing facility in Indianapolis. Construction of the 120,000squarefoot plant will begin late this year with completion scheduled in 1979. Parenteral pharmaceuticals are administered by subcutaneous or intravenous injection.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Islanders 2, Cleveland 1. Boston 5, Colorado 2. Atlanta 6, Minnesota 2. Washington 4, Toronto 2.

title: Cabinet Aides Disclose Holdings; No Net Worth Figures Included
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The White House released the financial disclosure statements of 15 Cabinetlevel officials today, identifying their financial holdings and corporate ties, but not listing specific individual net worth.

title: Alleged Gambling Club Raided Twice in Same Day
description: An alleged gambling casino in the Bronx was raided and closed twice by the police yesterdayshortly after midnight and again about 10:30 P.M., after its proprietors had reopened with reserve dealers and makeshift gaming tables to replace employees and paraphernalia seized earlier.

title: Strauss to Be Named As Trade Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)President Carter intends to appoint Robert S. Strauss, former Democratic national chairman, as his cheif international trade negotiator, White House sources said today.

title: PRESIDENT SENDING A MISSION TO HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Carter will send a highlevel commission to Vietnam in midMarch to discuss the possibility of obtaining a full report on the more than 1,900 Americans still unaccounted for there, the State Department announced today.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.25 (AP)The primary task for a growing number of stns dents and teachers is selfpreservation rather than education, a Senate subcommittee report on school violence said today.

title: Benzene Process Patented
description: A Florida chemist has patented a process to synthesize benzene and acetylene. Page 28.

title: 3 in the Transkei Opposition Freed After 7 Months in Jail
description: UMTATA, Transkei, Feb. 25 (Reuters)The leader of the Transkei opposition Democratic Party, Hector Ncokazi, and two party officials were freed from detention today after being held without charge since last July.

title: Chuck Davis Changes Style In Afro Dance
description: Over the years, Chuck Davis has slowly changed the emphasis in his program of Africanbased dances, from that of a string of set pieces into a ceremonial of daytoday life. The moments of sheer physical display are still there, but have been subsumed more or less into community celebration. Mr. Davis's dance company of seven, which will be appearing at the Lepercq Space in the Brooklyn Academy of Music through tomorrow afternoon, has the verve of a much larger group as well as the services of a splendid corps of musicians.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE WEIGHS PENN CENTRAL TAX PLAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (UPI)A Federal judge was asked today to approve a Penn Central Transportation Company proposal to pay $170 million to settle an estimated $335 million in back taxes owed to New Jersey and other states and cities.

title: World News Briefs
description: QUEBEC, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Quebec's Justice Minister. MarcAndre Bedard, announced today that there would be no further public Inquiry into the fatal road accident on Feb. 6 that involved the provlince's Premier, Rend Levesque.

title: Pittsburgh Nears End of Era as Flaherty Prepares to Move
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25An era and its style are about to end here.

title: La Mama's Alma Banks on Hallucinations
description: It Is hallucinations that are the most real thing in Ozzie Rodriguez's Alma, the Ghost of Spring Street, an imaginary story about a true murder.

title: Houston Oil Profit Shows Sharp Gains
description: The Houston Oil and Minerals Corporation, engaged in oil and gas activities with a small intrastate gathering pipeline, showed strong increases in revenues and earnings in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31.

title: TWO HOSTAGES FREED AFTER 13HOUR SIEGE
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 25A 30yearold unemployed laborer allegedly shot a friend to death here early today and then held a pregnant, 19yearold neighbor and her infant son hostage in a southside apartment for nearly 13 hours before surrendering to the police.

title: Islanders Win, Add Barons To Their List of 21 Victims
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 25Overcoming a team that found out only few days ago it would be paid regularly till the end of the season wasn't easy, but the Islanders accomplished that feat tonight. In rallying on goals by Denis Potvin and Andre St. Laurent, the Islanders beat the inspired Cleveland Barons, 21, and disappointed most of the fifth largest crowd of the season, 6,449 fans, at the Coliseum.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices or best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capitol shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount), or premium) between the net asset valuo and the asked.

title: Productivity's Rise Only 0.5% in Quarter
description: The growth of American workers productivity slowed sharply as 1976 went along, especially in the fourth quarter, although for the year as a whole it was substantially higher than in 1975.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified a business interest purchased by Marsh & McLennan Companies. The interest was in the HudigLangveldt Group.

title: Dow Stock Average Up 0.83 Point In Slowest Trading Since Nov. 30
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: Deficit Thinking
description: President Carter, as expected, is planning to spend about $60 billion more next year than he collects in taxes. Critics took the announcement of the budget deficit as an occasion to predict the demise of the Republic, though the passion of previous denunciations seems to be missing. Another deficitthe 18th in the last 20 yearsis hardly anything to get excited about.

title: EAST BERLIN RAISING FEE FOR AUTO TRIP FROM WEST
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 25The East German Government, faced with economic troubles and widespread disaffection, imposed additional restrictive measures on travel today in the form of a toll on eac,:a auto trip a Westerner takes to East Berlin.

title: O'Brien Vindicated By Suffolk Inquiry
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Feb. 25Special State Prosecutor Alfred J. Scotti, in a report to Governor Carey, today exonerated District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien of Suffolk County of allegations that he had corruptly covered up an investigation of misdeeds by public officials in the county.

title: Maravich: 68 in Rout Of the Knicks
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25Fouls stopped Pete Maravich before the Knick's could tonight and the Jazz guard scored 68 points as New Orleans routed the New Yorkers, 124107. Maravich's total was the most ever scored by a backcourtrnan in the. Na. tional Basketball Association and his pro career high. Only Wilt Chamberlain and Elgin Baylor scored more points in N.B.A. games.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Results
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: PRESIDENT SENDING A MISSION TO HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Carter will send a highlevel commission to Vietnam in midMarch to discuss the possibility of obtaining a full report on the more than 1,900 Americans still unaccounted for there, the State Department announced today.

title: UNIFORMED OFFICERS GRANTED FREE RIDES
description: In a new step to deter crime on subways and buses, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday offered free rides to New York City auxiliary policemen, correction officers and court officers provided they were in uniform.

title: An Authentic Hero at V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Eight years ago, Captain Joseph Maxwell Cleland of the First Air Cavalry Division jumped off a helicopter in Vietnam and saw a live grenade lying on the around near him. He went for it, but before he could reacn it, Man the grenade exploded and blew off both his legs and In the his right arm. For the next News 18 months, Captain Cleland was in army hospitals recovering. Since then, in one way or another, he has been trying to help solve the problems of other veterans.

title: Meany, Still Very Active at 82, Gives No Indication of Retiring
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 George Meany, old man labor, just keeps rolling along.

title: Letters: On Commuter Taxes
description: To the Editor: Why is it that when financial wizards don't have the intelligence or courage to face the fiscal problems of the city, they always slap an additional tax on the people who hold no voting power?

title: Coffee and Cocoa Futures Gain; Prices for Farm Products Drop
description: Coffee, cocoa and gold futures prices continued to rise yesterday while those of farm products, such as soybeans, wheat and corn fell.

title: Cocoa Producers Start Talks To Decide a Joint Price Rise
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 25 (UPI) Cocoa producers started a twoday meeting today to decide on a common increase of cocoa prices before they meet with consuming countries to revise 1975 price aereement.

title: Hollander Staged By Robert Darling Is Attractive Work
description: Robert E. Darling's production of Wagner's Der Fliegende Hollander at the New York City. Opera was not too kindly greeted at its premiere last fall. Subjective considerations aside, there are firm objective reasons why its return Thursday night was a far more gratifying success.

title: COMPROMISE OFFERED IN INQUIRY DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25House Majority Leader Jim Wright offered proposal today to break the deadlock between Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Assassinations Committee, and Richard Sprague, the staff director whom Mr. Gonzalez has dismissed, but who has the support of the rest of the committee and has refused to quit.

title: Five Die in Cleveland Fire
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (UPI)Two brothers and three sisters died early today when they were trapped in their burning twoandonehalfstory frame house as they slept. They were identified as Curtis Ellis Jr., 17 years old; Sandra, 13; Tammy, 11; Thelma, 9, and Clarence, 8. Another brother, Carl, 14, escaped by jumping through a second story window.

title: PEARL BERGEN
description: Pearl Bergen, codirector of the A.C.A. Galleries, 25 East 73d Street, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long illness. She was 53 years old and lived at 75 Central Park West and East Hollow Road, East Hampton, L.I.

title: Protection Is Termed Aim of Monitoring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee has authorized the Federal Bureau of Investigation to monitor selectively and watch the contacts of members and staff of the committee. Senate sources said today.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST46,000, pace, cl., mile. Prob. Odds

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: (Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.)

title: Carter Discouraged an Article on Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Describing King Hussein of Jordan as our most reliable source of information in the Middle East, President Carter told Congressional leaders he had sought to discourage The Washington Post from disclosing payments to the King by the Central Intelligence Agency, Congressional sources said today.

title: Dolores Gray Belts Out Songs
description: Dolores Gray has, like Ethel Merman, a big, old  fashioned, roomfilling voice that needs no amplification. She can overpower any song, although her voice does not have quite the brassy edge that Miss Merman's projects. In her current stand at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street, however, Miss Gray is more inclined to swarm over her material, sustaining momentum as she picks up dropped lines or reaches for cues from her pianist, Mike Garson, while maintaining a facade of unruffled assurance.

title: Telephone Interview With Amin Is Declined
description: Efforts to reach President Idi Amin of Uganda for an interview by telephone from New York last night and early this morning were unavailing.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The existence of fraud, misuse of funds and nepotism recently charged to the custodian engineers in the public schools (news story Feb. 13) should have come as no surprise to New Yorkers.

title: Volkswagen May Delay Start of U.S. Plant
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J. Feb. 25 (Reuters)  A start of Volkswagen's plant in New Stanton, Pa., maybe delayed because of possible air pollution problems, a spokesman for Volkswagen of America said.

title: Transcript of Amin's Message to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Following is the text of President Idi Amin's letter to President Carter, as broadcast today by the Kampala radio and monitored by the United States Government:

title: CourtOrdered Winds of Change Sweep Willow brook
description: Arlene looked half asleep. But when summoned, she sat down at a miniature xylophone. First she was asked to clap the two rhythm sticksOne and two and threeand she did that in time. Then, Play red. She struck the red musical key, and on following commands played the black and green keys.

title: Rutgers to Play UMass
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 25 (UPI)Rutgers, which won the Eastern Collegiate Basketball League title, will play Massachusetts next week in the opening round of the league's first tournament. Fred Gruninger, Rutgers athletic director and tourney director, said today the teams would meet Wednesday in the Spectrum in Philadelphia. The secondplace finisher, Villanova, will play George Washington. In other pairings Penn State meets Duquesne and West Virginia faces Pittsburgh.

title: Algerians Vote for a Parliament As Part of a New Socialist State
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 25Algerians today elected a parliament for their oneparty, socialist and Islamic state, but the turnout was expected to be below the 90 percent participation in previous pollings.

title: PRIVATE REPORT SAYS GAS PRODUCERS HELD RESERVES OFF MARKET
description: A private report commissioned by leading gas utilities has concluded that gas producers failed to bring to market proven reserves of gas in the Gulf of Mexico that would have been equal to much of this winter's cutbacks to consumers.

title: Exiles Tell Vance They Are Opposed to Any U.S.Cuban Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Seven Cuban exile leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that they were unanimously opposed to any United States negotiations with the Cuban Government of President Fidel Castro. The group, claiming to represent the feelings of substantial numbers of the more than 600,000 Cubans who have come to the United States since Mr. Castro seized power in 1959, had been invited by Mr. Vance to meet with him on the Carter Administration's policy toward Cuba.

title: Maine Central Petition Wins Partial Approval
description: The Maine Central Railroad said that the Interstate Commerce Commission had approved part of its petition for modification of an order requiring segregation of some funds received from boxcar rentals. The original order, announced in January, stems from a 1970I.C.C. regulation that required railroads to assess an additional charge to other railroads for boxcar rentals and then segregate the funds received for future acquisitions of boxcars.

title: O'Brien Vindicated By Suffolk Inquiry
description: HAUPPAUGE, Li., Feb. 25Special State Prosecutor Alfred J. Scotti. in report to Governor Carey, today exoner??? District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien of ??? County of allegations that he ??? corruptly covered up an investigation of misdeeds by public officials in the county.

title: Nets Lose; Barnes Out For Fighting
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb, 25The New York Nets won a fight but lost a game tonight at the Nassau Coliseum as the feisty Detroit Pistons swept by them in a fourthauarter rush. 112106.

title: Summary of Reports on Aides Personal Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)Following is a summary the personal financial information on Cabinet officers released by the White House today:

title: Clifford Says Solution Is Possible To the Cyprus Problem This Year
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 25As Clark M. Clifford ended his factfinding mission through the eastern Mediterranean tonight, he expressed the hope that the Cyprus problem could be settled by the end of this year.

title: $255 Million U.S. Loan Is Sought To Avert Default by New York City
description: With renewed warnings that New York City faces a default in the next two weeks, the state's Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday requested a $255 million emergency loan from the Federal Government to tide the city through early March while it steps up negotiations on its debt problems.

title: Veterinarian in Bergen County Gives Up Office To Limit Her Practice Only to House Calls
description: ORADELL, Feb. 5The recent snow and cold complicated the lives not only of mailmen and crossing guards but also that of Dr. Susan Cropper, a veterinarian whose practice consists evclusively of house calls.

title: Major Fire Sweeps Moscow Hotel, the World's Largest
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 26A major fire raged last night through the 5,250bed Hotel Rossiya, across from the Kremlin, as firemen fought to reach those trapped inside,. There were reports that at least 17 lives had been lost.

title: Dollar Slips in Trading Abroad Except in Italy; Price of Gold Is Easier
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP)The dollar declined in Europe today except in Milan, where it registered a fractional gain against the Italian lira. The price of gold eased from its climb earlier in the week.

title: Latest Strike at Leyland Raises Number of Idle Workers to 30,000
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters)British Leyland Ltd, said the number of its workers who are idle because of labor disputes totaled about 30,000 today.

title: Music: AllContemporary Concert
description: The Composers Guild for Performance opened its season on Thursday night with a concert at the McMillin Theater that presented works by seven contemporary composersArthur Berger, JacquesLouis Monod, George Edwards, Michel Philippot, Ben Weber, Frank Brickle and David Winkler.

title: NORTH JERSEY AREAS HARDHIT BY FLOODING
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25Flooding was reported today in a number of North Jersey communities. Motorists were stranded and scores of families were forced to be evacuated.

title: The Time of the People
description: The chic thing this year is people, writes a cheeseshop operator from First Avenue. I guess it started with Jimmy Carter trying to get the Government interested in the existence of people, which could be wrong, as I am not really a keen analyst of these things.

title: OFFICER ACQUITTED IN DEATH OF A BLACK
description: A white police officer who had been accused of killing a 22yearold black student on April 9, 1973, and leaving his own toy pistol beside the body to bolster a claim of selfdefense has been acquitted of a murder charge.

title: Business Records
description: ROBERT JAMES QUIGLEY, May Lane, Dover Plains, N.Y. Liabilities, $47,802; assets, $2,400.

title: City and Hunter Win, Gaining Tourney Final
description: City College, defending champion in the basketball tournament of the City University of New York, rebounded from an 11point halftime deficit to oust Queens, 68C2, in the tournament semifinals last night at City's Mahoney Gymnasium.

title: Bridge:
description: After more than two months of inactivity, the Grand National Team Championship resumes play today at the Vanderbilt Club, 1362 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Bukovsky Urges Labor to Support Carter on Rights
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25Vladimir K. Bukovsky, the exiled Soviet dissident, urged the American labor movement today to support President Carter's effort to encourage fuller human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: Psychiatric Unit on Wards Island Rebuts Sharp Criticism by Levitt
description: Arthur Levitt the New York State Comptroller, released a report yesterday that was sharply critical of administrative practices and security procedures at Manhattan Psychiatric Center, the state mental hospital complex on Wards Island.

title: Ferment in the Americas
description: WASHINGTONThe twin visits to President Carter within the past two weeks of Canada's Prime Minister Trudeau and Mexico's President Lopez Portillo dramatically emphasized recent ominous developments in both countries that could deeply affect the future of this one.

title: President Becomes A Grandfather Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)PresIdent Carter became a grandfather for the second time when 25yearold Caron Carter, a daughterinlaw, gave birth tonight to a 7pound boy. The family said that the boy would be named James Earl Carter 4th.

title: 2 Massachusetts State Senators Are Convicted in Extortion Case
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Two state senators were found guilty of conspiracy and extortion charges today in what has been described as the biggest political corruption trial in Massachusetts in decade.

title: Busing Fears and Facts
description: Fiery opposition to the bus as an instrument of school desegregation has brought injury to individuals, fear to neighborhoods, poison to community relations. There is another, perhaps even costlier price. Supporters of integration, discouraged by the politics of busing, have been willing to abandon even the theory of busing. Increasinalv it is rationalized away as dated, discredited dogma.

title: Archibald Galloway, 66; Lawyer and a Specialist On Bonds in New York
description: Archibald N. Galloway, a lawyer specializing in municipal bonds and counsel to the law firm of Wilikie Farr & Gallagher, died Wednesday during a visit to New York City. He was 66 years old and lived in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: No Problem in Uganda?
description: Idi Amin says there's no cause for alarm in his order barring some 200 Americans from leaving Uganda and summoning them to meet with him Monday. There is, an Amin spokesman said yesterday, no problem regarding the Americans here. Perhaps Americans would see no problem either, were they as inured as Ugandans must be by now to intimidation, disappearances, mysterious killings or crocodile tears over improbable auto accidents. To us, it looks as President Amin is holding some 200 United States citizens as hostages in his country, even if only for a few days. That is very much a problem. We wonder if Mr. Amin understands how seriously it will be regarded by an American public that last year enthusiastically acclaimed the Israeli military raid on Entebbe.

title: CORRECT/ON
description: A headline in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified a business interest purchased by Marsh & McLennan Companies. The interest was in the HudigLangveldt Group.

title: No Decision on U.N. Investigation
description: GENEVA, Feb. 25The United Nations Human Rights Commission was unable to agree today on how to respond to Britain's call for an investigation of the situation in Ueanda.

title: Harpsichord Music By Shirley Mathews
description: Shirley Mathews, a harpsichordist who made her New York debut in 1964 in Carnegie Recital Hall, returned there Thursday night for a program of works by Handel, Couperin, Rameau, Bach and Jacques Duphly. Now on the faculty of the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, Miss Mathews gave an admirably academic account of the music. It could not be faulted in matters of clarity, articulation, ornamentation and general style.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Pucini's II Trittico 2; Mozari'sLe Nozze di Fisaro, 8.

title: Notes on People
description: Informed sources in West Berlin said yesterday that Rudolf Hess, Hitler's former deputy, tried on Monday to slash his wrists in his cell in Spandau Prison but suffered only minor injuries. Allied spokesmen, under the strict rules that govern the imprisonment of the sole surviving war criminal under fourpower jurisdiction, declined to comment on the incident. It was learned, however, that the 82yearold Mr. Hess was in a state of depression and was seen by a psyhiatrist after the suicide attempt. He was said to be well enough yesterday to see his son, Wolf Rudiger Hess, who was at the prison for a regular monthly visit. Mr. Hess was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1946.

title: Bergland Planning Bid to Canada For Fixing of World Wheat Price
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that he intended to seek a pricefixing arrangement for wheat with Canada that would effectively set a world price on bread grain. He later discussed the idea at a meeting here with Otto Lang, Canadian Minister of Transportation, the top official in Canada's wheat marketing program.

title: Consumers Budgets Askew From High Heating Bills
description: I'm going to have to raise my rents, says Robert Morton, who owns 131 apartment units, largely in old houses, in Rochester. I'm getting gobbled up by heating bills, which he figures cost him an extra $500 to $1,000 for January alone.

title: Cold in Siberia As Low as 72 Below Puts Cold in U.S. in Second Place
description: a land of death and chains. No roads or railroads link it to the outside world; except by air, the only way in or out is by boat along 1,250 miles of the Lena River, then by trainan impossible route during most of the year when the river is frozen.

title: Constitutional Protection for the Unborn
description: CINCINNATIFour years ago, the United States Supreme Court shocked some Americans, and pleased others, by approving abortion in a wide variety of circumstances, with few significant restrictions.

title: Robert McCulloch,Oilman; Purchased London Bridge And Moved It to Arizona
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (UPI)Robert McCulloch, president of the McCulloch Oil Company and the industrialist who brought London Bridge to Lake Havasu City, Ariz., died of an apparent heart attack today at his Bel Air home. He was 65.

title: MRS. GANDHI DENIES DICTATOR CHARGES
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, taking an increasingly defensive tone in her reelection campaign, today strenuously denied opposition charges of dictatorship in India.

title: Folfier Raises Prices on VacuumPacked Coffee
description: The nation's second largest coffee roaster increased wholesale prices on vacuumpacked coffee yesterday by 40 cents to a record $3.68 a pound.

title: AMIN PROHIBITS EXIT BY 200 AMERICANS; BIDS THEM MEET HIM
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 25President Idi Amin of Uganda today ordered all United States citizens in the country to meet with him on Monday morning and said they would be barred from leaving the country before then.

title: Carter. Voices Concern of U.S. At Uganda Move

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission today approved the proposed sale by the Kennecott Copper Corporation and its subsidiary, the Peabody Coal Company, of two coal mines to the Utah Power and Light Company.

title: RETARDED CHILDREN SENT OUT OF STATE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25More than 600 emotionally disturbed children and 50p severely retarded children and adults from New Jersey are being boarded in states as far away as Idaho because NeW Jersey does not have facilities for them; a legislative investigating committee was told today.

title: OFFICER ACQUITTED IN DEATH OF A BLACK
description: A white police officer who had been accused of killing a 22yearold black student on April 9, 1973, and leaving his own toy pistol beside the body to bolster a claim of selfdefense has been acquitted of a murder charge.

description: DENVER, Feb. 25 British scientists have reported that for the first time they have determined the complete genetic structure of a living organism and havediscovered that a gene, controlling agent for all inherited characteristics, is more complicated than was thought.

title: Tennstedt Leads Philharmonic
description: There has been great word of mouth about Klaus Tennstedt, the German conductor who led Thursday evening's Philharmonic concert. He comes from East Germany, left in 1971, and is currently making his first round of American guestconducting engagements. For his New York Philharmonic debut he selectea a twopiece programthe Beethoven Violin Concerto, with Miriam Fried as soloist, and Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony.

title: LEONARD LEDDINGTON, 59, FORMER TODAY EDITOR
description: Leonard L. Leddington, a former news editor for the NBC Today show, died Thursday at the Veterans Hospital West Haven, Conn. He was 59 years old.

title: Albany Urges Nesting Boxes to Aid Bluebirds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25New York State is suddenly facing a major housing crisisfor bluebirds.

title: Glanville Picked by Falcons
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25 UPI A former Detroit Lions assistant coach, Jerry Glanville, was added to the Atlanta Falcons staff today as defensive secondary coach. He is the fifth assistant named by Leeman Bennett, who became head coach three weeks ago.

title: CARTER GIVES WALDHEIM A WELCOMING CEREMONY
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 25 (AP)President Carter welcomed Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations to the White House today and predicted that in 1977 he and Mr. Waldheim will be growing much closer together.

title: Hartford Job Outlook Gains With New Companies; American Airlines Opens a Center for East Coast
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 25An East Coast reservations center that will bring 800 new jobs to this employmentstarved city was opened today by American Airlines.

title: Yanks and Mets Open Camps as Spring Arrives for Baseball
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25On a grass field untouched by football cleats or baseball free agents, the New York Mets opened their 16th spring training today as half dozen more camps came alive across the Sun Belt.

title: Jersey Pharmacist Convicted
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25 (AP)An East Orange pharmacist has been convicted for the illegal distribution of amphetamines. Samuel Dearling, 65 years old, the owner of Frost Drugs at City Hall Plaza in East Orange, was convicted on two counts of illegal distribution, but was cleared of a charge of conspiracy in the case.

title: A High School Editor Gains Right to Print Birth Control Article
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 25 (AP)A high school newspaper editor has won a Federal court battle to publish an arti cle on birth control over the objections of her urincinal and school board.

title: Milt Kamen, Satirist, Dead at 55; Did Spontaneous Film Reviews
description: Milt Kamen, the comedian and satirist, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 55 years old.

title: Adams Rules Out Major Projects For Mass Transit Before 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams announced today that enough money was available forthe nation's mass transit funding program to last through 1979 and recommended against a new fiveyear program at this time.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR APARTMENT GARDENERS Cissus rhombifolia thrives in the low intensity light of a northern exposure artificial lighting helps. Allamanda nerifolia needs a southern exposure and a cool room. Brassiai actinophylla does well with east or west views. And for Gymnocalycium mihanovichii, a dry sunny room and cool night time temperatures are ideal.

title: JACQUES GARVIN IS DEAD FOUNDED CLARIDGE FOOD
description: Jacques Garvin, who retired in 1.970 as president and founder of the Claridge Food Company, died Wednesday in Metropolitan Hospital. He lived at 2 Pact 86th Street and was 78 years old.

title: Rail TonMiles Climb 6.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.9 billion tonmiles, 6.4 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloading in the same period totaled 447,463 cars, 2.0 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 13 percent above last year.

title: Delay in Fusion Tests Predicted
description: DENVER, Feb. 25The Carter Administration's plan to reduce fusion research funding by $80 million is expected to delay achievement of such energy in variety of ways, leaders in the field said here today.

title: News Summary
description: All United States citizens in Uganda whose number is estimated at 200mainly missionaries, some businessmen and the crews of President Idi Amin's several airplanes  were ordered by President Amin to meet with him in Kampala on Monday. The Americans will not be permitted to leave the country before then. President Amin also sent a long message to President Carter suggesting that the United states deal with its own humanrights problems before commenting on Uganda's affairs. He warned that Uganda forces would crush any attempt by the United States to rescue its citizens, accused the Central Intelligence Agency of plotting against him and expressed the hope that he could visit the United States soon. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Ford Lifts Sales Forecast
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25The Ford Motor Company's president, Lee A. Iacocca, said today that, because of signs that the economy is surging ahead, we have revised our 1977 calendar year industry sales forecast from 10.6 million cars to 10.9 million.

description: 67 AM, WNCN. Carrotin; Soleares, Rafaga. Turina; Symphony No. 10, J.C.F. Bach; Roumanian Rhapsody No. 1, Enesco; Suite of Trumpet Tunes, Purcell.

title: Soviet Astronauts Return to Earth After 18Day Orbit
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25Two Soviet astro1 nauts returned safely to Earth today in their Soyuz 24 space capsule after 18 days in orbit.

title: Dance: Yamini Krishnamurti in New York Debut
description: Yamini Krishnamurti is a name familiar to those with an interest in India's classical dance. But until her current tour, sponsored by the Asia Society's Performing Arts Program, the dancer had never performed in the United States.

title: G.M. to Offer Diesel Oldsmobiles Next Fall
description: DETROIT, Feb. 25The General Motors Corporation plans to offer the diesel engine as an option in its fullsize Oldsmobile 88's and 98's next fall, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of G.M., said today.

title: Flu Reported in New Areas
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25 (UPI)Seven more states and the District of Columbia have reported isolated cases of influenzaB virus, the Center for Disease Control reported today. The virus showed up in school children in Kentucky, Kansas, the District of Columbia, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri and Wisconsin, the disease center said.

title: To Defend, the Rights of the Chileans
description: Several weeks ago, President Augusto Pinochet of Chile, responding both to public criticism from then Presidentelect Carter and to a then pending United Nations resolution regarding human rights violations in Chile, released some 300 people detained without trial under the military junta's threeyearold state of siege. In its announcement of the release, the junta claimed that there were virtually no more political prisoners in Chile, and most newspapers carried that statement to the public as though it were true.

title: Hot Time on Ice, Newman's 'Slap Shot'
description: Charlestown is a middle-sized New England mill town where things are going from bad to worse. The mill is laying off 10,000 workers and the Charlestown Chiefs, the city's professional hockey team, once a source of pride, has become a third-rate club in a league of the second rank. Reggie Dunlop (Paul Newman), the team's player-coach, is getting old and feeling it. He knows it's his last season. He's about to be junked.Things are so bad that at one point we overhear the Chief's manager, Joe McGrath (Strother Martin), trying to unload some of the team's equipment, including its massage table. The Chiefs are nice guys. Though they don't win many games, they play clean and only talk dirty.George Roy Hill's unruly, funny new comedy, "Slap Shot," which opened at three theaters yesterday, dramatizes the age-old contest between good and evil as clean vs. dirty, and it's dirty that wins, hands (and pants) down."Slap Shot," which follows the fortunes of the Chiefs through their last, dizzy season, was written by Nancy Dowd, a Smith College graduate with a master's degree from the University of California School of Cinema Arts. She's a young woman who appears to know more about the content and rhythm of locker-room talk than most men.She knows the favorite word that can be used as a noun, verb or adjective, sometimes all in one sentence. She also knows the favorite sexual image that haunts the language of these hockey players as if all living had been reduced either to committing a sexual act or to preventing one, which is more or less a reflection of what the guys are doing out there on the ice with their hockey sticks and the puck. If you don't invade the enemy territory, the enemy will invade yours.I don't know enough about professional hockey to judge how accurate a picture "Slap Shot" is, but it does seem a stretch of the imagination to ask us to believe in this day and age, that neither the Chiefs' manager nor coach would have known that a dirty, violent game, accompanied by a lot of publicity hoopla, would bring in the crowds. Which is pretty much what happens to the Chiefs, first by accident, then on purpose, as the team goes onward and upward to the top of the league.The film's point of view also appears to be ambiguous, for though it seems to want to be on the side of the clean, old-fashioned game, played by the rules, "Slap Shot" itself, like the Chiefs, largely triumphs by exploitingsometimes uproariouslythe brutality of the game and the protective vulgarity of the players.Mr. Hill, a director of real sensibility, is certainly aware that people as thick-headed and slow-witted as are most of these characters aren't very interesting when seen in close-up for very long. Seen as a collective spectacle in a long-shot, though, they make a sometimes bitterly comic comment on one aspect of the industry that is professional American sports.The performanceswhich have a lot to do with the right casting, particularly in the smaller rolesare impeccable. Paul Newman maintains an easy balance between star and character-actor. The leading-man authority is there, but it's given comic perspective by the intensity of the character and by its tackiness, evident even in the clothes he wears.Michael Ontkean, a young actor I've not been aware of before, is equally good as the film's one unequivocal good guy, a Princeton graduate turned pro, which may be one of the nicest things Hollywood has said about the Ivy League in years. Jennifer Warren, who was so good in Arthur Penn's "Night Moves," plays Mr. Newman's estranged wife, a self-reliant beautician, and Lindsay Crouse is seen as Mr. Ontkean's heavy-drinking wife, a role that doesn't make too much sense as written.There isn't space to credit all of the vivid supporting performers but, in addition to Strother Martin, you're likely to remember Jerry Houser as a goalie who thinks of himself as a mystic, and Andrew Duncan as a hilariously phony-talking radio announcer."Slap Shot," which has been R-rated as much for its language as for the violence on the rink, has a kind of vitality to it that overwhelms most of the questions relating to consistency of character and point of view. Much in the manner of "Network," you know that it's an original and that it's alive, whether you like it or not.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Describing King Hussein of Jordan as our most reliable source ot information in the Middle East, President Carter told Congressional leaders he had sought to discourage The Washington Post from disclosing payments to the King by the Central Intelligence Agency, Congressional sources said today.

Harold Connolly won the Olympic gold medal for the hammer throw in 1956, the only American champion in that event in the last half century. Williams, Dean of the Graduate School of Management at the University of California at Los Angeles, and Peter J. Solomon, a managing partner of Lehman brothers.

title: Carter Voices Concern of U.S. At Uganda Move
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Carter, suddenly involved in his first international crisis, expressed concern today about the fate of the 200 or more Americans in Uganda who were ordered to meet with President idi Amin on Monday. Mr. Carter also set in motion the machinery to deal with any deterioration in the situation.

title: Schools Face Health Problems in Strike by Cleaners
description: Mounting accumulations of garbage and, in some schools, the stench from clogged and dirty lavatories plagued the New York City school system yesterday as it limped through the third day of curtailed classes and emergency operations because of a strike by 2,500 cleaners and handymen.

title: Books of The Times
description: In The Medieval Machine, Jean Gimpel, the FrancoBritish lecturer who is well known in the United States and Europe as a medievalist and social historian, advances three interesting and provocative complementary arguments. The first and crucial proposition is that the Middle Ages, a period Professor Gimpel defines as ranging from the 10th to the 14th centuries, was one of the great inventive eras of mankind.

title: Niagara Mohawk Maps Expansion
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation of Syracuse announced that had developed a comprehensive hydroelectric expansion program that will cost between $150 million and $200 million over the next 14 years and add 205,000 kilowatts to its generating capacity.

description: Queens Republican leaders agreed yesterday to support Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special state prosecutor, for the party's District Attorney nomination to oppose the Democratic incumbent, John J. Santucci.

description: Two works by George Crumb and two by Aaron Copland were performed at the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble's splendid New and Newer Music concert Tuesday night at the Lincoln Center Library. It is worth pondering that the Crumb pieces made the stronger impressionboth Copland compositions are more than 30 years old, and far from forgotten.

title: News Summary
description: All United States citizens in Uganda whose number is estimated at 200mainly missionaries, some businessmen and the crews of President Idi Amin's several airplanes  were ordered by President Amin to meet with him in Kampala on Monday. The Americans will not be permitted to leave the country before then. President Amin also sent a long message to President Carter suggesting that the United states deal with its own humanrights problems before commenting on Uganda's affairs. He warned that Uganda forces would crush any attempt by the United States to rescue its citizens, accused the Central Intelligence Agency of plotting against him and expressed the hope that'he could visit the United States soon. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: There's Feminist Editing Behind the Female Form In Top Men's Magazines
description: Give Jeri Lee an inch, and she'll take a mile. A streak of sassiness runs through this vivacious, 21yearold with snapping blue eyes. She admits she is dominant and hard to control. But the warmth of her native California sun brings out a softer, more mellow side in her nature, and she enjoys nothing so much as relaxing her gorgeous. 382536 frame on a secluded beach.

title: People in Sports
description: The regular National Hockey League season is over for Don Murdoch. The Rangers hope their highscoring rookie will be ready for the opening of the Stanley Cup playoffs the first week in April, but his injury and those to other Rangers make it questionable whether the New York team will be in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: A Toch of Paris And Haiti at P S. 9
description: On Manhattan's Upper West Side, a little bit of Paris and a little bit of PortauPrince resound in the classrooms of Public School 9. Most people who think of New York as a bilingual city, think of it as EnglishSpanish, but in this school on West 84th Street, 140 childrenmostly from Haiti, but some the offspring of parents who worked in France or have come from Frenchspeaking Canada  are enrolled in a FrenchEnglish program, one of three in the city's school system.

title: Morocco Quits O.A.U. in a Rift
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Morocco has suspended all participation in the Organization of African Unity to protest allegations that the Moroccans were involved in an attempted coup in Benin by a mysterious incursion by raiders on Jan. 16, the Government announced here today. The decision was announced by Foreign Minister Ahmed Laraki in a letter to O.A.U. officials.

description: St. John's vs. Providence, at Alumni Hall, Jamaica, Queens, S P.M. (RadioWGBB, 7:45 P.M.)

title: Admiral of the World Ocean
description: PARISFor the first time, to my knowledge, the Soviet Union now acknowledges that its fishing and scientific fleets play a military role in its enormous global sea power. Altogether this equals if it does not indeed surpass the overall maritime strength of the United States, only few years ago considered to have inherited waning Britannia's claims to rule the waves.

title: Grains of Sand Are Found to Assist Fluorocarbons Destruction by Sun
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The spray can gases that threaten to deplete the upper atmosphere's ozone layer may be decomposed by ordinary sunlight when the gas molecules cling to grains of ordinary sand, chemists at the National Bureau of Standards have discovered.

title: MAINE's BONDS SOLD IN FACE OF LAWSUIT
description: Maine sold $15.4 million of bonds yesterday in the first test of the state's acceptability in the bond market since the claims of the Passamaquoddies and Penobscots halted a Maine Bond Bank financing last September.

title: Flames 6, North Stars 2
description: ATLANTA, Feb., 25 (UPI)  Willi Plett, Bobby Simpson and Pat Ribble scored in a fourgoal thirdperiod tonight that carried the Atlanta Flames to a 62 victory over the Minnesota North Stars. Plett scored two thirdperiod goals to give him 26 for the season.

title: U. of Vermont's Men Skiers Lead Middlebury Carnival
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 25Skiing consistently, the men's team of the University of Vermont swept to victory in the giantslalom and crosscountry events today at the Eastern intercollegiate ski championships, being held at the Middlebury College Winter Carnival. The Catamounts thus built a 21point lead on the first day of the competition.

title: Israeli Labor Party Now Willing To Return Some Areas to Jordan
description: TEL AVIV, Feb 25Israel's governing Labor Party adopted an election platform today that for the first time came out for returning some occupied territories to Jordan in a peace settlement.

title: AMIN PROHIBITS EXIT BY 200 AMERICANS; BIDS THEM MEET HIM
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 25 President Idi Amin of Uganda today ordered all United States citizens in the country to meet with him on Monday morning and said they would be barred from leaving the country before then.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Michael D'Arminio, a former Hackensack Mayor, was given a sixmonth suspended sentence and was fined $2,000 Friday for wrongfully billing the City of Hackensack for travel expenses.

title: First Finding of Organism's Gene Makeup Reported
description: DENVER, Feb. 25  British scientists have reported that for the first time they have determined the complete genetic structure of a living organism and have discovered that a gene, controlling agent for all inherited characteristics, is more complicated than was thought.

title: Prague Is Now Insisting Charter 77 Appeal Violates Constitution
description: VIENNA, Feb. 25Czechoslovak embassies in Western Europe, in a belated attempt to justify harsh measures taken by Prague against members of the Charter 77 humanrights group, circulated an official statement this week describing the manifesto issued by Charter 77 as illegal and unconstitutional.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25James J. Sheeran the State Insurance Commissioner, held up action today on a request by the Hartford Insurance Companies for a 28.4 percent increase in premium rates for liability automobile insurance until they complied with his request for profitandloss information.

title: Converse Cuts Back
description: The Converse Rubber Company will shut its shoe manufacturing operations in Andover, Mass., because of increasing competition from imports. It said that 300 employees would be laid off as a result. In January, the plant laid off 200 of its 600 employees. It now will retain 100 workers to manufacture industrial rubber products.

title: Cairo Again Plans Food Subsidy Cut
description: CAIRO, Feb. 25The Egyptian Government still intends to make the cuts in food price subsidies that provoked two days of rioting last month, but the cuts will be introduced gradually beginning early next year, according to Dr. Hamed Abdel Latif elSayeh, Minister of Economy and Economic Cooperation.

title: Boy's Fight With Father Led to Spending. Spree
description: ROBSTOWN, Tex., Feb. 25 (UPI)After an argument with his father in January, Dean Bridges, decided to dig up almost a half million dollars in cash that he knew was buried on his father's south Texas ranch and run away.

title: Installing, Adjusting and Repairing Window Shades
description: Putting up window shades, or adjusting and repairing those that do not work properly, is simple home maintenance project that any home handyman or handywoman can easily take care of themselvesif they are familiar with the basic types of mounting brackets available, and the simple techniques involved in installing and adjusting shades.

title: What's Doing in MEXICO CITY
description: TENOCHTITLAN TODAYMexico City today bears little resemblance to the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan which Heiman Cortes sighted on an island in a mountain lake some 450 years ago. The lake has dried up and the city has spread chaotically in all directions to accommodate 12 million inhabitants. But the old city center built on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, still retains something of its Colonial grandeur, while the Paseo de la Reforma preserves enough 19thcentury elegance to be recognizable as a Mexican version of the ChampsElyses. The Reforma, as it is known, sweeps across the city from the posh residential district of Las Lomas in the through lush Chapultepec

title: The new evolution
description: In their hearts the Victorians never believed Darwin and never forgave him for shaking their beliefs, a feeling that survives with undiminished fervor among today's neoVictorians. The evidence continues to mount, however. Due largely to a research boom starting about a generation ago when doublehelix DNA (a merciful shortening of Deoxyribo Nucleic Acid) was identified as the stuff from which genes are made, evolution is emerging as a theory far richer and broader than even its founder envisioned. Past notions about the human speciesborn in original sin, plaything of the gods or halfgod or god in the making, naked or killer or imperial apeare being replaced by something more sophisticated and perhaps considerably more controversial.

title: SUNY's Feminist Biographer
description: THERE are lives that won't leave one alone, wrote Helene Moglen in the opening pages of Charlotte Bronte  The Self Conceived. Miss Moglen, who heads the English department at the State University College at Purchase, has written a frankly feminist, critical biography of the 19thcentury novelist that has been stirring discussion in the literary world.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE NEW KID on the block usually has to win his way to popularity, often a matter of some time. In the case of Greenstreet, which arrived in downtown Greenwich only last November, it hasn't taken long, to judge by the 20to40 minute wait for tables on weekend nights. Much of its popularity, we suspect, has to do with the ambience of the place, since on our two recent visits the food was for the most part indifferent.

title: Sears Store in California Opens Clinic for Dental Plan's Patients
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26  Now you can go to a Sears store near here and buy new tires, new furniture, new clothing and a new set of teeth.

title: Correction
description: The photograph accompanying the Washington Report in last Sunday's Business and Finance Section was incorrectly identified as that of Bernard (Bobby) Shapiro, chief of staff of the Joint Taxation Committee. It was James W. Wetzler, chief economist of the committee.

title: Stanley Levin Will Wed Robin Kantor in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Kantor of Woodsburgh, L.I., and Miami have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Karen Kantor, to Stanley L. Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Levin of Atlantic Beach, Li. A wedding next August in Old Westbury, Li., is planned.

title: For young readers
description: In 1974, exastronaut Michael Collins published a remarkable book. It was called Carrying the Fire: An Astronaut's Journeys, and in it Mr. Collins recounted his career up to and through the flight of Apollo 11, on which he was the third man: the one who watched while Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the moon.

title: Flower Show Schedule
description: Long Island: Flora 77 opens Saturday through March 13 at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale. Hours daily 10 A.M.10 P.M. except March 13, 8 P.M. closing. Adult tickets: $3.50.

title: Smithing With a Smile
description: DENNIS SUCILSKY, a 24yearold Setauket blacksmith, would rather people forgot Longfellow's ode to the village smithy.

title: Talking with the folks back home
description: The small town of Wigton is in Cumberland, near the border between England and Scotland. Melvyn Bragg, who was born there, went to Oxford University and then to London to work in television and as a writer. In 1971 he began taping a series of interviews with people in Wigton. This booka selection of interviews with a linking commentary and two statistical appendicesis the result. We can read the memories and observations of some 60 people, ranging in date of birth from 1889 to 1952, though more than twothirds were born before 1918, and ranging in occupation from doctor and solicitor to farm and factory workers, though middleclass and professional occupations are disproportionately represented. Through a variety of personal experiences we hear of the steady general improvement in health, housing, education, farming and job opportunities, which arc characteristic of this period in England as a whole. We hear also of the slow, yet reluctant dissolution of older kinds of emphatic (usually landed) privilege.

title: Carter and the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  In the last few days, President Carter has had new grandson, donated blood to the Red Cross, and advocated a number of good but neglected causes, including marriage, courtesy, punctuality, clarity, brevity and the United Nations.

title: Diana Soviero Is a Warm Mimi In La Boheme
description: The City Opera's production of La Boheme always seems to run on a consistently smooth, professional track no matter how often the cast changes over the years. Friday night's performance was no exceptionthere may not have been any special revelations or moments of exceptional vocalism for Puccini connoisseurs, but no one in the cast was anything less than thoroughly competent.

title: Questions on Hussein
description: Statements by President Carter and others have left unanswered several questions about the Central Intelligence Agency's secret payments to King Hussein of Jordan, and Mr. Carter's decision last week to stop them:

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There are at least five images I shan't forget as long as live in Andrei Serban's mounting of The Cherry Orchard for Joseph Papp's new season at Lincoln Center, and I'm going to mention them to see what you can begin to make of the confidently daring, alternately vulgar and delicate, perverse, funny, deeply original and visually stunning event that sweeps through the vast whiteonwhite reaches of the Vivian Beaumont stage like a circusbred whirlwind bent on making the world clean.

title: Yachting
A Boy Had A Mother Who Bought Him a Hat
description: Red as a rose and it kept off the snows is the accompanying line to the title of this variation on The House That Jack Built as the hat's owner acquires in succession a pet mouse, new shoes, boots, skis, a Halloween mask, a cello and an elephant. When the hat blows off, the line of ownership literally unravels in the wind; Mother runs out to buy a new hat, and the process starts all over again. The familiar dactyls of the nursery rhyme original keep the story bouncing along, complete with repetitions that underline childhood's pride of possession (He loved it so much/That whatever he did/Or whatever he said/When dressed in his hat/Which was wooly and red.

title: Hope for Chestnut Trees
description: Hope for the return of the American chestnut ever grows brighter. Plant scientists are now encouraged in their search for a biological control of the blight that killed the native American chestnut in a broad sweep more than 50 years ago.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Beautiful African violets can set off a responsive chord in the most sophisticated gathering of gardeners. This happened recently when Michael Kartuz lectured to a capacity audience at the Greenwich Garden Center in Cos Cob, Conn. Many of his listeners were experienced gardeners; many of them experts and owners of greenhouses. When Mr. Kartuz who is himself an expert grower and hybridizer of gesneriads from Wilmington, Mass, showed off just a few African violets, the women responded unanimously with ohs and ahs of delight.

title: Chocolate Town, Pa. A Sweet Smell of Success
description: Around the turn of the century Derry Township, in the gently rolling foothills of the Blue Mountains of Pennsylvania, was a patchwork of green forests and brown fields. Then Milton Snavely Hershey, at last triumphing over adversity in the form of a wellintentioned but economically selfdestructing father (see Page 20), returned to the farm where he was born and built a chocolate factory. Deny Township hasn't been the same since.

description: THE players use brooms, slide rocks that weigh 42 pounds along the ice and call their teams rinks and their tournaments bonsp els.

Hawes of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned. Mrs. Roy K. Ferguson of New Ycirk and Oyster Bay, L. I. Mr. Ferguson for many years was president and board chairman of the St. Regis Paper Company.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: One of the toughest strokes for most tennis players is the half volleya shot that's made down close to the ground just after the ball has bounced. It calls for the timing and agility of a baseball infielder scooping up a ball on the short hop.

title: Jerseyan Found Guilty Of Attempt to Tamper With Mandel Trial Jury
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 26  A Federal Districtcourt jury here found a 52yearold New Jersey man guilty today of offering to fix the jury verdict in the political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel and four associates.

title: HOME CLINIC

Unfortunately, this seldom works out because the studs are seldom if ever situated just where they needed.

description: Vladimir Ashkenazy devoted his entire concert to Chopin on Friday evening in Carnegie Hall. His followingand Chopin's, toowas out in force. Mr. Ashkenazy is one of the younger crop of pianists who disdains formal attire, playing in ousiness suit and turtleneck sweater.

description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 26A new boat, a technological marvel called Imp from San Francisco Bay, beat an old boat, Running Tide, from Annapolis, Md., for tile championship of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference. Imp, owned by David Allen of Belvedere. Calif., won the Nassau Cup yesterday, a 3Imile voyage over a beautiful blue ocean. It was her fifth first place in her class on corrected time on the sixrace Southern circuit, which has now concluded.

description: TOMORROW, in fact on most Monday nights, some 70 friends and neighbors will gather at Benjamin Franklin High School in Teaneck where, as members of the 40yearold Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra, they will rehearse under their conductor, Wolfgang Schanzer.

title: Mailbox: Not for Blacks Only
description: It is reassuring to hear Arthur Ashe put sports in a healthy perspective. Indeed, children of all races in today's televisionconditioned society would do well by setting realistic goals for themselves, establishing a place for sports within their personal physical abilities and appreciating the value of a good education.Ronald Stanley, Somerset, N.J.

title: RESIDENCE REQUIREMENT FOR INSURANCE IS UPHELD
description: A threejudge Federal Court panel Fri, day upheld the constitutionality of a New. York State law that says only those who live or work in the state can buy Savings. Bank Life Insurance in the state.

title: 200Mile Limit, Starting Tuesday, Cheers New England's Fishermen
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26  In the face of criticism from other countries and some misgivings in this country, the United States on Tuesday will take control of virtually all ocean fishing out to 200 miles off its coasts and far beyond that in some areas.

title: Coming: A vaccine against tooth decay
description: Every year America's 111000 dentists fill half a billion cavities and collect a respectable total of $4 billion for doing it. Even when they are through, according to U. S. Public Health Service estimates, a billion teeth with cavities remain unfilled for one reason or another. The cause of this enormous amount of costly drilling and holefilling is the disease known as dental caries, tooth decay, which affects nearly all human beings on earth and is as old as man himself.

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WINTER in all its harshness is my favorite time for tramping along the ocean beach. The surf sounds like snatches from nature's great symphony, and in the isolation and enormousness come glimpses of larger harmonies. Gentle or raging, the Key of Sea changes vrith the weather, a vast and volatile mistress to the dormant earth.

title: Article 11  No Title
KokaTo Piaf With Love
description: EDITH PIAF was born on the sidewalk of a Paris slum, raised in a brothel operated by her maternal grandmother, temporarily blinded at the age of 4, sang on street corners and in cafes to support herself and her father at 15, gave birth to an outofwedlock daughter (who died in infancy) at 17, was discovered by a prominent nightclub owner at 19, end, with fame and fortune, went on to become probably the most popular singer of laments of unrequited love in the history of France.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: One of the untold stories of photography is the impact of photojournalism on portraiture. Before photojournalism the typical photographic portrait was carefully posed in the studio or some selected corner of the sitter's own environment. The advent of photojournalism and the miniature camera in the 1920's and 30's led photographers to try to catch their subjects unposed and unaware in the course of their daily activities. A new kind of candid portraiture evolved which, rightly or wrongly, was believed to be more revealing of the subject's true self. Then, after World War II, in a kind of reaction against the Candid camera approach, certain photographers returned to the formal studio pose.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: A misconception about floating exchange rates and inflation has gained currency and is being repeated, not only in the popular press, hut in the statements of some government leaders. It is to the effect that floating rates are a source of inflation, as well as a result, so that an exchange rate movement, once Initiated, becomes selfreinforcing in the same direction.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: President Carter did not shuck off his farmerbusinessman attitudes when he entered the White House, to judge by his support for moves to deregulate the prices of both newly discovered natural gas and airline fares.

title: Diane D. Grosjean Plans To Wed C. D. Bergfeld 2d

title: Mr. Bones, How Come You're Wearing Burnt Cork?
description: In its formative years, American show business excluded black performers, but it never ignored black people. Part of the story of the black entertainment pioneers who fought for success, recognition and dignity in the late 19th century is told In Minstrel Man, a twohour fictionalized drama that will be telecast this Wednesday evening at 9 on CBS. The storyline of Minstrel Man begins in 1889; yet the actual story of minstrelsy began much earlier.

title: Bumpkin Chic
description: BACK when city dudes were sure that Park Avenue was the center of civilization and the bumpkins appeared to believe it, we all knew how to behave out here in the Hamptons. Dudes dressed for dinner, spoke lahdeedah and, over at the club, danced till dawn, swirling chiffon and breathing hard.

title: A Home With Little Light The Lot of Many Here
description: There are many things Patricia Burstein loves about her apartment. It is located at 40 Central Park South. A nice address. Close to work. about 10 blocks away, and she likes to walk to work.

title: INTERVIEW
description: EVER since he was a kid growing up in foster homes in Michigan, Wayne W. Dyer knew that some day he was going to write a best seller.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Toward the end of last year, It was widely expected in Wall Street that 1977 would be an upbeat year in both the stock and the bond markets for a number of reasons. The economy was pointed upward, inflation was headed downward, and a new Administration was preparing to move into the White House with a promise of moderate economic stimulus to bolster consumer spending and cut unemployment. All the elements seemed to be in place at that time for a positive, confident performance by the financial markets.

U.S. Review of BusAid Program Vexes Westchester and Connecticut
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26  A decision by the Carter Administration to review a program for buying advancedesign buses with Federal aid is causing concern among officials in Westchester County and in Connecticut that their plans for improving or expanding their fleets with hundreds of new buses may be significantly delayed.

description: BOSTON  Alan G. Dustin's route to the executive suite has been strictly oldrailroad. He started by heaving baggage during the summer of 1947 at Ticonderoga, N.Y., in the Lake Champlain resort area, and studying Morse at night to qualify for a telegrapher's job on the Delaware & Hudson Railway.

title: Auto Race to Ingram
description: RICHMOND. Va., Feb. 26 (AP)Tack Ingram of Asheville, N.C., led from start to finish today and won the Eastern 150mile event for NASCAR Sportsman cars at Richmond Fairgrounds. Second place went to Morgan Shepard of Conover, N.C., with Barry Grant of Taylorsville, N.C., third.

title: A Bergen Freeholder Says County Rule Has Atrophied
description: WHEN I was elected to the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders in 1974, I thought the New Jersey law called 40:201 meant what it said, hut I have learned something about yes, buts. The enabling statute says: The property, finances and affairs of every county shall be managed, controlled and governed by a board to be elected therein, to be known as the board of Chosen Freeholders.... The ellipses represent the exceptions and They are numerous.

title: Graduating from the Past
description: THIS is a critical year for higher ducation in Connecticut. A unique opportunity exists for substantial change, an opportunity created by hard times and much public discontent, provoking extensive debate as to how higher education should be reorganized to face the future. Last year, the General Assembly considered several bills for reorganization and evaded passage of any. This year, with old and new bills before them and with the education community divided as to the best direction to take, the legislature is almost certain to take some action to move the recurrent issue off the agenda.

title: TV VIEW
description: As a critic, primarily concerned with what comes out of a television set, I do not have to attend broadcasting conventions, which are generally preoccupied with what is being prepared for the home screen. The result is a measure essential isolation from the raw hucksterism the business. Count your blessings, colleagues insist Leave well enough alone immediate family members warn. But an invitation to attend the recent conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives proved irresistible. The site was Miami's Hotel Fontainebleau. The event would afford an opportunity to see major program suppliers in confrontation with programming chiefs from local stations representing the entire nation. The proposed rewriting of the 1934 Communications Act would be discussed by FCC commissioners and industry spokesmen. The educational potential was staggering. As it turned out, so was the conventionfiguratively and occasionally, under the load of hospitalitysuite largess, literally.

title: Yale Women Capture Ivy Gymnastics Title

description: AT GREENWICH, CONN.

title: The poet, his love and his plays
description: All three of these books deserve a place on your Yeats shelf. Though written in a pedestrian style, Samuel Levenson's biography is the first devoted to the poet's famous inamorata who was also a great Victorian beauty, Irish nationalist, street orator, actress (in Yeats's plays), and constant plotter in both France and Ireland against her native country, Britain. Frank Tuohy's volume, though no more than a biographical essay and something of a coffeetable book, redeems itself through graceful, accurate writing and lavish deployment of pictorial materials. Outstanding among the color plates are four fullpage Irish genre scenes by Jack Yeats, the poet's brother, a fascinating group portrait called Homage to Manet, by Sir William Orpen, which shows what Yeats's nemesis, George Moore, looked like in 1909, and a brilliant design for The Secret Rose done by the young Dublin painter, Norah McGuinness, in 1927.

title: Letters

title: Lindblad Finds Refuge With Yankees in War
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 Through the combined efforts of three club owners, one commissioner and one league president, Paul Lindblad was an Oakland Athletic signed to a Texas Ranger contract working out in a Yankee uniform today.

description: To an innocent outsider, the scene might have looked downright peculiar. Here was an officefull of conservatively dressed, grownup men and women, and what were they doing? They were twitching, that's what. Or Jiggling or snapping their fingers.
