title: Bonita L. Areman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan H. Areman of New Hyde Park and Montauk, Li., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonita Lynne Areman, to Stephen Joseph Zudnak Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zudnak of Lawrenceville, N.J. Miss Areman and her fianc graduated from Ithaca College.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to Montserrat, fly to Antigua on British West Indian Airways or Eastern, then connect with a L.I.A.T. (twicedaily) flight. Roundtrip fare: from New York: $340.,You need proof of citizenship (passport or birth certificate), and your driver's license if you choose to rent a car. Be sure to obtain a Montserrat license for about $2 at the police station in Plymouth. Both automatic and shift cars are available for rental; our 4door automatic Datsun cost $125 U.S. a week.

title: The Common Market's Growing Pains
description: ATHENS  Shortly before his recent death, Anthony Crosland said that enlarging the Common Market presented Europe with perhaps its most testing challenge. After enumerating the economic difficulties that growth would entail, the late British Foreign Secretary continued: Why, then, enlarge? Because simply, the political benefits of enlargement outweigh the practical difficulties.

title: FILM VIEW
description: AS I write this in an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side, an elderly man and his wife, who live across the street on the fifth floor of what can be described as Old LowerIncome Housing, sit, one to a window, watching the activity on the sidewalk below as if it were an unending Passion Play. When the incidents become juicy, the man sometimes allows the woman to use his opera glasses. Mostly, though, he hogs them. Day and night, summer and winter. From my vantage point four floors above them I can see their television set, but they seldom turn it on, even when the pace of real life slows down to argument over an inconveniently doubleparked car. Why should they watch television when at any moment they may chance upon a mugging, a rape, a lovers quarrel, a car being stripped or stolen? Angie Dickinson flashing her badge at a narcotics dealer isn't half as riveting watching David, our postman, coping with someone's uncurbed, unleashed dog.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ASKED what it was about the transportation field that turned him on, R. Raleigh D'Adamo, Westchestees Commissioner of Transportation, laughed and said: You know, every kid has his model trains, and a few of us just never give it up, never outgrow it.

title: Retired Nun Finds a 2d Career Preparing IncomeTax Retruns
description: The signature at the bottom of the completed form read Sister Regina Mary Elwell. The handwriting was small and neat, much like Sister Regina, a retired teacher with the Sisters of Charity who keeps busy this time of year preparing tax returns.

title: Army Plans to Bolster Divisions To Counter a Buildup by Soviet
description: The United States Army will begin this fall a longrange program to raise the firepower and manpower of armored and mechanized infantry divisions. The program is intended to counter the recent strengthening of Soviet division in these two areas.

title: Season in Purgatory
description: By Thomas Keneally. 206 pp. New Yorh: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $8.95.

title: Death Law Seen Issue in Coast Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26  If present trends continue, restoration of the death penalty in California will be the main campaign issue in next year's race for Governor.

title: Getting Less Education for More Money
description: I WAS much interested but not greatly surprised when the Briarcliff Manor Civic and Taxpayers Association published its study last month showing that education in the Briarcliff public schools over the last 10 years had seemed to have deteriorated while its costs had soared. The business of education often defies reason, or those venerable prejudices that loud repetition has made to seem reasonable. Many of us still cling to the dogged old myth that the more we spend on our children's education, as if by magic, the better it gets.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Rome's Prima Ballerina Finds Stardom in Paris
description: About the beginning of the 20th century, a curtain of deserved anonymity descended on ballet in Italy. It has been penetrated in recent times only by Carla Fraeci, whose talents in romantic and dramatic ballet have attracted international attention. She is from Milan.

title: Met's New Annenberg Center Stirs Controversy
description: Since the Metropolitan Museum's announcement last November that the publisher Walter H. Annenberg would donate $20 million to set up the Fine Arts Center of the Annenberg School of Communications on the museum's premises, some provocative questions have been raised about the project, several of them in writing.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1COURTESY GENERAL DYNAMICS 2021BLACK STAR/DENNIS BRACK 3639BLACK STAR/SIPA PRESS;

title: Food
description: There is one sign of spring infinitely more welcome to a dedicated, fishloving gastronome than the first robin on the lawn, the first jonquil under the trees. That is the succulent shad and, it goes without saying, shad roe. The sad thing about the shad season is its uncommon brevity. Whereas most fish in Atlantic waters may be had in one quantity or another throughout the year, shad comes in like a grace note or a rainbow and seems to disappear just as quickly.

title: GARDENING
description: ONE of the best antidotes for winter doldrums is a good flower show, and such an event will open at 10 A.M. next Saturday at the Morristown National Guard Armory.

title: The Jewish banker and the German statesman: the history of a 19thcentury partnership
description: Historians who attempt to explain political developments in terms of economic pressures generally run into difficulties when it comes to finding the exact point, the precise moment, when the pressure is applied. As a result, legends grow up about the power of bankers and the sinister influence of high finance, but there is often little evidence about what bankers actually do and about the real connection between their activities and the daytoday policies of their governments.

title: New York City Council, After Nearly 12 Hours of Debate, Approves New Lines for 33 Districts by 33 to 4 Vote
description: The City Council, after nearly 12 hours of discussion and sharp clashes between members, late last night adopted new lines for New York's 33 councilmanic districts.

title: Stacy Runyon Is Fiancee Of John William Prather
description: The engagement of Stacy Ann Runyon to John William Prather has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Boice Runyon of Barrington, R.I., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Prather of Greensboro, N.C.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Inflation anxieties caused the stock market to register a modest decline last week in continued slow trading.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EDWARD ALBEE chose the Hartford Stage Company for the opening of his two new plays, Counting the Ways and Listening. A fortunate choice for all concerned, as it turned out. Critics drove up from New York and wrote some disparaging reviews. However, the theatergoers in Hartford disagreed. They bought every seat in the house right through to the end of the engagement next Sundayeven including some folding chairs added at the ends of the aisles.

title: By Nigel Gosling. Illustrated. 298 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
description: There's a surprising family feeling about the portraits made by the 19thcentury French photographer Felix Tournachon, known as Nader. As seen in a beautiful new book Nader, with spirited text by Nigel Gosling, they don't really seem to represent the public personalities of their distinguished subjects from the Paris intellectual world, but the quirky and wellexplored faces of close friends and relatives.

title: POLITICS
description: THE entry of Robert A. Roe, the voluble Passaic County Congressman, into the Democratic gubernatorial primary poses some problems for Joseph A. Hoffman, the state's former Commissioner of Labor and Industry, who began his own quest for the nomination last month.

title: Dr. Barnara's Mother Dies
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 26 (AP)  Maria Elizabeth Barnard, the mother of Christiaan and IMarius Barnard, the heart surgeons, died here yesterday at the age of 22. Funeral services were planned for today.

title: LETTERS
description: The Jobless

title: McKoy's 2 Metamorphoses: As Player and Young Man
description: Seven years ago Wayne McKoy turned his back to the basket and began his metamorphosis from an unskilled 6foot4inch 11yearold into the type of player who makes college basketball coaches dream of national championshipsthe dominating center.

title: Japanese Satellite Shifts Orbit
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26 (AP)  Japan's first experimental stationary satellite continued to function normally and appeared to have shifted to a circular orbit from an elliptical orbit this afternoon, the National Space Development Agency said. The satellite, launched Wednesday, will become stationary over the eastern part of New Guinea on Thursday morning, the agency said.

title: UGANDA'S ASSURANCE IS WELCOMED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The White House said today that it welcomed assurances that the Government of Uganda intended no harm to the iiiore than 200 Americans in that country but that it remained concerned about their welfare.

title: 15 Whose Influence Is Felt
description: FOR two decades, according to envious outsiders, Westchester's political course was charted as much by twodozen powerful members of a luncheun club as it was in the White Plains office of the Republican County Executive, Edwin G. Michaelian.

title: Jane Frederick: Set to Claim Fame
description: Her right hand hugged the weighted ball to her cheek. Her left hand reached for the sky. Her leg muscles were stretched taut, like steel belts. In profile she was Diana, the huntress.

title: Boom Town in the Coal Country
description: WRIGHT, Wyo.  A year ago, what is now the town of Wright was scrubland populated by grazing cattle and occasional bands of pronghorn antelope. Today the town boasts 162 trailer homes, grass imported from Spearfish, S.D., a trailerpost office, a trailerchurch, a prefabricated elementary school and a population of 450.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: FebruaryA Month Without a Place
description: THE leanest and saddest month of the year must surely be February. It is surprising that no one has yet thought to pin a label on it. We have dog days in August and Indian summer in October. March. April. May and June have been appropriated by poets and songwriters, July and September by purveyors of travel brochures. November and December are the merchants favorites and everyone else's busiest.

title: Lanshy and 4 Subpoenaed In Miami in Investigation Into Murder of Rosselli
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)  Five reputed Mafia members and associates, including Meyer Lansky and Anthony Giacalone, have been subpoenaed by the Dade County state attorney's office to answer questions next week about the murder of John PosseIli. onetime Mafia member.

title: JOSEPH HYMAN, 80, PRODUCER, IS DEAD
description: Joseph M. Hyman, producer and coproducer with the late Bernard Hart of nearly a score of Broadway plays, died Friday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: Stephen Lounsbury Black Will Wed Susan K. Hines
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard R. Hines of Poway, Calif., formerly of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Karen Hines, to Stephen Lounsbury Black, son of Judge and Mrs. Robert L. Black Jr. of Cincinnati.

title: L. PAUL BREMER JR.
Carter's Top Aides Take Steps to Avoid Conflict of Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The financial disclosure statements released yesterday by the White House show that President Carter's Cabinet members and other top aides already have taken a number of significant actions designed to avoid actual or potential conflicts of interests.

title: A Cab Driver, 2d in 4 Days, Shot to Death
description: A woman out for an early morning walk with her dog on Riverside Drive yesterday came across a gypsy cab nosed into the curb at a bus stop just south of 76th Street, the driver slumped at the wheel, dead with several bullet wounds in the head.

title: Horse Shows
description: AT NORTH SALEM, N.Y.

title: How Finley Sealed Barons'
description: Most people associate Charles O. Finley strictly with baseball. They know the remnants of his Oakland A's are gathering in Mesa, Ariz., for spring training. They wonder what he will say to Commissioner Bowie Kuhn at the hearing on his recent $400,000 sale of Paul Lindblad to the Texas Rangers. Most people forget that Charles O. Finley once owned of the California Seals even hockey people had almost forgotten. But last week's refinancing of the Cleveland Barons for $1.3 million reminded them.

title: Cornell Wins Heptagonal Track Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 26  The posters on the Cornell campus advertising the Heptagonal indoor track and field championships bore the legend, Happiness is a Big Red Win, but few believed it would happen. Tonight, the Big Red track team delighted a partisan crowd of 4,000 at Baron Hall by winning the Hops for the first time since 1958. Cornell scored 44 points, 7 more than Pennsylvania, the defending champion.

title: Letters
description: In A proposal for a Palestinian state (Jan. 30), Edward R. F. Sheehan ignores the fact that for 19 years Jordan occupied the West Bank, and Egypt occupied the Gaza Strip. From 1998 to 1967, these two Arab countries had it in their power to establish a PalestinianArab state in these territories, yet they did not do what they are now asking Israel to do. Were there no Palestinian Arabs then in the West Bank or Gaza? Did the ofttrumpeted legitimate rights of the Palestinians not exercise the Arab states during all those years? Why were the Palestinian people unable to achieve in the West Bank under Jordan, or in Gaza under the Egyptians, the degree of control of their domestic affairs which they have achieved under Israel?

title: Track and Field
description: AT ITHACA, N.Y.

title: If You Go
description: on a Danish farm holiday, be prepared to mingle and cooperate at close quarters with persons of many nationalities. Also remember that these are not paintthetownred vacations, that you will be in private homes. Prices for adults in the peak season (the start of summer through the end of August and at Christmas and Easter) with full room and board are about $12 a day; $10, halfboard. Offseason prices are $10 or $8.50. Children, for whom farm holidays are ideal, are charged half the adult price up to the age of four, 75 percent of the adult price until 12. The minimum booking is seven days, and extra days may be negotiated individually; while strongly discouraged, in some cases stays of fewer than seven days can be booked for an extra charge.

title: An Odyssey With the Kids
description: OFF SANDS POINT

title: ART
description: ON the face of it, the exhibition of contemporary American art at the Sarah Lawrence College Gallery might appear somewhat limited and vaguely misleading. Limited because the show restricts itself to painting done between 1975 and and present. Misleading because we might be given the impression that the last two years and a few months produced a golden age in American art, a renaissance of creative activity following a period of relative indistinctiveness. Otherwise why arbitrarily select these years of chronological brackets or guideposts?

title: Possible Strategy: Combine Options and Savings
description: For the last four years, the fastest growing sector of the securities industry has been the options market. Ever since the Chicago Board Options Exchange opened in April 1973, business has been expanding. The New York Stock Exchange is committed to start options trading, and industry observers believe that step may come sometime this year.

title: On Reviving Stratford
description: IT DIDN'T have to happen. The American Shakespeare Theater did not have to come to its present sorry state surrendering its noble purpose to what is to be, in essence, a booking agency for roadcompany productions. To be sure this is announced as a temporary measure to allow delays or earn enough money to extricate the theater from its staggering current debt of $900,000.

title: Islanders Rout Flames; Hawks Beat Rangers, 21
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 26  The Islanders smell the roses! On the way to an 82 trouncing of the Atlanta Flames tonight at Nassau Coliseum, the New Yorkers set a club record by scoring three goals in 45 seconds.

title: Vilas Beats Ramirez in Semifinals
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 26Guillermo Vilas beat Raul Ramirez, 63, 63, in a match of nine service breaks and reached the final of the $225,000 American Airlines tennis tournament at the Mission Hills Country Club today. The Argentine southpaw has now won seven of seven matches against the Mexican.

title: The Fuzz vs. the Fuzzbusters
description: SGT. KENNETH KIRSCHNER drove out of the parking lot in back of State Police Headquarters on Washngton Street in Hartford. For the lean, baldish veteran of 11 years on the force, it was the start of another day in the steadily escalating electronic battle on the state highways between motorists intent on reaching their destinations as fast as possible and the state police who are determined to keep the driver within, or not much over, the 55mileanhour speed limit on the interstate highways.

title: Music in Review
description: Teresa Compos, a native of Pennsylvania and a Juilliard graduate, made her New York debut with a piano recital in Town Hall Monday night. Miss Compos went about her tasks in a neat, businesslike fashion, and everything she.played demonstrated a facile technique as well as a general understanding of what the music required in structural and textural orderliness.

title: Stamford Charter: Opening the Debate
description: I AM DAVID fighting Goliath! The speaker, Wayne L. Tyson, a 43yearold public relations executive in Stamford, explained with an air al earnest conviction and deep intensity that his Goliath in his lonely battle was the 15member Charter Revision Commission of Stamford, which he charged with violating the state's Freedom of Information law by barring the public from some of its meetings.

title: MUSIC
description: LET OTHER doctors take to the golf course for relaxation. When Caroline Bauman, a pediatrician, away from her White Plains office, she's more likely to be at the piano, brushing up on her Beethoven. or perhaps on the phone, negotiating a concert plum like the Tokyo Quartet for the Westchester Chamber Music Society.

title: Tokyo Protests to Soviet For Setting Fishing Zone Off Islands Near Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26  Japan protested to the Soviet Union today against a Russian announcement that a 200mile fishing zone would be enforced in waters surrounding four Sovietoccupied islands north of Japan that Tokyo claims as Japanese territory.

title: Letters: The Blimp As Morale Booster
description: To the Editor:

title: UGANDA'S RADIO SAYS U.S. NEED NOT WORRY OVER CITIZENS'
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sunday, Feb. 27 President Idi Amin of Uganda said yesterday that it had never been his intentibn to make any Americans hostages when he announced Friday that that no American citizens could leave the country until he met with them.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I WAS driving north along the Taconic Parkway one summery September evening at 7 in Westchester country, doing 50 in my 1968 Ford Fairlane, when I saw a UFO. It was off to my right at 500 yards, in an almost cloudless sky, traveling at perhaps 450 m.p.h. It looked much bigger than a 707. It was white, oblong, a solid contrast to the sky, and it had soft, feathery edges. I could see it clearly, and I watched it in the distance traveling even with me, for a long, slow countdown of, oh, say 10.

title: Finding a Home for Fairfield Vets
description: THERE ARE at least 150,000 veterans in Fairfield County, some whose service goes back to World War I, but nowhere in the county is there a veterans nursing home to serve them. Governor Grasso, the General Assembly and the Veterans Administration all agree one should be built, and soon, but the question of where to build it has created a controversy between Norwalk and Stamford legislators.

title: No Americans Among 20 Dead in Moscow Hotel Fire
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26  The Soviet authorities refused today to release figures on the number of killed and injured in the Rossiya Hotel fire last night, hut unoffiaal medical sources said there were more than 20 dead.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: NASA from Associated Press

title: Susan Washburn Bride of Christopher Talbot
description: Susan Lynn Washburn and Christopher W. Talbot, graduates of Franklin and Marshall College, class of 73, were married yesterday in the first United Methodist Church in Rahway, N. J., where the Rev. Koo Yong Na performed the ceremony.

title: BRIDGE
description: For serious players, almost all tournament play is matter of performing efficiently with a regular partner, or at any rate with a partner with whom at least 15 minutes of discussion about bidding and leads has been possible. Considering the vast spectrum of possible partnership agreements, one minute might not seem enough for this purpose, but it had to suffice in the Blue Ribbon Ina'minuet stagea earner this month by the Greater New York Bridge Association. The field included 36 players qualified by past performance on the international, national or local scene.

title: Bokassa and Macias Are Often Pictured as Singularly Cruel Autocrats
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Events in Uganda have brought into focus longstanding allegations of tyrannical rule, not only by President Idi Amin, but also by the leaders of two other African states, who are often privately regarded by other Africans as embarrassments to the continent, despotic and arbitrary rulers who are perhaps irrational.

title: Ridicule: Fourth R
description: COPIAGUE

title: Miss Kaserer Takes Cup Giant Slalom
description: FURANO, Japan, Sunday, Feb. 27 (UPI)Monika Kaserer of Austria won a women's giantslalom event in World Cup competition today, defeating LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland with a time of 1 minute 37.32 seconds.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: $2 Million in Stolen Goods Netted in 3d Bogus Fence By F.B.I. in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 26 (AP)  A fencing operation run by the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 14 months has recovered $2 million in stolen Jewelry, securities, luxury cars and antiques, the authorities announced today. Federal arrest warrants were issued for 16 persons in five East Coast stales.

title: A Partial U.S. Pullout From South Korea Now Seems Inevitable
description: WASHINGTON  Security commitments preclude a reduction in military assistance to South Korea, Secretary state Cyrus Ft. Vance told a Senate subcommittee last week on the other hand, the Carter Administration seems determined to withdraw large numbers of United States ground forces from the divided Korean peninsula. So far, that is a policy without a formal, public rationale. We have expressed the intent to withdraw, says an official here, but is not a plan yet. No timetable has been set, no numbers agreed upon, according to Administration officials,

title: Rare Italian Wine Bottled on West 103d St.
description: One of the rarest Italian wine labels in the world, Castello dei Tredanari, doesn't even come from Italy. And, as a matter fact, it really isn't even Italian. It is the house label for the wines of Lee J. Tredanari, onetime circus roustabout, taxi driver, ad agency executive and independent fellow.

title: Syracuse, Led by Williams, Sets Back Rutgers, 82 to 72
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 26Syracuse University completed its third undefeated season at home in the last seven years by staving off Rutgers, 8272, today in Manley Field House.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Reverse sides of the ninepiece proof set in ordinary metals.

title: Noise Is Music To This Expert Ear
description: NOISE is unwanted sound, said Dean McAdoo, whose vocation is noise and whose avocation is music, but sound may or may not be noise. I told my sons to stop all that noise when I came home from the office and found them wrestling and arguing. But soon afterward, I had a harrowing experience during a flight, and when I got home the noise of the boys was music to my ears.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Martin S. Stillman, who has been charged with seconddegree larceny, has resigned as director of the Connecticut Office of Emergency Medical Services.

title: Book Ends
description: Haute LoCal. When a hot subject comes down the pikebe it TM, est, rape or quick weight lossone can expect a cluster of books to follow. This has been the case with cuisine minceurslimming cuisine, a new style of French cooking that goes easy on the sugar, butter, flour and cream, of which Michel Guerard is considered the chief proponent and innovator. When the American rights to M. Guerard's still unwritten cookbook came up for grabs a year or so ago. Morrow won out in hot bidding for a reported $100,000.

title: Cincinnati Stops Intake of Water
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 26 (AP)  City officials ordered intake valves to Cincinnati's drinking water supply closed today as a second carbon tetrachloride spill in a week moved down the Ohio River. The action left this southwestern Ohio city of 450,000 with enough drinking water to last about three days. Carbon tetrachloride, which is used to dry cleaning, has caused cancer in laboratory animals.

title: Jean H. Tibbetts Is Engaged to Richard Peter Lenz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick B. Tibbetts of Newagen. Me., formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Henderson Tibbetts, to Richard Peter Lenz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Lenz of Kirmelon. N.J.

title: Article 16  No Title
Flowersand Something Extra
description: BY March I this place will be a fairyland, said Frank S. BonGiomo in a confident tone one recent morning as he stood between rows of barely budding plants, trees and shrubs in the warm humidity of a Huntington greenhouse.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Keane Comments On the Sunshine Law

title: Radio
description: I A.M.5 P.M., 1VORAM: Leukemia Radlothon Continues. Anne Meara, host. Live, from the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

title: Taft, Clinton and McKee Gain P.S.A.L. Semifinal
description: Albert King's remarkable high school basketball career came to an unhappy ending yesterday as his Fort Hamilton team lost, 6459, to Taft In a Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinal playoff at Long Island University in Brooklyn.

title: The World
description: An agreement in principle on confedbration between the Palestine Liberatinn Organization and the Government of Jordan has been reached in Amman. But the timing and specific details of the plan have to be worked out and until they are it will be impossible to tell whether the scheme can achieve its secondary but equally vital purpose: to circumvent Israel's objections to dealing directly with the Liberation Organization and so permit Middle East peace talks to resume in Geneva.

title: When March Comes
description: Traditionally, March brings migrant robins and redwing blackbirds back from the South. It inspires crocuses to open their deep purple and rich yellow chalices in sheltered places and lures the first hungry bees. It brings cold rain and gusty wind and the first sight of green grass, commonly on the sheltered banks of the pasture brook.

title: ALBANY SEEKS TO END FOODPROGRAM FRAUD
description: Asks U.S. for $4.3 Million to Scan the Feeding of Needy Children

title: Postal Service Files Suit Against Upstate Couple That Runs Mail Service
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 26  The National Postal Service has gone to court in an effort to stop a young couple from delivering leeters in the downtown business district here.

title: 66% in Gallup Poll Like Carter's Job Performance; Equal to Other Presidents
description: Sixtysix percent of the American public approves of the way President Carter is handling his new job, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Eliza C. Jones Plans Bridal In the Spring
description: Eliza Chase Jones and Thomas Grover Cleveland Jr., a greatgrandson of President Grover Cleveland, will be married in the spring.

title: What Kind of County Will It Be in 85?
description: ADECADE from now Westchester, once the enclave of the landed gentry and then the quintessential suburb, will be a very different county. There will be fewer children, more over65's and an increased percentage of minorities. The changes will have an impact on the county's major institutions; they will generate the need for careful planning rather than ad hoc coping and hoping.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1977

title: MUSIC
description: LET OTHER doctors take to the golf course for relaxation. When Caroline Bauman, a pediatrician, is away from her White Plains office, she's more likely to be at the piano, brushing up on her Beethoven, or perhaps on the phone, negotiating a concert plum like the Tokyo Quartet for the Westchester Chamber Music Society.

title: Fashion
description: Look what's happening in the august salons of French haute couture! Instead of languishing down the runways in elegant black or beige outfits, the mannequins are practically skipping along in rambunctious colors. To further turn the sedate salons on the Avenue Mon. taigne and the Faubourg SaintHonore into outposts of the Carnival in Rio, there are flying ribbons, ruffled necklines falling off the shoulder and tiered and flounced skirts.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE EASIEST WAY to hang a heavy mirror, a large picture frame or a set of shelves on a wall is simply to drive long screws or nails into the 2 by 4 studs behind the plaster. But this means that the object being hung must be positioned over, or in line with, the studs in that wall. Unfortunately, this seldom works out because the studs are seldom if ever situated just where they are needed.

title: 2Big Dog Shows on Local Weekend Slate
description: Metropolitan dog lovers have a wide choice the first weekend in March with two allbreed shows and a national specialty featuring more than 3,600 competitors on the schedule. The Bronx County KC. fixture will get

title: Parslow, With 72 for 205, In 5Shot Aussie Lead
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 26 (AP)  Geoff Parslow of Australia shot par 72 today for a threeround total of 205, 11 under par, and maintained a fivestroke lead after 54 holes of the Victorian open championship at Yarra Yarra Golf Club.

title: The art of budget making, Kennedy to Carter
description: 1. President Kennedy's first budget proposed to stimulate the economy by increasing spending. Despite his proposed 13 percent increase in spending, his estimated deficit was scarcely larger than his predecessor's, because he hoped an active economy would produce an increase in Federal revenues.

title: Battleground Between Leftists and Military in Argentina Shifts to Labor
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26  In the sprawling railroad yards of this port city, crudely mimeographed leaflets are circulating band to hand calling on workers to organize resistance groups against layoffs and changes in work schedules.

title: Newcomer to London Finds Some Surprises Among the Bowlers, the Umbrellasand the Bureaucracy
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  A middleaged American who comes to London to live in this 25th year of the reign of Queen Elizabeth 11 brings with him a lifetime of preconceptions, derived from sources as disparate as the wartime broadcasts of Edward R. Murrow and the novels of Ian Fleming and halfremembered Walter Bagehot essays.

title: An Open Letter to Arthur Ashe
description: I have always been impressed with your tunnel vision. Your open letter to black parents shoud earn you indubitably the myopic championship of our time.

title: REFORM THREATENS THE MEXICAN SIESTA
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20  The Mexican siesta hour, which in practice lasts as long as three hours and is used for eating and not sleeping, is being threatened by a major Government reorganization aimed at trimming and shaking up the country's huge and inefficient bureaucracy.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter's foreign policy has erupted in all directions. Emissaries come and go from Washington at an extraordinary pace, and statements are issued on every subject, often confusing more than claritying the complicated problems at hand.

title: For Spain's Small Businesses Muy Poquito
description: MADRID  Tomas Pueyo Gimena, who owns a printing company on the anonymous industrial fringes of Madrid, is one of thousands of middlesized Spanish businessmen caught in a vise of rising labor costs, stagnant productivity, tight capital and a taxation system he considers manifestly unjust.

title: POLITICS
description: JUDGE T. Clark Hull, who is now at the Supreme Court and who was once Lieutenant Governor, reflected often on the maddening obscurity of the latter and sometimes suggested to his friends in his own spoofing way that if tbe Governor would but go away and leave the Lieutenant Governor in charge long enough for him to mobilize it, he would call out the Governor's Ceremonial Foot Guard and, with band and banner and full colonial regalia march on Massachusetts and straighten out that annoying indentation in the border.

title: Golf
U. of Vermont Ski Team Is Victor at Middlebury
description: MIDDLEBURY. Vt., Feb. 26  Sweeping the slalom and jumping competition by substantial margins, the University of Vermont men's ski team won its second straight Eastern intercollegiate ski title by 60 points today at the Middlebury Winter Carnival.

title: Minibridge
description: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros

title: Weddings
description: JacobsonLippman

title: A New Chance At Federal Funds
description: WHEN THE THAW finally comes and Connecticut's 32 federally funded public works projects get under way in the spring, there will still be grumbles and snarls in parts of the state because wealthy West Hartford got a $1.8 million allotment to reconstruct some sidewalks or Greenwich, one of the state's richest communities got a $4.2 million grant to convert a former school into a town hall annex.

title: A dick and the mob
description: What figure in fiction has kept longer, stronger hold on the American imagination than the professional private eye? In all his mutations, from hardboiled to halfbaked, from the page to the screen to TV, he's been one of our staples for the last 50 years. Now Nicholas Pileggi, a contributing editor of New York magazine, has peered behind the popular image, quarried the world of a real private eye named Irwin Blye, and produced an artfully revealing profile of the truelife gumshoe, circa 1977.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Activist Shareholders Propose S.E.C. Disposes
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission decided early this month after several weeks deliberation that stockholders of the RCA Corporation need not vote on resolutions involving company contributions for animal experimentation.

title: Power Trackmen Take Catholic Schools Crown
description: One of the best team battles in years in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships yesterday ended in goingaway present for Brother Bielen, Power Memorial's head coach. His team won the title on some lastminute heroics.

title: How to Take a Kid on a Cruise Wow
description: It was an offer I couldn't refuse: For less than $600 my 9yearold son and I would have an eightday twoport West Indies cruise in March on the Italian Line's Leonardo da Vinci. I'd always wanted to sail on the Leonardo, and this special fare was obviously a bargain. Then I got a look at our cabin, deep in the hold and incredibly tiny. I was ready to cry tintil Arthur piped up: Boy, this is neat room. If you got bit by a mosquito, you'd have to step outside to swell up.

title: Lectures and Discussions
description: Saturday, March 5

title: New York City and State To Get Extra Federal Aid Under New Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The House of Representatives has approved a coldweather amendment by Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, to increase special assistance to state and local governments by $215 million in the next quarter, Including an extra $29 million to New York City.

title: Correction
description: Gerald G. May's Simply Sane, $7.95, was reviewed Feb. 6 under the title incorrectly provided by the publisher, Free to Go Sane.

title: Cauthen Wins Handicap, Notches Meeting Record
description: Turn and Count, a sorelegged colt running with a $200 Band Aid, rallied from last place yesterday to win the $82,650 Grey Leg Handicap, the richest race of the Aqueduct season so far, and give Steve Cauthen another record.

title: Nicklaus Clings to the Lead With 205 as Morgan Rallies
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)  Jack Nicklaus shot a threeunderpar 69 today but saw, his lead in the $250,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary Golf Classic drop to one stroke over the streaking Gil Morgan.

title: Duryea Playing Quiet Man
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Perry B. Duryea Jr., in the winter of his discontent, wears his status as the frontrunning Republican candidate for Governor next year gingerly, almost diffidently. He and his party are still reeling from the loss of two more Assembly seats in last November's elections, which shrank the Republicans Watergatedecimated minority even further, to 60 out of the charnbees 150 seats.

title: GARDENING
description: THE severity of this winter's weather has undoubtedly caused concern among the owners of home greenhouses on the Island. While relatively few of them are heated with natural gas, the unusually cold temperatures have placed additional stress on already strained heating budgets.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Joe Don Looney, once the Giants No. 1 draft choice, who also failed to make the grade with several other pro football teams in the 1960's, is at an ashram in the Catskills as a follower of Swami Baba Muktananda. The 35yearold former running back, now a 165pounder with a receding hairline, talks about his new life: We make our own clothes and food and have no real desires except to find ourselves through Baba. Baba is the Vince Lombardi of religion.

title: Gifts to Neediest Break Previous Record, Set in 1973
description: The 65th annual appeal of York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is now in its final weekend, has received contributions totaling $1,068,427.06, a record, from 10,209 donors.

title: OSSINING IS REVIVING URBANRENEWAL PLAN
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 26  Officials of this Hudson River village have got their longstalled urban renewal program off the ground with the sale to private developer of lend on which to build $25 million in residential and commercial development.

title: Indispensable Legumes. For Summer Menus
description: If pressed to name the plant family indispensable, my unquestionable choice would be the legumes.

title: A New Trend In Basic Blues
description: The blues, which was developed by black Americans in the Deep South around the end of the 19th century, is at once the simplest and sturdiest of musical idioms. It consists of three lines, the second of which is a repeat of the first, the third being a commentary on or answer to what has preceded it. Only three chords are involved. The melody often stays within a fivenote range and rarely exceeds an octave. The lyrics make liberal use of folk imagery and conventional wisdom. Nevertheless, the blues has been resilient enough to maintain its idiomatic integrity through the years, despite frequent attempts to bowdlerize it, commercialize it, orchestrate it, and otherwise complicate it.

title: Human Rights: Deeds as Well as Words
description: Secretary of State Vance gave a concrete reply last week to those who wondered whether the Administration would limit its criticism of humanrights violations to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries and whether its policy was only one of words. He told Senate subcommittee that the United States would reduce its aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia, where serious and widespread violations of human rights have been well documented.

title: BOOKS
description: To say that both the Coombs and Solomon books are insider views of international monetary developments since the Bretton Woods agreements of 1944 would be true, but seriously misleading. The books are in several ways complementary, not merely because the insiders viewpoints are different, or even opposed, but because their interests and experiences differed widely.

title: Notre Dame Overwhelms La Salle Five, 113 to 77
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 26 (AP)Don Williams scored 22 points, Toby Knight added 21 and Notre Dame produced its highest point total of the season today, crushing La Salle, 11377.

title: Denise Levitt Plans A Wedding in June With Alan Kirman
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Levitt of New York and Mill Neck, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Denise Levitt, to Alan Kirman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Kirman of East Hills, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Jean Ellen Lahey Is Bride Of David Starr Johnson Jr.
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jean Ellen Lahey, daughter of Mrs. Robert Matherson Jr. of New York and the late William J. Lahey, to David Starr Johnson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Easton, Md. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. George G. Maley.

title: Public Can Call Carter on Saturday With Questions or Suggestions, but Harangues Won't Be Allowed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  Pich up your phone next Saturday and give the President a call.

title: ART
description: ONE of the most exciting arid outstanding art shows to be offered in New Jersey in recent years is the Indian Art of the Americas exhbition of the Monmouth Museum in Lincroft. This is not the standard assortment of artifacts that we have seen in the rash of recent displays of this nature, but a large, ambitious and diverse array of approximately 500 examples; what makes them SO outstanding is their extraordinary beauty, their rich difference in design and craftsmanship and their consummate representation of Indian cultures from North and South America.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
Marcy Hill to Be Married
description: Carol Wexler of Columbus, Ohio, and Stephen Hill of Battle Creek, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcy Lynn Hill, to John Miles Degenshein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Degenshein of New York. Miss Hill is fashion coordinator for Accessories by Pearl Inc., a women's belt concern. of which her fiance is president. The couple will be married March 7.

title: Two moderns who drew on the past
description: By Anne Coffin Hanson. Illustrated. 222 pp. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $25.

title: Roots,
description: The television serialization of Roots carries many implications for American writers and publishers. Among the many that flood my mind, these may be of interest to the reading public.

title: ART VIEW
description: It will hardly be a surprise to anyone, I suppose, to hear that the 1977 Whitney Biennial Exhibition, now occupying the bulk of the gallery space at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is an unendurable bore. Most of us have learnedoh, how we have learned!to expect little or nothing from these periodic attempts to summarize what is happening in contemporary American art. Recent experience gives us ample reason to know in advance that the specialty of these showsthe thing that gives them their special quality and flavoris a surpassing esthetic boredom. They seem to be governed by oositive hostility toward a really visceral distaste foranything that might conceivably engage the eye in a significant or pleasurable visual experience.

title: ChrisCraft's Case
description: When the Supreme Court overturned the record $35.8 million judgment lower court had awarded ChrisCraft Industries last Wednesday, it defused one of the most dangerous time bombs ticking in Wall Streetthe liability of investment banking houses that advise companies in takeovers.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26 (AP)  Chairman Hua Kuofeng has begun a new campaign to sharpen the 3.5millionmember Chinese Army and end a practice of putting politics ahead of military expertise, the official press agency Hsinhua said today.

title: Eye on the ball
description: This first novel is about baseball in the way that Bernard Malamud's The Natural might be said to be about baseball, or Philip Roth's Great American Novel or Robert Coover's Universal Baseball Association, J. Henry Waugh, Prop. That is, Lamar Herrin is preoccupied, for so long as he keeps his eye on the ball, with magic, legend and farce. Like Mark Harris's Henry W. Wiggen (The Southpaw) and Roth's Gil Gamesh and Malamud's Roy Hobbs, Herrin's Dick Dixon is a pitcher. The heroes in conventional baseball fictions might be crafty shortstops or loping fielders whose mighty bats pull fat from a fire, but the main men of such fantastical romances as Roth's and Malamud's and Herrin's must be at the center of the wheel, spoilers who make a ball disappear into thin air.

title: Rock lives!
description: Peter Frampton. Homogenized rock for a mainstream audience.

title: County and Industry: Future Uncertain
description: ON a recent occasion the vice president of a San Francisco company that was considering opening offices in Westchester expressed surprise at the ardor with which county officials courted him. Nearly flabbergasted, he noted that he could never expect such cordial treatment and offers of assistance from the officials of his own town, and certainly none of the insights into and information on doing business in the area that he was getting from the county government.

title: If They're 65, Out They Go
description: THE image of older people as group whose principal needs are better nursing homes and/ or appropriate funding to finance their idleness has obscured an ongoing injustice and the waste of national resource. Every month the rigorous demands of mandatory retirement result in the involuntary idleness of great numbers of men and women, skilled in their work, seasoned and shrewd and capable of contributing to their employer and societyand rejected by both.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Forbes's Flight

title: Deaths
description: ALBRECHTS. D.. widow of Herman, mother of J. 1., grandmother of Rod. Heftier, stean.

title: Around the Nation
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 26 (AP)  Virginia has filed a $2 million lawsuit against the owners and operators of a ship that struck the Benjamin Harrison Bridge in Hopewell Thursday morning.

title: Notes: How North Carolina Cares for Its Orchestra
description: Back in 1943, the North Carolina General Assembly made an appropriation of $4,000 to support the North Carolina Symphony for two years. Despite the modest sum, this was a historic move in being one of the first such acts on the part of a state government. The people of the Tar Heel State called it, with disarming cracker  barrel humor, the Horn Tottin' Bill. Last year, the same lawmaking body was still breaking paths: It gave the orchestra S6I0,000 for one year, the largest sum to be granted a symphonic group by a statemore even than the comparatively rich New York State Council on the Ai:s offered the New York Philharmonic.

title: Woodruff Halsey 2d Planning to Marry Katherine Vickery
description: Katherin Anne Vickery, a freshman at Princeton University, and Woodruff Wendell Halsey 2d of Concord, N.H., who was her instructor in French at St. Paul's School in Concord, plan to be married in June in Princeton's chapel.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F. A. CUP

title: HOW TO RECOGNIZE IT AND HOW TO USE IT
description: JULIUS FAST has written another informative and effective book...wisdom for those on their way up the corporate ladder, singles, lovers, parents, teachers and all who want to improve communications in private or professional life.

title: GARDENING
description: FEBRUARY bottoms out this weekend and gives way to March. The flip of the calendar page should be significant to gardeners for it is dormant spray time.

title: S.C.L.C. LEADERS HOPE TO REJUVENATE GROUP
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 26  Leaders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference have begun a national campaign to rejuvenate their steadily deteriorating civil rights organization, which peaked more than a decade ago under the leadership of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: LETTER FROM UCONN
description: THERE ARE a few students left on university campuses today who still believe that there is strength in numbers. Somewhere along the way to the 70's, the organized protests and student involvement in efforts to make their opinions heard have got lost.

description: THEATER

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
MUSIC VIEW
description: Russia and the Russians are in the news this week. Lazar Berman will rhake several appearances, including one at a Pension Fund concert of the New York Philharmonic. There, with Leonard Bernstein at the helm, he will play concertos by Prokofiev and Raclunaninoff. Later in the week the Leningrad Philharmonic will be in Carnegie Hall. The programs are not yet in hand, but one can safely guess that Russian music will not be ignored.

title: Negotiating with the Soviets
description: WASHINGTON. President Carter begins his Administration at a time when the process for placing limits on nuclear competition is approaching an important turning point. The 1972 interim freeze on intercontinental and submarine missile launchers runs out in less than nine months. Replacing the freeze with a more comprehensive and longerlasting agreement is apparently one of Carter's toppriority goals. Setting his sights even higher than President Nixon and President Ford, he even speaks of an end to all nuclear tests, of early reduction in strategic forces, and of the longrange goal of banning nuclear weapons altoeether.

title: Linda Leadbetter to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Guy W. Leadbetter Jr. of Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda E. Leadbetter to Daniel G. Miner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua L. Miner of Andover, Mass. The weddins, is planned for June 25. Miss Leadbetter is an altunna uf ColbySawyer and Middlebury Colleges. Her fianc, an alumnus of Phillips Academy at Andover, is a senior at Swarthmore College.

title: Sports Called Opiate for Black Masses
description: Traditionally, sport has been viewed by Americans as the embodiment of the most cherished democratic ideals, where individuals of different races and ethnic backgrounds toil in free and open competition.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: Steve Cauthen had a dinner engagement at the Tavern on the Green but he zonked out, exhausted, so Lenny and Kathleen Goodman went along without him. Lenny Goodman, one of the best jockey agents in captivity, is the reason the kid zonked out. Lenny books him to ride eight or nine races a day at Aqueduct six days a

description: TOMbaele

title: Budget Is a Lot of Ford, With Carter Accessories
description: President Carter, as expected, has submitted proposed revisions in the fiscal 1978 budget that still leave the document mainly the handiwork of his predecessor, largely because of time constraints created by the budget procedure. But although the changes in spending levels recommended by Mr. Carter are relatively modest, they represent significant new policy departures on energy, defense and the economy.

title: White House Aide Named By Carter to Coordinate Drought Help to the West
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. 26 (UPI)President Carter announced today that Jack Watson, a White House aide and secretary to the Cabinet, will serve as coordinator of the Federal drought assistance program to the Western states.

title: Realty News
description: Fifth Avenue Lease

title: Cold? Why, Back in 34 ...
description: IF you are a typical Long Islander, you would probably prefer to spend the winter snuggled up in front of the fireplace in your family room. Unless, of course, you can escape Mother Nature's revenge altogether by fleeing south. Assuming that you have to spend at least part of the winter on this northern isle instead of Florida or a Caribbean island, however, you really should prepare for the worst. Invest in a down parka. Wax your skis. They may be your only form of transportation to the train station during and after a big snowfall.

title: LETTER FROM WESTCHESTER COMMUNITY COLLEGE
description: MOST students reasons for starting their higher education at Westchester Community College are simple enough. For example, this writer had been out of high school for a couple of years and felt a pressing need to get back into the academic world. My high school record was not very impressive, so the openadmissions policy at Westchester was enticing. The idea of driving to school was also attractive (Westchester Community is made up entirely of commuters) since I had a car and a parttime offcampus job. The $350 price was further stimulus, being that, without financial assistance, I could not afford to go away to college or even to commute to a local, private institution.

title: The fish are different from you and me
description: Biographers of living people often find themselves in Catch 22. Increasing personal knowledge carries the risk of uncritical approbationmost people, after all, are basically likable. But how can a writer opt for distance when his subject is at hand?

title: Danish farmer Johan Boserup takes a break.
description: mechanization. The farm's productive energies are devoted to fattening for market 700 pigs at a time, a feat accomplished by automatically doling out machinemeasured quantities of food. I stand in the barn 10 minutes before feeding time. Lights come on to wake up the sleeping pigs; grain comes tumbling through a hundred chutes; porcine ecstasy.

title: BILL VAUGHAN, COLUMNIST AND KANSAS CITY EDITOR
description: KANSAS CITY. Feb. 26 (AP)  Bill Vaughan, associate editor of The Kansas City Star and nationally syndicated columnist, died today at St. Luke's Hospital of cancer. He was 61 years old.

title: Headliners
description: Soviet Donation

title: POLITICS
description: THE word affluent has been used so'often to describe Westchester County and many Republicans that a casual observer might be tempted to assume that the Westchester Republican organization must indeed be prosperous. It isn't.

title: Deep Beneath the Sea, a New Industry Grows
description: Wherever the giant oil corporations go in search of offshore gas and oil, they are dependent on a rugged breed of worker who can operate deep beneath the sea. From the exploration stage until the last drop has been pumped from a well the role of commercial divers is crucial.

title: Stony rook's Fight to Grow
description: STONY BROOK'S growing pains may soon be felt in other quarters as the State University center pursues its behindthescenes fight to attain its masterplan equivalentenrollment goal of 21,600 fulltime students.

title: Laderman Quartet Has Its New York Premiere
description: In program notes for Friday night's New York premiere performance at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, Ezra Laderman described his Fifth String Quartet as a pluralistic composition embracing tonal, atonal and serial elements. Modern life, the composer explained, is a complex amalgam of disparate parts demanding accommodation and synthesis, making a musical parallel both natural and inevitable.

title: Lisa Emmons Bride of Robert Pyne
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lisa Anne Emmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Peter Emmons of Chestnut Hill, to Robert Wright Pyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Rivington Pyne 3d of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. John Harmon performed the ceremony.

title: What was a nice girl like Patty ...?; The Voices of Guns; The Life and Death of the S.L.A.
description: It is three years since Patricia Hearit vanished kicking and screaming into the revolutionary psychodrama trf the Symbionese Liberation Army. After almost daily worldwide coverage and three S.L.A. trials, more than a halfdozen books have given us a pretty good idea of what she did and when she did it. The question is still why? The two books at hand are the latest and most informative accounts of her oncehaunting, now familiar odyssey. Both are the work of journalists who were early hunters of the S.L.A.'s sevenheaded Cobra. While they offer no major revisions of S.L.A. history, both teams have come across some fascinating missing pieces in the puzzle. McLellan and Avery for instance, reveal that the famous S.L.A. aversion to bugs (Death to the Fascist Insect That Preys Upon the Life of the People.) was wellfounded. It was known that filthspawned cockroaches led the F.B.I. to the main San Francisco hideout where Patty gave birth to Tania. Now we learn that Wendy Yoshimura's fingerprint in the Pennsylvania farm retrgat, the clue which eventually led to the arrest of Tania, Miss Yoshimura and S.L.A. charter members Bill and Emily Harris, was also insectinstigated: Wendy stuffed a newspaper in her mattress to keep the bugs out. When the S.L.A. cleaned their house of fingerprints, no one

title: Getting Depots Back on the Track
description: THE onceproud railroad stations of Fairfield County have, with a very few exceptions fallen on hard days. The station in Riverside has not been replaced since burning down. Another suspicious fire destroyed Norwalk's facility. Stamford's shabby station, owned for the last 12 years by Transportation Plaza Associates, a private development concern, is to be the subject of a hearing this week aimed at condemnation and takeover by the state of Connecticut.

title: BOOKER WHITE, GUITARIST KNOWN FOR BLUES MUSIC
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 26 (UPI)  One of the last blues musicians of the W. C. Handy era, Booker T. Washington White, died today at the age of 71.

title: Opera: An Impressive Forza del Destino
description: Under its new directorial triumvirate the Metropolitan Opera has been accused of forsaking its central function of the last few decadesthe presentation of fullthroated singing of Italian opera. Those accusations would have seemed groundless at the company's third performance this season of Verdi's La Forza del Destino Friday night.

title: Antiabortion Bill Stirs New Debate
description: THE New Jersey Legislature has focused new attention on the abortion issue with a bill asking Congress to call a nationwide convention to consider an antiabortion amendment to the Federal Constitution that would prohibit abortions from the moment of conception.

title: Pope's U.S. Delegate Takes Powerful Role
description: Archbishop Jean Jadot, who was appointed Papal Delegate to the Roman Catholic Church in the United States four years ago, is being credited by many churchmen today with dramatically transforming his role from a largely ceremonial function to one of power and influence.

title: The Role of Lender Has Been No Fun
description: When unionized cleaners and handymen in New York City's public schools went on strike last week, they had the unintended effect of underscoring the revolution Civil Service labor relations caused by the city's fiscal problems.

title: What to Do With Schools Left Empty?
description: The old, battered, shutdown school is a new kind of ruin haunting the city's landscape.

title: Park's Access to Disabled Studied
description: ALBERTSON, L.I.  A study to determine how New York State's parks, recreational facilities and historic sites can be made more accessible to physically disabled people will be undertaken by the Human Resources Center here, according to Orin Lehman, the State Commissioner of Parks and Recreation.

title: It's Just That Talking About It Has Fallen From Favor
description: In the old days, says Howard Golden, the Brooklyn BorOugh President, the balanced ticketone Irishman, one Italian, one Jewmade political sense in New York City. It was practically mandatory.

title: CONTENTS: PAGE 9
Story of NeptuneCompany in Trauma
description: BEHIND the shock wave of national headlines that followed the Feb. 14 shooting spree in which Frederick W. Cowan, Nazi cultist, killed five people at the offices of Neptune World Wide Moving in New Rochelle, there was a special sadness for the Kirschenbaums, the family that owns the company.

title: AvignonAn Air Of Worldliness
description: On the night of Jan. 31, 1976, three robbers broke into an exhibition of Picassos in the 14thcentury Palace of the Popes in Avignon, overpowered two guards and made off with 119 v..orks worth an estimated $4.5 million. The police recovered the pictures in Marseilles eariy last October. But not before some wag had scrawled on a stone wall outside the Palace, in letters a foot high: DUFFAUT VEND LES PICASSOS ('Duffaut Sells Picassos) Duffaut being the name of Avignon's Deputy Mayor.

title: Confusion in the Land of Canaan
description: THE CANAAN PROBLEM has come up again. A new organization, the Falls Village Business Association, has proposed that the township of Canaan be renamed Falls Village Township, to end the confusion that has persisted for years about which and where is Canaan.

title: In the Short Term, Success
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter served notice on business and labor that he was reinstating jawboning to raise consciousness about prices and wages in corporation board rooms and union assembly halls, business and labor were not enthusiastic. They still are not, even though, as Mr. Carter reiterated last week controls or even guideposts are nnt nart of his Dian.

title: Upsurge of Racism in Toronto Afflicts South Asian Immigrants
description: TORONTO  After the big front windows of Aslam Khan's expensive house in the Toronto suburb of Scarborough had been shattered by stones for the fourth time, he moved his family to less conspicuous quarters in an innercity apartment building.

title: Arlen and The Art Of the Show Song
description: Blues in the Night, That Old Black Magic, Over the Rainbow, It's Only a Paper Moon, Stormy Weather, Come Rain or Come Shine, I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues, Let's Fall in Lovebeautiful and familiar songs, but few people know who wrote them, let alohe that they are all the work of one man, Harold Arlen.

title: Gulf stream Handicap Goes To Strike Me Lucky, $31
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)Strike Me Lucky, a supplementary nominee entered to serve as a pacesetter for his stablemate, Gravelines, ran alone and scored a stunning upset today in the $147,000 Gulfstream Handicap.

title: STAMPS
description: A new $1 stamp booklet for vending machines, containing a new 13cent stamp created especially for the booklet, is being put out by the United States in New York City on March 11.

title: Pension Bill Goes To Byrne
description: ABILL to exempt most pension payments from the provisions of the state income tax is expected to be signed shortly by Governor Byrne.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: LAST Thursday the House of Representatives began looking for fairer rules for local publicworks grants to replace the guidelines that so unsuccessfully governed distribution of $2 billion in January by the Economic Development Administration.

title: Oil Rigs: Not So Inevitable
description: FEDERAL Judge Jack B. Weinstein's decision against the sale of offshore oildrilling exploraleases in the Baltimore Canyon has given a breather for Long Islanders who are opposed to the drilling, left open the door to final victory for those who want it and sprinkled some spice on the political maneuverings that have surrounded the issue since its inception.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of typographical errors in some editions of last Sunday's New York Times, the name of Yigael Yadin, head of a new political party in Israel, was spelled Yadlin in several references. Asher Yadlin is an Israeli Labor Party official who has confessed to misuse of funds.

title: Promise of Disarmament
description: In the tradition of the bomber gap of the 1950's and the missile gap of the 1960's, the professional alarmists of the Pentagon are once again demanding bigger military buugets to keep the United States from falling behind the Soviet Union. Yet even most pessimistic strategists agree with the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that the United States is now ahead. The United States still has three times as many nuclear weapons as the Soviet Union, and more varied, more accurate and more sophisticated means to deliver them on Soviet territory. The United States Navy is far larger, is more flexible, has far greater fire power, and dominates distant oceans through a network of bases the Soviets cannot even approximate. In Europe, the numbers of NATO and Warsaw Pact combat troops are roughly equal. Soviet advantages in numbers of tanks are countered by U.S, advantages in quality and antitank weapons.

title: Wedding Is Held For Miss Morris, Richard Blossom
description: Christina Austin Morris, daughter of Vr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge Conn., was married yesterday in the Trinity Episcopal ChurchontheGreen in New Haven to Richard Warren Blossom, son of Mrs. Warren Blossom of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Blossom. The Rev. James G. Munroe performed the ceremony, assisted by Rev. Andrew Fiddler.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of Ogden Nash (190271) I am eager to see photocopies or copies of letters, unpublished verse and other materials by and about him and would be grateful for any recollections of him and/or information about him.

title: Israel's Uneasy Connections In Africa
description: JERUSALEM  As the search is pressed for peace in two of the world's perennial trouble spots, the Middle East and Southern Africa, a connection between two of the principal parties involved in the separate quarrels inevitably complicates the peace efforts.

description: Fiction & Poetry
